original: maggasamādhinā phalasamādhinā lokiyalokuttarasamādhinā, evaṃsamādhayoti attho. Evaṃpaññāti
analyzed: magga samādhinā phala samādhinā lokiya lokuttara samādhinā evaṃsamādhayaḥ ti atthaḥ evaṃpaññā ti
translated: and concentration of the path, concentration of fruition, and mundane and supramundane concentration. This is the meaning of ‘thus concentrated.’ ‘Thus wise’ means

original: maggapaññādivaseneva evaṃpaññā. Evaṃvihārīti ettha pana heṭṭhā samādhipakkhānaṃ dhammānaṃ
analyzed: magga paññā ādi vasena iva evaṃpaññā evaṃvihārī iti ettha pana heṭṭhā samādhi pakkhānam dhammānam
translated: wise in the wisdom of the path, and so on. ‘Thus abiding’ means that here, since the factors of concentration have already been taken up,

original: gahitattā vihāro gahitova puna kasmā gahitameva gaṇhātīti ce; na idaṃ gahitameva,🔽idañhi nirodhasamāpattidīpanatthaṃ vuttaṃ. Tasmā evaṃ nirodhasamāpattivihārī te bhagavanto
analyzed: vihāraḥ punar kasmai gahitam eva gaṇhāti iti ce na idam gahitam eva  idam hi nirodha samāpatti dīpana attham vuttam tasmai evam nirodha samāpatti vihārī te bhagavanto
translated: abiding has already been taken up. If it be asked, ‘Why take up again what has already been taken up?’—this is not what has already been taken up.🔽This is said for the purpose of showing the attainment of cessation. Therefore the meaning here should be regarded as follows: ‘Those Blessed Ones

original: ahesunti evamettha attho daṭṭhabbo.🔽Evaṃvimuttāti ettha vikkhambhanavimutti, tadaṅgavimutti, samucchedavimutti, paṭippassaddhivimutti,🔽nissaraṇavimuttīti pañcavidhā vimutti. Tattha aṭṭha samāpattiyo sayaṃ vikkhambhitehi
analyzed: ahesun ti evam ettha atthaḥ daṭṭhabbo  evam vimuttā ti ettha vikkhambhana vimutti tad aṅga vimutti samuccheda vimutti paṭippassaddhi vimutti  nissaraṇa vimutti iti pañcavidhā vimutti tattha aṭṭha samāpattiyo sayam vikkhambhitehi
translated: abided thus in the abiding of the attainment of cessation.’🔽‘Thus liberated’ means the fivefold liberation: liberation by suppression, liberation by substitution of opposites, liberation by eradication, liberation by tranquilization,🔽and liberation by renunciation. Herein, the eight attainments are called ‘liberation by suppression’ because they are liberated from the hindrances, etc., which are suppressed by them. The contemplations of impermanence, etc.,

original: nīvaraṇādīhi vimuttattā vikkhambhanavimuttīti saṅkhyaṃ gacchanti. Aniccānupassanādikā
analyzed: nīvaraṇa ādīhi vimutta ttā vikkhambhana vimutti iti saṅkhyam gacchanti anicca anupassanā ādikā
translated: are called ‘liberation by substitution of opposites’ because they liberate by substituting the opposite of the perception of permanence, etc.

original: sattānupassanā sayaṃ tassa tassa paccanīkaṅgavasena pariccattāhi niccasaññādīhi vimuttattā🔽tadaṅgavimuttīti saṅkhyaṃ gacchanti. Cattāro ariyamaggā sayaṃ samucchinnehi kilesehi🔽vimuttattā samucchedavimuttīti saṅkhyaṃ gacchanti. Cattāri sāmaññaphalāni maggānubhāvena
analyzed: satta anupassanā sayam tassa tassa paccanīka aṅga vasena pariccattāhi nicca saññā ādīhi vimutta ttā  tad aṅga vimutti iti saṅkhyam gacchanti cattāraḥ ariya maggā sayam samucchinnehi kilesehi  vimutta ttā samuccheda vimutti iti saṅkhyam gacchanti cattāri sāmañña phalāni magga anubhāvena
translated: The four paths are called “liberations” because they are liberated from defilements that have been cut off.

original: kilesānaṃ paṭippassaddhante uppannattā paṭippassaddhivimuttīti saṅkhyaṃ gacchanti.
analyzed: kilesānam paṭippassaddha nte uppanna ttā paṭippassaddhi vimutti iti saṅkhyam gacchanti
translated: The four fruits are called “liberations” because they are liberated by the subsidence of defilements that have arisen through the influence of the paths.

original: Nibbānaṃ sabbakilesehi nissaṭattā apagatattā dūre ṭhitattā nissaraṇavimuttīti saṅkhyaṃ
analyzed: nibbānam sabba kilesehi nissaṭa ttā apagata ttā dūre ṭhita ttā nissaraṇa vimutti iti saṅkhyam
translated: Nibbana is called “liberation” because it is the escape from all defilements, because it is free from them, because it is far removed from them.

original: gacchati. Iti imāsaṃ pañcannaṃ vimuttīnaṃ vasena – “evaṃ vimuttā”ti ettha attho daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: gacchati iti imāsam pañcannam vimuttīnam vasena evam vimuttā iti ettha atthaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: So the meaning of “thus liberated” should be regarded as referring to these five kinds of liberation.

original: 14. Paṭisallānā vuṭṭhitoti ekībhāvā vuṭṭhito.
analyzed: paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito ti ekībhāvā vuṭṭhito
translated: “Emerged from his solitary meditation”: emerged from his state of solitude.

original: 16. “Ito so, bhikkhave”ti ko anusandhi? Idañhi suttaṃ – “tathāgatassevesā, bhikkhave,
analyzed: itas so bhikkhave iti kaḥ anusandhi idam hi suttam tathāgatassa iva īsā bhikkhave
translated: “From here, bhikkhus” : what is the connection here? For this sutta is as follows: “Bhikkhus, this is the forerunner and precursor of the Tathāgata’s appearance, that is, the manifestation of a great light.”

original: dhammadhātu suppaṭividdhā”ti ca “devatāpi tathāgatassa etamatthaṃ ārocesu”nti ca
analyzed: dhammadhātu suppaṭividdhā ati ca devatā api tathāgatassa etam attham ārocesun ti ca
translated: and the Dhamma-element is well penetrated” and “the deities announced this matter to the Tathāgata”

original: imehi dvīhi padehi ābaddhaṃ. Tattha devatārocanapadaṃ suttantapariyosāne devacārikakolāhalaṃ
analyzed: imehi dvīhi padehi ābaddham tattha devatā ārocana padam suttanta pariyosāne deva cārika kolāhalam
translated: are bound up with these two terms. Herein, the term “the deities announced” will be investigated in the section on the “divine-messengers miracle” at the end of the Suttas.

original: dassento vicāressati. Dhammadhātupadānusandhivasena pana ayaṃ desanā āraddhā. Tattha
analyzed: dassentaḥ vicāressati dhammadhātu pada anusandhi vasena pana ayam desanā āraddhā tattha
translated: But this teaching was begun with the term “the Dhamma-element.”

original: khattiyo jātiyātiādīni ekādasapadāni nidānakaṇḍe vuttanayeneva veditabbāni.
analyzed: khattiyaḥ jātiyā ati ādīni ekādasa padāni nidāna kaṇḍe vutta nayena iva veditabbāni
translated: Herein, the eleven terms beginning with “He was of the warrior caste by birth” should be understood in the way given in the Nidana Book.

original: Bodhisattadhammatāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: bodhisatta dhamma tā vaṇṇanā
translated: The Bodhisatta’s Nature

original: 17. Atha kho, bhikkhave, vipassī bodhisattotiādīsu pana vipassīti tassa nāmaṃ, tañca
analyzed: atha kho bhikkhave vipassī bodhisatto ti ādīsu pana vipassī iti tassa nāmam tat ca
translated: Now, as regards the passage beginning “Then, bhikkhus, the future Buddha Vipassi” , the name of the future Buddha was Vipassi.

original: kho vividhe atthe passanakusalatāya laddhaṃ. Bodhisattoti paṇḍitasatto bujjhanakasatto.
analyzed: kho vividhe atthe passana kusala tāya laddham bodhisatto ti paṇḍitasatto bujjhanakasatto
translated: And that was given to him because of his skill in seeing the various meanings. The future Buddha is a wise being, a being who awakens,🔽or a being who is intent on, attached to, and preoccupied with, the four paths called “awakening” .

original: Bodhisaṅkhātesu vā catūsu maggesu satto āsatto laggamānasoti bodhisatto. Sato sampajānoti
analyzed: bodhi saṅkhātesu vā catūsu maggesu sattaḥ āsattaḥ lagga mānasaḥ iti bodhisatto sataḥ sampajānoti
translated: He was mindful and fully aware:

original: ettha satoti satiyeva. Sampajānoti ñāṇaṃ. Satiṃ sūpaṭṭhitaṃ katvā ñāṇena paricchinditvā
analyzed: ettha satā iti satiyā iva sampajānoti ñāṇam satim su upaṭṭhitam katvā ñāṇena paricchinditvā
translated: Herein, “mindful” is mindfulness itself. “Clearly comprehending” is knowledge. Having established mindfulness well, he should discern with knowledge.

original: mātukucchiṃ okkamīti attho. Okkamīti iminā cassa okkantabhāvo pāḷiyaṃ dassito, na
analyzed: mātukucchim okkamīti atthaḥ okkamīti iminā ca assa okkanta bhāvaḥ pāḷiyam dassitaḥ na
translated: Herein, ‘mindful’ is mindfulness itself. ‘Clearly comprehending’ is knowledge. The meaning is that he entered the mother’s womb having established mindfulness well and having delimited it with knowledge. ‘Entered’ : by this he shows the state of his having entered,

original: okkamanakkamo. So pana yasmā aṭṭhakathaṃ ārūḷho, tasmā evaṃ veditabbo –
analyzed: okkamana kkamo so pana yasmai aṭṭhakatham ārūḷhaḥ tasmai evam veditabbo
translated: not the manner of his entering. But since that is based on the commentary, it should be understood as follows.

original: Sabbabodhisattā hi samatiṃsa pāramiyo pūretvā, pañca mahāpariccāge pariccajitvā,
analyzed: sabba bodhisattāḥ hi pāramiyaḥ pūretvā pañca mahā pariccāge pariccajitvā
translated: For all Bodhisattas, after fulfilling the thirty perfections, after giving the five great gifts,

original: ñātatthacariyalokatthacariyabuddhacariyānaṃ koṭiṃ patvā, vessantarasadise tatiye
analyzed: ñātattha cariya lokattha cariya buddha cariyānam koṭim patvā vessantara sadise tatiye
translated: after reaching the pinnacle of the practice of the knowledge of what is profitable for oneself, for the world, and for the Buddhas, after standing in the third existence like Vessantara,

original: attabhāve ṭhatvā, satta mahādānāni datvā, sattakkhattuṃ pathaviṃ kampetvā, kālaṅkatvā,
analyzed: atta bhāve ṭhatvā satta mahā dānāni datvā sattakkhattum pathavim kampetvā kālaṃkatvā
translated: after giving the seven great gifts, after causing the earth to quake seven times, after dying,

original: dutiyacittavāre tusitabhavane nibbattanti. Vipassī bodhisattopi tatheva katvā tusitapure
analyzed: dutiya citta vāre tusita bhavane nibbattanti vipassī bodhisattaḥ api tathā iva katvā tusitapure
translated: in the second thought they are reborn in the Tusita heaven. The Bodhisatta Vipassi, after doing likewise,

original: nibbattitvā saṭṭhisatasahassādhikā sattapaññāsa vassakoṭiyo tattha aṭṭhāsi. Aññadā
analyzed: nibbattitvā saṭṭhi sata sahassa adhikā satta paññāsa vassa koṭiyaḥ tattha aṭṭhāsi aññadā
translated: was reborn in the Tusita heaven and remained there for seventy-five koṭis of years plus six hundred million years. At another time

original: pana dīghāyukadevaloke nibbattā bodhisattā na yāvatāyukaṃ tiṭṭhanti. Kasmā? Tattha
analyzed: pana dīgha āyuka deva loke nibbattāḥ bodhisattāḥ na yāvatāyukam tiṭṭhanti kasmā tattha
translated: But Bodhisattvas who have been reborn in the divine world of long-lived deities do not remain there for the whole life-span. Why?

original: pāramīnaṃ duppūraṇīyattā. Te adhimuttikālakiriyaṃ katvā manussapatheyeva nibbattanti.
analyzed: pāramīnam duppūraṇīya ttā te adhimutti kālakiriyam katvā manussa patheya iva nibbattanti
translated: Because it is difficult to fulfil the pāramīs there. They make an aspiration to be reborn in the human world and are reborn there.

original: Pāramīnaṃ pūrento pana yathā idāni ekena attabhāvena sabbaññutaṃ upanetuṃ sakkonti,
analyzed: pāramīnam pūrentaḥ pana yathā idāni ekena atta bhāvena sabbaññu tam upanetum sakkonti
translated: But one who is fulfilling the pāramīs is able to attain omniscience in a single existence,

original: evaṃ sabbaso pūritattā tadā vipassī bodhisatto tattha yāvatāyukaṃ aṭṭhāsi.🔽Devatānaṃ pana – “manussānaṃ gaṇanāvasena idāni sattahi divasehi cuti bhavissatī”ti🔽pañca pubbanimittāni uppajjanti – mālā milāyanti, vatthāni kilissanti, kacchehi sedā🔽muccanti, kāye dubbaṇṇiyaṃ okkamati, devo devāsane na saṇṭhāti. Tattha mālāti paṭisandhiggahaṇadivase
analyzed: evam sabbaso pūrita ttā tadā vipassī bodhisatto tattha yāvatāyukam aṭṭhāsi  devatānam pana manussānam gaṇanā vasena idāni sattahi divasehi cuti bhavissati iti  pañca pubbanimittāni uppajjanti mālāḥ milāyanti vatthāni kilissanti kacchehi sedā  muccanti kāye dubbaṇṇiyam okkamati devaḥ devāsane na saṇṭhāti tattha paṭisandhi ggahaṇa divase
translated: as he has fulfilled them completely. Therefore the Bodhisatta Vipassī remained there for the whole life-span.

original: piḷandhanamālā, tā kira saṭṭhisatasahassādhikā sattapaṇṇāsa vassakoṭiyo amilāyitvā
analyzed: piḷandhana mālā tā kira saṭṭhi sata sahassa adhikā satta paṇṇāsa vassa koṭiyaḥ a milāyitvā
translated: But five signs of death appear to deities: their garlands fade, their clothes get dirty, sweat appears from their armpits, their bodies become uncomfortable, and they no longer enjoy their seats. Herein, the garland is the garland they wear when they take rebirth-linking. It remains fresh for sixty-five times a hundred thousand years,🔽and then it fades.

original: tadā milāyanti. Vatthesupi eseva nayo. Ettakaṃ pana kālaṃ devānaṃ neva sītaṃ na uṇhaṃ
analyzed: tadā milāyanti vatthesu pi esa iva nayaḥ ettakam pana kālam devānam na iva sītam na uṇham
translated: For that length of time the gods have neither cold nor heat,

original: hoti, tasmiṃ kāle sarīrā bindubinduvasena sedā muccanti. Ettakañca kālaṃ tesaṃ sarīre
analyzed: tasmin kāle sarīrāḥ bindu bindu vasena sedāḥ muccanti ettakam ca kālam tesam sarīre
translated: but at that time sweat appears on their bodies drop by drop.

original: khaṇḍiccapāliccādivasena vivaṇṇatā na paññāyati, devadhītā soḷasavassuddesikā viya
analyzed: vivaṇṇa tā na paññāyati deva dhītā soḷasa vassuddesikā viya
translated: And for that length of time their bodies do not show any discoloration due to the formation of wrinkles, liver spots, etc.,🔽but they look like girls of sixteen years,

original: khāyanti, devaputtā vīsativassuddesikā viya khāyanti, maraṇakāle pana tesaṃ kilantarūpo
analyzed: khāyanti deva puttāḥ vīsati vassuddesikāḥ viya khāyanti maraṇa kāle pana tesam
translated: and the gods look like boys of twenty. But at the time of death their bodies become disfigured,

original: attabhāvo hoti. Ettakañca tesaṃ kālaṃ devaloke ukkaṇṭhitā nāma natthi, maraṇakāle
analyzed: atta bhāvaḥ hoti ettakam ca tesam kālam deva loke ukkaṇṭhitāḥ nāma natthi maraṇa kāle
translated: and for that length of time there is no discontent among the gods,

original: pana nissasanti vijambhanti, sake āsane nābhiramanti.🔽Imāni pana pubbanimittāni yathā loke mahāpuññānaṃ rājarājamahāmattādīnaṃyeva ukkāpātabhūmicālacandaggāhādīni
analyzed: pana nissasanti vijambhanti sake āsane na abhiramanti  imāni pana pubba nimittāni yathā loke mahā puññānam rāja rāja mahāmatta ādīnam yeva ukkāpāta bhūmi cāla canda ggāha ādīni
translated: but at the time of death they pant and gasp and they do not enjoy their own seats.🔽But these premonitory signs are known only in the case of gods of great distinction, just as in the world the omens of a great man’s birth, such as lights in the sky, earthquakes, and the appearance of the mare’s-mouth treasure,

original: nimittāni paññāyanti, na sabbesaṃ; evaṃ mahesakkhadevatānaṃyeva paññāyanti, na sabbesaṃ.
analyzed: nimittāni paññāyanti na sabbesam evam mahesakkha devatānam yeva paññāyanti na sabbesam
translated: are known only in the case of kings of royal race and their equals, and not in the case of all.

original: Yathā ca manussesu pubbanimittāni nakkhattapāṭhakādayova jānanti, na sabbe; evaṃ
analyzed: yathā ca manussesu pubba nimittāni nakkhatta pāṭhaka ādayaḥ iva jānanti na sabbe evam
translated: And just as among human beings only astrologers and so on know the omens, not all,

original: tānipi na sabbadevatā jānanti, paṇḍitā eva pana jānanti. Tattha ye mandena kusalakammena
analyzed: tāni api na sabba devatāḥ jānanti paṇḍitāḥ eva pana jānanti tattha ye mandena kusala kammena
translated: so too the omens are not known to all deities, but only to the wise ones. Herein, those deities who are reborn as gods through a small wholesome action

original: nibbattā devaputtā, te tesu uppannesu – “idāni ko jānāti, ‘kuhiṃ nibbattessāmā’ti”
analyzed: nibbattā deva puttā te tesu uppannesu idāni kaḥ jānāti kuhim nibbattessāma ati
translated: are afraid when these omens appear, thinking, “Who knows now where we will be reborn?”

original: bhāyanti. Ye mahāpuññā, te “amhehi dinnaṃ dānaṃ, rakkhitaṃ sīlaṃ, bhāvitaṃ bhāvanaṃ
analyzed: bhāyanti ye mahā puññā te amhehi dinnam dānam rakkhitam sīlam bhāvitam bhāvanam
translated: But those of great merit are not afraid, thinking, “Through our generosity, through our virtue, through our meditation,

original: āgamma upari devalokesu sampattiṃ anubhavissāmā”ti na bhāyanti. Vipassī bodhisattopi
analyzed: āgamma upari deva lokesu sampattim anubhavissāma ati na bhāyanti vipassī bodhisattaḥ api
translated: we will experience the excellence of the higher worlds.” The future Buddha Vipassi,

original: tāni pubbanimittāni disvā “idāni anantare attabhāve buddho bhavissāmī”ti na bhāyati.
analyzed: tāni pubba nimittāni disvā idāni anantare attabhāve buddhaḥ bhavissāmi iti na bhāyati
translated: seeing these omens, was not afraid, thinking, “In my next existence I will become a Buddha.”

original: Athassa tesu nimittesu pātubhūtesu dasasahassacakkavāḷadevatā sannipatitvā – “mārisa,
analyzed: athassa tesu nimittesu pātubhūtesu dasa sahassa cakkavāḷa devatā sannipatitvā mārisa
translated: Then, when these omens appeared, the deities of the ten thousand world systems assembled and said, “Good sir,

original: tumhehi dasa pāramiyo pūrentehi na sakkasampattiṃ, na mārasampattiṃ, na brahmasampattiṃ,
analyzed: tumhehi dasa pāramiyaḥ pūrentehi na sakka sampattim na māra sampattim na brahma sampattim
translated: while you were fulfilling the ten perfections, you did not seek the prosperity of Sakka, the prosperity of Mara, the prosperity of Brahma,

original: na cakkavattisampattiṃ patthentehi pūritā, lokanittharaṇatthāya pana buddhattaṃ patthayamānehi
analyzed: na cakkavatti sampattim patthentehi pūritā loka nittharaṇa tthāya pana buddha ttam patthayamānehi
translated: not by those who were seeking the glory of a Universal Monarch, but by those who were seeking Buddhahood for the purpose of delivering the world.

original: pūritā. So vo, idāni kālo, mārisa, buddhattāya, samayo, mārisa, buddhattāyā”ti yācanti.
analyzed: pūritā saḥ vaḥ idāni kālaḥ mārisa buddhattāya samayaḥ mārisa buddhattāya ati yācanti
translated: Now is the time, good sir, for Buddhahood, now is the opportunity, good sir, for Buddhahood.”🔽Then the Great Being, without giving his consent to those deities, surveyed the world in five great aspects, namely,

original: Atha mahāsatto tāsaṃ devatānaṃ paṭiññaṃ adatvāva kāladīpadesakulajanettiāyuparicchedavasena
analyzed: atha mahāsatto tāsam devatānam paṭiññam kāla dīpa desa kula jana itti āyu pariccheda vasena
translated: the time, the region, the family, the mother, and the span of life.

original: pañcamahāvilokanaṃ nāma vilokesi. Tattha “kālo nu kho, na kālo”ti paṭhamaṃ kālaṃ
analyzed: pañcamahāvilokanam nāma vilokesi tattha kālo nu kho na kāloti paṭhamam kālaṃ
translated: First of all he surveyed the time, asking himself, “Is it time or is it not time?”

original: vilokesi. Tattha vassasatasahassato uddhaṃ vaḍḍhitaāyukālo kālo nāma na hoti. Kasmā?
analyzed: vilokesi tattha vassa sata sahassataḥ uddham vaḍḍhita āyu kālo kālaḥ nāma na hoti kasmā
translated: Now, a time when the life-span of men is more than a hundred thousand years is not a time for the appearance of a Buddha. Why?

original: Tadā hi sattānaṃ jātijarāmaraṇāni na paññāyanti, buddhānañca dhammadesanā nāma tilakkhaṇamuttā
analyzed: tadā hi sattānam jāti jarā maraṇāni na paññāyanti buddhānam ca dhamma desanā nāma ti lakkhaṇa muttā
translated: For then birth, old age, and death are not known among men, and the teaching of the Buddhas is not concerned with anything other than the three characteristics.

original: natthi. Te tesaṃ – “aniccaṃ dukkhamanattā”ti kathentānaṃ – “kiṃ nāmetaṃ kathentī”ti
analyzed: natthi te tesam aniccam dukkham anattā ati kathentānam kim nāma etam kathenti iti
translated: And men, hearing the words “impermanent,” “suffering,” “not-self,” would ask, “What is this he is talking about?”

original: neva sotuṃ, na saddahituṃ maññanti, tato abhisamayo na hoti, tasmiṃ asati aniyyānikaṃ
analyzed: na iva sotum na saddahitum maññanti tatas abhisamayaḥ na hoti tasmin asati aniyyānikam
translated: they do not think to listen or believe, and then there is no penetration, and when that is absent, there is no going forth,

original: sāsanaṃ hoti. Tasmā so akālo. Vassasatato ūnaāyukālopi kālo na hoti. Kasmā? Tadā
analyzed: sāsanam hoti tasmā saḥ akālaḥ ūna āyu kālaḥ api kālaḥ na hoti kasmā tadā
translated: and they neither listen nor believe, and then there is no penetration of the Truth, and in the absence of that, the Dispensation is not successful. Therefore that time is not suitable. The time when the life-span is less than a hundred years is also not suitable. Why? Because then

original: hi sattā ussannakilesā honti, ussannakilesānañca dinno ovādo ovādaṭṭhāne na tiṭṭhati,
analyzed: hi sattāḥ ussanna kilesāḥ honti ussanna kilesānam ca dinnaḥ ovādaḥ ovāda ṭhāne na tiṭṭhati
translated: the defilements of beings are strong, and the advice given to those with strong defilements does not remain in the place where advice should remain,

original: udake daṇḍarāji viya khippaṃ vigacchati. Tasmā sopi akālova. Vassasatasahassato paṭṭhāya🔽heṭṭhā, vassasatato paṭṭhāya uddhaṃ āyukālo kālo nāma, tadā ca asītivassasahassāyukā
analyzed: udake daṇḍa rāji viya khippam vigacchati tasmā saḥ api akālaḥ uva vassa sata sahassataḥ paṭṭhāya  heṭṭhā vassa satataḥ paṭṭhāya uddham āyu kālo kālaḥ nāma tadā ca asīti vassa sahassa āyukā
translated: but quickly disappears, like a line drawn on water. Therefore that time is also not suitable. The time when the life-span is more than a hundred years

original: manussā. Atha mahāsatto – “nibbattitabbakālo”ti kālaṃ passi.
analyzed: manussāḥ atha mahāsattaḥ nibbattitabba kālaḥ iti kālam passi
translated: and less than a hundred thousand years is called suitable. And then the human life-span is eighty thousand years. Then the Great Being saw the time for his birth.

original: Tato dīpaṃ vilokento saparivāre cattāro dīpe oloketvā – “tīsu dīpesu buddhā na nibbattanti, jambudīpeyeva nibbattantī”ti dīpaṃ passi.
analyzed: tatas dīpam vilokento sa parivāre cattāraḥ dīpe oloketvā tīsu dīpesu buddhāḥ na nibbattanti jambudīpe iya iva nibbattanti iti dīpam passi
translated: Then, looking for an island, he looked at the four islands with their surrounding areas, and after looking, he thought: “Buddhas do not appear in the three islands, but only in the Rose-Apple Island.” Thus he looked at the island.

original: Tato – “jambudīpo nāma mahā, dasayojanasahassaparimāṇo, katarasmiṃ nu kho padese
analyzed: tatas jambudīpaḥ nāma mahā dasa yojana sahassa parimāṇaḥ katarasmin nu kho padese
translated: Then he considered: “The Rose-Apple Island is large, measuring ten thousand leagues. In which part of it

original: buddhā nibbattantī”ti desaṃ vilokento majjhimadesaṃ passi. Majjhimadeso nāma – “puratthimāya
analyzed: buddhāḥ nibbattanti iti desam vilokentaḥ majjhima desam passi majjhimadesaḥ nāma puratthimāya
translated: will the Buddhas arise?” He saw that the Middle Country was the place. The Middle Country is described in the Vinaya in the way beginning:

original: disāya gajaṅgalaṃ nāma nigamo”tiādinā nayena vinaye vuttova. So āyāmato tīṇi yojanasatāni,
analyzed: disāya gajaṅgalam nāma nigamaḥ ti ādinā nayena vinaye vuttaḥ uva saḥ āyāmataḥ tīṇi yojana satāni
translated: “The town called Gajaṅgala lies in the eastern direction” . It is three hundred leagues in extent from east to west,

original: vitthārato aḍḍhateyyāni, parikkhepato navayojanasatānīti. Etasmiñhi padese buddhā🔽paccekabuddhā aggasāvakā asīti mahāsāvakā cakkavattirājāno aññe ca mahesakkhā khattiyabrāhmaṇagahapatimahāsālā
analyzed: vitthārataḥ aḍḍhateyyāni parikkhepataḥ nava yojana satāni iti etasmin hi padese buddhāḥ  paccekabuddhāḥ aggasāvakā asīti mahāsāvakā cakkavatti rājāno aññe ca mahesakkhā khattiya brāhmaṇa gahapati mahā sālā
translated: and two hundred and forty leagues across in the middle. It is nine hundred leagues in circumference. For it is in this country that Buddhas,

original: uppajjanti. Idañcettha bandhumatī nāma nagaraṃ, tattha mayā nibbattitabbanti niṭṭhaṃ agamāsi.
analyzed: uppajjanti idam ca ittha bandhumatī nāma nagaram tattha mayā nibbattitabban ti niṭṭham agamāsi
translated: Paccekabuddhas, chief disciples, the eighty great great disciples, universal monarchs, and other great personages of the same rank as these are born. He decided that he would be reborn in this country, in the town of Bandhumati.

original: Tato kulaṃ vilokento – “buddhā nāma lokasammate kule nibbattanti. Idāni ca khattiyakulaṃ lokasammataṃ, tattha nibbattissāmi, bandhumā nāma me rājā pitā bhavissatī”ti kulaṃ passi.🔽Tato mātaraṃ vilokento – “buddhamātā nāma lolā surādhuttā na hoti, kappasatasahassaṃ
analyzed: tatas kulam vilokentaḥ buddhāḥ nāma loka sammate kule nibbattanti idāni ca khattiya kulam loka sammatam tattha nibbattissāmi bandhumā nāma me rājā pitā bhavissati iti kulam passi  tatas mātaram vilokentaḥ buddha mātā nāma lolā surādhuttā na hoti kappa sata sahassam
translated: Then, surveying the family, he thought, “Buddhas are born in a family that is honored in the world. Now the family of Khattiyas is honored in the world, so I will be born there. King Bandhuma will be my father.” Thus he surveyed the family.

original: pūritapāramī, jātito paṭṭhāya akhaṇḍapañcasīlā hoti, ayañca bandhumatī nāma devī
analyzed: pūrita pāramī jātitaḥ paṭṭhāya akhaṇḍa pañca sīlā hoti ayam ca bandhumatī nāma devī
translated: Then, surveying the mother, he thought, “The mother of a Buddha is not loose in morals, nor a drunkard, nor a fool. She has fulfilled the ten Perfections, and from the time of her birth she has observed the five precepts without break. And this Queen Bandhumati

original: īdisā, ayaṃ me mātā bhavissati, “kittakaṃ panassā āyū”ti āvajjanto “dasannaṃ māsānaṃ
analyzed: īdisā ayam me mātā bhavissati kittakam panassā āyu āvajjantaḥ dasannam māsānaṃ
translated: is such a one. She will be my mother.” Then he considered, “How long is her life?” and he saw that it would last

original: upari satta divasānī”ti passi.
analyzed: upari satta divasāni iti passi
translated: ten months and seven days more.

original: Iti imaṃ pañcamahāvilokanaṃ viloketvā “kālo, me mārisā, buddhabhāvāyā”ti devatānaṃ
analyzed: iti imam pañca mahā vilokanam viloketvā kālaḥ me mārisāḥ buddha bhāvāya ati
translated: Thus surveying the five great matters, he said to the deities, “The time has come, friends, for me to become a Buddha.”

original: saṅgahaṃ karonto paṭiññaṃ datvā – “gacchatha, tumhe”ti tā devatā uyyojetvā tusitadevatāhi
analyzed: saṅgaham karontaḥ paṭiññam da tvā gacchatha tumhā iti tāḥ devatāḥ uyyojetvā tusita devatāhi
translated: Then, making a promise to gather in the deities, he said, “Go, you,” and sent them away. Then the deities of the Tusita heaven

original: parivuto tusitapure nandanavanaṃ pāvisi. Sabbadevalokesu hi nandanavanaṃ atthiyeva.🔽Tatra naṃ devatā ito cuto sugatiṃ gacchāti pubbekatakusalakammokāsaṃ sārayamānā vicaranti.
analyzed: parivutaḥ tusitapure nandana vanam pāvisi sabba deva lokesu hi nandana vanam atthiyā iva  tatra nam devatāḥ itas cutaḥ sugatim gacchāti pubbekata kusala kamma ukāsam sārayamānāḥ vicaranti
translated: and surrounded by the devas he entered the Nandana Grove. For there is a Nandana Grove in every world of devas.🔽There the devas, reminding him of the opportunity for making merit he had in the past, saying, “You have passed away from here; you will go to a happy destiny,” wander about.

original: So evaṃ devatāhi kusalaṃ sārayamānāhi parivuto tattha vicarantoyeva cavi.
analyzed: saḥ evam devatāhi kusalam sārayamānāhi parivutaḥ tattha
translated: And while he was wandering about there, surrounded by the devas who were reminding him of his merit, he passed away.

original: Evaṃ cuto ca ‘cavāmī’ti jānāti, cuticittaṃ na jānāti. Paṭisandhiṃ gahetvāpi jānāti,
analyzed: evam cutaḥ ca cavāmi iti jānāti cuti cittam na jānāti paṭisandhim gahetvā api jānāti
translated: And when he had passed away he knew, “I have passed away,” but he did not know the death consciousness. And after he had taken rebirth-linking he knew,

original: paṭisandhicittameva na jānāti. “Imasmiṃ me ṭhāne paṭisandhiṃ gahitā”ti evaṃ pana
analyzed: paṭisandhi cittam eva na jānāti imasmin me ṭhāne paṭisandhim gahitā ati evam pana
translated: but he did not know the rebirth-linking consciousness. But he knew, “I have taken rebirth-linking in this place.”

original: jānāti. Keci pana therā – “āvajjanapariyāyo nāma laddhuṃ vaṭṭati, dutiyatatiyacittavāre
analyzed: jānāti keci pana therāḥ āvajjana pariyāyaḥ nāma laddhum vaṭṭati dutiya tatiya cittavāre
translated: But some elders say that the mode of apprehension is allowable, and that he will know in the second and third consciousnesses of the cognitive series.

original: eva jānissatī”ti vadanti. Tipiṭakamahāsīvatthero pana āha – “mahāsattānaṃ paṭisandhi
analyzed: eva jānissati iti vadanti tipiṭaka mahāsīva theraḥ pana āha mahāsattānam paṭisandhi
translated: But the Elder Tipiṭaka Mahā Dāyāda said: “The rebirth-linking of great beings🔽is not like that of others. But their mindfulness and awareness reach a peak. Since,

original: na aññesaṃ paṭisandhisadisā, koṭippattaṃ pana tesaṃ satisampajaññaṃ. Yasmā pana teneva
analyzed: na aññesam paṭisandhi sadisā koṭi ppattam pana tesam sati sampajaññam yasmā pana tena iva
translated: however, they have to take rebirth-linking in a place where they can fulfil the perfections, they do not know the place.

original: cittena taṃ cittaṃ ñātuṃ na sakkā, tasmā cuticittaṃ na jānāti. Cutikkhaṇepi ‘cavāmī’ti
analyzed: cittena tam cittam ñātum na sakkā tasmā cuti cittam na jānāti cuti kkhaṇe pi cavāmi iti
translated: But the death consciousness cannot know that consciousness, and so the death consciousness does not know, ‘I am dying.’

original: jānāti. Paṭisandhicittaṃ na jānāti. ‘Asukasmiṃ me ṭhāne paṭisandhi gahitā’ti jānāti,
analyzed: jānāti paṭisandhi cittam na jānāti asukasmin me ṭhāne paṭisandhi gahitā ati jānāti
translated: But the rebirth-linking consciousness knows, ‘I am dying,’ and it knows, ‘I am going to be reborn in such and such a place.’🔽And at that moment the ten-thousandfold world system shakes.”

original: tasmiṃ kāle dasasahassilokadhātu kampatī”ti. Evaṃ sato sampajāno mātukucchiṃ okkamanto
analyzed: tasmin kāle dasa sahassi lokadhātu kampati iti evam sataḥ sampajānaḥ mātukucchim okkamantaḥ
translated: But when he was thus mindful and clearly comprehending,

original: pana ekūnavīsatiyā paṭisandhicittesu mettāpubbabhāgassa somanassasahagatañāṇasampayuttaasaṅkhārikakusalacittassa
analyzed: pana ekūnavīsatiyā paṭisandhi cittesu mettā pubba bhāgassa somanassa sahagata ñāṇa sampayutta asaṅkhārika kusala cittassa
translated: he took rebirth-linking with a consciousness of the same kind as the profitable consciousness accompanied by joy and associated with knowledge consisting in what is heard, etc., that occurred as the forerunner of the loving-kindness,

original: sadisamahāvipākacittena paṭisandhi gaṇhi. Mahāsīvatthero pana upekkhāsahagatenāti
analyzed: sadisa mahā vipāka cittena paṭisandhi gaṇhi mahāsīva thero pana upekkhā sahagatena ati
translated: but of great potency. The Elder Mahā-Siva, however, says that it was accompanied by equanimity.

original: āha. Yathā ca amhākaṃ bhagavā, evaṃ sopi āsāḷhīpuṇṇamāyaṃ uttarāsāḷhanakkhatteneva🔽paṭisandhiṃ aggahesi.
analyzed: āha yathā ca amhākam bhagavā evam saḥ api āsāḷhīpuṇṇamāyam uttara āsāḷha nakkhattena iva  paṭisandhim aggahesi
translated: And just as our Blessed One did, he took rebirth-linking by the Uttarāsāḷha lunar mansion on the full-moon day of the month of Āsāḷhi.

original: Tadā kira pure puṇṇamāya sattamadivasato paṭṭhāya vigatasurāpānaṃ mālāgandhādivibhūtisampannaṃ
analyzed: tadā kira pure puṇṇamāya sattama divasataḥ paṭṭhāya vigata surā pānam mālā gandha ādi vibhūti sampannam
translated: For on that day, it seems, the city was decorated with garlands and scents and so on, and it was free from the smell of urine,

original: nakkhattakīḷaṃ anubhavamānā bodhisattamātā sattame divase pāto uṭṭhāya gandhodakena
analyzed: nakkhatta kīḷam anubhavamānā bodhisatta mātā sattame divase pāto uṭṭhāya gandha udakena
translated: And as she was enjoying the pleasures of the stars, on the seventh day, in the morning, she rose up, and bathed in scented water,

original: nahāyitvā sabbālaṅkāravibhūsitā varabhojanaṃ bhuñjitvā uposathaṅgāni adhiṭṭhāya sirigabbhaṃ🔽pavisitvā sirisayane nipannā niddaṃ okkamamānā idaṃ supinaṃ addasa – “cattāro kira
analyzed: nahāyitvā sabba alaṅkāra vibhūsitā vara bhojanam bhuñjitvā uposathaṅgāni adhiṭṭhāya sirigabbham  pavisitvā siri sayane nipannā niddam okkamamānā idam supinam addasa cattāraḥ kira
translated: and adorned herself with all her ornaments, and ate choice food, and took upon herself the duties of the fast-day, and entered the chamber of state,

original: naṃ mahārājāno sayaneneva saddhiṃ ukkhipitvā anotattadahaṃ netvā nahāpetvā dibbavatthaṃ
analyzed: nam mahā rājāno sayanena iva saddhim ukkhipitvā netvā nahāpetvā dibbavattham
translated: and lay down on the couch of state, and as she was falling asleep, she saw this dream: “Four great kings, it seems, took her up with the couch, and carried her to the Anotatta lake, and bathed her,

original: nivāsetvā dibbagandhehi vilimpetvā dibbapupphāni piḷandhitvā, tato avidūre rajatapabbato,
analyzed: nivāsetvā dibba gandhehi vilimpetvā dibba pupphāni piḷandhitvā tatas avidūre rajata pabbataḥ
translated: and clothed her in celestial raiment, and anointed her with celestial perfumes, and wreathed her with celestial flowers,🔽and not far from there was a silver mountain,

original: tassa anto kanakavimānaṃ atthi, tasmiṃ pācīnato sīsaṃ katvā nipajjāpesuṃ. Atha bodhisatto🔽setavaravāraṇo hutvā tato avidūre eko suvaṇṇapabbato, tattha caritvā tato oruyha
analyzed: tassa antaḥ kanaka vimānam atthi tasmin pācīnatas sīsam katvā atha bodhisatto  setavara vāraṇaḥ hutvā tatas avidūre ekaḥ suvaṇṇa pabbato tattha caritvā tatas oruyha
translated: and within it was a golden palace, and there they made her lie down, turning her head to the east. Then the Bodisat,🔽becoming a white, noble elephant, roamed about not far from there on a golden mountain, and coming down from there,

original: rajatapabbataṃ abhiruhitvā kanakavimānaṃ pavisitvā mātaraṃ padakkhiṇaṃ katvā dakkhiṇapassaṃ
analyzed: rajatapabbatam abhiruhitvā kanaka vimānam pavisitvā mātaram padakkhiṇam katvā dakkhiṇa passam
translated: he ascended the silver mountain, and entering the golden palace, he walked round his mother, keeping her to his right, and then he went out by the eastern door,🔽and

original: phāletvā kucchiṃ paviṭṭhasadiso ahosi”.
analyzed: phāletvā kucchim paviṭṭha sadisaḥ ahosi
translated: and it seemed as if it had entered her womb and burst it open.”🔽When the night had passed, the Queen told the King her dream. The King,

original: Atha pabuddhā devī taṃ supinaṃ rañño ārocesi. Rājā vibhātāya rattiyā catusaṭṭhimatte🔽brāhmaṇapāmokkhe pakkosāpetvā haritūpalittāya lājādīhi katamaṅgalasakkārāya bhūmiyā
analyzed: atha pabuddhā devī tam supinam raññaḥ ārocesi rājā vibhātāya rattiyā  brāhmaṇa pāmokkhe pakkosāpetvā haritūpalittāya lāja ādīhi kata maṅgala sakkārāya bhūmiyā
translated: when it was morning, summoned the sixty-four chief Brahmins,🔽and on a spot that had been swept clean and on which auspicious rites had been performed with parched grain, etc.,

original: mahārahāni āsanāni paññapetvā tattha nisinnānaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ sappimadhusakkarābhisaṅkhatassa🔽varapāyāsassa suvaṇṇarajatapātiyo pūretvā suvaṇṇarajatapātīheva paṭikujjitvā adāsi,
analyzed: mahā rahāni āsanāni paññapetvā tattha nisinnānam brāhmaṇānam sappi madhu sakkara abhisaṅkhatassa  varapāyāsassa suvaṇṇa rajata pātiyaḥ pūretvā suvaṇṇa rajata pātīha iva paṭikujjitvā adāsi
translated: he had costly seats arranged, and when the Brahmins had sat down, he gave them, in golden and silver dishes,🔽the best rice-milk, mixed with ghee, honey, and sugar, and covered with golden and silver foil,🔽and he satisfied them with other gifts of new cloth, tawny cows, etc. Then,

original: aññehi ca ahatavatthakapilagāvīdānādīhi nesaṃ santappesi. Atha nesaṃ sabbakāmasantappitānaṃ
analyzed: aññehi ca ahata vattha kapila gāvī dāna ādīhi nesam santappesi atha nesam sabba kāma santappitānam
translated: when they had been satisfied with all their desires,

original: taṃ supinaṃ ārocetvā – “kiṃ bhavissatī”ti pucchi. Brāhmaṇā āhaṃsu – “mā cintayi,
analyzed: tam supinam ārocetvā kim bhavissati iti pucchi brāhmaṇāḥ āhaṃsu mā cintayi
translated: he told them his dream and asked what it would mean. The Brahmins said, “Do not worry,

original: mahārāja, deviyā te kucchimhi gabbho patiṭṭhito, so ca kho purisagabbho na itthigabbho,
analyzed: mahā rāja deviyā te kucchimhi gabbho patiṭṭhito so ca kho purisa gabbho na itthi gabbho
translated: Great King. A child has been conceived in the Queen’s womb, and it is a male child, not a female.

original: putto te bhavissati. So sace agāraṃ ajjhāvasissati, rājā bhavissati cakkavattī. Sace
analyzed: puttaḥ te bhavissati saḥ sace agāram ajjhāvasissati rājā bhavissati cakkavattī sace
translated: He will be your son. If he lives in the house he will be a Wheel-turning Monarch,

original: agārā nikkhamma pabbajissati, buddho bhavissati loke vivaṭṭacchado”ti. Ayaṃ tāva
analyzed: agārā nikkhamma pabbajissati buddhaḥ bhavissati loke vivaṭṭa chado ti ayam tāva
translated: but if he goes forth from the house life he will become an Enlightened One, a man who has drawn out the dart of craving.”

original: – “mātukucchiṃ okkamī”ti ettha vaṇṇanākkamo.
analyzed: mātukucchim okkami iti ettha vaṇṇanā akkamo
translated: This, in the first place, is the order of the explanation of the words “entered his mother’s womb.”

original: Ayamettha dhammatāti ayaṃ ettha mātukucchiokkamane dhammatā, ayaṃ sabhāvo, ayaṃ niyāmoti
analyzed: ayam ettha dhamma tā ati ayam ettha mātukucchi okkamane dhamma tā ayam sabhāvaḥ ayam niyāmo ti
translated: This is the rule here: this is the rule, the nature, the regularity here in the descent into the womb.

original: vuttaṃ hoti. Niyāmo ca nāmesa kammaniyāmo, utuniyāmo, bījaniyāmo, cittaniyāmo, dhammaniyāmoti pañcavidho.
analyzed: vuttam hoti niyāmo ca nāma esa kamma niyāmaḥ utu niyāmaḥ bīja niyāmaḥ citta niyāmaḥ dhamma niyāmaḥ ti pañcavidhaḥ
translated: The rule is of five kinds, namely, rule of kamma, rule of season, rule of seed, rule of consciousness, and rule of Dhamma.

original: Tattha kusalassa iṭṭhavipākadānaṃ, akusalassa aniṭṭhavipākadānanti ayaṃ kammaniyāmo.🔽Tassa dīpanatthaṃ – “na antalikkhe”ti gāthāya vatthūni vattabbāni. Apica ekā kira
analyzed: tattha kusalassa iṭṭha vipāka dānam akusalassa aniṭṭha vipāka dānam ti ayam kammaniyāmo  tassa dīpana attham na antalikkhā iti gāthāya vatthūni vattabbāni apica ekā kira
translated: Herein, the rule of kamma is the giving of a desirable ripening by a profitable kamma and of an undesirable ripening by an unprofitable kamma.

original: itthī sāmikena saddhiṃ bhaṇḍitvā ubbandhitvā maritukāmā rajjupāse gīvaṃ pavesesi.
analyzed: itthī sāmikena saddhim bhaṇḍitvā ubbandhitvā maritu kāmā rajju pāse gīvam pavesesi
translated: To illustrate this, the stanzas beginning with “Not in the sky” should be quoted. Besides, it seems that a certain woman had a quarrel with her husband and, wanting to hang herself, she put her neck in a noose.

original: Aññataro puriso vāsiṃ nisento taṃ itthikammaṃ disvā rajjuṃ chinditukāmo – “mā bhāyi,
analyzed: aññataraḥ puriso vāsim nisento tam itthi kammam disvā rajjum chinditu kāmo mā bhāyi
translated: A certain man, sitting there with a knife, seeing that woman’s work, wanting to cut the rope, said: “Don’t be afraid,

original: mā bhāyī”ti taṃ samassāsento upadhāvi. Rajju āsīviso hutvā aṭṭhāsi. So bhīto palāyi.
analyzed: mā bhāyi iti tam samassāsento upadhāvi rajju āsīvisaḥ hutvā aṭṭhāsi saḥ bhīto palāyi
translated: A man sitting there with a knife in his hand saw the woman’s work and wanted to cut the rope. He ran up, saying, “Don’t be afraid, don’t be afraid,” to reassure her. The rope became a poisonous snake and stood there. He was frightened and ran away.

original: Itarā tattheva mari. Evamādīni cettha vatthūni dassetabbāni.
analyzed: itarā tattha iva mari evamādīni ca ittha vatthūni dassetabbāni
translated: She died right there. These are the kinds of stories that should be told.

original: Tesu tesu janapadesu tasmiṃ tasmiṃ kāle ekappahāreneva rukkhānaṃ pupphaphalagahaṇādīni,
analyzed: tesu tesu janapadesu tasmin tasmin kāle eka ppahārena iva rukkhānam puppha phala gahaṇa ādīni
translated: In this or that country, at this or that time, the flowering and fruiting of trees, etc., are all simultaneous.

original: vātassa vāyanaṃ avāyanaṃ, ātapassa tikkhatā mandatā, devassa vassanaṃ avassanaṃ,
analyzed: vātassa vāyanam avāyanam ātapassa tikkha tā manda tā devassa vassanam avassanam
translated: The blowing and not blowing of the wind, the intensity and mildness of the sun, the raining and not raining of the gods,

original: padumānaṃ divā vikasanaṃ rattiṃ milāyananti evamādi utuniyāmo.
analyzed: divā vikasanam rattim evamādi
translated: the opening of the day lotus and the closing of the night lotus, etc., are all regular.

original: Yaṃ panetaṃ sālibījato sāliphalameva, madhurato madhurasaṃyeva, tittato tittarasaṃyeva phalaṃ hoti, ayaṃ bījaniyāmo.
analyzed: yam pana itam sāli bījataḥ sāli phalam eva madhurataḥ madhura saṃyā iva tittataḥ tittara saṃyā iva phalam hoti ayam bīja niyāmaḥ
translated: But the fact that the fruit of rice is only the fruit of rice, the fruit of sugar cane only the fruit of sugar cane, the fruit of honey only the fruit of honey, is the regularity of seeds.

original: Purimā purimā cittacetasikā dhammā pacchimānaṃ pacchimānaṃ cittacetasikānaṃ dhammānaṃ
analyzed: purimā purimā citta cetasikā dhammā pacchimānam pacchimānam citta cetasikānam dhammānam
translated: The earlier and earlier states of consciousness and its concomitants are the condition, as repetition condition, for the later and later states of consciousness and its concomitants.

original: upanissayapaccayena paccayoti evaṃ yadetaṃ cakkhuviññāṇādīnaṃ anantarā sampaṭicchanādīnaṃ
analyzed: upanissaya paccayena paccayaḥ ti evam yat etam cakkhu viññāṇa ādīnam anantarā sampaṭicchanā ādīnam
translated: “Conditioned by proximity condition” is the production of the receiving, etc., of eye-consciousness, etc., immediately next to the eye, etc.

original: nibbattanaṃ, ayaṃ cittaniyāmo.
analyzed: nibbattanam ayam citta niyāmaḥ
translated: This is the regularity of consciousness.

original: Yā panesā bodhisattānaṃ mātukucchiokkamanādīsu dasasahassilokadhātukampanādīnaṃ pavatti,🔽ayaṃ dhammaniyāmo nāma. Tesu idha dhammaniyāmo adhippeto. Tasmā tamevatthaṃ dassento
analyzed: yā pana isā bodhisattānam mātukucchi ukkamana ādīsu dasa sahassi lokadhātu kampana ādīnam pavatti  ayam dhammaniyāmaḥ nāma tesu idha dhammaniyāmaḥ adhippetaḥ tasmā tam eva attham dassento
translated: But the occurrence of the quaking of the ten-thousand world-element, etc., at the descent into the womb, etc., of the Bodhisattas is called the regularity of states.🔽Herein, it is the regularity of states that is intended. Therefore, showing that,

original: dhammatā esā bhikkhavetiādimāha.
analyzed: dhammatā esā bhikkhave ti ādim āha
translated: he said, “Bhikkhus, this is the nature of states, this is the regularity of states, this is the way states are” .

original: 18. Tattha kucchiṃ okkamatīti ettha kucchiṃ okkanto hotīti ayamevattho. Okkante hi
analyzed: tattha kucchim okkamati iti ettha kucchim okkanto hoti iti ayam eva atthaḥ okkante hi
translated: Herein, the meaning is simply “he descends into the womb” in the passage, “He descends into the womb” .🔽For it is when he has descended that it is so, not while he is descending.

original: tasmiṃ evaṃ hoti, na okkamamāne. Appamāṇoti vuḍḍhippamāṇo, vipuloti attho. Uḷāroti
analyzed: tasmin evam hoti na okkamamāne appamāṇaḥ ati vuḍḍhi ppamāṇaḥ vipulaḥ ti attho uḷāraḥ ti
translated: Immeasurable: the measure of its growth is immeasurable; the meaning is, it is vast.🔽Exceedingly great:

original: tasseva vevacanaṃ. Uḷārāni uḷārāni khādanīyāni khādantītiādīsu hi madhuraṃ uḷāranti
analyzed: tassa iva vevacanam uḷārāni uḷārāni khādanīyāni khādanti itiādīsu hi madhuram uḷāranti
translated: this is a synonym for the former word. For in such passages as “Eating exceedingly great hard food” , etc., “exceedingly great” is said to be sweet.

original: vuttaṃ. Uḷārāya khalu bhavaṃ vacchāyano samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ pasaṃsāya pasaṃsatītiādīsu
analyzed: vuttam uḷārāya khalu bhavam vacchāyanaḥ samaṇam gotamam pasaṃsāya pasaṃsati itiādīsu
translated: And in such passages as “Master Vacchayana, in praising the recluse Gotama you praise him exceedingly” ,

original: seṭṭhaṃ uḷāranti vuttaṃ. Idha pana vipulaṃ adhippetaṃ. Devānaṃ devānubhāvanti ettha
analyzed: seṭṭham uḷāranti vuttam idha pana vipulam adhippetam devānam deva anubhāvanti ettha
translated: and the best is called the highest. But here the meaning is extensive.

original: devānaṃ ayamānubhāvo nivatthavatthassa pabhā dvādasayojanāni pharati, tathā sarīrassa,
analyzed: devānam ayam ānubhāvaḥ nivattha vatthassa pabhā dvādasa yojanāni tathā sarīrassa
translated: The splendour of the gods: the splendour of the gods is this, that the radiance of their clothes extends twelve leagues, and so does that of their bodies,

original: tathā alaṅkārassa, tathā vimānassa, taṃ atikkamitvāti attho.🔽Lokantarikāti tiṇṇaṃ tiṇṇaṃ cakkavāḷānaṃ antarā ekeko lokantariko hoti, tiṇṇaṃ sakaṭacakkānaṃ
analyzed: tathā alaṅkārassa tathā vimānassa tam atikkamitvā iti attho  lokantarikā ati tiṇṇam tiṇṇam cakkavāḷānam antarā ekekaḥ lokantarikaḥ hoti tiṇṇam sakaṭa cakkānam
translated: and so does that of their ornaments, and so does that of their palaces. The meaning is that it exceeds that.

original: vā tiṇṇaṃ pattānaṃ vā aññamaññaṃ āhacca ṭhapitānaṃ majjhe okāso viya. So pana lokantarikanirayo
analyzed: vā tiṇṇam pattānam vā aññamaññam āhacca ṭhapitānam majjhe okāsaḥ viya saḥ pana lokantarikanirayo
translated: The inter-Brahmā-world-system: between each three world-spheres of a thousand worlds there is one inter-Brahmā-world-system, like the space between three yokes placed with their points touching, or like the space between three cart-wheels placed with their rims touching.

original: parimāṇato aṭṭhayojanasahasso hoti. Aghāti niccavivaṭā. Asaṃvutāti heṭṭhāpi appatiṭṭhā.
analyzed: parimāṇato aṭṭha yojana sahassaḥ hoti aghā ati nicca vivaṭā a saṃvutā ati heṭṭhā api appatiṭṭhā
translated: But that inter-Brahmā-world-system is eight thousand leagues in extent. It is always open. It is not closed up below.

original: Andhakārāti tamabhūtā. Andhakāratimisāti cakkhuviññāṇuppattinivāraṇato andhabhāvakaraṇatimisena
analyzed: andhakārā ati tama bhūtā andhakāra timisā ti cakkhu viññāṇa uppatti nivāraṇataḥ andha bhāva karaṇa timisena
translated: It is dark. It is a gloom. It is a great gloom. It is a gloom that begets fear. It is a gloom that makes the hair stand on end.

original: samannāgatā. Tattha kira cakkhuviññāṇaṃ na jāyati. Evaṃmahiddhikāti candimasūriyā
analyzed: samannāgatā tattha kira cakkhu viññāṇam na jāyati evaṃmahiddhikā ati candima sūriyā
translated: There, it seems, eye-consciousness does not arise. So powerful: the moon and sun,

original: kira ekappahāreneva tīsu dīpesu paññāyanti, evaṃ mahiddhikā. Ekekāya disāya nava
analyzed: kira eka ppahārena iva tīsu dīpesu paññāyanti evam mahiddhikāḥ ekekāya disāya nava
translated: and it is said that they are known in the three continents at one and the same time. They are so powerful.

original: nava yojanasatasahassāni andhakāraṃ vidhamitvā ālokaṃ dassenti, evaṃmahānubhāvā.
analyzed: nava yojana sata sahassāni andhakāram vidhamitvā ālokam dassenti evaṃmahā anubhāvā
translated: They are so powerful that they are known in the three continents at one and the same time. They are so mighty that they dispel the darkness in the nine hundred and ninety-one systems of worlds in each of the four directions and shed light there.

original: Ābhāya nānubhontīti attano pabhāya nappahonti. Te kira cakkavāḷapabbatassa vemajjhena
analyzed: ābhāya na anubhonti iti attanaḥ pabhāya na pahonti te kira cakkavāḷa pabbatassa vemajjhena
translated: They cannot bear its splendor: they cannot bear the splendor of their own light. They wander about, it seems, in the middle of the Cakkavāḷa Mountain,

original: vicaranti, cakkavāḷapabbatañca atikkamma lokantarikanirayā. Tasmā te tattha ābhāya nappahonti.
analyzed: vicaranti cakkavāḷa pabbatam ca atikkamma lokantarika nirayā tasmā te tattha ābhāya na ppahonti
translated: and they go beyond the Cakkavāḷa Mountain to the Lokantarika hells. That is why they cannot bear the splendor there.

original: Yepi tattha sattāti yepi tasmiṃ lokantarikamahāniraye sattā uppannā. Kiṃ pana kammaṃ🔽katvā tattha uppajjantīti. Bhāriyaṃ dāruṇaṃ mātāpitūnaṃ dhammikasamaṇabrāhmaṇānañca
analyzed: ye pi tattha sattā ati ye pi tasmin lokantarikamahāniraye sattāḥ uppannāḥ kim pana kammaṃ  katvā tattha uppajjanti iti bhāriyam dāruṇam mātā pitūnam dhammika samaṇa brāhmaṇānam ca
translated: And the beings there: the beings who are reborn in that great hell of the Lokantarika. But what kind of kamma do they perform in order to be reborn there?

original: upari aparādhaṃ, aññañca divase divase pāṇavadhādisāhasikakammaṃ katvā uppajjanti,
analyzed: upari aparādham aññan ca divase divase pāṇa vadha ādi sāhasika kammam katvā uppajjanti
translated: They perform heavy and terrible offences against their parents and against ascetics and brahmans, and they perform other violent deeds such as killing living beings day after day.

original: tambapaṇṇidīpe abhayacoranāgacorādayo viya. Tesaṃ attabhāvo tigāvutiko hoti, vaggulīnaṃ
analyzed: tamba paṇṇi dīpe abhaya cora nāga cora ādayaḥ viya tesam attabhāvo tigāvutikaḥ hoti vaggulīnam
translated: They are reborn there after performing such kamma as that of the Abhaya, Nāga, and Corā robbers in Tambapaṇṇi Island .🔽Their bodies are thirty leagues tall,

original: viya dīghanakhā honti. Te rukkhe vagguliyo viya nakhehi cakkavāḷapabbate lagganti.
analyzed: viya dīgha nakhāḥ honti te rukkhe vagguliyaḥ viya nakhehi cakkavāḷa pabbate lagganti
translated: and their nails grow long like stakes. They climb the Cakkavāḷa mountain with their nails like wood-borers.

original: Yadā saṃsappantā aññamaññassa hatthapāsaṃ gatā honti, atha “bhakkho no laddho”ti
analyzed: yadā saṃsappantāḥ aññamaññassa hattha pāsam gatāḥ honti atha bhakkhaḥ no laddhaḥ ti
translated: When they have crawled and reached each other’s hands, they think, “We have got our food.”

original: maññamānā tattha vāvaṭā viparivattitvā lokasandhārakaudake patanti, vāte paharantepi
analyzed: maññamānā tattha vāvaṭāḥ viparivattitvā loka sandhāraka audake patanti vāte paharante pi
translated: and they turn round and round, rolling over and over, and fall into the water that supports the world.

original: madhukaphalāni viya chijjitvā udake patanti, patitamattāva accantakhāre udake piṭṭhapiṇḍi viya vilīyanti.🔽Aññepi kira bho santi sattāti bho yathā mayaṃ mahādukkhaṃ anubhavāma, evaṃ aññe kira
analyzed: madhuka phalāni viya chijjitvā udake patanti accantakhāre udake piṭṭha piṇḍi viya vilīyanti  aññe api kira bho santi sattā ati bho yathā mayam mahā dukkham anubhavāma evam aññe kira
translated: Even when the wind strikes them, they break up like honey-combs and fall into the water. As soon as they fall into the extremely caustic water, they dissolve like a lump of sugar in a cup of water.🔽“Are there any other beings, sir?” “Yes, there are other beings, sir.” “Just as we are experiencing great suffering, so are other beings experiencing this suffering.”

original: sattāpi imaṃ dukkhamanubhavanatthāya idhūpapannāti taṃ divasaṃ passanti. Ayaṃ pana
analyzed: sattā api imam dukkham anubhavana tthāya idha upapannā ti tam divasam passanti ayam pana
translated: On that day they see this. But this light

original: obhāso ekayāgupānamattampi na tiṭṭhati, accharāsaṅghāṭamattameva vijjobhāso viya
analyzed: eka yāgu pāna mattam pi na tiṭṭhati accharā saṅghāṭa mattam eva vijjobhāsaḥ
translated: does not last even for the time it takes to drink a cup of rice gruel. It disappears like a flash of lightning.

original: niccharitvā – “kiṃ ida”nti bhaṇantānaṃyeva antaradhāyati. Saṅkampatīti samantato
analyzed: niccharitvā kim antaradhāyati saṅkampati iti
translated: “It shakes” means that it shakes all around.

original: kampati. Itaradvayaṃ purimapadasseva vevacanaṃ. Puna appamāṇo cātiādi nigamanatthaṃ vuttaṃ.🔽19. Cattāro naṃ devaputtā cātuddisaṃ rakkhāya upagacchantīti ettha cattāroti catunnaṃ
analyzed: kampati itara dvayam purima padassa iva vevacanam puna appamāṇaḥ ca atiādi nigamana attham vuttam  cattāro nam deva puttā cātuddisam rakkhāya upagacchanti iti ettha cattāro ti catunnam
translated: The other two are synonyms for the first. Again, “immeasurable” is said for the purpose of concluding.

original: mahārājānaṃ vasena vuttaṃ. Dasasahassacakkavāḷesu pana cattāro cattāro katvā cattālīsasahassāni🔽honti. Tattha imasmiṃ cakkavāḷe mahārājāno khaggahatthā bodhisattassa ārakkhatthāya🔽upagantvā sirigabbhaṃ paviṭṭhā, itare gabbhadvārato paṭṭhāya avaruddhake paṃsupisācakādiyakkhagaṇe
analyzed: mahā rājānam vasena vuttam dasa sahassa cakkavāḷesu pana cattāro cattāro katvā cattālīsa sahassāni  honti tattha imasmin cakkavāḷe mahā rājāno khagga hatthāḥ bodhisattassa ārakkha tthāya  upagantvā siri gabbham paviṭṭhāḥ itare gabbha dvārataḥ paṭṭhāya avaruddhake paṃsu pisācaka ādi yakkha gaṇe
translated: As to “four divine princes approach for the protection of the four quarters”: here “four” is said with reference to the four great kings. But in the ten thousand world-spheres there are forty thousand,

original: paṭikkamāpetvā yāva cakkavāḷā ārakkhaṃ gaṇhiṃsu.
analyzed: paṭikkamāpetvā yāva cakkavāḷāḥ ārakkham gaṇhiṃsu
translated: making four for each of the ten thousand world-spheres. Therein, in this world-sphere, the great kings, taking swords in their hands, approached for the protection of the Bodhisatta. After entering the chamber of beauty, the others drove away from the door of the chamber all the hordes of goblins, ogres, and so on, who were besieging it, and they took up the protection of the Bodhisatta as far as the world-sphere.

original: Kimatthāya panāyaṃ rakkhā? Nanu paṭisandhikkhaṇe kalalakālato paṭṭhāya sacepi koṭisatasahassamārā
analyzed: kim atthāya pana ayam rakkhā nanu paṭisandhi kkhaṇe kalala kālataḥ paṭṭhāya sace pi koṭi sata sahassa mārā
translated: But for what purpose is this protection? Is it not the case that even if a hundred thousand koṭis of Māras

original: koṭisatasahassasineruṃ ukkhipitvā bodhisattassa vā bodhisattamātuyā vā antarāyakaraṇatthaṃ
analyzed: koṭi sata sahassa sinerum ukkhipitvā bodhisattassa vā bodhisatta mātuyāḥ vā antarāya karaṇa ttham
translated: were to take up a hundred thousand koṭis of Sinerus and hurl them at the Bodhisatta or the Bodhisatta’s mother in order to create an obstacle,

original: āgaccheyyuṃ, sabbe antarāva antaradhāyeyyuṃ. Vuttampi cetaṃ bhagavatā ruhiruppādavatthusmiṃ
analyzed: āgaccheyyum sabbe antarā ava antaradhāyeyyum vuttam pi ca itam bhagavatā ruhira uppāda vatthusmiṃ
translated: and all of them would disappear on the way. And this was said by the Blessed One in the Ruhiṇṇupādavatthu:

original: – “aṭṭhānametaṃ, bhikkhave, anavakāso, yaṃ parupakkamena tathāgataṃ jīvitā voropeyya.
analyzed: aṭṭhānam etam bhikkhave anavakāsaḥ yam parupakkamena tathāgatam jīvitā voropeyya
translated: “It is impossible, monks, it cannot come to pass, that a Tathāgata should be slain by another.

original: Anupakkamena, bhikkhave, tathāgatā parinibbāyanti. Gacchatha, tumhe bhikkhave, yathāvihāraṃ,
analyzed: an upakkamena bhikkhave tathāgatāḥ parinibbāyanti gacchatha tumhe bhikkhave yathāvihāram
translated: Monks, Tathāgatas attain final Nibbāna without anything left over. Go, monks, to your own dwellings,

original: arakkhiyā, bhikkhave tathāgatā”ti. Evameva, tena parupakkamena na tesaṃ jīvitantarāyo🔽atthi, santi kho pana amanussā virūpā duddasikā bheravarūpā migapakkhino, yesaṃ rūpaṃ
analyzed: arakkhiyāḥ bhikkhave tathāgatā ti evam eva tena paru pakkamena na tesam jīvita antarāyaḥ  atthi santi kho pana amanussā virūpāḥ duddasikāḥ bherava rūpāḥ miga pakkhino yesam rūpam
translated: Tathāgatas are not to be guarded.” So, in the same way, there was no danger to the Bodhisatta’s life from that quarter.

original: vā disvā saddaṃ vā sutvā bodhisattamātu bhayaṃ vā santāso vā uppajjeyya, tesaṃ nivāraṇatthāya
analyzed: vā disvā saddam vā sutvā bodhisatta mātu bhayam vā santāsaḥ vā uppajjeyya tesam nivāraṇa atthāya
translated: But there were certain non-human beings, ugly and repulsive, with terrifying forms, who were beasts of prey and birds, and if they saw the Bodhisatta’s mother or heard her voice,🔽she might become frightened or terrified. So they took up a guard for the purpose of preventing this.

original: rakkhaṃ aggahesuṃ. Apica bodhisattassa puññatejena sañjātagāravā attano gāravacoditāpi te evamakaṃsu.
analyzed: rakkham aggahesum apica bodhisattassa puñña tejena sañjāta gāravāḥ attanaḥ gārava coditā api te evam akaṃsu
translated: Moreover, out of respect for the Bodhisatta’s merit, they did this out of their own respect for him.

original: Kiṃ pana te antogabbhaṃ pavisitvā ṭhitā cattāro mahārājāno bodhisattassa mātuyā attānaṃ🔽dassenti, na dassentīti? Nahānamaṇḍanabhojanādisarīrakiccakāle na dassenti, sirigabbhaṃ
analyzed: kim pana te antogabbham pavisitvā ṭhitā cattāraḥ mahā rājānaḥ bodhisattassa mātuyā attānam  dassenti na dassenti iti na hāna maṇḍana bhojana ādi sarīra kicca kāle na dassenti sirigabbham
translated: But did the Four Great Kings, who were standing within the mother’s womb,

original: pavisitvā varasayane nipannakāle pana dassenti. Tattha kiñcāpi amanussadassanaṃ nāma
analyzed: pavisitvā vara sayane nipanna kāle pana dassenti tattha kiñcā api amanussadassanam nāma
translated: show themselves to the mother or not? They did not show themselves at the time of bathing, adorning, and feeding the mother, and at the time of other bodily activities. But they did show themselves when the mother entered the bedchamber and lay down on the excellent couch.

original: manussānaṃ sappaṭibhayaṃ hoti, bodhisattassa mātā pana attano ceva puttassa ca puññānubhāvena
analyzed: manussānam sa paṭibhayam hoti bodhisattassa mātā pana attano ca iva puttassa ca puñña anubhāvena
translated: Now although it is a frightening thing for human beings to see non-human beings, the mother of the Bodhisatta,

original: te disvā na bhāyati, pakatiantepurapālakesu viya assā etesu cittaṃ uppajjati.
analyzed: te disvā na bhāyati pakati antepura pālakesu viya assā etesu cittam uppajjati
translated: through the power of her own and her son’s merit, was not afraid when she saw them. Her mind became as calm as if she were in the presence of her own attendants.

original: 20. Pakatiyā sīlavatīti sabhāveneva sīlasampannā. Anuppanne kira buddhe manussā tāpasaparibbājakānaṃ
analyzed: pakatiyā sīlavatī iti sabhāvena iva sīla sampannā anuppanne kira buddhe manussā tāpasa paribbājakānam
translated: Naturally virtuous: she was naturally endowed with virtue. Before the Buddha had appeared, people used to take the precepts from ascetics and wanderers,

original: santike vanditvā ukkuṭikaṃ nisīditvā sīlaṃ gaṇhanti. Bodhisattamātāpi kāladevilassa
analyzed: santike vanditvā ukkuṭikam nisīditvā sīlam gaṇhanti bodhisatta mātā api kāladevilassa
translated: sitting in the posture of devotion and paying homage. The mother of the Bodhisatta took the precepts from the ascetic Kalakhemaka.

original: isino santike sīlaṃ gaṇhāti. Bodhisatte pana kucchigate aññassa pādamūle nisīdituṃ
analyzed: isinoḥ santike sīlam gaṇhāti bodhisatte pana kucchi gate aññassa pāda mūle nisīditum
translated: But when the Bodhisatta was in her womb, she would not sit at the feet of anyone else.

original: nāma na sakkā, samānāsane nisīditvā gahitasīlampi āvajjanakaraṇamattaṃ hoti. Tasmā
analyzed: nāma na sakkā samāna āsane nisīditvā gahita sīlam pi āvajjana karaṇam attam hoti tasmā
translated: It is not possible to do so. Even if one were to take up the precepts after sitting down in the same seat, it would be merely a matter of bringing to mind the precepts. Therefore

original: sayameva sīlaṃ aggahesīti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: sayam eva sīlam aggahesi iti vuttam hoti
translated: it is said that she herself took up the precepts.

original: 21. Purisesūti bodhisattassa pitaraṃ ādiṃ katvā kesuci manussesu purisādhippāyacittaṃ
analyzed: purisesu uti bodhisattassa pitaram ādim katvā kesuci manussesu purisa adhippāya cittam
translated: . Among men: in some men, beginning with the Bodhisatta’s father, a lustful thought arose

original: nuppajjati. Bodhisattamāturūpaṃ pana kusalā sippikā potthakammādīsupi kātuṃ na sakkonti.
analyzed: nuppajjati bodhisatta mātu rūpam pana kusalā sippikā pottha kamma ādīsu pi kātum na sakkonti
translated: with regard to the Bodhisatta’s mother. But skilled craftsmen are unable to make an image of the Bodhisatta’s mother even in cloth or in wood, etc.

original: Taṃ disvā purisassa rāgo nuppajjatīti na sakkā vattuṃ, sace pana taṃ rattacitto upasaṅkamitukāmo
analyzed: tam disvā purisassa rāgaḥ nuppajjati iti na sakkā vattum sace pana tam ratta cittaḥ upasaṅkamitu kāmo
translated: Seeing her, it cannot be said that lust does not arise in a man. But if a lustful man should wish to approach her,

original: hoti, pādā na vahanti, dibbasaṅkhalikā viya bajjhanti. Tasmā “anatikkamanīyā”tiādi vuttaṃ.🔽22. Pañcannaṃ kāmaguṇānanti pubbe kāmaguṇūpasañhitanti iminā purisādhippāyavasena
analyzed: hoti pādāḥ na vahanti dibba saṅkhalikāḥ viya bajjhanti tasmā an atikkamanīyā atiādi vuttam  pañcannam kāmaguṇānam ti pubbe kāma guṇa upasañhitanti iminā purisa adhippāya vasena
translated: his feet do not carry him; they are as if fettered with divine fetters. Therefore it is said, “incapable of being transgressed,” etc.

original: vatthupaṭikkhepo kato, idha ārammaṇappaṭilābho dassito. Tadā kira deviyā evarūpo
analyzed: vatthu paṭikkhepo kataḥ idha ārammaṇa ppaṭilābhaḥ dassito tadā kira deviyā evarūpaḥ
translated: . The five cords of sense desire: by the words “associated with the five cords of sense desire” above, the rejection of the object by way of the man’s lustful thought is shown; here the obtaining of the object is shown. At that time, it seems, the queen

original: putto kucchiṃ upapannoti sutvā samantato rājāno mahagghaābharaṇatūriyādivasena pañcadvārārammaṇavatthubhūtaṃ
analyzed: putto kucchim upapanno ti sutvā samantataḥ rājānaḥ mahaggha ābharaṇa tūriya ādi vasena pañca dvāra ārammaṇa vatthu bhūtam
translated: When it was reported that the child had entered the womb, kings from all quarters sent as gifts🔽jewels and precious stones, musical instruments, etc., which became the objects of the five sense-desires at the four gates of the palace.

original: paṇṇākāraṃ pesenti. Bodhisattassa ca bodhisattamātu ca katakammassa ussannattā lābhasakkārassa
analyzed: paṇṇa ākāram pesenti bodhisattassa ca bodhisatta mātu ca kata kammassa ussanna ttā lābha sakkārassa
translated: Because of the excellence of the Bodhisatta’s and the Bodhisatta-mother’s karma,

original: pamāṇaparicchedo natthi.
analyzed: pamāṇa paricchedaḥ na atthi
translated: there was no limit to the gifts they received.

original: 23. Akilantakāyāti yathā aññā itthiyo gabbhabhārena kilamanti hatthapādā uddhumātatādīni
analyzed: a kilantakāya iti yathā aññāḥ itthiyaḥ gabbha bhārena kilamanti hattha pādāḥ uddhumātata ādīni
translated: Her body was not fatigued: unlike other women, whose bodies become fatigued by the burden of pregnancy, and whose hands and feet become swollen,

original: pāpuṇanti, evaṃ tassā koci kilamatho nāhosi. Tirokucchigatanti antokucchigataṃ. Passatīti
analyzed: pāpuṇanti evam tassā koci kilamatho tiro kucchi gatanti antar kucchi gatam passati iti
translated: she had no fatigue at all. She was in her womb: she was in her belly. She saw: she saw the child in her womb,

original: kalalādikālaṃ atikkamitvā sañjātaaṅgapaccaṅgaahīnindriyabhāvaṃ upagataṃyeva passati.
analyzed: kalala ādi kālam atikkamitvā sañjāta aṅga paccaṅga ahīn indriya bhāvam upagatam yeva passati
translated: after it had passed the stages of kalala, etc., and had acquired the complete set of limbs and faculties.

original: Kimatthaṃ passati? Sukhavāsatthaṃyeva. Yatheva hi mātā puttena saddhiṃ nipannā vā
analyzed: kimattham passati sukha vāsa ttham yā iva yathā iva hi mātā puttena saddhim nipannā vā
translated: Why did she see it? For the sake of comfort. For just as a mother, whether sitting or lying down,

original: nisinnā vā – “hatthaṃ vāssa pādaṃ vā olambantaṃ ukkhipitvā saṇṭhapessāmī”ti sukhavāsatthaṃ
analyzed: nisinnā vā hattham vā assa pādam vā olambantam ukkhipitvā saṇṭhapessāmi iti sukha vāsattham
translated: thinks: “I will lift up his hand or foot, which is hanging down, and place it comfortably,”

original: puttaṃ oloketi, evaṃ bodhisattamātāpi yaṃ taṃ mātu uṭṭhānagamanaparivattananisajjādīsu
analyzed: puttam oloketi evam bodhisatta mātā api yam tam mātu uṭṭhāna gamana parivattana nisajja ādīsu
translated: When a mother has to get up and move about, turn over, sit down, etc.,

original: uṇhasītaloṇikatittakakaṭukāhāraajjhoharaṇakālesu ca gabbhassa dukkhaṃ uppajjati,
analyzed: uṇha sīta loṇika tittaka kaṭuka āhāra ajjhoharaṇa kālesu ca gabbhassa dukkham uppajjati
translated: and when she has to take hot or cold, salty or sour food, she suffers pain in the womb.

original: “atthi nu kho me taṃ puttassā”ti sukhavāsatthaṃ olokayamānā pallaṅkaṃ ābhujitvā nisinnaṃ
analyzed: atthi nu kho me tam puttassa ati sukha vāsattham olokayamānā pallaṅkam ābhujitvā nisinnam
translated: “Is there any of that in my son’s womb?” she asks, and looking for his comfort she sits down cross-legged.🔽She sees the Bodhisatta sitting cross-legged.

original: bodhisattaṃ passati. Yathā hi aññe antokucchigatā pakkāsayaṃ avattharitvā āmāsayaṃ
analyzed: bodhisattam passati yathā hi aññe antokucchi gatāḥ pakkāsayam avattharitvā āmāsayam
translated: For others in the womb, after the faeces and urine have fallen into the receptacle for urine,🔽they are lifted up into the receptacle for digested food,

original: ukkhipitvā udarapaṭalaṃ piṭṭhito katvā piṭṭhikaṇḍakaṃ nissāya ukkuṭikaṃ dvīsu muṭṭhīsu
analyzed: ukkhipitvā udara paṭalam piṭṭhitaḥ katvā piṭṭhi kaṇḍakam nissāya ukkuṭikam dvīsu muṭṭhīsu
translated: the belly-membrane is made into a back-rest, and they sit cross-legged leaning on the backbone,

original: hanukaṃ ṭhapetvā deve vassante rukkhasusire makkaṭā viya nisīdanti, na evaṃ bodhisatto,
analyzed: hanukam ṭhapetvā deve vassante rukkha susire makkaṭāḥ viya nisīdanti na evam bodhisatto
translated: with their chins resting on their two fists, like monkeys in a hollow tree when it rains. But not so the Bodhisatta.

original: bodhisatto pana piṭṭhikaṇḍakaṃ piṭṭhito katvā dhammāsane dhammakathiko viya pallaṅkaṃ
analyzed: bodhisatto pana piṭṭhi kaṇḍakam piṭṭhitaḥ katvā dhamma āsane dhamma kathikaḥ viya pallaṅkam
translated: The Bodhisatta makes the backbone his back-rest, and sits cross-legged like a preacher of Dhamma on a Dhamma seat,

original: ābhujitvā puratthābhimukho nisīdati. Pubbekatakammaṃ panassā vatthuṃ sodheti, suddhe
analyzed: ābhujitvā purattha abhimukhaḥ nisīdati pubbekata kammam panassā vatthum sodheti suddhe
translated: facing east. But first he cleans the place where he is going to sit,

original: vatthumhi sukhumacchavilakkhaṇaṃ nibbattati. Atha naṃ kucchitaco paṭicchādetuṃ na
analyzed: vatthumhi sukhuma chavi lakkhaṇam nibbattati atha nam kucchi tacaḥ paṭicchādetum na
translated: and the sign of the child’s delicate skin and complexion appears on the surface of the womb. Then the womb, being unable to conceal it,

original: sakkoti, olokentiyā bahiṭhito viya paññāyati. Tamatthaṃ upamāya vibhāvento bhagavā
analyzed: olokentiyā bahi ṭhitaḥ viya paññāyati tam attham upamāya vibhāventaḥ bhagavā
translated: appears as if it were split open. Explaining this matter by means of a simile, the Blessed One said:

original: seyyathāpītiādimāha. Bodhisatto pana antokucchigato mātaraṃ na passati. Na hi antokucchiyaṃ
analyzed: sā iyyathā api iti ādim āha bodhisatto pana antokucchi gataḥ mātaram na passati na hi antokucchiyam
translated: “Just as if a stout, strong, and clever fletcher were to prepare a shaft with a smooth shaft-socket,

original: cakkhuviññāṇaṃ uppajjati.🔽24. Kālaṅkarotīti na vijātabhāvapaccayā, āyuparikkhayeneva. Bodhisattena vasitaṭṭhānañhi🔽cetiyakuṭisadisaṃ hoti, aññesaṃ aparibhogārahaṃ, na ca sakkā bodhisattamātaraṃ apanetvā
analyzed: cakkhu viññāṇam uppajjati  kālaṅkaroti iti na vijāta bhāva paccayāḥ āyu parikkhayena iva bodhisattena vasita ṭṭhānam hi  cetiya kuṭi sadisam hoti aññesam a paribhoga araham na ca sakkā bodhisatta mātaram apanetvā
translated: and were to place it in a trough of oil,🔽and were to take a fine tuft of cotton wool in his left hand, and were to take a knife in his right hand, and were to say: ‘I shall cut this tuft of cotton wool and lower it into the trough of oil without letting it touch the sides of the trough,’ so too, bhikkhus, the mother’s womb is like the trough of oil,🔽and the sign of the child’s delicate skin and complexion is like the tuft of cotton wool.🔽But the Bodhisatta in the womb does not see his mother. For eye-consciousness does not arise in the womb.

original: aññaṃ aggamahesiṭṭhāne ṭhapetunti tattakaṃyeva bodhisattamātu āyuppamāṇaṃ hoti, tasmā
analyzed: aññam agga mahesi ṭṭhāne ṭhapetunti tattakam yeva bodhisatta mātu āyu ppamāṇam hoti tasmā
translated: “Dies” : not because of the condition of being born, but only because of the exhaustion of the life-span. For the place where the Bodhisatta dwells is like a shrine-room, not fit to be used by others, and it is not possible to set up another chief queen in the place of the Bodhisatta’s mother. Thus the life-span of the Bodhisatta’s mother is just that much,

original: tadā kālaṅkaroti. Katarasmiṃ pana vaye kālaṃ karotīti? Majjhimavaye. Paṭhamavayasmiñhi
analyzed: tadā kālaṅkaroti katarasmin pana vaye kālam karoti iti majjhima vaye paṭhama vayasmin hi
translated: and therefore she dies at that time. But in what age does she die? In the middle age. For in the first age

original: sattānaṃ attabhāve chandarāgo balavā hoti, tena tadā sañjātagabbhā itthī gabbhaṃ
analyzed: sattānam atta bhāve chanda rāgaḥ balavā hoti tena tadā sañjāta gabbhā itthī gabbham
translated: The desire and lust for the individual form of beings is strong, and so a woman who has conceived at that time is unable to keep the child in her womb.

original: anurakkhituṃ na sakkoti, gabbho bahvābādho hoti. Majjhimavayassa pana dve koṭṭhāse🔽atikkamma tatiye koṭṭhāse vatthu visadaṃ hoti, visade vatthumhi nibbattadārakā arogā🔽honti, tasmā bodhisattamātāpi paṭhamavaye sampattiṃ anubhavitvā majjhimavayassa tatiye
analyzed: anurakkhitum na sakkoti gabbhaḥ bahu ābādhaḥ hoti majjhimavayassa pana dve koṭṭhāse  atikkamma tatiye koṭṭhāse vatthu visadam hoti visade vatthumhi nibbatta dārakāḥ arogāḥ  honti tasmai bodhisatta mātā api paṭhama vaye sampattim anubhavitvā majjhima vayassa tatiye
translated: The child is afflicted with many illnesses. But after the middle period of the second month has passed,

original: koṭṭhāse vijāyitvā kālaṃ karotīti ayamettha dhammatā.🔽25. Nava vā dasa vāti ettha vā saddassa vikappanavasena satta vā aṭṭha vā ekādasa🔽vā dvādasa vāti evamādīnaṃ saṅgaho veditabbo. Tattha sattamāsajāto jīvati, sītuṇhakkhamo
analyzed: koṭṭhāse vijāyitvā kālam karoti iti ayam ettha dhamma tā  nava vā dasa vā ti ettha vā saddassa vikappana vasena satta vā aṭṭha vā ekādasa  vā dvādasa vā ati evamādīnam saṅgahaḥ veditabbo tattha satta māsa jātaḥ jīvati sītuṇha khamaḥ
translated: the womb becomes clear, and the child born in a clear womb is healthy. Therefore it is the rule that the Bodhisatta’s mother, having experienced well-being in the first period, gives birth in the third period of the second month and dies.

original: pana na hoti. Aṭṭhamāsajāto na jīvati, avasesā jīvanti.
analyzed: pana na hoti aṭṭha māsa jātaḥ na jīvati avasesā jīvanti
translated: Nine or ten months: here the word “or” should be understood as inclusive, so that the number of months is seven, eight, eleven, or twelve. Of these, one born after seven months lives, but is not able to bear cold and heat. One born after eight months does not live. The rest live.

original: 27. Devā paṭhamaṃ paṭiggaṇhantīti khīṇāsavā suddhāvāsabrahmāno paṭiggaṇhanti. Kathaṃ
analyzed: devā paṭhamam paṭiggaṇhanti iti khīṇa āsavā suddhāvāsa brahmāno paṭiggaṇhanti katham
translated: The gods receive it first: the gods of the Pure Abodes who are free from lust receive it first.

original: paṭiggaṇhanti? “Sūtivesaṃ gaṇhitvā”ti eke. Taṃ pana paṭikkhipitvā idaṃ vuttaṃ – ‘tadā🔽bodhisattamātā suvaṇṇakhacitaṃ vatthaṃ nivāsetvā macchakkhisadisaṃ dukūlapaṭaṃ yāva🔽pādantā pārupitvā aṭṭhāsi. Athassā sallahukagabbhavuṭṭhānaṃ ahosi, dhamakaraṇato🔽udakanikkhamanasadisaṃ. Atha te pakatibrahmaveseneva upasaṅkamitvā paṭhamaṃ suvaṇṇajālena
analyzed: paṭiggaṇhanti sūtivesam gaṇhitvā ati eke tam pana paṭikkhipitvā idam vuttam tadā  bodhisatta mātā suvaṇṇa khacitam vattham nivāsetvā mad śakkhi sadisam dukūla paṭam yāva  pādantā pārupitvā aṭṭhāsi athassā sallahuka gabbha vuṭṭhānam ahosi dhama karaṇato  udaka nikkhamana sadisam atha te pakati brahmavesena iva upasaṅkamitvā paṭhamam suvaṇṇa jālena
translated: Do they receive it? Some say: “They receive it in the form of a cloth.” But that is rejected. This is said:🔽At that time the Bodhisatta’s mother put on a golden-embroidered cloth, and she put on a silk shawl like a peacock’s🔽tail, and she stood there. Then it was as easy for her to give birth as it is to pour oil from one vessel into another.🔽Then they approached in the form of ordinary brahmans and first covered him with a golden net.

original: paṭiggahesuṃ. Tesaṃ hatthato cattāro mahārājāno ajinappaveṇiyā paṭiggahesuṃ. Tato🔽manussā dukūlacumbaṭakena paṭiggahesuṃ’. Tena vuttaṃ – “devā paṭhamaṃ paṭiggaṇhanti, pacchā manussā”ti.
analyzed: paṭiggahesum tesam hatthataḥ cattāraḥ mahā rājānaḥ ajinappaveṇiyā paṭiggahesum tatas  manussā dukūla cumbaṭakena paṭiggahesum tena vuttam devā paṭhamam paṭiggaṇhanti pacchā manussā ti
translated: Do the gods receive it? Some say that they do so in the guise of Sūtras. But this is rejected. It is said that the Bodhisatta’s mother put on a golden robe and covered herself with a fine cloth like a piece of fish-net, down to her feet. Then she stood up. Her delivery was easy, like the coming out of water from a water-jar. Then the gods came to her in their normal divine form and first received the child in a golden net. From their hands the Four Great Kings received it in a piece of deerskin. Then the men received it in a fine cloth. That is why it is said that the gods receive it first and then the men.

original: 28. Cattāro naṃ devaputtāti cattāro mahārājāno. Paṭiggahetvāti ajinappaveṇiyā paṭiggahetvā. Mahesakkhoti mahātejo mahāyaso lakkhaṇasampanno.
analyzed: cattāraḥ nam deva puttā ti cattāraḥ mahā rājānaḥ paṭiggahetvā ati ajinappaveṇiyā paṭiggahetvā mahesakkhaḥ iti mahā tejaḥ mahā yasaḥ lakkhaṇa sampanno
translated: The four gods, etc. The four Great Kings. Having received it, etc. Having received it in the piece of deerskin. The Great Being, etc. The Great Being, endowed with the major characteristics, of great splendour and fame.

original: 29. Visadova nikkhamatīti yathā aññe sattā yonimagge laggantā bhaggavibhaggā nikkhamanti,🔽na evaṃ nikkhamati, alaggo hutvā nikkhamatīti attho udenāti udakena. Kenaci asucināti🔽yathā aññe sattā kammajavātehi uddhaṃpādā adhosirā yonimagge pakkhittā sataporisaṃ🔽narakapapātaṃ patantā viya, tāḷacchiddena nikkaḍḍhiyamānā hatthī viya mahādukkhaṃ🔽anubhavantā nānāasucimakkhitāva nikkhamanti, na evaṃ bodhisatto. Bodhisattañhi kammajavātā
analyzed: visadaḥ uva nikkhamati iti yathā aññe sattāḥ yonimagge laggantāḥ bhagga vibhaggāḥ nikkhamanti  na evam nikkhamati alaggaḥ hutvā nikkhamati iti attho udena ati udakena kenaci asucinā ati  yathā aññe sattā kamma ja vātehi uddhaṃpādāḥ adhosirāḥ yonimagge pakkhittā sata porisam  naraka papātam patantā viya tāḷa chiddena nikkaḍḍhiyamānāḥ hatthī viya mahā dukkham  anubhavantā nānā asuci makkhitā ava nikkhamanti na evam bodhisattaḥ bodhisattam hi kamma ja vātā
translated: 29. He comes forth unsoiled: other beings come forth from the womb or from the egg smeared with feces and urine, their bodies broken and battered,

original: uddhapādaṃ adhosiraṃ kātuṃ na sakkonti. So dhammāsanato otaranto dhammakathiko viya,🔽nisseṇito otaranto puriso viya ca dve hatthe ca dve pāde ca pasāretvā ṭhitakova mātukucchisambhavena🔽kenaci asucinā amakkhitova nikkhamati.

original: 31. Sampatijātoti muhuttajāto. Pāḷiyaṃ pana mātukucchito nikkhantamatto viya dassito,
analyzed: sampati jātaḥ ti muhutta jātaḥ pāḷiyam pana mātu kucchitaḥ nikkhanta mattaḥ viya dassitaḥ
translated: ‘As soon as he is born’: as soon as he has been born. But in the text he is shown as if he were just coming out of his mother’s womb.

original: na evaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Nikkhantamattañhi naṃ paṭhamaṃ brahmāno suvaṇṇajālena paṭiggaṇhiṃsu,
analyzed: na evam daṭṭhabbam nikkhanta mattam hi nam paṭhamam brahmānaḥ suvaṇṇa jālena paṭiggaṇhiṃsu
translated: He should not be so regarded. For as soon as he was born, the Brahmās first received him in a gold net-work,

original: tesaṃ hatthato cattāro mahārājāno ajinappaveṇiyā, tesaṃ hatthato manussā dukūlacumbaṭakena.

translated: and from their hands the Four Great Kings received him in a net-work of silk, and from their hands men received him in a silken shawl.

original: Manussānaṃ hatthato muccitvā pathaviyaṃ patiṭṭhito. Setamhi chatte anudhāriyamāneti
analyzed: manussānam hatthataḥ muccitvā pathaviyam patiṭṭhitaḥ setamhi chatte anudhāriyamāne iti
translated: When he was released from their hands, he stood on the earth. ‘As the white parasol is held aloft’ means

original: dibbasetacchatte anudhāriyamānamhi. Ettha ca chattassa parivārāni khaggādīni pañca
analyzed: dibba seta chatte anudhāriyamānamhi ettha ca chattassa parivārāni khagga ādīni pañca

original: rājakakudhabhaṇḍānipi āgatāneva. Pāḷiyaṃ pana rājagamane rājā viya chattameva vuttaṃ.
analyzed: rāja kakudha bhaṇḍāni api āgatān eva pāḷiyam pana rāja gamane rājā viya chattam eva vuttam
