original: Tesu chattameva paññāyati, na chattaggāhako. Tathā khaggatālavaṇṭamorahatthakavāḷabījanīuṇhīsamattāyeva
analyzed: tesu chattam eva paññāyati na chatta ggāhakaḥ tathā khagga tāla vaṇṭa mora hatthaka vāḷa bījanī uṇhī sa mattāya iva
translated: Only the parasol is seen, not the parasol-bearer. Likewise only the sword, the fan, the elephant goad, the fly whisk, and the royal turban are seen,

original: paññāyanti, na tesaṃ gāhakā. Sabbāni kira tāni adissamānarūpā devatā gaṇhiṃsu. Vuttañcetaṃ –
analyzed: paññāyanti na tesam gāhakā sabbāni kira tāni a dissamāna rūpāḥ devatāḥ gaṇhiṃsu vuttam ca itam
translated: but not their bearers. It is said that all these were held by invisible deities. For this is said:

original: “Anekasākhañca sahassamaṇḍalaṃ,
analyzed: aneka sākham ca sahassa maṇḍalam
translated: “The parasol with its thousand ribs and many a branch,

original: Chattaṃ marū dhārayumantalikkhe;
analyzed: chattam marū dhārayumantalikkhe
translated: The Maruts held aloft in the sky;

original: Suvaṇṇadaṇḍā vipatanti cāmarā,
analyzed: suvaṇṇa daṇḍāḥ vipatanti
translated: The yak-tail fans with their golden handles,

original: Na dissare cāmarachattagāhakā”ti. ;
analyzed: na dissare cāmara chatta gāhakā ati
translated: The bearers of the parasol and the fans were not seen.”

original: Sabbā ca disāti idaṃ sattapadavītihārūpari ṭhitassa viya sabbadisānuvilokanaṃ vuttaṃ,
analyzed: sabbā ca disā ti idam satta padavī tihāru upari ṭhitassa viya sabba disa anuvilokanam vuttam
translated: “All directions”: this refers to the surveying of all directions as if he were standing on the seventh step.🔽But this should not be taken literally. For the Great Being, having escaped from the hands of men,

original: na kho panevaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Mahāsatto hi manussānaṃ hatthato muccitvā paṭhaviyaṃ patiṭṭhito
analyzed: na kho pana evam daṭṭhabbam mahāsattaḥ hi manussānam hatthataḥ muccitvā paṭhaviyam patiṭṭhitaḥ
translated: stood on the ground,

original: puratthimaṃ disaṃ olokesi. Anekāni cakkavāḷasahassāni ekaṅgaṇāni ahesuṃ. Tattha devamanussā
analyzed: puratthimam disam olokesi anekāni cakkavāḷa sahassāni ekaṅgaṇāni ahesum tattha deva manussāḥ
translated: He looked towards the eastern direction. Many thousands of world-spheres became one sphere. There the gods and men

original: gandhamālādīhi pūjayamānā – “mahāpurisa, idha tumhehi sadisopi natthi, kuto uttaritaro”ti
analyzed: gandha mālā ādīhi pūjayamānā mahā purisaḥ idha tumhehi sadisaḥ api natthi kutas
translated: worshipped him with perfumes, garlands, etc., saying: “Great Man, there is no one equal to you, how much less anyone greater!”

original: āhaṃsu. Evaṃ catasso disā, catasso anudisā, heṭṭhā, uparīti dasa disā anuviloketvā
analyzed: evam catasso disā catasso anudisā heṭṭhā upari iti dasa disāḥ anuviloketvā
translated: Thus, after looking around in the ten directions—the four quarters, the four intermediate directions, below, and above—

original: attanā sadisaṃ adisvā – “ayaṃ uttarā disā”ti uttarābhimukho sattapadavītihārena agamāsīti
analyzed: attanā sadisam a disvā ayam uttarā disā ati uttara abhimukhaḥ satta padavī tihārena agamāsi iti
translated: and seeing no one equal to himself, he went forward in a northerly direction, taking seven steps with the thought: “I am the chief in the world, supreme in the world, eldest in the world, the first in the world.”

original: evamettha attho veditabbo. Āsabhinti uttamaṃ. Aggoti guṇehi sabbapaṭhamo. Itarāni
analyzed: evam ettha atthaḥ veditabbaḥ āsabhinti uttamam aggo ti guṇehi sabba paṭhamaḥ itarāni
translated: This is the meaning here. Āsabhi means “supreme.” Agga means “foremost in qualities.” The other two terms

original: dve padāni etasseva vevacanāni. Ayamantimā jāti, natthi dāni punabbhavoti padadvayena
analyzed: dve padāni etassa iva vevacanāni ayam antimā jāti natthi dāni punabbhavaḥ ti pada dvayena
translated: are synonyms for the same meaning. With the two terms “This is my last birth” and “there is now no renewal of existence for me,”

original: imasmiṃ attabhāve pattabbaṃ arahattaṃ byākāsi.
analyzed: imasmin atta bhāve pattabbam arahattam byākāsi
translated: he proclaimed the state of arahantship, which is to be attained in that existence.

original: Ettha ca samehi pādehi pathaviyā patiṭṭhānaṃ caturiddhipādapaṭilābhassa pubbanimittaṃ,
analyzed: ettha ca samehi pādehi pathaviyā patiṭṭhānam catur iddhipāda paṭilābhassa pubba nimittam
translated: And here, the fact that he stood firm on the ground with level feet is a token of his acquisition of the four bases of success (iddhi-pāda).

original: uttarābhimukhabhāvo mahājanaṃ ajjhottharitvā abhibhavitvā gamanassa pubbanimittaṃ,
analyzed: uttara abhimukha bhāvaḥ mahājanam ajjhottharitvā abhibhavitvā gamanassa pubba nimittam
translated: The fact that he was facing north was a premonition of his going forth, overcoming and outshining the great crowd.

original: sattapadagamanaṃ sattabojjhaṅgaratanapaṭilābhassa pubbanimittaṃ, dibbasetacchattadhāraṇaṃ
analyzed: satta pada gamanam satta bojjhaṅga ratana paṭilābhassa pubba nimittam dibba seta chatta dhāraṇam
translated: The seven steps were a premonition of the acquisition of the seven gems of the enlightenment factors.🔽The holding up of the white parasol by the gods was a premonition of the acquisition of the supreme freedom-umbrella.

original: vimuttivarachattapaṭilābhassa pubbanimittaṃ, pañcarājakakudhabhaṇḍānaṃ paṭilābho🔽pañcahi vimuttīhi vimuccanassa pubbanimittaṃ, sabbadisānuvilokanaṃ anāvaraṇañāṇapaṭilābhassa
analyzed: vimuttivara chatta paṭilābhassa pubba nimittam pañca rāja kakudha bhaṇḍānam paṭilābhaḥ  pañcahi vimuttīhi vimuccanassa pubba nimittam sabba disā anuvilokanam anāvaraṇa ñāṇa paṭilābhassa
translated: The acquisition of the five royal treasures was a premonition of his being freed by the five freedoms.🔽The surveying of the directions was a premonition of the acquisition of unobstructed knowledge.

original: pubbanimittaṃ, āsabhivācābhāsanaṃ appaṭivattiyadhammacakkappavattanassa pubbanimittaṃ,
analyzed: pubba nimittam āsa abhivācā bhāsanam appaṭivattiya dhamma cakka ppavattanassa pubba nimittam
translated: The utterance of the lion’s roar was a premonition of the setting in motion of the wheel of the Dhamma, which cannot be rolled back.

original: “ayamantimā jātī”ti sīhanādo anupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā parinibbānassa pubbanimittanti
analyzed: ayam antimā jātī iti sīhanādaḥ anupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā parinibbānassa pubba nimittanti
translated: The utterance of the lion’s roar, “This is my last birth,” was a premonition of his final Nibbāna in the element of Nibbāna that is without residue of clinging.

original: veditabbaṃ. Ime vārā pāḷiyaṃ āgatā, sambahulavāro pana nāgato, āharitvā dīpetabbo.
analyzed: veditabbam ime vārāḥ pāḷiyam āgatā sambahula vāraḥ pana na āgataḥ āharitvā dīpetabbaḥ
translated: These are the verses given in the text. But there is also a section on the many kinds of premonitions, which should be brought in and expounded.

original: Mahāpurisassa hi jātadivase dasasahassilokadhātu kampi. Dasasahassilokadhātumhi devatā
analyzed: mahā purisassa hi jāta divase dasa sahassi lokadhātu dasa sahassi lokadhātumhi devatā
translated: For when the Great Man was born, the ten-thousandfold world system shook. The deities of the ten-thousandfold world system

original: ekacakkavāḷe sannipatiṃsu. Paṭhamaṃ devā paṭiggaṇhiṃsu, pacchā manussā. Tantibaddhā🔽vīṇā cammabaddhā bheriyo ca kenaci avāditā sayameva vajjiṃsu. Manussānaṃ andubandhanādīni
analyzed: eka cakkavāḷe sannipatiṃsu paṭhamam devā paṭiggaṇhiṃsu pacchā manussā tanti baddhā  vīṇā camma baddhā bheriyaḥ ca kenacid a vāditā sayam eva vajjiṃsu manussānam andu bandhana ādīni
translated: and assembled in one world-sphere. First the gods accepted it, afterwards men.🔽The lute-strings, the drum-skins, and so on, without anyone playing them, sounded of themselves. Men’s bonds on their feet and so on

original: khaṇḍākhaṇḍaṃ chijjiṃsu. Sabbarogā vūpasamiṃsu, ambilena dhotatambamalaṃ viya vigacchiṃsu.
analyzed: khaṇḍākhaṇḍam chijjiṃsu sabba rogāḥ vūpasamiṃsu ambilena dhota tamba malam viya vigacchiṃsu
translated: broke to pieces. All diseases disappeared, as if washed away by a rain of acid.

original: Jaccandhā rūpāni passiṃsu. Jaccabadhirā saddaṃ suṇiṃsu. Pīṭhasappī javasampannā ahesuṃ.
analyzed: rūpāni saddam suṇiṃsu pīṭhasappī java sampannāḥ ahesuṃ
translated: The blind saw forms, the deaf heard sounds, the lame became endowed with speed.

original: Jātijaḷānampi eḷamūgānaṃ sati patiṭṭhāsi. Videsapakkhandā nāvā supaṭṭanaṃ pāpuṇiṃsu.
analyzed: jāti jaḷānam pi eḷamūgānam sati videsa pakkhandāḥ nāvā su paṭṭanam pāpuṇiṃsu
translated: Even the dumb and the witless became possessed of mindfulness. Ships that had been wrecked reached land.

original: Ākāsaṭṭhakabhūmaṭṭhakaratanāni sakatejobhāsitāni ahesuṃ. Verino mettacittaṃ paṭilabhiṃsu.
analyzed: ākāsa aṭṭhaka bhūmaṭṭhaka ratanāni saka tejaḥ bhāsitāni ahesum verinaḥ metta cittam paṭilabhiṃsu
translated: The treasures in the sky and on the earth shone with their own radiance. The malevolent obtained a mind of loving-kindness.

original: Avīcimhi aggi nibbāyi. Lokantaresu āloko udapādi. Nadīsu jalaṃ nappavattati. Mahāsamudde
analyzed: avīcimhi aggi nibbāyi lokantaresu ālokaḥ udapādi nadīsu jalam na pavattati mahā samudde
translated: The fire in Avīci Hell went out. Light appeared in the world-interspaces. The water in the rivers did not flow. The great ocean

original: madhurasaṃ udakaṃ ahosi. Vāto na vāyi. Ākāsapabbatarukkhagatā sakuṇā bhassitvā pathavigatā
analyzed: madhu rasam udakam ahosi vātaḥ na vāyi ākāsa pabbata rukkha gatā sakuṇāḥ bhassitvā pathavi gatā
translated: and the water became sweet. The wind did not blow, and birds that were in the sky, on the mountains, and in the trees, came down to the ground

original: ahesuṃ. Cando ativiroci. Sūriyo na uṇho, na sītalo, nimmalo utusampanno ahosi. Devatā
analyzed: ahesum candaḥ ativiroci sūriyaḥ naḥ uṇhaḥ na sītalaḥ nimmalaḥ utu sampannaḥ ahosi devatā
translated: and spoke. The moon shone brightly, the sun was neither hot nor cold, and it was clear and in season. The gods

original: attano attano vimānadvāre ṭhatvā apphoṭanaseḷanacelukkhepādīhi mahākīḷakaṃ kīḷiṃsu.
analyzed: attanaḥ attanaḥ vimāna dvāre ṭhatvā apphoṭana seḷana celu khepa ādīhi mahā kīḷakam kīḷiṃsu
translated: stood at the doors of their own palaces and played a great game with clapping, snapping, and throwing their garments about.

original: Cātuddīpikamahāmegho vassi. Mahājanaṃ neva khudā na pipāsā pīḷesi. Dvārakavāṭāni
analyzed: cātuddīpika mahā meghaḥ mahā janam na iva khudā na pipāsā pīḍesi dvāra kavāṭāni
translated: A great rain fell from the four quarters of the world. The great people were not afflicted by hunger or thirst. The doors of the city gates

original: sayameva vivariṃsu. Pupphūpagaphalūpagā rukkhā pupphaphalāni gaṇhiṃsu. Dasasahassilokadhātu
analyzed: sayam eva vivariṃsu puppha upaga phala upagāḥ rukkhāḥ puppha phalāni gaṇhiṃsu dasa sahassi lokadhātu
translated: opened by themselves. The trees that were planted with flowers and fruits bore flowers and fruits. The world system of a thousand million worlds

original: ekaddhajamālā ahosi.
analyzed: ekaddha ja mālā ahosi
translated: became a garland of flags.

original: Tatrāpi dasasahassilokadhātukampo sabbaññutaññāṇapaṭilābhassa pubbanimittaṃ. Devatānaṃ
analyzed: tatra api dasa sahassi lokadhātu kampaḥ sabbaññuta ññāṇa paṭilābhassa pubba nimittam devatānam
translated: And the trembling of the world system of a thousand million worlds was a sign that the knowledge of omniscience would be attained. The gods

original: ekacakkavāḷe sannipāto dhammacakkappavattanakāle ekappahāreneva sannipatitvā dhammaṃ
analyzed: eka cakkavāḷe sannipātaḥ dhamma cakka ppavattana kāle eka ppahārena iva sannipatitvā dhammaṃ
translated: gathered in one world-sphere, and at the time of the setting in motion of the Wheel of the Dhamma, they assembled in one place and listened to the Dhamma.

original: paṭiggaṇhanassa pubbanimittaṃ. Paṭhamaṃ devatānaṃ paṭiggahaṇaṃ catunnaṃ rūpāvacarajjhānānaṃ
analyzed: paṭiggaṇhanassa pubba nimittam paṭhamam devatānam paṭiggahaṇam catunnam rūpāvacara jhānānam
translated: is the premonition of the acceptance of the offering. The acceptance of the offering by the deities first is the premonition of the acquisition of the four jhānas of the form-world.

original: paṭilābhassa pubbanimittaṃ. Pacchā manussānaṃ paṭiggahaṇaṃ catunnaṃ arūpāvacarajjhānānaṃ
analyzed: paṭilābhassa pubba nimittam pacchā manussānam paṭiggahaṇam catunnam arūpāvacara jhānānam
translated: The acceptance of the offering by human beings afterwards is the premonition of the acquisition of the four jhānas of the formless world.

original: paṭilābhassa pubbanimittaṃ. Tantibaddhavīṇānaṃ sayaṃ vajjanaṃ anupubbavihārapaṭilābhassa
analyzed: paṭilābhassa pubba nimittam tanti baddha vīṇānam sayam vajjanam anupubba vihāra paṭilābhassa
translated: The playing of the lute by Tantibaddha is the premonition of the acquisition of the successive abidings.

original: pubbanimittaṃ. Cammabaddhabherīnaṃ vajjanaṃ mahatiyā dhammabheriyā anussāvanassa🔽pubbanimittaṃ. Andubandhanādīnaṃ chedo asmimānasamucchedassa pubbanimittaṃ. Mahājanassa🔽rogavigamo catusaccapaṭilābhassa pubbanimittaṃ. Jaccandhānaṃ rūpadassanaṃ dibbacakkhupaṭilābhassa
analyzed: pubba nimittam camma baddha bherīnam vajjanam mahatiyā dhamma bheriyā anussāvanassa  pubba nimittam andu bandhana ādīnam chedaḥ asmimāna samucchedassa pubba nimittam mahājanassa  roga vigamaḥ catu sacca paṭilābhassa pubba nimittam rūpa dassanam dibba cakkhu paṭilābhassa
translated: The playing of the drum by Cammabandhana is the premonition of the beating of the great drum of the True Idea.🔽The cutting of the rope by the man with the axe is the premonition of the cutting off of the conceit ‘I am.’ The disappearance of the disease of the great multitude is the premonition of the acquisition of the four paths.

original: pubbanimittaṃ. Badhirānaṃ saddassavanaṃ dibbasotadhātupaṭilābhassa pubbanimittaṃ.
analyzed: pubba nimittam badhirānam sadda ssavanam dibba sota dhātu paṭilābhassa pubba nimittam
translated: The sight of visible objects by the man born blind is the premonition of the acquisition of the divine eye. The hearing of sounds by the man deaf from birth is the premonition of the acquisition of the divine ear element.

original: Pīṭhasappīnaṃ javasampadā caturiddhipādapaṭilābhassa pubbanimittaṃ. Jaḷānaṃ satipatiṭṭhānaṃ🔽catusatipaṭṭhānapaṭilābhassa pubbanimittaṃ. Videsapakkhandanāvānaṃ supaṭṭanasampāpuṇanaṃ
analyzed: pīṭha sappīnam java sampadā catur iddhipāda paṭilābhassa pubba nimittam jaḷānam sati patiṭṭhānam  catusati paṭṭhāna paṭilābhassa pubba nimittam videsa pakkhanda nāvānam su paṭṭana sampāpuṇanam
translated: The plumpness of the seats is a premonition of the acquisition of the four bases of success. The steadiness of the mindfulness of the dull-witted🔽is a premonition of the acquisition of the four foundations of mindfulness. The arrival of those who have been shipwrecked at a good harbor

original: catupaṭisambhidādhigamassa pubbanimittaṃ. Ratanānaṃ sakatejobhāsitattaṃ yaṃ lokassa
analyzed: catu paṭisambhidā adhigamassa pubba nimittam rata nānam saka tejaḥ bhāsi tattam yam lokassa
translated: is a premonition of the acquisition of the four discriminations. The radiance of the gems with their own effulgence is a premonition of the light of the Dhamma

original: dhammobhāsaṃ dassessati, tassa pubbanimittaṃ.
analyzed: dhamma ubhāsam dassessati tassa pubba nimittam
translated: that will be shown to the world.

original: Verīnaṃ mettacittapaṭilābho catubrahmavihārapaṭilābhassa pubbanimittaṃ. Avīcimhi🔽agginibbāyanaṃ ekādasaagginibbāyanassa pubbanimittaṃ. Lokantarikāloko avijjandhakāraṃ🔽vidhamitvā ñāṇālokadassanassa pubbanimittaṃ. Mahāsamuddassa madhuratā nibbānarasena
analyzed: verīnam metta citta paṭilābho catu brahmavihāra paṭilābhassa pubba nimittam avīcimhi  aggi nibbāyanam ekādasa aggi nibbāyanassa pubba nimittam lokantarikā lokaḥ avijjandhakāram  vidhamitvā ñāṇa āloka dassanassa pubba nimittam mahā samuddassa madhura tā nibbāna rasena
translated: The acquisition of a mind of loving-kindness by those who have enemies is a premonition of the acquisition of the four divine abodes. The extinguishing of the fire in Avīci Hell🔽is a premonition of the extinguishing of the eleven fires. The light in the space between the worlds is a premonition of the appearance of the light of knowledge

original: ekarasabhāvassa pubbanimittaṃ. Vātassa avāyanaṃ dvāsaṭṭhidiṭṭhigatabhindanassa pubbanimittaṃ.
analyzed: eka rasa bhāvassa pubba nimittam vātassa avāyanam dvāsaṭṭhi diṭṭhi gata bhindanassa pubba nimittam
translated: after the darkness of ignorance has been dispelled. The sweetness of the ocean is a premonition of the single taste of the taste of Nibbāna. The blowing of the wind is a premonition of the dispelling of the sixty-two views.

original: Sakuṇānaṃ pathavigamanaṃ mahājanassa ovādaṃ sutvā pāṇehi saraṇagamanassa pubbanimittaṃ.
analyzed: sakuṇānam pathavi gamanam mahājanassa ovādam sutvā pāṇehi saraṇa gamanassa pubba nimittam
translated: The birds’ flight to land was a premonition of the people’s going for refuge with their feet.

original: Candassa ativirocanaṃ bahujanakantatāya pubbanimittaṃ. Sūriyassa uṇhasītavivajjanautusukhatā
analyzed: candassa ati virocanam bahu jana kanta tāya pubba nimittam sūriyassa uṇha sīta vivajjana otu sukha tā
translated: The moon’s excessive brightness was a premonition of his being dear to the multitude. The sun’s freedom from heat and cold and the pleasantness of the season

original: kāyikacetasikasukhappattiyā pubbanimittaṃ. Devatānaṃ vimānadvāresu ṭhatvā apphoṭanādīhi
analyzed: kāyika cetasika sukha pattiyāḥ pubba nimittam devatānam vimāna dvāresu ṭhatvā apphoṭana ādīhi
translated: were a premonition of the attainment of bodily and mental bliss. The gods’ playing with clapping and so on, standing at the doors of their mansions,

original: kīḷanaṃ buddhabhāvaṃ patvā udānaṃ udānassa pubbanimittaṃ. Cātuddīpikamahāmeghavassanaṃ🔽mahato dhammameghavassanassa pubbanimittaṃ. Khudāpīḷanassa abhāvo kāyagatāsatiamatapaṭilābhassa
analyzed: kīḷanam buddha bhāvam patvā udānam udānassa pubba nimittam cātuddīpika mahā megha vassanam  mahataḥ dhamma megha vassanassa pubba nimittam khuda āpīḷanassa abhāvaḥ kāyagata asati amata paṭilābhassa
translated: was a premonition of the utterance of the Udāna on attaining Buddhahood. The great rain-cloud’s raining over the four continents

original: pubbanimittaṃ. Pipāsāpīḷanassa abhāvo vimuttisukhena sukhitabhāvassa pubbanimittaṃ.
analyzed: pubba nimittam pipāsā pīḷanassa abhāvaḥ vimutti sukhena sukhita bhāvassa pubba nimittam
translated: was a premonition of the great rain-cloud of the Dhamma. The absence of the suffering of hunger was a premonition of the attainment of the deathless through mindfulness occupied with the body. The absence of the suffering of thirst was a premonition of the state of being happy with the bliss of deliverance.

original: Dvārakavāṭānaṃ sayameva vivaraṇaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikamaggadvāravivaraṇassa pubbanimittaṃ.
analyzed: dvāra kavāṭānam sayam eva vivaraṇam aṭṭhaṅgika magga dvāra vivaraṇassa pubba nimittam
translated: The doors of the city gates’ opening of their own accord was a premonition of the opening of the door of the path with its eight factors.

original: Rukkhānaṃ pupphaphalaggahaṇaṃ vimuttipupphehi pupphitassa ca sāmaññaphalabhārabharitabhāvassa
analyzed: rukkhānam puppha phala ggahaṇam vimutti pupphehi pupphitassa ca sāmañña phala bhāra bharita bhāvassa
translated: The picking of the flowers and fruits of the trees is a symbol of the blossoming of the flowers of the eight liberations and the bearing of the fruit of the eight stages of holiness.

original: ca pubbanimittaṃ. Dasasahassilokadhātuyā ekaddhajamālitā ariyaddhajamālamālitāya
analyzed: ca pubba nimittam dasa sahassi lokadhātuyāḥ ekaddhaja mālitā ariyaddhaja māla mālitāya
translated: The wreath of the banner of the world of ten thousand worlds is a symbol of the wreath of the banner of the noble ones.

original: pubbanimittanti veditabbaṃ. Ayaṃ sambahulavāro nāma.
analyzed: pubba nimittam ti veditabbam ayam sambahulavāraḥ nāma
translated: This is called the section on the many.

original: Ettha pañhaṃ pucchanti – “yadā mahāpuriso pathaviyaṃ patiṭṭhahitvā uttarābhimukho🔽padasā gantvā āsabhiṃ vācaṃ abhāsi, tadā kiṃ pathaviyā gato, udāhu ākāsena; dissamāno🔽gato, udāhu adissamāno; acelako gato, udāhu alaṅkatapaṭiyatto; daharo hutvā gato,
analyzed: ettha pañham pucchanti yadā mahā purisaḥ pathaviyam patiṭṭhahitvā uttara abhimukhaḥ  padasā gantvā āsabhim vācam abhāsi tadā kim pathaviyā gataḥ udāhu ākāsena dissamānaḥ  gataḥ udāhu a dissamānaḥ a celakaḥ gataḥ udāhu alaṅkata paṭiyattaḥ daharaḥ hutvā gataḥ
translated: Here they ask the question: “When the Great Man stood on the earth and went forward on foot to the east,🔽did he go on the earth or through the air? Did he go being seen or unseen? Did he go naked or adorned? Did he go as a youth or as an old man?

original: udāhu mahallako; pacchāpi kiṃ tādisova ahosi, udāhu puna bāladārako”ti? Ayaṃ pana
analyzed: udāhu mahallako pacchā api kim tādisā uva ahosi udāhu puna ayam pana
translated: And afterwards, was he the same or was he again a foolish child?”🔽This question, however,

original: pañho heṭṭhālohapāsāde samuṭṭhito tipiṭakacūḷābhayattherena vissajjitova. Thero kira
analyzed: pañhaḥ heṭṭhā loha pāsāde samuṭṭhitaḥ tipiṭakacūḷābhaya therena vissajjitaḥ uva thero kira
translated: arose in the Copper Palace below and was answered by the Elder Tipiṭaka Cūḷa Abhaya. The elder, it seems,

original: ettha niyatipubbekatakammaissaranimmānavādavasena taṃ taṃ bahuṃ vatvā avasāne evaṃ
analyzed: ettha niyati pubbekata kammaissara nimmāna vāda vasena tam tam bahum vatvā avasāne evam
translated: Having said much about this in various ways according to the doctrine of fate, former action, the soul, and the doctrine of creation, he concluded thus:

original: byākari – “mahāpuriso pathaviyā gato, mahājanassa pana ākāsena gacchanto viya ahosi.
analyzed: byākari mahā puriso pathaviyā gataḥ mahā janassa pana ākāsena gacchantaḥ viya ahosi
translated: Herein, after expounding much on the lines of the doctrine of fate, former-making, a refuge, and creation, he concluded thus: “The Great Man went by earth, but to the multitude he was as though going through the air.

original: Dissamāno gato, mahājanassa pana adissamāno viya ahosi. Acelako gato, mahājanassa🔽pana alaṅkatapaṭiyatto viya upaṭṭhāsi. Daharova gato, mahājanassa pana soḷasavassuddesiko🔽viya ahosi. Pacchā pana bāladārakova ahosi, na tādiso”ti. Parisā cassa – “buddhena
analyzed: dissamānaḥ gataḥ mahājanassa pana a dissamānaḥ viya ahosi acelakaḥ gataḥ mahājanassa  pana alaṅkata paṭiyattaḥ viya upaṭṭhāsi daharaḥ uva gataḥ mahājanassa pana soḷasa vassuddesiko  viya ahosi pacchā pana bāla dārako uva ahosi na tādiso ti parisā ca assa buddhena
translated: He went in the visible way, but to the multitude he was as though invisible. He went as a naked ascetic, but to the multitude he appeared🔽adorned. He went as a youth, but to the multitude he appeared as a sixteen-year-old. But afterwards he appeared as a foolish child, not like that.” And the assembly was satisfied, thinking: “The elder has answered the question as though he were the Buddha.”

original: viya hutvā bho therena pañho kathito”ti attamanā ahosi. Lokantarikavāro vuttanayo eva.
analyzed: viya hutvā bho therena pañho kathito ti attamanāḥ ahosi lokantarika vāro vutta nayaḥ eva
translated: The section on the intervals between world systems is in the same way as stated.

original: Imā ca pana ādito paṭṭhāya kathitā sabbadhammatā sabbabodhisattānaṃ hontīti veditabbā.
analyzed: imā ca pana āditas paṭṭhāya kathitā sabba dhamma tā sabba bodhisattānam honti iti veditabbā
translated: And it should be understood that all these things stated from the beginning are the nature of all Bodhisattas.

original: Dvattiṃsamahāpurisalakkhaṇavaṇṇanā
translated: The Thirty-two Characteristics of a Great Man

original: 33. Addasa khoti dukūlacumbaṭake nipajjāpetvā ānītaṃ addasa. Mahāpurisassāti jātigottakulapadesādivasena
analyzed: addasa kho ti dukūla cumbaṭake nipajjāpetvā ānītam addasa mahā purisassa ati jāti gotta kula padesa ādi vasena
translated: He saw the Great Man: he saw the Great Man who was brought after being made to lie on a couch spread over with a skin sewn together.🔽The Great Man: a man who is great by reason of his clan, family, country, and so on.

original: mahantassa purisassa. Dve gatiyoti dve niṭṭhā, dve nipphattiyo. Ayañhi gatisaddo
analyzed: mahantassa purisassa dve gatiyo ti dve niṭṭhāḥ dve nipphattiyaḥ ayañhi gati saddo
translated: Two destinations: two ends, two results. For this word gati🔽occurs in the sense of a destination to be gone to by beings classed as hell-beings, etc.,

original: – “pañca kho imā, sāriputta, gatiyo”ti ettha nirayādibhedāya sattehi gantabbagatiyā
analyzed: pañca kho imā sāriputta gatiyaḥ ti ettha niraya ādi bhedāya sattehi gantabba gatiyā
translated: as in the passage “There are these five destinations, Sāriputta” .

original: vattati. “Imesaṃ kho ahaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ sīlavantānaṃ kalyāṇadhammānaṃ neva jānāmi āgatiṃ
analyzed: vattati imesam kho aham bhikkhūnam sīlavantānam kalyāṇa dhammānam na iva jānāmi āgatim
translated: It occurs in the sense of a mental orientation, as in the passage “As to these bhikkhus who are virtuous, of good character, I do not know whether they have any coming and going,🔽whether they stand or sit or lie down” .

original: vā gatiṃ vā”ti ettha ajjhāsaye. “Nibbānaṃ arahato gatī”ti ettha paṭissaraṇe. “Api
analyzed: vā gatim vā ati ettha ajjhāsaye nibbānam arahataḥ gatī iti ettha paṭissaraṇe api
translated: It occurs in the sense of a refuge, as in the passage “Nibbāna is the refuge of the arahat” .

original: ca tyāhaṃ brahme gatiñca pajānāmi, jutiñca pajānāmi evaṃmahiddhiko bako brahmā”ti
analyzed: ca tyā aham brahme gatiñca pajānāmi jutiñca pajānāmi evaṃmahiddhikaḥ bakaḥ brahmā ati
translated: It occurs in the sense of a result, as in the passage “But, brahmin, I know the destination and the radiance of the Great Brahma, who has such great power” .

original: ettha nipphattiyaṃ vattati. Svāyamidhāpi nipphattiyaṃ vattatīti veditabbo. Anaññāti
analyzed: ettha nipphattiyam vattati svāyam idha api nipphattiyam vattati iti veditabbaḥ anaññā iti
translated: And here it should be understood as occurring in the sense of a result.

original: aññā gati nipphatti nāma natthi.
analyzed: aññā gati nipphatti nāma natthi
translated: No other: there is no other destination, no other result.

original: Dhammikoti dasakusaladhammasamannāgato agatigamanavirahito. Dhammarājāti idaṃ purimapadasseva
analyzed: dhammikaḥ ti dasa kusala dhamma samannāgataḥ agati gamana virahitaḥ dhamma rājā ati idam purima padassa eva
translated: “Righteous” : endowed with the ten right ways of action, free from wrong ways of action. “King of Righteousness” : this is a synonym for the previous word.

original: vevacanaṃ. Dhammena vā laddharajjattā dhammarājā. Cāturantoti puratthimasamuddādīnaṃ
analyzed: vevacanam dhammena vā laddha rajjattā dhamma rājā puratthima samudda ādīnam
translated: Dhamiko means endowed with the ten virtues and free from going to the lower realms. Dhammaraja is a synonym for the previous word. Or he is a dhammaraja because he has obtained kingship by the dhamma. Caturanto means the lord of the earth with four oceans,

original: catunnaṃ samuddānaṃ vasena caturantāya pathaviyā issaro. Vijitāvīti vijitasaṅgāmo.
analyzed: catunnam samuddānam vasena catur antāya pathaviyā issaraḥ vijitāvī iti vijita saṅgāmaḥ
translated: in terms of the four oceans such as the eastern ocean. Vijitavī means one who has won battles.

original: Janapado asmiṃ thāvariyaṃ thirabhāvaṃ pattoti janapadatthāvariyappatto. Caṇḍassa🔽hi rañño balidaṇḍādīhi lokaṃ pīḷayato manussā majjhimajanapadaṃ chaḍḍetvā pabbatasamuddatīrādīni🔽nissāya paccante vāsaṃ kappenti. Atimudukassa rañño corehi sāhasikadhanavilopapīḷitā
analyzed: janapadaḥ asmin thāvariyam thira bhāvam patto ti janapada thāvariya patto caṇḍassa  hi raññaḥ bali daṇḍa ādīhi lokam pīḷayataḥ manussāḥ majjhima janapadam chaḍḍetvā pabbata samudda tīra ādīni  nissāya paccante vāsam kappenti ati mudukassa rañño corehi sāhasika dhana vilopa pīḍitā
translated: Janapada means the people. He has attained stability in this place, thus he is janapadatthāvariyappatto.🔽For when a fierce king oppresses the world with taxes, fines, etc., people abandon the central country and take up residence in the border areas such as the mountain and ocean shores.

original: manussā paccantaṃ pahāya janapadamajjhe vāsaṃ kappenti, iti evarūpe rājini janapado
analyzed: manussā paccantam pahāya janapada majjhe vāsam kappenti iti evarūpe rājini janapadaḥ
translated: When a king is too mild, people oppressed by thieves who violently steal their wealth abandon the border areas and take up residence in the center of the country. Thus in such a king the people

original: thirabhāvaṃ na pāpuṇāti. Imasmiṃ pana kumāre rajjaṃ kārayamāne etassa janapado pāsāṇapiṭṭhiyaṃ
analyzed: thira bhāvam na pāpuṇāti imasmin pana kumāre rajjam kārayamāne etassa janapadaḥ pāsāṇa piṭṭhiyam
translated: he will not be able to maintain his position. But if this prince is made king, this country will be like a stone-slab.

original: ṭhapetvā ayopaṭṭena parikkhitto viya thiro bhavissatīti dassento – “janapadatthāvariyappatto”ti āhaṃsu.
analyzed: ṭhapetvā ayaḥ paṭṭena parikkhittaḥ viya thiraḥ bhavissati iti dassento janapadatthāvariya patto ti āhaṃsu
translated: and it will not be stable. But when this prince is ruling, this country will be stable like a stone slab placed on a rocky surface surrounded by an iron band. ” So saying, they said, “He will be a king of kings. ”

original: Sattaratanasamannāgatoti ettha ratijananaṭṭhena ratanaṃ. Apica –
analyzed: satta ratana samannāgataḥ ti ettha rati janana ṭṭhena ratanam apica
translated: Possessed of the seven treasures: a treasure is so called because it generates delight . Moreover,

original: “Cittīkataṃ mahagghañca, atulaṃ dullabhadassanaṃ;
analyzed: cittīkatam mahaggham ca atulam dullabha dassanam
translated: “It is esteemed, very valuable, incomparable, difficult to see,

original: Anomasattaparibhogaṃ, ratanaṃ tena vuccati”.
analyzed: ratanam tena vuccati
translated: And is enjoyed by the best of men; therefore it is called a treasure. ”

original: Cakkaratanassa ca nibbattakālato paṭṭhāya aññaṃ devaṭṭhānaṃ nāma na hoti, sabbe gandhapupphādīhi🔽tasseva pūjañca abhivādanādīni ca karontīti cittīkataṭṭhena ratanaṃ. Cakkaratanassa
analyzed: cakka ratanassa ca nibbatta kālataḥ paṭṭhāya aññam devaṭṭhānam nāma na hoti sabbe gandha puppha ādīhi  tassa iva pūjam ca abhivādana ādīni ca karonti iti cittīkata ṭṭhena ratanam cakka ratanassa
translated: And from the time of the appearance of the wheel-treasure, there is no other royal residence; all the people, with perfumes, flowers, etc.,

original: ca ettakaṃ nāma dhanaṃ agghatīti aggho natthi, iti mahagghaṭṭhenāpi ratanaṃ. Cakkaratanañca
analyzed: ca ettakam nāma dhanam agghati iti agghaḥ natthi iti mahaggha ṭṭhena api ratanam cakka ratanam ca
translated: pay homage to it and make obeisance to it. Thus it is a treasure in the sense of being esteemed . And the wheel-treasure has no price, no value; therefore it is a treasure in the sense of being very valuable . And the wheel-treasure is

original: aññehi loke vijjamānaratanehi asadisanti atulaṭṭhenāpi ratanaṃ. Yasmā ca pana yasmiṃ
analyzed: aññehi loke vijjamāna ratanehi asadisanti atula ṭṭhena api ratanam yasmā ca pana yasmin
translated: and it is a treasure in the sense of being incomparable with any other treasure in the world.

original: kappe buddhā uppajjanti, tasmiṃyeva cakkavattino uppajjanti, buddhā ca kadāci karahaci🔽uppajjanti, tasmā dullabhadassanaṭṭhenāpi ratanaṃ. Tadetaṃ jātirūpakulaissariyādīhi
analyzed: kappe buddhāḥ uppajjanti tasmin yeva cakkavattinaḥ uppajjanti buddhāḥ ca kadāci karahaci  uppajjanti tasmā dullabha dassana ṭṭhena api ratanam tat etam jāti rūpa kula issariya ādīhi
translated: And since Buddhas appear only in those world-systems in which a wheel-turning monarch appears, and since Buddhas appear only occasionally,🔽it is a treasure in the sense of being rarely seen.🔽And it appears only in a being of such outstanding greatness as is characterized by the thirty-two marks of a Great Man, not in any other,🔽so it is a treasure in the sense of being the possession of a Great Man.

original: anomassa uḷārasattasseva uppajjati, na aññassāti anomasattaparibhogaṭṭhenāpi ratanaṃ.🔽Yathā cakkaratanaṃ, evaṃ sesānipīti. Imehi sattahi ratanehi parivārabhāvena ceva🔽sabbabhogūpakaraṇabhāvena ca samannāgatoti sattaratanasamannāgato.
analyzed: anomassa uḷāra sattassa iva uppajjati na aññassa ati anoma satta paribhoga ṭṭhena api ratanam  yathā cakka ratanam evam sesāni api iti imehi sattahi ratanehi parivāra bhāvena ca iva  sabba bhogu upakaraṇa bhāvena ca samannāgato ti satta ratana samannāgato
translated: So too with the other treasures.🔽He is endowed with the seven treasures in the sense that they surround him and in the sense that they are all his property.🔽Now, in order to show their individual characteristics, the following terms are used: “His are the seven treasures” , etc. Herein,

original: Idāni tesaṃ sarūpato dassanatthaṃ tassimānītiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha cakkaratanantiādīsu
analyzed: idāni tesam sarūpataḥ dassana attham tassa imāni itiādi vuttam tattha cakkaratana nti ādīsu
translated: the meaning is as follows. The wheel treasure, etc.,

original: ayaṃ saṅkhepādhippāyo – dvesahassadīpaparivārānaṃ catunnaṃ mahādīpānaṃ sirivibhavaṃ
analyzed: ayam saṅkhepa adhippāyaḥ dvi sahassa dīpa parivārānam catunnam mahā dīpānam siri vibhavam
translated: are the glory and wealth of the four great continents with their two thousand surrounding islands.

original: gahetvā dātuṃ samatthaṃ cakkaratanaṃ pātubhavati. Tathā purebhattameva sāgarapariyantaṃ
analyzed: gahetvā dātum samattham cakka ratanam pātubhavati tathā purebhattam eva sāgara pariyantam
translated: and the Wheel-Treasure appears, capable of conquering a unconquered land and of bringing to a conquered land🔽

original: pathaviṃ anusaṃyāyanasamatthaṃ vehāsaṅgamaṃ hatthiratanaṃ, tādisameva assaratanaṃ,🔽caturaṅgasamannāgate andhakāre yojanappamāṇaṃ andhakāraṃ vidhamitvā ālokadassanasamatthaṃ🔽maṇiratanaṃ, chabbidhadosavivajjitaṃ manāpacāri itthiratanaṃ, yojanappamāṇe antopathavigataṃ
analyzed: pathavim anusaṃyāyana samattham vehā saṅgamam hatthi ratanam tādisam eva assa ratanam  catur aṅga samannāgate andhakāre yojana ppamāṇam andhakāram vidhamitvā āloka dassana samattham  maṇi ratanam chabbidha dosa vivajjitam manāpa cāri itthi ratanam yojana ppamāṇe antopathavigatam
translated: The Wheel-Treasure appears, which is made of iron, with a thousand spokes, a rim, and a hub, complete in every aspect, and when the King sets out in the direction of the East, the Wheel rolls before him, and all the lands to the East submit to him.🔽The Elephant-Treasure appears, which is fully grown, white, endowed with sevenfold stance, and able to travel a thousand leagues in a day.

original: nidhiṃ dassanasamatthaṃ gahapatiratanaṃ, aggamahesiyā kucchimhi nibbattitvā sakalarajjamanusāsanasamatthaṃ🔽jeṭṭhaputtasaṅkhātaṃ pariṇāyakaratanaṃ pātubhavati.🔽Parosahassanti atirekasahassaṃ. Sūrāti abhīrukā. Vīraṅgarūpāti vīrānaṃ aṅgaṃ vīraṅgaṃ,
analyzed: nidhim dassana samattham gahapati ratanam aggamahesiyāḥ kucchimhi nibbattitvā sakala rajjam anusāsana samattham  jeṭṭha putta saṅkhātam pariṇāyaka ratanam pātubhavati  atireka sahassam sūrā ati abhīrukā vīraṅga rūpā ati vīrānam aṅgam vīraṅgam
translated: The Gem-Treasure appears, which is a gem of the finest water and color, eight-faceted, well cut, and it is placed in a high pavilion, and when the King sets out on a tour of inspection, it is placed on the top of a banner on the chariot in front, and it illuminates all the four quarters.

original: vīriyassetaṃ nāmaṃ, vīraṅgaṃ rūpametesanti vīraṅgarūpā, vīriyajātikā vīriyasabhāvā

analyzed: evam ekam nipphattim kathetvā dutiyam kathetum sace kho pana itiādi vuttam tattha
translated: Having thus described one kind of fruit, he went on to describe a second kind, saying: “If, on the other hand, he should leave home … “

original: rāgadosamohamānadiṭṭhikilesataṇhāsaṅkhātaṃ chadanaṃ āvaraṇaṃ vivaṭaṃ viddhaṃsitaṃ

original: ṭhapentānaṃ aggapādatalaṃ vā paṇhi vā passaṃ vā paṭhamaṃ phusati, vemajjhe vā pana🔽chiddaṃ hoti, ukkhipantānaṃ aggatalādīsu ekakoṭṭhāsova paṭhamaṃ uṭṭhahati, na evamassa.
analyzed: ṭhapentānam agga pāda talam vā paṇhi vā passam vā paṭhamam phusati vemajjhe vā pana  chiddam hoti ukkhipantānam agga tala ādīsu eka koṭṭhāsaḥ iva paṭhamam uṭṭhahati na evam assa

original: Assa pana suvaṇṇapādukatalamiva ekappahāreneva sakalaṃ pādatalaṃ bhūmiṃ phusati,
analyzed: assa pana suvaṇṇa pāduka talam iva eka ppahārena iva sakalam pāda talam bhūmim phusati

analyzed: eka ppahārena iva bhūmitaḥ uṭṭhahati tasmai ayam su patiṭṭhita pādaḥ
translated: He rises from the ground in one piece, not in parts. That is why he is “one whose feet are placed well” .

original: Cakkānīti dvīsu pādatalesu dve cakkāni, tesaṃ arā ca nemi ca nābhi ca pāḷiyaṃ vuttāva.🔽Sabbākāraparipūrānīti iminā pana ayaṃ viseso veditabbo, tesaṃ kira cakkānaṃ pādatalassa🔽majjhe nābhi dissati, nābhiparicchinnā vaṭṭalekhā dissati, nābhimukhaparikkhepapaṭṭo🔽dissati, panāḷimukhaṃ dissati, arā dissanti, aresu vaṭṭilekhā dissanti, nemimaṇikā

original: Dīghaṅgulīti yathā aññesaṃ kāci aṅguliyo dīghā honti, kāci rassā, na evaṃ mahāpurisassa.🔽Mahāpurisassa pana makkaṭasseva dīghā hatthapādaṅguliyo mūle thūlā, anupubbena gantvā

translated: Long-fingered: the fingers of other men are long in one place and short in another, but not so the Great Man’s.🔽But the Great Man’s fingers are long like a monkey’s. They are thick at the base,

original: agge tanukā, niyyāsatelena madditvā vaṭṭitaharitālavaṭṭisadisā honti. Tena vuttaṃ – “dīghaṅgulī”ti.

original: viya mudu. Yathā ca idāni jātamattassa, evaṃ vuḍḍhakālepi mudutalunāyeva bhavissanti,🔽mudutalunā hatthapādā etassāti mudutalunahatthapādo.🔽Jālahatthapādoti na cammena paṭibaddhaaṅgulantaro. Ediso hi phaṇahatthako purisadosena
analyzed: yathā ca idāni jāta mattassa evam vuḍḍha kāle pi bhavissanti  mudu talunā hattha pādāḥ etassa ati mudu taluna hattha pādo  jālahattha pādaḥ ti na cammena paṭibaddha aṅgula antaraḥ edisaḥ hi phaṇahatthako purisa dosena
translated: and they will be soft and tender even when he is old.🔽He has soft and tender hands and feet.

original: upahato pabbajjaṃ na paṭilabhati. Mahāpurisassa pana catasso hatthaṅguliyo pañcapi
analyzed: upahataḥ pabbajjam na paṭilabhati mahā purisassa pana catasso hattha aṅguliyaḥ pañca api
translated: Webbed hands and feet: the spaces between the fingers and toes are filled in, like a spoon. For one with spaces between the fingers and toes like a yak’s tail is despised like a yak. But the Great Man’s hands and feet are not like that.

original: pādaṅguliyo ekappamāṇā honti, tāsaṃ ekappamāṇatāya yavalakkhaṇaṃ aññamaññaṃ paṭivijjhitvā
analyzed: pāda aṅguliyaḥ eka ppamāṇāḥ honti tāsam eka ppamāṇa tāya yava lakkhaṇam aññam aññam paṭivijjhitvā
translated: His toes are of equal length, and because they are of equal length, the lines of the toes cross each other

original: tiṭṭhati. Athassa hatthapādā kusalena vaḍḍhakinā yojitajālavātapānasadisā honti.
analyzed: tiṭṭhati athassa hattha pādā kusalena vaḍḍhakinā yojita jālavāta pāna sadisāḥ honti
translated: and stand out. Then his hands and feet become like a well-made net with evenly spaced large and small meshes.

original: Tena vuttaṃ – “jālahatthapādo”ti.
analyzed: tena vuttam jālahattha pādaḥ ti
translated: Hence it is said: “He has feet with webbed fingers and toes” .

original: Uddhaṃ patiṭṭhitagopphakattā ussaṅkhā pādā assāti ussaṅkhapādo. Aññesañhi piṭṭhipāde
analyzed: uddham patiṭṭhita gopphaka ttā ussaṅkhā pādāḥ assa ati ussaṅkha pādaḥ aññesam hi piṭṭhi pāde
translated: Because his ankles are well-developed and stand out, his feet are like those of a hare, hence he is said to be “one who has feet with ankles that do not protrude” . For in other people the ankles are not well-developed and do not stand out;

original: gopphakā honti, tena tesaṃ pādā āṇibaddhā viya baddhā honti, na yathāsukhaṃ parivaṭṭanti,
analyzed: gopphakāḥ honti tena tesam pādāḥ āṇi baddhāḥ viya baddhāḥ honti na yathāsukham parivaṭṭanti
translated: therefore their feet are as though bound with thongs, they cannot be turned over as they wish,

original: gacchantānaṃ pādatalānipi na dissanti. Mahāpurisassa pana āruhitvā upari gopphakā
analyzed: gacchantānam pāda talāni pi na dissanti mahā purisassa pana āruhitvā upari gopphakā
translated: and the soles of their feet are not seen when they walk. But in the Great Man the ankles are well-developed and stand out;

original: patiṭṭhahanti, tenassa nābhito paṭṭhāya uparimakāyo nāvāya ṭhapitasuvaṇṇapaṭimā viya
analyzed: patiṭṭhahanti tena assa nābhitaḥ paṭṭhāya uparima kāyaḥ nāvāya ṭhapita suvaṇṇa paṭimā viya
translated: therefore his body above the navel is as steady as a gold image

original: niccalo hoti, adhokāyova iñjati, sukhena pādā parivaṭṭanti, puratopi pacchatopi ubhayapassesupi
analyzed: niccalaḥ hoti adhas kāyaḥ iva iñjati sukhena pādā parivaṭṭanti puratas pi pacchatas pi ubhaya passesu pi
translated: placed on a stand, while the lower part moves. His feet can be turned over easily, both forwards and backwards and to the left and right,

original: ṭhatvā passantānaṃ pādatalāni paññāyanti, na hatthīnaṃ viya pacchatoyeva.
analyzed: ṭhatvā passantānam pāda talāni paññāyanti na hatthīnam viya
translated: and when they stood and looked at him, they could see the soles of his feet.

original: Eṇijaṅghoti eṇimigasadisajaṅgho maṃsussadena paripuṇṇajaṅgho, na ekato baddhapiṇḍikamaṃso,
analyzed: eṇi jaṅghaḥ iti eṇi miga sadisa jaṅghaḥ maṃsussadena paripuṇṇa jaṅghaḥ na ekatas baddha piṇḍika maṃsaḥ
translated: He has the calves of an antelope: his calves are full and fleshy like those of an antelope, not like a bundle of sticks tied together.

original: samantato samasaṇṭhitena maṃsena parikkhittāhi suvaṭṭitāhi sāligabbhayavagabbhasadisāhi
analyzed: samantataḥ sama saṇṭhitena maṃsena parikkhittāhi su vaṭṭitāhi sāli gabbha yava gabbha sadisāhi
translated: His calves are covered with flesh that is evenly distributed all round, and they are well rounded, like the polished surface of a well-turned bamboo.

original: jaṅghāhi samannāgatoti attho.🔽Anonamantoti anamanto, etenassa akhujjaavāmanabhāvo dīpito. Avasesajanā hi khujjā

translated: This is the meaning.🔽He has no protruding belly: he has no belly that protrudes, which shows that he has no humped or stooped shoulders.

original: vā honti vāmanā vā. Khujjānaṃ uparimakāyo aparipuṇṇo hoti, vāmanānaṃ heṭṭhimakāyo.

translated: For other people have humped or stooped shoulders and their upper bodies are not well developed.🔽And because their bodies are not well developed, they are unable to rub their knees with their hands without bending forward.

translated: But the Great Man

original: paripuṇṇaubhayakāyattā sakkoti.
analyzed: paripuṇṇā aubhayaka āyattā
translated: is able to do so because his body is well developed on both sides.

original: Kosohitavatthaguyhoti usabhavāraṇādīnaṃ viya suvaṇṇapadumakaṇṇikasadisehi kosehi
analyzed: usabha vāraṇa ādīnam viya suvaṇṇa paduma kaṇṇika sadisehi kosehi
translated: He has a sexual organ ensheathed like that of a thoroughbred horse: like the sexual organ of a thoroughbred horse, his sexual organ is ensheathed and hidden away.

original: ohitaṃ paṭicchannaṃ vatthaguyhaṃ assāti kosohitavatthaguyho. Vatthaguyhanti vatthena
analyzed: ohitam paṭicchannam vattha guyham assa ati kosohita vattha guyhaḥ vattha guyhanti vatthena
translated: “The sheathed genitals” means the genitals are hidden in a sheath. “Sheathed” means🔽

original: guhitabbaṃ aṅgajātaṃ vuccati.🔽Suvaṇṇavaṇṇoti jātihiṅgulakena majjitvā dīpidāṭhāya ghaṃsitvā gerukaparikammaṃ katvā
analyzed: guhitabbam aṅga jātam vuccati  suvaṇṇa vaṇṇaḥ ti jāti hiṅgulakena majjitvā dīpi dāṭhāya ghaṃsitvā geruka parikammam katvā
translated: He is “sheathed” in that his organ is hidden in a sheath. “Sheath” is said of the organ that should be covered by a cloth.

original: ṭhapitaghanasuvaṇṇarūpasadisoti attho. Etenassa ghanasiniddhasaṇhasarīrataṃ dassetvā
analyzed: ṭhapita ghana suvaṇṇa rūpa sadisaḥ ti atthaḥ etena assa ghana siniddha saṇha sarīra tam dassetvā
translated: “Golden in color”: the meaning is that he is like a solid piece of gold that has been heated, hammered out, and polished by a goldsmith. This shows that his body is solid, compact, and well-proportioned.

original: chavivaṇṇadassanatthaṃ kañcanasannibhattacoti vuttaṃ. Purimassa vā vevacanametaṃ.
analyzed: chavi vaṇṇa dassana attham vuttam purimassa vā vevacanam etam
translated: “His skin is the color of gold” is said to show his skin’s color. This is a synonym for the previous phrase.

original: Rajojallanti rajo vā malaṃ vā. Na upalimpatīti na laggati padumapalāsato udakabindu🔽viya vivaṭṭati. Hatthadhovanādīni pana utuggahaṇatthāya ceva dāyakānaṃ puññaphalatthāya
analyzed: rajaḥ jallanti rajaḥ vā malam vā na upalimpati iti na laggati udaka bindu  viya vivaṭṭati hattha dhovana ādīni pana utu ggahaṇa atthāya ca iva dāyakānam puñña phala atthāya
translated: “Dust and dirt do not stick to his body”: dust and dirt do not adhere to his body, like water drops on a lotus leaf.

original: ca buddhā karonti, vattasīsenāpi ca karontiyeva. Senāsanaṃ pavisantena hi bhikkhunā
analyzed: ca buddhāḥ karonti vatta sīsena api ca karontiyā iva senāsanam pavisantena hi bhikkhunā
translated: The Buddhas wash their hands and so on in order to take care of their bodies and to give donors a chance to make merit. They do this even with their physical attendants.

original: pāde dhovitvā pavisitabbanti vuttametaṃ.
analyzed: pāde dhovitvā pavisitabbanti vuttam etam
translated: When entering the dwelling, the monk should wash his feet and then enter. This is what is meant.

original: Uddhaggalomoti āvaṭṭapariyosāne uddhaggāni hutvā mukhasobhaṃ ullokayamānāni viya ṭhitāni lomāni assāti uddhaggalomo.
analyzed: uddhagga lomaḥ ti āvaṭṭa pariyosāne uddhaggāni hutvā mukha sobham ullokayamānāni viya ṭhitāni lomāni assa ati uddhagga lomaḥ
translated: Uddhaggalomā: his hairs will stand erect, as if he were looking at the beauty of his face at the end of a turning.

original: Brahmujugattoti brahmā viya ujugatto, ujumeva uggatadīghasarīro bhavissati. Yebhuyyena
analyzed: brahma uju gattaḥ ti brahmā viya uju gattaḥ ujumeva uggata dīgha sarīraḥ bhavissati yebhuyyena
translated: Brahmujugatto: he will be straight like Brahmā, with a body that is tall and straight.

original: hi sattā khandhe kaṭiyaṃ jāṇūsūti tīsu ṭhānesu namanti, te kaṭiyaṃ namantā pacchato
analyzed: hi sattā khandhe kaṭiyam tīsu ṭhānesu namanti te kaṭiyam namantā pacchatas
translated: For most beings bend in three places, at the chest, the waist, and the knees. Those who bend at the waist bend backwards,

original: namanti, itaresu dvīsu ṭhānesu purato. Dīghasarīrā pana eke passavaṅkā honti, eke🔽mukhaṃ unnametvā nakkhattāni gaṇayantā viya caranti, eke appamaṃsalohitā sūlasadisā🔽honti, eke purato pabbhārā honti, pavedhamānā gacchanti. Ayaṃ pana ujumeva uggantvā
analyzed: namanti itaresu dvīsu ṭhānesu puratas dīgha sarīrā pana eke passavaṅkāḥ honti eke  mukham unnametvā nakkhattāni gaṇayantā viya caranti eke appa maṃsa lohitā sūla sadisā  honti eke puratas pabbhārāḥ honti pavedhamānāḥ gacchanti ayam pana ujum eva uggantvā
translated: and those who bend at the other two places bend forwards. Some who are tall and straight are bent to one side,🔽and some walk as if they were counting the stars by looking up at the sky. Some are bony and bloodless, like skeletons,

original: dīghappamāṇo devanagare ussitasuvaṇṇatoraṇaṃ viya bhavissatīti dīpenti. Yathā cetaṃ,
analyzed: dīgha ppamāṇaḥ devanagare ussita suvaṇṇa toraṇam viya bhavissati iti dīpenti yathā ca itam
translated: and some walk with their chests thrust out. But he will be tall and straight like a golden pillar set up in a shrine.🔽And just as,

original: evaṃ yaṃ yaṃ jātamattassa sabbaso aparipuṇṇaṃ mahāpurisalakkhaṇaṃ hoti, taṃ taṃ āyatiṃ
analyzed: evam yam yam jāta mattassa sabbaso a paripuṇṇam mahāpurisa lakkhaṇam hoti tam tam āyatim
translated: Thus, whatever mark of a Great Man is incomplete at birth,🔽in the future

original: tathābhāvitaṃ sandhāya vuttanti veditabbaṃ.🔽Sattussadoti dve hatthapiṭṭhiyo dve pādapiṭṭhiyo dve aṃsakūṭāni khandhoti imesu sattasu
analyzed: tathā bhāvitam sandhāya vuttan ti veditabbam  sattussadaḥ ti dve hattha piṭṭhiyaḥ dve pāda piṭṭhiyaḥ dve aṃsakūṭāni khandho ti imesu sattasu
translated: So it should be understood that what is said refers to the development of what is incomplete in one who is born a Great Man.

original: ṭhānesu paripuṇṇo maṃsussado assāti sattussado. Aññesaṃ pana hatthapādapiṭṭhādīsu🔽sirājālaṃ paññāyati, aṃsakūṭakkhandhesu aṭṭhikoṭiyo. Te manussā petā viya khāyanti,🔽na tathā mahāpuriso, mahāpuriso pana sattasu ṭhānesu paripuṇṇamaṃsussadattā nigūḷhasirājālehi
analyzed: ṭhānesu paripuṇṇaḥ maṃsussadaḥ assa ati sattussadaḥ aññesam pana hattha pāda piṭṭha ādīsu  sirā jālam paññāyati aṃsakūṭa khandhesu aṭṭhi koṭiyaḥ te manussā petāḥ viya khāyanti  na tathā mahā purisaḥ mahā purisaḥ pana sattasu ṭhānesu nigūḍha sirā jālehi
translated: Seven convex surfaces: the two hands, the two feet, the two shoulders, and the neck are fully fleshed and convex. Others have the bones showing through the flesh in the palms of the hands, the soles of the feet, the shoulders, and the neck. They look like ghosts.

original: hatthapiṭṭhādīhi vaṭṭetvā suṭṭhapitasuvaṇṇāḷiṅgasadisena khandhena silārūpakaṃ viya
analyzed: hattha piṭṭha ādīhi vaṭṭetvā su ṭṭhapita suvaṇṇa āḷiṅga sadisena khandhena silā rūpakam viya
translated: But the Great Man does not. Because of the fullness of flesh on the seven convex surfaces, his hands, feet, etc., are as if covered with a network of gold leaf, and his neck and shoulders are like a polished gem.

original: khāyati, cittakammarūpakaṃ viya ca khāyati.🔽Sīhassa pubbaddhaṃ viya kāyo assāti sīhapubbaddhakāyo. Sīhassa hi puratthimakāyova
analyzed: khāyati citta kamma rūpakam viya ca khāyati 🔽sīhassa pubbaddham viya kāyaḥ assa ati sīha pubbaddha kāyaḥ sīhassa hi puratthima kāyaḥ uva
translated: He looks as if he were made of stone, and he looks as if he were made of bronze.🔽His body is shaped like a banyan fig tree. The body of the Great Man is shaped like a banyan fig tree. For the banyan fig tree is deep green, and its branches, leaves, and fruits are dense. The Great Man’s body is deep in colour, and his hair, pores, skin, and the flesh and blood are dense.

original: paripuṇṇo hoti, pacchimakāyo aparipuṇṇo. Mahāpurisassa pana sīhassa pubbaddhakāyo🔽viya sabbo kāyo paripuṇṇo. Sopi sīhasseva tattha tattha vinatunnatādivasena dussaṇṭhitavisaṇṭhito
analyzed: paripuṇṇaḥ hoti pacchimakāyaḥ a paripuṇṇaḥ mahāpurisassa pana sīhassa pubbaddha kāyo  viya sabbaḥ kāyaḥ paripuṇṇo saḥ api sīhassa iva tattha tattha vinatunnatā ādi vasena dussaṇṭhita visaṇṭhitaḥ
translated: the front part of the body is complete, the back part is incomplete. But the Great Man’s body is complete all over like a lion’s. And it is not ill-proportioned, like a lion’s, with some parts stretched out and some parts drawn in. But it is long in the places where it should be long, and

original: na hoti, dīghayuttaṭṭhāne pana dīgho, rassathūlakisaputhulaanuvaṭṭitayuttaṭṭhānesu
analyzed: na hoti dīgha yutta ṭṭhāne pana dīghaḥ rassa thūla kisa puthula anuvaṭṭita yutta ṭṭhānesu
translated: short in the places where it should be short, and it is well-proportioned with the thirty-two marks of a Great Man. This is how the Blessed One is “well-proportioned.”

original: tathāvidhova hoti. Vuttañhetaṃ bhagavatā –
analyzed: tathāvidhaḥ uva hoti vuttam ha etam bhagavatā
translated: This is said of him:

original: “Manāpiyeva kho, bhikkhave, kammavipāke paccupaṭṭhite yehi aṅgehi dīghehi sobhati,🔽tāni aṅgāni dīghāni saṇṭhanti. Yehi aṅgehi rassehi sobhati, tāni aṅgāni rassāni saṇṭhanti.
analyzed: manāpiyā iva kho bhikkhave kamma vipāke paccupaṭṭhite yehi aṅgehi dīghehi sobhati  tāni aṅgāni dīghāni saṇṭhanti yehi aṅgehi rassehi sobhati tāni aṅgāni rassāni saṇṭhanti
translated: “When the ripening of the deed that is to be experienced as a pleasant object of the senses is present, the parts of the body that are long are long,🔽the parts that are short are short.🔽When the ripening of the deed that is to be experienced as a bitter object of the senses is present, the parts of the body that are stout are stout,🔽the parts that are lean are lean.

original: Yehi aṅgehi thūlehi sobhati, tāni aṅgāni thūlāni saṇṭhanti. Yehi aṅgehi kisehi sobhati,
analyzed: yehi aṅgehi thūlehi sobhati tāni aṅgāni thūlāni saṇṭhanti yehi aṅgehi kisehi sobhati
translated: When the ripening of the deed that is to be experienced as a gross object of the senses is present, the parts of the body that are gross are gross,

original: tāni aṅgāni kisāni saṇṭhanti. Yehi aṅgehi puthulehi sobhati, tāni aṅgāni puthulāni
analyzed: tāni aṅgāni kisāni saṇṭhanti yehi aṅgehi puthulehi sobhati tāni aṅgāni puthulāni
translated: the parts that are fine are fine.

original: saṇṭhanti. Yehi aṅgehi vaṭṭehi sobhati, tāni aṅgāni vaṭṭāni saṇṭhantī”ti.
analyzed: saṇṭhanti yehi aṅgehi vaṭṭehi sobhati tāni aṅgāni vaṭṭāni saṇṭhanti iti
translated: and the ribs are the spokes. The parts by which the wheel is beautified are the spokes of the wheel.”

original: Iti nānācittena puññacittena cittito dasahi pāramīhi sajjito mahāpurisassa attabhāvo, loke sabbasippino vā sabbaiddhimanto vā patirūpakampi kātuṃ na sakkonti.
analyzed: iti nānācittena puññacittena cittitaḥ dasahi pāramīhi sajjitaḥ mahāpurisassa atta bhāvaḥ loke sabba sippinaḥ vā sabba eddhimantaḥ vā patirūpakam pi kātum na sakkonti
translated: Thus the Great Man’s body, which is adorned with the thirty-two marks produced by the ten perfections through a variety of wholesome volitions, cannot be duplicated by anyone in the world, by any artist or magician.

original: Citantaraṃsoti antaraṃsaṃ vuccati dvinnaṃ koṭṭānaṃ antaraṃ, taṃ citaṃ paripuṇṇaṃ🔽antaraṃsaṃ assāti citantaraṃso. Aññesañhi taṃ ṭhānaṃ ninnaṃ hoti, dve piṭṭhikoṭṭā
analyzed: citantaraṃso ti antaraṃsam vuccati dvinnam koṭṭānam antaram tam citam paripuṇṇam  antaraṃsam assa ati citantaraṃsaḥ aññesam hi tat ṭhānam ninnam hoti dve piṭṭhikoṭṭā
translated: The “in-between” is called the “in-between of the two shoulders.” The in-between of the two shoulders is filled up🔽and complete in the Great Man. The in-between of the two shoulders of other men is sunken, and the two shoulder-blades

original: pāṭiyekkā paññāyanti. Mahāpurisassa pana kaṭito paṭṭhāya maṃsapaṭalaṃ yāva khandhā
analyzed: pāṭiyekkā paññāyanti mahāpurisassa pana kaṭitaḥ paṭṭhāya maṃsa paṭalam yāva khandhāḥ
translated: are seen separately. But in the Great Man, the layer of flesh extends from the waist up to the shoulders

original: uggamma samussitasuvaṇṇaphalakaṃ viya piṭṭhiṃ chādetvā patiṭṭhitaṃ.
analyzed: uggamma samussita suvaṇṇa phalakam viya piṭṭhim chādetvā patiṭṭhitam
translated: and covers the back like a well-polished gold plate.

original: Nigrodhaparimaṇḍaloti nigrodho viya parimaṇḍalo. Yathā paññāsahatthatāya vā satahatthatāya
analyzed: nigrodha parimaṇḍalo ti nigrodhaḥ viya parimaṇḍalaḥ yathā paññāsa hattha tāya vā sata hattha tāya
translated: “Round like the nyagrodha tree” means round like the nyagrodha tree. Just as the nyagrodha tree is round,

original: vā samakkhandhasākho nigrodho dīghatopi vitthāratopi ekappamāṇova hoti, evaṃ kāyatopi
analyzed: vā sama khandha sākhaḥ nigrodhaḥ dīghataḥ pi vitthārataḥ pi eka ppamāṇaḥ uva hoti evam kāyataḥ pi
translated: and the banyan tree with its trunk and branches is the same in height and breadth, so too the Great Man’s body is the same in height and breadth.

original: byāmatopi ekappamāṇo. Yathā aññesaṃ kāyo dīgho vā hoti byāmo vā, na evaṃ visamappamāṇoti
analyzed: byāmataḥ api eka ppamāṇaḥ yathā aññesam kāyaḥ dīghaḥ vā hoti byāmaḥ vā na evam visama ppamāṇaḥ ti
translated: The meaning is that while the bodies of others are long or broad, his is not uneven in size.🔽That is why it is said, “As much again as his body is long” ,

original: attho. Teneva yāvatakvassa kāyotiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha yāvatako assāti yāvatakvassa.
analyzed: attho tena iva yāvatakvassa kāyo ti ādi vuttam tattha yāvatakaḥ assa ati yāvatakvassa
translated: and so on. Herein, as much again as his body is long is yāvatakvassa kāyo.🔽Evenly rounded limbs is evenly rounded limbs .

original: Samavaṭṭakkhandhoti samavaṭṭitakkhandho. Yathā eke koñcā viya ca bakā viya ca varāhā
analyzed: samavaṭṭa khandho ti samavaṭṭita kkhandhaḥ yathā eke koñcāḥ viya ca bakāḥ viya ca varāhā
translated: While the limbs of some are like a crane’s or a heron’s or a pig’s,

original: viya ca dīghagalā vaṅkagalā puthulagalā ca honti, kathanakāle sirājālaṃ paññāyati,
analyzed: ca dīgha galā vaṅka galā puthula galā ca honti kathana kāle sirā jālam paññāyati
translated: long-jointed, crooked-jointed, or thick-jointed, and when they speak their jawbones rattle like castanets,

analyzed: mandaḥ saraḥ nikkhamati na evam mahā purisassa mahā purisassa pana su vaṭṭita suvaṇṇa āḷiṅga sadisaḥ
translated: the Great Man’s limbs are not like that. His limbs are like well-turned ivory ornaments,

analyzed: khandhaḥ hoti kathana kāle sirā jālam na paññāyati meghassa viya gajjitaḥ saraḥ mahā hoti
translated: and when he speaks his voice is as majestic as the rumbling of a cloud.

analyzed: ettha rasam gasanti haranti iti adhivacanam
translated: He has the jaws of a lion is rasaggasaggī . Herein, they devour the taste , thus they are devourers of taste ; this is a term for the sense-desire element.

analyzed: tāḥ aggāḥ assa ati rasagga saggī mahā purisassa kira satta rasa haraṇī sahassāni uddhaggāni
translated: They are the best of tastes, thus he is the one with the best of tastes. The Great Man, it seems, having made a fire of twenty-thousand myrobalans,

analyzed: hutvā paṭimukkāni tila phala mattaḥ api āhāraḥ jivhagge ṭhapito sabba kāyam  anupharati tena iva mahā padhānam padahantassa
translated: put them on his neck and then the food placed in his mouth, even if it was only a grain of rice,

original: kāyassa yāpanaṃ ahosi. Aññesaṃ pana tathā abhāvā na sakalaṃ kāyaṃ ojā pharati. Tena
analyzed: kāyassa yāpanam ahosi aññesam pana tathā abhāvā na sakalam kāyam ojā pharati tena
translated: spread through his whole body. So when he was doing the Great Ascetic Practice, he was able to maintain his body on a mere hundred palas of black gram curry and so on, with a grain of rice in it. But because others are not like that, the nutriment does not spread through their whole body. Consequently

original: te bahvābādhā honti.
analyzed: te bahu ābādhāḥ honti
translated: they are afflicted with much illness.

original: Sīhasseva hanu assāti sīhahanu. Tattha sīhassa heṭṭhimahanumeva paripuṇṇaṃ hoti,🔽na uparimaṃ. Mahāpurisassa pana sīhassa heṭṭhimaṃ viya dvepi paripuṇṇāni dvādasiyā
analyzed: sīhassa iva hanu assa ati sīha hanu tattha sīhassa heṭṭhima hanum eva paripuṇṇam hoti  na uparimam mahāpurisassa pana sīhassa heṭṭhimam viya dve pi paripuṇṇāni
translated: He has a jaw like a lion’s, thus he is the one with a lion’s jaw. Herein, the lower jaw of a lion is complete,

analyzed: pakkhassa canda sadisāni honti atha nemittakāḥ hanuka pariyantam olokentā ava imesu hanukesu
translated: but not the upper one. But in the Great Man the two jaws are complete like the lower one of a lion, and they are twelve-peaked like the moon. Then the augurs, looking only as far as the jaws,

analyzed: heṭṭhime vīsati uparime vīsati iti cattālīsa dantā samā aviraḷā patiṭṭhahissanti iti sallakkhetvā
translated: “Twenty below and twenty above” means that he will have forty teeth, even and without gaps.

analyzed: ayan hi deva kumāraḥ cattālīsa dantaḥ hoti iti ādim āhaṃsu tatra ayam atthaḥ aññesam hi paripuṇṇa dantānam pi
translated: “Your majesty, this prince has forty teeth.” The meaning is this: Other people, even though they have a full complement of teeth,

analyzed: dvattiṃsa dantāḥ honti imassa pana cattālīsam bhavissanti aññesam ca keci dantāḥ uccā  keci nīcā ati visamāḥ honti imassa pana chinna saṅkha paṭalam viya samāḥ
translated: have only thirty-two teeth. But this prince will have forty. And while the teeth of others are uneven,🔽some long and some short, this prince’s teeth will be even,🔽like the surface of a moha-viya mirror. And while the teeth of others are set with gaps between them,

analyzed: tūlikāya dassita paricchedāḥ viya dantāḥ bhavissanti aññesam ca pūti dantāḥ uṭṭhahanti 🔽tena kāci dāṭhā kāḷā api vivaṇṇā api honti ayam pana suṭṭhu sukka dāṭhaḥ osadhi tārakam pi
translated: this prince’s teeth will be pure white, like jasmine flowers or snow or oyster-shells or well-refined silver.

original: atikkamma virocamānāya pabhāya samannāgatadāṭho bhavissati.🔽Pahūtajivhoti puthulajivho. Aññesaṃ jivhā thūlāpi honti kisāpi rassāpi thaddhāpi🔽visamāpi, mahāpurisassa pana jivhā mudu dīghā puthulā vaṇṇasampannā hoti. So hi etaṃ🔽lakkhaṇaṃ pariyesituṃ āgatānaṃ kaṅkhāvinodanatthaṃ mudukattā taṃ jivhaṃ kathinasūciṃ
analyzed: atikkamma virocamānāya pabhāya samannāgata dāṭhaḥ bhavissati  pahūta jivho ti puthula jivhaḥ aññesam jivhā thūlā api honti kisā api rassā api thaddhā api  mahā purisassa pana jivhā mudu dīghā puthulā vaṇṇa sampannā hoti saḥ hi etam  lakkhaṇam pariyesitum āgatānam kaṅkhā vinodana attham mudu kattā tam jivham kathina sūcim
translated: his teeth will be even, without any gaps.🔽He will have a large tongue: his tongue will be broad. The tongues of others are thick, short, small, stiff,

original: viya vaṭṭetvā ubho nāsikasotāni parāmasati, dīghattā ubho kaṇṇasotāni parāmasati,🔽puthulattā kesantapariyosānaṃ kevalampi nalāṭaṃ paṭicchādeti. Evamassa mududīghaputhulabhāvaṃ
analyzed: viya vaṭṭetvā ubhaḥ nāsika sotāni parāmasati dīghattā ubhaḥ kaṇṇa sotāni parāmasati  puthula ttā kesanta pariyosānam kevalam pi nalāṭam paṭicchādeti evam assa mudu dīgha puthula bhāvam
translated: uneven, but the tongue of the Great Man is soft, long, broad, and well-formed. In order to remove the doubts of those who have come to investigate this mark, he rolls his tongue up and touches both ear holes and both nostrils with it, as if it were a stiff thread.

original: pakāsento tesaṃ kaṅkhaṃ vinodeti. Evaṃ tilakkhaṇasampannaṃ jivhaṃ sandhāya “pahūtajivho”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: pakāsento tesam kaṅkham vinodeti evam ti lakkhaṇa sampannam jivham sandhāya pahūta jivhaḥ ti vuttam
translated: By this he shows his tongue’s softness, length, and breadth, and he removes their doubts. “He will have a large tongue” is said with reference to a tongue endowed with these three characteristics.

original: Brahmassaroti aññe chinnassarāpi bhinnassarāpi kākassarāpi honti, ayaṃ pana mahābrahmuno
analyzed: brahmassarā uti aññe chinnassarā api bhinnassarā api kākassarā api honti ayam pana
translated: He will have a divine voice: the voices of others are broken, split, and crow-like, but the voice of the Great Man is like the call of the kalaviṅka bird.

original: sarasadisena sarena samannāgato bhavissati, mahābrahmuno hi pittasemhehi apalibuddhattā
analyzed: sara sadisena sarena samannāgataḥ bhavissati mahābrahmunaḥ hi pitta semhehi a palibuddha ttā
translated: He will have a voice like Brahmā’s, for Brahmā’s voice is clear because he is free from bile and phlegm.

original: saro visado hoti. Mahāpurisenāpi katakammaṃ tassa vatthuṃ sodheti. Vatthuno suddhattā
analyzed: saraḥ visadaḥ hoti mahā purisena api kata kammam tassa vatthum sodheti vatthuno suddha ttā
translated: The Great Man’s past action purifies the place of his birth.

original: nābhito paṭṭhāya samuṭṭhahanto saro visado aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgatova samuṭṭhāti. Karavīko
analyzed: nābhitas paṭṭhāya samuṭṭhahanto saraḥ visadaḥ aṭṭhaṅga samannāgataḥ uva samuṭṭhāti karavīko
translated: Because the place is pure, the voice that arises from there is clear and possesses the eight characteristics.

original: viya bhaṇatīti karavīkabhāṇī, mattakaravīkarutamañjughosoti attho.🔽Abhinīlanettoti na sakalanīlanetto, nīlayuttaṭṭhāne panassa umāpupphasadisena ativisuddhena
analyzed: viya bhaṇati iti karavīka bhāṇī matta karavīka ruta mañjughoso ti attho  abhinīla netto ti na sakala nīla netto nīla yutta ṭṭhāne panassa umā puppha sadisena ati visuddhena
translated: He speaks with a voice like that of a karavīka bird. The meaning is that his voice is as sweet as the call of a karavīka bird.🔽He has eyes that are very dark blue. His eyes are not entirely dark blue, but the eyes that are suitable to be dark blue are very pure, like the umā flower.

original: nīlavaṇṇena samannāgatāni nettāni honti, pītayuttaṭṭhāne kaṇikārapupphasadisena pītavaṇṇena,🔽lohitayuttaṭṭhāne bandhujīvakapupphasadisena lohitavaṇṇena, setayuttaṭṭhāne osadhitārakasadisena
analyzed: nīla vaṇṇena samannāgatāni nettāni honti pīta yutta ṭṭhāne kaṇikāra puppha sadisena pīta vaṇṇena  lohita yutta ṭṭhāne bandhujīvaka puppha sadisena lohita vaṇṇena seta yutta ṭṭhāne osadhi tāraka sadisena
translated: The eyes that are suitable to be yellow are yellow like the kaṇikāra flower.🔽The eyes that are suitable to be red are red like the bandhujīvaka flower. The eyes that are suitable to be white are white like the osadhitāraka star.

original: setavaṇṇena, kāḷayuttaṭṭhāne addāriṭṭhakasadisena kāḷavaṇṇena samannāgatāni. Suvaṇṇavimāne
analyzed: seta vaṇṇena kāḷa yutta ṭṭhāne addāriṭṭhaka sadisena kāḷa vaṇṇena samannāgatāni suvaṇṇa vimāne
translated: The eyes that are suitable to be black are black like the addāriṭṭhaka gem. In the golden palace of the gods,

original: ugghāṭitamaṇisīhapañjarasadisāni khāyanti.
analyzed: ugghāṭita maṇi sīha pañjara sadisāni khāyanti
translated: They are like a lion’s cage with its door thrown open.

original: Gopakhumoti ettha pakhumanti sakalacakkhubhaṇḍaṃ adhippetaṃ, taṃ kāḷavacchakassa🔽bahaladhātukaṃ hoti, rattavacchakassa vippasannaṃ, taṃmuhuttajātataruṇarattavacchakasadisacakkhubhaṇḍoti🔽attho. Aññesañhi cakkhubhaṇḍā aparipuṇṇā honti, hatthimūsikādīnaṃ akkhisadisehi viniggatehipi
analyzed: gopakhumo ti ettha pakhumanti sakala cakkhu bhaṇḍam adhippetam tam kāḷavacchakassa  bahala dhātukam hoti ratta vacchakassa vippasannam tad muhutta jāta taruṇa ratta vacchaka sadisa cakkhubhaṇḍaḥ ti  atthaḥ aññesam hi cakkhu bhaṇḍāḥ a paripuṇṇāḥ honti hatthi mūsika ādīnam akkhi sadisehi viniggatehi pi
translated: Gopakhumo: here the word pakhuma is intended to mean the whole eye. It is thick in the case of a black bird,🔽and clear in the case of a red bird. The meaning is that the eye is like the eye of a very young red bird just hatched.🔽For the eyes of other beings are incomplete. The eyes of elephants, mice, etc., are deep-set and protruding,

original: gambhīrehipi akkhīhi samannāgatā honti. Mahāpurisassa pana dhovitvā majjitvā ṭhapitamaṇiguḷikā
analyzed: gambhīrehi pi akkhīhi samannāgatāḥ honti mahāpurisassa pana dhovitvā majjitvā ṭhapita maṇi guḷikā
translated: and they have only two eyes. But the eyes of the Great Man are like two polished crystal beads,

original: viya mudusiniddhanīlasukhumapakhumācitāni akkhīni.
analyzed: viya akkhīni
translated: with eyelashes as fine and soft as a yak’s tail washed and laid aside.

original: Uṇṇāti uṇṇalomaṃ. Bhamukantareti dvinnaṃ bhamukānaṃ vemajjhe nāsikamatthakeyeva jātā,
analyzed: uṇṇā ati uṇṇa lomam bhamuka antarā iti dvinnam bhamukānam vemajjhe
translated: Uṇṇā: the hair on the forehead. Bhamukantare: between the eyebrows, on the forehead itself.

original: uggantvā pana nalāṭavemajjhe jātā. Odātāti parisuddhā, osadhitārakasamānavaṇṇā. Mudūti
analyzed: uggantvā pana nalāṭa vemajjhe jātā odātā ati parisuddhā osadhi tāraka samāna vaṇṇā
translated: But it grows up in the middle of the forehead, like a star of pure crystal, soft,

original: sappimaṇḍe osāretvā ṭhapitasatavāravihatakappāsapaṭalasadisā. Tūlasannibhāti simbalitūlalatātūlasamānā,
analyzed: sappi maṇḍe osāretvā ṭhapita sata vāra vihata kappāsa paṭala sadisā tūla sannibhā ati simbali tūla latā tūla samānā
translated: and it is like a hundred-weight of cotton wool spread out on a slab of cotton-wool-wood. It is like cotton-wool in being like a tuft of cotton-wool.

original: ayamassa odātatāya upamā. Sā panesā koṭiyaṃ gahetvā ākaḍḍhiyamānā upaḍḍhabāhuppamāṇā🔽hoti, vissaṭṭhā dakkhiṇāvaṭṭavasena āvaṭṭitvā uddhaggā hutvā santiṭṭhati. Suvaṇṇaphalakamajjhe🔽ṭhapitarajatapubbuḷakaṃ viya, suvaṇṇaghaṭato nikkhamamānā khīradhārā viya, aruṇappabhārañjite
analyzed: ayam assa odāta tāya upamā sā pana isā koṭiyam gahetvā ākaḍḍhiyamānā upaḍḍha bāhu ppamāṇā  hoti vissaṭṭhā dakkhiṇa avaṭṭa vasena āvaṭṭitvā uddhaggā hutvā santiṭṭhati suvaṇṇa phalaka majjhe  ṭhapita rajata pubbuḷakam viya suvaṇṇa ghaṭataḥ nikkhamamānā khīra dhārā viya aruṇa ppabhā rañjite
translated: This is the simile for its whiteness. But when it is seized at the tip and pulled, it is about the length of a forearm.🔽When it is loosened, it curls up to the right and stands up straight. It is as though it were a silver bubble placed in the middle of a golden plate,

original: gaganappadese osadhitārakā viya ca atimanoharāya siriyā virocati.
analyzed: gagana ppadese osadhi tārakā ca ati manoharāya siriyā virocati
translated: or a stream of milk flowing from a golden vase, or medicinal herbs in a part of the sky made lovely by the glow of dawn. It is radiant with a beauty that is most delightful.

original: Uṇhīsasīsoti idaṃ paripuṇṇanalāṭatañca paripuṇṇasīsataṃ cāti dve atthavase paṭicca
analyzed: idam paripuṇṇa nalāṭa tam ca paripuṇṇa sīsa tam ca ati dve attha vase paṭicca
translated: He has a head like a turban-coil: this was said of him because of two reasons, namely, because of his forehead being quite full and because of his head being quite full.

original: vuttaṃ. Mahāpurisassa hi dakkhiṇakaṇṇacūḷikato paṭṭhāya maṃsapaṭalaṃ uṭṭhahitvā sakalanalāṭaṃ
analyzed: vuttam mahā purisassa hi dakkhiṇa kaṇṇa cūḷikataḥ paṭṭhāya maṃsa paṭalam uṭṭhahitvā sakala nalāṭam
translated: For in a Great Man the flesh-pad rises up from the point of the right ear-hole and covers the whole of the forehead,

original: chādayamānaṃ pūrayamānaṃ gantvā vāmakaṇṇacūḷikāyaṃ patiṭṭhitaṃ, taṃ rañño bandhauṇhīsapaṭṭo
analyzed: chādayamānam pūrayamānam gantvā vāma kaṇṇa cūḷikāyam patiṭṭhitam tam raññaḥ bandha oṇhīsa paṭṭaḥ
translated: and having gone, it stood in the left ear-hole, covering and filling it, like a turban for the King’s head.

original: viya virocati. Mahāpurisassa kira imaṃ lakkhaṇaṃ disvā rājūnaṃ uṇhīsapaṭṭaṃ akaṃsu.
analyzed: viya virocati mahā purisassa kira imam lakkhaṇam disvā uṇhīsa paṭṭam akaṃsu
translated: It covers and fills up the whole head and comes to rest at the left ear-hole. It shines like a turban-wrap on the king’s head. It is said that after seeing this mark of the Great Man, kings had turban-wraps made.

original: Ayaṃ tāva eko attho. Aññe pana janā aparipuṇṇasīsā honti, keci kapisīsā, keci phalasīsā,
analyzed: ayam tāva ekaḥ atthaḥ aññe pana janā a paripuṇṇa sīsāḥ honti keci kapi sīsā keci phala sīsā
translated: This is one meaning. But other people have incomplete heads, some have monkey-heads, some have fruit-heads,

original: keci aṭṭhisīsā, keci hatthisīsā, keci tumbasīsā, keci pabbhārasīsā. Mahāpurisassa
analyzed: keci aṭṭhi sīsā keci hatthi sīsā keci tumba sīsā keci pabbhāra sīsā mahāpurisassa
translated: some have bone-heads, some have elephant-heads, some have pumpkin-heads, some have flat-heads. But the Great Man’s

original: pana āraggena vaṭṭetvā ṭhapitaṃ viya suparipuṇṇaṃ udakapubbuḷasadisaṃ sīsaṃ hoti.🔽Tattha purimanaye uṇhīsaveṭhitasīso viyāti uṇhīsasīso. Dutiyanaye uṇhīsaṃ viya sabbattha
analyzed: pana āraggena vaṭṭetvā ṭhapitam viya su paripuṇṇam udaka pubbuḷa sadisam sīsam hoti  tattha purima naye uṇhīsa veṭhita sīsaḥ viya ati uṇhīsa sīsaḥ dutiya naye uṇhīsam viya sabbattha
translated: head is complete, like a ball set on a pivot, and is like a water bubble.

original: parimaṇḍalasīsoti uṇhīsasīso.
analyzed: parimaṇḍala sīsaḥ ti uṇhīsa sīsaḥ
translated: Herein, in the first case, he has a head like a turban-wrap, thus he is a head-wrap-wearer . In the second case, he has a head that is all round like a turban, thus he is a head-wrap-wearer.

original: Vipassīsamaññāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: vipassī samaññā vaṇṇanā
translated: The Description of the Name Vipassi

original: 37. Sabbakāmehīti idaṃ lakkhaṇāni pariggaṇhāpetvā pacchā kataṃ viya vuttaṃ, na panevaṃ
analyzed: sabba kāmehi iti idam lakkhaṇāni pariggaṇhāpetvā pacchā katam viya vuttam na pana evam
translated: All desires satisfied: this is said as if it were spoken after discerning the marks, but it was not spoken then.

original: daṭṭhabbaṃ. Paṭhamañhi te nemittake santappetvā pacchā lakkhaṇapariggaṇhanaṃ katanti
analyzed: daṭṭhabbam paṭhamam hi te nemittake santappetvā pacchā lakkhaṇa pariggaṇhanam katanti
translated: should be understood. For the first of these was to satisfy the diviners, and only afterwards did he have the characteristics discerned.🔽The details are given in the Description of the Conception.

original: veditabbaṃ. Tassa vitthāro gabbhokkantiyaṃ vuttoyeva. Pāyentīti thaññaṃ pāyenti.🔽Tassa kira niddosena madhurena khīrena samannāgatā saṭṭhi dhātiyo upaṭṭhāpesi, tathā
analyzed: veditabbam tassa vitthāro gabbhokkantiyam vutto yeva pāyenti iti thaññam pāyenti  tassa kira niddosena madhurena khīrena samannāgatā saṭṭhi dhātiyaḥ upaṭṭhāpesi tathā
translated: They gave him milk: they gave him milk to drink.🔽It seems that he had sixty nurses who gave him milk, for he was endowed with milk of a special quality, sweet and free from impurities.

original: sesāpi tesu tesu kammesu kusalā saṭṭhisaṭṭhiyeva. Tāsaṃ pesanakārake saṭṭhi purise,
analyzed: sesā api tesu tesu kammesu kusalā tāsam pesana kārake saṭṭhi purise
translated: And he had sixty nurses for each of the other duties, skilled in their several tasks,🔽and sixty men to carry the messages to them,

original: tassa tassa katākatabhāvaṃ sallakkhaṇe saṭṭhi amacce upaṭṭhāpesi. Evaṃ cattāri saṭṭhiyo
analyzed: tassa tassa kata a kata bhāvam sat lakkhaṇe saṭṭhi amacce upaṭṭhāpesi evam cattāri saṭṭhiyaḥ
translated: and sixty ministers to supervise the performance of their duties. Thus there were four times sixty

analyzed: itthīnam dve saṭṭhiyaḥ purisānanti cha saṭṭhiyaḥ upaṭṭhakānam yeva ahesum seta chattanti
translated: women, and two times sixty men, that is, sixty times six, who attended on him. The white parasol:

analyzed: dibba seta chattam kuladattiyam pana sirigabbheyā iva tiṭṭhati mā nam sītam vāti ādīsu
translated: the divine white parasol. But in the Kula tradition it is said to have been in the House of Glory. The meaning should be understood as follows: “Let not cold, wind, etc.,

original: mā abhibhavīti attho veditabbo. Svāssudanti so assudaṃ. Aṅkeneva aṅkanti aññassa
analyzed: mā abhibhavīti atthaḥ veditabbo su āssudanti saḥ aṅkena iva aññassa
translated: overcome him.” The horse Kaṇṭaka: the horse Kaṇṭaka. With his own body: with his own body.

original: bāhunāva aññassa bāhuṃ. Aññassa ca aṃsakūṭeneva aññassa aṃsakūṭaṃ. Parihariyatīti
analyzed: bāhunā ava aññassa bāhum aññassa ca aṃsa kūṭena iva aññassa aṃsa kūṭam parihariyati iti
translated: ‘Is avoided’:

analyzed: nīyati sampāpiyati iti attho
translated: is removed, is done away with, is the meaning.

original: 38. Mañjussaroti akharassaro. Vaggussaroti chekanipuṇassaro. Madhurassaroti sātassaro.
analyzed: mañjussaro ti akharassaraḥ vaggussaro ti cheka nipuṇa ssaraḥ madhurassaro ti sātassaro
translated: ‘Sweet-voiced’: not harsh-voiced. ‘Clear-voiced’: distinct and clever-voiced. ‘Honey-voiced’: pleasant-voiced.

original: Pemaniyassaroti pemajanakassaro. Tatridaṃ karavīkānaṃ madhurassaratāya – karavīkasakuṇe
analyzed: tatra idam karavīkānam madhurassaratāya karavīka sakuṇe
translated: ‘Dear-voiced’: voice-producing-affection. Herein, as to the honey-voicedness of the partridge, it seems that

analyzed: kira madhura rasam amba pakkam mukhatuṇḍakena paharitvā paggharita rasam pivitvā pakkhena
translated: partridge-birds, having hit with their beaks a ripe mango of sweet juice, drink the juice that exudes, and then,

original: tālaṃ datvā vikūjamāne catuppadā mattā viya laḷituṃ ārabhanti. Gocarapasutāpi catuppadā
analyzed: tālam da tvā vikūjamāne catuppadāḥ mattāḥ viya laḷitum ārabhanti gocarapasutā api catuppadā
translated: having given a wing-flap, they begin to dance as if they were intoxicated. Even quadrupeds that have gone out to pasture

original: mukhagatāni tiṇāni chaḍḍetvā taṃ saddaṃ suṇanti. Vāḷamigā khuddakamige anubandhamānā
analyzed: mukha gatāni tiṇāni chaḍḍetvā tam saddam suṇanti vāḷa migā khuddaka mige anubandhamānā
translated: drop the grass in their mouths and listen to that sound. Deer that are pursuing small deer

analyzed: ukkhittam pādam a nikkhipitvā ava tiṭṭhanti anubaddha migā ca maraṇa bhayam jahitvā tiṭṭhanti
translated: stand still without putting down the foot that is lifted up. And the deer that are being pursued stand still, having laid aside their fear of death.

original: Ākāse pakkhandā pakkhinopi pakkhe pasāretvā taṃ saddaṃ suṇamānāva tiṭṭhanti. Udake
analyzed: ākāse pakkhandā pakkhinaḥ api pakkhe pasāretvā tam saddam suṇamānā ava tiṭṭhanti udake
translated: Even birds in the sky, stretching out their wings, stand still listening to that sound. In the water

original: macchāpi kaṇṇapaṭalaṃ papphoṭetvā taṃ saddaṃ suṇamānāva tiṭṭhanti. Evaṃ madhurassarā karavīkā.🔽Asandhimittāpi dhammāsokassa devī – “atthi nu kho, bhante, buddhassarena sadiso kassaci
analyzed: macchā api kaṇṇa paṭalam papphoṭetvā tam saddam suṇamānā ava tiṭṭhanti evam madhurassarā karavīkā  a sandhi mittā api dhamma asokassa devī atthi nu kho bhante buddhassarena sadisaḥ kassaci
translated: fish, slapping their fins, stand still listening to that sound. So sweet-voiced are the cuckoos.

original: saro”ti saṅghaṃ pucchi. Atthi karavīkasakuṇassāti. Kuhiṃ, bhante, te sakuṇāti? Himavanteti.🔽Sā rājānaṃ āha – “deva, ahaṃ karavīkasakuṇaṃ passitukāmāmhī”ti. Rājā – “imasmiṃ pañjare🔽nisīditvā karavīko āgacchatū”ti suvaṇṇapañjaraṃ vissajjesi. Pañjaro gantvā ekassa
analyzed: saroti saṅgham pucchi atthi karavīka sakuṇassa ati kuhim bhante te sakuṇā ati himavanta iti  sā rājānam āha deva aham karavīka sakuṇam passitu kāmā amhi iti rājā imasmim pañjare  nisīditvā karavīkaḥ āgacchatu uti suvaṇṇa pañjaram vissajjesi pañjaraḥ gantvā ekassa
translated: Even Asandhimittā, the queen of Dhammayu, asked the Order: “Is there, revered sirs, anyone’s voice like that of the Buddha?” They said: “There is the voice of the cuckoo bird.” “Where, revered sirs, are those birds?” “In the Himalayas.”

translated: What else can be born or reborn beyond this? Is it not just this that is born and re-arises?🔽Having thus shown the five terms with the successive fall and rebirth, he now concludes the meaning of the words “to this extent” by saying, “When there is consciousness as condition, there is mentality-materiality; when there is mentality-materiality as condition, there is consciousness” .

original: āyatimpi jātijarāmaraṇaṃ dassetuṃ nāmarūpapaccayā saḷāyatanantiādimāha. Tattha kevalassa
