analyzed: obhāsaṭṭhaḥ attho ti ettakehi padehi kim kathitam ti imasmin sati idam hoti iti paccaya sañjānana mattam  kathitam athavā vīthi paṭipannā taruṇa vipassanā kathitā ati  adhigataḥ kho myāyanti adhigataḥ kho me ayam maggo ti vipassanā maggaḥ bodhāya ati  catu sacca bujjhana tthāya nibbāna bujjhana tthāya eva vā api ca bujjhati iti bodhi ariya maggassa etam  nāmam tad atthāya ati pi vuttam hoti vipassanā magga mūlakaḥ hi ariya maggaḥ ti idāni tam

With the arising of craving … With the arising of kamma … With the arising of nutriment there is the arising of matter. Seeing the characteristic of generation, he sees the origin of the materiality aggregate” .🔽This is how it should be understood.

original: rūpakkhandhassa nirodhaṃ passatī”ti ayamassa vitthāro.
analyzed: rūpakkhandhassa nirodham passati iti ayam assa vitthāro
translated: And in the case of cessation: “With the cessation of ignorance there is the cessation of matter. … With the cessation of nutriment there is the cessation of matter. Seeing the characteristic of change, he sees the cessation of the materiality aggregate” . This is the detailed explanation.

original: Iti vedanātiādīsupi ayaṃ vedanā, ettakā vedanā, ito uddhaṃ vedanā natthi. Ayaṃ saññā,
analyzed: iti vedanā ati ādīsu pi ayam vedanā ettakā vedanā itas uddham vedanā na atthi ayam saññā
translated: “Thus feeling” and so on: this is feeling, so much feeling, no more than this is feeling. This is perception,🔽these are formations, this is consciousness, so much consciousness, no more than this is consciousness.

original: ime saṅkhārā, idaṃ viññāṇaṃ, ettakaṃ viññāṇaṃ, ito uddhaṃ viññāṇaṃ natthīti vedayitasañjānanaabhisaṅkharaṇavijānanasabhāvañceva
analyzed: ime saṅkhārāḥ idam viññāṇam ettakam viññāṇam itas uddham viññāṇam natthi iti vedayita sañjānana abhisaṅkharaṇa vijānana sabhāvañca iva
translated: And he defines feeling, perception, formations, and consciousness without exception by their individual essences as the states of being felt, of perceiving, of forming, and of cognizing,

original: sukhādirūpasaññādi phassādi cakkhuviññāṇādi bhedañca ādiṃ katvā lakkhaṇarasapaccupaṭṭhānapadaṭṭhānavasena
analyzed: sukha ādi rūpa saññā ādi phassa ādi cakkhu viññāṇa ādi bhedam ca ādim katvā lakkhaṇa rasa paccupaṭṭhāna padaṭṭhāna vasena
translated: and by their specific characteristics, functions, etc., as pleasant, painful, and neither-painful-nor-pleasant, as the perception of visible objects, etc., as contact, etc., and as eye-consciousness, etc.

original: anavasesavedanāsaññāsaṅkhāraviññāṇapariggaho vutto. Iti vedanāya samudayotiādīhi
analyzed: anavasesa vedanā saññā saṅkhāra viññāṇa pariggahaḥ vuttaḥ iti vedanāya samudayaḥ ti ādīhi
translated: “Thus with the arising of ignorance” and so on:

original: pana evaṃ pariggahitānaṃ vedanāsaññāsaṅkhāraviññāṇānaṃ samudayadassanaṃ vuttaṃ. Tatrāpi🔽itīti evaṃ samudayo hotīti attho. Tesampi vitthāro – “avijjāsamudayā vedanāsamudayo”ti
analyzed: pana evam pariggahitānam vedanā saññā saṅkhāra viññāṇānam samudaya dassanam vuttam tatra api  iti iti evam samudayaḥ hoti iti attho tesam pi vitthāraḥ
translated: this is said to show the seeing of the arising of feeling, perception, formations, and consciousness, which have been defined in the way just described.🔽Herein,🔽the meaning is that the arising is thus. The detailed explanation of these should be understood in the way given under the case of form.

original: rūpe vuttanayeneva veditabbo. Ayaṃ pana viseso – tīsu khandhesu “āhārasamudayā”ti
analyzed: rūpe vutta nayena iva veditabbaḥ ayam pana visesaḥ tīsu khandhesu āhāra samudayā ti
translated: But there is this difference. In the case of the three aggregates beginning with feeling, “with the arising of nutriment” should be supplied.

original: avatvā “phassasamudayā”ti vattabbaṃ. Viññāṇakkhandhe “nāmarūpasamudayā”ti atthaṅgamapadampi🔽tesaṃyeva vasena yojetabbaṃ. Ayamettha saṅkhepo, vitthāro pana udayabbayavinicchayo
analyzed: a vatvā phassa samudayā ti vattabbam viññāṇa kkhandhe nāma rūpa samudayā ti atthaṅgama padam pi  tesam yeva vasena yojetabbam ayam ettha saṅkhepaḥ vitthāraḥ pana udaya bbaya vinicchayo
translated: and it should be said “with the arising of contact” instead of “with the arising of name-and-form.”🔽The passage beginning, “With the arising of ignorance” should be construed in the same way with the other four aggregates.

original: sabbākāraparipūro visuddhimagge vutto. Tassa pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu udayabbayānupassino
analyzed: sabba ākāra paripūraḥ visuddhi magge vuttaḥ tassa pañcasu upādāna khandhesu udaya bbaya anupassinaḥ
translated: This is the brief treatment here. The detailed treatment, however, is given in the Path of Purification in the chapter on the exposition of insight .🔽When he abides contemplating rise and fall in the five aggregates affected by clinging,

original: viharatoti tassa vipassissa bodhisattassa imesu rūpādīsu pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu
analyzed: viharato ti tassa vipassissa bodhisattassa imesu rūpa ādīsu pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu
translated: in these five aggregates beginning with form,🔽contemplating their rise and fall by defining them according to the characteristic of rise and fall,

original: samapaññāsalakkhaṇavasena udayabbayānupassino viharato yathānukkamena vaḍḍhite vipassanāñāṇe
analyzed: sama paññāsa lakkhaṇa vasena udaya bbaya anupassinaḥ viharataḥ yathānukkamena vaḍḍhite vipassanā ñāṇe
translated: as his insight knowledge grows in the way already described,

original: anuppādanirodhena nirujjhamānehi āsavasaṅkhātehi kilesehi anupādāya aggahetvāva cittaṃ🔽vimuccati, tadetaṃ maggakkhaṇe vimuccati nāma, phalakkhaṇe vimuttaṃ nāma; maggakkhaṇe
analyzed: anuppāda nirodhena nirujjhamānehi āsava saṅkhātehi kilesehi an upādāya aggahetvā ava cittam  vimuccati tat etam magga kkhaṇe vimuccati nāma phala kkhaṇe vimuttam nāma magga kkhaṇe
translated: his mind is liberated by non-clinging, that is, without taking anything as “I” or “mine,” from defilements that can be eliminated by insight.🔽This is called “liberated” at the moment of the path, and “liberated” at the moment of fruition.

original: vā vimuttañceva vimuccati ca, phalakkhaṇe vimuttameva.
analyzed: vā vimuttam ca iva vimuccati ca phala kkhaṇe vimuttam eva
translated: Or it is “liberated” and “being liberated” at the moment of the path, and “liberated” only at the moment of fruition.

original: Ettāvatā ca mahāpuriso sabbabandhanā vippamutto sūriyarasmisamphuṭṭhamiva padumaṃ
analyzed: ettāvatā ca mahā purisaḥ sabba bandhanā vippamuttaḥ sūriya rasmi samphuṭṭham iva padumam

translated: with his heart’s entire entanglement completely destroyed, like a lotus untouched by water,🔽with his heart’s entire entanglement completely destroyed, like a lotus untouched by water,

analyzed: catu yoni paricchedaka ñāṇam pañca gati paricchedaka ñāṇam cha asādhāraṇa ñāṇāni sakale  ca buddha guṇe hattha gate katvā paripuṇṇa saṅkappaḥ bodhi pallaṅke nisinnaḥ uva
translated: with his heart’s entire entanglement completely destroyed, like a lotus untouched by water,🔽with his heart’s entire entanglement completely destroyed, like a lotus untouched by water,

analyzed: aneka jāti saṃsāram sandhāvissam anibbisam  gahakāram gavesantaḥ dukkhā jāti punappunam  gahakāraka diṭṭhaḥ asi puna geham na

analyzed: sabbā te phāsukā bhaggā gaha kūṭam visaṅkhatam  visaṅkhāra gatam cittam taṇhānam khayam ajjhagāti

analyzed: ayaḥ ghana hatassa iva jalataḥ jātavedaso  anupubbūpasantassa yathā na ñāyate gati

analyzed: evam sammā vimuttānam kāma bandha ogha tārinam
translated: with his heart’s entire entanglement completely destroyed, like a lotus

original: Paññāpetuṃ gati natthi, pattānaṃ acalaṃ sukha”nti. ;
analyzed: paññāpetum gati natthi pattānam acalam sukhanti
translated: There is no way to describe it, The bliss of the unshakable attainment.”

original: Evaṃ manasi karonto sarade sūriyo viya, puṇṇacando viya ca virocitthāti.
analyzed: evam manasi karontaḥ sarade sūriyaḥ viya puṇṇa candaḥ viya ca virocittha ati
translated: Thus, as he reflected, he shone like the sun in autumn, like the full moon.

original: Dutiyabhāṇavāravaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: dutiya bhāṇa vāra vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the second recitation section is finished.

original: Brahmayācanakathāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: brahma yācana kathā vaṇṇanā
translated: The story of Brahmā’s invitation

original: 64. Tatiyabhāṇavāre yaṃnūnāhaṃ dhammaṃ deseyyanti yadi panāhaṃ dhammaṃ deseyyaṃ.
analyzed: tatiya bhāṇavāre yaṃ nūna aham dhammaṃ deseyyanti yadi pana aham dhammam deseyyam
translated: “If I were to teach the Dhamma, there would be none to understand me” means “If I were to teach the Dhamma, there would be none to understand me.”

original: Ayaṃ pana vitakko kadā uppannoti? Buddhabhūtassa aṭṭhame sattāhe. So kira buddho
analyzed: ayam pana vitakko kadā uppanno ti buddha bhūtassa aṭṭhame sattāhe so kira buddhaḥ
translated: But when did this thought occur to him? It occurred to him in the eighth week after his enlightenment. For it seems that the Buddha

original: hutvā sattāhaṃ bodhipallaṅke nisīdi, sattāhaṃ bodhipallaṅkaṃ olokento aṭṭhāsi, sattāhaṃ
analyzed: hutvā sattāham bodhi pallaṅke nisīdi sattāham bodhi pallaṅkaṃ olokento aṭṭhāsi sattāham
translated: sat on the seat of enlightenment for seven days, and for seven days he stood gazing at the seat of enlightenment;

original: ratanacaṅkame caṅkami, sattāhaṃ ratanagabbhe dhammaṃ vicinanto nisīdi, sattāhaṃ ajapālanigrodhe
analyzed: ratana caṅkame caṅkami sattāham ratana gabbhe dhammam vicinantaḥ nisīdi sattāham ajapāla nigrodhe
translated: for seven days he walked up and down in the diamond-dealer’s place; for seven days he sat in the jewel chamber contemplating the Dhamma; for seven days he sat at the Ajapāla banyan tree;

original: nisīdi, sattāhaṃ mucalinde nisīdi, sattāhaṃ rājāyatane nisīdi. Tato uṭṭhāya aṭṭhame
analyzed: nisīdi sattāham mucalinde nisīdi sattāham rājāyatane nisīdi tatas uṭṭhāya aṭṭhame
translated: for seven days he sat at the Mucalinda tree; for seven days he sat in the Rājāyatana tree. Then, rising up,🔽in the eighth week he came again and sat at the Ajapāla banyan tree. As soon as he sat down,

original: sattāhe puna āgantvā ajapālanigrodhe nisinnamattasseva sabbabuddhānaṃ āciṇṇasamāciṇṇo
analyzed: satta ahe puna āgantvā ajapāla nigrodhe nisinna mattassa iva sabba buddhānam āciṇṇa samāciṇṇaḥ
translated: the thought occurred to him: “It is the custom of all Buddhas to go to the Deer Park at Isipatana and set in motion the Wheel of the Dhamma that has not been set in motion before.”

original: ayañceva ito anantaro ca vitakko uppannoti.
analyzed: ayam ca iva itas anantaraḥ ca vitakko uppannoti
translated: and this thought and the next one arose.

original: Tattha adhigatoti paṭividdho. Dhammoti catusaccadhammo. Gambhīroti uttānabhāvapaṭikkhepavacanametaṃ.
analyzed: tattha adhigataḥ ti paṭividdhaḥ dhammaḥ ti catu sacca dhammaḥ gambhīraḥ iti uttāna bhāva paṭikkhepa vacanam etam
translated: Herein, mastered is penetrated. Dhamma is the four noble Truths. Deep is a term for the opposite of what is obvious.

original: Duddasoti gambhīrattāva duddaso dukkhena daṭṭhabbo, na sakkā sukhena daṭṭhuṃ. Duddasattāva
analyzed: duddaso ti gambhīra ttā va duddasaḥ dukkhena daṭṭhabbaḥ na sakkā sukhena daṭṭhum duddasa ttā va
translated: Hard to see is hard to see because of its profundity; it is to be seen with difficulty, not with ease. Because of its hard to see nature

original: duranubodho dukkhena avabujjhitabbo, na sakkā sukhena avabujjhituṃ. Santoti nibbuto.🔽Paṇītoti atappako. Idaṃ dvayaṃ lokuttarameva sandhāya vuttaṃ. Atakkāvacaroti takkena
analyzed: duranubodhaḥ dukkhena avabujjhitabbaḥ na sakkā sukhena avabujjhitum santo ti nibbutaḥ  paṇītaḥ iti atappakaḥ idam dvayam lokuttaram eva sandhāya vuttam a takka avacaraḥ ti takkena
translated: it is hard to comprehend; it is to be comprehended with difficulty, not with ease. Calm is extinguished.

original: avacaritabbo ogāhitabbo na hoti, ñāṇeneva avacaritabbo. Nipuṇoti saṇho. Paṇḍitavedanīyoti
analyzed: avacaritabbaḥ ogāhitabbaḥ na hoti ñāṇena iva avacaritabbaḥ nipuṇaḥ ti saṇhaḥ paṇḍita vedanīyaḥ iti
translated: Excellent is not feverish. This pair is stated with reference to what is supramundane only. Not to be reached by reasoning is not to be entered upon, not to be grasped, by reasoning; it is to be entered upon, to be grasped, by knowledge only. Subtle is gentle. To be known by the wise is to be known by those who practice rightly and are wise.

original: sammāpaṭipadaṃ paṭipannehi paṇḍitehi veditabbo. Ālayarāmāti sattā pañcasu kāmaguṇesu
analyzed: sammā paṭipadam paṭipannehi paṇḍitehi veditabbaḥ ālayarāmā ati sattā pañcasu kāmaguṇesu
translated: Addicted to attachment: beings are addicted to the five strands of sense pleasure,

original: allīyanti, tasmā te ālayāti vuccanti. Aṭṭhasatataṇhāvicaritāni ālayanti, tasmā ālayāti
analyzed: tasmā te ālayā ati vuccanti aṭṭha sata taṇhā vicaritāni ālayanti tasmā ālayā ati
translated: therefore they are called addicted. The eighty-eight ways of behavior of craving are addicted to them, therefore they are called addicted.

original: vuccanti. Tehi ālayehi ramantīti ālayarāmā. Ālayesu ratāti ālayaratā. Ālayesu suṭṭhu🔽muditāti ālayasammuditā. Yatheva hi susajjitaṃ pupphaphalabharitarukkhādisampannaṃ
analyzed: vuccanti tehi ālayehi ramanti iti ālaya rāmāḥ ālayesu ratā ati ālaya ratāḥ ālayesu suṭṭhu  muditā ati ālaya sammuditā yathā iva hi su sajjitam puppha phala bharita rukkha ādi sampannam
translated: They delight in those attachments, thus they are delighting in attachments. They are pleased with attachments, thus they are pleased with attachments. They are well pleased with attachments, thus they are well pleased with attachments.

original: uyyānaṃ paviṭṭho rājā tāya tāya sampattiyā ramati, pamudito āmodito hoti, na ukkaṇṭhati,
analyzed: uyyānam paviṭṭhaḥ rājā tāya tāya sampattiyā ramati pamuditaḥ āmoditaḥ hoti na ukkaṇṭhati
translated: For just as a king who has entered a pleasure garden well laid out with trees laden with flowers and fruits delights in its various excellences, is pleased and gladdened, does not feel the need to go out,

original: sāyaṃ nikkhamituṃ na icchati, evamimehipi kāmālayataṇhālayehi sattā ramanti, saṃsāravaṭṭe🔽pamuditā anukkaṇṭhitā vasanti. Tena nesaṃ bhagavā duvidhampi ālayaṃ uyyānabhūmiṃ
analyzed: sāyam nikkhamitum na icchati evam imehi pi kāma ālaya taṇhā ālayehi sattāḥ ramanti saṃsāra vaṭṭe  pamuditāḥ an ukkaṇṭhitāḥ vasanti tena bhagavā duvidham pi ālayam uyyāna bhūmim
translated: and does not want to leave in the evening, so too, beings delight in these attachments, which are the attachments to sense desires and the attachments to craving,

original: viya dassento – “ālayarāmā”tiādimāha.🔽Yadidanti nipāto, tassa ṭhānaṃ sandhāya – “yaṃ ida”nti, paṭiccasamuppādaṃ sandhāya
analyzed: viya dassentaḥ  yat idam ti nipātaḥ tassa ṭhānam sandhāya yam idam ti paṭiccasamuppādam sandhāya
translated: and they live pleased and satisfied in the round of rebirths. The Blessed One, showing that these two kinds of attachment are like a pleasure garden, says: “Delight in attachments.”🔽The word “yada” is a particle. The meaning should be regarded as follows: “the place” in the sense of “the place where”; “the dependent origination” in the sense of “that which is so”;

original: – “yo aya”nti evamattho daṭṭhabbo. Idappaccayatāpaṭiccasamuppādoti imesaṃ paccayā
analyzed: yaḥ ayanti evamatthaḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ idappaccaya tā paṭiccasamuppādaḥ ti imesam paccayā
translated: and “the conditionality” in the sense of “the conditionality of this.”

original: idappaccayā, idappaccayā eva idappaccayatā, idappaccayatā ca sā paṭiccasamuppādo
analyzed: idappaccayāḥ idappaccayāḥ eva idappaccaya tā idappaccaya tā ca sā paṭiccasamuppādaḥ
translated: “With this as condition” is the state of being with this as condition. And that state of being with this as condition is dependent origination.

original: cāti idappaccayatāpaṭiccasamuppādo. Saṅkhārādipaccayānaṃ avijjādīnaṃ etaṃ adhivacanaṃ.
analyzed: ca ati idappaccaya tā paṭiccasamuppādaḥ saṅkhāra ādi paccayānam avijjā ādīnam etam adhivacanam
translated: This is a designation for ignorance, etc., which are conditions for formations, and so on.

original: Sabbasaṅkhārasamathotiādi sabbaṃ nibbānameva. Yasmā hi taṃ āgamma sabbasaṅkhāravipphanditāni🔽sammanti vūpasammanti tasmā – “sabbasaṅkhārasamatho”ti vuccati. Yasmā ca taṃ āgamma
analyzed: sabba saṅkhāra samatha uti ādi sabbam nibbānam eva yasmā hi tam āgamma sabba saṅkhāra vipphanditāni  sammanti vūpasammanti tasmā sabba saṅkhāra samatho ti vuccati yasmā ca tam āgamma
translated: “The stilling of all formations,” etc., is all Nibbāna. For it is said that all the activities of formations🔽come to rest in it, cease in it,

original: sabbe upadhayo paṭinissaṭṭhā honti, sabbā taṇhā khīyanti, sabbe kilesarāgā virajjanti,
analyzed: sabbe upadhayaḥ paṭinissaṭṭhāḥ honti sabbā taṇhā khīyanti sabbe kilesa rāgāḥ virajjanti
translated: and that all the clingings are relinquished in it, all craving is exhausted, all defilements fade away,

original: sabbaṃ dukkhaṃ nirujjhati, tasmā “sabbūpadhipaṭinissaggo taṇhākkhayo virāgo nirodho”ti
analyzed: sabbam dukkham nirujjhati tasmā sabba upadhi paṭinissaggo taṇhā kkhayaḥ virāgaḥ nirodho ti
translated: and all suffering ceases. Therefore it is called “the stilling of all formations,” “the relinquishing of all clinging,” “the exhaustion of craving,” “fading away,” “cessation,”

original: vuccati. Sā panesā taṇhā bhavena bhavaṃ, phalena vā saddhiṃ kammaṃ vinati saṃsibbatīti
analyzed: vuccati sā pana isā taṇhā bhavena bhavam phalena vā saddhim kammam vinati saṃsibbati iti
translated: and “Nibbāna.” And that craving is said to “vanish” because it is destroyed together with the kamma that produces existence, or because it is destroyed together with the result of that kamma.

original: katvā vānanti vuccati. Tato vānato nikkhantanti nibbānaṃ. So mamassa kilamathoti
analyzed: katvā vānanti vuccati tatas vānataḥ nikkhantanti nibbānam saḥ mama assa kilamatho ti
translated: Therefore Nibbāna is said to be “gone beyond vanishing.” “That was my weariness” means:

original: yā ajānantānaṃ desanā nāma, so mama kilamatho assa, sā mama vihesā assāti attho.
analyzed: yā a jānantānam desanā nāma saḥ mama kilamathaḥ assa sā mama vihesā assa ati attho
translated: The meaning is: ‘That would be a weariness for me, that would be a trouble for me.’

original: Kāyakilamatho ceva kāyavihesā ca assāti vuttaṃ hoti, citte pana ubhayampetaṃ buddhānaṃ natthi.
analyzed: kāya kilamatho ca iva kāya vihesā ca assa ati vuttam hoti citte pana ubhayam petam buddhānam natthi
translated: What is meant is: ‘There would be weariness of body and trouble of body.’ But in the case of Buddhas there is none of this either in body or in mind.

original: 65. Apissūti anubrūhanatthe nipāto. So – “na kevalaṃ etadahosi, imāpi gāthā paṭibhaṃsū”ti
analyzed: apissu iti anubrūhana atthe nipātaḥ saḥ na kevalam imā api gāthā
translated: ‘And’: this is a particle in the sense of sequence. It shows that ‘not only did this happen, but also these verses occurred to me.’

original: dīpeti. Vipassintiādīsu vipassissa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassāti attho. Anacchariyāti
analyzed: dīpeti vipassin ti ādīsu vipassissa bhagavataḥ arahataḥ sammāsambuddhassa ati atthaḥ anacchariyā ti
translated: In the passage beginning with ‘Vipassī’ the meaning is: ‘the Lord Buddha Vipassī, accomplished and fully enlightened.’ ‘Not wonderful’:

original: anuacchariyā. Paṭibhaṃsūti paṭibhānasaṅkhātassa ñāṇassa gocarā ahesuṃ, parivitakkayitabbataṃ pāpuṇiṃsu.
analyzed: anuacchariyā paṭibhaṃsū ti paṭibhāna saṅkhātassa ñāṇassa gocarāḥ ahesum parivitakkayitabba tam pāpuṇiṃsu
translated: ‘not wonderful’ means ‘not surprising.’ ‘Occurred to me’: they came into the range of the knowledge called ‘inspiration,’ they became objects of thought.

original: Kicchenāti dukkhena, na dukkhāya paṭipadāya. Buddhānañhi cattāropi maggā sukhapaṭipadāva
analyzed: kicchena ati dukkhena na dukkhāya paṭipadāya buddhānam hi cattāraḥ api maggāḥ sukha paṭipadā ava
translated: ‘With difficulty’: with pain, not with the painful way. For the four paths of the Buddhas are the easy way.

original: honti. Pāramīpūraṇakāle pana sarāgasadosasamohasseva sato āgatāgatānaṃ yācakānaṃ
analyzed: honti pāramī pūraṇa kāle pana sa rāga sa dosa sa mohassa iva sataḥ āgata āgatānam yācakānam
translated: But at the time of fulfilling the pāramīs, while still subject to greed, hatred, and delusion, the Buddhas-to-be

original: alaṅkatapaṭiyattaṃ sīsaṃ chinditvā galalohitaṃ nīharitvā suañjitāni akkhīni uppāṭetvā
analyzed: alaṅkata paṭiyattam sīsam chinditvā gala lohitam nīharitvā su añjitāni akkhīni uppāṭetvā
translated: and having cut off his head adorned and decked out, and having drawn out his blood, and having torn out his eyes,

original: kulavaṃsapadīpakaṃ puttaṃ manāpacāriniṃ bhariyanti evamādīni dentassa aññāni ca khantivādisadisesu
analyzed: kula vaṃsa padīpakam puttam manāpa cārinim bhariyanti evamādīni dentassa aññāni ca khanti vādi sadisesu
translated: and having given his son, the lamp of the family line, and his wife, who was dear to him, and so on, and having given other things,

original: attabhāvesu chejjabhejjādīni pāpuṇantassa āgamanīyapaṭipadaṃ sandhāyetaṃ vuttaṃ.🔽Halanti ettha hakāro nipātamatto, alanti attho. Pakāsitunti desetuṃ; evaṃ kicchena🔽adhigatassa dhammassa alaṃ desetuṃ; ko attho desitenāti vuttaṃ hoti. Rāgadosaparetehīti
analyzed: atta bhāvesu chejja bhejja ādīni pāpuṇantassa āgamanīya paṭipadam sandhāya itam vuttam  ettha hakāraḥ nipāta mattaḥ alanti attho pakāsitunti desetum evam kicchena  adhigatassa dhammassa alam desetum kaḥ atthaḥ desitena ati vuttam hoti rāga dosa paretehi iti
translated: and having had his body cut, pierced, etc., in other existences, this was said with reference to the way of coming to that.

original: rāgadosaphuṭṭhehi rāgadosānugatehi vā.
analyzed: rāga dosa phuṭṭhehi rāga dosa anugatehi vā
translated: ‘Hal’ is a mere particle here, the meaning is ‘al’. ‘Pakāsitun’ means ‘to teach’; thus, it is said: ‘it is enough to teach the Dhamma that has been obtained with difficulty’, what is the use of teaching? ‘Rāgadosaparetehi’ means: those who are affected by greed and hatred, or those who are followed by greed and hatred.

original: Paṭisotagāminti niccādīnaṃ paṭisotaṃ aniccaṃ dukkhamanattāsubhanti evaṃ gataṃ catusaccadhammaṃ.
analyzed: paṭisota gāmin ti nicca ādīnam paṭisotam aniccam dukkham anatta asubham ti evam gatam catu sacca dhammam
translated: ‘Paṭisotagāmi’ means: the Dhamma of the Four Noble Truths that has gone in the opposite direction to permanence, etc., as impermanent, suffering, not-self, and foul.

original: Rāgarattāti kāmarāgena bhavarāgena diṭṭhirāgena ca rattā. Na dakkhantīti aniccaṃ
analyzed: rāga rattā ati kāma rāgena bhava rāgena diṭṭhi rāgena ca rattā na dakkhanti iti aniccam
translated: ‘Rāgarattā’ means: those who are attached to sensual desire, to existence, and to views. ‘Na dakkhanti’ means: they will not see

original: dukkhamanattā asubhanti iminā sabhāvena na passissanti, te apassante ko sakkhissati
analyzed: dukkham anattā asubhanti iminā sabhāvena na passissanti te a passante kaḥ sakkhissati
translated: They will not see it as painful, not-self, and foul. When they do not see it thus, who will be able to make them understand?

original: evaṃ gāhāpetuṃ? Tamokhandhena āvuṭāti avijjārāsinā ajjhotthaṭā.
analyzed: evam gāhāpetum tamaḥ khandhena avijjā rāsinā ajjhotthaṭā
translated: “Enveloped in a mass of darkness”: overwhelmed by the mass of ignorance.

original: Appossukkatāyāti nirussukkabhāvena, adesetukāmatāyāti attho. Kasmā panassa evaṃ cittaṃ nami? Nanu esa – “mutto mocessāmī, tiṇṇo tāressāmi”,
analyzed: appossukka tāya āti nirussukka bhāvena a desetu kāma tāya āti attho kasmā panassa evam cittam nami nanu esa muttaḥ mocessāmi tiṇṇaḥ tāressāmi
translated: “Out of idleness”: out of a lack of enthusiasm, out of an unwillingness to teach. But why did he incline his mind in this way? Has he not said: “I am freed, I will liberate others; I am released, I will release others”?

original: “Kiṃ me aññātavesena, dhammaṃ sacchikatenidha;
analyzed: kim me aññāta vesena dhammam
translated: “What is the use of the state of omniscience to me? I have realized the Dhamma here and now.

original: Sabbaññutaṃ pāpuṇitvā, santāressaṃ sadevaka”nti.🔽Patthanaṃ katvā pāramiyo pūretvā sabbaññutaṃ pattoti. Saccametaṃ, paccavekkhaṇānubhāvena
analyzed: sabbaññu tam pāpuṇitvā santāressam sa devakam ti  patthanam katvā pāramiyaḥ pūretvā sabbaññu tam patto ti saccam etam paccavekkhaṇa anubhāvena
translated: Having attained omniscience, I will liberate the world with its gods.”

original: panassa evaṃ cittaṃ nami. Tassa hi sabbaññutaṃ patvā sattānaṃ kilesagahanataṃ dhammassa
analyzed: panassa evam cittam tassa hi sabbaññu tam patvā sattānam kilesa gahana tam dhammassa
translated: Having made this aspiration, fulfilled the perfections, and attained omniscience, he has now attained omniscience. This is true. But his mind inclines in this way through the power of his reflection. For, having attained omniscience, he reflects on the depth of the defilements of beings and on the profundity of the Dhamma.

original: ca gambhīrataṃ paccavekkhantassa sattānaṃ kilesagahanatā ca dhammagambhīratā ca sabbākārena
analyzed: ca gambhīra tam paccavekkhantassa sattānam kilesa gahana tā ca dhamma gambhīra tā ca sabba ākārena
translated: When he reflects on the depth of the defilements of beings and on the profundity of the Dhamma, he is unable to teach the Dhamma to beings in all its aspects.

original: pākaṭā jātā. Athassa – “ime sattā kañjikapuṇṇalābu viya takkabharitacāṭi viya vasātelapītapilotikā
analyzed: pākaṭāḥ jātāḥ athassa ime sattā kañjika puṇṇa lābu viya takka bharita cāṭi viya vasā tela pīta pilotikā
translated: and they became manifest. Then he thought, “These beings are so defiled by defilements that they are like a gourd full of urine, like a bag full of takka-beans, like a cloth soaked in oil,

original: viya añjanamakkhitahatthā viya kilesabharitā atisaṃkiliṭṭhā rāgarattā dosaduṭṭhā
analyzed: viya añjana makkhita hatthā viya kilesa bharitā ati saṃkiliṭṭhā rāga rattā dosa duṭṭhā
translated: like hands smeared with ointment. They are so defiled by lust, hatred, and delusion that they are red with lust, rotten with hatred,

original: mohamūḷhā, te kiṃ nāma paṭivijjhissantī”ti cintayato kilesagahanapaccavekkhaṇānubhāvenāpi evaṃ cittaṃ nami.🔽“Ayañca dhammo pathavīsandhārakaudakakkhandho viya gambhīro, pabbatena paṭicchādetvā
analyzed: moha mūḷhā te kim nāma paṭivijjhissanti iti cintayataḥ kilesa gahana paccavekkhaṇa anubhāvena api evam cittam nami  ayam ca dhammaḥ pathavī sandhāraka odaka khandhaḥ viya gambhīraḥ pabbatena paṭicchādetvā
translated: and confused with delusion. What will they penetrate?” And his mind inclined in this way through the power of reflecting on the depth of the defilements.🔽“And this Dhamma is as deep as the water in the ocean, as deep as the earth’s foundation. It is as hard to see as a mustard seed placed on the point of an awl,

original: ṭhapito sāsapo viya duddaso, satadhā bhinnassa vālassa koṭiyā koṭiṃ paṭipādanaṃ viya🔽duranubodho, nanu mayā hi imaṃ dhammaṃ paṭivijjhituṃ vāyamantena adinnaṃ dānaṃ nāma
analyzed: ṭhapitaḥ sāsapaḥ viya duddasaḥ satadhā bhinnassa vālassa koṭiyā koṭim paṭipādanam viya  duranubodhaḥ nanu mayā hi imam dhammam paṭivijjhitum vā āyamantena adinnam dānam nāma
translated: as hard to understand as the tip of a hair split a hundred times.

original: natthi, arakkhitaṃ sīlaṃ nāma natthi, aparipūritā kāci pāramī nāma natthi. Tassa
analyzed: natthi arakkhitam sīlam nāma natthi a paripūritā kāci pāramī nāma natthi tassa
translated: But when I was striving to penetrate this Dhamma, there was no gift I would not give, no moral precept I would not observe, no perfection I would not fulfill.

original: me nirussāhaṃ viya mārabalaṃ vidhamantassāpi pathavī na kampittha, paṭhamayāme pubbenivāsaṃ
analyzed: me nirussāham viya māra balam vidhamantassa api pathavī na kampittha paṭhama yāme pubbenivāsam
translated: and the earth did not tremble, even though he was destroying the power of Mara as if it were nothing.

original: anussarantassāpi na kampittha, majjhimayāme dibbacakkhuṃ visodhentassāpi na kampittha,
analyzed: anussarantassa api na kampittha majjhima yāme dibba cakkhum visodhentassa api na kampittha
translated: and when I was destroying the power of Māra, the earth did not quake. When I was recollecting my past lives in the first watch of the night, the earth did not quake. When I was purifying the divine eye in the middle watch of the night, the earth did not quake.

original: pacchimayāme pana paṭiccasamuppādaṃ paṭivijjhantasseva me dasasahassilokadhātu kampittha.
analyzed: pacchima yāme pana paṭiccasamuppādam paṭivijjhantassa iva me dasa sahassi lokadhātu kampittha
translated: But when I was penetrating dependent origination in the last watch of the night, the earth quaked in ten thousand world-systems.

original: Iti mādisenāpi tikkhañāṇena kicchenevāyaṃ dhammo paṭividdho taṃ lokiyamahājanā kathaṃ
analyzed: iti mādisena api tikkha ñāṇena kicchena iva ayam dhammo paṭividdhaḥ tam lokiya mahājanāḥ katham
translated: “So even one like me, with keen knowledge, penetrated this Dhamma only with difficulty. How will ordinary people penetrate it? ”

original: paṭivijjhissantī”ti dhammagambhīratāpaccavekkhaṇānubhāvenāpi evaṃ cittaṃ namīti veditabbaṃ.🔽Apica brahmunā yācite desetukāmatāyapissa evaṃ cittaṃ nami. Jānāti hi bhagavā – “mama
analyzed: paṭivijjhissanti iti dhamma gambhīra tā paccavekkhaṇa anubhāvena api evam cittam namīti veditabbam  apica brahmunā yācite evam cittam jānāti hi bhagavā mama
translated: It should be understood that his mind also bows down thus through the power of reflecting on the profundity of the Dhamma.

original: appossukkatāya citte namamāne maṃ mahābrahmā dhammadesanaṃ yācissati, ime ca sattā
analyzed: appossukka tāya citte namamāne mam mahābrahmā dhamma desanam yācissati ime ca sattā
translated: Besides, his mind also bows down thus through his desire to teach when requested by Brahmā. For the Exalted One knows: “If my mind bows down to rest, Great Brahmā will request me to teach the Dhamma, and then these beings will not be able to understand the Dhamma.

original: brahmagarukā, te ‘satthā kira dhammaṃ na desetukāmo ahosi, atha naṃ mahābrahmā yācitvā
analyzed: brahma garukā te satthā kira dhammam na desetu kāmo ahosi atha nam mahābrahmā yācitvā
translated: “They will be eager to listen, thinking: ‘It seems that the Teacher was unwilling to teach the Dhamma, but Great Brahma requested him to do so,

original: desāpesi, santo vata bho dhammo, paṇīto vata bho dhammo’ti maññamānā sussūsissantī”ti.
analyzed: desāpesi santaḥ vata bho dhammo paṇītaḥ vata bho dhammo ti maññamānā sussūsissanti iti
translated: and so he consented. How wonderful and marvellous that the Dhamma should be taught! ‘”

original: Imampissa kāraṇaṃ paṭicca appossukkatāya cittaṃ nami, no dhammadesanāyāti veditabbaṃ.🔽66. Aññatarassāti ettha kiñcāpi “aññataro”ti vuttaṃ, atha kho imasmiṃ cakkavāḷe jeṭṭhakamahābrahmā
analyzed: imam pi issa kāraṇam paṭicca appa ussukka tāya cittam nami no dhamma desanāya ati veditabbam  aññatarassa ti ettha kiñcā api aññataro ti vuttam atha kho imasmin cakkavāḷe jeṭṭhaka mahābrahmā
translated: This is the reason why his mind inclined to inaction rather than to teaching the Dhamma.🔽“A certain deity”: although “a certain deity” is said, it should be understood that it was the chief Brahma of this world-sphere.

original: esoti veditabbo. Nassati vata bho lokoti so kira imaṃ saddaṃ tathā nicchāresi, yathā🔽dasasahassilokadhātubrahmāno sutvā sabbe sannipatiṃsu. Yatra hi nāmāti yasmiṃ nāma
analyzed: esaḥ iti veditabbaḥ nassati vata bho loko ti so kira imam saddam tathā nicchāresi yathā  dasa sahassi lokadhātu brahmāno sutvā sabbe sannipatiṃsu yatra hi nāma ati yasmin nāma
translated: “The world is surely lost” : it seems that he uttered this cry in such a way that🔽the Brahmas of the ten-thousand world-system heard it and all assembled. “In this world” : in this

original: loke. Purato pāturahosīti tehi dasahi brahmasahassehi saddhiṃ pāturahosi. Apparajakkhajātikāti
analyzed: loke puratas pāturahosi iti tehi dasahi brahma sahassehi saddhim pāturahosi appara jakkha jātikā ati
translated: world-sphere. “Appeared in the east” : he appeared together with the ten-thousand Brahmas. “Of little dust” :

original: paññāmaye akkhimhi appaṃ parittaṃ rāgadosamoharajaṃ etesaṃ, evaṃ sabhāvāti apparajakkhajātikā.
analyzed: paññā maye akkhimhi appam parittam rāga dosa moha rajam etesam evam sabhāvā ati appa rajakkha jātikā
translated: In the eye of wisdom, there is little, a small amount, of the stains of lust, hatred, and delusion. Thus they are of the nature of having few stains.

original: Assavanatāti assavanatāya. Bhavissantīti purimabuddhesu dasapuññakiriyavatthuvasena
analyzed: assavana tā ti assavana tāya bhavissanti iti purima buddhesu dasa puñña kiriya vatthu vasena
translated: Will be eager: because of their eagerness. Will be: those who have made merit in the past under previous Buddhas by means of the ten bases of meritorious action,

original: katādhikārā paripākagatā padumāni viya sūriyarasmisamphassaṃ, dhammadesanaṃyeva ākaṅkhamānā
analyzed: kata adhikārā paripāka gatā viya sūriya rasmi samphassam dhamma desanaṃyā iva ākaṅkhamānā
translated: who are ripe for arahatship like lotuses touched by the sun’s rays, who are eager for the teaching of the Dhamma,

original: catuppadikagāthāvasāne ariyabhūmiṃ okkamanārahā na eko, na dve, anekasatasahassā
analyzed: catuppadika gāthā avasāne ariya bhūmim okkamana arahā na ekaḥ na dve aneka sata sahassā
translated: who are worthy to enter the noble plane at the end of the four-line stanza, will not be one or two, but many hundreds of thousands.

original: dhammassa aññātāro bhavissantīti dasseti.🔽69. Ajjhesananti evaṃ tikkhattuṃ yācanaṃ. Buddhacakkhunāti indriyaparopariyattañāṇena🔽ca āsayānusayañāṇena ca. Imesañhi dvinnaṃ ñāṇānaṃ “buddhacakkhū”ti nāmaṃ, sabbaññutaññāṇassa
analyzed: dhammassa aññātāraḥ bhavissanti iti dasseti  ajjhesanam ti evam tikkhattum yācanam buddha cakkhunā ati indriya para upari yatta ñāṇena  ca āsaya anusaya ñāṇena ca imesam hi dvinnam ñāṇānam buddha cakkhu iti nāmam sabbaññuta ññāṇassa
translated: The Blessed One shows that there will be many who will understand the Dhamma.🔽Invitation: the request made three times in this way. With the Buddha-eye: with the knowledge of the degree of acumen of others and with the knowledge of the mental proclivities and latent tendencies of others.🔽For these two kinds of knowledge are called the “Buddha-eye,” while the knowledge of omniscience is called the “all-seeing eye” and the three path knowledges are called the “Dhamma-eye.”

original: “samantacakkhū”ti, tiṇṇaṃ maggañāṇānaṃ “dhammacakkhū”ti. Apparajakkhetiādīsu yesaṃ
analyzed: samantacakkhu iti tiṇṇam magga ñāṇānam dhammacakkhu iti apparajakkha iti ādīsu yesam
translated: In the passage beginning with “of few stains” ,

original: vuttanayeneva paññācakkhumhi rāgādirajaṃ appaṃ, te apparajakkhā. Yesaṃ taṃ mahantaṃ,
analyzed: vutta nayena iva paññācakkhumhi rāga ādi rajam appam te apparajakkhāḥ yesam tam mahantam
translated: And the dust of greed, etc., is small in the eye of understanding in the way already stated. Those in whom it is small are called “of little dust.”🔽Those in whom it is great are “of great dust.”

original: te mahārajakkhā. Yesaṃ saddhādīni indriyāni tikkhāni, te tikkhindriyā. Yesaṃ tāni
analyzed: te mahārajakkhāḥ yesam saddhā ādīni indriyāni tikkhāni te tikkhindriyāḥ yesam tāni
translated: Those in whom faith, etc., are keen are “of keen faculties.”🔽Those in whom they are feeble are “of feeble faculties.”🔽Those in whom these same things are beautiful are “of beautiful character.”

original: mudūni, te mudindriyā. Yesaṃ teyeva saddhādayo ākārā sundarā, te svākārā. Ye kathitakāraṇaṃ🔽sallakkhenti, sukhena sakkā honti viññāpetuṃ, te suviññāpayā. Ye paralokañceva vajjañca
analyzed: te mud indriyāḥ te ye iva saddha ādayaḥ ākārā te su ākārāḥ ye kathita kāraṇam  sallakkhenti sukhena sakkāḥ honti viññāpetum te su viññāpayāḥ ye para lokañca iva vajjam ca
translated: Those who can be easily exhorted are “easy to exhort.”

original: bhayato passanti, te paralokavajjabhayadassāvino nāma.🔽Ayaṃ panettha pāḷi – “saddho puggalo apparajakkho, assaddho puggalo mahārajakkho.…🔽Āraddhavīriyo…pe… kusīto… upaṭṭhitassati… muṭṭhassati… samāhito… asamāhito… paññavā…
analyzed: bhayataḥ passanti te para loka vajja bhaya dassāvinaḥ nāma  ayam pana ittha pāḷi saddhaḥ puggalaḥ apparajakkhaḥ assaddhaḥ puggalaḥ mahārajakkhaḥ  kusītaḥ upaṭṭhita sati muṭṭha sati samāhitaḥ asamāhito paññavā
translated: Those who see the other world and the danger in wrongdoing are called “seers of the other world and of danger in wrongdoing.”🔽The text here is: “A faithful person is of little dust; an faithless person is of great dust.🔽An energetic person … a lazy person … a mindful person … a forgetful person … a concentrated person … an unconcentrated person … a wise person …

original: duppañño puggalo mahārajakkho. Tathā saddho puggalo tikkhindriyo…pe… paññavā puggalo
analyzed: duppaññaḥ puggalaḥ mahā rajakkhaḥ tathā saddhaḥ puggalo paññavā puggalo
translated: a faithless person … an energetic person … a lazy person … a mindful person … a forgetful person … a concentrated person … an unconcentrated person … a wise person …

original: paralokavajjabhayadassāvī, duppañño puggalo na paralokavajjabhayadassāvī. Lokoti
analyzed: para loka vajja bhaya dassāvī duppaññaḥ puggalo na para loka vajja bhaya dassāvī
translated: The wise person sees fear in the next world, but the unwise person does not see fear in the next world. The world is

original: khandhaloko, dhātuloko, āyatanaloko, sampattibhavaloko, vipattibhavaloko, sampattisambhavaloko,
analyzed: khandha lokaḥ dhātu lokaḥ āyatana lokaḥ sampatti bhava lokaḥ vipatti bhava lokaḥ sampatti sambhava lokaḥ
translated: the world of the aggregates, the world of the elements, the world of the sense-spheres, the world of fortunate and unfortunate existences, the world of fortunate and unfortunate rebirths, the world of fortunate and unfortunate existences,

original: vipattisambhavaloko. Eko loko – sabbe sattā āhāraṭṭhitikā. Dve lokā – nāmañca rūpañca.
analyzed: vipatti sambhava lokaḥ ekaḥ lokaḥ sabbe sattā āhāra ṭṭhitikā dve lokā nāmañca rūpañca
translated: the world of fortunate and unfortunate rebirths. There is one world: all beings subsist on food. There are two worlds: mind and bodily form.

original: Tayo lokā – tisso vedanā. Cattāro lokā – cattāro āhārā. Pañca lokā – pañcupādānakkhandhā.
analyzed: tayaḥ lokā tissaḥ vedanā cattāraḥ lokā cattāraḥ āhārā pañca lokā pañca upādānakkhandhā
translated: There are three worlds: the three kinds of feeling. There are four worlds: the four kinds of nutriment. There are five worlds: the five aggregates as objects of clinging.

analyzed: pamuñcantu vissajjentu pacchima pada dvaye ayam atthaḥ ahañhi attano paguṇam
translated: Let them release, let them give up. The meaning is this: I did not speak this excellent, sublime Dhamma, which is suitable for me and well proclaimed,

original: imaṃ paṇītaṃ uttamaṃ dhammaṃ kāyavācākilamathasaññī hutvā na bhāsiṃ, idāni pana sabbe
analyzed: imam paṇītam uttamam dhammam kāya vācā kilamatha saññī hutvā na bhāsim idāni pana sabbe
translated: because I considered bodily and verbal exertion. But now let all people

original: janā saddhābhājanaṃ upanentu, pūressāmi tesaṃ saṅkappanti.
analyzed: janā saddhā bhājanam upanentu pūressāmi tesam saṅkappanti
translated: approach as vessels of faith; I will fulfill their expectations.

original: Aggasāvakayugavaṇṇanā
analyzed: agga sāvaka yuga vaṇṇanā
translated: The description of the foremost pair of disciples

original: 73. Bodhirukkhamūleti bodhirukkhassa avidūre ajapālanigrodhe antarahitoti attho.🔽Kheme migadāyeti isipatanaṃ tena samayena khemaṃ nāma uyyānaṃ hoti, migānaṃ pana
analyzed: bodhi rukkha mūla iti bodhi rukkhassa avidūre ajapāla nigrodhe antarahitaḥ ti attho  kheme migadāya iti isipatanam tena samayena khemam nāma uyyānam migānam pana
translated: . At the foot of the Bodhi tree: the meaning is, he disappeared in the Ajapāla banyan tree not far from the Bodhi tree.🔽In the Deer Park at Isipatana: at that time the Deer Park was called the Khemā Park, but it is called the Deer Park because it was given to the deer

original: abhayavāsatthāya dinnattā migadāyoti vuccati. Taṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ – “kheme migadāye”ti.
analyzed: abhaya vāsa atthāya dinna ttā migadāya iti vuccati tam sandhāya vuttam kheme migadāya iti
translated: for a safe dwelling. With reference to that it is said: “In the Deer Park at Isipatana.”

original: Yathā ca vipassī bhagavā, evaṃ aññepi buddhā paṭhamaṃ dhammadesanatthāya gacchantā
analyzed: yathā ca vipassī bhagavā evam aññe api buddhā paṭhamam dhamma desana tthāya gacchantā
translated: And just as the Lord Buddha Vipassī, so also the other Buddhas, when they first go to teach the Dhamma,

original: ākāsena gantvā tattheva otaranti. Amhākaṃ pana bhagavā upakassa ājīvakassa upanissayaṃ
analyzed: ākāsena gantvā tattha iva otaranti amhākam pana bhagavā upakassa ājīvakassa upanissayam
translated: go through the air and alight there. But our Lord Buddha, after considering the support of the Ājīvaka Upaka,

original: disvā – “upako imaṃ addhānaṃ paṭipanno, so maṃ disvā sallapitvā gamissati. Atha puna
analyzed: disvā upakaḥ imam addhānam paṭipanno saḥ mam disvā sallapitvā gamissati atha puna
translated: and seeing him, he thought, “Upāka is coming along this road. He will see me, will speak to me, and will go away. Then,

original: nibbindanto āgamma arahattaṃ sacchikarissatī”ti ñatvā aṭṭhārasayojanamaggaṃ padasāva🔽agamāsi. Dāyapālaṃ āmantesīti disvāva punappunaṃ oloketvā – “ayyo no, bhante, āgato”ti
analyzed: nibbindantaḥ āgamma arahattam sacchikarissati iti ñatvā aṭṭhārasa yojana maggam padasāva  agamāsi dāyapālam āmantesi iti disvā ava punappunam oloketvā ayyaḥ naḥ bhante āgataḥ iti
translated: becoming disenchanted again, he will come and realize arahatship.” Knowing this, he went the eighteen leagues of the road on foot.

original: vatvā upagataṃ āmantesi.🔽75-6. Anupubbiṃ kathanti dānakathaṃ, dānānantaraṃ sīlaṃ, sīlānantaraṃ saggaṃ, saggānantaraṃ
analyzed: vatvā upagatam āmantesi  anupubbim kathanti dāna katham dāna anantaram sīlam sīla anantaram saggam sagga anantaram
translated: He addressed the keeper of the park: having seen him, he looked again and again, and saying, “Venerable sir, our master has come,” he addressed Upāka, who had come.

original: magganti evaṃ anupaṭipāṭikathaṃ kathesi. Tattha dānakathanti idaṃ dānaṃ nāma sukhānaṃ🔽nidānaṃ, sampattīnaṃ mūlaṃ, bhogānaṃ patiṭṭhā, visamagatassa tāṇaṃ leṇaṃ gati parāyaṇaṃ,
analyzed: magganti evam anupaṭipāṭi katham kathesi tattha dāna katham ti idam dānam nāma sukhānam  nidānam sampattīnam mūlam bhogānam patiṭṭhā visama gatassa tāṇam leṇam gati parāyaṇam
translated: The gradual talk: he gave the talk on giving, on virtue, on heaven, and on the danger, degradation, and defilement in worldly pleasures, and on the benefit in renouncing the world, in due course. Herein, the talk on giving is this: “Giving is the way to happiness, giving is the highest treasure, giving bears fruit in a good womb, giving leads to fame in this world, giving leads to delight in the heavenly state.🔽Giving is the highest wealth in the world, giving is the highest support, giving is the highest kinsman in the world beyond.🔽Giving is the highest treasure in the world, giving is the highest wealth in the world beyond.

original: idhalokaparalokesu dānasadiso avassayo patiṭṭhā ārammaṇaṃ tāṇaṃ leṇaṃ gati parāyaṇaṃ
analyzed: idhaloka paralokesu dāna sadisaḥ avassayaḥ patiṭṭhā ārammaṇam tāṇam leṇam gati parāyaṇam
translated: Giving is the highest wealth in the world, giving is the highest support in the world beyond.

original: natthi. Idañhi avassayaṭṭhena ratanamayasīhāsanasadisaṃ, patiṭṭhānaṭṭhena mahāpathavīsadisaṃ,
analyzed: natthi idam hi avassaya ṭṭhena ratana maya sīhāsana sadisam patiṭṭhāna ṭṭhena mahā pathavī sadisam
translated: It is like a jewel-studded lion-throne in the sense of being the support for the jewel of the supramundane states; it is like the great earth in the sense of being the foundation for the jewel of the supramundane states;

original: ārammaṇaṭṭhena ālambanarajjusadisaṃ. Idañhi dukkhanittharaṇaṭṭhena nāvā, samassāsanaṭṭhena
analyzed: ārammaṇa ṭṭhena ālambana rajju sadisam idam hi dukkha nittharaṇa ṭṭhena nāvā samassāsana ṭṭhena
translated: it is like a rope for tethering the jewel of the supramundane states. For the path is a raft for crossing the ocean of suffering,🔽a hero in the battle with defilements, a refuge from fear, a well-fortified city,

original: saṅgāmasūro, bhayaparittāṇaṭṭhena susaṅkhatanagaraṃ, maccheramalādīhi anupalittaṭṭhena🔽padumaṃ, tesaṃ nidahanaṭṭhena aggi, durāsadaṭṭhena āsīviso, asantāsanaṭṭhena sīho,
analyzed: saṅgāma sūraḥ bhaya parittāṇa ṭṭhena susaṅkhata nagaram macchera mala ādīhi an upalitta ṭṭhena  padumam tesam nidahana ṭṭhena aggi durāsada ṭṭhena āsīvisaḥ asanta asana ṭṭhena sīhaḥ
translated: a lotus unstained by the mud of stinginess and so on,🔽a fire for burning the fuel of defilements, a cobra for striking terror, a lion for terrifying the deer of defilements,

original: balavantaṭṭhena hatthī, abhimaṅgalasammataṭṭhena setausabho, khemantabhūmisampāpanaṭṭhena
analyzed: balavanta ṭṭhena hatthī abhimaṅgala sammata ṭṭhena setausabhaḥ khemanta bhūmi sampāpana ṭṭhena
translated: an elephant for its great strength, a bull for its excellence, a rain-cloud for its ability to fill the earth with the water of the Dhamma.

original: valāhakaassarājā. Dānañhi loke sakkasampattiṃ mārasampattiṃ brahmasampattiṃ cakkavattisampattiṃ
analyzed: valāhakaassa rājā dānan hi loke sakka sampattim māra sampattim brahma sampattim cakkavatti sampattim
translated: For the Dhamma is the giver of the perfection of Sakka, of Māra, of Brahmā, of the wheel-turning monarch,

original: sāvakapāramiñāṇaṃ paccekabodhiñāṇaṃ abhisambodhiñāṇaṃ detīti evamādidānaguṇapaṭisaṃyuttaṃ kathaṃ.
analyzed: sāvaka pārami ñāṇam paccekabodhi ñāṇam abhisambodhi ñāṇam deti iti evamādi dāna guṇa paṭisaṃyuttam katham
translated: of the knowledge of the disciple, of the paccekabuddha, of the perfect enlightenment. Thus the discussion of the Dhamma is a discussion connected with the special qualities of generosity and so on.

original: Yasmā pana dānaṃ dadanto sīlaṃ samādātuṃ sakkoti, tasmā tadanantaraṃ sīlakathaṃ kathesi.
analyzed: yasmai pana dānam dadantaḥ sīlam samādātum sakkoti tasmai tad anantaram sīla katham kathesi
translated: But since one who gives gifts is able to undertake virtue, therefore he spoke next about virtue.

original: Sīlakathanti sīlaṃ nāmetaṃ avassayo patiṭṭhā ārammaṇaṃ tāṇaṃ leṇaṃ gati parāyaṇaṃ.
analyzed: sīlakathanti sīlam nāma etam avassayaḥ patiṭṭhā ārammaṇam tāṇam leṇam gati parāyaṇam
translated: “Talk about virtue”: virtue is a refuge, a support, a foundation, a protection, a shelter, a final relief, a goal, a haven.

original: Idhalokaparalokasampattīnañhi sīlasadiso avassayo patiṭṭhā ārammaṇaṃ tāṇaṃ leṇaṃ
analyzed: idhaloka paraloka sampattīnam hi sīla sadisaḥ avassayaḥ patiṭṭhā ārammaṇam tāṇam leṇam
translated: For there is no refuge, no support, no foundation, no protection, no shelter, no final relief, no goal, no haven equal to virtue for the attainment of mundane and supramundane benefits.

original: gati parāyaṇaṃ natthi, sīlasadiso alaṅkāro natthi, sīlapupphasadisaṃ pupphaṃ natthi,🔽sīlagandhasadiso gandho natthi, sīlālaṅkārena hi alaṅkataṃ sīlakusumapiḷandhanaṃ
analyzed: gati parāyaṇam natthi sīla sadisaḥ alaṅkāraḥ natthi sīla puppha sadisam puppham natthi  sīla gandha sadisaḥ gandhaḥ na atthi sīla alaṅkārena hi alaṅkatam sīla kusuma piḷandhanam
translated: There is no ornament equal to virtue, no flower equal to the flower of virtue,🔽no perfume equal to the perfume of virtue. For the world with its gods, surveyed by the eye of one possessing knowledge, never tires of looking at one adorned with the ornament of virtue, sprinkled with the water of the flower of virtue,

original: sīlagandhānulittaṃ sadevakopi loko olokento tittiṃ na gacchatīti evamādisīlaguṇapaṭisaṃyuttaṃ kathaṃ.
analyzed: sīla gandha anulittam sa devakaḥ api lokaḥ olokentaḥ tittim na gacchati iti evamādi sīla guṇa paṭisaṃyuttam katham
translated: perfumed with the perfume of virtue.

original: Idaṃ pana sīlaṃ nissāya ayaṃ saggo labbhatīti dassetuṃ sīlānantaraṃ saggakathaṃ kathesi.
analyzed: idam pana sīlam nissāya ayam saggo labbhati iti dassetum sīla anantaram sagga katham kathesi
translated: In order to show that this heaven is obtained by means of this virtue, he spoke next about heaven.

original: Saggakathanti ayaṃ saggo nāma iṭṭho kanto manāpo, niccamettha kīḷā, niccaṃ sampattiyo
analyzed: sagga kathanti ayam saggaḥ nāma iṭṭhaḥ kantaḥ manāpaḥ niccam ettha kīḷā niccam sampattiyaḥ
translated: “Talk about heaven”: this heaven is desirable, lovely, pleasing, there is always play there, always prosperity,

original: labbhanti, cātumahārājikā devā navutivassasatasahassāni dibbasukhaṃ dibbasampattiṃ
analyzed: labbhanti cātumahārājikāḥ devāḥ navuti vassa sata sahassāni dibba sukham dibba sampattim
translated: the gods of the Four Great Kings for nine hundred thousand years of heavenly happiness, heavenly prosperity,

original: paṭilabhanti, tāvatiṃsā tisso ca vassakoṭiyo saṭṭhi ca vassasatasahassānīti evamādisaggaguṇapaṭisaṃyuttaṃ
analyzed: paṭilabhanti tāvatiṃsā tisso ca vassa koṭiyo saṭṭhi ca vassa sata sahassāni iti evamādi sagga guṇa paṭisaṃyuttam
translated: The gods of the Four Kings’ Heaven enjoy divine happiness and divine prosperity for nine hundred thousand years; the gods of the Thirty-three for three million six hundred thousand years. Thus he spoke about the qualities of the heavens.

original: kathaṃ. Saggasampattiṃ kathayantānañhi buddhānaṃ mukhaṃ nappahoti. Vuttampi cetaṃ
analyzed: katham sagga sampattim kathayantānam hi buddhānam mukham na ppahoti vuttam pi ca itam
translated: When the Buddhas speak about the excellence of the heavens, their faces do not become distorted. For this is said:

original: – “anekapariyāyena kho ahaṃ, bhikkhave, saggakathaṃ katheyya”ntiādi.🔽Evaṃ saggakathāya palobhetvā puna hatthiṃ alaṅkaritvā tassa soṇḍaṃ chindanto viya
analyzed: aneka pariyāyena kho aham bhikkhave sagga katham katheyya tiādi  evam sagga kathāya palobhetvā puna hatthim alaṅkaritvā tassa soṇḍam chindantaḥ viya
translated: “Monks, I could speak in many ways about the excellence of the heavens” .

original: – “ayampi saggo anicco addhuvo, na ettha chandarāgo kātabbo”ti dassanatthaṃ – “appassādā
analyzed: ayam pi saggaḥ aniccaḥ addhuvaḥ na ettha chanda rāgo kātabbaḥ iti dassana ttham appassādā
translated: Having thus enticed them with a talk on the heavens, he again spoke about the danger, the degradation, and the defilement in sensual pleasures, as if cutting off the trunk of the elephant he had decorated, in order to show that even this heaven is impermanent and unstable, and that one should not delight in it.

original: kāmā bahudukkhā bahupāyāsā, ādīnavo ettha bhiyyo”tiādinā nayena kāmānaṃ ādīnavaṃ
analyzed: kāmāḥ bahu dukkhāḥ bahu pāyāsāḥ ādīnavaḥ ettha bhiyyo ti ādinā nayena kāmānam ādīnavam
translated: “Sensual pleasures are of little satisfaction and much pain, and the danger in them is greater” .

original: okāraṃ saṃkilesaṃ kathesi. Tattha ādīnavoti doso. Okāroti avakāro lāmakabhāvo. Saṃkilesoti
analyzed: okāram saṃkilesam kathesi tattha ādīnavaḥ ati doso okāro ati avakāro lāmaka bhāvo saṃkileso ti
translated: Herein, danger is the disadvantage. Degradation is the state of being low, the state of being base. Defilement is the state of being mixed up with evil, the state of being sullied.

original: tehi sattānaṃ saṃsāre saṃkilissanaṃ. Yathāha – “kilissanti vata bho sattā”ti. Evaṃ
analyzed: tehi sattānam saṃsāre saṃkilissanam yathā āha kilissanti vata bho sattā ati evam
translated: and by them beings are defiled in the round of rebirths. As it is said: “Beings are defiled, good sirs” .

original: kāmādīnavena tejjatvā nekkhamme ānisaṃsaṃ pakāsesi, pabbajjāya guṇaṃ pakāsesīti attho.
analyzed: kāma ādīnavena tejja tvā nekkhamme ānisaṃsam pakāsesi pabbajjāya guṇam pakāsesi iti attho
translated: Having thus extolled the danger in sense desires, etc., he revealed the benefit in renunciation, the virtue of going forth, is the meaning.

original: Sesaṃ ambaṭṭhasuttavaṇṇanāyaṃ vuttanayañceva uttānatthañca.🔽77. Alatthunti kathaṃ alatthuṃ? Ehibhikkhubhāvena. Bhagavā kira tesaṃ iddhimayapattacīvarassūpanissayaṃ
analyzed: sesam ambaṭṭha sutta vaṇṇanāyam vutta nayam ca iva uttāna ttham ca  a latthum ti katham a latthum ehi bhikkhu bhāvena bhagavā kira tesam iddhi maya pattacīvara ssu upanissayam
translated: The rest is in the method stated in the commentary on the Ambattha Sutta and is of clear meaning.🔽How did they obtain it? By the state of being bidden to come and be monks. The Blessed One, it seems, was looking at their requisites of the supernormal power, namely, the bowl, the robe, and the alms food,

original: olokento anekāsu jātīsu cīvaradānādīni disvā etha bhikkhavotiādimāha. Te tāvadeva
analyzed: olokentaḥ anekāsu jātīsu cīvara dāna ādīni disvā etha bhikkhavaḥ ti ādim āha te tāvat eva
translated: and seeing that they had given a robe, etc., in many births, he said, “Come, bhikkhus.” They sat down reverently,

original: bhaṇḍū kāsāyavasanā aṭṭhahi bhikkhuparikkhārehi sarīrapaṭimukkeheva vassasatikattherā🔽viya bhagavantaṃ namassamānāva nisīdiṃsu.
analyzed: bhaṇḍū kāsāya vasanā aṭṭhahi bhikkhu parikkhārehi sarīra paṭimukkehi iva vassasatika therā  viya bhagavantam namassamānā ava nisīdiṃsu
translated: wearing the ochre robes, with the eight requisites of monks on their bodies, like the Elder Assaji, who had been a monk for a hundred years.

original: Sandassesītiādīsu idhalokatthaṃ sandassesi, paralokatthaṃ sandassesi. Idhalokatthaṃ
analyzed: sandassesi itiādīsu idha loka attham sandassesi para loka attham sandassesi idha loka attham
translated: In the passage beginning “He revealed” , he revealed what is for the welfare and happiness of the people of this world, and he revealed what is for the welfare and happiness of the people of the other world.

original: dassento aniccanti dassesi, dukkhanti dassesi, anattāti dassesi, khandhe dassesi,
analyzed: dassentaḥ aniccanti dassesi dukkhanti dassesi anattā ati dassesi khandhe dassesi
translated: He showed them impermanent, he showed them painful, he showed them not-self, he showed them the categories,

original: dhātuyo dassesi, āyatanāni dassesi, paṭiccasamuppādaṃ dassesi, rūpakkhandhassa udayaṃ
analyzed: dhātuyaḥ dassesi āyatanāni dassesi paṭiccasamuppādam dassesi rūpa kkhandhassa udayam
translated: he showed them the elements, he showed them the sense-bases, he showed them dependent origination, he showed them the arising of the form category,

original: dassento pañca lakkhaṇāni dassesi, tathā vedanākkhandhādīnaṃ, tathā vayaṃ dassentopi
analyzed: dassentaḥ pañca lakkhaṇāni dassesi tathā vedanā khandha ādīnam tathā vayam dassentaḥ api
translated: showing them the five characteristics, likewise the feeling category, etc., likewise the passing away of these, showing them

original: udayabbayavasena paññāsalakkhaṇāni dassesi, paralokatthaṃ dassento nirayaṃ dassesi,
analyzed: udaya bbaya vasena paññāsa lakkhaṇāni dassesi para loka attham dassentaḥ nirayam dassesi
translated: the five characteristics of understanding by way of arising and passing away, showing them the other world, he showed them hell,

original: tiracchānayoniṃ, pettivisayaṃ, asurakāyaṃ, tiṇṇaṃ kusalānaṃ vipākaṃ, channaṃ devalokānaṃ,
analyzed: tiracchāna yonim petti visayam asura kāyam tiṇṇam kusalānam vipākam channam deva lokānam
translated: the animal realm, the realm of ghosts, the asura group, the result of the three kinds of profitable action, the excellence of the six divine worlds,

original: navannaṃ brahmalokānaṃ sampattiṃ dassesi.
analyzed: navannam brahmalokānam sampattim dassesi
translated: and the nine divine worlds.

original: Samādapesīti catupārisuddhisīlaterasadhutaṅgadasakathāvatthuādike kalyāṇadhamme gaṇhāpesi.
analyzed: samādapesi iti catu pārisuddhi sīla terasa dhutaṅga dasa kathā vatthu ādike kalyāṇa dhamme gaṇhāpesi
translated: He exhorted: he made them take up the good things of the Dhamma such as the fourfold purification, the thirteen bad ways, the thirteen good ways, the ten ascetic practices, the ten topics for conversation, and so on.

original: Samuttejesīti suṭṭhu uttejesi, abbhussāhesi. Idhalokatthañceva paralokatthañca tāsetvā
analyzed: samuttejesi iti suṭṭhu uttejesi abbhussāhesi idha loka tthañca iva para loka tthañca tāsetvā
translated: He roused them: he roused them thoroughly, he stirred them up. Having alarmed them about the good of this world and the good of the other world,

original: tāsetvā adhigataṃ viya katvā kathesi. Dvattiṃsakammakāraṇapañcavīsatimahābhayappabhedañhi🔽idhalokatthaṃ buddhe bhagavati tāsetvā tāsetvā kathayante pacchābāhaṃ, gāḷhabandhanaṃ
analyzed: tāsetvā adhigatam viya katvā kathesi dvattiṃsa kamma kāraṇa pañcavīsati mahā bhaya ppabhedam hi  idhalokattham buddhe bhagavati tāsetvā tāsetvā kathayante pacchābāham gāḷha bandhanam
translated: and he spoke as if he had already attained it.

original: bandhitvā cātumahāpathe pahārasatena tāḷetvā dakkhiṇadvārena niyyamāno viya āghātanabhaṇḍikāya🔽ṭhapitasīso viya sūle uttāsito viya mattahatthinā maddiyamāno viya ca saṃviggo hoti.
analyzed: bandhitvā cātumahāpathe pahāra satena tāḷetvā dakkhiṇa dvārena niyyamānaḥ viya āghātana bhaṇḍikāya  ṭhapita sīsaḥ viya sūle uttāsitaḥ viya matta hatthinā maddiyamānaḥ viya ca saṃviggaḥ hoti
translated: For the thirty-two aspects of the four noble truths and the twenty-five great fears are spoken of as if they were already attained when they are spoken of for the sake of this world, and then one is alarmed as if one were being led out by the southern gate after being bound with heavy fetters and being beaten a hundred times at the crossroads.

original: Paralokatthañca kathayante nirayādīsu nibbatto viya devalokasampattiṃ anubhavamāno viya ca hoti.
analyzed: para loka attham ca kathayante niraya ādīsu nibbattaḥ viya deva loka sampattim anubhavamānaḥ viya ca hoti
translated: And they are spoken of as if one were already reborn in the hells, etc., and were already experiencing the bliss of the heavenly world when they are spoken of for the sake of the other world.

original: Sampahaṃsesīti paṭiladdhaguṇena codesi, mahānisaṃsaṃ katvā kathesīti attho.
analyzed: sampahaṃsesi iti paṭiladdha guṇena codesi mahā nisaṃsam katvā kathesi iti attho
translated: “He exhorted them” means he urged them with the special qualities he had attained. The meaning is: he spoke of them with great profit.

original: Saṅkhārānaṃ ādīnavanti heṭṭhā paṭhamamaggādhigamatthaṃ kāmānaṃ ādīnavaṃ kathesi,
analyzed: saṅkhārānaṃ ādīnavanti heṭṭhā paṭhama magga adhigama attham kāmānam ādīnavam kathesi
translated: “The danger in determinations” : previously he spoke of the danger in sensual desires for the purpose of attaining the first path.

original: – “kurūsu viharati kammāsadhammaṃ nāma kurūnaṃ nigamo, taṃ gocaragāmaṃ katvā”ti.
analyzed: kurūsu viharati kammāsadhammam nāma kurūnam nigamaḥ tam gocara gāmam katvā ati
translated: That is why the meaning should be regarded here as follows: “He was staying among the Kurus in a market town of the Kurus named Kammasadhamma, making that town his base for alms.”

original: Āyasmāti piyavacanametaṃ, gāravavacanametaṃ. Ānandoti tassa therassa nāmaṃ. Ekamantanti
analyzed: āyasma iti piya vacanam etam gārava vacanam etam ānandaḥ ti tassa therassa nāmam eka mantanti
translated: Venerable is a term of affection, a term of respect. The venerable one called Ānanda: this is the name of that elder. Seated at one side:

original: bhāvanapuṃsakaniddeso – “visamaṃ candimasūriyā parivattantī”tiādīsu viya. Tasmā yathā
analyzed: bhāva napuṃsaka niddesaḥ visamam candima sūriyā parivattanti itiādīsu tasmai yathā
translated: this is a demonstrative pronoun, as in the passages: “The moon and sun go irregularly” , etc.

original: nisinno ekamantaṃ nisinno hoti, tathā nisīdīti evamettha attho daṭṭhabbo. Bhummatthe
analyzed: nisinnaḥ ekamantam nisinnaḥ hoti tathā nisīdī iti evam ettha atthaḥ daṭṭhabbo bhummatthe
translated: Therefore the meaning here should be regarded as follows: “Seated in such a way that he was seated at one side,”

original: vā etaṃ upayogavacanaṃ nisīdīti upāvisi. Paṇḍitā hi garuṭṭhāniyaṃ upasaṅkamitvā āsanakusalatāya
analyzed: vā etam upayoga vacanam nisīdi iti upāvisi paṇḍitāḥ hi garuṭṭhāniyam upasaṅkamitvā āsana kusala tāya
translated: or this is a locative expression, meaning “having sat down.” For the wise, when they approach a venerable person, sit down after first arranging their outer robe over one shoulder so as to show that they are humble.

original: ekamantaṃ nisīdanti. Ayañca tesaṃ aññataro, tasmā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
analyzed: ekamantam nisīdanti ayam ca tesam aññataraḥ tasmai ekamantam nisīdi
translated: and so he sat down to one side.

original: Kathaṃ nisinno kho pana ekamantaṃ nisinno hotīti? Cha nisajjadose vajjetvā. Seyyathidaṃ
analyzed: katham nisinnaḥ kha pana ekamantam nisinnaḥ hoti iti nisajja dose vajjetvā sā iyyathidam
translated: But how does one sit down to one side? By avoiding the six faults of sitting, that is to say,

original: – atidūraṃ, accāsannaṃ, uparivātaṃ, unnatappadesaṃ, atisammukhaṃ, atipacchāti. Atidūre
analyzed: ati dūram acca āsannam upari vātam unnata ppadesam ati sammukham ati pacchā ati ati dūre
translated: sitting too far away, too near, upwind, on higher ground, facing away from the teacher, or with one’s head screened off.🔽For if one sits too far away, one may have to speak loudly,

original: nisinno hi sace kathetukāmo hoti, uccāsaddena kathetabbaṃ hoti. Accāsanne nisinno🔽saṅghaṭṭanaṃ karoti. Uparivāte nisinno sarīragandhena bādhati. Unnatappadese nisinno🔽agāravaṃ pakāseti. Atisammukhā nisinno sace daṭṭhukāmo hoti, cakkhunā cakkhuṃ āhacca
analyzed: nisinnaḥ hi sace kathetu kāmaḥ hoti uccāsaddena kathetabbam hoti accāsanne nisinnaḥ  saṅghaṭṭanam karoti upari vāte nisinnaḥ sarīra gandhena bādhati unnata ppadese nisinnaḥ  agāravam pakāseti atisammukhā nisinnaḥ sace daṭṭhu kāmo hoti cakkhunā cakkhum āhacca
translated: and if one sits too near, one may touch the teacher.🔽If one sits upwind, one is offended by the smell of the teacher’s body.🔽If one sits on higher ground, one shows disrespect.🔽If one sits facing away from the teacher, one may look at the teacher only by turning one’s head.

original: daṭṭhabbaṃ hoti. Atipacchā nisinno sace daṭṭhukāmo hoti, gīvaṃ parivattetvā daṭṭhabbaṃ
analyzed: daṭṭhabbam hoti atipacchā nisinnaḥ sace daṭṭhu kāmo hoti gīvam parivattetvā daṭṭhabbam
translated: If one sits with one’s head screened off, one may look at the teacher only by uncovering one’s head.

original: hoti. Tasmā ayampi tikkhattuṃ bhagavantaṃ padakkhiṇaṃ katvā sakkaccaṃ vanditvā ete
analyzed: hoti tasmai ayam pi tikkhattum bhagavantam padakkhiṇam katvā sakkaccam vanditvā ete
translated: Therefore, after circumambulating the Blessed One three times, he paid respect with his head at the Blessed One’s feet and sat down to one side.

original: cha nisajjadose vajjetvā dakkhiṇajāṇumaṇḍalassa abhimukhaṭṭhāne chabbaṇṇānaṃ buddharasmīnaṃ🔽anto pavisitvā pasannalākhārasaṃ vigāhanto viya suvaṇṇapaṭaṃ pārupanto viya rattuppalamālāvitānamajjhaṃ
analyzed: cha nisajja dose vajjetvā dakkhiṇa jāṇu maṇḍalassa abhimukha ṭṭhāne chabbaṇṇānam buddha rasmīnam  antar pavisitvā pasanna lākhā rasam vigāhantaḥ viya suvaṇṇa paṭam pārupantaḥ viya rattuppala mālā vitāna majjham
translated: after entering into the midst of the six-coloured rays of the Buddha’s beauty,

original: pavisanto viya ca dhammabhaṇḍāgāriko āyasmā ānando nisīdi. Tena vuttaṃ – “ekamantaṃ nisīdī”ti.
analyzed: pavisantaḥ viya ca dhammabhaṇḍāgārikaḥ āyasmā ānandaḥ nisīdi tena vuttam ekamantam nisīdi iti
translated: as if he were squeezing a cloth of gold, as if he were putting on a golden cloth, as if he were entering into the middle of a garland of red lotuses, the venerable Ānanda, the treasurer of the Dhamma, sat down. Therefore it is said: “sat down on one side.”

original: Kāya pana velāya, kena kāraṇena ayamāyasmā bhagavantaṃ upasaṅkamantoti? Sāyanhavelāyaṃ🔽paccayākārapañhapucchanakāraṇena. Taṃ divasaṃ kirāyamāyasmā kulasaṅgahatthāya gharadvāre
analyzed: kāya pana kena kāraṇena bhagavantam upasaṅkamantaḥ iti  paccaya ākāra pañha pucchana kāraṇena tam divasam kula saṅga hatthāya ghara dvāre
translated: But at what time, and for what reason, did this venerable one approach the Fortunate One? In the evening time,

original: gharadvāre sahassabhaṇḍikaṃ nikkhipanto viya kammāsadhammagāmaṃ piṇḍāya caritvā piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto
analyzed: ghara dvāre sahassa bhaṇḍikam nikkhipantaḥ viya kammāsadhammagāmam piṇḍāya caritvā piṇḍapāta paṭikkantaḥ
translated: for the purpose of asking a question about the method of conditions. On that day, it seems, this venerable one, after wandering for alms in the village of Kammāsadhamma, as if placing a thousand coins at the door of each house for the purpose of gathering the families,🔽after returning from the alms round,

original: satthu vattaṃ dassetvā satthari gandhakuṭiṃ paviṭṭhe satthāraṃ vanditvā attano divāṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: satthu vattam dassetvā satthari gandhakuṭim paviṭṭhe satthāram vanditvā attanaḥ divāṭṭhānam
translated: after showing respect to the Teacher, after worshipping the Teacher who had entered the Fragrant Cottage, and after going to his own day-quarters,

original: gantvā antevāsikesu vattaṃ dassetvā paṭikkantesu divāṭṭhānaṃ paṭisammajjitvā cammakkhaṇḍaṃ🔽paññapetvā udakatumbato udakaṃ gahetvā udakena hatthapāde sītale katvā pallaṅkaṃ
analyzed: gantvā antevāsikesu vattam dassetvā paṭikkantesu divāṭṭhānam paṭisammajjitvā camma kkhaṇḍaṃ  paññapetvā udaka tumbataḥ udakam gahetvā udakena hattha pāde sītale katvā pallaṅkam
translated: and after he had done so, he swept the meditation yard, spread out a piece of leather,

original: ābhujitvā nisinno sotāpattiphalasamāpattiṃ samāpajji. Atha paricchinnakālavasena🔽samāpattito uṭṭhāya paccayākāre ñāṇaṃ otāresi. So – “avijjāpaccayā saṅkhārā”tiādito🔽paṭṭhāya antaṃ, antato paṭṭhāya ādiṃ, ubhayantato paṭṭhāya majjhaṃ, majjhato paṭṭhāya
analyzed: ābhujitvā nisinnaḥ sa utāpatti phala samāpattim samāpajji atha paricchinna kāla vasena  samāpattitaḥ uṭṭhāya paccaya ākāre ñāṇam otāresi saḥ avijjā paccayā saṅkhāra ati āditaḥ  paṭṭhāya antam antatas paṭṭhāya ādim ubhayantataḥ paṭṭhāya majjham majjhataḥ paṭṭhāya
translated: took water in his alms-bowl from a water-pot, cooled his limbs with the water, and then he sat down cross-legged.🔽He attained the state of concentration called Stream-Entry. Then, after the lapse of a time determined by the Dhamma,🔽he rose from that state of concentration and directed his mind to the principle of conditionality. He began at the beginning

original: ubho ante pāpento tikkhattuṃ dvādasapadaṃ paccayākāraṃ sammasi. Tassevaṃ sammasantassa🔽paccayākāro vibhūto hutvā uttānakuttānako viya upaṭṭhāsi.
analyzed: ubho ante pāpentaḥ tikkhattum dvādasa padam paccaya ākāram sammasi tassa ivam sammasantassa  paccaya ākāraḥ vibhūtaḥ hutvā uttānaka uttānakaḥ viya upaṭṭhāsi
translated: with the words, “With ignorance as condition there are formations,” and he worked through to the end, and then he began again at the beginning and worked through to the end, and then he began at the middle and worked through to the end in both directions.🔽As he did so, the principle of conditionality became clear to him, and it appeared as if he were looking at the finest piece of woven silk.🔽Then he thought, “This principle of conditionality is called ‘profound and appears profound’

original: Tato cintesi – “ayaṃ paccayākāro sabbabuddhehi – ‘gambhīro ceva gambhīrāvabhāso cā’ti
analyzed: tatas cintesi ayam paccaya ākāraḥ sabba buddhehi gambhīraḥ ca iva gambhīra avabhāso ca ati
translated: by all the Buddhas,

original: kathito, mayhaṃ kho pana padesañāṇe ṭhitassa sāvakassa sato uttāno vibhūto pākaṭo
analyzed: kathitaḥ mayham kho pana padesa ñāṇe ṭhitassa sāvakassa sataḥ uttānaḥ vibhūtaḥ pākaṭaḥ
translated: “When I am standing on the knowledge of the region, the knowledge of the past and future, which is clear, open, and manifest to me,

original: hutvā upaṭṭhāti, mayhaṃyeva nu kho esa uttānako hutvā upaṭṭhāti, udāhu aññesampī”ti?
analyzed: hutvā upaṭṭhāti mayham yeva nu kho esa uttānakaḥ hutvā upaṭṭhāti udāhu aññesam pi iti
translated: does it occur to me alone, or to others also?”

original: Athassa etadahosi – “handāhaṃ imaṃ pañhaṃ gahetvā bhagavantaṃ pucchāmi, addhā me🔽bhagavā imaṃ atthuppattiṃ katvā sālindaṃ sineruṃ ukkhipanto viya ekaṃ suttantakathaṃ🔽kathetvā dassessati. Buddhānañhi vinayapaññattiṃ, bhummantaraṃ, paccayākāraṃ, samayantaranti
analyzed: atha assa etat ahosi handa aham imam pañham gahetvā bhagavantam pucchāmi addhā me  bhagavā imam attha uppattim katvā sālindam sinerum ukkhipantaḥ viya ekam suttanta katham  kathetvā dassessati buddhānam hi vinaya paññattim bhummantaram paccaya ākāram samayantaram ti
translated: Then he thought: “Let me take this question to the Blessed One.🔽He will make a statement of the meaning and will give a discourse on the Dhamma like one who is lifting up the Sineru, the king of mountains,

original: imāni cattāri ṭhānāni patvā gajjitaṃ mahantaṃ hoti, ñāṇaṃ anupavisati, buddhañāṇassa
analyzed: imāni cattāri ṭhānāni patvā gajjitam mahantam hoti ñāṇam anupavisati buddha ñāṇassa
translated: For when the Buddhas have reached these four topics, their roar is great: the formulation of the Discipline, the plane of the worlds, the analysis of conditions, and the analysis of time.

original: mahantabhāvo paññāyati, desanā gambhīrā hoti tilakkhaṇabbhāhatā suññatapaṭisaṃyuttā”ti.
analyzed: mahanta bhāvaḥ paññāyati desanā gambhīrā hoti ti lakkhaṇa bbhā hatā suññata paṭisaṃyuttā ati
translated: Their knowledge penetrates, the greatness of the Buddha knowledge is seen, the teaching is profound, stamped with the three characteristics, and concerned with voidness.

original: So kiñcāpi pakatiyāva ekadivase satavārampi sahassavārampi bhagavantaṃ upasaṅkamanto
analyzed: saḥ kiñcā api eka divase sata vāram pi sahassa vāram pi bhagavantam upasaṅkamantaḥ
translated: ” Although he could have gone to the Blessed One a hundred or a thousand times a day,

original: na ahetuakāraṇena upasaṅkamati, taṃ divasaṃ pana imaṃ pañhaṃ gahetvā – “imaṃ buddhagandhahatthiṃ
analyzed: na ahetu akāraṇena upasaṅkamati tam divasam pana imam pañham gahetvā imam buddha gandhahatthim
translated: He did not go to the Blessed One without reason or cause. On that day he had taken the question with him, thinking, “I shall listen to the cry of the wisdom-peacock when it has approached the Buddha-elephant,

original: āpajja ñāṇakoñcanādaṃ sossāmi, buddhasīhaṃ āpajja ñāṇasīhanādaṃ sossāmi, buddhasindhavaṃ🔽āpajja ñāṇapadavikkamaṃ passissāmī”ti cintetvā divāṭṭhānā uṭṭhāya cammakkhaṇḍaṃ papphoṭetvā
analyzed: āpajja ñāṇa koñca nādam sossāmi buddha sīham āpajja ñāṇa sīha nādam sossāmi buddha sindhavam  āpajja ñāṇa pada vikkamam passissāmi iti cintetvā divāṭṭhānāt uṭṭhāya camma kkhaṇḍam papphoṭetvā
translated: I shall listen to the cry of the wisdom-lion when it has approached the Buddha-lion, I shall see the stride of the wisdom-horse when it has approached the Buddha-horse.”

original: ādāya sāyanhasamaye bhagavantaṃ upasaṅkami. Tena vuttaṃ – “sāyanhavelāyaṃ paccayākārapañhapucchanakāraṇena upasaṅkamanto”ti.
analyzed: ādāya sāyanha samaye bhagavantam upasaṅkami tena vuttam sāyanha velāyam paccaya ākāra pañha pucchana kāraṇena upasaṅkamantaḥ iti
translated: Rising from his day-quarters, he shook out his hide, took it, and approached the Blessed One in the evening. That is why it is said “in the evening, for the purpose of asking the question about the dependent origination.”

original: Yāva gambhīroti ettha yāvasaddo pamāṇātikkame, atikkamma pamāṇaṃ gambhīro, atigambhīroti🔽attho. Gambhīrāvabhāsoti gambhīrova hutvā avabhāsati, dissatīti attho. Ekañhi uttānameva
analyzed: yāva gambhīraḥ iti ettha yāva saddo pamāṇa atikkame atikkamma pamāṇam gambhīraḥ atigambhīraḥ ti  atthaḥ gambhīra avabhāsaḥ ti gambhīraḥ uva hutvā avabhāsati dissati iti attho ekam hi uttānam eva
translated: As to “as deep as it is wide”: the word as is used here in the sense of beyond measure; it is deep beyond measure, extremely deep, is the meaning.🔽It shines with the radiance of the deep, is what is meant. For one kind of water is deep but does not shine with the radiance of the deep, like old water in a black pool overgrown with moss, etc.;

original: gambhīrāvabhāsaṃ hoti pūtipaṇṇādivasena kāḷavaṇṇapurāṇaudakaṃ viya. Tañhi jāṇuppamāṇampi
analyzed: gambhīra avabhāsam hoti pūti paṇṇa ādi vasena kāḷa vaṇṇa purāṇa audakam viya tat hi jāṇu ppamāṇam pi
translated: for that is only knee-deep or waist-deep.

original: sataporisaṃ viya dissati. Ekaṃ gambhīraṃ uttānāvabhāsaṃ hoti maṇigaṅgāya vippasannaudakaṃ🔽viya. Tañhi sataporisampi jāṇuppamāṇaṃ viya khāyati. Ekaṃ uttānaṃ uttānāvabhāsaṃ
analyzed: sata porisam viya dissati ekam gambhīram uttāna avabhāsam hoti maṇi gaṅgāya vippasanna audakam  viya tat hi sata porisam pi jāṇu ppamāṇam viya khāyati ekam uttānam uttāna avabhāsam
translated: It is like a fathom-deep pool that appears to be only knee-deep. One is deep but appears to be shallow, like the water of the Maṇikaṅgala Lake.🔽For although it is a fathom deep, it appears to be only knee-deep. One is shallow and appears to be shallow, like the water in a saucer.

original: hoti cāṭiādīsu udakaṃ viya. Ekaṃ gambhīraṃ gambhīrāvabhāsaṃ hoti sinerupādakamahāsamudde
analyzed: hoti cāṭi ādīsu udakam viya ekam gambhīram gambhīra avabhāsam hoti sineru pādaka mahā samudde
translated: One is deep and appears to be deep, like the water in the great ocean under the Sineru mountain.

original: udakaṃ viya. Evaṃ udakameva cattāri nāmāni labhati. Paṭiccasamuppāde panetaṃ natthi.🔽Ayañhi gambhīro ceva gambhīrāvabhāso cāti ekameva nāmaṃ labhati. Evarūpo samānopi
analyzed: udakam viya evam udakam eva cattāri nāmāni labhati paṭiccasamuppāde pana etam natthi  ayam hi gambhīraḥ ca iva gambhīra avabhāsaḥ ca ati ekam eva nāmam labhati evarūpaḥ samānaḥ api
translated: Thus water itself gets four different names. But this is not so in the case of dependent origination.🔽For this is deep and appears to be deep. It gets only one name.

original: atha ca pana me uttānakuttānako viya khāyati, yadidaṃ acchariyaṃ, bhante, abbhutaṃ
analyzed: atha ca pana me uttānaka uttānakaḥ viya khāyati yat idam acchariyam bhante abbhutam
translated: But it appears to me to be shallow and easy to understand, as if it were something wonderful, venerable sir, as if it were something marvelous, venerable sir.”

original: bhanteti. Evaṃ attano vimhayaṃ pakāsento pañhaṃ pucchitvā tuṇhībhūto nisīdi.
analyzed: bhante ti evam attanaḥ vimhayam pakāsento pañham pucchitvā tuṇhībhūtaḥ nisīdi
translated: Thus he asked his question, making known his own wonderment, and then sat down in silence.

original: Bhagavā tassa vacanaṃ sutvā – “ānando bhavaggaggahaṇāya hatthaṃ pasārento viya, sineruṃ
analyzed: bhagavā tassa vacanam sutvā ānandaḥ bhavagga ggahaṇāya hattham pasārentaḥ viya sinerum
translated: When the Exalted One heard his words, he said: “Ānanda, you are like one who stretches out his hand to grasp at the top of the world, or to grasp at Sineru, the monarch of mountains,

original: chinditvā miñjaṃ nīharituṃ vāyamamāno viya, vinā nāvāya mahāsamuddaṃ taritukāmo viya,
analyzed: chinditvā miñjam nīharitum vāyamamānaḥ viya vinā nāvāya mahā samuddam taritu kāmaḥ viya
translated: as if trying to thresh the husk after cutting the rice, as if trying to cross the great ocean without a boat,

original: pathaviṃ parivattetvā pathavojaṃ gahetuṃ vāyamamāno viya buddhavisayapañhaṃ attano
analyzed: pathavim parivattetvā pathavojam gahetum vāyamamānaḥ viya buddha visaya pañham attano
translated: as if trying to turn the earth upside down and take the earth below. He is speaking as if the question within the Buddha’s domain were obvious to him.🔽I will explain its profundity to him.” He said:

original: uttānaṃ vadati. Handassa gambhīrabhāvaṃ ācikkhissāmī”ti cintetvā mā hevantiādimāha.
analyzed: uttānam vadati handassa gambhīra bhāvam ācikkhissāmi iti cintetvā mā hevanti ādim āha
translated: “Do not say so, Ānanda!”

original: Tattha mā hevanti ha-kāro nipātamattaṃ. Evaṃ mā bhaṇīti attho. Mā hevanti ca idaṃ vacanaṃ bhagavā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ ussādentopi bhaṇati apasādentopi.
analyzed: tattha mā hevanti hakāraḥ nipāta mattam evam mā bhaṇi iti atthaḥ ca idam vacanam bhagavā āyasmantam ānandam ussādentaḥ api bhaṇati apasādentaḥ api
translated: Herein, the syllable ha is merely a particle. The meaning is: “Do not say thus.” And this statement, “Do not say so, Ānanda,” the Blessed One says in order to encourage the venerable Ānanda and in order to discourage him.

original: Ussādanāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: ussādanā vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the encouragement

original: Tattha ussādento – ānanda, tvaṃ mahāpañño visadañāṇo, tena te gambhīropi paṭiccasamuppādo
analyzed: tattha ussādentaḥ ānanda tvam mahā paññaḥ visada ñāṇo tena te gambhīraḥ api paṭiccasamuppādaḥ
translated: Herein, encouraging him, the Blessed One said: “Ānanda, you are greatly wise, you are of clear understanding. Therefore dependent origination, though profound, appears to you as if it were obvious.

original: uttānako viya khāyati. Aññesaṃ panesa uttānakoti na sallakkhetabbo, gambhīroyeva
analyzed: uttānakaḥ viya khāyati aññesam pana esa uttānakaḥ ti na sallakkhetabbo gambhīraḥ eva
translated: But to others it should not be regarded as obvious. It is profound and it appears profound.

original: ca gambhīrāvabhāso ca. Tattha catasso upamā vadanti. Chamāse subhojanarasapuṭṭhassa
analyzed: ca gambhīra avabhāso ca tattha catasso upamāḥ vadanti cha māse su bhojana rasa puṭṭhassa
translated: Herein, four similes are given. To one who has eaten fine food, flavoured with various sauces,

original: kira katayogassa mahāmallassa samajjasamaye katamallapāsāṇaparicayassa yuddhabhūmiṃ
analyzed: kira kata yogassa mahā mallassa sa majja samaye kata malla pāsāṇa paricayassa yuddha bhūmim
translated: The story goes that when the great wrestler Kattayagga was going to the wrestling-ground,

original: gacchantassa antarā mallapāsāṇaṃ dassesuṃ, so – kiṃ etanti āha. Mallapāsāṇoti. Āharatha
analyzed: gacchantassa antarā malla pāsāṇam dassesum saḥ kim etat iti āha malla pāsāṇaḥ iti āharatha
translated: they showed him a wrestling-stone on the way. He asked, “What is that?” “A wrestling-stone.” “Bring it.”

analyzed: nanti ukkhipitum na sakkoma ati vutte sayam gantvā kuhim imassa bhāriya ṭṭhānan ti vatvā
translated: When they said, “We cannot lift it,” he went himself and said, “Where is its heavy end?”

analyzed: dvīhi hatthehi dve pāsāṇe ukkhipitvā kīḷā guḷe viya khipitvā agamāsi tattha mallassa

analyzed: malla pāsāṇaḥ lahukaḥ api na aññesam lahukaḥ ti vattabbo cha māse su bhojana rasa puṭṭhaḥ mallo

analyzed: viya hi kappa sata sahassam abhinīhāra sampannaḥ āyasmai ānandaḥ yathā mallassa mahā bala tāya  mallapāsāṇaḥ lahukaḥ evam therassa mahā pañña tāya paṭiccasamuppādaḥ uttānaḥ so aññesam
translated: was great in understanding. Just as the wrestling-stone was light for the wrestler because of his great strength,
