analyzed: catu yojana satiko timirapiṅgalo pañca yojana satikaḥ ānandaḥ timinandaḥ ajjhārohaḥ mahātimī iti
translated: four leagues long, and a Timirapiṅgala, five leagues long, and a Timinanda, a Mahātimī, and an Ajjhāroha,

analyzed: ime cattāraḥ yojana sahassikā tattha timira piṅgalena iva dīpenti tassa kira dakkhiṇa kaṇṇam
translated: all of them a thousand leagues long. The Timirapiṅgala illuminates the ocean. When he moves his right fin,

translated: the water in a region five hundred leagues long is disturbed. So too when he moves his left fin, his tail,

analyzed: tathā sīsam dve pana kaṇṇe cāletvā naṅguṭṭhena udakam paharitvā sīsam apara aparam  katvā kīḷitum āraddhassa satta ṭṭha yojana sate padese bhājane pakkhipitvā uddhane āropitam
translated: and his head. When he moves both fins, strikes the water with his tail, and begins to play, moving his head this way and that,🔽the water in a region seven or eight hundred leagues long boils up like milk in a pot over the fire. In a region three hundred leagues long,

original: So evaṃ vadeyya – “ayaṃ mahāsamuddo gambhīro gambhīroti vadanti kutassa gambhīratā,

translated: He might say: “They say that this great ocean is deep, deep. But where is its depth?

translated: We cannot even get water to drink.”

original: mahāsamuddo uttānoti, aññesaṃ khuddakamacchānaṃ uttānoti na vattabbo, evameva ñāṇupapannassa
analyzed: mahā samuddaḥ uttānaḥ ti aññesam khuddakam acchānam uttānaḥ ti na vattabbaḥ evam eva ñāṇa upapannassa
translated: The great ocean is “open” to the king of the garuḍas, but it is not “open” to the other small fish.

original: therassa paṭiccasamuppādo uttānoti, aññesampi uttānoti na vattabbo.🔽Supaṇṇarājā ca diyaḍḍhayojanasatiko, tassa dakkhiṇapakkho paññāsayojaniko hoti tathā
analyzed: therassa paṭiccasamuppādaḥ uttānaḥ ti aññesam pi uttānaḥ ti na vattabbo  supaṇṇa rājā ca diyaḍḍha yojana satiko tassa dakkhiṇa pakkhaḥ paññāsa yojanikaḥ hoti tathā
translated: Similarly, dependent origination is “open” to the Elder, but it is not “open” to others.

original: vāmapakkho, piñchavaṭṭi saṭṭhiyojanikā, gīvā tiṃsayojanikā, mukhaṃ navayojanaṃ, pādā

original: nappahoti. So evaṃ vadeyya – “ayaṃ ākāso ananto anantoti vadanti, kutassa anantatā,
analyzed: so evam vadeyya ayam ākāsaḥ anantaḥ anantaḥ iti vadanti kutassa ananta tā
translated: He might say: “They say that space is infinite, but where is its infinity?

original: mayaṃ pakkhavātappasāraṇokāsampi na labhāmā”ti. Tattha kāyupapannassa supaṇṇarañño
analyzed: mayam pakkha vāta pasāraṇa ukāsam pi na labhāma ati tattha kāya upapannassa supaṇṇa rañño
translated: We cannot even get room to spread our wings.”🔽The king of the garuḍas, who is embodied in that way,

analyzed: ākāsaḥ parittaḥ ti aññesam khuddaka pakkhīnam parittaḥ ti na vattabbo evam eva ñāṇa upapannassa

translated: So too, the Elder’s dependent origination was clear, but it should not be said that it was clear for others.

translated: But the asura king Rāhu is four thousand eight hundred leagues from the soles of his feet to the top of his head.

translated: The space between his two arms is one hundred and twenty leagues. His breadth is one hundred leagues.

analyzed: hattha pāda talāni ti yojana satikāni tathā mukham ekekam aṅguli pabbam paññāsa yojanam

analyzed: tathā bhamukantaram nalāṭam ti yojana satikam sīsam nava yojana satikam tassa mahā samuddaṃ  otiṇṇassa gambhīram udakam jāṇu pamāṇam hoti saḥ evam vadeyya ayam mahā samuddaḥ
translated: so too the space between his eyebrows. His forehead is one hundred leagues. His head is nine hundred leagues. When he enters the ocean,

original: udakaṃ na labhāmā”ti. Tattha kāyupapannassa rāhuno mahāsamuddo uttānoti, aññesaṃ
analyzed: udakam na labhāma ati tattha kāya upapannassa rāhuno mahā samuddo uttānoti aññesam
translated: “We cannot find any water.” Herein, the Elder Rāhula had the Great Ocean revealed to him, but it could not be said that it was revealed to others.

original: uttānoti na vattabbo, evameva ñāṇupapannassa therassa paṭiccasamuppādo uttānoti,🔽aññesampi uttānoti na vattabbo. Etamatthaṃ sandhāya bhagavā – “mā hevaṃ, ānanda,
analyzed: uttānaḥ ti na vattabbaḥ evam eva ñāṇa upapannassa therassa paṭiccasamuppādaḥ uttānaḥ ti  aññesam pi uttānaḥ ti na vattabbaḥ etam attham sandhāya bhagavā mā ha ivam ānanda

translated: With reference to this matter the Blessed One said: “Do not say so, Ānanda! Do not say so, Ānanda!”

analyzed: therassa hi catūhi kāraṇehi gambhīraḥ api paṭiccasamuppādaḥ uttānaḥ ti upaṭṭhāti katamehi catūhi pubba upanissaya sampattiyā tittha vāsena sotāpanna tāya bahu ssuta bhāvena ati
translated: For the Elder, although profound, dependent origination appeared as clear as clear could be for four reasons. What are the four? The possession of the prerequisite for the past, the dwelling in a place of pilgrimage, the state of being a stream-enterer, and the state of being learned.

original: Pubbūpanissayasampattikathā
analyzed: pubba upanissaya sampatti kathā
translated: The possession of the prerequisite for the past

analyzed: ṭhāne bhoga gāmam adāsi saḥ kadāci āgantvā pitaram ca satthāram ca passati atha eka divasam  paccantaḥ kupitaḥ sumanaḥ rañño pesesi paccantaḥ kupito ti rājā mayā tvam tattha

translated: He embraced him, kissed him on the head, and said, “I will grant you a boon, my son.” “Very well, sire.

original: icchāmahaṃ mahārāja bhagavantaṃ temāsaṃ catūhi paccayehi upaṭṭhahanto jīvitaṃ avañjhaṃ🔽kātuṃ, imameva varaṃ dehī”ti āha. “Na sakkā tāta, aññaṃ varehī”ti vutte “deva, khattiyānaṃ
analyzed: icchāmaham mahā rāja bhagavantam temāsam catūhi paccayehi upaṭṭhahantaḥ jīvitam a vañjham  kātum imam eva varam dehi iti āha na sakkā tāta aññam varehi iti vutte deva khattiyānam
translated: I wish, sire, to render the life of the Exalted One fruitful by ministering to him for three months with the four requisites.🔽Grant me this boon.” “It is not possible, my son. Ask for another boon.” “Sire, there are two things that are not possible for princes.

original: nāma dve kathā natthi, etameva dehi, na me aññenattho”ti. Tāta buddhānaṃ nāma cittaṃ
analyzed: nāma dve kathā natthi etam eva dehi na me tāta buddhānam nāma cittam
translated: Grant me this boon. I have no desire for anything else.” “My son, the minds of Buddhas are hard to fathom.

original: dujjānaṃ, sace bhagavā na icchissati, mayā dinnepi kiṃ bhavissatīti? So – “sādhu,
analyzed: dujjānam sace bhagavā naḥ icchissati mayā dinne pi kim bhavissati iti saḥ sādhu
translated: If the Exalted One does not wish it, what will become of it even if I grant it?” “Very well, sire.

original: deva, ahaṃ bhagavato cittaṃ jānissāmī”ti vihāraṃ gato.
analyzed: deva aham bhagavato cittam jānissāmi iti vihāram gataḥ
translated: I will know the mind of the Exalted One.” He went to the monastery.

original: Tena ca samayena bhattakiccaṃ niṭṭhapetvā bhagavā gandhakuṭiṃ paviṭṭho hoti. So maṇḍalamāḷe
analyzed: tena ca samayena bhatta kiccam niṭṭhapetvā bhagavā gandhakuṭim paviṭṭhaḥ hoti saḥ maṇḍala māḷe
translated: At that time the Exalted One had entered his fragrant chamber after finishing his meal. He went to the bhikkhus who were sitting in the pavilion.

original: sannisinnānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ santikaṃ agamāsi. Te taṃ āhaṃsu – “rājaputta, kasmā āgatosī”ti?
analyzed: sannisinnānam bhikkhūnam santikam agamāsi te tam āhaṃsu rāja putta kasmai āgataḥ asi iti
translated: They asked him, “Prince, why have you come?”

original: Bhagavantaṃ dassanāya, dassetha me bhagavantanti. Na mayaṃ, rājaputta, icchiticchitakkhaṇe
analyzed: bhagavantam dassanāya dassetha me bhagavantanti na mayam rāja putte icchiticchita kkhaṇe
translated: “Prince, we do not get to see the Teacher whenever we want to.”🔽“But who does get to see him, venerable sir?”

original: satthāraṃ daṭṭhuṃ labhāmāti. Ko pana, bhante, labhatīti? Sumanatthero nāma rājaputtāti.
analyzed: satthāram daṭṭhum labhāma ati kaḥ pana bhante labhati iti sumana theraḥ nāma rāja putta ati
translated: “There is a monk named Sumana, prince.”🔽“Where is the elder, venerable sir?”

original: “So kuhiṃ, bhante, thero”ti. Therassa nisinnaṭṭhānaṃ pucchitvā gantvā vanditvā –
analyzed: saḥ kuhim bhante thero ti therassa nisinna ṭṭhānam pucchitvā gantvā vanditvā
translated: After asking where the elder’s seat was, he went there, paid homage to him, and said,🔽“Venerable sir, I want to see the Blessed One. Please show me the Blessed One.”

original: “icchāmahaṃ, bhante, bhagavantaṃ passituṃ, dassetha me”ti āha. Thero – “ehi rājaputtā”ti
analyzed: icchāmaham bhante bhagavantam passitum dassetha mā iti āha theraḥ ehi rāja putta ati
translated: The elder said, “Come, prince,”

original: taṃ gahetvā taṃ gandhakuṭipariveṇe ṭhapetvā gandhakuṭiṃ abhiruhi. Atha naṃ bhagavā
analyzed: tam gahetvā tam gandha kuṭi pariveṇe ṭhapetvā gandha kuṭim abhiruhi atha nam bhagavā
translated: and after taking him to the courtyard of the Fragrant Cottage, he went up into the Fragrant Cottage. Then the Blessed One🔽said, “Sumana, why have you come?”

original: – “sumana, kasmā āgatosī”ti āha. Rājaputto, bhante, bhagavantaṃ dassanāya āgatoti.🔽Tena hi bhikkhu āsanaṃ paññāpehīti. Thero āsanaṃ paññāpesi, nisīdi bhagavā paññatte
analyzed: sumana kasmai āgataḥ asi iti āha rāja puttaḥ bhante bhagavantam dassanāya āgataḥ ti  tena hi bhikkhu āsanam paññāpehi iti theraḥ āsanam paññāpesi nisīdi bhagavā paññatte
translated: “Venerable sir, I have come to see the Blessed One.”🔽“Well then, monk, prepare a seat.” The elder prepared a seat, and the Blessed One sat down on the seat that was prepared. The prince paid homage to the Blessed One and exchanged polite and courteous greetings with him.

original: āsane. Rājaputto bhagavantaṃ vanditvā paṭisanthāraṃ akāsi. Kadā āgatosi rājaputtāti?
analyzed: āsane rāja puttaḥ bhagavantam vanditvā paṭisanthāram akāsi kadā āgataḥ si rāja putta ati
translated: “When did you come, prince?”

original: Bhante, tumhesu gandhakuṭiṃ paviṭṭhesu. Bhikkhū pana – “na mayaṃ icchiticchitakkhaṇe
analyzed: bhante tumhesu gandhakuṭim paviṭṭhesu bhikkhū pana na mayam icchiticchita khaṇe
translated: “Venerable sir, when you entered the Perfumed Cell, the bhikkhus said: ‘We do not get to see the Blessed One whenever we want to.

original: bhagavantaṃ daṭṭhuṃ labhāmā”ti maṃ therassa santikaṃ pāhesuṃ. Thero pana ekavacaneneva🔽dassesi. Thero, bhante, tumhākaṃ sāsane vallabho maññeti. Āma rājakumāra, vallabho
analyzed: bhagavantam daṭṭhum labhāma ati mam therassa santikam pāhesum thero pana eka vacanena iva  dassesi theraḥ bhante tumhākam sāsane vallabhaḥ maññeti rāja kumāra vallabho
translated: But the elder showed you to me with a mere word. Venerable sir, that bhikkhu is dear and beloved in the Blessed One’s eyes, is he not? ‘

original: esa bhikkhu mayhaṃ sāsaneti. Bhante, buddhānaṃ sāsane kiṃ katvā vallabho hotīti?🔽Dānaṃ datvā sīlaṃ samādiyitvā uposathakammaṃ katvā kumārāti. Bhagavā, ahaṃ thero🔽viya buddhasāsane vallabho hotukāmo, temāsaṃ me vassāvāsaṃ adhivāsethāti. Bhagavā🔽– “atthi nu kho tattha gatena attho”ti oloketvā atthīti disvā “suññāgāre, kho rājakumāra
analyzed: esa bhikkhu mayham sāsane ti bhante buddhānam sāsane kim katvā vallabhaḥ hoti iti  dānam da tvā sīlam samādiyitvā uposatha kammam katvā kumārāti bhagavā aham thero  buddha sāsane vallabhaḥ hotu kāmo temāsam me vassāvāsam adhivāsetha ati bhagavā  atthi nu kho tattha gatena attho ti oloketvā atthi iti disvā suññāgāre kho rāja kumāra
translated: ‘Yes, prince, that bhikkhu is dear and beloved in my eyes.’ ‘Venerable sir, what must one do to be dear and beloved in the Blessed One’s eyes in this Dhamma and Discipline? ‘

original: tathāgatā abhiramantī”ti āha. Kumāro “aññātaṃ bhagavā, aññātaṃ sugatā”ti vatvā “ahaṃ,
analyzed: tathāgatāḥ abhiramanti iti āha kumāraḥ aññātam bhagavā aññātam sugata ati vatvā aham
translated: ‘One must give gifts, observe the moral precepts, and enter upon the observance of the Uposatha day.’ ‘Venerable sir, I want to be dear and beloved in the Blessed One’s eyes in this Dhamma and Discipline, just like that bhikkhu. Let the Blessed One consent to stay for three months during the rains, with me as your attendant.’ The Blessed One considered: ‘Is there any purpose for me to stay there?’ Seeing that there was, he said: ‘Prince, Tathagatas delight in solitude.’ The prince said: ‘I understand, venerable sir, I accept the Dhamma taught by the Blessed One.’

original: bhante, purimataraṃ gantvā vihāraṃ kāremi, mayā pesite bhikkhusatasahassena saddhiṃ
analyzed: bhante purimataram gantvā vihāram kāremi mayā pesite bhikkhu sata sahassena saddhim
translated: “Venerable sir, I will go first and have a monastery built. Then you can come

original: āgacchathā”ti paṭiññaṃ gahetvā pitusantikaṃ gantvā “dinnā me, deva, bhagavatā paṭiññā,
analyzed: āgacchatha ati paṭiññam gahetvā pitu santikam gantvā dinnā me deva bhagavatā paṭiññā
translated: with a hundred thousand bhikkhus.” After he had obtained the Master’s promise, he went to his father and said, “Sire, the Blessed One has promised to come.

original: mayā pahite bhagavantaṃ peseyyāthā”ti pitaraṃ vanditvā nikkhamitvā yojane yojane
analyzed: mayā pahite bhagavantam peseyyātha ati pitaram vanditvā nikkhamitvā yojane yojane
translated: When I send word, you must send the Blessed One.” After paying homage to his father, he left.

original: vihāraṃ kāretvā vīsayojanasataṃ addhānaṃ gantvā attano nagare vihāraṭṭhānaṃ vicinanto
analyzed: vihāram kāretvā vīsa yojana satam addhānam gantvā attanaḥ nagare vihāra ṭhānam vicinantaḥ
translated: Having had a monastery built every yojana, he went a hundred and twenty yojanas and began to look for a site for a monastery in his own city.

original: sobhanaṃ nāma kuṭumbikassa uyyānaṃ disvā satasahassena kiṇitvā satasahassaṃ vissajjetvā
analyzed: sobhanam nāma kuṭumbikassa uyyānam disvā sata sahassena kiṇitvā sata sahassam vissajjetvā
translated: He saw a park belonging to a rich man named Sobhita and bought it for a hundred thousand pieces of money. He spent another hundred thousand pieces of money on having a monastery built there.

original: vihāraṃ kāresi. Tattha bhagavato gandhakuṭiṃ sesabhikkhūnañca rattiṭṭhānadivāṭṭhānatthāya🔽kuṭileṇamaṇḍape kārāpetvā pākāraparikkhepe katvā dvārakoṭṭhakañca niṭṭhapetvā pitusantikaṃ
analyzed: vihāram kāresi tattha bhagavataḥ gandhakuṭim sesa bhikkhūnam ca ratti ṭṭhāna divāṭṭhāna tthāya  kuṭileṇa maṇḍape kārāpetvā pākāra parikkhepe katvā dvāra koṭṭhakam ca niṭṭhapetvā pitu santikam
translated: He had a Perfumed Chamber built for the Blessed One and huts for the other bhikkhus, and he had them provided with night quarters and day quarters,

original: pesesi – “niṭṭhitaṃ mayhaṃ kiccaṃ, satthāraṃ pahiṇathā”ti.
analyzed: pesesi niṭṭhitam mayham kiccam satthāram pahiṇatha ati
translated: and he had a wall built round them and a gate house made. When he had finished, he sent word to his father, “My task is done. Send the Teacher.”

original: Rājā bhagavantaṃ bhojetvā – “bhagavā, sumanassa kiccaṃ niṭṭhitaṃ, tumhākaṃ gamanaṃ
analyzed: rājā bhagavantam bhojetvā bhagavā sumanassa kiccam niṭṭhitam tumhākam gamanam
translated: The king entertained the Exalted One and said, “The business of Sumana is finished. You may go.

original: paccāsīsatī”ti āha. Bhagavā satasahassabhikkhuparivāro yojane yojane vihāresu vasamāno
analyzed: paccāsīsati iti āha bhagavā sata sahassa bhikkhu parivāraḥ yojane yojane vihāresu vasamānaḥ
translated: ” The Exalted One, surrounded by a company of a hundred thousand monks, went on his way, stopping in monasteries one yojana apart.

original: agamāsi. Kumāro “satthā āgato”ti sutvā yojanaṃ paccuggantvā mālādīhi pūjayamāno vihāraṃ pavesetvā –
analyzed: agamāsi kumāraḥ satthā āgataḥ iti sutvā yojanam paccuggantvā mālā ādīhi pūjayamānaḥ vihāram pavesetvā
translated: When the prince heard that the Teacher had come, he went out a yojana to meet him, and after honoring him with garlands and so on, he led him into the monastery.

original: “Satasahassena me kītaṃ, satasahassena māpitaṃ;
analyzed: sata sahassena me kītam sata sahassena māpitam
translated: “I have built it with a hundred thousand, and with a hundred thousand it has been made ready.

original: Sobhanaṃ nāma uyyānaṃ, paṭiggaṇha mahāmunī”ti.🔽Vihāraṃ niyyātesi. So vassūpanāyikadivase dānaṃ datvā attano puttadāre ca amacce🔽ca pakkosāpetvā āha – “ayaṃ satthā amhākaṃ santikaṃ dūrato āgato, buddhā ca nāma🔽dhammagaruno na āmisagarukā. Tasmā ahaṃ temāsaṃ dve sāṭake nivāsetvā dasa sīlāni
analyzed: sobhanam nāma uyyānam paṭiggaṇha mahā muni iti  vihāram so vassūpanāyika divase dānam da tvā attano putta dāre ca amacce  ca pakkosāpetvā āha ayam satthā amhākam santikam dūratas āgataḥ buddhā ca nāma  dhamma garunaḥ naḥ āmisa garukā tasmai aham temāsam dve sāṭake nivāsetvā dasa sīlāni
translated: Accept, O Great Sage, this beautiful garden.”

original: samādiyitvā idheva vasissāmi, tumhe khīṇāsavasatasahassassa imināva nīhārena temāsaṃ
analyzed: samādiyitvā idhā iva vasissāmi tumhe khīṇāsava sata sahassassa iminā ava nīhārena
translated: He presented the monastery to the Teacher. On the day of the beginning of the rains, the prince gave alms, and after summoning his own wife and children and his ministers, he said to them, “This Teacher has come a long way to see us. But the Buddhas honor the Dhamma, not material things. Therefore I will spend the three months of the rains right here, wearing these two robes and observing the ten precepts. You may go to Sāvatthī and spend the three months of the rains there.🔽“

original: dānaṃ dadeyyāthā”ti.
analyzed: dānam dadeyyāḥ atha ati
translated: “Give gifts.”

original: So sumanattherassa vasanaṭṭhānasabhāgeyeva ṭhāne vasanto yaṃ thero bhagavato vattaṃ🔽karoti, taṃ sabbaṃ disvā “imasmiṃ ṭhāne ekantavallabho esa thero, etasseva me ṭhānantaraṃ
analyzed: so sumana therassa vasana ṭṭhāna sabhāgeya iva ṭhāne vasantaḥ yam thero bhagavataḥ vattaṃ  karoti tam sabbam disvā imasmin ṭhāne ekanta vallabhaḥ esa theraḥ etassa iva me
translated: He lived in a place not far from the place where the Elder Sumana lived. He saw all the duties that the Elder performed for the Buddha.

original: patthetuṃ vaṭṭatī”ti cintetvā upakaṭṭhāya pavāraṇāya gāmaṃ pavisitvā sattāhaṃ mahādānaṃ
analyzed: patthetum vaṭṭati iti cintetvā upakaṭṭhāya pavāraṇāya gāmam pavisitvā sattāham mahādānam
translated: Thinking, “In this place, this Elder is completely beloved. It is fitting for me to seek a place next to him,” he entered the village on the invitation day and gave a great gift for seven days.

original: datvā sattame divase bhikkhusatasahassassa pādamūle ticīvaraṃ ṭhapetvā bhagavantaṃ🔽vanditvā – “bhante, yadetaṃ mayā magge yojanantarikaṃ yojanantarikaṃ vihāraṃ kārāpanato
analyzed: da tvā sattame divase bhikkhu sata sahassassa pāda mūle ti cīvaram ṭhapetvā bhagavantam  vanditvā bhante yat etam mayā magge yojana nantarikam yojana nantarikam vihāram
translated: On the seventh day, he placed three robes at the feet of a hundred thousand monks.🔽After worshipping the Buddha, he said, “Venerable Sir, the merit that I have made by building monasteries every league along the road,

original: paṭṭhāya puññaṃ kataṃ, taṃ neva sakkasampattiṃ, na mārasampattiṃ, na brahmasampattiṃ
analyzed: paṭṭhāya puññam katam tam na iva sakka sampattim na māra sampattim na brahma sampattim
translated: I did not make it seeking the prosperity of Sakka, Māra, or Brahmā,

original: patthayantena, buddhassa pana upaṭṭhākabhāvaṃ patthayantena kataṃ. Tasmā ahampi,
analyzed: patthayantena buddhassa pana upaṭṭhāka bhāvam patthayantena katam tasmai aham pi
translated: but seeking to be an attendant to the Buddha. Therefore,

original: bhagavā, anāgate sumanatthero viya buddhassa upaṭṭhāko bhaveyya”nti pañcapatiṭṭhitena nipatitvā vandi.
analyzed: bhagavā anāgate sumana thero viya buddhassa upaṭṭhākaḥ bhaveyyanti pañca patiṭṭhitena nipatitvā vandi
translated: “May the Exalted One be the attendant of the Buddha in the future, as the Elder Suman was.”

original: Bhagavā – “mahantaṃ kulaputtassa cittaṃ, samijjhissati nu kho no”ti olokento – “anāgate
analyzed: bhagavā mahantam kula puttassa cittam samijjhissati nu kho no ti olokentaḥ anāgate
translated: The Exalted One, observing that the heart of the young man was great, thought to himself, “Will he be successful or not?”

original: ito satasahassime kappe gotamo nāma buddho uppajjissati, tasseva upaṭṭhāko bhavissatī”ti ñatvā –
analyzed: itas sata sahassime kappe gotamaḥ nāma buddhaḥ uppajjissati tassa eva upaṭṭhākaḥ bhavissati iti ñatvā
translated: And beholding that in the future, after a hundred thousand cycles of time, a Buddha would arise named Gotama, and that he would be his attendant, he said,

original: “Icchitaṃ patthitaṃ tuyhaṃ, sabbameva samijjhatu;
analyzed: icchitam patthitam tuyham sabbam eva samijjhatu
translated: “May all that you desire and wish be fulfilled.

original: Sabbe pūrentu saṅkappā, cando pannaraso yathā”ti.🔽Āha. Kumāro taṃ sutvā – “buddhā nāma advejjhakathā hontī”ti dutiyadivaseyeva tassa
analyzed: sabbe pūrentu saṅkappā cando pannarasaḥ yathā ati  āha kumāro tam sutvā buddhāḥ nāma advejjha kathāḥ honti iti dutiya divaseya iva tassa
translated: May all your purposes be accomplished, as the moon is on the fifteenth day of the month.”

original: bhagavato pattacīvaraṃ gahetvā piṭṭhito piṭṭhito gacchanto viya ahosi. So tasmiṃ
analyzed: bhagavato patta cīvaram gahetvā piṭṭhitaḥ piṭṭhitaḥ gacchantaḥ viya ahosi saḥ tasmin
translated: The young man, hearing this, thought to himself, “The Buddhas are not wont to speak falsely.” Therefore on the following day he took the bowl and robe of the Exalted One, and went about with him as though he were his attendant.

original: buddhuppāde vassasatasahassaṃ dānaṃ datvā sagge nibbattitvā kassapabuddhakālepi piṇḍāya
analyzed: buddhuppāde vassa sata sahassam dānam da tvā sagge nibbattitvā kassapa buddha kāle pi piṇḍāya
translated: In the dispensation of this Buddha he gave alms for a hundred thousand years, and was reborn in the World of the Gods. In the dispensation of the Buddha Kassapa he went about begging his food.

original: carato therassa pattaggahaṇatthaṃ uttarisāṭakaṃ datvā pūjamakāsi. Puna sagge nibbattitvā
analyzed: carataḥ therassa patta ggahaṇa attham uttari sāṭakam da tvā pūjam akāsi puna sagge nibbattitvā
translated: After she died, she was reborn in heaven.

original: tato cuto bārāṇasirājā hutvā aṭṭhannaṃ paccekabuddhānaṃ paṇṇasālāyo kāretvā maṇiādhārake
analyzed: tatas cutaḥ bārāṇasi rājā hutvā aṭṭhannam paccekabuddhānam kāretvā maṇi ādhārake
translated: After she died, she was reborn as the king of Bārāṇasī. She had eight huts built for eight Paccekabuddhas and served them

original: upaṭṭhapetvā catūhi paccayehi dasavassasahassāni upaṭṭhānaṃ akāsi. Etāni pākaṭaṭṭhānāni.
analyzed: upaṭṭhapetvā catūhi paccayehi dasa vassa sahassāni upaṭṭhānam akāsi etāni pākaṭa ṭṭhānāni
translated: with the four requisites for ten thousand years. These are the well-known events.

original: Kappasatasahassaṃ pana dānaṃ dadamānova amhākaṃ bodhisattena saddhiṃ tusitapure nibbattitvā
analyzed: kappa sata sahassam pana dānam dadamānaḥ iva amhākam bodhisattena saddhim tusitapure nibbattitvā
translated: For a hundred thousand aeons she gave gifts, and was reborn in the Tusita heaven together with our Bodhisatta.

original: tato cuto amitodanasakkassa gehe paṭisandhiṃ gahetvā anupubbena katābhinikkhamano
analyzed: tatas cutaḥ amitodana sakkassa gehe paṭisandhim gahetvā anupubbena kata abhinikkhamanaḥ
translated: After she died, she was conceived in the womb of Amitodana the Sakyan, and in due course went forth into homelessness.🔽After he had attained supreme enlightenment, he came to Kapilavatthu on his first journey.

original: sammāsambodhiṃ patvā paṭhamagamanena kapilavatthuṃ āgantvā tato nikkhamante bhagavati
analyzed: sammāsambodhim patvā paṭhama gamanena kapilavatthum āgantvā tatas nikkhamante bhagavati
translated: When he was about to leave Kapilavatthu,

original: bhagavato parivāratthaṃ rājakumāresu pabbajitesu bhaddiyādīhi saddhiṃ nikkhamitvā
analyzed: bhagavataḥ parivāra attham rāja kumāresu pabbajitesu bhaddiya ādīhi saddhim nikkhamitvā
translated: the princes went forth, and Bhaddiya and the others went forth with them.

original: bhagavato santike pabbajitvā nacirasseva āyasmato puṇṇassa mantāṇiputtassa santike
analyzed: bhagavato santike pabbajitvā nacirassa iva āyasmataḥ puṇṇassa mantāṇi puttassa santike
translated: They went forth into the presence of the Blessed One, and soon afterwards

original: dhammakathaṃ sutvā sotāpattiphale patiṭṭhahi. Evamesa āyasmā pubbūpanissayasampanno
analyzed: dhamma katham sutvā sotāpatti phale patiṭṭhahi evam esa āyasmā pubba upanissaya sampanno
translated: and he was established in the fruit of stream-entry. So this venerable one was endowed with the prerequisite of previous condition.

original: tassimāya pubbūpanissayasampattiyā gambhīropi paṭiccasamuppādo uttānako viya upaṭṭhāsi.
analyzed: tassa imāya pubba upanissaya sampattiyā gambhīraḥ api paṭiccasamuppādaḥ uttānakaḥ viya upaṭṭhāsi
translated: And because of this endowment with the prerequisite of previous condition, dependent origination, though profound, appeared to him as if it were standing upright in front of him.

original: Titthavāsādivaṇṇanā
analyzed: tittha vāsa ādi vaṇṇanā
translated: The Description of the Tīrthikas’ Dwelling Place

original: Titthavāsoti punappunaṃ garūnaṃ santike uggahaṇasavanaparipucchanadhāraṇāni vuccanti.
analyzed: titthavāso ti punappunam garūnam santike uggahaṇa savana paripucchana dhāraṇāni vuccanti
translated: The tīrthikas’ dwelling place is said to be the repeated learning, hearing, questioning, and remembering in the presence of teachers.

original: So therassa ativiya parisuddho, tenāpissāyaṃ gambhīropi paṭiccasamuppādo uttānako viya upaṭṭhāsi.
analyzed: so therassa ati viya parisuddho tena api ssa ayam gambhīraḥ api paṭiccasamuppādaḥ uttānakaḥ viya upaṭṭhāsi
translated: It was extremely pure in the Elder, and so dependent origination, though profound, appeared to him as if it were standing upright in front of him.🔽And the principle of conditionality appears to stand upright in front of stream-enterers,

original: Sotāpannānañca nāma paccayākāro uttānakova hutvā upaṭṭhāti, ayañca āyasmā sotāpanno.
analyzed: sotāpannānam ca nāma paccaya ākāraḥ uttānakaḥ va hutvā upaṭṭhāti ayañca āyasmā sotāpanno
translated: and this venerable one was a stream-enterer.

original: Bahussutānañca catuhatthe ovarake padīpe jalamāne mañcapīṭhaṃ viya nāmarūpaparicchedo🔽pākaṭo hoti, ayañca āyasmā bahussutānaṃ aggo hoti, bāhusaccānubhāvenapissa gambhīropi
analyzed: catu hatthe ovarake padīpe jala māne mañca pīṭham viya nāma rūpa paricchedaḥ  pākaṭaḥ hoti ayam ca āyasmai bahu sutānam aggaḥ hoti bāhu sacca anubhāvena pi ssa gambhīraḥ api
translated: And the delimitation of mentality-materiality is evident to the learned as a bed and chair are to one standing close to them when a four-cubit oil-lamp is burning,

original: paccayākāro uttānako viya upaṭṭhāsi.
analyzed: paccaya ākāraḥ uttānakaḥ viya upaṭṭhāsi
translated: and this venerable one was the most learned of all, and so dependent origination, though profound, appeared to him as if it were standing upright in front of him by the power of his learning.

original: Paṭiccasamuppādagambhīratā
analyzed: paṭiccasamuppāda gambhīra tā
translated: The Profundity of Dependent Origination

original: Tattha atthagambhīratāya, dhammagambhīratāya, desanāgambhīratāya, paṭivedhagambhīratāyāti catūhi ākārehi paṭiccasamuppādo gambhīro nāma.
analyzed: tattha attha gambhīra tāya dhamma gambhīra tāya desanā gambhīra tāya paṭivedha gambhīra tāya ati catūhi ākārehi paṭiccasamuppādaḥ gambhīraḥ nāma
translated: Herein, dependent origination is called profound in four ways: in meaning, in dhammas, in teaching, and in penetration.

original: Tattha jarāmaraṇassa jātipaccayasambhūtasamudāgataṭṭho gambhīro…pe… saṅkhārānaṃ avijjāpaccayasambhūtasamudāgataṭṭho gambhīroti ayaṃ atthagambhīratā.
analyzed: tattha jarā maraṇassa jāti paccaya sambhūta samudāgata ṭṭhaḥ saṅkhārānam avijjā paccaya sambhūta samudāgata ṭṭhaḥ gambhīraḥ ti ayaṃ attha gambhīra tā
translated: Herein, the meaning of the origination and occurrence of aging-and-death that has the condition of birth is profound … down to … the meaning of the origination and occurrence of volitional formations that have the condition of ignorance is profound. This is profundity of meaning.

original: Avijjāya saṅkhārānaṃ paccayaṭṭho gambhīro…pe… jātiyā jarāmaraṇassa paccayaṭṭho gambhīroti ayaṃ dhammagambhīratā.
analyzed: avijjāya saṅkhārānam paccaya ṭṭhaḥ jātiyā jarā maraṇassa paccaya ṭṭhaḥ gambhīraḥ ti ayam dhamma gambhīra tā
translated: The meaning of ignorance as condition for formations is profound … down to … the meaning of birth as condition for aging-and-death is profound. This is profundity of dhammas.

original: Katthaci sutte paṭiccasamuppādo anulomato desiyati, katthaci paṭilomato, katthaci🔽anulomapaṭilomato, katthaci majjhato paṭṭhāya anulomato vā paṭilomato vā anulomapaṭilomato🔽vā, katthaci tisandhi catusaṅkhepo, katthaci dvisandhi tisaṅkhepo, katthaci ekasandhi
analyzed: katthaci sutte paṭiccasamuppādaḥ anulomataḥ desiyati katthaci paṭilomataḥ katthaci  anuloma paṭilomataḥ katthaci majjhataḥ paṭṭhāya anulomataḥ vā paṭilomataḥ vā anuloma paṭilomataḥ  vā katthaci ti sandhi catu saṅkhepaḥ katthaci dvi sandhi ti saṅkhepaḥ katthaci eka sandhi
translated: In some suttas dependent origination is taught forwards, in some backwards,

original: dvisaṅkhepoti ayaṃ desanāgambhīratā.
analyzed: ayam desanā gambhīra tā
translated: in some forwards and backwards, in some from the middle to the end and from the end to the middle, in some in three sections, in some in two sections, in some in one section. This is profundity of teaching.

original: Avijjāya pana aññāṇaadassanasaccāpaṭivedhaṭṭho gambhīro, saṅkhārānaṃ abhisaṅkharaṇāyūhanasarāgavirāgaṭṭho,
analyzed: avijjāya pana aññāṇa a dassana sacca a paṭivedha ṭṭho gambhīraḥ saṅkhārānaṃ abhisaṅkharaṇa a yūhana sa rāga virāga ṭṭho
translated: But ignorance is deep in the sense of non-knowing, non-seeing, non-penetrating, non-understanding, of the four truths;🔽formations are deep in the sense of forming, accumulating, lusting, and lust-free;

original: viññāṇassa suññataabyāpāraasaṅkantipaṭisandhipātubhāvaṭṭho, nāmarūpassa ekuppādavinibbhogāvinibbhoganamanaruppanaṭṭho,
analyzed: viññāṇassa suññata a byāpāra asaṅkanti paṭisandhi pātubhāva ṭho nāma rūpassa eka uppāda vinibbhoga avinibbhoga namana ruppana ṭho
translated: consciousness is deep in the sense of voidness, inactivity, non-transmigration, rebirth-linking, and manifestation; mentality-materiality is deep in the sense of non-division, non-separation, bending, and moulding;

original: saḷāyatanassa adhipatilokadvārakkhettavisayibhāvaṭṭho, phassassa phusanasaṅghaṭṭanasaṅgatisannipātaṭṭho,
analyzed: saḷāyatanassa adhipati loka dvāra kkhetta visayi bhāva ṭho phassassa phusana saṅghaṭṭana saṅgati sannipāta ṭho
translated: the sixfold base is deep in the sense of predominance, world, door, field, and province; contact is deep in the sense of touching, impingement, meeting, and concurrence;

original: vedanāya ārammaṇarasānubhavanasukhadukkhamajjhattabhāvanijjīvavedayitaṭṭho, taṇhāya
analyzed: vedanāya taṇhāya
translated: feeling is deep in the sense of experiencing the taste of an object, and of pleasant, painful, and neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling, of life, and of being felt; craving is deep

original: abhinanditaajjhosānasaritālatātaṇhānadītaṇhāsamuddaduppūraṇaṭṭho, upādānassa ādānaggahaṇābhinivesaparāmāsaduratikkamaṭṭho,
analyzed: abhinandita ajjhosāna saritā latā taṇhā nadī taṇhā samudda duppūraṇa ṭhaḥ upādānassa ādāna ggahaṇa abhinivesa parāmāsa duratikkama ṭhaḥ
translated: in the sense of delighting in, cleaving to, flowing, streaming, craving, river, craving-flood, and filling up the ocean of suffering; clinging is deep in the sense of grasping, holding, misapprehending, and not surmounting;

original: bhavassa āyūhanābhisaṅkharaṇayonigatiṭhitinivāsesu khipanaṭṭho, jātiyā jātisañjātiokkantinibbattipātubhāvaṭṭho,
analyzed: bhavassa āyūhana abhisaṅkharaṇa yoni gati ṭhiti nivāsesu khipana ṭhaḥ jātiyā jāti sañjāti okkanti nibbatti pātubhāva ṭhaḥ
translated: existence is deep in the sense of accumulating, forming, and hurling into a womb, destiny, station of consciousness, and abode of beings; birth is deep in the sense of birth, generation, reincarnation, appearance, and manifestation;

original: jarāmaraṇassa khayavayabhedavipariṇāmaṭṭho gambhīroti. Evaṃ yo avijjādīnaṃ sabhāvo,🔽yena paṭivedhena avijjādayo sarasalakkhaṇato paṭividdhā honti; so gambhīroti ayaṃ
analyzed: jarā maraṇassa khaya vaya bheda vipariṇāma ṭṭhaḥ gambhīraḥ ti evam yaḥ avijjā ādīnam sabhāvaḥ  yena paṭivedhena avijjā ādayo sa rasa lakkhaṇato paṭividdhāḥ honti so gambhīraḥ ti ayaṃ
translated: and the meaning of the ending, the passing away, the fading away, the cessation, the giving up, the relinquishing of aging-and-death is deep. So too, the individual essences of ignorance, etc.,🔽and the penetration of which ignorance, etc., are penetrated by the penetration of their individual essences,

original: paṭivedhagambhīratāti veditabbā. Sā sabbāpi therassa uttānakā viya upaṭṭhāsi. Tena
analyzed: paṭivedha gambhīra tā ti veditabbā sā sabbā api therassa uttānakā viya upaṭṭhāsi tena
translated: is deep. All this appeared clear to the Elder as if turned upside down. Therefore,

original: bhagavā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ ussādento – “mā heva”ntiādimāha. Ayañcettha adhippāyo🔽– ānanda, tvaṃ mahāpañño visadañāṇo, tena te gambhīropi paṭiccasamuppādo uttānako
analyzed: bhagavā āyasmantam ānandam ussādentaḥ mā heva iti ādim āha ayaṃ ca ittha adhippāyaḥ  ānanda tvam mahā paññaḥ visada ñāṇo tena te gambhīraḥ api paṭiccasamuppādaḥ uttānakaḥ
translated: in order to encourage the venerable Ananda, the Exalted One said, “Do not say so, Ananda.” The purport is this:

original: viya khāyati, tasmā – “mayhameva nu kho esa uttānako hutvā upaṭṭhāti, udāhu aññesampī”ti mā evaṃ avacāti.
analyzed: viya khāyati tasmai mayham eva nu kho esaḥ uttānakaḥ hutvā upaṭṭhāti udāhu aññesam pi iti mā evam avacāti
translated: “Ananda, you are of great understanding and clear knowledge. Therefore dependent origination, though deep, appears clear to you. So do not say, ‘It appears clear to me alone, not to others.’“

original: Apasādanāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: apasādanā vaṇṇanā
translated: Criticism

original: Yaṃ pana vuttaṃ – “apasādento”ti, tattha ayaṃ adhippāyo – ānanda, “atha ca pana me
analyzed: yam pana vuttam apasādento ti tattha ayam adhippāyaḥ ānanda atha ca pana me
translated: But as to what was said above about “criticism,” the purport is this: “Ananda, you are of great understanding and clear knowledge. Therefore dependent origination, though deep, appears clear to you. So do not say, ‘It appears clear to me alone, not to others.’“

original: uttānakuttānako viya khāyatī”ti mā hevaṃ avaca. Yadi hi te esa uttānakuttānako viya
analyzed: uttānakuttānakaḥ viya khāyati iti mā ha ivam avaca yadi hi te esaḥ uttānakuttānakaḥ viya
translated: “You are like a man who is looking at the sky and the earth.”

original: khāyati, kasmā tvaṃ attano dhammatāya sotāpanno nāhosi, mayā dinnanayeva ṭhatvā sotāpattimaggaṃ
analyzed: khāyati kasmā tvam attanaḥ dhammatāya sotāpannaḥ na ahosi mayā dinna nayā iva ṭhatvā sotāpatti maggaṃ
translated: If you are like a man who is looking at the sky and the earth, why did you not become a stream-enterer by your own efforts, but only after following my instructions did you penetrate the path to

original: paṭivijjhasi. Ānanda, idaṃ nibbānameva gambhīraṃ, paccayākāro pana tava uttānako🔽jāto, atha kasmā oḷārikaṃ kāmarāgasaṃyojanaṃ paṭighasaṃyojanaṃ, oḷārikaṃ kāmarāgānusayaṃ
analyzed: paṭivijjhasi ānanda idam nibbānam eva gambhīram paccaya ākāraḥ pana tava uttānakaḥ  jātaḥ atha kasmai oḷārikam kāma rāga saṃyojanam paṭigha saṃyojanam oḷārikam kāma rāga anusayam
translated: stream-entry? Ānanda, this Nibbāna is indeed deep, but the principle of conditionality is clear to you.

original: paṭighānusayanti ime cattāro kilese samugghāṭetvā sakadāgāmiphalaṃ na sacchikarosi?🔽Teyeva aṇusahagate cattāro kilese samugghāṭetvā anāgāmiphalaṃ na sacchikarosi? Rūparāgādīni
analyzed: ime cattāro kilese samugghāṭetvā sakadāgāmi phalam na sacchikarosi  teyeva aṇu sahagate cattāraḥ kilese samugghāṭetvā anāgāmi phalam na sacchikarosi rūpa rāga ādīni
translated: Why, then, did you not eradicate the four defilements that are to be eradicated by the path of once-returning and realize the fruit of once-returning?

original: pañca saṃyojanāni, bhavarāgānusayaṃ, mānānusayaṃ, avijjānusayanti ime aṭṭha kilese
analyzed: pañca saṃyojanāni bhava rāga anusayam māna anusayam avijjā anusayanti ime aṭṭha kilese
translated: Why did you not eradicate the four defilements that are to be eradicated by the path of non-returning and realize the fruit of non-returning? Why did you not eradicate the five lower fetters

original: samugghāṭetvā arahattaṃ na sacchikarosi?
analyzed: samugghāṭetvā arahattam na sacchikarosi
translated: and realize the fruit of arahantship?

original: Kasmā ca satasahassakappādhikaṃ ekaṃ asaṅkhyeyyaṃ pūritapāramino sāriputtamoggallānā🔽viya sāvakapāramiñāṇaṃ nappaṭivijjhasi? Satasahassakappādhikāni dve asaṅkhyeyyāni
analyzed: kasmā ca sata sahassa kappa adhikam ekam asaṅkhyeyyam pūrita pāramino sāriputta moggallānā  viya sāvaka pāramiñāṇam na paṭivijjhasi sata sahassa kappa adhikāni dve asaṅkhyeyyāni
translated: And why do you not penetrate the knowledge of the disciple-perfections, like Sāriputta and Moggallāna, who fulfilled the perfections for more than a hundred thousand eons?

original: pūritapāramino paccekabuddhā viya ca paccekabodhiñāṇaṃ nappaṭivijjhasi? Yadi vā te🔽sabbathāva esa uttānako hutvā upaṭṭhāti, atha kasmā satasahassakappādhikāni cattāri
analyzed: pūrita pāraminaḥ paccekabuddhāḥ ca pacceka bodhi ñāṇam na paṭivijjhasi yadi vā te  sabbathā va esa uttānakaḥ hutvā upaṭṭhāti atha kasmā sata sahassa kappa adhikāni cattāri
translated: And why do you not penetrate the knowledge of the paccekabuddha-enlightenment, like the paccekabuddhas who fulfilled the perfections for two incalculable eons and a hundred thousand eons?

original: aṭṭha soḷasa vā asaṅkhyeyyāni pūritapāramino buddhā viya sabbaññutaññāṇaṃ na sacchikarosi?
analyzed: aṭṭha soḷasa vā asaṅkhyeyyāni pūrita pāraminaḥ buddhāḥ viya sabbaññuta ññāṇam na sacchikarosi
translated: If this is so clear to you in every way, then why do you not realize omniscience, like the Buddhas who fulfilled the perfections for four, eight, or sixteen incalculable eons?

original: Kiṃ anatthikosi etehi visesādhigamehi, passa yāvañca te aparaddhaṃ, tvaṃ nāma sāvako
analyzed: kim anatthikaḥ asi etehi visesa adhigamehi passa yāvat ca te aparaddham tvam nāma sāvako
translated: Are you not interested in attaining these special knowledges? See how far you have strayed! You, a disciple,

original: padesañāṇe ṭhito atigambhīraṃ paccayākāraṃ – “uttānako me upaṭṭhātī”ti vadasi, tassa
analyzed: padesa ñāṇe ṭhitaḥ ati gambhīram paccaya ākāram uttānakaḥ me upaṭṭhāti iti vadasi tassa
translated: standing in the knowledge of a fraction, say that the very profound principle of conditionality is clear to you.

original: te idaṃ vacanaṃ buddhānaṃ kathāya paccanīkaṃ hoti, na tādisena nāma bhikkhunā buddhānaṃ
analyzed: te idam vacanam buddhānam kathāya paccanīkam hoti na tādisena nāma bhikkhunā buddhānam
translated: This statement of yours is contrary to the teaching of the Buddhas. It is not proper for a bhikkhu like you

original: kathāya paccanīkaṃ kathetabbanti yuttametaṃ.🔽Nanu mayhaṃ, ānanda, idaṃ paccayākāraṃ paṭivijjhituṃ vāyamantasseva satasahassakappādhikāni
analyzed: kathāya paccanīkam kathetabban ti yuttam etam  nanu mayham ānanda idam paccaya ākāram paṭivijjhitum vā āyam antassa iva sata sahassa kappa adhikāni
translated: It is proper to say that the opposite of talk is silence.🔽“Ānanda, didn’t I tell you that the time would come when you would be affected by aging?

original: cattāri asaṅkhyeyyāni atikkantāni? Paccayākāraṃ paṭivijjhanatthāya ca pana me adinnaṃ
analyzed: cattāri asaṅkhyeyyāni atikkantāni paccaya ākāram paṭivijjhana atthāya ca pana me adinnam
translated: For I have been striving to penetrate the principle of conditionality for more than forty eons.

original: dānaṃ nāma natthi, apūritapāramī nāma natthi. Paccayākāraṃ paṭivijjhassāmīti pana
analyzed: dānam nāma natthi a pūrita pāramī nāma natthi paccaya ākāram paṭivijjhassāmi iti pana
translated: There is no gift that I have not given, no virtue that I have not observed, no patience that I have not practiced, no energy that I have not exerted, no concentration that I have not developed, no wisdom that I have not cultivated.

original: me nirussāhaṃ viya mārabalaṃ vidhamantassa ayaṃ mahāpathavī dvaṅgulamattampi na kampi
analyzed: me nirussāham viya māra balam vidhamantassa ayam mahā pathavī na kampi
translated: But when I was striving to penetrate the principle of conditionality, I was unable to do so.🔽Then, when I was striving to penetrate the principle of conditionality, I was unable to do so.🔽Then, when I was striving to penetrate the principle of conditionality, I was unable to do so.

original: tathā paṭhamayāme pubbenivāsaṃ, majjhimayāme dibbacakkhuṃ sampādentassa. Pacchimayāme
analyzed: tathā paṭhama yāme pubbenivāsam majjhima yāme dibba cakkhum sampādentassa pacchima yāme
translated: Then, when I was striving to penetrate the principle of conditionality, I was unable to do so.🔽Then, when I was striving to penetrate the principle of conditionality, I was unable to do so.🔽Then, when I was striving to penetrate the principle of conditionality, I was unable to do so.🔽Then, when I was striving to penetrate the principle of conditionality, I was unable to do so.🔽Then, when I was striving to penetrate the principle of conditionality, I was unable to do so.🔽Then, when I was striving to penetrate the principle of conditionality, I was unable to do so.🔽Then, when I was striving to penetrate the principle of conditionality, I was unable to do so.🔽Then, when I was striving to penetrate the principle of conditionality, I was unable to do so.🔽Then, when I was striving to penetrate the principle of conditionality, I was unable to do so.🔽Then, when I was striving to penetrate the principle of conditionality, I was unable to do so.🔽Then, when I was striving to penetrate the principle of conditionality, I was unable to do so.🔽Then, when I was striving to penetrate the principle of conditionality, I was unable to do so.🔽Then, when I was striving to penetrate the principle of conditionality, I was unable to do so.🔽Then, when I was striving to penetrate the principle of conditionality, I was unable to do so.

original: pana me balavapaccūsasamaye – “avijjā saṅkhārānaṃ navahi ākārehi paccayo hotī”ti🔽diṭṭhamatteva dasasahassilokadhātu ayadaṇḍakena ākoṭitakaṃsatālaṃ viya viravasataṃ
analyzed: pana me balava paccūsa samaye avijjā saṅkhārānam navahi ākārehi paccayaḥ hoti iti 🔽diṭṭha mattā iva dasa sahassi lokadhātu aya daṇḍakena ākoṭita kaṃsa tālam viya virava satam
translated: Then, when I was striving to penetrate the principle of conditionality, I was unable to do so.🔽Then, when I was striving to

original: viravasahassaṃ muñcamānā vātāhate paduminipaṇṇe udakabindu viya kampittha. Evaṃ gambhīro🔽cāyaṃ, ānanda, paṭiccasamuppādo, gambhīrāvabhāso ca. Etassa ānanda, dhammassa ananubodhā…pe… nātivattatīti.
analyzed: virava sahassam muñcamānā vāta āhate padumini paṇṇe udaka bindu viya kampittha evam gambhīraḥ  ca ayam ānanda paṭiccasamuppādaḥ gambhīra avabhāso ca etassa ānanda dhammassa na ativattati iti
translated: and the thousand bhikkhus trembled like a palm leaf shaken by the wind.🔽“So it is, Ananda, so it is. This dependent origination is deep and it appears deep to you, Ananda, because it is deep and profound, hard to see and hard to understand, because it is subtle, and because it is abstruse.🔽“This Dhamma is deep, Ananda, and hard to see, hard to understand, peaceful, excellent, beyond the sphere of logic, profound, understandable (only) by the wise.🔽This Dhamma is deep, Ananda, and hard to see, hard to understand, peaceful, excellent, beyond the sphere of logic, profound, understandable (only) by the wise.

translated: non-human beings. Bhutas are any beings that have been reborn. Birds are any beings that have wings of bone, wings of skin, or wings of hair. Reptiles are any beings that creep on the ground. Of these, of these

analyzed: tesam deva gandhabba ādīnam tad atthāya ati deva gandhabba ādi bhāvāya jāti nirodhā ati jāti vigamāḥ jāti abhāvā ati atthaḥ
translated: For the sake of that: for the sake of the state of a divine gandhabba, etc. Cessation of birth: disappearance of birth; the meaning is, non-existence of birth.

original: Hetūtiādīni sabbānipi kāraṇavevacanāni eva. Kāraṇañhi yasmā attano phalatthāya hinoti🔽pavattati, tasmā “hetū”ti vuccati. Yasmā taṃ phalaṃ nideti – “handa, naṃ gaṇhathā”ti🔽appeti viya tasmā nidānaṃ. Yasmā phalaṃ tato samudeti uppajjati, tañca paṭicca eti🔽pavattati, tasmā samudayoti ca paccayoti ca vuccati. Esa nayo sabbattha. Api ca yadidaṃ
analyzed: hetu uti ādīni sabbāni api kāraṇa vevacanāni eva kāraṇam hi yasmai attano phala tthāya hinoti  pavattati tasmai hetu uti vuccati yasmai tam phalam nideti handa nam gaṇhatha ati  appeti viya tasmā nidānam yasmā phalam tatas samudeti uppajjati tat ca paṭicca eti  pavattati tasmā samudayaḥ iti ca paccayaḥ iti ca vuccati esa nayo sabbattha api ca yat idam
translated: Causes, etc., are all synonyms for reason. For a cause is so called because it causes its fruit to come forth,🔽to appear, as it were, by its presence. It is a condition because it makes the fruit come to rest, as it were, by the words “Come, take this.”

original: jātīti ettha yadidanti nipāto. Tassa sabbapadesu liṅgānurūpato attho veditabbo. Idha
analyzed: jātī iti ettha yat idam ti nipātaḥ tassa sabba padesu liṅga anurūpataḥ atthaḥ veditabbaḥ idha
translated: It is an origin because the fruit originates from it, arises from it, and it is a source because the fruit occurs in dependence on it. The same method applies in all cases. Moreover, as to the words “this birth,” the word “this” is a demonstrative pronoun. Its meaning should be understood in accordance with the gender of the noun it refers to. But here

original: pana – “yā esā jātī”ti ayamassa attho. Jarāmaraṇassa hi jāti upanissayakoṭiyā paccayo hoti.
analyzed: pana yā esā jātī iti ayam assa atthaḥ jarā maraṇassa hi jāti upanissaya koṭiyā paccayaḥ hoti
translated: the meaning is “this birth.” For birth is a condition for aging-and-death by acting as its support.

original: 99. Bhavapade – “kimhicī”ti iminā okāsapariggaho kato. Tattha heṭṭhā avīcipariyantaṃ
analyzed: bhava pade kimhici iti iminā okāsa pariggaho kato tattha heṭṭhā avīci pariyantam
translated: In the section on the plane of existence, the delimitation by means of the words “whatever is material” is made. Herein, below, down to Avīci Hell,

original: katvā upari paranimmitavasavattideve antokaritvā kāmabhavo veditabbo. Ayaṃ nayo upapattibhave.
analyzed: katvā upari paranimmitavasavattideve antokaritvā kāma bhavaḥ veditabbaḥ ayam nayaḥ upapatti bhave
translated: “Any” in the clause “through any attachment” indicates the sphere. Herein, sense-desire becoming should be understood as the sense-desire realm, which is bounded below by the Avīci hell and above by the gods of the “Delight in Creating” . This method applies to the case of rebirth-becoming.🔽But here it applies to the case of kamma-becoming, which is a condition for rebirth-becoming by means of decisive support.

original: Idha pana kammabhave yujjati. So hi jātiyā upanissayakoṭiyāva paccayo hoti. Upādānapadādīsupi
analyzed: idha pana kamma bhave yujjati so hi jātiyā upanissaya koṭiyā āva paccayaḥ hoti upādāna pada ādīsu pi
translated: And in the case of the terms “clinging” , etc.,

original: – “kimhicī”ti iminā okāsapariggahova katoti veditabbo.
analyzed: kimhici iti iminā okāsa pariggahaḥ uva kataḥ ti veditabbo
translated: “any” should be understood to indicate the sphere.

original: 100. Upādānapaccayā bhavoti ettha kāmupādānaṃ tiṇṇampi kammabhavānaṃ tiṇṇañca upapattibhavānaṃ
analyzed: upādāna paccayā bhavo ti ettha kāma upādānam tiṇṇam pi kamma bhavānam tiṇṇam ca upapatti bhavānam
translated: “With clinging as condition, becoming”: Herein, sense-desire clinging is a condition for the three kinds of kamma-becoming and for the three kinds of rebirth-becoming,

original: paccayo, tathā sesānipīti upādānapaccayā catuvīsatibhavā veditabbā. Nippariyāyenettha
analyzed: paccayaḥ tathā sesāni pi iti upādāna paccayāḥ catuvīsati bhavāḥ veditabbāḥ nippariyāyena ittha
translated: and so too are the others. So twenty-four kinds of becoming should be understood with clinging as condition.

original: dvādasa kammabhavā labbhanti. Tesaṃ upādānāni sahajātakoṭiyāpi upanissayakoṭiyāpi paccayo.
analyzed: dvādasa kamma bhavāḥ labbhanti tesam upādānāni sahajāta koṭiyā api upanissaya koṭiyā api paccayaḥ
translated: Herein, twelve kinds of kamma-becoming are obtained in the strict sense. Their clingings are conditions for them by means of the conascence condition and by means of the decisive-support condition.

original: 101. Rūpataṇhāti rūpārammaṇe taṇhā. Esa nayo saddataṇhādīsu. Sā panesā taṇhā upādānassa sahajātakoṭiyāpi upanissayakoṭiyāpi paccayo hoti.
analyzed: rūpa taṇhā ati rūpa ārammaṇe taṇhā esa nayaḥ sadda taṇhā ādīsu sā pana isā taṇhā upādānassa sahajāta koṭiyā api upanissaya koṭiyā api paccayaḥ hoti
translated: Craving for visible forms : craving for visible-form objects. So too with the rest. This craving is a condition for the kinds of clinging in two ways, as conascence and as decisive-support.

original: 102. Esa paccayo taṇhāya, yadidaṃ vedanāti ettha vipākavedanā taṇhāya upanissayakoṭiyā paccayo hoti, aññā aññathāpīti.🔽103. Ettāvatā pana bhagavā vaṭṭamūlabhūtaṃ purimataṇhaṃ dassetvā idāni desanaṃ, piṭṭhiyaṃ
analyzed: esa paccayaḥ taṇhāya yat idam vedanā ti ettha vipāka vedanā taṇhāya upanissaya koṭiyā paccayaḥ hoti aññā aññathā api iti  ettāvatā pana bhagavā vaṭṭa mūla bhūtam purima taṇham dassetvā idāni desanam piṭṭhiyam
translated: “Craving is dependent on feeling” : resultant feeling is a condition for craving in the way stated, but other kinds of feeling are conditions for craving in other ways as well.

original: paharitvā kesesu vā gahetvā viravantaṃ viravantaṃ maggato okkamento viya navahi padehi
analyzed: paharitvā kesesu vā gahetvā viravantam viravantam maggataḥ okkamentaḥ viya navahi padehi
translated: So far the Exalted One has shown the craving that is the root of the round. Now he will show the craving that is the round itself. He does this by means of nine terms, as if to say: “Just as a man who is running away from another man and who falls into a pit, falls further and further, so too, Ānanda, the fool, running away from craving, falls further and further into craving.”

original: samudācārataṇhaṃ dassento – “iti kho panetaṃ, ānanda, vedanaṃ paṭicca taṇhā”tiādimāha.🔽Tattha taṇhāti dve taṇhā esanataṇhā ca, esitataṇhā ca. Yāya taṇhāya ajapathasaṅkupathādīni
analyzed: samudācāra taṇham dassento iti kho pana itam ānanda vedanam paṭicca taṇhā ati ādim āha  tattha taṇhā ti dve taṇhāḥ esana taṇhā ca esita taṇhā ca yāya taṇhāya aja patha saṅku patha ādīni
translated: “Thus, Ānanda, with feeling as condition there is craving” .

original: paṭipajjitvā bhoge esati gavesati, ayaṃ esanataṇhā nāma. Yā tesu esitesu gavesitesu
analyzed: paṭipajjitvā bhoge esati gavesati ayam esana taṇhā nāma yā tesu esitesu gavesitesu
translated: Herein, there are two kinds of craving: craving for search and craving for enjoyment. The craving by which one searches for and seeks out wealth by wrong means such as trickery, deceit, etc., is called craving for search. The craving by which one enjoys wealth that has been searched out and found is called craving for enjoyment.

original: paṭiladdhesu taṇhā, ayaṃ esitataṇhā nāma. Tadubhayampi samudācārataṇhāya eva adhivacanaṃ.
analyzed: paṭiladdhesu taṇhā ayam esitataṇhā nāma tat ubhayam pi samudācāra taṇhāyaḥ eva adhivacanam
translated: Craving for what is obtained is called craving for search. Both these are terms for craving in occurrence.

original: Tasmā duvidhāpesā vedanaṃ paṭicca taṇhā nāma. Pariyesanā nāma rūpādiārammaṇapariyesanā,
analyzed: tasmā duvidhā apesā vedanam paṭicca taṇhā nāma pariyesanā nāma rūpa ādi ārammaṇa pariyesanā
translated: So craving is called craving for feeling because it is of two kinds in dependence on feeling. Searching is the searching for the object consisting in visible forms, etc.,

original: sā hi taṇhāya sati hoti. Lābhoti rūpādiārammaṇapaṭilābho, so hi pariyesanāya sati🔽hoti. Vinicchayo pana ñāṇataṇhādiṭṭhivitakkavasena catubbidho. Tattha – “sukhavinicchayaṃ
analyzed: sā hi taṇhāya sati hoti rūpa ādi ārammaṇa paṭilābho saḥ hi pariyesanāya sati  hoti vinicchayaḥ pana ñāṇa taṇhā diṭṭhi vitakka vasena catubbidhaḥ tattha sukha vinicchayam
translated: for that is when there is craving. Gain is the obtaining of the object consisting in visible forms, etc., for that is when there is searching.🔽As regards defining, it is of four kinds as knowledge, craving, view, and thinking. Herein, “One should know the defining of pleasure. Having known the defining of pleasure, one should practice in conformity with pleasure internally” .

original: jaññā, sukhavinicchayaṃ ñatvā ajjhattaṃ sukhamanuyuñjeyyā”ti ayaṃ ñāṇavinicchayo.
analyzed: jaññā sukha vinicchayam ñatvā ajjhattam sukham anuyuñjeyya iti ayam ñāṇa vinicchayaḥ
translated: This is the defining of knowledge.

original: “Vinicchayoti dve vinicchayā – taṇhāvinicchayo ca diṭṭhivinicchayo cā”ti. Evaṃ āgatāni🔽aṭṭhasatataṇhāvicaritāni taṇhāvinicchayo. Dvāsaṭṭhi diṭṭhiyo diṭṭhivinicchayo. “Chando
analyzed: vinicchayā iti dve vinicchayā taṇhā vinicchayo ca diṭṭhi vinicchayo ca ati evam āgatāni  aṭṭha sata taṇhā vicaritāni taṇhā vinicchayaḥ dvāsaṭṭhi diṭṭhiyaḥ diṭṭhi vinicchayo chando
translated: “Defining: there are these two definings, defining through craving and defining through view” .

original: kho, devānaminda, vitakkanidāno”ti imasmiṃ pana sutte idha vinicchayoti vutto vitakkoyeva
analyzed: kho devānaminda vitakka nidānaḥ ti imasmim pana sutte idha vinicchayaḥ ti vuttaḥ
translated: The eighty-one kinds of craving given in the passage beginning, “There are these eighty-one kinds of defining through craving” are defining through craving. The sixty-two views are defining through view. And in the passage beginning, “Longing, Ruler of Gods, has thinking as its source” , thinking is what is called defining here.

original: āgato. Lābhaṃ labhitvā hi iṭṭhāniṭṭhaṃ sundarāsundarañca vitakkeneva vinicchināti
analyzed: āgataḥ lābham labhitvā hi iṭṭha aniṭṭham sundara asundaram ca vitakkena iva vinicchināti
translated: Having got gain, he decides by means of thinking what is desirable and undesirable, beautiful and ugly, in it,

original: – “ettakaṃ me rūpārammaṇatthāya bhavissati, ettakaṃ saddādiārammaṇatthāya, ettakaṃ
analyzed: ettakam me rūpa ārammaṇa tthāya bhavissati ettakam sadda ādi ārammaṇa tthāya ettakam
translated: thus: “So much of this will be for the purpose of visible-data objects, so much for the purpose of sound objects, and so on.

original: mayhaṃ bhavissati, ettakaṃ parassa, ettakaṃ paribhuñjissāmi, ettakaṃ nidahissāmī”ti.
analyzed: mayham bhavissati ettakam parassa ettakam paribhuñjissāmi ettakam nidahissāmi iti
translated: So much will be for me, so much for others. So much I shall use, so much I shall set aside.”

original: Tena vuttaṃ – “lābhaṃ paṭicca vinicchayo”ti.🔽Chandarāgoti evaṃ akusalavitakkena vitakkitavatthusmiṃ dubbalarāgo ca balavarāgo🔽ca uppajjati, idañhi idha taṇhā. Chandoti dubbalarāgassādhivacanaṃ. Ajjhosānanti
analyzed: tena vuttam lābham paṭicca vinicchayaḥ ti  chanda rāgaḥ ti evam akusala vitakkena vitakkita vatthusmim dubbala rāgo ca balava rāgo  ca uppajjati idam hi idha taṇhā chando ti dubbala rāgassa adhivacanam ajjhosānam ti
translated: Hence it was said above: “Decision contingent on gain” .

original: ahaṃ mamanti balavasanniṭṭhānaṃ. Pariggahoti taṇhādiṭṭhavasena pariggahaṇakaraṇaṃ.
analyzed: aham mama nti balava sanniṭṭhānam pariggaho ti taṇhā diṭṭha vasena pariggahaṇa karaṇam
translated: Desire and lust: weak lust and strong lust arise in the object of thought by means of the unwholesome thinking. For this is craving here. “Desire” is a term for weak lust. “Clinging” is the strong determination of “I” and “mine.” “Misapprehension” is the act of misapprehending by means of craving and views.

original: Macchariyanti parehi sādhāraṇabhāvassa asahanatā. Tenevassa porāṇā evaṃ vacanatthaṃ
analyzed: mat śariyanti parehi sādhāraṇa bhāvassa a sahana tā porāṇāḥ evam vacana attham
translated: “Avarice” is the inability to bear sharing with others. Hence the ancients said:

original: vadanti – “idaṃ acchariyaṃ mayhameva hotu, mā aññesaṃ acchariyaṃ hotūti pavattattā
analyzed: vadanti idam acchariyam mayham eva hotu mā aññesam acchariyam hotu uti pavatta ttā
translated: They say: “It is called ‘envy’ because it occurs thus: ‘Let this wonder be mine alone, let it not be another’s wonder.’ ”

original: macchariyanti vuccatī”ti. Ārakkhoti dvārapidahanamañjūsagopanādivasena suṭṭhu rakkhaṇaṃ.
analyzed: macchariya nti vuccati iti ārakkho ti dvāra pidahana mañjūsa gopana ādi vasena suṭṭhu rakkhaṇam
translated: “Guarding” is guarding well by such means as locking the door and guarding the mouth.

original: Adhikarotīti adhikaraṇaṃ, kāraṇassetaṃ nāmaṃ. Ārakkhādhikaraṇanti bhāvanapuṃsakaṃ,
analyzed: adhikaroti iti adhikaraṇam kāraṇassa itam nāmam ārakkha adhikaraṇam ti bhāva napuṃsakam
translated: “Cause of guarding” is a feminine noun; the meaning is: “cause of guarding.”

original: ārakkhahetūti attho. Daṇḍādānādīsu paranisedhanatthaṃ daṇḍassa ādānaṃ daṇḍādānaṃ.
analyzed: ārakkha hetu uti atthaḥ daṇḍa ādāna ādīsu para nisedhana attham daṇḍassa ādānam daṇḍa ādānam
translated: “Taking up a stick” is the taking up of a stick for the purpose of restraining others in the case of such things as punishment.

original: Ekato dhārādino satthassa ādānaṃ satthādānaṃ. Kalahoti kāyakalahopi vācākalahopi.
analyzed: ekatas dhārā ādinaḥ satthassa ādānam sattha ādānam kalaho ti kāya kalahaḥ api vācā kalahaḥ api
translated: “Taking up a weapon” is the taking up of a sword, etc. “Quarrel” is a quarrel by body or by speech.

original: Purimo purimo virodho viggaho. Pacchimo pacchimo vivādo. Tuvaṃtuvanti agāravavacanaṃ tuvaṃtuvaṃ.
analyzed: purimaḥ purimaḥ virodhaḥ viggahaḥ pacchimaḥ pacchimaḥ vivādo agārava vacanam tuvaṃtuvam
translated: The first is the first opposition, the second is the first dispute. “You, you!” is the expression of disrespect.

original: 112. Idāni paṭilomanayenāpi taṃsamudācārataṇhaṃ dassetuṃ puna – “ārakkhādhikaraṇa”nti
analyzed: idāni paṭiloma nayena api taṃ samudācāra taṇham dassetum puna ārakkha adhikaraṇam ti
translated: Now, in order to show that craving for the recurrence of that same experience by the reverse order, he again began the teaching with “the cause of guarding”

original: ārabhanto desanaṃ nivattesi. Tattha kāmataṇhāti pañcakāmaguṇikarāgavasena uppannā
analyzed: ārabhantaḥ desanam nivattesi tattha kāma taṇhā ti pañca kāma guṇika rāga vasena uppannā
translated: and reversed the order of the teaching. Herein, craving for sense desires is that which arises through the lust for the five strands of sense pleasure.

original: rūpāditaṇhā. Bhavataṇhāti sassatadiṭṭhisahagato rāgo. Vibhavataṇhāti ucchedadiṭṭhisahagato🔽rāgo. Ime dve dhammāti vaṭṭamūlataṇhā ca samudācārataṇhā cāti ime dve dhammā. Dvayenāti🔽taṇhālakkhaṇavasena ekabhāvaṃ gatāpi vaṭṭamūlasamudācāravasena dvīhi koṭṭhāsehi vedanāya
analyzed: rūpa ādi taṇhā bhava taṇhā ati sassata diṭṭhi sahagataḥ rāgaḥ vibhava taṇhā ati uccheda diṭṭhi sahagataḥ  rāgaḥ ime dve dhammā ati vaṭṭa mūla taṇhā ca samudācāra taṇhā ca ati ime dve dhammā dvayena ati  taṇhā lakkhaṇa vasena eka bhāvam gatā api vaṭṭa mūla samudācāra vasena dvīhi koṭṭhāsehi vedanāya
translated: Craving for form, etc. Craving for becoming is lust associated with the eternalist view. Craving for non-becoming is lust associated with the annihilationist view. These two ideas: the craving that is the root of the round and the craving that is its manifestation. By a dyad:🔽though they are of one nature by way of the characteristic of craving, they are of two sections by way of the root of the round and manifestation. By feeling:🔽

original: ekasamosaraṇā bhavanti, vedanāpaccayena ekapaccayāti attho. Tividhañhi samosaraṇaṃ🔽osaraṇasamosaraṇaṃ, sahajātasamosaraṇaṃ, paccayasamosaraṇañca. Tattha – “atha kho🔽sabbāni tāni kāmasamosaraṇāni bhavantī”ti idaṃ osaraṇasamosaraṇaṃ nāma. “Chandamūlakā,🔽āvuso, ete dhammā phassasamudayā vedanāsamosaraṇā”ti idaṃ sahajātasamosaraṇaṃ nāma.
analyzed: eka samosaraṇāḥ bhavanti vedanā paccayena eka paccayā ati attho tividham hi samosaraṇam  osaraṇa samosaraṇam sahajāta samosaraṇam paccaya samosaraṇam ca tattha atha kho  sabbāni tāni kāma samosaraṇāni bhavanti iti idam osaraṇa samosaraṇam nāma chanda mūlakā  āvuso ete dhammā phassa samudayā vedanā samosaraṇā ti idam sahajāta samosaraṇam nāma
translated: Craving for visible forms, etc. Craving for becoming is lust associated with the eternalist view. Craving for non-becoming is lust associated with the annihilationist view. These two ideas: the craving that is the root of the round and the craving that is its manifestation. By a duality: although they are one in the characteristic of craving, they are included in two sections as root-cause craving and manifestation craving. They converge on a single thing, namely, feeling. The meaning is that they have a single condition, namely, feeling. For convergence is threefold, namely,

original: “Dvayena vedanāya ekasamosaraṇā”ti idaṃ pana paccayasamosaraṇanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: dvayena vedanāya eka samosaraṇā ti idam pana paccaya samosaraṇam ti veditabbam
translated: convergence by way of falling into , convergence by way of conascence, and convergence by way of condition. Herein, “Then all those things converge on sense desires” is called convergence by way of falling into . “These ideas, friends, have will as their source, their origin; they converge on contact; they issue in feeling” is called convergence by way of conascence. “By a duality they converge on a single thing, namely, feeling” should be understood as convergence by way of condition.

original: 113. Cakkhusamphassoti ādayo sabbe vipākaphassāyeva. Tesu ṭhapetvā cattāro lokuttaravipākaphasse🔽avasesā dvattiṃsa phassā honti. Yadidaṃ phassoti ettha pana phasso bahudhā vedanāya paccayo hoti.
analyzed: cakkhu samphasso ti ādayo sabbe vipāka phassāya iva tesu ṭhapetvā cattāro lokuttara vipāka phasse  avasesāḥ dvattiṃsa phassāḥ honti yat idam phasso ti ettha pana phasso bahudhā vedanāya paccayaḥ hoti
translated: Eye-contact, etc., are all resultant contact. Of these, excluding the four supramundane resultant contacts,🔽the remaining thirty-two are contact. As to the words “Contact is a condition for feeling” , contact is a condition for feeling in many ways.

original: 114. Yehi, ānanda, ākārehītiādīsu ākārā vuccanti vedanādīnaṃ aññamaññaṃ asadisasabhāvā.🔽Teyeva sādhukaṃ dassiyamānā taṃ taṃ līnamatthaṃ gamentīti liṅgāni. Tassa tassa sañjānanahetuto🔽nimittāni. Tathā tathā uddisitabbato uddesā. Tasmā ayamettha attho – “ānanda, yehi🔽ākārehi…pe… yehi uddesehi nāmakāyassa nāmasamūhassa paññatti hoti, yā esā ca vedanāya
analyzed: yehi ānanda ākārehi itiādīsu ākārāḥ vuccanti vedanā ādīnam aññam aññam asadisa sabhāvā  teyā iva sādhukam dassiyamānā tam tam līnam attham gamenti iti liṅgāni tassa tassa sañjānana hetutaḥ  nimittāni tathā tathā uddisitabbataḥ uddesā tasmā ayam ettha atthaḥ ānanda yehi  yehi uddesehi nāmakāyassa nāma samūhassa paññatti hoti yā esā ca vedanāya
translated: Eye-contact, etc., are all resultant contact. Of these, excluding the four supramundane resultant contacts,

original: vedayitākāre vedayitaliṅge vedayitanimitte vedanāti uddese sati, saññāya sañjānanākāre
analyzed: vedayita ākāre vedayita liṅge vedayita nimitte vedanā ati uddese sati saññāya sañjānana ākāre
translated: the remaining thirty-two are contact. As to the words “Contact is a condition for feeling” , contact is a condition for feeling in many ways.

original: sañjānanaliṅge sañjānananimitte saññāti uddese sati, saṅkhārānaṃ cetanākāre cetanāliṅge
analyzed: sañjānana liṅge sañjānana nimitte uddese sati cetanā ākāre cetanā liṅge
translated: When there is the expression ‘perception’ for the sign of perceiving and the cause of perceiving, and when there is the expression ‘volition’ for the mode of determining of formations and for the sign of determining and the cause of determining,

original: cetanānimitte cetanāti uddese sati, viññāṇassa vijānanākāre vijānanaliṅge vijānananimitte
analyzed: cetanā nimitte cetanā ati uddese sati viññāṇassa vijānana ākāre vijānana liṅge vijānana nimitte
translated: and when there is the expression ‘consciousness’ for the mode of cognizing of consciousness and for the sign of cognizing and the cause of cognizing,

original: viññāṇanti uddese sati – ‘ayaṃ nāmakāyo’ti nāmakāyassa paññatti hoti. Tesu nāmakāyappaññattihetūsu
analyzed: viññāṇanti uddese sati ayam nāmakāyaḥ ti nāmakāyassa paññatti hoti tesu nāmakāya ppaññatti hetūsu
translated: then there is the definition of the mental body as ‘this is the mental body.’🔽Now, when there is no feeling, etc., and no mode, etc., in those things that are the cause for the definition of the mental body,

original: vedanādīsu ākārādīsu asati api nu kho rūpakāye adhivacanasamphasso paññāyetha? Yvāyaṃ
analyzed: vedanā ādīsu ākāra ādīsu asati api nu kho rūpa kāye adhivacana samphasso paññāyetha yvā ayam
translated: would the contact with mental data that is called ‘contact with the mental body’ be evident in the material body?

original: cattāro khandhe vatthuṃ katvā manodvāre adhivacanasamphassavevacano manosamphasso
analyzed: cattāro khandhe vatthum katvā manaḥ dvāre adhivacana samphassa vevacanaḥ manaḥ samphassaḥ
translated: This is the contact with mental data that occurs in the mind door having the four mental aggregates as its object, and it is called ‘contact with the mental body’ because it is contact with the mental body.

original: uppajjati, api nu kho so rūpakāye paññāyetha, pañca pasāde vatthuṃ katvā katvā uppajjeyyā”ti.🔽Atha āyasmā ānando ambarukkhe asati jamburukkhato ambapakkassa uppattiṃ viya rūpakāyato
analyzed: uppajjati api nu kho so rūpa kāye paññāyetha pañca pasāde vatthum katvā katvā uppajjeyya ati  atha āyasmai ānandaḥ amba rukkhe asati jambu rukkhataḥ amba pakkassa uppattim viya rūpa kāyataḥ
translated: Would that be evident in the material body, which is the object of the five senses, and occur having that as its object?”

original: tassa uppattiṃ asampaṭicchanto no hetaṃ bhanteti āha.
analyzed: tassa uppattim a sampaṭicchantaḥ no ha etam bhante ti āha
translated: Then the venerable Ānanda, like the non-admission that a mango can grow from a rose-apple tree when the mango tree is absent, did not admit that it could occur in the material body, which is the object of the five senses, and he said: “No, indeed, venerable sir.”

original: Dutiyapañhe ruppanākāraruppanaliṅgaruppananimittavasena rūpanti uddesavasena ca ākārādīnaṃ
analyzed: dutiya pañhe ruppana ākāra ruppana liṅga ruppana nimitta vasena uddesa vasena ca ākāra ādīnam
translated: In the second question, the meaning of the terms “form” and so on should be understood as the arising of form by way of the mode of appearance, the sign of appearance, and the cause of appearance, and by way of the designation “form.”

original: attho veditabbo. Paṭighasamphassoti sappaṭighaṃ rūpakkhandhaṃ vatthuṃ katvā uppajjanakasamphasso.🔽Idhāpi thero jamburukkhe asati ambarukkhato jambupakkassa uppattiṃ viya nāmakāyato
analyzed: atthaḥ veditabbaḥ paṭigha samphassaḥ ti sa paṭigham rūpa kkhandham vatthum katvā uppajjanaka samphassaḥ  idha api theraḥ jambu rukkhe asati amba rukkhataḥ jambu pakkassa uppattim viya nāmakāyato
translated: “Contact with impingement”: the contact that arises with the resistant aggregate of form as its object.

original: tassa uppattiṃ asampaṭicchanto “no hetaṃ bhante”ti āha.
analyzed: tassa uppattim a sampaṭicchantaḥ no ha etam bhante ti āha
translated: Here, the elder, denying the arising of the fruit of the rose-apple tree from the mango tree in the absence of the rose-apple tree, said, “No, venerable sir.”

original: Tatiyapañho ubhayavaseneva vutto. Tatra thero ākāse ambajambupakkānaṃ uppattiṃ viya nāmarūpābhāve dvinnampi phassānaṃ uppattiṃ asampaṭicchanto “no hetaṃ bhante”ti āha.
analyzed: tatiya pañhaḥ ubhaya vasena iva vuttaḥ tatra theraḥ ākāse amba jambu pakkānam uppattim viya nāma rūpa abhāve dvinnam pi phassānam uppattim a sampaṭicchantaḥ no hetam bhante iti āha
translated: The third question is stated by way of both. There, the elder, denying the arising of both contacts in the absence of mentality-materiality, said, “No, venerable sir,” as if denying the arising of the fruits of the mango and rose-apple trees in the sky.

original: Evaṃ dvinnaṃ phassānaṃ visuṃ visuṃ paccayaṃ dassetvā idāni dvinnampi tesaṃ avisesato
analyzed: evam dvinnam phassānam visum visum paccayam dassetvā idāni dvinnam pi tesam avisesato
translated: Having thus shown the conditions for the two contacts separately, now, in order to show the conditionality of both of them together,

original: nāmarūpapaccayataṃ dassetuṃ – “yehi ānanda ākārehī”ti catutthaṃ pañhaṃ ārabhi. Yadidaṃ
analyzed: nāma rūpa paccaya tam dassetum yehi ānanda ākārehi iti catuttham pañham ārabhi yat idam
translated: he began the fourth question with the words, “By what are these two things conditioned?”

original: nāmarūpanti yaṃ idaṃ nāmarūpaṃ, yaṃ idaṃ chasupi dvāresu nāmarūpaṃ, eseva hetu eseva
analyzed: nāma rūpanti yam idam nāma rūpam yam idam dvāresu nāma rūpam eṣa iva hetu eṣa iva
translated: “Name-and-form”: whatever this name-and-form is, whatever this name-and-form is in the six sense-spheres, this is the cause,

original: paccayoti attho. Cakkhudvārādīsu hi cakkhādīni ceva rūpārammaṇādīni ca rūpaṃ, sampayuttakā
analyzed: paccayaḥ ti attho cakkhu dvāra ādīsu hi cakkha ādīni ca iva rūpa ārammaṇa ādīni ca rūpam sampayuttakā
translated: “Name-and-form”: the name-and-form that is in the six bases beginning with the eye, this is the cause, this is the reason, is the meaning. For in the case of the eye door, etc., the eye, etc., are materiality, and the associated aggregates are name.

original: khandhā nāmanti evaṃ pañcavidhopi so phasso nāmarūpapaccayāva phasso. Manodvārepi🔽hadayavatthuñceva yañca rūpaṃ ārammaṇaṃ hoti, idaṃ rūpaṃ. Sampayuttadhammā ceva yañca
analyzed: khandhāḥ nāmanti evam pañcavidhaḥ pi so phassaḥ nāma rūpa paccayā vā phasso manaḥ dvāre pi  hadaya vatthuṃ ca iva yat ca rūpam ārammaṇam hoti idam rūpam sampayutta dhammā ca iva yat ca
translated: Thus the fivefold contact is due only to name-and-form as condition. In the mind door, too,🔽the heart-basis and the materiality that is the object are materiality, and the associated states are name.

original: arūpaṃ ārammaṇaṃ hoti, idaṃ arūpaṃ nāma. Evaṃ manosamphassopi nāmarūpapaccayā phassoti
analyzed: arūpam ārammaṇam hoti idam arūpam nāma evam manaḥ samphassaḥ api nāma rūpa paccayā phasso ti
translated: Thus mind-contact should be understood as due to name-and-form as condition.

original: veditabbo. Nāmarūpaṃ panassa bahudhā paccayo hoti.
analyzed: veditabbaḥ nāma rūpam pana assa bahudhā paccayaḥ hoti
translated: But name-and-form is a condition for it in many ways.

original: 115. Na okkamissathāti pavisitvā pavattamānaṃ viya paṭisandhivasena na vattissatha.
analyzed: na okkamissatha ati pavisitvā pavattamānam viya paṭisandhi vasena na vattissatha
translated: “Would not enter upon”: would not occur by way of rebirth-linking, as if entering and occurring.

original: Samuccissathāti paṭisandhiviññāṇe asati api nu kho suddhaṃ avasesaṃ nāmarūpaṃ antomātukucchismiṃ
analyzed: samuccissatha ati paṭisandhi viññāṇe asati api nu kho suddham avasesam nāma rūpam antomātukucchismim
translated: “Would not continue”: if rebirth-linking consciousness did not exist, would mere name-and-form continue in the mother’s womb?

original: kalalādibhāvena samuccitaṃ missakabhūtaṃ hutvā vattissatha. Okkamitvā vokkamissathāti
analyzed: kalala ādi bhāvena samuccitam missaka bhūtam hutvā vattissatha okkamitvā vokkamissatha ati
translated: It will go on occurring as a compound of the various stages of the embryo, beginning with the kalala stage. It will descend and ascend:

original: paṭisandhivasena okkamitvā cutivasena vokkamissatha, nirujjhissathāti attho. So panassa🔽nirodho na tasseva cittassa nirodhena, na tato dutiyatatiyānaṃ nirodhena hoti. Paṭisandhicittena
analyzed: paṭisandhi vasena okkamitvā cuti vasena vā ukkamissatha nirujjhissatha ati attho so panassa  nirodhaḥ na tassa iva cittassa nirodhena na tatas dutiya tatiyānam nirodhena hoti paṭisandhi cittena
translated: it will descend by rebirth-linking and ascend by death. The meaning is that it will cease. But that cessation of it

original: hi saddhiṃ samuṭṭhitāni samatiṃsa kammajarūpāni nibbattanti. Tesu pana ṭhitesuyeva🔽soḷasa bhavaṅgacittāni uppajjitvā nirujjhanti. Etasmiṃ antare gahitapaṭisandhikassa🔽dārakassa vā mātuyā vā panassa antarāyo natthi. Ayañhi anokāso nāma. Sace pana paṭisandhicittena
analyzed: hi saddhim samuṭṭhitāni kamma ja rūpāni nibbattanti tesu pana ṭhitesu yeva  soḷasa bhavaṅga cittāni uppajjitvā nirujjhanti etasmin antare gahita paṭisandhikassa  dārakassa vā mātuyā vā panassa antarāyaḥ natthi ayam hi anokāsaḥ nāma sace pana paṭisandhi cittena
translated: is not by the cessation of that same consciousness, nor by the cessation of a second or third consciousness. For when the rebirth-linking consciousness arises, thirty kinds of materiality arise together with it that have their origin in kamma. But while they last,

original: saddhiṃ samuṭṭhitarūpāni sattarasamassa bhavaṅgassa paccayaṃ dātuṃ sakkonti, pavatti
analyzed: saddhim samuṭṭhita rūpāni sattarasamassa bhavaṅgassa paccayam dātum sakkonti pavatti
translated: sixteen kinds of consciousness arise and cease. In this interval there is no obstacle to the death of the child that has taken rebirth-linking or to the death of its mother. For this is a “safe period.” But if the material instances that arose together with the rebirth-linking consciousness are able to give their support to the second life-continuum consciousness, then the process of becoming continues.

original: pavattati, paveṇī ghaṭiyati. Sace pana na sakkonti, pavatti nappavattati, paveṇī
analyzed: pavattati paveṇī ghaṭiyati sace pana na sakkonti pavatti na ppavattati paveṇī
translated: and the line of succession is established. But if they cannot, the succession does not continue,

original: na ghaṭiyati, vokkamati nāma hoti. Taṃ sandhāya “okkamitvā vokkamissathā”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: na ghaṭiyati vokkamati nāma hoti tam sandhāya okkamitvā vokkamissatha iti vuttam
translated: and the line of succession is not established. It is this that is called “transgression.” It is with reference to this that it is said: “Having entered upon it, you will transgress it.”

original: Itthattāyāti itthabhāvāya, evaṃ paripuṇṇapañcakkhandhabhāvāyāti attho. Daharasseva🔽satoti mandassa bālasseva santassa. Vocchijjissathāti upacchijjissatha vuḍḍhiṃ virūḷhiṃ
analyzed: itthattāya ati ittha bhāvāya evam paripuṇṇa pañcakkhandha bhāvāya ati atthaḥ daharassa iva  sataḥ iti mandassa bālassa iva santassa vā ucchijjissatha ati upacchijjissatha vuḍḍhim virūḍhim
translated: Itthattāyāti = itthabhāvāya. The meaning is: for the state of being of the five aggregates complete in all respects.

original: vepullanti viññāṇe upacchinne suddhaṃ nāmarūpameva uṭṭhahitvā paṭhamavayavasena vuḍḍhiṃ,
analyzed: vepullanti viññāṇe upacchinne suddham nāma rūpam eva uṭṭhahitvā paṭhama vaya vasena vuḍḍhim
translated: Daharasseva sato = of one who is young, of one who is foolish, of one who is inexperienced. Vocchijjissathāti = upacchijjissatha. If consciousness is cut off, will mere mentality-materiality, having arisen in the first stage, attain growth,

original: majjhimavayavasena virūḷhiṃ, pacchimavayavasena vepullaṃ api nu kho āpajjissathāti.🔽Dasavassavīsativassavassasatavassasahassasampāpanena vā api nu kho vuḍḍhiṃ virūḷhiṃ
analyzed: virūḷhim pacchima vayavasena vepullam api nu kho āpajjissatha ati  dasa vassa vīsati vassa vassa sata vassa sahassa sampāpanena vā api nu kho vuḍḍhim virūḍhim
translated: increase, and abundance in the middle stage, and fulfilment in the last stage?

original: vepullaṃ āpajjissathāti attho.
analyzed: vepullam āpajjissatha ati attho
translated: Or, having attained the duration of ten years, twenty years, a hundred years, a thousand years, will it attain growth, increase, and abundance? This is the meaning.

original: Tasmātihānandāti yasmā mātukucchiyaṃ paṭisandhiggahaṇepi kucchivāsepi kucchito nikkhamanepi,
analyzed: tasmā ati ha ānanda ati yasmā mātukucchiyam paṭisandhi ggahaṇe api kucchi vāse pi kucchitaḥ nikkhamane pi
translated: Therefore, Ananda, means: because consciousness is the condition for the arising of mentality-materiality in the womb, in the ten-month period, and in the five-hundred-year period, etc.,

original: pavattiyaṃ dasavassādikālepi viññāṇamevassa paccayo, tasmā eseva hetu esa paccayo🔽nāmarūpassa, yadidaṃ viññāṇaṃ. Yathā hi rājā attano parisaṃ niggaṇhanto evaṃ vadeyya
analyzed: pavattiyam dasa vassa ādi kāle pi viññāṇam eva assa paccayo tasmai esa iva hetu esa paccayo  nāma rūpassa yat idam viññāṇam yathā hi rājā attanaḥ parisam niggaṇhantaḥ evam vadeyya
translated: this is the reason, this is the cause, this is the condition for mentality-materiality, namely, consciousness.

original: – “tvaṃ uparājā, tvaṃ senāpatīti kena kato nanu mayā kato, sace hi mayi akaronte
analyzed: tvam uparājā tvam senāpatiḥ iti kena kataḥ nanu mayā sace hi mayi a karonte
translated: Just as a king, when he is suppressing his retinue, might say: “Who made you a crown prince, who made you a general? Was it not I who made you? If you were to become a crown prince or a general by your own nature,

original: tvaṃ attano dhammatāya uparājā vā senāpati vā bhaveyyāsi, jāneyyāma vo bala”nti;
analyzed: tvam attanaḥ dhammatāya upa rājā vā senāpati vā bhaveyyāsi jāneyyāma vaḥ balanti
translated: without my making you, we would know your strength,”

original: evameva viññāṇaṃ nāmarūpassa paccayo hoti. Atthato evaṃ nāmarūpaṃ vadati viya “tvaṃ
analyzed: evam eva viññāṇam nāma rūpassa paccayaḥ hoti atthataḥ evam nāma rūpam vadati viya tvam
translated: so too, consciousness is the condition for mentality-materiality. In effect, it is as if mentality-materiality were to say: “You mentality, you materiality, you mentality-materiality,

original: nāmaṃ, tvaṃ rūpaṃ, tvaṃ nāmarūpaṃ nāmāti kena kataṃ, nanu mayā kataṃ, sace hi mayi
analyzed: nāmam tvam rūpam tvam nāma rūpam nāma ati kena katam nanu mayā katam sace hi mayi
translated: who made you? Was it not I who made you? If you were to become mentality, materiality, or mentality-materiality

original: purecārike hutvā mātukucchismiṃ paṭisandhiṃ agaṇhante tvaṃ nāmaṃ vā rūpaṃ vā nāmarūpaṃ
analyzed: purecārike hutvā mātukucchismim paṭisandhim a gaṇhante tvam nāmam vā rūpam vā nāma rūpam
translated: without my having gone before you and taken rebirth in the mother’s womb,🔽we would know your strength.”

original: vā bhaveyyāsi, jāneyyāma vo bala”nti. Taṃ panetaṃ viññāṇaṃ nāmarūpassa bahudhā paccayo hoti.
analyzed: vā bhaveyyāsi jāneyyāma vaḥ balanti tam pana itam viññāṇam nāma rūpassa bahudhā paccayaḥ hoti
