translated: But this consciousness is a condition in many ways for mentality-materiality.🔽The origin of the origin of suffering: the origin of the mass of suffering.

original: 116. Dukkhasamudayasambhavoti dukkharāsisambhavo. Yadidaṃ nāmarūpanti yaṃ idaṃ nāmarūpaṃ,🔽eseva hetu esa paccayo. Yathā hi rājapurisā rājānaṃ niggaṇhanto evaṃ vadeyyuṃ – “tvaṃ
analyzed: dukkha samudaya sambhavaḥ ti dukkha rāsi sambhavaḥ yat idam nāma rūpam iti yam idam nāma rūpam  esa iva hetu esa paccayaḥ yathā hi rāja purisāḥ rājānam niggaṇhantaḥ evam vadeyyum tvam
translated: What is this mentality-materiality?

original: rājāti kena kato, nanu mayā kato, sace hi mayi uparājaṭṭhāne, mayi senāpatiṭṭhāne
analyzed: rājā ati kena kataḥ nanu mayā kataḥ sace hi mayi uparāja ṭṭhāne mayi senāpati ṭṭhāne
translated: Just as the king’s men, in arresting the king, might say: “By whom were you made king? By us, surely, were you made king. If we were to stand in the place of the king, in the place of the general,

original: atiṭṭhante tvaṃ ekakova rājā bhaveyyāsi, passeyyāma te rājabhāva”nti; evameva nāmarūpampi🔽atthato evaṃ viññāṇaṃ vadati viya “tvaṃ paṭisandhiviññāṇanti kena kataṃ, nanu amhehi
analyzed: atiṭṭhante tvam ekakaḥ iva rājā bhaveyyāsi passeyyāma te rāja bhāvanti evam eva nāma rūpam pi  atthataḥ evam viññāṇam vadati viya tvam paṭisandhi viññāṇam ti kena katam nanu amhehi
translated: in the place of the minister, you would be no king at all. We would see your king-ship.” So too,

original: kataṃ, sace hi tvaṃ tayo khandhe hadayavatthuñca anissāya paṭisandhiviññāṇaṃ nāma
analyzed: katam sace hi tvam tayo khandhe hadaya vatthuñca a nissāya paṭisandhi viññāṇam nāma
translated: mentality-materiality speaks as it were, in effect, to consciousness: “By whom were you made rebirth-linking consciousness? By us, surely, were you made rebirth-linking consciousness. If you were to stand depending on the three aggregates and the heart-basis,🔽we would see your rebirth-linking consciousness.”

original: bhaveyyāsi, passeyyāma te paṭisandhiviññāṇabhāva”nti. Tañca panetaṃ nāmarūpaṃ viññāṇassa
analyzed: bhaveyyāsi passeyyāma te paṭisandhi viññāṇa bhāvanti tat ca pana itam nāma rūpam viññāṇassa
translated: And this mentality-materiality is a condition for that consciousness

original: bahudhā paccayo hoti.
analyzed: bahudhā paccayaḥ hoti
translated: It is a condition in many ways.

original: Ettāvatā khoti viññāṇe nāmarūpassa paccaye honte, nāmarūpe viññāṇassa paccaye honte,
analyzed: ettāvatā kho ti viññāṇe nāma rūpassa paccaye honte nāma rūpe viññāṇassa paccaye honte
translated: To this extent: to the extent that consciousness is a condition for mentality-materiality and mentality-materiality is a condition for consciousness,🔽and the two occur by way of reciprocal conditionality, to that extent there would be birth, etc.,

original: dvīsu aññamaññapaccayavasena pavattesu ettakena jāyetha vā…pe… upapajjetha vā, jātiādayo🔽paññāyeyyuṃ aparāparaṃ vā cutipaṭisandhiyoti.🔽Adhivacanapathoti “sirivaḍḍhako dhanavaḍḍhako”tiādikassa atthaṃ adisvā vacanamattameva🔽adhikicca pavattassa vohārassa patho. Niruttipathoti saratīti sato, sampajānātīti
analyzed: dvīsu aññamañña paccaya vasena pavattesu ettakena jāyetha vā āpe upapajjetha vā jāti ādayaḥ  paññāyeyyum apara aparam vā cuti paṭisandhiyā ti  adhivacana patho ti sirivaḍḍhakaḥ dhanavaḍḍhaka uti ādikassa attham a disvā vacanam attam eva  adhikicca pavattassa vohārassa pathaḥ nirutti pathaḥ ti sarati iti sataḥ sampajānāti iti
translated: or there would be death and rebirth-linking in succession.🔽The path of designation: the path of the usage that occurs by way of designation, without regard to the meaning, as in the case of “Sirivaḍḍha” and “Dhanavaḍḍha” .

original: sampajānotiādikassa kāraṇāpadesavasena pavattassa vohārassa patho. Paññattipathoti
analyzed: sampajānoti ādikassa kāraṇa apadesa vasena pavattassa vohārassa patho paññatti pathoti
translated: The path of linguistic usage: the path of the usage that occurs by way of linguistic usage, by the expression of a reason, as in the case of “one who remembers is mindful” and “one who understands is fully aware” .

original: – “paṇḍito byatto medhāvī nipuṇo kataparappavādo”tiādikassa nānappakārato ñāpanavasena
analyzed: paṇḍitaḥ byattaḥ medhāvī nipuṇaḥ kata para pavādaḥ ti ādikassa nānā ppakārataḥ ñāpana vasena
translated: The path of description: the path of the usage that occurs by way of description in various ways, as in the case of “the wise one, the competent one, the virtuous one, the one skilled in the disciplines, the one who has overcome the dispute” .

original: pavattassa vohārassa patho. Iti tīhi padehi adhivacanādīnaṃ vatthubhūtā khandhāva
analyzed: pavattassa vohārassa pathaḥ iti tīhi padehi adhivacana ādīnam vatthu bhūtā khandhāva
translated: Thus, by means of the three terms, the aggregates that are the basis of designation, etc., are shown.

original: kathitā. Paññāvacaranti paññāya avacaritabbaṃ jānitabbaṃ. Vaṭṭaṃ vattatīti saṃsāravaṭṭaṃ
analyzed: kathitā paññāvacaranti paññāya avacaritabbam jānitabbam vaṭṭam vattati iti saṃsāravaṭṭam
translated: and the rest is said. “The range of understanding”: what should be known by understanding. “The round of births goes on turning”: the round of the samsaric process.

original: vattati. Itthattanti itthaṃbhāvo, khandhapañcakassetaṃ nāmaṃ. Paññāpanāyāti nāmapaññattatthāya.
analyzed: vattati itthattanti itthaṃbhāvaḥ khandha pañcakassa itam nāmam paññāpanāya ati nāma paññatta tthāya
translated: “The state of being thus”: the state of being in the five aggregates. “For the purpose of designation”: for the purpose of the designation of a name.

original: “Vedanā saññā”tiādinā nāmapaññattatthāya, khandhapañcakampi ettāvatā paññāyatīti🔽attho. Yadidaṃ nāmarūpaṃ saha viññāṇenāti yaṃ idaṃ nāmarūpaṃ saha viññāṇena aññamaññapaccayatāya
analyzed: vedanā saññāti ādinā nāma paññatta tthāya khandha pañcakam pi ettāvatā paññāyati iti  atthaḥ yat idam nāma rūpam saha viññāṇena ati yam idam nāma rūpam saha viññāṇena aññamañña paccaya tāya
translated: “Feeling, perception” and so on are for the purpose of the designation of a name. The meaning is that the five aggregates are known up to this point.

original: pavattati, ettāvatāti vuttaṃ hoti. Idañhettha niyyātitavacanaṃ.
analyzed: pavattati ettāvatā iti vuttam hoti idam ha ittha niyyātita vacanam
translated: “This name-and-form together with consciousness”: this name-and-form together with consciousness that occurs by way of mutual conditionality. This is what is meant by “up to this point.” This is the explanation of the words “up to this point.”

original: Attapaññattivaṇṇanā
analyzed: atta paññatti vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the designation of a self

original: 117. Iti bhagavā – “gambhīro cāyaṃ, ānanda, paṭiccasamuppādo, gambhīrāvabhāso cā”ti
analyzed: iti bhagavā gambhīraḥ ca ayam ānanda paṭiccasamuppādaḥ gambhīra avabhāso ca ati
translated: Thus the Exalted One, having shown the connection of the words “deep, Ananda, is this dependent origination, and deep appears”🔽now, in order to show the connection of the words “like a tangled skein,”

original: padassa anusandhiṃ dassetvā idāni “tantākulakajātā”ti padassa anusandhiṃ dassento
analyzed: padassa anusandhim dassetvā idāni tantā kulaka jātā ti padassa anusandhim dassento
translated: says:

original: “kittāvatā cā”tiādikaṃ desanaṃ ārabhi. Tattha rūpiṃ vā hi, ānanda, parittaṃ attānantiādīsu🔽yo avaḍḍhitaṃ kasiṇanimittaṃ attāti gaṇhāti, so rūpiṃ parittaṃ paññapeti. Yo pana
analyzed: kittāvatā ca ati ādikam desanam ārabhi tattha rūpim vā hi ānanda parittam attā ananti ādīsu  yaḥ a vaḍḍhitam kasiṇa nimittam attā ati gaṇhāti saḥ rūpim parittam paññapeti yaḥ pana
translated: Herein, in the case of the first two views, namely, “The self is possessed of material form and limited” and “The self is possessed of material form and infinite,”

original: nānākasiṇalābhī hoti, so taṃ kadāci nīlo, kadāci pītakoti paññapeti. Yo vaḍḍhitaṃ🔽kasiṇanimittaṃ attāti gaṇhāti, so rūpiṃ anantaṃ paññapeti. Yo vā pana avaḍḍhitaṃ🔽kasiṇanimittaṃ ugghāṭetvā nimittaphuṭṭhokāsaṃ vā tattha pavatte cattāro khandhe vā🔽tesu viññāṇamattameva vā attāti gaṇhāti, so arūpiṃ parittaṃ paññapeti. Yo vaḍḍhitaṃ
analyzed: nānā kasiṇa lābhī hoti so tam kadāci nīlo kadāci pītako ti paññapeti yaḥ vaḍḍhitam  kasiṇa nimittam attā ati gaṇhāti saḥ rūpim anantam paññapeti yaḥ vā pana a vaḍḍhitam  kasiṇa nimittam ugghāṭetvā nimitta phuṭṭha ukāsam vā tattha pavatte cattāraḥ khandhe vā  tesu viññāṇam attam eva vā attā ati gaṇhāti saḥ arūpim parittam paññapeti yaḥ vaḍḍhitam
translated: one who apprehends the undemonstrated kasiṇa sign as the self is “possessed of material form and limited.” But one who has attained the various kasiṇas apprehends the self as blue or yellow, etc.,🔽and so he is “possessed of material form and infinite.”🔽Or one who apprehends the undemonstrated kasiṇa sign as the self is “possessed of material form and limited.” But one who has attained the kasiṇa sign and has removed the object of the sign, or who apprehends the four mental aggregates occurring therein, or the mere consciousness therein, as the self, is “possessed of material form and infinite.”

original: nimittaṃ ugghāṭetvā nimittaphuṭṭhokāsaṃ vā tattha pavatte cattāro khandhe vā tesu🔽viññāṇamattameva vā attāti gaṇhāti, so arūpiṃ anantaṃ paññapeti.
analyzed: nimittam ugghāṭetvā nimitta phuṭṭha ukāsam vā tattha pavatte cattāro khandhe vā tesu 🔽viññāṇam attam eva vai attā iti gaṇhāti saḥ arūpim anantam paññapeti
translated: One who apprehends the demonstrated kasiṇa sign as the self is “possessed of material form and limited.” But one who has removed the object of the sign, or who apprehends the four mental aggregates occurring therein, or the mere consciousness therein, as the self, is “possessed of material form and infinite.”

original: 118. Tatrānandāti ettha tatrāti tesu catūsu diṭṭhigatikesu. Etarahi vāti idāneva,🔽na ito paraṃ. Ucchedavasenetaṃ vuttaṃ. Tatthabhāviṃ vāti tattha vā paraloke bhāviṃ.
analyzed: tatra ānanda iti ettha tatra ati tesu catūsu diṭṭhigatikesu etarahi vā ati idānā iva  na itas param uccheda vasena itam vuttam tatthabhāvim vā ati tattha vā para loke bhāvim
translated: “There, Ananda,” here “there” refers to the four views. “Now” means just now,🔽not after this. This is said in terms of annihilationism. “What will come to be there” means what will come to be in the next world.

original: Sassatavasenetaṃ vuttaṃ. Atathaṃ vā pana santanti atathasabhāvaṃ samānaṃ. Tathattāyāti
analyzed: sassata vasena itam vuttam atatham vā pana santanti atatha sabhāvam samānam tathattāya ati
translated: This is said in terms of eternalism. “Or otherwise, as it is not”: as it is not of such a nature. “To that”: to such a nature.

original: tathabhāvāya. Upakappessāmīti sampādessāmi. Iminā vivādaṃ dasseti. Ucchedavādī hi
analyzed: tathabhāvāya upakappessāmi iti sampādessāmi iminā vivādam dasseti uccheda vādī hi
translated: “I will make it so”: I will bring it about. By this he shows the dispute. For the annihilationist thinks:

original: “sassatavādino attānaṃ atathaṃ anucchedasabhāvampi samānaṃ tathatthāya ucchedasabhāvāya
analyzed: sassata vādinaḥ attānam atatham an uccheda sabhāvam pi samānam tathatthāya uccheda sabhāvāya
translated: “I will make the eternalist’s self, which is not of such a nature, not of the nature of annihilation, to be of such a nature, to be of the nature of annihilation,

original: upakappessāmi, sassatavādañca jānāpetvā ucchedavādameva naṃ gāhessāmī”ti cinteti.
analyzed: upakappessāmi sassata vādam ca jānāpetvā uccheda vādam eva nam gāhessāmi iti cinteti
translated: and having made him understand eternalism, I will make him adopt annihilationism.”

original: Sassatavādīpi “ucchedavādino attānaṃ atathaṃ asassatasabhāvampi samānaṃ tathatthāya
analyzed: uccheda vādinaḥ attānam atatham samānam tathatthāya
translated: And the eternalist thinks: “I will make the annihilationist’s self, which is not of such a nature, not of the nature of eternity, to be of such a nature,

original: sassatabhāvāya upakappessāmi, ucchedavādañca jānāpetvā sassatavādameva naṃ gāhessāmī”ti cinteti.
analyzed: sassata bhāvāya upakappessāmi uccheda vādam ca jānāpetvā sassata vādam eva nam gāhessāmi iti cinteti
translated: to be of the nature of eternity, and having made him understand annihilationism, I will make him adopt eternalism.”

original: Evaṃ santaṃ khoti evaṃ samānaṃ rūpiṃ parittaṃ attānaṃ paññapentanti attho. Rūpinti
analyzed: evam santam kho ti evam samānam rūpim parittam attānam paññapentanti attho rūpin ti
translated: The meaning is: when it is so, they describe the self as having material form and as limited.🔽Having material form: having attained the material-kasiṇa jhāna.

original: rūpakasiṇalābhiṃ. Parittattānudiṭṭhi anusetīti paritto attāti ayaṃ diṭṭhi anuseti,
analyzed: rūpa kasiṇa lābhim paritta ttā anudiṭṭhi anuseti iti parittaḥ attā ati ayam diṭṭhi anuseti
translated: The view that the self is limited obsesses him: the view that the self is limited obsesses him,

original: sā pana na valli viya ca latā viya ca anuseti. Appahīnaṭṭhena anusetīti veditabbo.
analyzed: sā pana na valli viya ca latā viya ca anuseti appahīna ṭṭhena anuseti iti veditabbo
translated: but it does not obsess him as a creeper or a lath. It should be understood as obsessing him in the sense of not being abandoned.

original: Iccālaṃ vacanāyāti taṃ puggalaṃ evarūpā diṭṭhi anusetīti vattuṃ yuttaṃ. Esa nayo sabbattha.
analyzed: iccā alam vacanāya ati tam puggalam evarūpā diṭṭhi anuseti iti vattum yuttam esa nayo sabbattha
translated: This is how the description should be applied: it is proper to say that such a view obsesses that person. The same method applies in all cases.

original: Arūpinti ettha pana arūpakasiṇalābhiṃ, arūpakkhandhagocaraṃ vāti evamattho daṭṭhabbo.🔽Ettāvatā lābhino cattāro, tesaṃ antevāsikā cattāro, takkikā cattāro, tesaṃ antevāsikā
analyzed: arūpin ti ettha pana arūpa kasiṇa lābhim arūpa kkhandha gocaram vā ti evamatthaḥ daṭṭhabbo  ettāvatā lābhinaḥ cattāraḥ tesam antevāsikā cattāro takkikā cattāro tesam antevāsikā
translated: Having no material form: here the meaning should be regarded in this way: having attained the immaterial-kasiṇa jhāna, having the immaterial aggregates as one’s domain.

original: cattāroti attato soḷasa diṭṭhigatikā dassitā honti.
analyzed: cattāro ti attataḥ soḷasa diṭṭhigatikāḥ dassitāḥ honti
translated: Up to this point sixteen theorists have been shown, four who have attained jhāna, four who are their pupils, four logicians, and four who are their pupils.

original: Naattapaññattivaṇṇanā
analyzed: naatta paññatti vaṇṇanā
translated: The exposition of the description of the self.

original: 119. Evaṃ ye attānaṃ paññapenti, te dassetvā idāni ye na paññapenti, te dassetuṃ
analyzed: evam ye attānam paññapenti te dassetvā idāni ye na paññapenti te dassetum
translated: Having thus shown those who describe the self, he now shows those who do not describe the self.

original: – “kittāvatā ca ānandā”tiādimāha. Ke pana na paññapenti? Sabbe tāva ariyapuggalā
analyzed: kittāvatā ca ānanda ati ādim āha ke pana na paññapenti sabbe tāva ariya puggalā
translated: Who do not describe? All noble persons

original: na paññapenti. Ye ca bahussutā tipiṭakadharā dvipiṭakadharā ekapiṭakadharā, antamaso
analyzed: na paññapenti ye ca bahu ssutā ti piṭaka dharāḥ dvi piṭaka dharāḥ eka piṭaka dharāḥ antamaso
translated: do not describe. And those who are learned, who have memorized the three baskets, the two baskets, or one basket, and who, having well investigated

original: ekanikāyampi sādhukaṃ vinicchinitvā uggahitadhammakathikopi āraddhavipassakopi puggalo,
analyzed: eka nikāyam pi sādhukam vinicchinitvā uggahita dhamma kathikaḥ api āraddha vipassakaḥ api puggalaḥ
translated: the Dhamma they have learned, are preachers of the Dhamma, or are practicing insight,

original: te na paññapentiyeva. Etesañhi paṭibhāgakasiṇe paṭibhāgakasiṇamicceva ñāṇaṃ hoti.
analyzed: te na etesam hi paṭibhāga kasiṇe paṭibhāga kasiṇam iccā iva ñāṇam hoti
translated: these people do not describe. For to them the counterpart sign is simply a counterpart sign,

original: Arūpakkhandhesu ca arūpakkhandhā icceva.
analyzed: arūpa kkhandhesu ca arūpa kkhandhāḥ icca eva
translated: and the immaterial aggregates are simply the immaterial aggregates.

original: Attasamanupassanāvaṇṇanā🔽121. Evaṃ ye na paññapenti, te dassetvā idāni ye te paññapenti, te yasmā diṭṭhivasena🔽samanupassitvā paññapenti, sā ca nesaṃ samanupassanā vīsativatthukāya sakkāyadiṭṭhiyā
analyzed: atta samanupassanā vaṇṇanā  evam ye na paññapenti te dassetvā idāni ye te paññapenti te yasmā diṭṭhi vasena  samanupassitvā paññapenti sā ca nesam samanupassanā vīsati vatthukāya sakkāyadiṭṭhiyā
translated: The Description of the View of Self🔽Having thus shown those who do not describe, he now shows those who do describe, since they describe after viewing through views. And since their viewing is due to the non-abandoning of the twenty types of personality view,

original: appahīnattā hoti, tasmā taṃ vīsativatthukaṃ sakkāyadiṭṭhiṃ dassetuṃ puna kittāvatā ca ānandātiādimāha.
analyzed: appahīna ttā hoti tasmā tam vīsati vatthukam sakkāyadiṭṭhim dassetum puna kittāvatā ca ānanda iti ādim āha
translated: he says, “And how, Ananda,” in order to show the twenty types of personality view.

original: Tattha vedanaṃ vā hīti iminā vedanākkhandhavatthukā sakkāyadiṭṭhi kathitā. Appaṭisaṃvedano🔽me attāti iminā rūpakkhandhavatthukā. Attā me vediyati, vedanādhammo hi me attāti🔽iminā saññāsaṅkhāraviññāṇakkhandhavatthukā. Idañhi khandhattayaṃ vedanāsampayuttattā
analyzed: tattha vedanam vā hi iti iminā vedanā khandha vatthukā sakkāya diṭṭhi kathitā appaṭisaṃvedanaḥ  me attā ati iminā rūpa kkhandha vatthukā attā me vediyati vedanā dhammo hi me attā ati  iminā saññā saṅkhāra viññāṇa kkhandha vatthukāḥ idam hi khandha ttayam vedanā sampayutta ttā
translated: Herein, “Or feeling” refers to personality view based on the aggregates of feeling. “I shall be without feeling” refers to personality view based on the form aggregate. “My self feels” refers to personality view based on the aggregates of perception, mental formations, and consciousness. For these three aggregates are associated with feeling.

original: vediyati. Etassa ca vedanādhammo avippayuttasabhāvo.🔽122. Idāni tattha dosaṃ dassento – “tatrānandā”tiādimāha. Tattha tatrāti tesu tīsu🔽diṭṭhigatikesu. Yasmiṃ, ānanda, samayetiādi yo yo yaṃ yaṃ vedanaṃ attāti samanupassati,
analyzed: etassa ca vedanā dhammo a vippayutta sabhāvaḥ  idāni tattha dosam dassentaḥ tatra ānanda ati ādim āha tattha tatra ati tesu tīsu  diṭṭhigatikesu yasmin ānanda samaya itiādi yaḥ yaḥ yam yam vedanam attā ati samanupassati
translated: Herein, “Or feeling” : this states personality view based on the aggregate of feeling. “I shall be without feeling” : this states personality view based on the aggregate of form. “My self feels” : this states personality view based on the aggregates of perception, mental formations, and consciousness. For these three aggregates are felt because they are associated with feeling. And the self-state of the self is inseparable from them.

original: tassa tassa attano kadāci bhāvaṃ, kadāci abhāvanti evamādidosadassanatthaṃ vuttaṃ.
analyzed: tassa tassa attano kadāci bhāvam kadāci abhāvanti evamādi dosa dassana ttham vuttam
translated: Now, in order to show the fault in this, he said, “Therein, Ananda” , etc. Herein, therein means in those three views. “In whatever, Ananda, one feels” , etc., is said in order to show the fault that in the case of each one who regards any feeling as self, sometimes there is a self and sometimes there is not.

original: 123. Aniccādīsu hutvā abhāvato aniccā. Tehi tehi kāraṇehi saṅgamma samāgamma katāti
analyzed: anicca ādīsu hutvā abhāvataḥ aniccā tehi tehi kāraṇehi saṅgamma samāgamma katā ati
translated: . In the case of the impermanent, etc., they are impermanent because of non-existence after having been. They are formed because they are made by the coming together of this and that cause.

original: saṅkhatā. Taṃ taṃ paccayaṃ paṭicca sammā kāraṇeneva uppannāti paṭiccasamuppannā.🔽Khayotiādi sabbaṃ bhaṅgassa vevacanaṃ. Yañhi bhijjati, taṃ khiyatipi vayatipi virajjhatipi
analyzed: saṅkhatā tam tam paccayam paṭicca sammā kāraṇena iva uppannā ati paṭiccasamuppannā  khaya uti ādi sabbam bhaṅgassa vevacanam yat hi bhijjati tam khiyati pi vayati pi virajjhati pi
translated: They are formed because they have come about by being rightly formed through the various conditions. They are conditionally arisen because they have come about by being rightly formed through the various conditions.

original: nirujjhatipi, tasmā khayadhammātiādi vuttaṃ.🔽Byagā meti viagāti byagā, vigato niruddho me attāti attho. Kiṃ pana ekasseva tīsupi
analyzed: tasmā khaya dhamma ati ādi vuttam  mā iti viagā ati byagā vigataḥ niruddhaḥ me attā ati attho kim pana ekassa iva tīsu pi
translated: “Breaking up,” etc., are all synonyms for dissolution. For what breaks up also disintegrates, vanishes, fades away, and ceases. That is why it is said that they have the nature of breaking up, and so on.

original: kālesu – “eso me attā”ti hotīti, kiṃ pana na bhavissati? Diṭṭhigatikassa hi thusarāsimhi
analyzed: kālesu esaḥ me attā ati hoti iti kim pana na bhavissati diṭṭhi gatikassa hi thusa rāsimhi
translated: “Gone away” is “dispersed” . The meaning is that my self has gone away, has ceased. But can it not be that “it is” in the three times? But can it not be that it is not? For the theorist is like one who places a stick on a heap of chaff.

original: nikkhittakhāṇukasseva niccalatā nāma natthi, vanamakkaṭo viya aññaṃ gaṇhāti, aññaṃ🔽muñcati. Aniccasukhadukkhavokiṇṇanti visesena taṃ taṃ vedanaṃ attāti samanupassanto
analyzed: nikkhitta khāṇukassa iva niccala tā nāma natthi vana makkaṭaḥ viya aññam gaṇhāti aññam  muñcati anicca sukha dukkha vokiṇṇam ti visesena tam tam vedanam attā ati samanupassanto
translated: He has no stability at all. He seizes one thing and lets go of another, like a forest monkey.

original: aniccañceva sukhañca dukkhañca attānaṃ samanupassati avisesena vedanaṃ attāti samanupassanto
analyzed: aniccam ca iva sukham ca dukkham ca attānam samanupassati avisesena vedanam attā ati samanupassanto
translated: When he regards feeling as a self that is afflicted by the suffering of impermanence, he regards the impermanent as a self. When he regards feeling as a self that is afflicted by the suffering inherent in the impermanent, he regards the painful as a self.

original: vokiṇṇaṃ uppādavayadhammaṃ attānaṃ samanupassati. Vedanā hi tividhā ceva uppādavayadhammā🔽ca, tañcesa attāti samanupassati. Iccassa anicco ceva attā āpajjati, ekakkhaṇe ca🔽bahūnaṃ vedanānaṃ uppādo. Taṃ kho panesa aniccaṃ attānaṃ anujānāti, na ekakkhaṇe
analyzed: vokiṇṇam uppāda vaya dhammam attānam samanupassati vedanā hi tividhā ca iva uppāda vaya dhammā  ca tat ca isa attā ati samanupassati iccassa aniccaḥ ca iva attā āpajjati eka khaṇe ca  bahūnam vedanānam uppādaḥ tam kho pana esa aniccam attānam anujānāti na eka khaṇe
translated: He regards the self as the materiality that is mixed, subject to arising and falling away. For feeling is threefold and subject to arising and falling away.🔽He regards that as the self. Thus he misapprehends the self as impermanent. And there is the arising of many feelings at one moment.

original: bahūnaṃ vedanānaṃ uppatti atthi. Imamatthaṃ sandhāya – “tasmātihānanda, etenapetaṃ
analyzed: bahūnam vedanānam uppatti atthi imam attham sandhāya tasmā ati ha ānanda etena apetam
translated: But he admits that the self is impermanent. There is no arising of many selves at one moment. With reference to this matter it was said:🔽“Therefore, Ananda, this is not the right way in this case.”🔽. “But, friend, where there is no feeling at all,

original: nakkhamati ‘vedanā me attā’ti samanupassitu”nti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: na khamati vedanā me attā ati samanupassitunti vuttam
translated: would the thought ‘I am’ occur there?”

original: 124. Yattha panāvusoti yattha suddharūpakkhandhe sabbaso vedayitaṃ natthi. Api nu🔽kho tatthāti api nu kho tasmiṃ vedanāvirahite tālavaṇṭe vā vātapāne vā asmīti evaṃ🔽ahaṃkāro uppajjeyyāti attho. Tasmātihānandāti yasmā suddharūpakkhandho uṭṭhāya ahamasmīti
analyzed: yattha pana āvuso ti yattha suddha rūpa kkhandhe sabbasas vedayitam natthi api nu 🔽kho tattha ati api nu kho tasmin vedanā virahite tālavaṇṭe vā vāta pāne vā asmi iti evam 🔽ahaṃkāraḥ uppajjeyya ati attho tasmā ati ha ānanda ati yasmā suddha rūpa kkhandhaḥ uṭṭhāya aham asmi iti
translated: “Therefore, Ananda, this is not the right way in this case.”

original: na vadati, tasmā etenapi etaṃ nakkhamatīti attho. Api nu kho tattha ayamahamasmīti🔽siyāti api nu kho tesu vedanādhammesu tīsu khandhesu ekadhammopi ayaṃ nāma ahamasmīti
analyzed: na vadati tasmai etena api etam na khamati iti attho api nu kho tattha ayam aham asmi iti  siyā ati api nu kho tesu vedanā dhammesu tīsu khandhesu eka dhammaḥ api ayam nāma aham asmi iti
translated: Would it be proper to say:🔽“Herein I am this”?🔽Or would the thought occur to him: “Herein I am this”

original: evaṃ vattabbo siyā. Atha vā vedanānirodhā saheva vedanāya niruddhesu tesu tīsu khandhesu🔽api nu kho ayamahamasmīti vā ahamasmīti vā uppajjeyyāti attho. Athāyasmā ānando sasavisāṇassa
analyzed: evam vattabbo siyā atha vā vedanā nirodhā saha iva vedanāya niruddhesu tesu tīsu khandhesu  api nu kho ayam aham asmi iti vā aham asmi iti vā uppajjeyya atthaḥ atha āyasmai ānandaḥ sasa visāṇassa
translated: when the three aggregates subject to feeling have ceased together with the feeling?🔽Then the venerable Ananda, as if to show that the matter is as clear to him as if it were a tusk in an elephant’s head,

original: tikhiṇabhāvaṃ viya taṃ asampaṭicchanto no hetaṃ bhanteti āha.
analyzed: tikhiṇa bhāvam viya tam a sampaṭicchantaḥ na u ha itam bhanta iti āha
translated: said: “No indeed, venerable sir.”

original: Ettāvatā kiṃ kathitaṃ hoti? Vaṭṭakathā kathitā hoti. Bhagavā hi vaṭṭakathaṃ kathento
analyzed: ettāvatā kim kathitam hoti vaṭṭa kathā kathitā hoti bhagavā hi vaṭṭa katham kathento
translated: What has been said so far? The round of rebirths has been said. For the Blessed One, in expounding the round of rebirths,🔽has expounded it in some places under the heading of ignorance, in some places under the heading of craving, and in some places under the heading of views.

original: katthaci avijjāsīsena kathesi, katthaci taṇhāsīsena, katthaci diṭṭhisīsena. Tattha
analyzed: katthaci avijjā sīsena kathesi katthaci taṇhā sīsena katthaci diṭṭhi sīsena tattha
translated: Herein,

original: “purimā, bhikkhave, koṭi nappaññāyati avijjāya, ‘ito pubbe avijjā nāhosi, atha pacchā
analyzed: purimā bhikkhave koṭi nappaññāyati avijjāya ito pubbe avijjā na ahosi atha pacchā
translated: “Bhikkhus, there is no setting forth of a first point of ignorance … ‘Before this there was no ignorance, afterwards ignorance came to be’—this is not maintained by me.

original: samabhavī’ti. Evañcidaṃ, bhikkhave, vuccati. Atha ca pana paññāyati idappaccayā avijjā”ti
analyzed: samabhavīti evañcidam bhikkhave vuccati atha ca pana paññāyati idappaccayā avijjāti
translated: and so it is said. But it is evident that ignorance has a specific condition.”

original: evaṃ avijjāsīsena kathitā. “Purimā, bhikkhave, koṭi nappaññāyati bhavataṇhāya, ‘ito🔽pubbe bhavataṇhā nāhosi, atha pacchā samabhavī’ti. Evañcidaṃ, bhikkhave, vuccati.
analyzed: evam avijjā sīsena kathitā purimā bhikkhave koṭi na paññāyati bhava taṇhāya itas  pubbe bhava taṇhā na ahosi atha pacchā samabhavi iti evam ca idam bhikkhave vuccati
translated: So it is stated with ignorance as the root. “Bhikkhus, no first point of craving for existence is evident, to the effect that ‘prior to this it did not exist and afterwards it came into being.’ And so it is said.

original: Atha ca pana paññāyati idappaccayā bhavataṇhā”ti evaṃ taṇhāsīsena kathitā. “Purimā,🔽bhikkhave, koṭi nappaññāyati bhavadiṭṭhiyā, ‘ito pubbe bhavadiṭṭhi nāhosi, atha pacchā🔽samabhavī’ti, evañcidaṃ, bhikkhave, vuccati. Atha ca pana paññāyati idappaccayā bhavadiṭṭhī”ti
analyzed: atha ca pana paññāyati idappaccayā bhava taṇhā ti evam taṇhā sīsena kathitā purimā  bhikkhave koṭi na paññāyati bhava diṭṭhiyā ito pubbe bhava diṭṭhi na ahosi atha pacchā  samabhavi iti evañca idam bhikkhave vuccati atha ca pana paññāyati idappaccayā bhava diṭṭhī iti
translated: But it is evident that craving for existence has a specific condition.” So it is stated with craving as the root. “Bhikkhus, no first point of the view of existence is evident, to the effect that ‘prior to this it did not exist and afterwards it came into being.’ And so it is said.

original: evaṃ diṭṭhisīsena kathitā. Idhāpi diṭṭhisīseneva kathitā.
analyzed: evam diṭṭhi sīsena kathitā idha api diṭṭhi sīsena iva kathitā
translated: But it is evident that the view of existence has a specific condition.” So it is stated with the view of existence as the root. Here too it is stated with the view of existence as the root.

original: Diṭṭhigatiko hi sukhādivedanaṃ attāti gahetvā ahaṅkāramamaṅkāraparāmāsavasena sabbabhavayonigati
analyzed: diṭṭhi gatikaḥ hi sukha ādi vedanam attā ati gahetvā ahaṅkāra mamaṅkāra parāmāsa vasena sabba bhava yoni gati
translated: For one who has views about the world, having apprehended the pleasant and painful feelings as self, by the obsessions of I-making, mine-making, and the underlying tendency to conceit, in all the realms of existence, in all the orders of beings, in all kinds of birth,

original: – viññāṇaṭṭhitisattāvāsesu tato tato cavitvā tattha tattha upapajjanto mahāsamudde
analyzed: viññāṇa ṭṭhiti sattā vāsesu tatas tatas cavitvā tattha tattha upapajjantaḥ mahā samudde
translated: He is like a ship on the ocean driven hither and thither by the wind.

original: vātukkhittanāvā viya satataṃ samitaṃ paribbhamati, vaṭṭato sīsaṃ ukkhipituṃyeva na sakkoti.🔽126. Iti bhagavā paccayākāramūḷhassa diṭṭhigatikassa ettakena kathāmaggena vaṭṭaṃ kathetvā idāni vivaṭṭaṃ kathento yato kho pana, ānanda, bhikkhūtiādimāha.
analyzed: vātukkhitta nāvā viya satatam samitam paribbhamati vaṭṭataḥ sīsam ukkhipitum yeva na sakkoti  iti bhagavā paccaya ākāra mūḷhassa diṭṭhi gatikassa ettakena kathāmaggena vaṭṭam kathetvā idāni vivaṭṭam kathentaḥ yatas kho pana ānanda bhikkhu iti ādim āha
translated: He is unable to lift his head from the round of rebirths.🔽Having thus expounded the round of rebirths by this method of exposition, the Exalted One now expounds the cessation of the round of rebirths.🔽The Exalted One expounds the cessation of the round of rebirths in this way because he is skilled in teaching.

original: Tañca pana vivaṭṭakathaṃ bhagavā desanāsu kusalattā vissaṭṭhakammaṭṭhānaṃ navakammādivasena
analyzed: tat ca pana vivaṭṭa katham bhagavā desanāsu kusala ttā vissaṭṭha kammaṭṭhānam nava kamma ādi vasena
translated: He does not refer to a person whose meditation subject is confused or who is distracted by new duties, etc.,

original: vikkhittapuggalaṃ anāmasitvā kārakassa satipaṭṭhānavihārino puggalassa vasena ārabhanto
analyzed: vikkhitta puggalam a nāmasitvā kārakassa sati paṭṭhāna vihārino puggalassa vasena ārabhantaḥ
translated: but to a person who is practicing the foundations of mindfulness and who is the doer of the deed.🔽He says: “He does not consider feeling to be the self” , etc.

original: neva vedanaṃ attānaṃ samanupassatītiādimāha. Evarūpo hi bhikkhu – “yaṃ kiñci rūpaṃ
analyzed: na iva vedanam attānam samanupassati itiādim āha evarūpaḥ hi bhikkhu yam kiñci rūpam
translated: For such a bhikkhu thinks: “Whatever material form there is,

original: atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikaṃ vā sukhumaṃ vā hīnaṃ vā
analyzed: atīta anāgata paccuppannam ajjhattam vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikam vā sukhumam vā hīnam vā
translated: whether past, future, or present, internal or external, gross or subtle, inferior or superior, far or near—he considers nothing among these as self or as belonging to self.

original: paṇītaṃ vā yaṃ dūre vā santike vā, sabbaṃ rūpaṃ aniccato vavatthapeti, ekaṃ sammasanaṃ.
analyzed: paṇītam vā yam dūre vā santike vā sabbam rūpam aniccataḥ vavatthapeti ekam sammasanam
translated: and what is excellent and what is far and what is near, he defines all materiality as impermanent. This is one kind of absorption.

original: Dukkhato vavatthapeti, ekaṃ sammasanaṃ. Anattato vavatthapeti, ekaṃ sammasana”ntiādinā
analyzed: dukkhataḥ vavatthapeti ekam sammasanam anattataḥ vavatthapeti ekam sammasana ntiādinā
translated: He defines it as painful. This is one kind of absorption. He defines it as not self. This is one kind of absorption” .

original: nayena vuttassa sammasanañāṇassa vasena sabbadhammesu pavattattā neva vedanaṃ attāti🔽samanupassati, na aññaṃ, so evaṃ asamanupassanto na kiñci loke upādiyatīti khandhalokādibhede
analyzed: nayena vuttassa sammasana ñāṇassa vasena sabba dhammesu pavatta ttā na iva vedanam attā ti  samanupassati na aññam saḥ evam a samanupassantaḥ na kiñci loke upādiyati iti khandha loka ādi bhede
translated: Because it occurs with the knowledge of absorption stated in this way, he does not see any kind of feeling as self,🔽nor anything apart from feeling as self,🔽thus he does not assume anything in the world.

original: loke rūpādīsu dhammesu kiñci ekadhammampi attāti vā attaniyanti vā na upādiyati.
analyzed: loke rūpa ādīsu dhammesu kiñci eka dhammam pi attāti vā attaniyanti vā na upādiyati
translated: In the world classed as the world of the aggregates, etc., he does not assume any phenomenon whatever as self or as belonging to self.🔽Not assuming, he does not tremble.

original: Anupādiyaṃ na paritassatīti anupādiyanto taṇhādiṭṭhimānaparitassanāyāpi na paritassati.🔽Aparitassanti aparitassamāno. Paccattaṃyeva parinibbāyatīti attanāva kilesaparinibbānena
analyzed: anupādiyam na paritassati iti taṇhā diṭṭhi māna paritassanāya api na paritassati 🔽a paritassanti a paritassamāno paccattam yeva parinibbāyati iti attanā va kilesa parinibbānena
translated: Not trembling, he personally attains nibbāna.

original: parinibbāyati. Evaṃ parinibbutassa panassa paccavekkhaṇāpavattidassanatthaṃ khīṇā jātītiādi vuttaṃ.🔽Iti sā diṭṭhīti yā tathāvimuttassa arahato diṭṭhi, sā evaṃ diṭṭhi. “Itissa diṭṭhī”tipi
analyzed: parinibbāyati evam parinibbutassa panassa paccavekkhaṇa apavatti dassana tham khīṇā jātī itiādi vuttam  iti sā diṭṭhi iti yā tathāvimuttassa arahataḥ diṭṭhi sā evam diṭṭhi iti ssa diṭṭhi iti pi
translated: “He attains nibbana” . But in order to show the reviewing of one who has attained nibbana thus, it is said, “Birth is destroyed” , and so on.🔽“Thus his view”: the view of the Arahant who is thus liberated is such a view. The reading “itissa diṭṭhi” is also allowable. The meaning is: the view of the Arahant who is thus liberated is thus.

original: pāṭho. Yo tathāvimutto arahā, evamassa diṭṭhīti attho. Tadakallanti taṃ na yuttaṃ.🔽Kasmā? Evañhi sati – “arahā na kiñci jānātī”ti vuttaṃ bhaveyya, evaṃ ñatvā vimuttañca
analyzed: yaḥ tathā vimuttaḥ arahā evam assa diṭṭhī iti attho tat akallanti tam na yuttam  kasmai evam hi sati arahā na kiñci jānāti iti vuttam bhaveyya evam ñatvā vimuttam ca
translated: “That is not proper”: that is not right.🔽Why? For if it were so, it would mean that the Arahant knows nothing at all. And it is not proper to say that the Arahant who is liberated by such knowledge knows nothing at all.

original: arahantaṃ “na kiñci jānātī”ti vattuṃ na yuttaṃ. Teneva catunnampi nayānaṃ avasāne
analyzed: arahantam na kiñci jānāti iti vattum na yuttam tena iva catunnam api avasāne
translated: Therefore, at the end of the four methods,

original: – “taṃ kissa hetū”tiādimāha.
analyzed: tam kim sa hetu iti ādim āha
translated: the Exalted One says, “And why is that?”

original: Tattha yāvatā ānanda adhivacananti yattako adhivacanasaṅkhāto vohāro atthi. Yāvatā
analyzed: tattha yāvatā ānanda adhivacanan ti yattakaḥ adhivacana saṅkhātaḥ vohāraḥ atthi yāvatā
translated: Herein, “as far as there are terms, Ananda” : as far as there is a designation, a mode of expression.

original: adhivacanapathoti yattako adhivacanassa patho, khandhā āyatanāni dhātuyo vā atthi.
analyzed: adhivacana patho ti yattakaḥ adhivacanassa patho khandhāḥ āyatanāni dhātuyaḥ vā atthi
translated: “As far as there is a course of terms” : as far as there is a range for terms, for aggregates, bases, and elements.

original: Esa nayo sabbattha. Paññāvacaranti paññāya avacaritabbaṃ khandhapañcakaṃ. Tadabhiññāti
analyzed: esa nayo sabbattha paññāvacaranti paññāya avacaritabbam khandha pañcakam tat abhiñāti
translated: So in all cases. The province of understanding: the five aggregates as objects of clinging, which are the province of understanding. Having directly known that:

original: taṃ abhijānitvā. Ettakena bhagavatā kiṃ dassitaṃ? Tantākulapadasseva anusandhi dassito.
analyzed: tam abhijānitvā ettakena bhagavatā kim dassitam tantā kula padassa iva anusandhi dassitaḥ
translated: having directly known that, what has been shown by the Blessed One in this much? The continuity of the “ball of thread” expression has been shown.

original: Sattaviññāṇaṭṭhitivaṇṇanā
analyzed: satta viññāṇa ṭṭhiti vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the seven stations for consciousness and the four bases for consciousness

original: 127. Idāni yo – “na paññapetī”ti vutto, so yasmā gacchanto gacchanto ubhatobhāgavimutto
analyzed: idāni yaḥ na paññapeti iti vutto so yasmai gacchantaḥ gacchantaḥ ubhatobhāga vimutto
translated: Now, the one who is said not to “define” is called “one liberated in both ways” as he goes on progressing.

original: nāma hoti. Yo ca – “na samanupassatī”ti vutto, so yasmā gacchanto gacchanto paññāvimutto
analyzed: nāma hoti yaḥ ca na samanupassati iti vutto so yasmai gacchantaḥ gacchantaḥ paññā vimutto
translated: And the one who is said not to “contemplate” is called “one liberated by wisdom” as he goes on progressing.

original: nāma hoti. Tasmā tesaṃ heṭṭhā vuttānaṃ dvinnaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ nigamanañca nāmañca dassetuṃ
analyzed: nāma hoti tasmā tesam heṭṭhā vuttānam dvinnam bhikkhūnam nigamanam ca nāmañca dassetuṃ
translated: So in order to show the conclusion and the name of the two bhikkhus mentioned above,

original: satta kho imānanda viññāṇaṭṭhitiyotiādimāha.
analyzed: satta kho imā ānanda viññāṇa ṭṭhitiyaḥ ti ādim āha
translated: the Exalted One said, “Ānanda, there are these seven stations for consciousness and these four bases for consciousness.”

original: Tattha sattāti paṭisandhivasena vuttā, ārammaṇavasena saṅgītisutte vuttā catasso
analyzed: tattha sattā ati paṭisandhi vasena vuttā ārammaṇa vasena saṅgīti sutte vuttā catasso
translated: Herein, seven means that, reckoned by way of rebirth-linking, the four mentioned in the Saṅgīti Sutta as objects of clinging will come.

original: āgamissanti. Viññāṇaṃ tiṭṭhati etthāti viññāṇaṭṭhiti, viññāṇapatiṭṭhānassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ.
analyzed: āgamissanti viññāṇam tiṭṭhati ettha ati viññāṇa ṭhiti viññāṇa patiṭṭhānassa etam adhivacanam
translated: Consciousness stands here, thus it is a station for consciousness; this is a term for a basis for consciousness.

original: Dve ca āyatanānīti dve nivāsaṭṭhānāni. Nivāsaṭṭhānañhi idhāyatananti adhippetaṃ.
analyzed: dve ca āyatanāni iti dve nivāsaṭṭhānāni nivāsaṭṭhānam hi idha āyatananti adhippetam
translated: And two bases : two stations for the rebirth-linking consciousness. For here the word “base” is intended to mean “station” .

original: Teneva vakkhati – “asaññasattāyatanaṃ nevasaññānāsaññāyatanameva dutiya”nti. Kasmā🔽panetaṃ sabbaṃ gahitanti? Vaṭṭapariyādānatthaṃ. Vaṭṭañhi na suddhaviññāṇaṭṭhitivasena
analyzed: tena iva vakkhati asañña satta āyatanam nevasaññānāsaññāyatanam eva dutiyanti kasmā  pana etam sabbam gahitanti vaṭṭa pariyādāna attham vaṭṭan hi na suddha viññāṇa ṭṭhiti vasena
translated: That is why he says, “The base consisting of non-percipient beings and the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception are the second” .

original: suddhāyatanavasena vā pariyādānaṃ gacchati, bhavayonigatisattāvāsavasena pana gacchati,
analyzed: suddha āyatana vasena vā pariyādānam gacchati bhava yoni gati sattā vāsa vasena pana gacchati
translated: But why is all this included? —In order to show the exhaustion of the round. For the round does not come to exhaustion by means of the mere base consisting of the ten immaterial states or by means of the mere pure bases. It comes to exhaustion by means of the kinds of becoming, destinies, and stations of consciousness and by means of the abodes of beings.

original: tasmā sabbametaṃ gahitaṃ.🔽Idāni anukkamena tamatthaṃ vibhajanto katamā sattātiādimāha. Tattha seyyathāpīti
analyzed: tasmā sabbam etam gahitam  idāni anukkamena tam attham vibhajantaḥ katamā sattā ati ādim āha tattha sā iyyathā api iti
translated: That is why all this is included.

original: nidassanatthe nipāto, yathā manussāti attho. Aparimāṇesu hi cakkavāḷesu aparimāṇānaṃ
analyzed: nidassana atthe nipātaḥ yathā manussā iti atthaḥ aparimāṇesu hi cakkavāḷesu aparimāṇānam
translated: Now, in order to analyse the meaning of that in due sequence, he said, “What are the ten immaterial states? ” Herein, the particle seyyathāpi is in the sense of illustration; the meaning is “just as.” For among the immeasurable world-spheres and the immeasurable beings there are none alike in colour, configuration, etc.,

original: manussānaṃ vaṇṇasaṇṭhānādivasena dvepi ekasadisā natthi. Yepi hi katthaci yamakabhātaro
analyzed: manussānam vaṇṇa saṇṭhāna ādi vasena dve pi eka sadisāḥ natthi ye pi hi katthaci yamaka bhātaro
translated: even twins are not alike in all respects. Those who are alike in some respects

original: vaṇṇena vā saṇṭhānena vā ekasadisā honti, tesampi ālokitavilokitakathitahasitagamanaṭhānādīhi
analyzed: vaṇṇena vā saṇṭhānena vā eka sadisāḥ honti tesam pi ālokita vilokita kathita hasita gamana ṭhāna ādīhi
translated: They are called “of different bodies” because their bodies are not alike in colour and shape, and because there is a difference between them in their looking straight ahead or to the side, in their laughing and talking and going and sitting, and so on.

original: viseso hotiyeva. Tasmā nānattakāyāti vuttā. Paṭisandhisaññā pana nesaṃ tihetukāpi🔽dvihetukāpi ahetukāpi honti, tasmā nānattasaññinoti vuttā. Ekacce ca devāti cha kāmāvacaradevā.
analyzed: visesaḥ tasmā nānattakāya ati vuttā paṭisandhi saññā pana nesam ti hetukā api  dvi hetukā api ahetukā api honti tasmā nānatta saññinaḥ ti vuttāḥ ekacce ca devā ti cha kāmāvacara devā
translated: But their rebirth-linking perceptions are of three kinds, namely, due to the fine-material, immaterial, and neither-fine-material-nor-immaterial sphere, and so they are called “of different perceptions.”🔽“Some gods” are the six kinds of sense-sphere gods.

original: Tesu hi kesañci kāyo nīlo hoti, kesañci pītakādivaṇṇo. Saññā pana nesaṃ dvihetukāpi🔽tihetukāpi honti, ahetukā natthi. Ekacce ca vinipātikāti catuapāyavinimuttā uttaramātā
analyzed: tesu hi kesañci kāyaḥ nīlaḥ hoti kesañci pītaka ādi vaṇṇo saññā pana nesam dvi hetukā api  ti hetukā api honti ahetukā natthi ekacce ca vinipātikā ati catu apāya vinimuttā uttara mātā
translated: For some of them the body is blue, some are yellow, and so on. But their perceptions are of two kinds, namely, due to the fine-material sphere and to the immaterial sphere; there are none due to the neither-fine-material-nor-immaterial sphere.

original: yakkhinī, piyaṅkaramātā, phussamittā, dhammaguttāti evamādikā aññe ca vemānikā petā.
analyzed: yakkhinī piyaṅkaramātā phussamittā dhammaguttā ati evamādikā aññe ca vemānikā
translated: “Some beings in the underworld” are the petas called “owners of vimāna,” who are free from the four states of deprivation. They are such as Uttarā’s mother, the ogress Piyaṅkara’s mother, Phussamittā, and Dhammaguttā.

original: Etesañhi pītaodātakāḷamaṅguracchavisāmavaṇṇādivasena ceva kisathūlarassadīghavasena
analyzed: etesam hi ca iva kisa thūla rassa dīgha vasena
translated: For their bodies are different in colour, being blue, yellow, black, red, white, variegated, and so on, and in shape, being short, fat, tall, and thin, and so on,

original: ca kāyo nānā hoti, manussānaṃ viya dvihetukatihetukaahetukavasena saññāpi. Te pana
analyzed: ca kāyaḥ nānā hoti manussānam viya dvi hetuka ti hetuka ahetuka vasena saññā api te pana
translated: and their perceptions are of three kinds, like those of human beings.

original: devā viya na mahesakkhā, kapaṇamanussā viya appesakkhā, dullabhaghāsacchādanā dukkhapīḷitā🔽viharanti. Ekacce kāḷapakkhe dukkhitā juṇhapakkhe sukhitā honti, tasmā sukhasamussayato
analyzed: devāḥ viya na mahesakkhāḥ kapaṇa manussāḥ viya appesakkhāḥ dullabha ghāsa chādanāḥ dukkha pīḷitā  viharanti ekacce kāḷapakkhe dukkhitāḥ juṇhapakkhe sukhitāḥ honti tasmā sukha samussayato
translated: They are not greatly honoured like the gods, but are lowly like poor people. They find it hard to get food and clothing and are oppressed by suffering.🔽Some are miserable in the dark fortnight but happy in the bright fortnight. Therefore they are called “fallen”

original: vinipatitattā vinipātikāti vuttā. Ye panettha tihetukā tesaṃ dhammābhisamayopi hoti,
analyzed: vinipatita ttā vinipātikā ati vuttā ye pana ittha ti hetukā tesam dhamma abhisamayaḥ api hoti
translated: because they have fallen from the opportunity for happiness. But those among them who are of the triple-knowledge class have penetration of the Dhamma too.

original: piyaṅkaramātā hi yakkhinī paccūsasamaye anuruddhattherassa dhammaṃ sajjhāyato sutvā –
analyzed: piyaṅkara mātā hi yakkhinī paccūsa samaye anuruddha therassa dhammam sajjhāyato sutvā
translated: For the female spirit Piyaṅkara’s mother, while the Elder Anuruddha was reciting the Dhamma, heard him and🔽“Do not make a noise, Piyaṅkara,

original: “Mā saddamakari piyaṅkara, bhikkhu dhammapadāni bhāsati;
analyzed: mā saddam akari piyaṅkara bhikkhu dhamma padāni bhāsati
translated: The monk is reciting the Dhamma.🔽If we understand the Dhamma,

original: Api dhammapadaṃ vijāniya, paṭipajjema hitāya no siyā;
analyzed: api dhamma padam vijāniya paṭipajjema hitāya no siyā
translated: We may practice for our good.🔽We will restrain ourselves from harming living beings,

original: Pāṇesu ca saṃyamāmase, sampajānamusā na bhaṇāmase;
analyzed: pāṇesu ca saṃyamāmase sampajāna musā na bhaṇāmase
translated: And we will not tell lies knowingly.🔽We will train ourselves in good conduct,

original: Sikkhema susīlyamattano, api muccema pisācayoniyā”ti. ;
analyzed: sikkhema susīlya mattano api muccema pisāca yoniyā ati
translated: And we may be released from the realm of ghosts.”

original: Evaṃ puttakaṃ saññāpetvā taṃ divasaṃ sotāpattiphalaṃ pattā. Uttaramātā pana bhagavato dhammaṃ sutvāva sotāpannā jātā.
analyzed: evam puttakam saññāpetvā tam divasam sotāpatti phalam pattā uttara mātā pana bhagavataḥ dhammam sutvā va sotāpannā jātā
translated: Having thus instructed her son, she reached the fruit of stream-entry that same day. But Uttara’s mother became a stream-enterer just by hearing the Blessed One’s Dhamma.

original: Brahmakāyikāti brahmapārisajjabrahmapurohitamahābrahmāno. Paṭhamābhinibbattāti te
analyzed: brahmakāyikā ati brahma pārisajja brahmapurohita mahābrahmāno paṭhama abhinibbattā ati te
translated: “Brahma-world beings” are the group-of-six Brahmas, namely, the Parittābhā, Appamāṇābhā, Ābhassarā, Parittasubhā, Appamāṇasubhā, and Vehapphalas .

original: sabbepi paṭhamena jhānena abhinibbattā. Tesu brahmapārisajjā pana parittena abhinibbattā,
analyzed: sabbe api paṭhamena jhānena abhinibbattā tesu brahmapārisajjā pana parittena abhinibbattā
translated: They are all generated by the first jhāna. But the Parittābhā are generated by the lesser first jhāna,🔽and their life span is a third of an aeon. The Appamāṇābhā are generated by the medium first jhāna, and their life span is half an aeon.

original: tesaṃ kappassa tatiyo bhāgo āyuppamāṇaṃ. Brahmapurohitā majjhimena, tesaṃ upaḍḍhakappo
analyzed: tesam kappassa tatiyaḥ bhāgaḥ āyu ppamāṇam brahmapurohitāḥ majjhimena tesam upaḍḍha kappo
translated: The Ābhassarā are generated by the greater first jhāna, and their life span is an aeon.🔽The Parittasubhā are generated by the lesser second jhāna, and their life span is two aeons. The Appamāṇasubhā are generated by the medium second jhāna, and their life span is four aeons.

original: āyuppamāṇaṃ, kāyo ca tesaṃ vipphārikataro hoti. Mahābrahmāno paṇītena, tesaṃ kappo🔽āyuppamāṇaṃ, kāyo pana tesaṃ ativipphāriko hoti. Iti te kāyassa nānattā, paṭhamajjhānavasena
analyzed: āyu ppamāṇam kāyo ca tesam vipphārikataraḥ hoti mahābrahmānaḥ paṇītena tesam kappo  āyu ppamāṇam kāyaḥ pana tesam ati vipphārikaḥ hoti iti te kāyassa nānattā paṭhamajjhāna vasena
translated: The Vehapphalas are generated by the greater second jhāna, and their life span is five hundred aeons.

original: saññāya ekattā nānattakāyā ekattasaññinoti veditabbā.🔽Yathā ca te, evaṃ catūsu apāyesu sattā. Nirayesu hi kesañci gāvutaṃ, kesañci aḍḍhayojanaṃ,
analyzed: saññāyaḥ ekattā nānatta kāyāḥ ekatta saññino ti veditabbā  yathā ca te evam catūsu apāyesu sattāḥ nirayesu hi kesañci gāvutam kesañci aḍḍha yojanam
translated: So they are to be understood as “having different bodies and different perceptions” because of the difference in their bodies and the sameness of their perception owing to the first jhāna.🔽And just as they are, so are the beings in the four lower unhappy destinations.🔽For in the hells some have the size of a centipede, some a snake’s, some a hog’s, some a human’s, and some are even bigger than this.

original: kesañci yojanaṃ attabhāvo hoti, devadattassa pana yojanasatiko jāto. Tiracchānesupi
analyzed: kesañci yojanam atta bhāvaḥ hoti devadattassa pana yojana satikaḥ jātaḥ tiracchānesu pi
translated: And among animals, ghosts, and some gods and human beings too.

original: keci khuddakā, keci mahantā. Pettivisayepi keci saṭṭhihatthā, keci sattatihatthā,
analyzed: keci khuddakā keci mahantā petti visaye pi keci saṭṭhi hatthā keci sattati hatthā
translated: Some are small, some are big. Among the ghosts, too, some are sixty hands high, some are seventy hands high,

original: keci asītihatthā honti, keci suvaṇṇā, keci dubbaṇṇā honti. Tathā kālakañjikā asurā.🔽Api cettha dīghapiṭṭhikapetā nāma saṭṭhiyojanikāpi honti. Saññā pana sabbesampi akusalavipākaahetukāva
analyzed: keci asīti hatthāḥ honti keci suvaṇṇā keci dubbaṇṇāḥ honti tathā kālakañjikāḥ asurā  api ca ittha dīghapiṭṭhika petāḥ nāma saṭṭhi yojanikā api honti saññā pana sabbesam pi akusala vipāka ahetukā va
translated: some are eighty hands high. Some are fair, some are ugly. So too, the Kālakañja asuras.🔽And here the ghosts called Long-Backs are sixty leagues long. But the perception of all is non-causally arisen unprofitable perception only.

original: honti. Iti āpāyikāpi nānattakāyā ekattasaññinotveva saṅkhyaṃ gacchanti.🔽Ābhassarāti daṇḍaukkāya acci viya etesaṃ sarīrato ābhā chijjitvā chijjitvā patantī🔽viya sarati vissaratīti ābhassarā. Tesu pañcakanayena dutiyatatiyajjhānadvayaṃ parittaṃ
analyzed: honti iti āpāyikā api nānatta kāyāḥ ekatta saññinā uta eva saṅkhyam gacchanti  daṇḍaukkāya etesam sarīrataḥ ābhā chijjitvā chijjitvā patantī  sarati vissarati iti ābhassarā tesu pañcaka nayena dutiya tatiya jhāna dvayam parittam
translated: So those in states of loss, though their bodies are various, are still reckoned as “having a single perception.”🔽“They shine”: light shoots forth from their bodies like the flame of a burning grass torch,🔽and it goes forth, it spreads, thus they are “shining” . Among them, those who have been reborn there by developing the second and third jhānas of the fivefold system to a limited extent are called “limited shiners” ;

original: bhāvetvā upapannā parittābhā nāma honti, tesaṃ dve kappā āyuppamāṇaṃ. Majjhimaṃ bhāvetvā
analyzed: bhāvetvā upapannā parittābhāḥ nāma honti tesam dve kappā āyu pamāṇam majjhimam bhāvetvā
translated: their life-span is two eons. Those who have been reborn there by developing them to an extensive extent are called “measureless shiners” ;

original: upapannā appamāṇābhā nāma honti, tesaṃ cattāro kappā āyuppamāṇaṃ. Paṇītaṃ bhāvetvā
analyzed: upapannāḥ appamāṇābhāḥ nāma honti tesam cattāro kappāḥ āyu ppamāṇam paṇītam bhāvetvā
translated: their life-span is four eons. Those who have been reborn there by developing them to the highest extent are called “shiners with superior vision” ;

original: upapannā ābhassarā nāma honti, tesaṃ aṭṭha kappā āyuppamāṇaṃ. Idha pana ukkaṭṭhaparicchedavasena🔽sabbepi te gahitā. Sabbesañhi tesaṃ kāyo ekavipphārova hoti, saññā pana avitakkavicāramattā
analyzed: upapannāḥ ābhassarāḥ nāma honti tesam aṭṭha kappāḥ āyu pamāṇam idha pana ukkaṭṭha pariccheda vasena  sabbe api te gahitā sabbesam hi tesam kāyaḥ eka vipphāraḥ va hoti saññā pana a vitakka vicāra mattā
translated: They are called the Gods of Streaming Radiance. Their life-span is eight eons. But here they are all included under the maximum limit.

original: vā avitakkaavicārā vāti nānā.
analyzed: vā a vitakka a vicārā vāti nānā
translated: For all of them have a single mode of materiality, but their perception is either with thought and applied thought or without thought and only with applied thought.

original: Subhakiṇhāti subhena okiṇṇā vikiṇṇā, subhena sarīrappabhāvaṇṇena ekagghanāti attho.
analyzed: subhakiṇhā ati subhena okiṇṇā vikiṇṇā subhena sarīra pabhā vaṇṇena ekagghanā ati attho
translated: They are called the Gods of Refulgent Glory because they are sprinkled and scattered with beauty, that is to say, with the colour of the radiance of their bodies.

original: Etesañhi ābhassarānaṃ viya na chijjitvā chijjitvā pabhā gacchati. Pañcakanaye pana
analyzed: etesam hi viya na chijjitvā chijjitvā pabhā gacchati pañcaka naye pana
translated: For their radiance does not go forth in separate jets like the radiance of the Streaming Radiance Gods. But in the fivefold system they are called the Gods of Limited Glory, the Gods of Immeasurable Glory, the Gods of Refulgent Glory, the Gods of Glory with Limited Radiance, the Gods of Glory with Immeasurable Radiance, and the Gods of Refulgent Glory.

original: parittamajjhimapaṇītassa catutthajjhānassa vasena soḷasadvattiṃsacatusaṭṭhikappāyukā🔽parittasubhaappamāṇasubhasubhakiṇhā nāma hutvā nibbattanti. Iti sabbepi te ekattakāyā
analyzed: paritta majjhima paṇītassa catuttha jhānassa vasena soḷasa dvattiṃsa catusaṭṭhi kappa āyukā  paritta subha appamāṇa subha subha kiṇhāḥ nāma hutvā nibbattanti iti sabbe pi te ekatta kāyā
translated: They are reborn with a life-span of sixteen, thirty-two, sixty-four eons respectively, according to whether their fourth jhāna is small, medium, or great.

original: ceva catutthajjhānasaññāya ekattasaññino cāti veditabbā. Vehapphalāpi catutthaviññāṇaṭṭhitimeva
analyzed: ca iva catuttha jhāna saññāyaḥ ekatta saññinaḥ ca ati veditabbā vehapphalā api catuttha viññāṇa ṭṭhitim eva
translated: So all of them should be understood as having a single mode of materiality and a single kind of perception, which is that of the fourth jhāna. The Gods of Great Fruit are the fourth plane of beings with a single mode of materiality.

original: bhajanti. Asaññasattā viññāṇābhāvā ettha saṅgahaṃ na gacchanti, sattāvāsesu gacchanti.🔽Suddhāvāsā vivaṭṭapakkhe ṭhitā na sabbakālikā, kappasatasahassampi asaṅkhyeyyampi
analyzed: bhajanti asañña sattāḥ viññāṇa abhāvāḥ ettha saṅgaham na gacchanti sattāvāsesu gacchanti  suddhāvāsā vivaṭṭa pakkhe ṭhitā na sabba kālikā kappa sata sahassam pi asaṅkhyeyyam pi
translated: But the non-percipient beings do not come under this heading because of the absence of consciousness in them. They come under the heading of the abodes of beings.

original: buddhasuññe loke nuppajjanti. Soḷasakappasahassabbhantare buddhesu uppannesuyeva
analyzed: buddha suññe loke nuppajjanti soḷasa kappa sahassa abbhantare buddhesu uppannesu yeva
translated: The Suddhāvāsa Brahmās do not come under this heading because they are not always present. They are not present in the period of world contraction. They are not present in the period of world expansion until a world-creator arises. They are not present in a world devoid of Buddhas for a hundred thousand years and for an incalculable period.

original: uppajjanti, dhammacakkappavattassa bhagavato khandhavāraṭṭhānasadisā honti. Tasmā
analyzed: uppajjanti dhamma cakka ppavattassa bhagavato khandha vāra ṭṭhāna sadisāḥ honti tasmā
translated: They are present only when sixteen thousand world-systems have Buddhas arising in them. They are like the Buddha’s retinue in the Exalted One’s turning of the Wheel of the Dhamma.

original: neva viññāṇaṭṭhitiṃ na sattāvāsaṃ bhajanti. Mahāsīvatthero pana – “na kho pana so🔽sāriputta sattāvāso sulabharūpo yo mayā anivutthapubbo iminā dīghena addhunā aññatra
analyzed: na iva viññāṇa ṭṭhitim na sattāvāsam bhajanti mahāsīva thero pana na kho pana so  sāriputta sattāvāsaḥ sulabha rūpaḥ yaḥ mayā a nivuttha pubbaḥ iminā dīghena addhunā aññatra
translated: Therefore they do not come under the heading of the stations of consciousness or the abodes of beings.

original: suddhāvāsehi devehī”ti iminā suttena suddhāvāsāpi catutthaviññāṇaṭṭhitiṃ catutthasattāvāsaṃyeva
analyzed: suddhāvāsehi devehi iti iminā suttena suddhāvāsā api catuttha viññāṇa ṭṭhitim catuttha sattā vāsam yeva
translated: But the Elder Mahā-Siva says that the Suttas declare that the Suddhāvāsa Brahmās come under the fourth station of consciousness and the fourth abode of beings. He says: “Sāriputta, it is not easy to find a place for beings that has not already been occupied by me in the course of this long journey, except among the Suddhāvāsa gods” .

original: bhajantīti vadati, taṃ appaṭibāhiyattā suttassa anuññātaṃ.
analyzed: bhajanti iti vadati tam appaṭibāhiya ttā suttassa anuññātam
translated: This statement is accepted because it cannot be refuted.

original: Sabbaso rūpasaññānantiādīnaṃ attho visuddhimagge vutto. Nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ pana
analyzed: sabbaso rūpa saññānaṃ ti ādīnam attho visuddhi magge vuttaḥ nevasaññānāsaññāyatanam pana
translated: The meaning of the phrases “perceptions of form” and so on is given in the Path of Purification . The base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception is explained in the following way:

original: yatheva saññāya, evaṃ viññāṇassapi sukhumattā neva viññāṇaṃ nāviññāṇaṃ. Tasmā viññāṇaṭṭhitīsu
analyzed: yathā iva saññāyaḥ evam viññāṇassa api sukhuma ttā na iva viññāṇam na aviññāṇam tasmā viññāṇa ṭhitīsu
translated: The meaning of the passage beginning “With the complete surmounting of perceptions of form” is given in the Path of Purity . But the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception is called neither perception nor non-perception because of the subtlety of the perception and of the consciousness there. Therefore it is not mentioned among the stations of consciousness.

original: avatvā āyatanesu vuttaṃ.
analyzed: a vatvā āyatanesu vuttam
translated: But it is mentioned among the bases.

original: 128. Tatrāti tāsu viññāṇaṭṭhitīsu. Tañca pajānātīti tañca viññāṇaṭṭhitiṃ pajānāti.
analyzed: tatra ati tāsu viññāṇa ṭṭhitīsu tat ca pajānāti iti tat ca viññāṇa ṭṭhitim pajānāti
translated: Therein: among those stations of consciousness. He understands: he understands that station of consciousness.

original: Tassā ca samudayanti “avijjāsamudayā rūpasamudayo”tiādinā nayena tassā samudayañca
analyzed: tassā ca avijjā samudayā rūpa samudayā iti ādinā nayena tassā samudayañca
translated: And its origin: he understands its origin in this way: “With the arising of ignorance there is the arising of form” , and so on.

original: pajānāti. Tassā ca atthaṅgamanti – “avijjānirodhā rūpanirodho”tiādinā nayena tassā🔽atthaṅgamañca pajānāti. Assādanti yaṃ rūpaṃ paṭicca…pe… yaṃ viññāṇaṃ paṭicca uppajjati
analyzed: pajānāti tassā ca atthaṅgamanti avijjā nirodhā rūpa nirodhaḥ iti ādinā nayena tassā  atthaṅgamañca pajānāti assādanti yam rūpam yam viññāṇam paṭicca uppajjati
translated: And its passing away: he understands its passing away in this way: “With the cessation of ignorance there is the cessation of form” , and so on.

original: sukhaṃ somanassaṃ, ayaṃ viññāṇassa assādoti, evaṃ tassā assādañca pajānāti. Ādīnavanti
analyzed: sukham somanassam ayam viññāṇassa assādaḥ ti evam tassāḥ assādam ca pajānāti ādīnavanti
translated: And its satisfaction: he understands its satisfaction in this way: “The pleasure and joy that arise in dependence on form, that is the satisfaction in form” , and so on. And its unsatisfactoriness: he understands its unsatisfactoriness in this way:

original: yaṃ rūpaṃ…pe… yaṃ viññāṇaṃ aniccaṃ dukkhaṃ vipariṇāmadhammaṃ, ayaṃ viññāṇassa ādīnavoti,🔽evaṃ tassā ādīnavañca pajānāti. Nissaraṇanti yo rūpasmiṃ…pe… yo viññāṇe chandarāgavinayo,
analyzed: yam rūpaṃ pe yam viññāṇam aniccam dukkham vipariṇāma dhammam ayam viññāṇassa ādīnavaḥ ti  evam tassaḥ ādīnavam ca pajānāti nissaraṇam ti yaḥ rūpasmiṃpe yaḥ viññāṇe chanda rāga vinayo
translated: “Whatever consciousness there is, whether past, future, or present, internal or external, gross or subtle, inferior or superior, far or near — in short, all consciousness — is impermanent, suffering, and subject to change. This is the danger in consciousness.🔽“The removal and abandonment of desire and lust, the abandonment of desire and lust for material form,🔽the abandonment of desire and lust for feeling, the abandonment of desire and lust for perception, the abandonment of desire and lust for mental formations, the abandonment of desire and lust for consciousness: this is the escape from material form,

original: chandarāgappahānaṃ, idaṃ viññāṇassa nissaraṇanti evaṃ tassā nissaraṇañca pajānāti.
analyzed: chanda rāga ppahānam idam viññāṇassa nissaraṇan ti evam tassāḥ nissaraṇam ca pajānāti
translated: this is the escape from feeling, this is the escape from perception, this is the escape from mental formations, this is the escape from consciousness.

original: Kallaṃ nu tenāti yuttaṃ nu tena bhikkhunā taṃ viññāṇaṭṭhitiṃ taṇhāmānadiṭṭhīnaṃ vasena🔽ahanti vā mamanti vā abhinanditunti. Etenupāyena sabbattha veditabbo. Yattha pana
analyzed: kallam nu tena ati yuttam nu tena bhikkhunā tam viññāṇa ṭṭhitim taṇhā māna diṭṭhīnam vasena  ahanti vā mamanti vā abhinanditunti etena upāyena sabbattha veditabbaḥ yattha pana
translated: “It is proper for that bhikkhu to delight in and to speak in praise of that escape.”🔽In this way, the origin should be applied to the four remaining bases of consciousness.🔽Where there is no material form, there is no origin of the four aggregates.

original: rūpaṃ natthi, tattha catunnaṃ khandhānaṃ vasena, yattha viññāṇaṃ natthi, tattha ekassa🔽khandhassa vasena samudayo yojetabbo. Āhārasamudayā āhāranirodhāti idañcettha padaṃ yojetabbaṃ.
analyzed: rūpam natthi tattha catunnam khandhānam vasena yattha viññāṇam natthi tattha ekassa 🔽khandhassa vasena samudayaḥ yojetabbo āhāra samudayāḥ āhāra nirodhā ti idam ca ittha padam yojetabbam
translated: Where there is no consciousness, there is no origin of the single aggregate.

original: Yato kho, ānanda, bhikkhūti yadā kho ānanda, bhikkhu. Anupādā vimuttoti catūhi upādānehi🔽aggahetvā vimutto. Paññāvimuttoti paññāya vimutto. Aṭṭha vimokkhe asacchikatvā paññābaleneva🔽nāmakāyassa ca rūpakāyassa ca appavattiṃ katvā vimuttoti attho. So sukkhavipassako🔽ca paṭhamajjhānādīsu aññatarasmiṃ ṭhatvā arahattaṃ patto cāti pañcavidho. Vuttampi
analyzed: yatas kho ānanda bhikkhu iti yadā kho ānanda bhikkhu anupādā vimuttaḥ ti catūhi upādānehi  aggahetvā vimutto paññā vimutto ti paññāya vimutto aṭṭha vimokkhe a sacchikatvā paññā balena iva  nāma kāyassa ca rūpa kāyassa ca appavattim katvā vimuttaḥ ti attho so sukkha vipassako  ca paṭhamajjhāna ādīsu aññatarasmin arahattam ca ati pañcavidhaḥ vuttam pi
translated: “When a bhikkhu is liberated by non-clinging” : when a bhikkhu is liberated by not grasping the four kinds of clinging. “Liberated by wisdom” : liberated by wisdom. The meaning is that he is liberated by the power of wisdom without realizing the eight liberations, by causing the non-occurrence of the mental body and the material body. He is a bare-insight worker who has attained arahatship by standing in one of the jhanas beginning with the first. Thus he is of five kinds. It is said:

original: cetaṃ – “katamo ca puggalo paññāvimutto? Idhekacco puggalo na heva kho aṭṭha vimokkhe🔽kāyena phusitvā viharati, paññāya cassa disvā āsavā parikkhīṇā honti, ayaṃ vuccati🔽puggalo paññāvimutto”ti.🔽Aṭṭhavimokkhavaṇṇanā🔽129.
