original: imetiādimāha. Tattha vimokkhoti kenaṭṭhena vimokkho? Adhimuccanaṭṭhena. Ko panāyaṃ
analyzed: imā iti ādim āha tattha vimokkho ti kena aṭṭhena vimokkhaḥ adhimuccana ṭṭhena kaḥ pana ayam
translated: He said this. Herein, as to deliverance: in what sense deliverance? In the sense of resolving .

original: adhimuccanaṭṭho nāma? Paccanīkadhammehi ca suṭṭhu muccanaṭṭho, ārammaṇe ca abhirativasena🔽suṭṭhu muccanaṭṭho, pituaṅke vissaṭṭhaṅgapaccaṅgassa dārakassa sayanaṃ viya aniggahitabhāvena
analyzed: adhimuccana aṭṭhaḥ nāma paccanīka dhammehi ca suṭṭhu muccana aṭṭhaḥ ārammaṇe ca abhirati vasena  suṭṭhu mucca naṭṭho pitu aṅke vissaṭṭhaṅga paccaṅgassa dārakassa sayanam viya a niggahita bhāvena
translated: But what is this resolving? It is the sense of being well delivered from opposing states and of being well delivered by surmounting the object,

original: nirāsaṅkatāya ārammaṇe pavattīti vuttaṃ hoti. Ayaṃ panattho pacchime vimokkhe natthi,
analyzed: nirāsaṅka tāya ārammaṇe pavatti iti vuttam hoti ayam pana attho pacchime vimokkhe natthi
translated: like a child’s lying in its mother’s lap, which is said to be “lying in a place without constraint.” So it is said that it occurs with respect to the object without constraint. But this sense is not in the last deliverance,

original: purimesu sabbesu atthi.🔽Rūpī rūpāni passatīti ettha ajjhattaṃ kesādīsu nīlakasiṇādīsu nīlakasiṇādivasena🔽uppāditaṃ rūpajjhānaṃ rūpaṃ, tadassatthīti rūpī. Bahiddhā rūpāni passatīti bahiddhāpi
analyzed: purimesu sabbesu atthi  rūpī rūpāni passati iti ettha ajjhattam kesa ādīsu nīla kasiṇa ādīsu nīla kasiṇa ādi vasena  uppāditam rūpa jjhānam rūpam tat assa atthi iti rūpī bahiddhā rūpāni passati iti bahiddhā api
translated: but it is in all the others.

original: nīlakasiṇādīni rūpāni jhānacakkhunā passati. Iminā ajjhattabahiddhāvatthukesu kasiṇesu
analyzed: nīla kasiṇa ādīni rūpāni jhāna cakkhunā passati iminā ajjhatta bahiddhā vatthukesu kasiṇesu
translated: As to “possessed of materiality, seeing material shapes”: here the material- ity is the fine-material-sphere jhāna arisen in the eye-door regarding the blue kasiṇa, etc., as blue, and so on. He is “possessed of materiality” because he has that. “Seeing material shapes externally”: he sees material shapes externally too as blue kasiṇa, and so on, with the jhāna eye. By this means he is “possessed of materiality” because he has the kasiṇa as the materiality of the jhāna, and he is “seeing material shapes externally” because he sees the kasiṇa as a material shape externally.

original: uppāditajjhānassa puggalassa cattāri rūpāvacarajjhānāni dassitāni. Ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññīti
analyzed: uppādita jhānassa puggalassa cattāri rūpāvacara jhānāni dassitāni ajjhattam arūpa saññī iti
translated: The four jhānas of the fine-material sphere are shown for the person who has aroused jhāna. With the phrase “not percipient of forms internally”

original: ajjhattaṃ na rūpasaññī, attano kesādīsu anuppāditarūpāvacarajjhānoti attho. Iminā
analyzed: ajjhattam na rūpa saññī attano kesa ādīsu anuppādita rūpāvacara jhāno ti atthaḥ iminā
translated: the meaning is that he is not percipient of forms internally, having aroused no fine-material jhāna in his own continuity. With this

original: bahiddhā parikammaṃ katvā bahiddhāva uppāditajjhānassa puggalassa rūpāvacarajjhānāni dassitāni.
analyzed: bahiddhā parikammam katvā bahiddhā vā uppādita jhānassa puggalassa rūpāvacara jhānāni dassitāni
translated: the jhānas of the fine-material sphere are shown for the person who has aroused jhāna externally, having made external the preliminary work.

original: Subhantveva adhimutto hotīti iminā suvisuddhesu nīlādīsu vaṇṇakasiṇesu jhānāni dassitāni.
analyzed: adhimuttaḥ hoti iti iminā su visuddhesu nīla ādīsu vaṇṇa kasiṇesu jhānāni dassitāni
translated: With the phrase “but with the pervasion of the idea of beauty” the jhānas are shown in the case of the colour kasiṇas such as blue, etc., that are quite purified.

original: Tattha kiñcāpi antoappanāyaṃ subhanti ābhogo natthi, yo pana visuddhaṃ subhaṃ kasiṇamārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: tattha kiñcā api antoappanā ayam subhanti ābhogo natthi yaḥ pana visuddham subham kasiṇam ārammaṇam
translated: Herein, although there is no pervasion of the idea of beauty in the first jhāna, still the jhāna is called “pervaded by the idea of beauty” because it is pervaded by the pervasion of the idea of beauty.🔽And the jhāna in the second, etc., is so called because it is pervaded by the pervasion of the idea of beauty that has arisen in the second, etc., itself.

original: karitvā viharati, so yasmā subhanti adhimutto hotīti vattabbataṃ āpajjati, tasmā
analyzed: karitvā viharati saḥ yasmai adhimutto hoti iti vattabbatam āpajjati tasmai
translated: But in the case of the kasiṇa that is quite purified as beauty, the jhāna is called “pervaded by the idea of beauty” because it is pervaded by the pervasion of the idea of beauty that has arisen in that same kasiṇa.

original: evaṃ desanā katā. Paṭisambhidāmagge pana – “kathaṃ subhantveva adhimutto hotīti vimokkho?
analyzed: evam desanā katā paṭisambhidā magge pana katham adhimuttaḥ hoti iti vimokkhaḥ
translated: So the teaching is given in this way. But in the Paṭisambhidā it is said: “How is it that the liberation of mind by the beautiful comes about through the pervasion of the idea of beauty?

original: Idha bhikkhu mettāsahagatena cetasā ekaṃ disaṃ pharitvā viharati…pe… mettāya bhāvitattā
analyzed: idha bhikkhu mettā sahagatena cetasā ekam disam pharitvā viharati pe mettāya bhāvita ttā
translated: Here a bhikkhu abides pervading one quarter with a mind imbued with loving-kindness, likewise the second, likewise the third, likewise the fourth; so above, below, around, and everywhere, and to all as to himself, he abides pervading the all-encompassing world with a mind imbued with loving-kindness, abundant, exalted, immeasurable, without hostility and without ill will.🔽Because loving-kindness is developed in this way, beings are not repulsive.

original: sattā appaṭikūlā honti. Karuṇā, muditā, upekkhāsahagatena cetasā ekaṃ disaṃ pharitvā
analyzed: sattāḥ a paṭikūlāḥ honti karuṇāḥ muditāḥ upekkhā sahagatena cetasā ekam disam pharitvā
translated: He abides pervading one quarter with a mind imbued with compassion…with a mind imbued with appreciative joy…with a mind imbued with equanimity…🔽Because equanimity is developed in this way, beings are not repulsive. Thus he is intent on what is directly perceived,

original: viharati…pe… upekkhāya bhāvitattā sattā appaṭikūlā honti. Evaṃ subhaṃ tveva adhimutto🔽hotīti vimokkho”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: viharati pe upekkhāya bhāvita ttā sattāḥ a paṭikūlāḥ honti evam subham tu eva adhimuttaḥ  hoti iti vimokkhaḥ ti vuttam
translated: on what is present, on the here and now. This is called liberation by the beautiful.

original: Sabbaso rūpasaññānantiādīsu yaṃ vattabbaṃ, taṃ sabbaṃ visuddhimagge vuttameva. Ayaṃ
analyzed: sabbasas rūpa saññānaṃ ti ādīsu yam vattabbam tat sabbam visuddhi magge vuttam eva ayam
translated: As regards the passage beginning “With the complete surmounting of perceptions of form,” etc., all that should be understood as already explained in the Description of the Meditations .

original: aṭṭhamo vimokkhoti ayaṃ catunnaṃ khandhānaṃ sabbaso visuddhattā vimuttattā aṭṭhamo🔽uttamo vimokkho nāma.🔽130. Anulomanti ādito paṭṭhāya yāva pariyosānā. Paṭilomanti pariyosānato paṭṭhāya
analyzed: aṭṭhamaḥ vimokkho ti ayam catunnam khandhānam sabbasas visuddha ttā vimutta ttā aṭṭhamaḥ  uttamaḥ vimokkhaḥ nāma  anulomanti āditaḥ paṭṭhāya yāva pariyosānā paṭilomanti pariyosānataḥ paṭṭhāya
translated: This is the eighth liberation. This is called the eighth liberation because of the complete purification and cleansing of the four immaterial aggregates.🔽In the order of succession: in the order of succession from the beginning to the end.🔽In the reverse order: in the reverse order from the end to the beginning.

original: yāva ādito. Anulomapaṭilomanti idaṃ atipaguṇattā samāpattīnaṃ aṭṭhatvāva ito cito
analyzed: āditas anuloma paṭilomanti idam samāpattīnam itas ca itas
translated: In the order of succession and in the reverse order: without omitting any of the attainments, and without skipping any,

original: ca sañcaraṇavasena vuttaṃ. Yatthicchakanti okāsaparidīpanaṃ, yattha yattha okāse🔽icchati. Yadicchakanti samāpattidīpanaṃ, yaṃ yaṃ samāpattiṃ icchati. Yāvaticchakanti
analyzed: ca sañcaraṇa vasena vuttam okāsa paridīpanam yattha yattha okāse  icchati yadi śakanti samāpatti dīpanam yam yam samāpattim icchati yāvati śakanti
translated: and it is said in terms of the succession of the jhānas. ‘Whenever he wishes’: this shows the place.🔽Wherever he wishes.🔽‘In whatever way he wishes’: this shows the attainment. In whatever way he wishes.🔽‘For as long as he wishes’: this shows the duration. For as long as he wishes.

original: addhānaparicchedadīpanaṃ, yāvatakaṃ addhānaṃ icchati. Samāpajjatīti taṃ taṃ samāpattiṃ
analyzed: addhāna pariccheda dīpanam yāvatakam addhānam icchati samāpajjati iti tam tam samāpattim
translated: ‘He attains’: he enters upon.

original: pavisati. Vuṭṭhātīti tato uṭṭhāya tiṭṭhati.
analyzed: pavisati vuṭṭhāti iti tatas uṭṭhāya tiṭṭhati
translated: ‘He emerges’: having risen from it, he remains.

original: Ubhatobhāgavimuttoti dvīhi bhāgehi vimutto, arūpasamāpattiyā rūpakāyato vimutto, maggena nāmakāyato vimuttoti. Vuttampi cetaṃ –
analyzed: ubhatobhāga vimuttaḥ ti dvīhi bhāgehi vimuttaḥ arūpa samāpattiyā rūpa kāyataḥ vimuttaḥ maggena nāma kāyataḥ vimuttaḥ iti vuttam pi ca itam
translated: ‘Both-ways liberated’: liberated by both ways. He is liberated from the form-body by the immaterial jhāna, and he is liberated from the mental body by the path. And this is said:

original: “Accī yathā vātavegena khittā, (upasivāti bhagavā)
analyzed: accī yathā vāta vegena khittā bhagavā
translated: ‘As a flame tossed by gusts of wind

original: Atthaṃ paleti na upeti saṅkhaṃ;
analyzed: attham paleti naḥ upeti saṅkham
translated: Goes out and cannot be defined,

original: Evaṃ munī nāmakāyā vimutto,
analyzed: evam muniḥ nāma kāyāḥ vimuttaḥ
translated: So the sage liberated from both sides

original: Atthaṃ paleti na upeti saṅkha”nti. ;
analyzed: attham paleti naḥ upeti
translated: Goes out and cannot be defined.’

original: So panesa ubhatobhāgavimutto ākāsānañcāyatanādīsu aññatarato uṭṭhāya arahattaṃ patto
analyzed: so pana isaḥ ubhatobhāga vimuttaḥ ākāsa anañcāyatana ādīsu aññataratas uṭṭhāya arahattam patto
translated: And this both-ways liberated one, having risen from one of the immaterial jhānas, attains Arahantship.

original: ca anāgāmī hutvā nirodhā uṭṭhāya arahattaṃ patto cāti pañcavidho. Keci pana – “yasmā
analyzed: ca anāgāmī hutvā nirodhā uṭṭhāya arahattam patto ca ati pañcavidhaḥ keci pana yasmā
translated: and the fifth is one who attains it as a non-returner and then reaches Arahantship by emerging from cessation.

original: rūpāvacaracatutthajjhānampi duvaṅgikaṃ upekkhāsahagataṃ, arūpāvacarajjhānampi tādisameva.
analyzed: rūpāvacara catuttha jhānam pi duvaṅgikam upekkhā sahagatam arūpāvacara jhānam pi tādisam eva
translated: But some say that since the fourth jhāna of the fine-material sphere is also of two factors, namely, equanimity and unification of mind, and so is the immaterial jhāna,

original: Tasmā rūpāvacaracatutthajjhānato uṭṭhāya arahattaṃ pattopi ubhatobhāgavimutto”ti.
analyzed: tasmā rūpāvacara catuttha jjhānataḥ uṭṭhāya arahattam pattaḥ api ubhatobhāga vimuttaḥ ti
translated: therefore one who reaches Arahantship after emerging from the fourth jhāna of the fine-material sphere is also one “liberated in both ways.”🔽But this question of “liberated in both ways” arose long ago in the Copper Palace at the beginning of the dispensation.

original: Ayaṃ pana ubhatobhāgavimuttapañho heṭṭhā lohapāsāde samuṭṭhahitvā tipiṭakacūḷasumanattherassa🔽vaṇṇanaṃ nissāya cirena vinicchayaṃ patto. Girivihāre kira therassa antevāsiko ekassa🔽piṇḍapātikassa mukhato taṃ pañhaṃ sutvā āha – “āvuso, heṭṭhālohapāsāde amhākaṃ ācariyassa
analyzed: ayam pana ubhatobhāga vimutta pañhaḥ heṭṭhā loha pāsāde samuṭṭhahitvā tipiṭakacūḷasumana therassa  vaṇṇanam nissāya cirena vinicchayam pattaḥ giri vihāre kira therassa antevāsikaḥ ekassa  piṇḍapātikassa mukhataḥ tam pañham sutvā āha āvuso heṭṭhā loha pāsāde amhākam ācariyassa
translated: It was settled by the Elder Tipiṭaka Cūḷa Sumana, it seems.🔽A pupil of the elder, it seems, who was a bowl-food-eater, heard this question from the elder’s mouth and said, “Friend, this question has never been heard before by me when my teacher was expounding the Dhamma in the Copper Palace below.”

original: dhammaṃ vaṇṇayato na kenaci sutapubba”nti. Kiṃ pana, bhante, thero avacāti? Rūpāvacaracatutthajjhānaṃ
analyzed: dhammam vaṇṇayataḥ na kenacid suta pubban ti kim pana bhante theraḥ avacāti rūpāvacara catuttha jhānam
translated: “But, venerable sir, what does the elder say?”🔽“The fourth jhāna of the fine-material sphere is of two factors, namely, equanimity and unification of mind,

original: kiñcāpi duvaṅgikaṃ upekkhāsahagataṃ kilese vikkhambheti, kilesānaṃ pana āsannapakkhe
analyzed: kiñca api duvaṅgikam upekkhā sahagatam kilese vikkhambheti kilesānam pana āsannapakkhe
translated: Although the jhāna has two factors, it suppresses defilements by being associated with equanimity.🔽But it occurs in a place near to the arising of defilements.

original: virūhanaṭṭhāne samudācarati. Ime hi kilesā nāma pañcavokārabhave nīlādīsu aññataraṃ
analyzed: virūhana ṭṭhāne samudācarati ime hi kilesāḥ nāma pañca vokāra bhave nīla ādīsu aññataram
translated: For these defilements occur with some object among the five kinds of objects, blue and so on,

original: ārammaṇaṃ upanissāya samudācaranti, rūpāvacarajjhānañca taṃ ārammaṇaṃ na samatikkamati.
analyzed: ārammaṇam upanissāya samudācaranti rūpāvacara jhānam ca tam ārammaṇam na samatikkamati
translated: and the jhāna does not surmount that object.

original: Tasmā sabbaso rūpaṃ nivattetvā arūpajjhānavasena kilese vikkhambhetvā arahattaṃ pattova
analyzed: tasmā sabbaso rūpam nivattetvā arūpa jhāna vasena kilese vikkhambhetvā arahattam patto va
translated: So it is only when he has sur­mounted all material things and has reached the immaterial jhāna that he can suppress the defilements and reach Arahantship.

original: ubhatobhāgavimuttoti, idaṃ āvuso thero avaca. Idañca pana vatvā idaṃ suttaṃ āhari🔽– “katamo ca puggalo ubhatobhāgavimutto. Idhekacco puggalo aṭṭhavimokkhe kāyena phusitvā
analyzed: ubhatobhāga vimuttaḥ ti idam āvuso theraḥ avaca idam ca pana vatvā idam suttam āhari  katamaḥ ca puggalo ubhatobhāga vimuttaḥ idha ekaccaḥ puggalo aṭṭha vimokkhe kāyena phusitvā
translated: That is why the elder said this. And after saying this he quoted this sutta:

original: viharati, paññāya cassa disvā āsavā parikkhīṇā honti, ayaṃ vuccati puggalo ubhatobhāgavimutto”ti.
analyzed: viharati paññāya cassa disvā āsavā parikkhīṇāḥ honti ayam vuccati puggalo ubhatobhāga vimutto ti
translated: “What kind of person is liberated in both ways? Here a person attains the eight liberations by body and, by seeing with wisdom, his cankers are destroyed. This kind of person is called liberated in both ways” .

original: Imāya ca ānanda ubhatobhāgavimuttiyāti ānanda ito ubhatobhāgavimuttito. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānamevāti.
analyzed: imāya ca ānanda ubhatobhāga vimuttiyā ati ānanda itas ubhatobhāga vimuttitaḥ sesam sabbattha uttānam eva ati
translated: And by this, Ananda, as to the emancipation of both kinds: by this, Ananda, as to the emancipation of both kinds. The rest is all clear.

original: Iti sumaṅgalavilāsiniyā dīghanikāyaṭṭhakathāyaṃ🔽Mahānidānasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: iti sumaṅgalavilāsiniyā dīgha nikāya ṭṭhakathā ayam  mahānidāna sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: Thus in the Sumangalavilāsini, the Commentary on the Long Division,🔽the description of the Great Discourse on the Roots of Controversy is completed.

original: 3. Mahāparinibbānasuttavaṇṇanā🔽131. Evaṃ me sutanti mahāparinibbānasuttaṃ. Tatrāyamanupubbapadavaṇṇanā – gijjhakūṭeti
analyzed: mahāparinibbāna sutta vaṇṇanā  evam me sutam ti mahāparinibbāna suttam tatra ayam anupubba pada vaṇṇanā gijjhakūṭa iti
translated: THE GREATEST OF THE GREAT

original: gijjhā tassa kūṭesu vasiṃsu, gijjhasadisaṃ vā tassa kūṭaṃ atthīti gijjhakūṭo, tasmiṃ🔽gijjhakūṭe. Abhiyātukāmoti abhibhavanatthāya yātukāmo. Vajjīti vajjirājāno. Evaṃmahiddhiketi
analyzed: gijjhā tassa kūṭesu vasiṃsu gijjha sadisam vā tassa kūṭam atthi iti gijjha kūṭaḥ tasmin  gijjhakūṭe abhiyātu kāmo ti abhibhavana tthāya yātu kāmaḥ vajjī iti vajji rājānaḥ evaṃmahiddhikā iti
translated: Thus have I heard. This is the Great Discourse on the Final Nibbana. Herein, the word by word commentary is this: On the Vulture Peak: the vultures dwelt on its peaks, or its peaks were like vultures, thus it was the Vulture Peak.

original: evaṃ mahatiyā rājiddhiyā samannāgate, etena nesaṃ samaggabhāvaṃ kathesi. Evaṃmahānubhāveti
analyzed: evam mahatiyā rājiddhiyā samannāgate etena na īsam samagga bhāvam kathesi evaṃmahā anubhāva iti
translated: He was desirous of going to overwhelm: he was desirous of going to overcome. The Vajjis: the Vajji kings. Thus possessed of great majesty: thus possessed of great royal majesty. By this he tells of their unity. Thus possessed of great influence:

original: evaṃ mahantena ānubhāvena samannāgate, etena nesaṃ hatthisippādīsu katasikkhataṃ
analyzed: evam mahantena ānubhāvena samannāgate etena nesam hatthi sippa ādīsu kata sikkha tam
translated: thus possessed of great influence. By this he tells of their skill in elephant craft, etc.

original: kathesi, yaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ – “sikkhitā vatime licchavikumārakā, susikkhitā vatime
analyzed: kathesi yam sandhāya vuttam sikkhitāḥ vatime licchavi kumārakā susikkhitāḥ vatime
translated: and it was in reference to this that it was said: “These Licchavi boys are trained, they are well trained,

original: licchavikumārakā, yatra hi nāma sukhumena tāḷacchiggalena asanaṃ atipātayissanti
analyzed: licchavi kumārakāḥ yatra hi nāma su khumena tāḷa chiggalena asanam atipātayissanti
translated: in that they will throw their seats with a fine-bladed spear without missing.”

original: poṅkhānupoṅkhaṃ avirādhita”nti. Ucchecchāmīti ucchindissāmi. Vināsessāmīti nāsessāmi,
analyzed: poṅkha anupoṅkham a virādhitanti ucchā icchāmi iti ucchindissāmi vināsessāmi iti nāsessāmi
translated: I will cut them off: I will cut them off. I will destroy them: I will destroy them.

original: adassanaṃ pāpessāmi. Anayabyasananti ettha na ayoti anayo, avaḍḍhiyā etaṃ nāmaṃ.
analyzed: a dassanam pāpessāmi anaya byasanam ti ettha na ayaḥ a vaḍḍhiyā etam nāmam
translated: I will bring it about that they will not be seen. Misery and disaster: here, not a is misery, a synonym for non-increase.

original: Hitañca sukhañca viyassati vikkhipatīti byasanaṃ, ñātipārijuññādīnaṃ etaṃ nāmaṃ.
analyzed: hitam ca sukham ca viyassati vikkhipati iti byasanam ñāti pārijuñña ādīnam etam nāmam
translated: And disaster is the scattering and separation of what is beneficial and pleasurable, a synonym for the loss of relatives, property, and so on.

original: Āpādessāmīti pāpayissāmi.
analyzed: āpādessāmi iti pāpayissāmi
translated: I will bring it about: I will bring it about.

original: Iti kira so ṭhānanisajjādīsu imaṃ yuddhakathameva katheti, gamanasajjā hothāti evaṃ
analyzed: iti kira saḥ imam yuddha katham eva kathā iti gamana sajjāḥ hotha ati evam
translated: So it seems that he is making this speech about war in regard to standing, sitting, and so on. He is ordering the army, saying: “Be ready to go.”

original: balakāyaṃ āṇāpeti. Kasmā? Gaṅgāyaṃ kira ekaṃ paṭṭanagāmaṃ nissāya aḍḍhayojanaṃ ajātasattuno
analyzed: balakāyam kasmai ekam paṭṭana gāmam nissāya aḍḍha yojanam ajātasattuno
translated: Why? It seems that on the Ganges there is a port town, and the territory extending one-and-a-half leagues from it is under the control of Ajatasattu,

original: āṇā, aḍḍhayojanaṃ licchavīnaṃ. Ettha pana āṇāpavattiṭṭhānaṃ hotīti attho. Tatrāpi
analyzed: āṇā aḍḍha yojanam licchavīnam ettha pana āṇā pavatti ṭhānam hoti iti tatra api
translated: and the territory extending one-and-a-half leagues is under the control of the Licchavis. The meaning is that this is the place where the control of the two kings meets. There,

original: ca pabbatapādato mahagghabhaṇḍaṃ otarati. Taṃ sutvā – “ajja yāmi, sve yāmī”ti ajātasattuno
analyzed: ca pabbata pādataḥ mahagghabhaṇḍam otarati tam sutvā ajja yāmi sve yāmi iti ajātasattuno
translated: and precious goods were brought down from the mountain. The Licchavi princes heard this and made an agreement with Ajatasattu, saying, “We will go today, we will go tomorrow.”

original: saṃvidahantasseva licchavirājāno samaggā sammodamānā puretaraṃ gantvā sabbaṃ gaṇhanti.
analyzed: saṃvidahantassa iva licchavi rājāno samaggā sammodamānā puretaram gantvā sabbam gaṇhanti
translated: But before they could go, the Licchavi princes, united and in harmony, went first and took all the goods.

original: Ajātasattu pacchā āgantvā taṃ pavattiṃ ñatvā kujjhitvā gacchati. Te punasaṃvaccharepi
analyzed: ajātasattu pacchā āgantvā tam pavattim ñatvā kujjhitvā gacchati te
translated: Ajatasattu came later and, learning what had happened, went away in a rage.🔽The Licchavi princes did the same thing again the next year.

original: tatheva karonti. Atha so balavāghātajāto tadā evamakāsi.
analyzed: tathā iva karonti atha saḥ tadā
translated: Then Ajatasattu, his anger growing stronger, did as follows.

original: Tato cintesi – “gaṇena saddhiṃ yuddhaṃ nāma bhāriyaṃ, ekopi moghappahāro nāma natthi,🔽ekena kho pana paṇḍitena saddhiṃ mantetvā karonto nipparādho hoti, paṇḍito ca satthārā
analyzed: tatas cintesi gaṇena saddhim yuddham nāma bhāriyam ekaḥ api moghappahāraḥ nāma natthi  ekena kho pana paṇḍitena saddhim mantetvā karontaḥ nipparādhaḥ hoti paṇḍitaḥ ca satthārā
translated: He thought to himself, “To wage war with a multitude is a serious matter. There is no such thing as a blow struck in vain.🔽But if one consults with a wise man before acting, one is not at fault. And there is no one so wise as the Teacher.

original: sadiso natthi, satthā ca avidūre dhuravihāre vasati, handāhaṃ pesetvā pucchāmi. Sace
analyzed: sadisaḥ natthi satthā ca avidūre dhuravihāre vasati handa aham pesetvā pucchāmi sace
translated: And the Teacher lives in the monastery not far away. Let me send for him and ask him what I should do.

original: me gatena koci attho bhavissati, satthā tuṇhī bhavissati, anatthe pana sati kiṃ rañño
analyzed: me gatena koci atthaḥ bhavissati satthā tuṇhī bhavissati anatthe pana sati kim rañño
translated: If he remains silent, it means that he has some purpose in view. If he does not, what does it matter to me what he says?

original: tattha gamanenāti vakkhatī”ti. So vassakārabrāhmaṇaṃ pesesi. Brāhmaṇo gantvā bhagavato
analyzed: tattha gamanena ati vakkhati iti so vassakāra brāhmaṇam pesesi brāhmaṇaḥ gantvā bhagavataḥ
translated: He rose from his seat, and after paying homage to the Blessed One, keeping him on his right, he departed.🔽The brahmin Vassakara then went to King Ajatasattu of Magadha, son of the Videhi queen, and told him: ‘Sire, King Ajatasattu of Magadha, son of the Videhi queen, is paying homage with his head at the Blessed One’s feet and is asking the Blessed One to visit him at his earliest convenience, saying: “It would be good if the Blessed One would honour my realm with his presence, out of compassion for me.” The Blessed One has consented.’

original: etamatthaṃ ārocesi. Tena vuttaṃ – “atha kho rājā…pe… āpādessāmī”ti.
analyzed: etam attham ārocesi tena vuttam atha kho rājāpe āpādessāmi iti
translated: Translation: tattha gamanenā”ti. So vassakārabrāhmaṇaṃ pesesi. Brāhmaṇo gantvā bhagavato etamatthaṃ ārocesi. Tena vuttaṃ – “atha kho rājā …pe… āpādessāmī”ti.

original: Rājaaparihāniyadhammavaṇṇanā🔽134. Bhagavantaṃ bījayamānoti thero vattasīse ṭhatvā bhagavantaṃ bījati, bhagavato🔽pana sītaṃ vā uṇhaṃ vā natthi. Bhagavā brāhmaṇassa vacanaṃ sutvā tena saddhiṃ amantetvā
analyzed: rāja aparihāniya dhamma vaṇṇanā  bhagavantam bījayamānaḥ iti theraḥ vatta sīse ṭhatvā bhagavantam bījati  pana sītam vā uṇham vā na atthi bhagavā brāhmaṇassa vacanam sutvā tena saddhim a mantetvā
translated: Rājaaparihāniyadhammavaṇṇanā

original: therena saddhiṃ mantetukāmo kinti te, ānanda, sutantiādimāha. Abhiṇhaṃ sannipātāti
analyzed: therena saddhim mantetu kāmaḥ kinti te ānanda sutanti ādim āha abhiṇham sannipāta iti
translated: Bhagavantaṃ bījayamānoti thero vattasīse ṭhatvā bhagavantaṃ bījati, bhagavato pana sītaṃ vā uṇhaṃ vā natthi. Bhagavā brāhmaṇassa vacanaṃ sutvā tena saddhiṃ amantetvā therena saddhiṃ mantetukāmo “kiṃ te ānanda suta”ntiādimāha | Abhiṇhaṃ sannipātāti

original: divasassa tikkhattuṃ sannipatantāpi antarantarā sannipatantāpi abhiṇhaṃ sannipātāva.🔽Sannipātabahulāti hiyyopi sannipatimhā, purimadivasampi sannipatimhā, puna ajja kimatthaṃ🔽sannipatitā homāti vosānaṃ anāpajjantā sannipātabahulā nāma honti. Yāvakīvañcāti
analyzed: divasassa tikkhattum sannipatantā api antar antarā sannipatantā api abhiṇham sannipātāva 🔽sannipāta bahulā ati hiyyo pi sannipatimhā purima divasam pi sannipatimhā puna ajja kimattham 🔽sannipatitāḥ vosānam an āpajjantā sannipāta bahulāḥ nāma honti yāvakī vañca ati
translated: divasassa tikkhattuṃ sannipatantāpi antarantarā sannipatantā

original: yattakaṃ kālaṃ. Vuddhiyeva, ānanda, vajjīnaṃ pāṭikaṅkhā, no parihānīti – abhiṇhaṃ🔽asannipatantā hi disāvidisāsu āgataṃ sāsanaṃ na suṇanti, tato – “asukagāmasīmā vā
analyzed: yattakam kālam ānanda pāṭikaṅkhā no parihāni iti  a sannipatantāḥ hi disā vidisāsu āgatam sāsanam na suṇanti tatas asuka gāma sīmāḥ vā
translated: For as long as the Vajjians hold regular and frequent assemblies, growth, Ānanda, is to be expected among them, not decline.

original: nigamasīmā vā ākulā, asukaṭṭhāne corā vā pariyuṭṭhitā”ti na jānanti, corāpi “pamattā
analyzed: nigama sīmā vā ākulā asuka ṭṭhāne corāḥ vā pariyuṭṭhitā ati na jānanti corāḥ api pamattā
translated: For when they do not assemble often, they do not hear the Dhamma and Discipline expounded, and they do not know what the rules are and what not. Then thieves and robbers become active, and people flee from the countryside to the towns, and from the towns to the fortified cities, and from the fortified cities they take to the waterways.

original: rājāno”ti ñatvā gāmanigamādīni paharantā janapadaṃ nāsenti. Evaṃ rājūnaṃ parihāni🔽hoti. Abhiṇhaṃ sannipatantā pana taṃ taṃ pavattiṃ suṇanti, tato balaṃ pesetvā amittamaddanaṃ
analyzed: rājānā iti ñatvā gāma nigama ādīni paharantā janapadam evam  hoti abhiṇham sannipatantā pana tam tam pavattim suṇanti tatas balam pesetvā amitta maddanam
translated: Thus there is decline among the kings.

original: karonti, corāpi – “appamattā rājāno, na sakkā amhehi vaggabandhehi vicaritu”nti bhijjitvā🔽palāyanti. Evaṃ rājūnaṃ vuddhi hoti. Tena vuttaṃ – “vuddhiyeva, ānanda, vajjīnaṃ
analyzed: karonti corāḥ api appamattāḥ rājānaḥ na sakkā amhehi vagga bandhehi vicaritunti bhijjitvā  palāyanti evam rājūnam vuddhi hoti tena vuttam  vuddhiyā iva ānanda vajjīnam
translated: But when they assemble often, they hear the Dhamma and Discipline expounded, and they know what the rules are and what not. Then they send out armies and crush their enemies, and thieves and robbers are suppressed. Thus there is growth among the kings.🔽That is why it was said: ‘For as long as the Vajjians hold regular and frequent assemblies, growth, Ānanda, is to be expected among them, not decline.’

original: pāṭikaṅkhā no parihānī”ti. Tattha pāṭikaṅkhāti icchitabbā, avassaṃ bhavissatīti evaṃ daṭṭhabbāti attho.
analyzed: pāṭikaṅkhā no parihāni iti tattha pāṭikaṅkhā ati icchitabbā avassam bhavissati iti evam daṭṭhabbā ati attho
translated: Herein, expected means desired, to be looked for, to be reckoned with. This is the meaning.

original: Samaggātiādīsu sannipātabheriyā niggatāya – “ajja me kiccaṃ atthi, maṅgalaṃ atthī”ti
analyzed: samaggā ati ādīsu sannipāta bheriyā niggatāya ajja me kiccam atthi maṅgalam atthi iti
translated: As regards “united” and so on, when the drum is beaten for the assembly, those who make an excuse, thinking “Today I have some business or other, there is a festival,”

original: vikkhepaṃ karontā na samaggā sannipatanti nāma. Bherisaddaṃ pana sutvāva bhuñjantāpi
analyzed: vikkhepam karontā na samaggā sannipatanti nāma bheri saddam pana sutvā ava bhuñjantā api
translated: and do not go to the assembly are not “united in coming together.” But those who go to the assembly even while eating,

original: alaṅkariyamānāpi vatthāni nivāsentāpi aḍḍhabhuttā vā aḍḍhālaṅkatā vā vatthaṃ nivāsayamānā🔽vā sannipatantā samaggā sannipatanti nāma. Sannipatitā pana cintetvā mantetvā kattabbaṃ
analyzed: alaṅkariyamānā api vatthāni nivāsentā api aḍḍha bhuttā vā aḍḍha alaṅkatā vā vattham nivāsayamānā  vā sannipatantā samaggā sannipatanti nāma sannipatitā pana cintetvā mantetvā kattabbam
translated: or while adorning themselves, or while putting on their robes, and who go to the assembly even though they have eaten a lot, or are half-dressed, or have not put on their robes, are “united in coming together.”

original: katvā ekatova avuṭṭhahantā na samaggā vuṭṭhahanti nāma. Evaṃ vuṭṭhitesu hi ye paṭhamaṃ
analyzed: katvā ekatas iva a vuṭṭhahantā na samaggāḥ vuṭṭhahanti nāma evam vuṭṭhitesu hi ye paṭhamam
translated: But those who go to the assembly after thinking, deliberating, and doing what should be done, and who do not leave the assembly together, are not “united in leaving.”

original: gacchanti, tesaṃ evaṃ hoti – “amhehi bāhirakathāva sutā, idāni vinicchayakathā bhavissatī”ti.
analyzed: gacchanti tesam evam hoti amhehi sutā idāni vinicchaya kathā bhavissati iti
translated: For when they leave in this way, those who go first think, “We have heard only the outside talk; now there will be a discussion of the case.”

original: Ekato vuṭṭhahantā pana samaggā vuṭṭhahanti nāma. Apica – “asukaṭṭhānesu gāmasīmā
analyzed: ekatas vuṭṭhahantā pana samaggāḥ vuṭṭhahanti nāma apica  asuka ṭṭhānesu gāma sīmā
translated: But those who leave together are “united in leaving.”

original: vā nigamasīmā vā ākulā, corā pariyuṭṭhitā”ti sutvā – “ko gantvā imaṃ amittamaddanaṃ
analyzed: vā nigama sīmā vā ākulā corā pariyuṭṭhitā ati sutvā kaḥ gantvā imam amitta maddanam
translated: Moreover, when they hear that in such-and-such a place the village boundary or the town boundary is crowded, or that thieves are plundering, and they think, “Who will go and kill this enemy of ours?

original: karissatī”ti vutte – “ahaṃ paṭhamaṃ, ahaṃ paṭhama”nti vatvā gacchantāpi samaggā vuṭṭhahanti
analyzed: karissati iti vutte aham paṭhamam aham paṭhamam iti vatvā gacchantā api samaggā vuṭṭhahanti
translated: When it is said, “He will do it,” they go, saying, “I will do it first, I will do it first,” and they emerge united.

original: nāma. Ekassa pana kammante osīdamāne sesā rājāno puttabhātaro pesetvā tassa kammantaṃ
analyzed: nāma ekassa pana kammante osīdamāne sesāḥ rājāno putta bhātaro pesetvā tassa kammantaṃ
translated: But when the work of one of them is failing, the other kings, his sons and brothers, send him help,

original: upatthambhayamānāpi, āgantukarājānaṃ – “asukassa gehaṃ gacchatu, asukassa gehaṃ gacchatū”ti
analyzed: upatthambhayamānā api āgantuka rājānam asukassa geham gacchatu asukassa geham gacchatu uti
translated: and they emerge united when they do not send the newly arrived king to such and such a house, to such and such a house,

original: avatvā sabbe ekato saṅgaṇhantāpi, ekassa maṅgale vā roge vā aññasmiṃ vā pana tādise
analyzed: a vatvā sabbe ekatas saṅgaṇhantā api ekassa maṅgale vā roge vā aññasmin vā pana tādise
translated: but gather all together, and when they go to the place of one of them who has had good or bad fortune or some such event,

original: sukhadukkhe uppanne sabbe tattha sahāyabhāvaṃ gacchantāpi samaggā vajjikaraṇīyāni karonti nāma.🔽Apaññattantiādīsu pubbe akataṃ suṅkaṃ vā baliṃ vā daṇḍaṃ vā āharāpentā apaññattaṃ
analyzed: sukha dukkhe uppanne sabbe tattha sahāya bhāvam gacchantā api samaggāḥ vajjikaraṇīyāni karonti nāma  a paññatta nti ādīsu pubbe a katam suṅkam vā balim vā daṇḍam vā āhara apentā a paññattam
translated: and they emerge united when they do the duties of friendship.

original: paññapenti nāma. Porāṇapaveṇiyā āgatameva pana anāharāpentā paññattaṃ samucchindanti
analyzed: paññapenti nāma porāṇa paveṇiyā āgatam eva pana paññattam samucchindanti
translated: In the case of the words “not laid down,” etc., they lay down what has not been laid down, that is to say, they cause to bring what has not been made before, such as a sacrificial post, a sacrificial grass-bundle, or a sacrificial chip.🔽But they abolish what has been laid down when they do not cause to bring what has come down in the ancient tradition.

original: nāma. Coroti gahetvā dassite avicinitvāva chejjabhejjaṃ anusāsentā porāṇaṃ vajjidhammaṃ
analyzed: nāma cora uti gahetvā dassite a vicinitvā ava chejja bhejjam anusāsentā porāṇam vajji dhammaṃ
translated: “They do not follow the ancient royal laws” means that they do not follow the ancient royal laws of the kings of old, who, when they saw thieves, did not execute, mutilate, or torture them, but rather sent them away.

original: samādāya na vattanti nāma. Tesaṃ apaññattaṃ paññapentānaṃ abhinavasuṅkādīhi pīḷitā🔽manussā – “atiupaddutamha, ko imesaṃ vijite vasissatī”ti paccantaṃ pavisitvā corā
analyzed: samādāya na vattanti nāma tesam a paññattam paññapentānam abhinava suṅka ādīhi pīḷitā  manussāḥ kaḥ imesam vijite vasissati iti paccantam pavisitvā corāḥ
translated: “They make new laws” means that they make new laws such as the Suṅka Prohibition, etc., and oppress the people.

original: vā corasahāyā vā hutvā janapadaṃ paharanti. Paññattaṃ samucchindantānaṃ paveṇīāgatāni🔽suṅkādīni agaṇhantānaṃ koso parihāyati. Tato hatthiassabalakāyaorodhādayo yathānibaddhaṃ
analyzed: vā cora sahāyāḥ vā hutvā janapadam paharanti paññattam samucchindantānam paveṇī āgatāni  suṅka ādīni a gaṇhantānam kosaḥ parihāyati tatas hatthi assa balakāya orodha ādayaḥ yathānibaddham
translated: “The people are oppressed” means that the people are oppressed by the new laws such as the Suṅka Prohibition, etc., and they flee to the border areas. There they become thieves or friends of thieves and attack the country.🔽“The treasury is depleted” means that the treasury is depleted because they do not collect the taxes that have come down from ancient times such as the Suṅka Tax, etc.

original: vaṭṭaṃ alabhamānā thāmena balena parihāyanti. Te neva yuddhakkhamā honti, na pāricariyakkhamā.🔽Porāṇaṃ vajjidhammaṃ samādāya avattantānaṃ vijite manussā – “amhākaṃ puttaṃ pitaraṃ
analyzed: vaṭṭam a labhamānā thāmena balena parihāyanti te na iva yuddha kkhamāḥ honti na pāricariya kkhamāḥ  porāṇam vajji dhammam samādāya avattantānam vijite manussāḥ amhākam puttam pitaram
translated: “The army is depleted” means that the army is depleted because the commanders of the army, the elephant troops, the cavalry, etc., do not receive their wages as usual. They are not fit for battle or for service.

original: bhātaraṃ acoraṃyeva coroti katvā chindiṃsu bhindiṃsū”ti kujjhitvā paccantaṃ pavisitvā
analyzed: bhātaram a coraṃya iva coro ti katvā chindiṃsu bhindiṃsu iti kujjhitvā paccantam pavisitvā
translated: “The people are angry” means that the people are angry because they do not follow the ancient royal laws of the kings of old, who did not execute, mutilate, or torture innocent people, but rather sent them away. They flee to the border areas and become thieves or friends of thieves and attack the country.

original: corā vā corasahāyā vā hutvā janapadaṃ paharanti, evaṃ rājūnaṃ parihāni hoti, paññattaṃ🔽paññapentānaṃ pana “paveṇīāgatameva rājāno karontī”ti manussā haṭṭhatuṭṭhā kasivāṇijjādike
analyzed: corāḥ vā cora sahāyāḥ vā hutvā janapadam paharanti evam hoti paññattam  paññapentānam pana paveṇī āgatam eva rājāno karonti iti manussā haṭṭha tuṭṭhā kasi vāṇijja ādike
translated: Or else, having become thieves or accomplices of thieves, they plunder the country. Thus there is loss to the king.

original: kammante sampādenti. Paññattaṃ asamucchindantānaṃ paveṇīāgatāni suṅkādīni gaṇhantānaṃ
analyzed: kammante sampādenti paññattam a samucchindantānam paveṇī āgatāni suṅka ādīni gaṇhantānam
translated: But when the established law is not abolished, people are pleased and satisfied and they engage in agriculture, trade, etc.,🔽and they take the established law’s produce such as the land revenue, etc.,

original: koso vaḍḍhati, tato hatthiassabalakāyaorodhādayo yathānibaddhaṃ vaṭṭaṃ labhamānā
analyzed: kosaḥ vaḍḍhati tatas hatthi assa balakāya orodha ādayaḥ yathā nibaddham vaṭṭam labhamānā
translated: and the treasury is filled. Then the elephant troops, the cavalry, etc., receiving their wages regularly,

original: thāmabalasampannā yuddhakkhamā ceva pāricariyakkhamā ca honti.
analyzed: thāma bala sampannāḥ yuddha kkhamāḥ ca iva pāricariya kkhamāḥ ca honti
translated: become strong and powerful and fit for battle and service.

original: Porāṇaṃ vajjidhammanti ettha pubbe kira vajjirājāno “ayaṃ coro”ti ānetvā dassite

original: uparājā rañño, rājā vinicchinitvā acoro ce, vissajjeti. Sace pana coro hoti, paveṇīpotthakaṃ🔽vācāpeti. Tattha – “yena idaṃ nāma kataṃ, tassa ayaṃ nāma daṇḍo”ti likhitaṃ. Rājā
analyzed: upa rājā raññaḥ rājā vinicchinitvā a coraḥ ce vissajjeti sace pana coraḥ hoti paveṇī potthakam  tattha yena idam nāma katam tassa ayam nāma daṇḍaḥ iti likhitam rājā
translated: The chief minister hands him over to the king. The king investigates and if he says he is not, he releases him.🔽But if he is, he has the register of crimes read out. There it is written: “Whoever does such and such is to be punished thus and so.”

original: tassa kiriyaṃ tena samānetvā tadanucchavikaṃ daṇḍaṃ karoti. Iti etaṃ porāṇaṃ vajjidhammaṃ🔽samādāya vattantānaṃ manussā na ujjhāyanti, “rājāno porāṇapaveṇiyā kammaṃ karonti,
analyzed: tassa kiriyam tena samānetvā tad anucchavikam daṇḍam karoti iti etam porāṇam vajji dhammam  samādāya vattantānam manussāḥ na ujjhāyanti rājāno porāṇa paveṇiyā kammam karonti

analyzed: ayam vacana atthaḥ evam hi karontānam vijite manussāḥ amhākam gehe putta mātaraḥ api  kheḷa siṅghāṇika ādīni mukhena apanetvā ime rājānaḥ balakkārena
translated: saying: ‘Even our sons’ mothers and

analyzed: kammāni karontāḥ rāja kosam vaḍḍhenti evam ettha vuddhi hāniyaḥ veditabbā  vajjīnam vajjicetiyāni iti vajji rājūnam vajji raṭṭhe cittīkata ṭṭhena cetiyāni iti laddha nāmāni

original: Dhammikā rakkhāvaraṇaguttīti ettha rakkhā eva yathā anicchitaṃ na gacchati, evaṃ🔽āvaraṇato āvaraṇaṃ. Yathā icchitaṃ na vinassati, evaṃ gopāyanato gutti. analyzed: dhammikā rakkhā āvaraṇa gutti iti ettha rakkhā eva yathā anicchitam na gacchati evam  āvaraṇataḥ āvaraṇam yathā icchitam na vinassati evam gopāyanataḥ tattha balakāyena  parivāretvā rakkhaṇam pabbajitānam dhammikā rakkhā āvaraṇa gutti nāma na hoti yathā  pana vihārassa upavane rukkhe na chindanti vājikāḥ vajjham na karonti pokkharaṇīsu
translated: “Dhammikā rakkhāvaraṇaguttī” means that protection is the preventing of what is not wanted from happening,🔽and guarding is the preventing of what is wanted from being destroyed. translated: Herein, those who do not want the coming of future arahats are faithless and have no confidence.

analyzed: pabbajite ca sampatte paccuggamanam na karonti gantvā na passanti paṭisanthāram

Atha nesaṃ avaṇṇo abbhuggacchati – “asuko🔽nāma rājā assaddho appasanno, pabbajite sampatte paccuggamanaṃ na karoti…pe… nivāsanaṭṭhānaṃ🔽na saṃvidahatī”ti. analyzed: na karonti pañham na pucchanti dhammam na suṇanti dānam na denti anumodanam na  suṇanti nivāsanaṭṭhānam na saṃvidahanti atha nesam avaṇṇaḥ abbhuggacchati asukaḥ  nāma rājā assaddhaḥ appasanno pabbajite sampatte paccuggamanam na karoti pe nivāsanaṭṭhānam  na saṃvidahati iti tam sutvā pabbajitā tassa nagara dvārena na gacchanti gacchantā api
translated: they do not ask questions, they do not listen to the Dhamma, they do not give gifts, they do not listen to the blessings,

analyzed: nagaram na pavisanti evam anāgatānam arahantānam an āgamanam eva hoti āgatānam pi
translated: they do not prepare a place to stay. Thus there is no coming of future arahats. And for those who have come

analyzed: phāsu vihāre asati ye pi a jānitvā āgatā te vasissāma ati tāva cintetvā
translated: if there is no comfortable living, even those who have come without knowing, think: “We have come thinking we will live here,

analyzed: imesam pana rājūnam iminā nīhārena kaḥ vasissati iti nikkhamitvā gacchanti evam anāgatesu
translated: “Who will live in this country when these kings have gone away?” and they leave and go elsewhere.🔽Thus, when they do not come,

analyzed: an āgacchantesu āgatesu dukkham viharantesu so deso pabbajitānam anāvāsaḥ hoti tatas
translated: and when they come, they live unhappily, that country becomes a place unfit for ascetics. Then

analyzed: devatā rakkhā na hoti devatā rakkhāya asati amanussāḥ okāsam labhanti amanussā ussannā
translated: there is no divine protection, and when there is no divine protection, non-human beings get the opportunity . When non-human beings are rampant,

analyzed: anuppannam byādhim uppādenti sīlavantānam dassana pañhāpucchana ādi vatthukassa puññassa
translated: they produce a disease that has not existed before, and there is no opportunity for the merit of seeing virtuous people, asking them questions, etc.

original: anāgamo hoti. Vipariyāyena pana yathāvuttakaṇhapakkhaviparītassa sukkapakkhassa sambhavo
analyzed: anāgamaḥ hoti vipariyāyena pana yathā vutta kaṇha pakkha viparītassa sukka pakkhassa sambhavaḥ
translated: But when the opposite of the dark side occurs, the bright side comes into being in the way already described.

original: 135. Ekamidāhanti idaṃ bhagavā pubbe vajjīnaṃ imassa vajjisattakassa desitabhāvappakāsanatthamāha.
analyzed: ekam idā aham ti idam bhagavā pubbe vajjīnam imassa vajji sattakassa desita bhāva ppakāsana attham āha
translated: “At one time”: this the Blessed One said in order to show that he had previously taught this Vajjian people this Dhamma of the seven conditions of non-decline.

translated: There, in the Sārandada Monastery, which was so named, it seems, because it was given by a brāhmaṇa named Sārandada. Before the Buddha arose, it seems, the brāhmaṇa gave it to some independent ascetics.

analyzed: sārandade cetiye sārandada cetiyantu eva saṅkhyam  a karaṇīyā ati a kātabbā aggahetabbā ati atthaḥ yat idam ti nipāta mattam yuddhassa ati karaṇa tthe  sāmi vacanam abhimukha yuddhena gahetum na sakkā iti atthaḥ aññatra upalāpanāya ati ṭhapetvā

original: upalāpanaṃ. Upalāpanā nāma – “alaṃ vivādena, idāni samaggā homā”ti hatthiassarathahiraññasuvaṇṇādīni🔽pesetvā saṅgahakaraṇaṃ. Evañhi saṅgahaṃ katvā kevalaṃ vissāsena sakkā gaṇhitunti
analyzed: upalāpanam upalāpanā nāma alam vivādena idāni samaggāḥ homa ati hatthi assa ratha hirañña suvaṇṇa ādīni  pesetvā saṅgaha karaṇam evam hi saṅgaham katvā kevalam vissāsena sakkā gaṇhitun ti
translated: ‘Not to be conquered’: not to be done, not to be taken, is the meaning. ‘Yadidam’: this is merely a particle. ‘War’: the genitive case is used in the sense of an instrument. The meaning is: it cannot be conquered by waging war. ‘Except by beguilement’: setting aside beguilement. ‘Beguilement’ means sending elephants, horses, chariots, gold, silver, etc., saying: ‘Enough of this dispute. Now let us be united,’ and thus gaining their confidence.

analyzed: vā ākoṭitāya mayham cīvara kammaṃ atthi mayham pattaḥ pacitabbaḥ mayham nava kammam  atthi iti vikkhepam karontā na samaggā sannipatanti nāma sabbam pana tam kammam ṭhapetvā

original: – “ahaṃ purimataraṃ, ahaṃ purimatara”nti ekappahāreneva sannipatantā samaggā sannipatanti🔽nāma. Sannipatitā pana cintetvā mantetvā kattabbaṃ katvā ekato avuṭṭhahantā samaggā
analyzed: aham purimataram aham purimataranti eka pahārena iva sannipatantā samaggā sannipatanti  nāma sannipatitā pana cintetvā mantetvā kattabbam katvā ekatas a vuṭṭhahantā samaggā
translated: If they are not in agreement when they gather, they do not gather in harmony. But if they put aside all that business and gather all together at the same time, saying, “I’ll do this first, I’ll do that first,” then they gather in harmony.

original: na vuṭṭhahanti nāma. Evaṃ vuṭṭhitesu hi ye paṭhamaṃ gacchanti, tesaṃ evaṃ hoti –
analyzed: na vuṭṭhahanti nāma evam vuṭṭhitesu hi ye paṭhamam gacchanti tesam evam hoti
translated: But if they do not get up together after they have thought and discussed what should be done, then they do not get up in harmony.

original: “amhehi bāhirakathāva sutā, idāni vinicchayakathā bhavissatī”ti. Ekappahāreneva vuṭṭhahantā🔽pana samaggā vuṭṭhahanti nāma. Apica “asukaṭṭhāne vihārasīmā ākulā, uposathapavāraṇā
analyzed: amhehi sutā idāni vinicchaya kathā bhavissati iti eka ppahārena iva vuṭṭhahantā  pana samaggāḥ vuṭṭhahanti nāma apica asuka ṭṭhāne vihāra sīmā ākulā uposatha pavāraṇā
translated: For when they get up, those who go first think, “We have only heard the outside talk. Now there will be a discussion of the legal issue.” But if they get up all together at the same time, then they get up in harmony.

original: ṭhitā, asukaṭṭhāne vejjakammādikārakā pāpabhikkhū ussannā”ti sutvā – “ko gantvā tesaṃ
analyzed: ṭhitāḥ asuka ṭṭhāne vejja kamma ādi kārakā pāpa bhikkhū ussannā ati sutvā kaḥ gantvā tesaṃ
translated: Moreover, if they hear that the monastery zone is crowded in such-and-such a place, that the observance-day ceremony and the invitation ceremony are being held there, and that bad monks who are doctors, etc., are in the ascendant there, they think, “Who should go there?

original: niggahaṃ karissatī”ti vutte – “ahaṃ paṭhamaṃ, ahaṃ paṭhama”nti vatvā gacchantāpi
analyzed: niggaham karissati iti vutte aham paṭhamam aham paṭhamam iti vatvā gacchantā api
translated: If it is said, “He will do the reproving,” and they go, saying, “I first, I first,”

original: samaggā vuṭṭhahanti nāma.
analyzed: samaggāḥ vuṭṭhahanti nāma
translated: they are said to go forth in unity.

original: Āgantukaṃ pana disvā – “imaṃ pariveṇaṃ yāhi, etaṃ pariveṇaṃ yāhi, ayaṃ ko”ti avatvā
analyzed: āgantukam pana disvā imam pariveṇam yāhi etam pariveṇam yāhi ayam avatvā
translated: But if, on seeing a visitor, they do not say, “Go to this yard, go to that yard, who is he? “

original: sabbe vattaṃ karontāpi, jiṇṇapattacīvarakaṃ disvā tassa bhikkhācāravattena pattacīvaraṃ🔽pariyesamānāpi, gilānassa gilānabhesajjaṃ pariyesamānāpi, gilānameva anāthaṃ – “asukapariveṇaṃ🔽yāhi, asukapariveṇaṃ yāhī”ti avatvā attano attano pariveṇe paṭijaggantāpi, eko oliyamānako
analyzed: sabbe vattam karontā api jiṇṇa patta cīvarakam disvā tassa bhikkhā cāra vattena patta cīvaram  pariyesamānā api gilānassa gilāna bhesajjam pariyesamānā api gilānam eva anātham asuka pariveṇam  yāhi asuka pariveṇam yāhi iti avatvā attano attano pariveṇe ekaḥ oliyamānako
translated: and they all do the duties, and if, on seeing a monk with an old bowl or robe, they do not seek bowl or robe for him by way of the alms round,🔽and if, on seeing a sick monk, they do not seek medicine for him, and if they do not look after a sick monk themselves, saying, “Go to this yard, go to that yard,”

original: gantho hoti, paññavantaṃ bhikkhuṃ saṅgaṇhitvā tena taṃ ganthaṃ ukkhipāpentāpi samaggā
analyzed: ganthaḥ hoti paññavantam bhikkhum saṅgaṇhitvā tena tam gantham ukkhipāpentā api samaggā
translated: but if they look after him in their own yard, and if they do not get a learned monk to recite the Monastic Code and then recite it themselves,

original: saṅghaṃ karaṇīyāni karonti nāma.
analyzed: saṅgham karaṇīyāni karonti nāma
translated: they are said to do the duties of the Sangha in unity.

original: Apaññattantiādīsu navaṃ adhammikaṃ katikavattaṃ vā sikkhāpadaṃ vā bandhantā apaññattaṃ
analyzed: a paññatta nti ādīsu navam adhammikam katikavattam vā sikkhāpadam vā bandhantā a paññattam
translated: “Not laid down”: if they make a new, illegitimate motion or a new training rule, it is not laid down.

original: paññapenti nāma, purāṇasanthatavatthusmiṃ sāvatthiyaṃ bhikkhū viya. Uddhammaṃ ubbinayaṃ🔽sāsanaṃ dīpentā paññattaṃ samucchindanti nāma, vassasataparinibbute bhagavati vesālikā
analyzed: paññapenti nāma purāṇa santhata vatthusmiṃ sāvatthiyam bhikkhū viya uddhammam ubbinayam  sāsanam dīpentā paññattam samucchindanti nāma vassa sata parinibbute bhagavati vesālikā
translated: They make known: as the monks at Sāvatthī did in regard to the old cloth.

original: vajjiputtakā viya. Khuddānukhuddakā pana āpattiyo sañcicca vītikkamantā yathāpaññattesu🔽sikkhāpadesu samādāya na vattanti nāma, assajipunabbasukā viya. Navaṃ pana katikavattaṃ🔽vā sikkhāpadaṃ vā abandhantā, dhammavinayato sāsanaṃ dīpentā, khuddānukhuddakāni
analyzed: vajjiputtakāḥ viya khudda anukhuddakāḥ pana āpattiyaḥ sañcicca vītikkamantāḥ yathā paññattesu  sikkhāpadesu samādāya na vattanti nāma assa jipu nabbasukāḥ viya navam pana katika vattam  vā sikkhāpadam vā a bandhantā dhamma vinayataḥ sāsanam dīpentā khuddānukhuddakāni
translated: They abolish what has been laid down: as the Vajjian monks at Vesālī did a hundred years after the Blessed One had attained final Nibbāna.🔽They do not undertake and do not train in the training rules that have been laid down: as the monks Assaji and Punabbasuka did.

original: sikkhāpadāni asamūhanantā apaññattaṃ na paññapenti, paññattaṃ na samucchindanti,🔽yathāpaññattesu sikkhāpadesu samādāya vattanti nāma, āyasmā upaseno viya, āyasmā
analyzed: sikkhāpadāni a samūhanantāḥ a paññattam na paññapenti paññattam na samucchindanti  yathā paññattesu sikkhāpadesu samādāya vattanti nāma āyasmai upasenaḥ viya āyasmā
translated: They do not introduce what has not been laid down: as the venerable Upasena did.

original: yaso kākaṇḍakaputto viya ca.
analyzed: yaso kākaṇḍaka putto viya ca
translated: They do not abolish what has been laid down: as the venerable Yasa, the son of Kākaṇḍakī, did.

original: “Suṇātu, me āvuso saṅgho, santamhākaṃ sikkhāpadāni gihigatāni, gihinopi jānanti,🔽‘idaṃ vo samaṇānaṃ sakyaputtiyānaṃ kappati, idaṃ vo na kappatī’ti. Sace hi mayaṃ
analyzed: suṇātu me āvuso saṅghaḥ santamhākam sikkhāpadāni gihi gatāni gihinaḥ api jānanti  idam vaḥ samaṇānam sakyaputtiyānam kappati idam vaḥ na kappati iti sace hi mayam
translated: “Venerable friends, there are training rules for us that are related to householders. Householders know

original: khuddānukhuddakāni sikkhāpadāni samūhanissāma, bhavissanti vattāro – ‘dhūmakālikaṃ
analyzed: khuddānukhuddakāni sikkhāpadāni samūhanissāma bhavissanti vattāraḥ dhūmakālikam
translated: that ‘This is allowable for the Sakyan monastics, this is not allowable for them.’ If we were to abolish the minor and minor training rules,

original: samaṇena gotamena sāvakānaṃ sikkhāpadaṃ paññattaṃ, yāvimesaṃ satthā aṭṭhāsi, tāvime
analyzed: samaṇena gotamena sāvakānam sikkhāpadam paññattam yau imesam satthā aṭṭhāsi tau ime
translated: there would be those who say, ‘The ascetic Gotama has introduced the training rules for his disciples when he was alive,

original: sikkhāpadesu sikkhiṃsu. Yato imesaṃ satthā parinibbuto, na dānime sikkhāpadesu sikkhantī’ti.
analyzed: sikkhāpadesu sikkhiṃsu yatas imesam satthā parinibbutaḥ na dāni ime sikkhāpadesu sikkhanti iti
translated: but now that the ascetic Gotama has attained final Nirvana, the training rules are no longer observed.’

original: Yadi saṅghassa pattakallaṃ, saṅgho apaññattaṃ na paññapeyya, paññattaṃ na samucchindeyya,
analyzed: yadi saṅghassa patta kallam saṅghaḥ a paññattam na paññapeyya paññattam na samucchindeyya
translated: If it seems right to the Sangha, the Sangha should not introduce what has not been introduced and should not abolish what has been introduced.

original: yathāpaññattesu sikkhāpadesu samādāya vatteyyā”ti –
analyzed: yathā paññattesu sikkhāpadesu samādāya vatteyya ati
translated: Let the Sangha undertake and observe the training rules as they have been laid down.”🔽And he should do so like the venerable Maha Kassapa.

original: Imaṃ tantiṃ ṭhapayanto āyasmā mahākassapo viya ca. Vuddhiyevāti sīlādīhi guṇehi vuḍḍhiyeva, no parihāni.
analyzed: imam tantim ṭhapayantaḥ āyasmā mahākassapaḥ viya ca sīla ādīhi guṇehi
translated: There will be growth: growth in virtue, etc.

original: Therāti thirabhāvappattā therakārakehi guṇehi samannāgatā. Bahū rattiyo jānantīti
analyzed: therā ati thira bhāva ppattā thera kārakehi guṇehi samannāgatāḥ bahū rattiyaḥ jānanti iti
translated: “Elders” : they have reached stability, they are endowed with the qualities that make elders. “Long-lived” : they have known many nights,

original: rattaññū. Ciraṃ pabbajitānaṃ etesanti cirapabbajitā. Saṅghassa pituṭṭhāne ṭhitāti
analyzed: rattaññū ciram pabbajitānam etesan ti cira pabbajitā saṅghassa pitu ṭṭhāne ṭhitā ati
translated: many years. “Long-lived” means they have been gone forth for a long time. “Fathers of the Order” : they are established in the place of the Order’s father.

original: saṅghapitaro. Pituṭṭhāne ṭhitattā saṅghaṃ parinenti pubbaṅgamā hutvā tīsu sikkhāsu
analyzed: saṅgha pitaraḥ pitu ṭṭhāne ṭhita ttā saṅgham parinenti pubbaṅgamāḥ hutvā tīsu sikkhāsu
translated: Because they are established in the place of the Order’s father, they lead the Order, they are the forerunners, they cause it to go forward in the three trainings.

original: pavattentīti saṅghapariṇāyakā.
analyzed: pavattenti iti saṅgha pariṇāyakā
translated: They are “leaders of the Order”.

original: Ye tesaṃ sakkārādīni na karonti, ovādatthāya dve tayo vāre upaṭṭhānaṃ na gacchanti,🔽tepi tesaṃ ovādaṃ na denti, paveṇīkathaṃ na kathenti, sārabhūtaṃ dhammapariyāyaṃ
analyzed: ye tesam sakkāra ādīni na karonti ovāda atthāya dve tayaḥ vāre upaṭṭhānam na gacchanti  te api tesam ovādam na denti paveṇīkatham na kathenti sāra bhūtam dhammapariyāyam
translated: Those who do not render them honour, etc., who do not go to wait on them two or three times for the sake of advice,🔽they do not give them advice, they do not tell them the tradition, they do not instruct them in the essence, the discourse of the Dhamma.

original: na sikkhāpenti. Te tehi vissaṭṭhā sīlādīhi dhammakkhandhehi sattahi ca ariyadhanehīti
analyzed: na sikkhāpenti te tehi vissaṭṭhā sīla ādīhi dhammakkhandhehi sattahi ca ariya dhanehi iti
translated: They are separated from them by virtue, etc., and by the seven kinds of noble wealth.

original: evamādīhi guṇehi parihāyanti. Ye pana tesaṃ sakkārādīni karonti, upaṭṭhānaṃ gacchanti,
analyzed: evamādīhi guṇehi parihāyanti ye pana tesam sakkāra ādīni karonti upaṭṭhānam gacchanti
translated: Thus they fall away from the special qualities beginning with virtue. But those who render them honour, etc., who go to wait on them,

original: tepi tesaṃ ovādaṃ denti. “Evaṃ te abhikkamitabbaṃ, evaṃ te paṭikkamitabbaṃ, evaṃ
analyzed: te api tesam ovādam denti evam te abhikkamitabbam evam te paṭikkamitabbam evam
translated: they give them advice: “You should approach thus, you should withdraw thus, you should sit down thus, you should lie down thus, you should look straight ahead thus, you should fold your legs crosswise thus, you should guard the doors of your sense faculties thus, you should be moderate in eating thus, you should strive for mindfulness and full awareness thus, you should arouse energy thus, you should be devoted to concentration thus, you should be devoted to wisdom thus, you should be devoted to liberation thus, you should be devoted to the vision of the knowledge and vision of liberation thus.”

original: te ālokitabbaṃ, evaṃ te vilokitabbaṃ, evaṃ te samiñjitabbaṃ, evaṃ te pasāritabbaṃ,
analyzed: te ālokitabbam evam te vilokitabbam evam te samiñjitabbam evam te pasāritabbam
translated: They instruct them in the way of walking, looking straight on, looking ahead, bending the limbs, stretching the limbs,

original: evaṃ te saṅghāṭipattacīvaraṃ dhāretabba”nti paveṇīkathaṃ kathenti, sārabhūtaṃ dhammapariyāyaṃ
analyzed: evam te saṅghāṭi patta cīvaram dhāretabbanti paveṇī katham kathenti sāra bhūtam dhammapariyāyam
translated: and in the way of wearing the patched cloak, bowl, and robes. They instruct them in the Dhamma that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, with the right meaning and phrasing, and they reveal the perfectly complete and pure spiritual life.

original: sikkhāpenti, terasahi dhutaṅgehi dasahi kathāvatthūhi anusāsanti. Te tesaṃ ovāde
analyzed: sikkhāpenti terasahi dhutaṅgehi dasahi kathāvatthūhi anusāsanti te tesam ovāde
translated: They instruct them in the thirteen ascetic practices and the ten ways of conducting oneself. Those who follow their advice

original: ṭhatvā sīlādīhi guṇehi vaḍḍhamānā sāmaññatthaṃ anupāpuṇanti. Evamettha hānivuddhiyo veditabbā.🔽Punabbhavadānaṃ punabbhavo, punabbhavo sīlamassāti ponobbhavikā, punabbhavadāyikāti🔽attho, tasmā ponobbhavikāya. Na vasaṃ gacchantīti ettha ye catunnaṃ paccayānaṃ kāraṇā
analyzed: ṭhatvā sīla ādīhi guṇehi vaḍḍhamānā sāmañña attham anupāpuṇanti evam ettha hāni vuddhiyaḥ veditabbā  punabbhava dānam punabbhavaḥ punabbhavaḥ sīlam assa ati ponobbhavikā punabbhava dāyikā ati  attho tasmā ponobbhavikāya na vasam gacchanti iti ettha ye catunnam paccayānam kāraṇā
translated: and increase in the special qualities of virtue, etc., reach the goal of recluseship. This is how the decline and growth should be understood here.🔽“The round of rebirths” is the round of rebirths itself. He who has the round of rebirths is a “rebirther” . The meaning is that he is one who brings about the round of rebirths. Therefore “not subject to future becoming” is said.

original: upaṭṭhākānaṃ padānupadikā hutvā gāmato gāmaṃ vicaranti, te tassā taṇhāya vasaṃ gacchanti
analyzed: upaṭṭhākānam padānupadikāḥ hutvā gāmataḥ gāmam vicaranti te tassā taṇhāya vasam gacchanti
translated: As to “not subject to the control of others”: those who go from village to village following the alms round for the sake of the four requisites and who are dependent on others for their livelihood are said to be “subject to the control of others” .

original: nāma, itare na gacchanti nāma. Tattha hānivuddhiyo pākaṭāyeva.
analyzed: nāma itare na gacchanti nāma tattha hāni vuddhiyaḥ pākaṭāya iva
translated: The others are not so. Herein, the decline and growth are evident.

original: Āraññakesūti pañcadhanusatikapacchimesu. Sāpekkhāti sataṇhā sālayā. Gāmantasenāsanesu🔽hi jhānaṃ appetvāpi tato vuṭṭhitamattova itthipurisadārikādisaddaṃ suṇāti, yenassa
analyzed: āraññakesu uti pañca dhanusatika pacchimesu sa apekkhā ati sa taṇhā sa ālayā gāmanta senāsanesu  hi jhānam appetvā api tatas vuṭṭhita mattaḥ va itthi purisa dārikā ādi saddam suṇāti yena assa
translated: In forest-dwellings: in the five-league radius around a village. With hankering: with craving and attachment.🔽For when a bhikkhu has entered upon jhāna in a dwelling in a village neighbourhood, as soon as he emerges from it he hears the sounds of women, men, boys and girls,

original: adhigatavisesopi hāyatiyeva. Araññe pana niddāyitvā paṭibuddhamatto sīhabyagghamorādīnaṃ
analyzed: adhigata visesaḥ api hāyatiyā iva araññe pana niddāyitvā paṭibuddha mattaḥ sīha byaggha mora ādīnam
translated: and then his attainment of distinction is lost. But when he has slept in the forest and wakes up, he hears the sounds of lions, tigers, and bears,

original: saddaṃ suṇāti, yena āraññakaṃ pītiṃ labhitvā tameva sammasanto aggaphale patiṭṭhāti.
analyzed: saddam suṇāti yena āraññakam pītim labhitvā tam eva sammasantaḥ agga phale patiṭṭhāti
translated: and then he obtains the happiness of forest-dwelling and he establishes himself in the supreme fruit by developing that.

original: Iti bhagavā gāmantasenāsane jhānaṃ appetvā nisinnabhikkhuno araññe niddāyantameva
analyzed: iti bhagavā gāmanta senāsane jhānam appetvā nisinna bhikkhunaḥ araññe niddāyantam eva
translated: So the Blessed One praises the bhikkhu who sleeps in the forest,

original: pasaṃsati. Tasmā tameva atthavasaṃ paṭicca – “āraññakesu senāsanesu sāpekkhā bhavissantī”ti āha.
analyzed: pasaṃsati tasmā tam eva atthavasam paṭicca āraññakesu senāsanesu sa apekkhāḥ bhavissanti iti āha
translated: and it is with reference to this meaning that he said: “They will be with hankering for dwellings in forest-dwellings.”

original: Paccattaññeva satiṃ upaṭṭhapessantīti attanāva attano abbhantare satiṃ upaṭṭhapessanti.
analyzed: paccattaññā iva satim upaṭṭhapessanti iti attanā ava attanaḥ abbhantare satim upaṭṭhapessanti
translated: They will establish mindfulness: they will establish mindfulness in themselves.

original: Pesalāti piyasīlā. Idhāpi sabrahmacārīnaṃ āgamanaṃ anicchantā nevāsikā assaddhā honti
analyzed: piya sīlāḥ idha api sabrahmacārīnam āgamanam an icchantāḥ nevāsikāḥ assaddhāḥ honti
translated: Virtuous: of lovable virtue. Here the resident bhikkhus are faithless

original: appasannā. Sampattabhikkhūnaṃ paccuggamanapattacīvarappaṭiggahaṇaāsanapaññāpanatālavaṇṭaggahaṇādīni
analyzed: appasannā sampatta bhikkhūnam paccuggamana patta cīvara ppaṭiggahaṇa āsana paññāpana tāla vaṇṭa ggahaṇa ādīni
translated: They are not respectful. They do not do the duties of receiving bowl and robe when bhikkhus arrive, of preparing seats, of providing water for washing the feet and a foot stool, etc.

original: na karonti, atha nesaṃ avaṇṇo uggacchati – “asukavihāravāsino bhikkhū assaddhā appasannā🔽vihāraṃ paviṭṭhānaṃ vattapaṭivattaṃ na karontī”ti. Taṃ sutvā pabbajitā vihāradvārena
analyzed: na karonti atha nesam avaṇṇaḥ uggacchati asuka vihāra vāsinaḥ bhikkhū assaddhāḥ appasannāḥ  vihāram paviṭṭhānam vatta paṭivattam na karonti iti tam sutvā pabbajitā vihāra dvārena
translated: Then their disrepute spreads: “The bhikkhus living in such-and-such a dwelling are without faith and without devotion.

original: gacchantāpi vihāraṃ na pavisanti. Evaṃ anāgatānaṃ anāgamanameva hoti. Āgatānaṃ pana
analyzed: gacchantā api vihāram na pavisanti evam anāgatānam anāgamanam eva āgatānam pana
translated: When bhikkhus enter the dwelling, they do not do the duties of hospitality.” When the wanderers hear this, they go by the dwelling’s gate but do not enter it. So it is that they do not come to stay there. But even if they come,

original: phāsuvihāre asati yepi ajānitvā āgatā, te – “vasissāmāti tāva cintetvā āgatāmha,
analyzed: phāsu vihāre asati ye pi a jānitvā āgatā te vasissāma ati tāva cintetvā āgatāmha
translated: if there is no comfort for them, then even those who come without knowing this think, “We came thinking, ‘We will stay here,’

original: imesaṃ pana nevāsikānaṃ iminā nīhārena ko vasissatī”ti nikkhamitvā gacchanti. Evaṃ
analyzed: imesam pana nevāsikānam iminā nīhārena kaḥ vasissati iti nikkhamitvā gacchanti evam
translated: but with these residents as a pretext, who will stay here?” So they leave and go away.

original: so vihāro aññesaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ anāvāsova hoti. Tato nevāsikā sīlavantānaṃ dassanaṃ
analyzed: so vihāraḥ aññesam bhikkhūnam anāvāsaḥ uva hoti tatas nevāsikā sīlavantānam dassanam
translated: So that dwelling becomes a non-dwelling for other bhikkhus. Then the residents, not getting to see the virtuous,

original: alabhantā kaṅkhāvinodanaṃ vā ācārasikkhāpakaṃ vā madhuradhammassavanaṃ vā na labhanti,
analyzed: a labhantā kaṅkhā vinodanam vā ācāra sikkhāpakam vā madhura dhamma ssavanam vā na labhanti
translated: not getting to clear up their doubts or to learn proper conduct or to hear the sweet Dhamma,

original: tesaṃ neva aggahitadhammaggahaṇaṃ, na gahitasajjhāyakaraṇaṃ hoti. Iti nesaṃ hāniyeva hoti, na vuddhi.
analyzed: tesam na iva aggahita dhamma ggahaṇam na gahita sajjhāya karaṇam hoti iti na īsam hāniyā iva hoti na
translated: They neither learn what has not been learned nor do what has been learned. So there is only loss for them, not growth.🔽But those who want to receive co-farers in the life of purity are faithful and confident.

original: Ye pana sabrahmacārīnaṃ āgamanaṃ icchanti, te saddhā honti pasannā, āgatānaṃ sabrahmacārīnaṃ🔽paccuggamanādīni katvā senāsanaṃ paññapetvā denti, te gahetvā bhikkhācāraṃ pavisanti,
analyzed: ye pana sabrahmacārīnam āgamanam icchanti te saddhāḥ honti pasannāḥ āgatānam sabrahmacārīnam  paccuggamana ādīni katvā senāsanam paññapetvā denti te gahetvā bhikkhācāram pavisanti
translated: They receive the co-farers in the life of purity who have come,🔽and after welcoming them, etc., they give them a dwelling place. The visitors take it, and they enter the village for alms.

original: kaṅkhaṃ vinodenti, madhuradhammassavanaṃ labhanti. Atha nesaṃ kittisaddo uggacchati
analyzed: kaṅkham vinodenti madhura dhamma ssavanam labhanti atha nesam kitti saddaḥ uggacchati
translated: They clear up their doubts, and they get to hear the sweet Dhamma. Then their fame spreads

original: – “asukavihārabhikkhū evaṃ saddhā pasannā vattasampannā saṅgāhakā”ti. Taṃ sutvā bhikkhū
analyzed: asuka vihāra bhikkhū evam saddhā pasannā vatta sampannā saṅgāhakā ati tam sutvā bhikkhū
translated: and it is said: “The bhikkhus in such-and-such a dwelling place are faithful and confident, they are virtuous, and they are hospitable.” When the bhikkhus

original: dūratopi enti, tesaṃ nevāsikā vattaṃ karonti, samīpaṃ āgantvā vuḍḍhataraṃ āgantukaṃ
analyzed: dūratas pi enti tesam nevāsikāḥ vattam karonti samīpam āgantvā vuḍḍhataram āgantukam
translated: hear that, they come even from afar. The residents do the duties for them. When they have come near, they pay respect to the more senior visitors

analyzed: vanditvā nisīdanti navakatarassa santike āsanam gahetvā nisīdanti nisīditvā imasmin
translated: and sit down. They take a seat near the more junior visitors and sit down. After sitting down, they ask: “Is there any work to be done?

original: vihāre vasissatha gamissathā”ti pucchanti. ‘Gamissāmī’ti vutte – “sappāyaṃ senāsanaṃ,🔽sulabhā bhikkhā”tiādīni vatvā gantuṃ na denti. Vinayadharo ce hoti, tassa santike🔽vinayaṃ sajjhāyanti. Suttantādidharo ce, tassa santike taṃ taṃ dhammaṃ sajjhāyanti.
analyzed: vihāre vasissatha gamissatha ati pucchanti gamissāmi iti vutte sappāyam senāsanam  sulabhā bhikkhā ati ādīni vatvā gantum na denti vinaya dharo ce hoti tassa santike  vinayam sajjhāyanti suttanta ādi dharo ce tassa santike tam tam dhammam sajjhāyanti
translated: “Are you going to live in the monastery or are you going to leave?” If they say, “We’re going to leave,” they say, “The dwelling is suitable.🔽The alms are easy to get,” and so on, and they don’t let them go. If the visitors are experts in the Monastic Law, they recite the Monastic Law in their presence. If they are experts in the discourses, they recite the discourses in their presence.

original: Āgantukānaṃ therānaṃ ovāde ṭhatvā saha paṭisambhidāhi arahattaṃ pāpuṇanti. Āgantukā🔽“ekaṃ dve divasāni vasissāmāti āgatāmha, imesaṃ pana sukhasaṃvāsatāya dasadvādasavassāni
analyzed: āgantukānam therānam ovāde ṭhatvā saha paṭisambhidāhi arahattam pāpuṇanti āgantukā  ekam dve divasāni vasissāma ati āgatāmha imesam pana sukha saṃvāsa tāya dasa dvādasa vassāni
translated: The visitors live in accordance with the advice of the senior monks. They reach perfection, together with the analytic knowledges. The visitors say,

analyzed: vasissāma ati vattāraḥ honti evam ettha hāni vuddhiyaḥ veditabbā
translated: “We came for one or two days, but we’ll stay for ten or twelve years because of the pleasant company.” This is how the decline and growth should be understood in this case.

original: 137. Dutiyasattake kammaṃ ārāmo etesanti kammārāmāti. Kamme ratāti kammaratā. Kammārāmatamanuyuttāti
analyzed: dutiya sattake kammaṃ ārāmaḥ etesanti kamma ārāmā ati kamme ratā ati kamma ratā
translated: In the second triad, those who delight in work are those who delight in work. Those who delight in work are those who delight in work. Those who are devoted to delighting in work are those who are devoted to work.

analyzed: yuttā payuttā anuyuttā tattha kamman ti itikātabba kammam vuccati seyyathīdam cīvara vicāraṇam
translated: Herein, work is called what should be done, such as the consideration of robes,

translated: Making a robe, making a support for the bowl, making a bag for the bowl, making a bag for the bathing-cloth, making a waistband,

original: nāma. Yo pana rattindivaṃ dhammaṃ katheti, pañhaṃ vissajjeti, ayaṃ appabhassova bhasse🔽pariyantakārīyeva. Kasmā? “Sannipatitānaṃ vo, bhikkhave, dvayaṃ karaṇīyaṃ – dhammī
analyzed: nāma yaḥ pana rattindivam dhammam katheti pañham vissajjeti ayam appa bhassaḥ uva bhasse  kasmā sannipatitānam vaḥ bhikkhave dvayam karaṇīyam dhammī
translated: But one who teaches the Dhamma or answers questions day and night is one who speaks only as much as is appropriate.

original: vā kathā, ariyo vā tuṇhībhāvo”ti vuttattā.
analyzed: vā kathā ariyaḥ vā tuṇhībhāvaḥ ti vutta ttā
translated: He is one who speaks only as much as is necessary. Why? Because it is said: “Bhikkhus, there are these two things that should be cultivated. Conversation on the Dhamma and noble silence” .

original: Na niddārāmāti ettha yo gacchantopi nisinnopi nipannopi thinamiddhābhibhūto niddāyatiyeva,
analyzed: na ettha yaḥ gacchantaḥ api nisinnaḥ api nipannaḥ api thina middha abhibhūtaḥ
translated: Not delighting in sleep: here one who is overcome by sloth and torpor sleeps whether he is walking, sitting, or lying down.

original: ayaṃ niddārāmo nāma. Yassa pana karajakāyagelaññena cittaṃ bhavaṅge otarati, nāyaṃ🔽niddārāmo. Tenevāha – “abhijānāmahaṃ aggivessana, gimhānaṃ pacchime māse pacchābhattaṃ
analyzed: ayam niddārāmaḥ nāma yassa pana karaja kāya gelaññena cittam bhavaṅge otarati na ayam  niddārāmaḥ tena iva āha abhijānāmaham aggivessana gimhānam pacchime māse pacchābhattam
translated: He is called one who delights in sleep. But when consciousness descends into the life-continuum through the flaccidity of the physical body,

original: piṇḍapātappaṭikkanto catugguṇaṃ saṅghāṭiṃ paññapetvā dakkhiṇena passena sato sampajāno niddaṃ okkamitā”ti.
analyzed: piṇḍapāta paṭikkantaḥ catugguṇam saṅghāṭim paññapetvā dakkhiṇena passena sataḥ sampajānaḥ niddam okkamitā ti
translated: that is not delight in sleep. Hence it is said: “I remember one occasion, Aggivessana, in the last month of the hot season, after finishing my alms round I went to the bank of the Hiraññavati River, spread out my outer robe on the sand, and lay down on my right side. Mindfully and with clear comprehension I entered into the attainment of the first jhāna” .

original: Na saṅgaṇikārāmāti ettha yo ekassa dutiyo dvinnaṃ tatiyo tiṇṇaṃ catutthoti evaṃ saṃsaṭṭhova
analyzed: na saṅgaṇikā rāmā ti ettha yaḥ ekassa dutiyaḥ dvinnam tatiyaḥ tiṇṇam catutthaḥ ti evam saṃsaṭṭhaḥ uva
translated: Not delighting in company: here one who is a companion to one, a companion to two, a companion to three, and so on, who is thus entangled

original: viharati, ekako assādaṃ na labhati, ayaṃ saṅgaṇikārāmo. Yo pana catūsu iriyāpathesu
analyzed: viharati ekakaḥ assādam na labhati ayam saṅgaṇikā ārāmaḥ yaḥ pana catūsu iriyāpathesu
translated: he does not get satisfaction when he is alone, this is one who delights in company.

original: ekako assādaṃ labhati, nāyaṃ saṅgaṇikārāmoti veditabbo.
analyzed: ekakaḥ assādam labhati na ayam saṅgaṇikā ārāmaḥ iti veditabbo
translated: He who does not find satisfaction in being alone is called one who delights in company. But he who finds satisfaction in being alone should be understood as not one who delights in company.

original: Na pāpicchāti ettha asantasambhāvanāya icchāya samannāgatā dussīlā pāpicchā nāma.
analyzed: na pāpa icchā ati ettha asanta sambhāvanāya icchāya samannāgatā dussīlā pāpa icchā nāma
translated: Not of evil wishes: those who are unvirtuous are called those of evil wishes because they are possessed by a wish for what is not good.

original: Na pāpamittādīsu pāpā mittā etesanti pāpamittā. Catūsu iriyāpathesu saha ayanato pāpā sahāyā etesanti pāpasahāyā. Tanninnatappoṇatappabbhāratāya pāpesu sampavaṅkāti pāpasampavaṅkā.
analyzed: na pāpa mitta ādīsu pāpāḥ mittāḥ etesanti pāpa mittā catūsu iriyāpathesu saha ayanataḥ pāpā sahāyāḥ etesanti pāpa sahāyā pāpa sahāyā pāpesu sampavaṅkā ati pāpa sampavaṅkā
translated: Not of evil friends, etc.: those who have evil friends are called those of evil friends. Those who have evil companions are called those of evil companions because they are accompanied by evil in the four modes of deportment. Those who are completely given over to evil are called those completely given over to evil because they are devoted to evil by reason of their inclination, tendency, and proclivity.🔽With a mere little: with a mere small amount, with a mere bit.

original: Oramattakenāti avaramattakena appamattakena. Antarāti arahattaṃ apatvāva etthantare.
analyzed: ora mattakena ati avara mattakena appamattakena antarā ati arahattam ettha antare
translated: In the interval: before reaching arahatship.

original: Vosānanti pariniṭṭhitabhāvaṃ – “alamettāvatā”ti osakkanaṃ ṭhitakiccataṃ. Idaṃ vuttaṃ
analyzed: vosānam ti pariniṭṭhita bhāvam alam ettāvatā iti osakkanam idam vuttam
translated: Cessation: the state of completion. Relinquishment: the state of standing still, thinking, “This much is enough.” This is what is meant.

original: hoti – “yāva sīlapārisuddhimattena vā vipassanāmattena vā jhānamattena vā sotāpannabhāvamattena
analyzed: hoti yāva sīla pārisuddhi mattena vā vipassanā mattena vā jhāna mattena vā sotāpanna bhāva mattena
translated: “As far as the purity of virtue, the purity of insight, the jhāna attainment, the attainment of the fruit of stream-entry,

original: vā sakadāgāmibhāvamattena vā anāgāmibhāvamattena vā vosānaṃ na āpajjissanti, tāva
analyzed: vā sakadāgāmi bhāva mattena vā anāgāmi bhāva mattena vā vosānam na āpajjissanti tāva
translated: they will not come to a standstill with just the state of a Once-Returner or with just the state of a Non-Returner,

original: vuddhiyeva bhikkhūnaṃ pāṭikaṅkhā, no parihānī”ti.
analyzed: vuddhiyā iva bhikkhūnam pāṭikaṅkhā no parihāni iti
translated: but they can expect growth, not decline.”

original: 138. Tatiyasattake saddhāti saddhāsampannā. Tattha āgamanīyasaddhā, adhigamasaddhā,🔽pasādasaddhā, okappanasaddhāti catubbidhā saddhā. Tattha āgamanīyasaddhā sabbaññubodhisattānaṃ
analyzed: tatiya sattake saddhā ati saddhā sampannā tattha āgamanīya saddhā adhigama saddhā  pasāda saddhā okappana saddhā ati catubbidhā saddhā tattha āgamanīya saddhā sabbaññu bodhisattānam
translated: In the third triad “endowed with faith” : here there are four kinds of faith: faith as coming , faith as attainment ,

original: hoti. Adhigamasaddhā ariyapuggalānaṃ. Buddho dhammo saṅghoti vutte pana pasādo pasādasaddhā.
analyzed: hoti adhigama saddhā ariya puggalānam buddhaḥ dhammo saṅghaḥ ti vutte pana pasādaḥ pasāda saddhā
translated: faith as confidence , and faith as preference . Herein, faith as coming is in all-knowing Bodhisattas. Faith as attainment is in Noble Persons. But when the Buddha, the Dhamma, and the Sangha are mentioned, confidence is faith as confidence.

original: Okappetvā pakappetvā pana saddahanaṃ okappanasaddhā. Sā duvidhāpi idhādhippetā. Tāya🔽hi saddhāya samannāgato saddhāvimutto, vakkalittherasadiso hoti. Tassa hi cetiyaṅgaṇavattaṃ
analyzed: okappetvā pakappetvā pana saddahanam okappana saddhā sā duvidhā api idha adhippetā tāya  hi saddhāya samannāgataḥ saddhā vimuttaḥ vakkalitthera sadisaḥ hoti tassa hi cetiyaṅgaṇa vattam
translated: And after preference and choice, there is the believing in faith as preference. And both these kinds are intended here.🔽For one who is endowed with this faith is a faith-liberated bhikkhu like the Elder Vakkali. For he had only to make a shrine terrace or a Bo tree terrace and all the duties were done for him.

original: vā, bodhiyaṅgaṇavattaṃ vā katameva hoti. Upajjhāyavattaācariyavattādīni sabbavattāni
analyzed: vā bodhiyaṅgaṇa vattam vā katamā eva hoti upajjhāya vatta ācariya vatta ādīni sabba vattāni
translated: And all the duties of a preceptor, a teacher, and so on,

original: pūreti. Hirimanāti pāpajigucchanalakkhaṇāya hiriyā yuttacittā. Ottappīti pāpato bhāyanalakkhaṇena🔽ottappena samannāgatā.
analyzed: pūreti hirimanā ati pāpa jigucchana lakkhaṇāya hiriyā yutta cittā ottappī iti pāpataḥ bhāyana lakkhaṇena  ottappena samannāgatā
translated: He is endowed with a sense of moral shame, that is, with a mind possessed of the characteristic of abhorrence of evil. He is endowed with moral dread, that is, with a mind possessed of the characteristic of fear of the evil .

original: Bahussutāti ettha pana pariyattibahussuto, paṭivedhabahussutoti dve bahussutā. Pariyattīti
analyzed: bahussutā ati ettha pana pariyatti bahussuto paṭivedha bahussuto ti dve bahussutā pariyattī iti
translated: He is learned, that is, he is one of two kinds: learned in the scriptures and learned in the supermundane .

original: tīṇi piṭakāni. Paṭivedhoti saccappaṭivedho. Imasmiṃ pana ṭhāne pariyatti adhippetā.
analyzed: tīṇi piṭakāni paṭivedhaḥ ti sacca paṭivedhaḥ imasmim pana ṭhāne pariyatti adhippetā
translated: Herein, the scriptures are the three Piṭakas. The supermundane is the penetration of the truths. But in this context the scriptures are intended.

original: Sā yena bahu sutā, so bahussuto. So panesa nissayamuccanako, parisupaṭṭhāko, bhikkhunovādako,
analyzed: sā yena bahu sutā so bahussuto so pana isa nissayamuccanako parisupaṭṭhāko bhikkhunovādako
translated: He who has heard much is called “learned” . He is of four kinds as one who has heard much for himself, as one who has heard much for others, as one who has heard much for both himself and others, and as one who has heard much everywhere.

original: sabbatthakabahussutoti catubbidho hoti. Tattha tayo bahussutā samantapāsādikāya vinayaṭṭhakathāya
analyzed: sabbatthaka bahussuto ti catubbidhaḥ hoti tattha tayaḥ bahussutā samantapāsādikāya vinayaṭṭhakathāya
translated: Herein, the first three kinds of learned one should be understood as stated in the Commentary on the Chapter on Conduct in the section on the learned disciple who gives advice .

original: ovādavagge vuttanayena gahetabbā. Sabbatthakabahussutā pana ānandattherasadisā honti. Te idha adhippetā.
analyzed: ovāda vagge vutta nayena gahetabbā sabbatthaka bahussutā pana ānanda tthera sadisāḥ honti te idha adhippetā
translated: But the one who has heard much everywhere is like the Elder Ānanda. He is intended here.

original: Āraddhavīriyāti yesaṃ kāyikañca cetasikañca vīriyaṃ āraddhaṃ hoti. Tattha ye kāyasaṅgaṇikaṃ
analyzed: āraddha vīriyā ti yesam kāyikam ca cetasikam ca vīriyam āraddham hoti tattha ye kāya saṅgaṇikam
translated: He is energetic, that is, he is one in whom bodily and mentally inceptive energy is aroused. analyzed: āvi ca iva raho ca ati sammukhā ca parammukhā ca tattha navakānam cīvara kamma ādīsu sahāya bhāva gamanaṃ  sammukhāḥ mettam kāyakammam nāma therānam pana pāda dhovana vandana bījana dāna ādi bhedam  sabbam sāmīcikammam sammukhā mettam kāya kammam nāma ubhayehi pi dunnikkhittānam dāru bhaṇḍa ādīnam
translated: Face to face and behind the back: face to face and out of sight. original: tesu avamaññaṃ akatvā attanā dunnikkhittānaṃ viya paṭisāmanaṃ parammukhā mettaṃ kāyakammaṃ nāma.🔽Devatthero tissattheroti evaṃ paggayha vacanaṃ sammukhā mettaṃ vacīkammaṃ nāma. Vihāre
analyzed: tesu avamaññam a katvā attanā dunnikkhittānam viya paṭisāmanam parammukhā mettam kāyakammam nāma  deva thero tissa thero ti evam paggayha vacanam sammukhāḥ mettam vacīkammam nāma vihāre
translated: is a friendly action of body face to face. original: asantaṃ pana paṭipucchantassa kuhiṃ amhākaṃ devatthero, kuhiṃ amhākaṃ tissatthero,

translated: is a friendly action of speech face to face. But the speaking of words of praise for the elders out of sight, saying, “Where is our elder so-and-so? Where is our venerable one so-and-so?
