analyzed: pucchi cattāraḥ mahā rājānaḥ upāsikā iti tāta tvam catūhi mahā rājehi mahantataraḥ iti
translated: “The Four Great Kings.” “Dear Sir, are you greater than the Four Great Kings?”

original: Ārāmikasadisā ete upāsike, amhākaṃ satthu paṭisandhiggahaṇato paṭṭhāya khaggahatthā🔽hutvā ārakkhaṃ akaṃsūti. Tesaṃ tāta, gatāvasāne ko āgatoti? Sakko devānamindoti.
analyzed: ārāmika sadisāḥ ete upāsike amhākam satthu paṭisandhi ggahaṇato paṭṭhāya khagga hatthā  hutvā ārakkham akaṃsu iti tesam tāta gata avasāne kaḥ āgataḥ iti sakkaḥ devānamindo ti
translated: “These lay disciples are like the slaves in the monastery; ever since the time when our Teacher took his stand upon the earth, they have stood guard over him with drawn swords.” “Dear Sir, who came after them?”🔽“Sakka Ruler of Gods.” “Dear Sir, are you greater than the Ruler of Gods?”

original: Devarājatopi tvaṃ tāta, mahantataroti? Bhaṇḍagāhakasāmaṇerasadiso esa upāsike, amhākaṃ🔽satthu tāvatiṃsato otaraṇakāle pattacīvaraṃ gahetvā otiṇṇoti. Tassa tāta gatāvasāne
analyzed: tvam tāta bhaṇḍa gāhaka sāmaṇera sadisaḥ esaḥ upāsike amhākam  satthu tāvatiṃsataḥ otaraṇa kāle patta cīvaram gahetvā otiṇṇoti tassa tāta gata avasāne
translated: “This lay disciple is like the novice Bhandagāhaka; when our Teacher descended from the World of the Gods, he descended carrying the bowl and robe.” “Dear Sir, who came after him?”

original: jotamāno viya ko āgatoti? Upāsike tuyhaṃ bhagavā ca satthā ca mahābrahmā nāma esoti.
analyzed: jotamānaḥ viya kaḥ āgataḥ iti upāsike tuyham bhagavā ca satthā ca mahābrahmā nāma eso ti
translated: “The lay disciple Jyotiṣka.” “Dear Sir, is your Teacher the Exalted One greater than Jyotiṣka?” “Dear Sir, the Exalted One is the Teacher of us all; he is Mahā-Brahmā.”

original: Mayhaṃ bhagavato mahābrahmatopi tvaṃ tāta mahantataroti? Āma upāsike, ete nāma kira
analyzed: tvam tāta tvam tāta upāsike ete nāma kira
translated: “But, dear Sir, you are greater than the Great Brahmā himself?”

original: amhākaṃ satthu jātadivase cattāro mahābrahmāno mahāpurisaṃ suvaṇṇajālena paṭiggaṇhiṃsūti.
analyzed: amhākam satthu jāta divase cattāro mahābrahmānaḥ mahāpurisam suvaṇṇa jālena paṭiggaṇhiṃsu iti
translated: “Yes, lay disciple, these four Great Brahmās received the Great Man in their golden nets on the day of my Master’s birth.”

original: Atha brāhmaṇiyā – “puttassa tāva me ayaṃ ānubhāvo, kīdiso vata mayhaṃ puttassa bhagavato
analyzed: atha brāhmaṇiyā puttassa tāva me ayaṃ ānubhāvaḥ kīdisaḥ vata mayham puttassa bhagavato
translated: Then the thought occurred to the brāhmaṇī: “This is the power of my son. But what will be the power of my son, the Exalted One?”

original: satthu ānubhāvo bhavissatī”ti cintayantiyā sahasā pañcavaṇṇā pīti uppajjitvā sakalasarīre
analyzed: satthu ānubhāvaḥ bhavissati iti cintayantiyā sahasā pañca vaṇṇā pīti uppajjitvā sakala sarīre
translated: And as she thought thus, a thrill of joy ran through her whole body.

original: phari. Thero – “uppannaṃ me mātu pītisomanassaṃ, ayaṃ dāni kālo dhammadesanāyā”ti🔽cintetvā – “kiṃ cintesi mahāupāsike”ti āha. Sā – “puttassa tāva me ayaṃ guṇo, satthu
analyzed: theraḥ uppannam me mātu pīti somanassam ayam dāni kālaḥ dhamma desanāya ati  cintetvā kim cintesi mahā upāsikā iti āha sā puttassa tāva me ayam guṇo satthu
translated: The Elder thought: “My mother has experienced joy and gladness. This is the time to preach the Law to her.”🔽And he asked: “What were you thinking of, lay disciple?”

original: panassa kīdiso guṇo bhavissatīti idaṃ, tāta, cintemī”ti āha. Mahāupāsike, mayhaṃ
analyzed: panassa kīdisaḥ guṇaḥ bhavissati iti idam tāta cintemi iti āha mahā upāsike mayham
translated: She replied: “I was thinking: ‘This is the power of my son. But what will be the power of my son, the Master?’”🔽“Lay disciple, at the moment of my birth, at the moment of my Great Renunciation, at the moment of my Enlightenment, and at the moment of my first preaching of the Law,

original: satthu jātakkhaṇe, mahābhinikkhamane, sambodhiyaṃ, dhammacakkappavattane ca dasasahassilokadhātu
analyzed: satthu jāta kkhaṇe mahā abhinikkhamane sambodhiyam dhamma cakka ppavattane ca dasa sahassi lokadhātu
translated: the ten thousand world systems

original: kampittha, sīlena samādhinā paññāya vimuttiyā vimuttiñāṇadassanena samo nāma natthi,
analyzed: kampittha sīlena samādhinā paññāya vimuttiyā vimutti ñāṇa dassanena samaḥ nāma natthi
translated: “There is no one equal to the Exalted One in virtue, concentration, wisdom, emancipation, or knowledge and vision of emancipation.”

original: itipi so bhagavāti vitthāretvā buddhaguṇappaṭisaṃyuttaṃ dhammadesanaṃ kathesi.🔽Brāhmaṇī piyaputtassa dhammadesanāpariyosāne sotāpattiphale patiṭṭhāya puttaṃ āha🔽– “tāta, upatissa, kasmā evamakāsi, evarūpaṃ nāma amataṃ mayhaṃ ettakaṃ kālaṃ na🔽adāsī”ti. Thero – “dinnaṃ dāni me mātu rūpasāriyā brāhmaṇiyā posāvanikamūlaṃ, ettakena
analyzed: iti pi saḥ bhagavā ati vitthāretvā buddha guṇa paṭisaṃyuttam dhamma desanam kathesi  brāhmaṇī piya puttassa dhamma desanā pariyosāne sotāpatti phale patiṭṭhāya puttam āha  tāta upatissa kasmai evam akāsi evarūpam nāma amatam mayham ettakam kālam na  theraḥ  dinnam dāni me mātu rūpasāriyā brāhmaṇiyā posāvanika mūlam ettakena
translated: And he preached the Dhamma in detail, expounding the virtues of the Buddha.

original: vaṭṭissatī”ti cintetvā “gaccha mahāupāsike”ti brāhmaṇiṃ uyyojetvā “cunda kā velā”ti
analyzed: vaṭṭissati iti cintetvā gaccha mahā upāsikā iti brāhmaṇim uyyojetvā cunda kā velā ati
translated: At the conclusion of the discourse the Brahman lady attained the Fruit of Conversion. Thereupon she said to her son, “Dear Upatissa, why did you do this thing? For all this time you have not given me the ambrosial taste of the Buddha’s word. ” The Elder thought to himself, “Now I have paid the Brahman lady Rōhini the price of her nursing, and with this much it will be sufficient for me.” So he said to the Brahman lady, “Go, lay disciple.” Then he said to Cunda, “What time is it, Cunda?”🔽“It is the time of the strong dawn, Reverend Sir.”

original: āha. Balavapaccūsakālo, bhanteti. Tena hi bhikkhusaṅghaṃ sannipātehīti. Sannipatito,
analyzed: āha balava paccūsa kālaḥ bhante ti tena hi bhikkhu saṅgham sannipātehi iti sannipatitaḥ
translated: “Well then, assemble the Congregation of Monks.”🔽“The Congregation has already assembled, Reverend Sir.”

original: bhante, saṅghoti. Maṃ ukkhipitvā nisīdāpehi cundāti ukkhipitvā nisīdāpesi. Thero
analyzed: bhante saṅghaḥ iti mama ukkhipitvā nisīda apehi cunda ati ukkhipitvā nisīdāpesi theraḥ
translated: “Well then, Cunda, have me lifted up and seated.” So they lifted him up and seated him.

original: bhikkhū āmantesi – “āvuso catucattālīsaṃ vo vassāni mayā saddhiṃ vicarantānaṃ yaṃ🔽me kāyikaṃ vā vācasikaṃ vā na rocetha, khamatha taṃ āvusoti. Ettakaṃ, bhante, amhākaṃ🔽chāyā viya tumhe amuñcitvā vicarantānaṃ aruccanakaṃ nāma natthi, tumhe pana amhākaṃ🔽khamathāti. Atha thero aruṇasikhāya paññāyamānāya mahāpathaviṃ unnādayanto anupādisesāya
analyzed: bhikkhū āmantesi āvuso catucattālīsam vaḥ vassāni mayā saddhim vicarantānam yaṃ  me kāyikam vā vācasikam vā na rocetha khamatha tam āvuso ti ettakam bhante amhākam  chāyā viya tumhe a muñcitvā vicarantānam aruccanakam nāma natthi tumhe pana amhākam  khamatha ati atha theraḥ aruṇasikhāya paññāyamānāya mahā pathavim unnādayantaḥ anupādisesāya
translated: He addressed the monks, saying: “Friends, you have wandered about with me for forty-four years.

original: nibbānadhātuyā parinibbāyi. Bahū devamanussā therassa parinibbāne sakkāraṃ kariṃsu.
analyzed: nibbānadhātuyā parinibbāyi bahū deva manussā therassa parinibbāne sakkāram kariṃsu
translated: If there is anything that you have not liked in my bodily or verbal action, forgive me, friends.” “Reverend Sir, we have wandered about with you, never leaving your shadow, for so long. There is nothing that we have not liked. But we ask you to forgive us.” Then, as the dawn was breaking, the Elder, making the great earth tremble, attained Nibbāna in the element of Nibbāna that is without attachment. Many gods and men paid homage to the Elder’s body.

original: Āyasmā cundo therassa pattacīvarañca dhātuparissāvanañca gahetvā jetavanaṃ gantvā🔽ānandattheraṃ gahetvā bhagavantaṃ upasaṅkami. Bhagavā dhātuparissāvanaṃ gahetvā pañcahi
analyzed: āyasmā cundaḥ therassa patta cīvarañca dhātu parissāvanañca gahetvā jetavanam gantvā  ānanda ttheram gahetvā bhagavantam upasaṅkami bhagavā dhātu parissāvanam gahetvā pañcahi
translated: The venerable Cunda took the Elder’s bowl and robe and the water with which he had bathed the body, and, accompanied by the Elder Ānanda, he went to Jeta’s Grove.

original: gāthāsatehi therassa guṇaṃ kathetvā dhātucetiyaṃ kārāpetvā rājagahagamanatthāya ānandattherassa
analyzed: gāthā satehi therassa guṇam kathetvā dhātu cetiyam kārāpetvā rājagaha gamana atthāya ānanda therassa
translated: The Exalted One took the water in which the Elder’s body had been bathed, and, after extolling the Elder’s virtues in five hundred stanzas, he had a shrine erected for the water. Then, in order to go to Rājagaha, he took leave of the Elder Ānanda.

original: saññaṃ adāsi. Thero bhikkhūnaṃ ārocesi. Bhagavā mahābhikkhusaṅghaparivuto rājagahaṃ
analyzed: saññam adāsi theraḥ bhikkhūnam ārocesi bhagavā mahā bhikkhu saṅgha parivutaḥ rājagaham
translated: and gave it to the monks. The Elder told the monks. The Fortunate One, surrounded by a great Saṅgha of monks, went to Rājagaha.

original: agamāsi. Tattha gatakāle mahāmoggallānatthero parinibbāyi. Bhagavā tassa dhātuyo
analyzed: agamāsi tattha gata kāle mahāmoggallāna thero parinibbāyi bhagavā tassa dhātuyaḥ
translated: When he had gone there, the Elder Mahāmoggallāna attained Final Emancipation. The Fortunate One,

original: gahetvā cetiyaṃ kārāpetvā rājagahato nikkhamitvā anupubbena gaṅgābhimukho gantvā🔽ukkacelaṃ agamāsi. Tattha gaṅgātīre bhikkhusaṅghaparivuto nisīditvā tattha sāriputtamoggallānānaṃ
analyzed: gahetvā cetiyam kārāpetvā rājagahataḥ nikkhamitvā anupubbena gaṅgā abhimukhaḥ gantvā  ukka celam agamāsi tattha gaṅgā tīre bhikkhu saṅgha parivutaḥ nisīditvā tattha sāriputta moggallānānam
translated: having taken his bodily relics, had a Shrine made, and after leaving Rājagaha, he gradually went to the Ganges, and

original: parinibbānappaṭisaṃyuttaṃ suttaṃ desetvā ukkacelato nikkhamitvā vesāliṃ agamāsi.
analyzed: parinibbāna paṭisaṃyuttam suttam desetvā ukka celataḥ nikkhamitvā vesālim agamāsi
translated: went to Ukkacela. There, on the bank of the Ganges, sitting surrounded by the Saṅgha of monks, he taught the Discourse connected with the Final Emancipation of Sāriputta and Moggallāna, and after leaving Ukkacela he went to Vesālī.

original: Evaṃ gate atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya vesāliṃ piṇḍāya
analyzed: evam gate atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇha samayam nivāsetvā patta cīvaram ādāya vesālim piṇḍāya
translated: After going (there), then the Fortunate One, having dressed in the morning time, after picking up his bowl and robe, entered Vesālī for alms.

original: pāvisīti ayamettha anupubbī kathā.
analyzed: pāvisi iti ayam ettha anupubbī kathā
translated: This is the sequence here.

original: Nisīdananti ettha cammakkhaṇḍaṃ adhippetaṃ. Udenacetiyanti udenayakkhassa cetiyaṭṭhāne
analyzed: nisīdanam ti ettha cammakkhaṇḍam adhippetam udena cetiyanti udena yakkhassa cetiya ṭṭhāne
translated: As to ‘seat’: here a piece of leather is intended. Udena Shrine: in the place of the Shrine of the Yakkha Udena.

original: katavihāro vuccati. Gotamakādīsupi eseva nayo. Bhāvitāti vaḍḍhitā. Bahulīkatāti punappunaṃ🔽katā. Yānīkatāti yuttayānaṃ viya katā. Vatthukatāti patiṭṭhānaṭṭhena vatthu viya
analyzed: kata vihāraḥ vuccati gotamaka ādīsu pi esā iva nayaḥ bhāvitā ati vaḍḍhitā bahulīkatā ati punappunam  katā yā anīka tā ati yutta yānam viya katā vatthukatā ati patiṭṭhāna ṭṭhena vatthu viya
translated: is called “lived in.” The same method applies in the case of Gotamaka, etc. “Developed” means “increased.” “Repeatedly practiced” means “done again and again.” “Practiced much” means “done much.” “Made the vehicle” means “made the vehicle” as a vehicle is made. “Made the basis” means “made the basis” as a basis is made.

original: katā. Anuṭṭhitāti adhiṭṭhitā. Paricitāti samantato citā suvaḍḍhitā. Susamāraddhāti suṭṭhu samāraddhā.
analyzed: katā anuṭṭhitā ati adhiṭṭhitā paricitā ati samantataḥ citā su vaḍḍhitā su samāraddhā ati suṭṭhu samāraddhā
translated: “He has lived the life” is said. The same method applies to Gotamaka and the rest. “He has developed” means he has increased. “He has made much of” means he has done again and again. “He has made a vehicle” means he has made a vehicle as if it were yoked. “He has made a basis” means he has made a basis as if it were a basis in the sense of a foundation. “He has made it his own” means he has made it his own. “He has made it familiar” means he has made it familiar all round, well increased. “He has undertaken it well” means he has undertaken it well.

original: Iti aniyamena kathetvā puna niyametvā dassento tathāgatassa khotiādimāha. Ettha ca
analyzed: iti aniyamena kathetvā puna niyametvā dassentaḥ tathāgatassa kho ti ādim āha ettha ca
translated: Having spoken in this way without restriction, he now said “The Tathagata, bhikkhus” in order to show it with restriction. And here

original: kappanti āyukappaṃ. Tasmiṃ tasmiṃ kāle yaṃ manussānaṃ āyuppamāṇaṃ hoti, taṃ paripuṇṇaṃ
analyzed: kappanti āyu kappam tasmin tasmin kāle yam manussānam āyu ppamāṇam hoti tam paripuṇṇam
translated: “an aeon” is a life-span. He could live on completing the life-span that is the measure of life for human beings at that time.

original: karonto tiṭṭheyya. Kappāvasesaṃ vāti – “appaṃ vā bhiyyo”ti vuttavassasatato atirekaṃ
analyzed: karontaḥ tiṭṭheyya kappa avasesam vā ti appam vā bhiyyas ti vutta vassa satataḥ atirekam
translated: “The remainder of the aeon” is more than the remaining hundred years mentioned in the words “or less” .

original: vā. Mahāsīvatthero panāha – “buddhānaṃ aṭṭhāne gajjitaṃ nāma natthi. Yatheva hi veḷuvagāmake
analyzed: vā mahāsīva theraḥ pana āha buddhānam aṭṭhāne gajjitam nāma natthi yathā iva hi veḷuva gāmake
translated: But the Elder Maha Siva said: “The Buddhas have no such thing as a false cry. For just as in the village of Veḷuva

original: uppannaṃ māraṇantikaṃ vedanaṃ dasa māse vikkhambheti, evaṃ punappunaṃ taṃ samāpattiṃ🔽samāpajjitvā dasa dasa māse vikkhambhento imaṃ bhaddakappameva tiṭṭheyya, kasmā pana🔽na ṭhitoti? Upādinnakasarīraṃ nāma khaṇḍiccādīhi abhibhuyyati, buddhā ca khaṇḍiccādibhāvaṃ🔽apatvā pañcame āyukoṭṭhāse bahujanassa piyamanāpakāleyeva parinibbāyanti. Buddhānubuddhesu🔽ca mahāsāvakesu parinibbutesu ekakeneva khāṇukena viya ṭhātabbaṃ hoti, daharasāmaṇeraparivāritena
analyzed: uppannam māraṇa antikam vedanam dasa māse vikkhambheti evam punappunam tam samāpattim  samāpajjitvā dasa dasa māse vikkhambhentaḥ imam bhadda kappam eva tiṭṭheyya kasmā pana  na upādinnaka sarīram nāma khaṇḍicca ādīhi buddhā ca khaṇḍicca ādi bhāvam  a patvā pañcame āyu koṭṭhāse bahu janassa piya manāpa kāleya iva parinibbāyanti buddha anubuddhesu  ca mahāsāvakesu parinibbutesu ekakena iva khāṇukena viya ṭhātabbam hoti dahara sāmaṇera parivāritena
translated: and he suppresses the arisen mortal pain for ten months. Thus he would remain in this auspicious aeon, entering upon and emerging from that attainment again and again,🔽and suppressing it for ten months each time. But why does he not remain? Because a body that is still subject to kamma-result is overcome by the effects of past kamma in the form of breaking up, etc.,🔽and Buddhas do not attain final Nibbāna until they have become free from all such effects. And when the Buddhas and their chief disciples have attained final Nibbāna, there is no one left to support the Dispensation, which therefore breaks up like a chariot without a charioteer.🔽🔽And when the great disciples have attained final Nibbāna, the Buddha’s chief disciples, who were like the Buddha’s own trunk, are no more. There remains only the trunk, and it has to be supported by the branches, that is, by the elder bhikkhus.🔽

original: vā. Tato – ‘aho buddhānaṃ parisā’ti hīḷetabbataṃ āpajjeyya. Tasmā na ṭhito”ti. Evaṃ
analyzed: vā tatas aho buddhānam parisā ati hīḷetabbatam āpajjeyya tasmā na ṭhitaḥ iti evam
translated: and he suppresses the arisen mortal pain for ten months. Thus he would remain in this fortunate aeon by repeatedly entering upon that attainment and suppressing the pain for ten months at a time. But why does he not remain? Because a body that is still subject to cankers is overcome by the breaking up of the body’s components, etc., and Buddhas attain final Nibbāna without having their bodies broken up by such things. And when the Buddhas and their chief disciples have attained final Nibbāna, it would be necessary for him to remain alone with only a single tree stump left, or surrounded by young bhikkhus and novices. Then he would be open to the criticism, “Oh, the Buddha’s following is a small one!” That is why he does not remain.”

original: vuttepi so na ruccati, “āyukappo”ti idameva aṭṭhakathāyaṃ niyamitaṃ.
analyzed: vutte api so na ruccati āyu kappo ti idam eva aṭṭhakathā ayam niyamitam
translated: Even when this is said, he is not satisfied. Only this is settled in the commentary:

original: 167. Yathā taṃ mārena pariyuṭṭhitacittoti ettha tanti nipātamattaṃ. Yathā mārena
analyzed: yathā tam mārena ettha nipāta mattam yathā mārena
translated: “As though his mind was possessed by Mara”: the word “as though” is merely an expression.

original: pariyuṭṭhitacitto ajjhotthaṭacitto aññopi koci puthujjano paṭivijjhituṃ na sakkuṇeyya,🔽evameva nāsakkhi paṭivijjhitunti attho. Kiṃ kāraṇā? Māro hi yassa sabbena sabbaṃ🔽dvādasa vipallāsā appahīnā, tassa cittaṃ pariyuṭṭhāti. Therassa cattāro vipallāsā
analyzed: pariyuṭṭhita cittaḥ ajjhotthaṭa cittaḥ aññaḥ api koci puthujjanaḥ paṭivijjhitum na sakkuṇeyya  evam eva nā asakkhi paṭivijjhitunti atthaḥ kim kāraṇā māraḥ hi yassa sabbena sabbam  dvādasa vipallāsā appahīnā tassa cittam pariyuṭṭhāti therassa cattāro vipallāsā
translated: If anyone else, a worldling, were to have his mind obsessed and overwhelmed, he would not be able to penetrate.🔽The meaning is that he was not able to penetrate. Why? Because Mara’s obsession is with one whose twelve obsessions are unabandoned.

original: appahīnā, tenassa māro cittaṃ pariyuṭṭhāti. So pana cittapariyuṭṭhānaṃ karonto kiṃ🔽karotīti? Bheravaṃ rūpārammaṇaṃ vā dasseti, saddārammaṇaṃ vā sāveti, tato sattā taṃ
analyzed: appahīnā tena assa māro cittam pariyuṭṭhāti saḥ pana citta pariyuṭṭhānam karonto kim  karoti iti bheravam rūpa ārammaṇam vā dasseti sadda ārammaṇam vā sāveti tatas sattā tam
translated: And the Elder had not abandoned four obsessions, so Mara obsessed his mind. But what does he do in obsessing the mind?

original: disvā vā sutvā vā satiṃ vissajjetvā vivaṭamukhā honti. Tesaṃ mukhena hatthaṃ pavesetvā
analyzed: disvā vā sutvā vā satim vissajjetvā vivaṭa mukhāḥ honti tesam mukhena hattham pavesetvā
translated: He shows a terrifying object, a visible form or a sound. Then beings, on seeing or hearing it, lose their mindfulness and stand with their mouths open.

original: hadayaṃ maddati. Tato visaññāva hutvā tiṭṭhanti. Therassa panesa mukhena hatthaṃ
analyzed: hadayam maddati tatas visaññā ava hutvā tiṭṭhanti therassa pana isa mukhena hattham
translated: He inserts his hand into their mouths and crushes their hearts. Then they stand there as if unconscious.

original: pavesetuṃ kiṃ sakkhissati? Bheravārammaṇaṃ pana dasseti. Taṃ disvā thero nimittobhāsaṃ
analyzed: pavesetum kim sakkhissati bherava ārammaṇam pana dasseti tam disvā theraḥ nimitta ubhāsam
translated: But how could he insert his hand into the Elder’s mouth? He showed a terrifying object. On seeing it the Elder recognized the nimitta

original: na paṭivijjhi. Bhagavā jānantoyeva – “kimatthaṃ yāvatatiyaṃ āmantesī”ti? Parato “tiṭṭhatu,🔽bhante, bhagavā”ti yācite “tuyhevetaṃ dukkaṭaṃ, tuyhevetaṃ aparaddha”nti dosāropanena
analyzed: na paṭivijjhi bhagavā jānantaḥ yā iva kimattham yāvatatiyam āmantesi iti paratas tiṭṭhatu  bhante bhagavāti yācite tuyhā iva etam dukkaṭam tuyhā iva etam aparaddhanti dosa āropanena
translated: He did not penetrate it. The Blessed One, though he knew already, asked: “Why did you call me three times?” The other, when asked, said: “Let the Blessed One remain, venerable sir.” The Blessed One said: “It is your fault, it is your mistake.”

original: sokatanukaraṇatthaṃ.
analyzed: soka tanu karaṇa ttham
translated: He said this in order to lessen his sorrow by laying the blame on him.

original: Mārayācanakathāvaṇṇanā🔽168. Māro pāpimāti ettha māroti satte anatthe niyojento māretīti māro. Pāpimāti tasseva
analyzed: māra yācana kathā vaṇṇanā  māraḥ pāpimā ati ettha māro ti satte anatthe niyojentaḥ māreti iti māraḥ pāpimā ati tassa iva
translated: The explanation of the story of Mara’s request is ended.

original: vevacanaṃ. So hi pāpadhammasamannāgatattā “pāpimā”ti vuccati. Kaṇho, antako, namuci,🔽pamattabandhūtipi tasseva nāmāni. Bhāsitā kho panesāti ayañhi bhagavato sambodhipattiyā
analyzed: vevacanam so hi pāpa dhamma samannāgata ttā pāpimā iti vuccati kaṇhaḥ antakaḥ namuci  tassa iva nāmāni bhāsitā kho pana isā ati ayan hi bhagavato sambodhi pattiyā
translated: Mara the Evil One: here Mara is one who causes beings to be reborn in evil states, thus he is the evil one . Pāpimato is a synonym for him. He is called the evil one because he is endowed with evil states . He is also called Kaṇha , Antaka , Namuci , and Pamattabandhu .

original: aṭṭhame sattāhe bodhimaṇḍeyeva āgantvā – “bhagavā yadatthaṃ tumhehi pāramiyo pūritā,
analyzed: aṭṭhame sattāhe āgantvā bhagavā yadattham tumhehi pāramiyā pūritā
translated: Bhāsitā kho panesā : now, this is the story of the time when Mara came to the Blessed One in the eighth week after his enlightenment, while he was still at the foot of the Bodhi Tree. He said: “The purpose for which you fulfilled the perfections,

original: so vo attho anuppatto, paṭividdhaṃ sabbaññutaññāṇaṃ, kiṃ te lokavicāraṇenā”ti vatvā,
analyzed: saḥ vaḥ atthaḥ an uppattaḥ paṭividdham sabbaññuta ññāṇam kim te loka vicāraṇena ati vatvā
translated: that purpose has been attained by you. Omniscient knowledge has been penetrated by you. What have you to do with wandering for the world’s sake?”

original: yathā ajja, evameva “parinibbātu dāni, bhante, bhagavā”ti yāci. Bhagavā cassa – “na🔽tāvāha”ntiādīni vatvā paṭikkhipi. Taṃ sandhāya “bhāsitā kho panesā bhante”tiādimāha.🔽Tattha viyattāti maggavasena viyattā. Tatheva vinītā tathā visāradā. Bahussutāti
analyzed: yathā ajja evam eva parinibbātu dāni bhante bhagavā ati yāci bhagavā ca ssa na  tāva aham iti ādīni vatvā paṭikkhipi tam sandhāya bhāsitā kho pana isā bhante ti ādim āha  tattha viyattā ati magga vasena viyattā tathā iva vinītā tathā visāradā bahu sutā
translated: “Just as today, so also in the past, the Blessed One was asked by Ananda to attain final Nibbana, but the Blessed One refused, saying: ‘Ananda, this is not the time for that.’“

original: tepiṭakavasena bahu sutametesanti bahussutā. Tameva dhammaṃ dhārentīti dhammadharā.
analyzed: te piṭaka vasena bahu tam eva dhammam dhārenti iti dhamma dharā
translated: Herein, they are skilled is skilled by means of the path. They are trained is trained in that way. They are confident is confident in that way. They are learned is they have learned much by way of the three Baskets . They are bearers of the Dhamma is they bear that Dhamma.🔽Or alternatively, they are learned in the sense of being learned in the scriptures and learned in the sense of being learned in the penetration of the truths.

original: Athavā pariyattibahussutā ceva paṭivedhabahussutā ca. Pariyattipaṭivedhadhammānaṃyeva
analyzed: athavā pariyatti bahussutā ca iva paṭivedha bahussutā ca pariyatti paṭivedha dhammānaṃ eva
translated: They are bearers of the Dhamma in the sense that they bear the Dhamma of the scriptures and the Dhamma of penetration.🔽They are followers of the Dhamma in the sense of being followers of the noble Dhamma.🔽They are followers of the Dhamma in the sense of being followers of the Dhamma of insight, which is the Dhamma that follows on the noble Dhamma.

original: dhāraṇato dhammadharāti evamettha attho daṭṭhabbo. Dhammānudhammapaṭipannāti ariyadhammassa
analyzed: dhāraṇataḥ dhamma dharā ti evam ettha atthaḥ daṭṭhabbo dhamma anudhamma paṭipannā ti ariya dhammassa
translated: They are followers of the Dhamma in the sense of being followers of the Dhamma that is suitable.🔽They are of right practice in the sense of being of practice that accords with the Dhamma.🔽They are of right behaviour in the sense of being of behaviour that accords with the Dhamma.🔽They are of right livelihood in the sense of being of livelihood that accords with the Dhamma.🔽They are of right views in the sense of being of views that accord with the Dhamma.🔽They are of right way in the sense of being of way that accords with the Dhamma.🔽They are of right endeavour in the sense of being of endeavour that accords with the Dhamma.🔽They are of right mindfulness in the sense of being of mindfulness that accords with the Dhamma.🔽They are of right concentration in the sense of being of concentration that accords with the Dhamma.🔽They are of right knowledge in the sense of being of knowledge that accords with the Dhamma.

original: anudhammabhūtaṃ vipassanādhammaṃ paṭipannā. Sāmīcippaṭipannāti anucchavikapaṭipadaṃ
analyzed: anudhamma bhūtam vipassanā dhammam paṭipannā sāmīci paṭipannā ati anucchavika paṭipadam
translated: They are of right deliverance in the sense of being of deliverance that accords with the Dhamma.🔽They are of right practice in the sense of being of practice that accords with the Dhamma.🔽They are of right behaviour in the sense of being of behaviour that accords with the Dhamma.

original: paṭipannā. Anudhammacārinoti anudhammacaraṇasīlā. Sakaṃ ācariyakanti attano ācariyavādaṃ.
analyzed: paṭipannāḥ anudhamma cārino ti anudhamma caraṇa sīlā sakam ācariyakam ti attanaḥ ācariya vādam
translated: They are of right livelihood in the sense of being of livelihood that accords with the Dhamma.🔽They are of right views in the sense of being

original: Ācikkhissantītiādīni sabbāni aññamaññassa vevacanāni. Sahadhammenāti sahetukena sakāraṇena
analyzed: ācikkhissanti iti ādīni sabbāni aññamaññassa vevacanāni sahadhammena ati sa hetukena sa kāraṇena
translated: “With the Dhamma”: with a statement that has a reason, a cause.

original: vacanena. Sappāṭihāriyanti yāva na niyyānikaṃ katvā dhammaṃ desessanti.
analyzed: vacanena sappāṭihāriyanti yāva na niyyānikam katvā dhammam desessanti
translated: “With the miracle of instruction”: until they teach the Dhamma that leads to Nibbāna.🔽“The holy life”: the entire holy life of the Dispensation, which is included in the three trainings.

original: Brahmacariyanti sikkhattayasaṅgahitaṃ sakalaṃ sāsanabrahmacariyaṃ. Iddhanti samiddhaṃ
analyzed: brahmacariyanti sikkhattaya saṅgahitam sakalam sāsana brahmacariyam iddham ti samiddham
translated: “Flourished”: it was successful,🔽through the satisfaction of jhāna. “It was widespread”: it had grown,

original: jhānassādavasena. Phītanti vuddhippattaṃ sabbaphāliphullaṃ viya abhiññāya sampattivasena.
analyzed: jhāna ssāda vasena phītanti vuddhi ppattam sabba phāli phullam viya abhiññāya sampatti vasena
translated: like a crop that has borne fruit, through the attainment of the excellence of the higher knowledges.🔽“It was well proclaimed”: it was spread out,

original: Vitthārikanti vitthataṃ tasmiṃ tasmiṃ disābhāge patiṭṭhitavasena. Bāhujaññanti bahujanehi
analyzed: vitthārikanti vitthatam tasmin tasmin disā bhāge patiṭṭhita vasena bāhujaññanti bahu janehi
translated: through its establishment in this and that direction. “It was well described”: it was well known,

original: ñātaṃ paṭividdhaṃ mahājanābhisamayavasena. Puthubhūtanti sabbākāravasena puthulabhāvappattaṃ.
analyzed: ñātam paṭividdham mahājana abhisamaya vasena puthu bhūtanti sabba ākāra vasena puthula bhāva ppattam
translated: well penetrated, through its being well understood by the multitude. “It was resplendent”: it had reached the state of being well known in all aspects.

original: Kathaṃ? Yāva devamanussehi suppakāsitanti yattakā viññujātikā devā ceva manussā ca
analyzed: katham yāva deva manussehi suppakāsitanti yattakā viññu jātikā devā ca iva manussā ca
translated: How? “As far as human beings and gods”: as far as the gods and human beings who have the capacity to understand.

original: atthi sabbehi suṭṭhu pakāsitanti attho.
analyzed: atthi sabbehi suṭṭhu pakāsitanti attho
translated: The meaning is: it was well proclaimed by all of them.

original: Appossukkoti nirālayo. Tvañhi pāpima, aṭṭhamasattāhato paṭṭhāya – “parinibbātu dāni,
analyzed: appossukko ti nirālayaḥ tvam hi pāpima aṭṭhama satta ahataḥ paṭṭhāya parinibbātu dāni
translated: “Unconcerned” means without any support. For, Evil One, from the eighth day after the Enlightened One’s attaining of omniscience, you have been thinking: “Now he will attain final Nibbāna.

original: bhante, bhagavā parinibbātu, sugato”ti viravanto āhiṇḍittha. Ajja dāni paṭṭhāya vigatussāho
analyzed: bhante bhagavā parinibbātu sugataḥ iti viravantaḥ āhiṇḍittha ajja dāni paṭṭhāya vigatussāhaḥ
translated: “Unconcerned” means without attachment. “You, Evil One, from the eighth day after the Exalted One’s enlightenment, have been crying out: ‘Now let the Exalted One attain final Nibbana, let the Well-Farer attain final Nibbana!’ From today onwards, you should be free from anxiety.

original: hohi; mā mayhaṃ parinibbānatthaṃ vāyāmaṃ karohīti vadati.
analyzed: hohi mā mayham parinibbāna attham vāyāmam karohi iti vadati
translated: Do not make any effort to bring about my final Nibbana.”

original: Āyusaṅkhāraossajjanavaṇṇanā
analyzed: āyu saṅkhāra ossajjana vaṇṇanā
translated: The Buddha’s relinquishment of the life-span

original: 169. Sato sampajāno āyusaṅkhāraṃ ossajīti satiṃ sūpaṭṭhitaṃ katvā ñāṇena paricchinditvā🔽āyusaṅkhāraṃ vissajji, pajahi. Tattha na bhagavā hatthena leḍḍuṃ viya āyusaṅkhāraṃ
analyzed: sataḥ sampajānaḥ āyu saṅkhāram ossajīti satim su upaṭṭhitam katvā ñāṇena paricchinditvā  āyu saṅkhāram vissajji pajahi tattha na bhagavā hatthena leḍḍum viya āyu saṅkhāram
translated: “Mindfully and with full awareness he relinquished the control of his life-span”: he relinquished, gave up, his life-span, having established mindfulness well-established, having discerned it with knowledge.

original: ossaji, temāsamattameva pana samāpattiṃ samāpajjitvā tato paraṃ na samāpajjissāmīti
analyzed: ossaji te māsa mattam eva pana samāpattim samāpajjitvā tatas param na samāpajjissāmi iti
translated: Here the Exalted One did not relinquish his life-span like a stone thrown away with the hand. He merely generated the thought: “I will not enter into concentration for three months. I will not enter into concentration beyond that.”

original: cittaṃ uppādesi. Taṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ – “ossajī”ti. “Ussajjī”ti pi pāṭho. Mahābhūmicāloti
analyzed: cittam uppādesi tam sandhāya vuttam
translated: With reference to this, it is said: “he relinquished.” The reading “ussajji” is also correct. “A great earthquake”

original: mahanto pathavīkampo. Tadā kira dasasahassī lokadhātu kampittha. Bhiṃsanakoti bhayajanako.
analyzed: mahantaḥ pathavī kampo tadā kira dasa sahassī lokadhātu kampittha bhiṃsanako uti bhaya janako
translated: means a great trembling of the earth. At that time, it is said, the ten-thousandfold world system shook. “Frightful” means causing fear.

original: Devadundubhiyo ca phaliṃsūti devabheriyo phaliṃsu, devo sukkhagajjitaṃ gajji, akālavijjulatā
analyzed: ca deva bheriyaḥ ca devaḥ sukkha gajjitam gajji akāla vijjula tā
translated: And the divine drums beat: the divine drums sounded. The god’s dry lightning flashed:

original: nicchariṃsu, khaṇikavassaṃ vassīti vuttaṃ hoti.🔽Udānaṃ udānesīti kasmā udānesi? Koci nāma vadeyya – “bhagavā pacchato pacchato anubandhitvā
analyzed: nicchariṃsu khaṇika vassam vassī iti vuttam hoti  udānam udānesi iti kasmai udānesi koci nāma vadeyya bhagavā pacchatas pacchatas anubandhitvā
translated: the god’s lightning without rain flashed. The momentary showers rained: the momentary showers rained down, is what is meant.

original: – ‘parinibbāyatha, bhante, parinibbāyatha, bhante’ti upadduto bhayena āyusaṅkhāraṃ
analyzed: parinibbāyatha bhante parinibbāyatha bhanteti upaddutaḥ bhayena āyu saṅkhāram
translated: He uttered a Solemn Utterance: why did he utter it? Someone might say: “The Blessed One, being pressed and frightened by the thought ‘They are passing away, venerable sirs, they are passing away, venerable sirs,’

original: vissajjesī”ti. “Tassokāso mā hotu, bhītassa udānaṃ nāma natthī”ti etassa dīpanatthaṃ
analyzed: vissajjesi iti tassa ukāsaḥ mā hotu bhītassa udānam nāma natthi iti etassa dīpana attham
translated: released the life-continuum” . To show that that is not so,

original: pītivegavissaṭṭhaṃ udānaṃ udānesi.🔽Tattha sabbesaṃ soṇasiṅgālādīnampi paccakkhabhāvato tulitaṃ paricchinnanti tulaṃ.🔽Kiṃ taṃ? Kāmāvacarakammaṃ. Na tulaṃ, na vā tulaṃ sadisamassa aññaṃ lokiyaṃ kammaṃ
analyzed: pīti vega vissaṭṭham udānam udānesi  tattha sabbesam soṇa siṅgāla ādīnam pi paccakkha bhāvato tulitam paricchinnanti tulam  kim tam kāmāvacara kammam na tulam na vā tulam sadisam assa aññam lokiyam kammam
translated: he uttered the Solemn Utterance, which was a spontaneous utterance of his joy.🔽Herein, weighed and measured is a scale .

original: atthīti atulaṃ. Kiṃ taṃ? Mahaggatakammaṃ. Athavā kāmāvacararūpāvacaraṃ tulaṃ, arūpāvacaraṃ
analyzed: atthi iti atulam kim tam mahaggata kammam athavā kāmāvacara rūpāvacaram tulam arūpāvacaram
translated: What is that? Sense-desire-sphere kamma. There is no other mundane kamma that is equal to it or similar to it, thus it is unequalled . What is that? High-sense-desire-sphere kamma. Or else, sense-desire-sphere and fine-material-sphere kamma is a scale ; immaterial-sphere kamma is unequalled .

original: atulaṃ. Appavipākaṃ vā tulaṃ, bahuvipākaṃ atulaṃ. Sambhavanti sambhavassa hetubhūtaṃ,
analyzed: atulam appa vipākam vā tulam bahu vipākam atulam sambhavanti sambhavassa hetu bhūtam
translated: Incomparable: either “incomparable” means “having little result,” or “incomparable” means “having much result.”🔽The “maker of becoming” is the maker of the mass, the maker of the collection.

original: piṇḍakārakaṃ rāsikārakanti attho. Bhavasaṅkhāranti punabbhavasaṅkhāraṇakaṃ. Avassajīti
analyzed: piṇḍa kārakam rāsi kārakam ti atthaḥ bhava saṅkhāranti punabbhava saṅkhāraṇakam avassaji iti
translated: The “formation of being” is the formation that brings about renewed existence.🔽He cast off: he let go of.🔽The sage: the Buddha, the sage.🔽Delighting in: delighting in his own mind.

original: vissajjesi. Munīti buddhamuni. Ajjhattaratoti niyakajjhattarato. Samāhitoti upacārappanāsamādhivasena
analyzed: vissajjesi muni iti buddha muni ajjhattarataḥ ti niyaka ajjhattarataḥ samāhitaḥ ti upacāra ppanā samādhi vasena
translated: Concentrated: concentrated by means of access concentration and absorption concentration.🔽He broke: he broke like a coat of mail.

original: samāhito. Abhindi kavacamivāti kavacaṃ viya abhindi. Attasambhavanti attani sañjātaṃ🔽kilesaṃ. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – “savipākaṭṭhena sambhavaṃ, bhavābhisaṅkhāraṇaṭṭhena bhavasaṅkhāranti🔽ca laddhanāmaṃ tulātulasaṅkhātaṃ lokiyakammañca ossaji. Saṅgāmasīse mahāyodho kavacaṃ
analyzed: samāhitaḥ abhindi kavacam iva ati kavacam viya abhindi sañjātam  kilesam idam vuttam hoti sa vipāka ṭṭhena sambhavam bhava abhisaṅkhāraṇa ṭṭhena bhava saṅkhāranti  ca laddha nāmam tulā tula saṅkhātam lokiya kammaṃ ca ossaji saṅgāma sīse mahā yodhaḥ kavacaṃ
translated: Arisen from himself: arisen in himself.

original: viya attasambhavaṃ kilesañca ajjhattarato samāhito hutvā abhindī”ti.
analyzed: atta sambhavam kilesam ca ajjhattaratas samāhitaḥ hutvā abhindi iti
translated: This is the meaning: “He cast off the worldling’s kamma, which is called ‘becoming’ in the sense of having result, and which is called ‘the formation of being’ in the sense of forming and shaping renewed existence, and which is known as ‘comparable’ and ‘incomparable’ in the sense of having little result and much result. Like a great warrior breaking his coat of mail in the forefront of the battle, he, delighting in his own mind, concentrated, broke the defilements arisen from himself.”

original: Atha vā tulanti tulento tīrento. Atulañca sambhavanti nibbānañceva sambhavañca. Bhavasaṅkhāranti🔽bhavagāmikammaṃ. Avassaji munīti “pañcakkhandhā aniccā, pañcannaṃ khandhānaṃ nirodho
analyzed: atha vā tulanti tulentaḥ tīrentaḥ atulam ca sambhavanti nibbānam ca iva sambhavañca bhava saṅkhāranti  bhava gāmi kammam avassaji muni iti pañca kkhandhāḥ aniccā pañcannam khandhānam nirodhaḥ
translated: Or alternatively, he is a “weigher” because he weighs, he crosses over, the “unweighed” and the “unreached” , that is, Nibbāna and the path to Nibbāna. The “formations of existence” are kamma that leads to existence. The Sage “cast off”: the Enlightened One, the Sage, weighed the five aggregates as impermanent and the cessation of the five aggregates as permanent,

original: nibbānaṃ nicca”ntiādinā nayena tulayanto buddhamuni bhave ādīnavaṃ, nibbāne ca ānisaṃsaṃ🔽disvā taṃ khandhānaṃ mūlabhūtaṃ bhavasaṅkhārakammaṃ – “kammakkhayāya saṃvattatī”ti🔽evaṃ vuttena kammakkhayakarena ariyamaggena avassaji. Kathaṃ? Ajjhattarato samāhito
analyzed: nibbānam niccanti ādinā nayena tulayantaḥ buddha muni bhave ādīnavam nibbāne ca ānisaṃsam  disvā tam khandhānam mūla bhūtam bhava saṅkhāra kammam kamma kkhayāya saṃvattati iti  evam vuttena kamma khaya karena ariya maggena avassaji katham ajjhattarataḥ samāhitaḥ
translated: and so on, and seeing the danger in existence and the benefit in Nibbāna,

original: abhindi kavacamiva attani sambhavaṃ. So hi vipassanāvasena ajjhattarato samathavasena🔽samāhitoti evaṃ pubbabhāgato paṭṭhāya samathavipassanābalena kavacamiva attabhāvaṃ
analyzed: abhindi kavacam iva attani sambhavam saḥ hi vipassanā vasena ajjhattaratas samatha vasena  samāhitaḥ ti evam pubba bhāgataḥ paṭṭhāya samatha vipassanā balena kavacam iva atta bhāvam
translated: he cast off the kamma-formation of existence, which is the root of the aggregates, by means of the noble path called “the means to the destruction of kamma.” How? “Delighting in the mind’s concentration, he broke the ‘self-originated’ armor within himself.” For he delighted in the mind’s concentration by means of serenity and in the mind’s concentration by means of insight.

original: pariyonandhitvā ṭhitaṃ, attani sambhavattā “attasambhava”nti laddhanāmaṃ sabbakilesajālaṃ
analyzed: ṭhitam sambhavattā attasambhavanti laddha nāmam sabba kilesa jālam
translated: Thus, beginning with the preparatory path, by the power of serenity and insight he broke the “self-originated” net of all defilements, which is called “self-originated” because it originates by itself, and which is situated enveloping the person like armor.

original: abhindi. Kilesābhāvena ca katakammaṃ appaṭisandhikattā avassaṭṭhaṃ nāma hotīti evaṃ
analyzed: kilesa abhāvena ca kata kammam appaṭisandhika ttā avassaṭṭham nāma hoti iti evam
translated: and it broke up. And because of the absence of defilements, the kamma that had been done was not able to produce a rebirth- linking, and so it was called “unbound.” Thus

original: kilesappahānena kammaṃ pajahi, pahīnakilesassa ca bhayaṃ nāma natthi, tasmā abhītova
analyzed: kilesa ppahānena kammam pajahi pahīna kilesassa ca bhayam nāma natthi tasmai abhītaḥ uva
translated: he abandoned kamma by abandoning the defilements. And because he had abandoned the defilements, he had no fear. Therefore,

original: āyusaṅkhāraṃ ossaji, abhītabhāvañāpanatthañca udānaṃ udānesīti veditabbo.
analyzed: āyu saṅkhāram ossaji a bhīta bhāva ñāpana tham ca udānam udānesi iti veditabbo
translated: fearlessly he relinquished the life-continuum, and he uttered the solemn utterance in order to proclaim his fearlessness.

original: Mahābhūmicālavaṇṇanā
translated: The great earthquake

original: 171. Yaṃ mahāvātāti yena samayena yasmiṃ vā samaye mahāvātā vāyanti, mahāvātā vāyantāpi
analyzed: yam yena samayena yasmin vā samaye mahāvātāḥ vāyanti mahāvātāḥ vāyanta api
translated: . “When there are great winds”: at the time when great winds are blowing, or at the time when great winds blow,

analyzed: gaṇhāti tatas udakam uggacchati tasmin uggacchante pathavī uggacchati evam udakam

original: Mahiddhiko mahānubhāvoti ijjhanassa mahantatāya mahiddhiko, anubhavitabbassa mahantatāya🔽mahānubhāvo. Parittāti dubbalā. Appamāṇāti balavā. analyzed: mahiddhikaḥ mahā anubhāvaḥ ti ijjhanassa mahanta tāya mahiddhikaḥ anubhavitabbassa mahanta tāya  mahā anubhāvaḥ parittā ati dubbalā appamāṇā ati balavā saḥ imam pathavim kampeti iti saḥ  iddhim nibbattetvā saṃvejentaḥ mahāmoggallānaḥ viya vīmaṃsantaḥ vā mahānāga ttherassa  bhāgineyyaḥ saṅgha rakkhita sāmaṇeraḥ viya pathavim kampeti saḥ kira ayasmai  arahattam patvā cintesi atthi nu kho koci bhikkhu yena pabbajita divaseya iva arahattam
translated: Great in power and great in majesty: great in power because of the greatness of the success,

original: patvā vejayanto pāsādo kampitapubbo”ti? Tato – “natthi kocī”ti ñatvā – “ahaṃ kampessāmī”ti
analyzed: patvā vejayanto pāsādo kampita pubbaḥ ti tatas na atthi koci iti ñatvā aham kampessāmi iti
translated: great in majesty because of the greatness of the experience. Small: weak. Immeasurable: powerful. He causes this earth to quake: having generated success and causing it to quake like the Elder Mahā Moggallāna, or investigating like the Elder Mahā Nāga’s niece Saṅgharakkhita the novice, he causes the earth to quake. It is said that the venerable one, having attained arahatship on the very day of his higher ordination, thought: “Is there any bhikkhu who, on the very day of his higher ordination, having attained arahatship, has caused the Vejayanta Palace to quake?” Then, knowing that there was none, he thought: “I will cause it to quake.”

original: abhiññābalena vejayantamatthake ṭhatvā pādena paharitvā kampetuṃ nāsakkhi. Atha naṃ
analyzed: abhiññā balena vejayanta matthake ṭhatvā pādena paharitvā kampetum na asakkhi atha naṃ

analyzed: sakkassa nāṭakitthiyaḥ āhaṃsu putta saṅgha rakkhita tvam pūti gandhena iva sīsena

original: Sāmaṇero – “imā devatā mayā saddhiṃ keḷiṃ karonti, ahaṃ kho pana ācariyaṃ nālatthaṃ,🔽kahaṃ nu kho me ācariyo sāmuddikamahānāgatthero”ti āvajjento mahāsamudde udakaleṇaṃ
analyzed: sāmaṇeraḥ imāḥ devatāḥ mayā saddhim keḷim karonti aham kho pana ācariyam na alattham  kaham nu kho me ācariyaḥ sāmuddika mahānāga ttheraḥ ti āvajjentaḥ mahā samudde udaka leṇam
translated: The novice thought, “These deities are making fun of me. I have not yet received my teacher’s permission.

original: thero – “kiṃ, tāta saṅgharakkhita, asikkhitvāva yuddhaṃ paviṭṭhosī”ti vatvā “nāsakkhi,
analyzed: theraḥ kim tāta saṅgha rakkhita a sikkhitvā ava yuddham paviṭṭhaḥ asi iti vatvā na asakkhi
translated: He went there and paid homage to the Elder, who said to him, “Why, dear Saṅgharakkhita, have you gone to war without being trained?”🔽“I was unable to shake Vejayanta, Sir.”

translated: “I have not yet received my teacher’s permission, Sir.” The Elder said,

analyzed: gomaya khaṇḍam pilavantam tāta kapallaka pūvam pacantāḥ antantena paricchindanti  iminā opammena jānāhi iti āha saḥ vaṭṭissati bhante ettakena ati vatvā pāsādena

translated: By this parable you may know that it will be enough.” “It will be enough, Reverend Sir,” he said, and after determining that the water should be as high as the base of the palace, he went toward the Vejayanta Palace.

original: Devadhītaro taṃ disvā – “ekavāraṃ lajjitvā gato, punapi sāmaṇero eti, punapi etī”ti🔽vadiṃsu. Sakko devarājā – “mā mayhaṃ puttena saddhiṃ kathayittha, idāni tena ācariyo
analyzed: tam disvā eka vāram lajjitvā gataḥ punar api sāmaṇeraḥ eti punar api eti iti  vadiṃsu sakkaḥ devarājā mā mayham puttena saddhim kathayittha idāni tena ācariyaḥ
translated: When the daughters of the gods saw him, they said, “He has gone away, ashamed once, but now the novice comes again, and again he comes.”

translated: “Today I have gone forth, today I have destroyed the corruptions,

analyzed: ajja iva aham pabbajitā upe aho saṅghaḥ suḷāra tā ati

translated: What should be said concerning the six earthquakes that occurred after this has been said in the Great Birth Stories.

At the time of the Setting in Motion of the Wheel of the Dhamma🔽it shook, giving a good reception to the Good News. At the time of the Renunciation of the Life-Span it shook, being unable to bear the agitation of the mind

original: cittasaṅkhobhaṃ asahamānā akampittha. Parinibbāne ārodanavegatunnā hutvā akampittha.

analyzed: ayam pana atthaḥ pathavī devatāya vasena veditabbo mahābhūta pathaviyā pana etam natthi acetana ttā ati  ime kho ānanda aṭṭha hetū ti ettha ime iti niddiṭṭha nidassanam ettāvatā ca pana ayasmā

analyzed: sallakkhita bhāvam jānantaḥ api okāsam a datvā ava aññāni api aṭṭhakāni sampiṇḍentaḥ aṭṭha kho imā ti ādim āha
translated: though he knew, asked, “Why do you say that, Ānanda?” and then, without giving him an opportunity to reply, he said, “There are these eight reasons, Ānanda,” and so on, combining the other eight reasons.

original: Aṭṭhaparisavaṇṇanā
analyzed: aṭṭha parisa vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the eight assemblies

analyzed: sākacchā ati dhammasākacchā api samāpajjita pubbā tesam vaṇṇo ti te odātā api honti

analyzed: satthā suvaṇṇa vaṇṇo va idam pana saṇṭhānam paṭicca kathitam

analyzed: saṇṭhānam pi ca kevalam tesam paññāyatiyā iva na pana bhagavā milakkhu sadisaḥ hoti
translated: And that is only what they themselves perceived, for the Master was not like a foreigner,

analyzed: na api āmutta maṇi kuṇḍalaḥ buddha vesena iva nisīdati te pana attano samāna saṇṭhānam eva
translated: nor was he like a man with dangling earrings; he sat down in the Buddha-array. But they saw only their own shape.

analyzed: passanti tesam saroti te chinna ssarā api honti gaggara ssarā api kāka ssarā api
translated: Such was their voice means they had a voice like that of a saw, like that of a water-drawer, like that of a crow,

analyzed: satthā brahmassarovaḥ idam pana bhāsantaram sandhāya kathitam sace pi hi satthā rāja āsane
translated: but the Master had a voice like Brahma’s. But this is said with reference to the sound of their speech. For if the Master

original: nisinno katheti, “ajja rājā madhurena sarena kathetī”ti tesaṃ hoti. Kathetvā pakkante
analyzed: nisinnaḥ katheti ajja rājā madhurena sarena katheti iti tesam hoti kathetvā pakkante
translated: “Today the king spoke with a sweet voice,” they thought.

analyzed: pana bhagavati punar rājānam āgatam disvā kaḥ nu khalu ayanti vīmaṃsā uppajjati
translated: But when the Blessed One had finished speaking and left, the king returned. When the brahmin saw him, he wondered, “Who was that? “

original: Tattha ko nu kho ayanti imasmiṃ ṭhāne idāneva māgadhabhāsāya sīhaḷabhāsāya madhurenākārena
analyzed: tattha kaḥ nu kho ayanti imasmin ṭhāne idānā iva māgadha bhāsāya sīhaḷa bhāsāya madhurena ākārena
translated: Here, in the phrase “Who was that? “ the word “that” is used in the Magadhan language in the sense of “now.”

original: kathento ko nu kho ayaṃ antarahito, kiṃ devo, udāhu manussoti evaṃ vīmaṃsantāpi na
analyzed: kathentaḥ kaḥ nu kho ayam antarahitaḥ kim devaḥ udāhu manusso ti evam vīmaṃsantā api na
translated: Wondering thus, “Who was that who just now disappeared, was it a god or a human being?” they did not know.

original: jānantīti attho. Kimatthaṃ panevaṃ ajānantānaṃ dhammaṃ desetīti? Vāsanatthāya. Evaṃ
analyzed: jānanti iti atthaḥ kimattham pana evam a jānantānam dhammam deseti iti vāsana tthāya evam
translated: Why did he teach the Dhamma to those who did not know? For the sake of the impression .

original: sutopi hi dhammo anāgate paccayo hoti yevāti anāgataṃ paṭicca deseti. Anekasataṃ🔽brāhmaṇaparisantiādīnampi soṇadaṇḍakūṭadaṇḍasamāgamādivasena ceva aññacakkavāḷavasena
analyzed: sutaḥ api hi dhammaḥ anāgate paccayaḥ hoti yā iva ati anāgatam paṭicca deseti aneka satam  brāhmaṇa parisanti ādīnam pi soṇa daṇḍa kūṭa daṇḍa samāgama ādi vasena ca iva añña cakkavāḷa vasena
translated: For even if one hears the Dhamma while asleep, it becomes a condition for him in the future.

original: ca sambhavo veditabbo.

translated: The origin of the assembly of many hundreds of brahmins should be understood as follows: some came from the meeting of the Sonadanda and the Kūṭadanta assemblies, and some came from other world systems.

original: Imā pana aṭṭha parisā bhagavā kimatthaṃ āhari? Abhītabhāvadassanatthameva. Imā kira
analyzed: imāḥ pana aṭṭha parisāḥ bhagavā kimattham āhari abhīta bhāva dassana attham eva imāḥ kira
translated: Why did the Blessed One bring together these eight assemblies? To show that he was not afraid.

original: āharitvā evamāha – “ānanda, imāpi aṭṭha parisā upasaṅkamitvā dhammaṃ desentassa tathāgatassa
analyzed: āharitvā evam āha ānanda imāḥ api aṭṭha parisāḥ upasaṅkamitvā dhammam desentassa tathāgatassa
