original: bhayaṃ vā sārajjaṃ vā natthi, māraṃ pana ekakaṃ disvā tathāgato bhāyeyyāti ko evaṃ
analyzed: bhayam vā sārajjam vā natthi māram pana ekakam disvā tathāgataḥ bhāyeyya ati kaḥ evam
translated: But who would be so foolish as to think that the Tathāgata would be afraid or frightened when he sees Māra alone?

original: saññaṃ uppādetumarahati. Abhīto, ānanda, tathāgato acchambhī, sato sampajāno āyusaṅkhāraṃ ossajī”ti.
analyzed: saññam uppādetum arahati abhītaḥ ānanda tathāgataḥ a chambhī sataḥ sampajānaḥ āyu saṅkhāram ossajīti
translated: The Tathāgata is fearless and free from trembling, anxiety, and fear. He is mindful and clearly aware. He will lay down his life.”

original: Aṭṭhaabhibhāyatanavaṇṇanā
analyzed: aṭṭha abhibhāyatana vaṇṇanā
translated: The eight spheres of mastery

original: 173. Abhibhāyatanānīti abhibhavanakāraṇāni. Kiṃ abhibhavanti? Paccanīkadhammepi ārammaṇānipi.🔽Tāni hi paṭipakkhabhāvena paccanīkadhamme abhibhavanti, puggalassa ñāṇuttariyatāya ārammaṇāni.
analyzed: abhibhāyatanāni iti abhibhavana kāraṇāni kim abhibhavanti paccanīka dhamme pi ārammaṇāni pi  tāni hi paṭipakkha bhāvena paccanīka dhamme abhibhavanti puggalassa ñāṇuttariya tāya ārammaṇāni
translated: The spheres of mastery are the causes of overcoming. What does he overcome? Adverse states and objects.🔽For these spheres overcome adverse states by being their opposites, and they overcome objects by the surpassing of the jhāna.

original: Ajjhattaṃ rūpasaññītiādīsu pana ajjhattarūpe parikammavasena ajjhattaṃ rūpasaññī
analyzed: ajjhattam rūpa saññī iti ādīsu pana ajjhatta rūpe parikamma vasena ajjhattam rūpa saññī
translated: As regards the passages beginning “Perceiving forms internally” , etc., he is called “perceiving forms internally” because he has made the resolution to do the preliminary work on the internal form.

original: nāma hoti. Ajjhattañhi nīlaparikammaṃ karonto kese vā pitte vā akkhitārakāya vā karoti.
analyzed: nāma hoti ajjhattam hi nīla parikammam karonto kese vā pitte vā akkhi tārakāya vā karoti
translated: For when he is doing the preliminary work on the blue, he does it either on the hair of the head, or on bile, or on the pupil of the eye, or on the blue gem.

original: Pītaparikammaṃ karonto mede vā chaviyā vā hatthapādapiṭṭhesu vā akkhīnaṃ pītakaṭṭhāne🔽vā karoti. Lohitaparikammaṃ karonto maṃse vā lohite vā jivhāya vā akkhīnaṃ rattaṭṭhāne
analyzed: pīta parikammam karontaḥ mede vā chaviyā vā hattha pāda piṭṭhesu vā akkhīnam pītakaṭṭhāne  vā karoti lohita parikammam karontaḥ maṃse vā lohite vā jivhāya vā akkhīnam ratta ṭṭhāne
translated: He does the work of looking on at the blue kasiṇa as blue, or he does the work of looking on at the yellow kasiṇa as yellow, and so on.🔽He does the work of looking on at the red kasiṇa as red in the flesh, in the blood, in the tongue, or in the red of the eyes.

original: vā karoti. Odātaparikammaṃ karonto aṭṭhimhi vā dante vā nakhe vā akkhīnaṃ setaṭṭhāne
analyzed: vā karoti odāta parikammam karontaḥ aṭṭhimhi vā dante vā nakhe vā akkhīnam seta ṭṭhāne
translated: He does the work of looking on at the white kasiṇa as white in the bones, in the teeth, in the nails, or in the white of the eyes.

original: vā karoti. Taṃ pana sunīlaṃ supītaṃ sulohitakaṃ suodātakaṃ na hoti, avisuddhameva hoti.🔽Eko bahiddhā rūpāni passatīti yassevaṃ parikammaṃ ajjhattaṃ uppannaṃ hoti, nimittaṃ🔽pana bahiddhā, so evaṃ ajjhattaṃ parikammassa bahiddhā ca appanāya vasena – “ajjhattaṃ
analyzed: vā karoti tam pana su nīlam su pītam su lohitakam su odātakam na hoti a visuddham eva hoti  ekaḥ bahiddhā rūpāni passati iti yassa evam parikammam ajjhattam uppannam hoti nimittam  pana bahiddhā so evam ajjhattam parikammassa bahiddhā ca appanāya vasena ajjhattam
translated: But it is not very clear blue, or very clear yellow, or very clear red, or very clear white; it is just plain.🔽One looks at mental objects externally: when the work of looking on has arisen thus in one, the sign is external.🔽So it is said of him that “inwardly he has the perception of form, outwardly he looks at forms” .

original: rūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passatī”ti vuccati. Parittānīti avaḍḍhitāni. Suvaṇṇadubbaṇṇānīti
analyzed: rūpa saññī ekaḥ bahiddhā rūpāni passati iti vuccati parittāni iti avaḍḍhitāni suvaṇṇa dubbaṇṇāni iti
translated: Limited: not extended. Fair and ugly:

original: suvaṇṇāni vā honti, dubbaṇṇāni vā. Parittavaseneva idaṃ abhibhāyatanaṃ vuttanti veditabbaṃ.🔽Tāni abhibhuyyāti yathā nāma sampannagahaṇiko kaṭacchumattaṃ bhattaṃ labhitvā – “kiṃ
analyzed: suvaṇṇāni vā honti dubbaṇṇāni vā paritta vasena iva idam abhibhāyatanam vuttan ti veditabbam  tāni yathā nāma sampanna gahaṇikaḥ kaṭacchumattam bhattam labhitvā kim
translated: They may be beautiful or ugly. This is how it should be understood that the jhāna is called “adverting” because of the adverting of the mind to the sign consisting in the beauty, etc., of the kasiṇa as a limited or exalted object.

original: ettha bhuñjitabbaṃ atthī”ti saṅkaḍḍhitvā ekakabaḷameva karoti, evameva ñāṇuttariko
analyzed: ettha bhuñjitabbam atthi iti saṅkaḍḍhitvā eka kabaḷam eva karoti evam eva ñāṇuttarikaḥ
translated: He adverts to them and looks on: just as a man with good sight might take a handful of various kinds of gems, such as are strung on a thread, and look at them, so too, this meditator adverts to the various forms and looks on at them.

original: puggalo visadañāṇo – “kiṃ ettha parittake ārammaṇe samāpajjitabbaṃ atthi, nāyaṃ mama
analyzed: puggalaḥ visada ñāṇaḥ kim ettha parittake ārammaṇe samāpajjitabbam atthi na ayam mama
translated: He resolves with knowledge: just as the man with the gems might think “I will sell these gems,” so too, this meditator resolves thus with knowledge: “I will attain jhāna in these forms.”

original: bhāro”ti tāni rūpāni abhibhavitvā samāpajjati, saha nimittuppādenevettha appanaṃ🔽pāpetīti attho. Jānāmi passāmīti iminā panassa ābhogo kathito. So ca kho samāpattito🔽vuṭṭhitassa, na antosamāpattiyaṃ. Evaṃsaññī hotīti ābhogasaññāyapi jhānasaññāyapi
analyzed: tāni rūpāni abhibhavitvā samāpajjati saha nimitta uppādena iva itthā appanam  pāpā iti iti atthaḥ jānāmi passāmi iti iminā pana assa ābhogaḥ kathitaḥ saḥ ca kho samāpattitaḥ  vuṭṭhitassa na antosamāpattiyam evaṃsaññī hoti iti ābhoga saññāya api jhāna saññāya api
translated: He attains jhāna in them: just as the man with the gems might string the gems on a thread, so too, this meditator attains jhāna in those forms.🔽He emerges thus: just as the man with the gems might unstring them and put them down, so too, this meditator emerges from jhāna.🔽He recollects thus: just as the man with the gems might recollect, “I have such gems,” so too, this meditator recollects, “I have attained jhāna in such forms.”

original: evaṃsaññī hoti. Abhibhavanasaññā hissa antosamāpattiyampi atthi, ābhogasaññā pana
analyzed: evaṃsaññī hoti abhibhavana saññā hissa antosamāpattiyam pi atthi ābhoga saññā pana
translated: He understands thus: just as the man with the gems might understand, “These gems are of such kind,” so too, this meditator understands, “I have attained such jhāna.”

original: samāpattito vuṭṭhitasseva.
analyzed: samāpattitaḥ vuṭṭhitassa eva
translated: As soon as he has emerged from the attainment.

original: Appamāṇānīti vaḍḍhitappamāṇāni, mahantānīti attho. Abhibhuyyāti ettha pana yathā🔽mahagghaso puriso ekaṃ bhattavaḍḍhitakaṃ labhitvā – “aññampi hotu, kiṃ etaṃ mayhaṃ🔽karissatī”ti taṃ na mahantato passati, evameva ñāṇuttaro puggalo visadañāṇo “kiṃ🔽ettha samāpajjitabbaṃ, nayidaṃ appamāṇaṃ, na mayhaṃ cittekaggatākaraṇe bhāro atthī”ti
analyzed: appamāṇāni iti vaḍḍhita ppamāṇāni mahantāni iti atthaḥ ettha pana yathā  mahagghasaḥ puriso ekam bhatta vaḍḍhitakam labhitvā aññam pi hotu kim etam mayham  karissati iti tam na mahantataḥ passati evam eva ñāṇa uttaraḥ puggalaḥ visada ñāṇo kim  ettha samāpajjitabbam na yidam appamāṇam na mayham citta ekagga tā karaṇe bhāraḥ atthi iti
translated: Immeasurable: of increased measure, is the meaning.

original: tāni abhibhavitvā samāpajjati, saha nimittuppādenevettha appanaṃ pāpetīti attho.
analyzed: tāni abhibhavitvā samāpajjati saha nimitta uppādena iva ittha appanam pāpeti iti atthaḥ
translated: As to “he surpasses …”: just as a man of high status, getting a hundred kahapanas, would not regard it as much, thinking, “What can I do with so little?” so too the person whose knowledge is superior, whose knowledge is clear, does not see it as much, thinking, “What is there to be attained here? This is not immeasurable. It is no effort for me to unify my mind.” He attains it by surpassing it, is what is meant. The meaning is that he brings it to absorption with the mere arising of the sign.

original: Ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññīti alābhitāya vā anatthikatāya vā ajjhattarūpe parikammasaññāvirahito.
analyzed: ajjhattam arūpa saññī iti alābhi tāya vā anatthikatāya vā ajjhatta rūpe parikamma saññā virahitaḥ
translated: Perceiving forms internally: he is devoid of perception of reviewing of forms internally owing to non-obtainment or non-desire.

original: Eko bahiddhā rūpāni passatīti yassa parikammampi nimittampi bahiddhāva uppannaṃ,🔽so evaṃ bahiddhā parikammassa ceva appanāya ca vasena – “ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññī eko
analyzed: ekaḥ bahiddhā rūpāni passati iti yassa parikammam pi nimittam pi bahiddhā vā uppannam 🔽so evam bahiddhā parikammassa ca iva appanāya ca vasena ajjhattam arūpa saññī ekaḥ
translated: One sees forms externally: for one to whom the reviewing and the sign arise externally only,🔽one who is thus externally both in reviewing and in absorption, “Perceiving forms internally, one sees forms externally” is said.

original: bahiddhā rūpāni passatī”ti vuccati. Sesamettha catutthābhibhāyatane vuttanayameva.
analyzed: bahiddhā rūpāni passati iti vuccati sesam ettha catuttha abhibhāyatane vutta nayam eva
translated: He sees external visible objects” . The rest here is in the way already stated under the fourth base of mastery.

original: Imesu pana catūsu parittaṃ vitakkacaritavasena āgataṃ, appamāṇaṃ mohacaritavasena,
analyzed: imesu pana catūsu parittam vitakka carita vasena āgatam appamāṇam moha carita vasena
translated: But of these four, the limited one is given in the case of one of greedy temperament, the measureless one in the case of one of deluded temperament,

original: suvaṇṇaṃ dosacaritavasena, dubbaṇṇaṃ rāgacaritavasena. Etesañhi etāni sappāyāni.
analyzed: su vaṇṇam dosa carita vasena dubbaṇṇam rāga carita vasena etesam hi etāni sappāyāni
translated: the beautiful one in the case of one of hating temperament, and the ugly one in the case of one of greedy temperament. For these are suitable for them.

original: Sā ca nesaṃ sappāyatā vitthārato visuddhimagge caritaniddese vuttā.
analyzed: sā ca nesam sappāya tā vitthārataḥ visuddhi magge carita niddese vuttā
translated: And the suitability of these for them is given in detail in the Description of Types of Character in the Path of Purification .

original: Pañcamaabhibhāyatanādīsu nīlānīti sabbasaṅgāhakavasena vuttaṃ. Nīlavaṇṇānīti vaṇṇavasena.
translated: As regards the fifth base of mastery, etc., “blue” is said as the general characteristic; “blue in colour” as the colour characteristic;

original: Nīlanidassanānīti nidassanavasena, apaññāya mānavivarāni asambhinnavaṇṇāni ekanīlāneva🔽hutvā dissantīti vuttaṃ hoti. Nīlanibhāsānīti idaṃ pana obhāsavasena vuttaṃ, nīlobhāsāni
analyzed: nīla nidassanāni iti nidassana vasena a paññāya māna vivarāni asambhinna vaṇṇāni eka nīlāni eva  hutvā dissanti iti vuttam hoti nīla nibhāsāni iti idam pana obhāsa vasena vuttam nīla ubhāsāni
translated: “blue in appearance” as the appearance characteristic; “blue in hue” as the hue characteristic. What is meant is that they appear as blue, not as mixed up with any other colour, not as having a different hue, like the blue of the utpala flower.

original: nīlappabhāyuttānīti attho. Etena nesaṃ visuddhataṃ dasseti. Visuddhavaṇṇavaseneva
analyzed: nīla ppabhā yuttāni iti atthaḥ etena nesam visuddha tam dasseti visuddha vaṇṇa vasena iva
translated: “Blue in lustre” is said as the lustre characteristic. What is meant is that they are endowed with the blue radiance of the blue of the utpala flower. By this he shows their purity.

original: hi imāni cattāri abhibhāyatanāni vuttāni. Umāpupphanti etañhi pupphaṃ siniddhaṃ mudu,
analyzed: hi imāni cattāri abhibhāyatanāni vuttāni umāpupphanti etat hi puppham siniddham mudu
translated: These are the four bases for transcending the form element. The blue water lily: this is a lily that is glossy and soft,

original: dissamānampi nīlameva hoti. Girikaṇṇikapupphādīni pana dissamānāni setadhātukāneva
analyzed: dissamānam pi nīlam eva hoti girikaṇṇika puppha ādīni pana dissamānāni seta dhātukāna eva
translated: and when seen it is blue. But the flowers of the girikaṇṇika and so on are white when seen,

original: honti. Tasmā idameva gahitaṃ, na tāni. Bārāṇaseyyakanti bārāṇasisambhavaṃ. Tattha
analyzed: honti tasmai idam eva gahitam na tāni bārāṇaseyyakanti bārāṇasi sambhavam tattha
translated: so only this is taken, not those. The Benares cloth: the cloth produced in Benares. It seems that

original: kira kappāsopi mudu, suttakantikāyopi tantavāyāpi chekā, udakampi suci siniddhaṃ.
analyzed: kira kappāsaḥ api mudu tantavāyā api chekāḥ udakampi suci
translated: there the cotton is soft, the weavers are skilled, and the water is pure and glossy.

original: Tasmā taṃ vatthaṃ ubhatobhāgavimaṭṭhaṃ hoti; dvīsupi passesu maṭṭhaṃ mudu siniddhaṃ khāyati.
analyzed: tasmā tam vattham ubhatobhāga vimaṭṭham hoti dvīsu pi passesu maṭṭham mudu siniddham khāyati
translated: So the cloth is well washed on both sides; it looks soft, glossy, and well washed on both sides.

original: Pītānītiādīsupi imināva nayena attho veditabbo. “Nīlakasiṇaṃ uggaṇhanto nīlasmiṃ
analyzed: pītāni iti ādīsu pi iminā ava nayena atthaḥ veditabbaḥ nīla kasiṇam uggaṇhantaḥ nīlasmin
translated: The meaning should be understood in the same way in the case of the yellow kasina, etc. “One who is learning the blue kasiṇa apprehends the sign in blue,

original: nimittaṃ gaṇhāti pupphasmiṃ vā vatthasmiṃ vā vaṇṇadhātuyā vā”tiādikaṃ panettha kasiṇakaraṇañca
analyzed: nimittam gaṇhāti pupphasmim vā vatthasmim vā vaṇṇa dhātuyā vāti ādikam pana ittha kasiṇa karaṇam ca
translated: in a flower or in a piece of cloth or in a colour element,” and so on. The making of the kasiṇa,

original: parikammañca appanāvidhānañca sabbaṃ visuddhimagge vitthārato vuttameva. Imānipi
analyzed: parikammañca appanā vidhānañca sabbam visuddhi magge vitthārataḥ vuttam eva imāni pi
translated: the preliminary work, and the directions for attaining jhāna are all given in detail in the Visuddhimagga. These kasiṇas🔽are called “earth kasiṇa” and so on

original: aṭṭha abhibhāyatanāni abhītabhāvadassanatthameva ānītāni. Imāni kira vatvā evamāha
analyzed: aṭṭha abhibhāyatanāni abhīta bhāva dassana attham eva ānītāni imāni kira vatvā evam āha
translated: The eight spheres of mastery are brought in only to show that he is not afraid.

original: – “ānanda, evarūpāpi samāpattiyo samāpajjantassa ca vuṭṭhahantassa ca tathāgatassa
analyzed: ānanda evarūpāḥ api samāpattiyaḥ samāpajjantassa ca vuṭṭhahantassa ca tathāgatassa
translated: After saying this, he said further: “Ananda, when the Tathagata enters into and emerges from such attainments, he has no fear or trembling.

original: bhayaṃ vā sārajjaṃ vā natthi, māraṃ pana ekakaṃ disvā tathāgato bhāyeyyāti ko evaṃ
analyzed: bhayam vā sārajjam vā natthi māram pana ekakam disvā tathāgataḥ bhāyeyya ati kaḥ evam
translated: But if the Tathagata were to be afraid on seeing Mara alone, who else would he expect to be afraid?

original: saññaṃ uppādetumarahati. Abhīto, ānanda, tathāgato acchambhī, sato sampajāno āyusaṅkhāraṃ ossajī”ti.🔽Aṭṭhavimokkhavaṇṇanā
analyzed: saññam uppādetum arahati abhītaḥ ānanda tathāgataḥ a chambhī sataḥ sampajānaḥ āyu saṅkhāram ossajīti  aṭṭha vimokkha vaṇṇanā
translated: Ananda, the Tathagata is fearless and free from trembling, mindful and fully aware. He relinquishes the life formation.”🔽The eight emancipations are also stated in the same way.

original: 174. Vimokkhakathā uttānatthāyeva. Imepi aṭṭha vimokkhā abhītabhāvadassanatthameva🔽ānītā. Imepi kira vatvā evamāha – “ānanda, etāpi samāpattiyo samāpajjantassa ca vuṭṭhahantassa
analyzed: vimokkha kathā uttāna tthāya iva ime pi aṭṭha vimokkhāḥ abhīta bhāva dassana ttham eva  ānītāḥ ime api kira vatvā evam āha ānanda etāḥ api samāpattiyaḥ samāpajjantassa ca vuṭṭhahantassa
translated: The explanation of the emancipations is straightforward. These eight emancipations are brought in only to show that he is not afraid.🔽After saying this, he said further: “Ananda, when the Tathagata enters into and emerges from such attainments, he has no fear or trembling. …

original: ca tathāgatassa bhayaṃ vā sārajjaṃ vā natthi…pe… ossajī”ti.
analyzed: ca tathāgatassa bhayam vā sārajjam vā ossaji iti
translated: He relinquishes the life formation.”

original: 175. Idānipi bhagavā ānandassa okāsaṃ adatvāva ekamidāhantiādinā nayena aparampi desanaṃ ārabhi. Tattha paṭhamābhisambuddhoti abhisambuddho hutvā paṭhamameva aṭṭhame sattāhe.
analyzed: bhagavā ānandassa okāsam a datvā ava ekam idā aham ti ādinā nayena aparam pi desanam ārabhi tattha paṭhama abhisambuddhaḥ ti abhisambuddhaḥ hutvā paṭhamam eva aṭṭhame sattāhe
translated: Now, the Blessed One, without giving Ānanda an opportunity to speak, began another teaching, beginning with the words, “Once, Ānanda, when I was staying at Uruvelā. ” Herein, he was first enlightened means that he was enlightened and that it was only seven days later that he did this.

original: 177. Ossaṭṭhoti vissajjito paricchinno, evaṃ kira vatvā – “tenāyaṃ dasasahassī lokadhātu kampitthā”ti āha.
analyzed: ossaṭṭhaḥ ti vissajjitaḥ paricchinnaḥ evam kira vatvā tena ayam dasa sahassī lokadhātu kampittha iti āha
translated: He was set free means that he was released, defined. After saying this, he said, “Then this ten-thousandfold world system shook” .

original: Ānandayācanakathā
analyzed: ānanda yācana kathā
translated: The story of Ānanda’s request

original: 178. Alanti paṭikkhepavacanametaṃ. Bodhinti catumaggañāṇapaṭiveghaṃ. Saddahasi tvanti
analyzed: alam paṭikkhepa vacanam etam bodhim ti catu magga ñāṇa paṭivegham saddahasi tvam ti
translated: “No” is a word of refusal. “Enlightenment” is the penetration of the four paths of knowledge. “Do you believe”

original: evaṃ vuttabhāvaṃ tathāgatassa saddahasīti vadati. Tasmātihānandāti yasmā idaṃ vacanaṃ
analyzed: evam vutta bhāvam tathāgatassa saddahasi iti vadati tasmā ati ha ānanda ati yasmai idam vacanam
translated: means “Do you believe that the Tathāgata has the state described in this way?” Therefore, Ānanda means “Since you believe this statement,

original: saddahasi, tasmā tuyhevetaṃ dukkaṭanti dasseti.
analyzed: sat dahasi tasmā tuyhā iva etam dukkaṭanti dasseti
translated: this is your fault” is what he shows.

original: 179. Ekamidāhanti idaṃ bhagavā – “na kevalaṃ ahaṃ idheva taṃ āmantesiṃ, aññadāpi
analyzed: ekam idā ahanti idam bhagavā na kevalam aham idha iva tam āmantesim aññadā api
translated: Once, Ānanda means “Not only did I address you here,

original: āmantetvā oḷārikaṃ nimittaṃ akāsiṃ, tampi tayā na paṭividdhaṃ, tavevāyaṃ aparādho”ti
analyzed: āmantetvā oḷārikam nimittam tayā na paṭividdham tava iva ayam aparādhaḥ iti
translated: but on another occasion also I addressed you and made a gross sign, which you did not understand. This is your fault” is what he shows.

original: evaṃ sokavinodanatthāya nānappakārato therasseva dosāropanatthaṃ ārabhi.
analyzed: evam soka vinodana tthāya nānā pakārataḥ therassa iva dosa āropana tham ārabhi
translated: Thus he began to heap up the Elder’s faults in various ways in order to dispel his sorrow.🔽“Dear and pleasing” : there is difference of birth, difference of death,

original: 183. Piyehi manāpehīti mātāpitābhātābhaginiādikehi jātiyā nānābhāvo, maraṇena vinābhāvo,
analyzed: manāpehi iti mātā pitā bhātā bhagini ādikehi jātiyā nānābhāvaḥ maraṇena vinābhāvaḥ
translated: and difference of destiny with mother, father, brother, sister, etc.

original: bhavena aññathābhāvo. Taṃ kutettha labbhāti tanti tasmā, yasmā sabbeheva piyehi manāpehi
analyzed: bhavena aññathābhāvo tam kuta ittha tanti tasmai yasmai sabbehi iva piyehi manāpehi
translated: “Where can that be found?” : since that is so, since there is difference with all dear and pleasing persons,

original: nānābhāvo, tasmā dasa pāramiyo pūretvāpi, sambodhiṃ patvāpi, dhammacakkaṃ pavattetvāpi,
analyzed: tasmā dasa pāramiyaḥ pūretvā api sambodhim patvā api dhammacakkam pavattetvā api
translated: therefore, even after fulfilling the ten perfections, even after attaining enlightenment, even after setting the Wheel of the Dhamma rolling,🔽even after showing the Twin Miracle, even after descending from the Tāvatimsa heaven,

original: yamakapāṭihāriyaṃ dassetvāpi, devorohaṇaṃ katvāpi, yaṃ taṃ jātaṃ bhūtaṃ saṅkhataṃ
analyzed: yamaka pāṭihāriyam dassetvā api deva ārohaṇam katvā api yam tam jātam bhūtam saṅkhatam
translated: that which is born, become, compounded,

original: palokadhammaṃ, taṃ vata tathāgatassāpi sarīraṃ mā palujjīti netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati,
analyzed: paloka dhammam tam vata tathāgatassa api sarīram mā palujji iti na itam ṭhānam vijjati
translated: subject to decay, that very body of the Tathāgata, too, will not escape decay.🔽It is not possible to obtain that cause, even by weeping and wailing.

original: rodantenāpi kandantenāpi na sakkā taṃ kāraṇaṃ laddhunti. Puna paccāvamissatīti yaṃ
analyzed: rodantena api kandantena api na sakkā tam kāraṇam laddhunti puna paccāvamissati iti yam
translated: “Will he come back again?” : what is lost, gone,

original: cattaṃ vantaṃ, taṃ vata puna paṭikhādissatīti attho.
analyzed: cattam vantam tam vata puna paṭikhādissati iti atthaḥ
translated: will that come back again? is the meaning.

original: 184. Yathayidaṃ brahmacariyanti yathā idaṃ sikkhāttayasaṅgahaṃ sāsanabrahmacariyaṃ.
analyzed: yathā idam yathā idam sāsana brahmacariyam
translated: ‘As this spiritual life’: as this spiritual life of the Dispensation which comprises the three trainings.

original: Addhaniyanti addhānakkhamaṃ. Ciraṭṭhitikanti cirappavattivasena ciraṭṭhitikaṃ. Cattāro
analyzed: addhaniyam addhānakkhamam ciraṭṭhitikam ti cira ppavatti vasena ciraṭṭhitikam cattāro
translated: ‘For a long time’: for a long period. ‘For a long endurance’: for a long endurance in occurrence.

original: satipaṭṭhānātiādi sabbaṃ lokiyalokuttaravaseneva kathitaṃ. Etesaṃ pana bodhipakkhiyānaṃ
analyzed: sati paṭṭhāna ati ādi sabbam lokiya lokuttara vasena iva kathitam etesam pana bodhi pakkhiyānam
translated: The four foundations of mindfulness and so on are all stated in terms of the mundane and supramundane.🔽But the exposition of these enlightenment factors

original: dhammānaṃ vinicchayo sabbākārena visuddhimagge paṭipadāñāṇadassanavisuddhiniddese
analyzed: dhammānam vinicchayaḥ sabba ākārena visuddhi magge paṭipadā ñāṇa dassana visuddhi niddese
translated: is given in all its aspects in the Path of Purity under the discernment of knowledge and vision of the way .

original: vutto. Sesamettha uttānamevāti.
analyzed: vuttaḥ sesam ettha uttānam eva ati
translated: The rest here is clear.

original: Tatiyabhāṇavāravaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: tatiya bhāṇa vāra vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the third recitation section is finished.

original: Nāgāpalokitavaṇṇanā
analyzed: nāgāpalokita vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the looking back

original: 186. Nāgāpalokitanti yathā hi mahājanassa aṭṭhīni koṭiyā koṭiṃ āhacca ṭhitāni paccekabuddhānaṃ,🔽aṅkusakalaggāni viya, na evaṃ buddhānaṃ. Buddhānaṃ pana saṅkhalikāni viya ekābaddhāni
analyzed: nāga apalokitam ti yathā hi mahā janassa aṭṭhīni koṭiyā koṭim āhacca ṭhitāni paccekabuddhānam  aṅkusaka laggāni viya na evam buddhānam buddhānam pana saṅkhalikāni viya eka ābaddhāni
translated: As for the looking back, just as the bones of the great man are set one on top of the other, like the links of a chain,

original: hutvā ṭhitāni, tasmā pacchato apalokanakāle na sakkā hoti gīvaṃ parivattetuṃ. Yathā
analyzed: hutvā ṭhitāni tasmai pacchatas apalokana kāle na sakkā hoti gīvam parivattetum yathā
translated: so that when he looks back he cannot turn his neck,

original: pana hatthināgo pacchābhāgaṃ apaloketukāmo sakalasarīreneva parivattati, evaṃ parivattitabbaṃ
analyzed: pana hatthi nāgaḥ pacchābhāgam apaloketu kāmo sakala sarīrena iva parivattati evam parivattitabbam
translated: But when an elephant wants to look back, it turns its whole body round. It must be turned round in this way.

original: hoti. Bhagavato pana nagaradvāre ṭhatvā – “vesāliṃ apalokessāmī”ti citte uppannamatte🔽– “bhagavā anekāni kappakoṭisahassāni pāramiyo pūrentehi tumhehi na gīvaṃ parivattetvā
analyzed: hoti bhagavataḥ pana nagara dvāre ṭhatvā vesālim apalokessāmi iti citte uppanna matte  bhagavā anekāni kappa koṭi sahassāni pāramiyaḥ pūrentehi tumhehi na gīvam parivattetvā
translated: But when the Blessed One stood at the city gate and thought, “I shall look at Vesālī,”

original: apalokanakammaṃ kata”nti ayaṃ pathavī kulālacakkaṃ viya parivattetvā bhagavantaṃ
analyzed: apalokana kammam katanti ayam pathavī kulāla cakkam viya parivattetvā bhagavantam
translated: the earth turned round like a potter’s wheel, bringing the Blessed One face to face with the city of Vesālī, as if to say, “You have not done this looking back by turning your neck, as you did when you were fulfilling the perfections for countless thousands of eons.”

original: vesālinagarābhimukhaṃ akāsi. Taṃ sandhāyetaṃ vuttaṃ.🔽Nanu ca na kevalaṃ vesāliyāva, sāvatthirājagahanāḷandapāṭaligāmakoṭigāmanātikagāmakesupi
analyzed: vesāli nagara abhimukham akāsi tam sandhāya itam vuttam  nanu ca na kevalam sāvatthi rājagahana āḷanda pāṭali gāma koṭi gāmana atika gāmakesupi
translated: This is what is meant by the words, “The earth turned round.”🔽But did not the Blessed One look back on all these places, Sāvatthī, Rājagaha, Nāḷandā, Pāṭaliputta, Koṭigāma, and Anāthapiṇḍika’s Park, when he left them?

original: tato tato nikkhantakāle taṃ taṃ sabbaṃ pacchimadassanameva, tattha tattha kasmā nāgāpalokitaṃ
analyzed: tatas tatas nikkhanta kāle tam tam sabbam pacchima dassanam eva tattha tattha kasmā nāga apalokitam
translated: Why then did he not look back on Vesālī?

original: nāpalokesīti? Anacchariyattā. Tattha tattha hi nivattetvā apalokentassetaṃ na acchariyaṃ
analyzed: na apalokesi iti an acchariya ttā tattha tattha hi nivattetvā apalokentassa etam na acchariyam
translated: Because it was not remarkable. It would not have been remarkable if he had looked back on any of these places.

original: hoti, tasmā nāpalokesi. Api ca vesālirājāno āsannavināsā, tiṇṇaṃ vassānaṃ upari vinassissanti.
analyzed: hoti tasmai na apalokesi api ca vesāli rājānaḥ āsanna vināsā tiṇṇam vassānam upari vinassissanti
translated: and therefore he did not look back. Moreover, the kings of Vesālī will be destroyed soon, within three years.

original: Te taṃ nagaradvāre nāgāpalokitaṃ nāma cetiyaṃ katvā gandhamālādīhi pūjessanti, taṃ
analyzed: te tam nagara dvāre nāgāpalokitam nāma cetiyam katvā gandha mālā ādīhi pūjessanti tam
translated: They will make a shrine called the Nāga’s Look-back at the city gate, and they will worship it with perfumes, garlands, and so on.

original: nesaṃ dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāya bhavissatīti tesaṃ anukampāya apalokesi.
analyzed: na isam dīgharattam hitāya sukhāya bhavissati iti tesam anukampāya apalokesi
translated: That will be for their benefit and happiness for a long time. Out of compassion for them he looked back.

original: Dukkhassantakaroti vaṭṭadukkhassa antakaro. Cakkhumāti pañcahi cakkhūhi cakkhumā. Parinibbutoti kilesaparinibbānena parinibbuto.
analyzed: dukkhassa anta karoti vaṭṭa dukkhassa anta karo cakkhumā ti pañcahi cakkhūhi cakkhumā parinibbutoti kilesa parinibbānena parinibbuto
translated: “The end of suffering”: the end of the suffering of the round. “The eye”: the one who is endowed with the five eyes. “Extinguished”: extinguished by the extinction of defilements.

original: Catumahāpadesavaṇṇanā
analyzed: catu mahā padesa vaṇṇanā
translated: The Four Great Authorities

original: 187. Mahāpadeseti mahāokāse, mahāapadese vā, buddhādayo mahante mahante apadisitvā vuttāni mahākāraṇānīti attho.
analyzed: mahāpadesa iti mahāokāse mahāapadese vā buddha ādayaḥ mahante mahante apadisitvā vuttāni mahā kāraṇāni iti attho
translated: “Great authorities”: great occasions, or great authorities. The meaning is: the great reasons that are stated after the Buddhas and so on have been given great authority.

original: 188. Neva abhinanditabbanti haṭṭhatuṭṭhehi sādhukāraṃ datvā pubbeva na sotabbaṃ,
analyzed: na iva abhinanditabbanti haṭṭha tuṭṭhehi sādhukāram da tvā pubbā iva na sotabbam
translated: “Should not be delighted in”: should not be listened to with cries of “Excellent!” even before .

original: evaṃ kate hi pacchā “idaṃ na sametī”ti vuccamāno – “kiṃ pubbeva ayaṃ dhammo, idāni
analyzed: evam kate hi pacchā idam na sameti iti vuccamānaḥ kim pubbā iva ayam dhammaḥ idāni
translated: For if that is done, then when it is said later, “This does not agree with that,” one will think, “Why, this doctrine is just like that one!

original: na dhammo”ti vatvā laddhiṃ na vissajjeti. Nappaṭikkositabbanti – “kiṃ esa bālo vadatī”ti
analyzed: na dhammaḥ ti vatvā laddhim na vissajjeti na paṭikkositabbanti kim esa bālaḥ vadati iti
translated: He does not give up his opinion. He should not contradict: he should not say, “What is this fool talking about? ”

original: evaṃ pubbeva na vattabbaṃ, evaṃ vutte hi vattuṃ yuttampi na vakkhati. Tenāha – “anabhinanditvā🔽appaṭikkositvā”ti. Padabyañjanānīti padasaṅkhātāni byañjanāni. Sādhukaṃ uggahetvāti🔽imasmiṃ ṭhāne pāḷi vuttā, imasmiṃ ṭhāne attho vutto, imasmiṃ ṭhāne anusandhi kathito,
analyzed: evam pubbā iva na vattabbam evam vutte hi vattum yuttam pi na vakkhati tena āha an abhinanditvā  a paṭikkositvā iti pada byañjanāni iti pada saṅkhātāni byañjanāni sādhukam uggahetvā iti  imasmin ṭhāne pāḷi vuttā imasmin ṭhāne atthaḥ vuttaḥ imasmin ṭhāne anusandhi kathitaḥ
translated: For if he does say this, he will not say what should be said, even though it is proper to say it. Hence it was said: “without approving or rejecting” .🔽The phrasing and the letter: the phrasing is the words, and the letter is the sounds.🔽He should learn them well: he should learn them well in this way: “In this place the text is recited, in this place the meaning is explained, in this place the connection is explained, in this place the sequence is explained.”

original: imasmiṃ ṭhāne pubbāparaṃ kathitanti suṭṭhu gahetvā. Sutte osāretabbānīti sutte otāretabbāni.
analyzed: imasmin ṭhāne pubba aparam kathitanti suṭṭhu gahetvā sutte osāretabbāni iti sutte otāretabbāni
translated: He should apply them to the Discourses: he should apply them to the Discourses.

original: Vinaye sandassetabbānīti vinaye saṃsandetabbāni.
analyzed: vinaye sandassetabbāni iti vinaye saṃsandetabbāni
translated: He should settle them in the Discipline: he should settle them in the Discipline.

original: Ettha ca suttanti vinayo. Yathāha – “kattha paṭikkhittaṃ? Sāvatthiyaṃ suttavibhaṅge”ti.
analyzed: ettha ca suttanti vinayaḥ yathā āha kattha paṭikkhittam sāvatthiyam sutta vibhaṅga iti
translated: And here the Discourses are the Discipline, as it is said: “Where was it laid down? At Sāvatthī, in the Suttavibhaṅga” .

original: Vinayoti khandhako. Yathāha – “vinayātisāre”ti. Evaṃ vinayapiṭakampi na pariyādiyati.
analyzed: khandhakaḥ yathā āha vinaya atisāra iti evam vinaya piṭakam pi na
translated: The Discipline is the chapter, as it is said: “In the case of an offense entailing expulsion” . In this way he does not neglect the Discourses or the Monastic Law.

original: Ubhatovibhaṅgā pana suttaṃ, khandhakaparivārā vinayoti evaṃ vinayapiṭakaṃ pariyādiyati.🔽Athavā suttantapiṭakaṃ suttaṃ, vinayapiṭakaṃ vinayoti evaṃ dveyeva piṭakāni pariyādiyanti.
analyzed: ubhatas vibhaṅgā pana suttam khandhaka parivārā vinayo ti evam vinaya piṭakam  athavā suttanta piṭakam suttam vinaya piṭakam vinaya uti evam dveyā iva piṭakāni
translated: But if the Sutta is taken as the Vibhaṅga in both parts, then the Vinaya is the Khandhaka and the Parivāra.🔽Or else, the Sutta Piṭaka is the Sutta and the Vinaya Piṭaka is the Vinaya. In this way only two Piṭakas are included.

original: Suttantābhidhammapiṭakāni vā suttaṃ, vinayapiṭakaṃ vinayoti evampi tīṇi piṭakāni
analyzed: suttanta abhidhamma piṭakāni vā suttam vinaya piṭakam vinayaḥ ti evam pi tīṇi piṭakāni
translated: Or else, the Sutta and Abhidhamma Piṭakas are the Sutta and the Vinaya Piṭaka is the Vinaya. In this way three Piṭakas are included.

original: na tāva pariyādiyanti. Asuttanāmakañhi buddhavacanaṃ nāma atthi. Seyyathidaṃ – jātakaṃ,
analyzed: na tāva pariyādiyanti a sutta nāmakam hi buddha vacanam nāma atthi sā iyyathā idam jātakam
translated: But they are not included in this way. For there is what is called the Buddha’s Word without Sutta, that is to say, the Jātaka,

original: paṭisambhidā, niddeso, suttanipāto, dhammapadaṃ, udānaṃ, itivuttakaṃ, vimānavatthu,
analyzed: paṭisambhidā niddesaḥ sutta nipātaḥ dhammapadam udānam itivuttakam vimāna vatthu
translated: the Paṭisambhidā, the Niddesa, the Suttanipāta, the Dhammapada, the Udāna, the Itivuttaka, the Vimānavatthu,

original: petavatthu, theragāthā, therīgāthā, apadānanti.
analyzed: petavatthu thera gāthā therī gāthāḥ
translated: the Petavatthu, the Theragāthā, the Therīgāthā, and the Apadāna.

original: Sudinnatthero pana – “asuttanāmakaṃ buddhavacanaṃ na atthī”ti taṃ sabbaṃ paṭipakkhipitvā
analyzed: sudinna theraḥ pana a sutta nāmakam buddha vacanam na atthi iti tam sabbam paṭipakkhipitvā
translated: But the Elder Sudinna rejected all this, saying: “There is no Buddha’s Word without sutta.”

original: – “tīṇi piṭakāni suttaṃ, vinayo pana kāraṇa”nti āha. Tato taṃ kāraṇaṃ dassento idaṃ suttamāhari –
analyzed: tīṇi piṭakāni suttam vinayaḥ pana kāraṇam ti āha tatas tam kāraṇam dassentaḥ idam suttam āhari
translated: And he said: “The three Piṭakas are the Sutta, but the Vinaya is the reason.” Then, in order to show that reason, he quoted this sutta:

original: “Ye kho tvaṃ, gotami, dhamme jāneyyāsi, ime dhammā sarāgāya saṃvattanti no virāgāya,
analyzed: ye kho tvam gotami dhamme jāneyyāsi ime dhammā sa rāgāya saṃvattanti no virāgāya
translated: “If you know of any qualities, Gotami, that lead to passion, not to dispassion,

original: saññogāya saṃvattanti no visaññogāya, ācayāya saṃvattanti no apacayāya, mahicchatāya
analyzed: saññogāya saṃvattanti no visaññogāya ācayāya saṃvattanti no apacayāya mahicchatāya
translated: to bondage, not to the absence of bondage, to an increase in things, not to a decrease in things, to great desires,

original: saṃvattanti no appicchatāya, asantuṭṭhiyā saṃvattanti no santuṭṭhiyā, saṅgaṇikāya
analyzed: saṃvattanti naḥ appicchatāya a santuṭṭhiyā saṃvattanti no santuṭṭhiyā saṅgaṇikāya
translated: not to fewness of wishes, to discontent, not to contentment, to socializing,

original: saṃvattanti no pavivekāya, kosajjāya saṃvattanti no vīriyārambhāya, dubbharatāya
analyzed: saṃvattanti no pavivekāya kosajjāya saṃvattanti no vīriya ārambhāya dubbharatāya
translated: not to solitude, to laziness, not to the arousal of energy, to difficulty in supporting oneself,

original: saṃvattanti no subharatāya. Ekaṃsena, gotami, dhāreyyāsi – ‘neso dhammo, neso vinayo,
analyzed: saṃvattanti naḥ subharatāya ekaṃsena gotami dhāreyyāsi na isaḥ dhammaḥ na isaḥ vinayo
translated: not to ease in supporting oneself, then you should definitely remember: ‘This is not the Teaching,’ ‘This is not the Discipline,’🔽‘This is not the Teacher’s instruction.’

original: netaṃ satthusāsana’nti. Ye ca kho tvaṃ, gotami, dhamme jāneyyāsi, ime dhammā virāgāya🔽saṃvattanti no sarāgāya, visaññogāya saṃvattanti no saññogāya, apacayāya saṃvattanti
analyzed: na itam satthu sāsanam ti ye ca kho tvam gotami dhamme jāneyyāsi ime dhammāḥ virāgāya  saṃvattanti no sa rāgāya visaññogāya saṃvattanti no saññogāya apacayāya saṃvattanti
translated: “If you know of any qualities, Gotami, that lead to dispassion, not to passion,🔽to the absence of bondage, not to bondage, to a decrease in things, not to an increase in things, to fewness of wishes,

original: no ācayāya, appicchatāya saṃvattanti no mahicchatāya, santuṭṭhiyā saṃvattanti no
analyzed: no ācayāya appicchatāya saṃvattanti no mahicchatāya santuṭṭhiyā saṃvattanti no
translated: not to great desires, to contentment, not to discontent,

original: asantuṭṭhiyā, pavivekāya saṃvattanti no saṅgaṇikāya, vīriyārambhāya saṃvattanti no
analyzed: a santuṭṭhiyā pavivekāya saṃvattanti no saṅgaṇikāya vīriya ārambhāya saṃvattanti no
translated: They lead to discontent, to solitude, to instigation of energy,

original: kosajjāya, subharatāya saṃvattanti no dubbharatāya. Ekaṃsena, gotami, dhāreyyāsi
analyzed: kosajjāya subharatāya saṃvattanti no dubbharatāya ekaṃsena gotami dhāreyyā asi
translated: to ease of support, not to difficulty of support. You can accept this, Gotami,

original: – ‘eso dhammo, eso vinayo, etaṃ satthusāsana’nti”.
analyzed: esaḥ dhammaḥ esaḥ vinayaḥ etam satthu sāsanan ti
translated: as a fact: ‘This is the Dhamma, this is the Discipline, this is the Teacher’s instruction.’ ”

original: Tasmā sutteti tepiṭake buddhavacane otāretabbāni. Vinayeti etasmiṃ rāgādivinayakāraṇe
analyzed: tasmā sutta iti tepiṭake buddha vacane otāretabbāni vinaya iti etasmim rāga ādi vinaya kāraṇe
translated: So they should be brought into line with the Suttas, that is to say, with the three Baskets of Discourses, Discourses in Chants, and Abstract Statements, which are the Buddha’s word.🔽They should be checked in the Discipline, that is to say, in this cause for the destruction of lust, etc.,

original: saṃsandetabbānīti ayamettha attho. Na ceva sutte osarantīti suttapaṭipāṭiyā katthaci
analyzed: saṃsandetabbāni iti ayam ettha atthaḥ na ca iva sutte osaranti iti sutta paṭipāṭiyā katthaci
translated: is the meaning here. And they do not come into line with the Suttas: the meaning is that they do not come into line with any of the Suttas in the Suttas’ sequence,

original: anāgantvā challiṃ uṭṭhapetvā guḷhavessantara-guḷhaummagga-guḷhavinaya-vedallapiṭakānaṃ
analyzed: an āgantvā challim uṭṭhapetvā guḷha vessantara guḷha ummagga guḷha vinaya vedalla piṭakānam
translated: but are found to come from the Challi, the Vessantara, the Guḷha, the Ummagga, the Guḷhavinaya, or the Vedalla Baskets.

original: aññatarato āgatāni paññāyantīti attho. Evaṃ āgatāni hi rāgādivinaye ca na paññāyamānāni
analyzed: aññataratas āgatāni paññāyanti iti attho evam āgatāni hi rāga ādi vinaye ca na paññāyamānāni
translated: For what comes from these is not found in the cause for the destruction of lust, etc.,

original: chaḍḍetabbāni honti. Tena vuttaṃ – “iti hetaṃ, bhikkhave, chaḍḍeyyāthā”ti. Etenupāyena
analyzed: chaḍḍetabbāni honti tena vuttam iti ha etam bhikkhave chaḍḍeyyātha ati etena upāyena
translated: and so it should be rejected. Hence it was said above ‘ So you can reject it, bhikkhus’ .

original: sabbattha attho veditabbo.
analyzed: sabbattha atthaḥ veditabbaḥ
translated: The meaning should be understood in this way in all instances.

original: Idaṃ, bhikkhave, catutthaṃ mahāpadesaṃ dhāreyyāthāti idaṃ catutthaṃ dhammassa patiṭṭhānokāsaṃ dhāreyyātha.
analyzed: idam bhikkhave catuttham mahā padesam dhāreyyātha ati idam catuttham dhammassa patiṭṭhāna ukāsam dhāreyyātha
translated: “You should bear in mind this fourth great reference.”

original: Imasmiṃ pana ṭhāne imaṃ pakiṇṇakaṃ veditabbaṃ. Sutte cattāro mahāpadesā, khandhake
analyzed: imasmim pana ṭhāne imam pakiṇṇakam veditabbam sutte cattāro mahāpadesā khandhake
translated: But in this place this additional matter should be known: In the discourses there are four great references,

analyzed: cattāraḥ mahāpadesā cattāri pañha byākaraṇāni suttam sutta anulomam ācariyavādo
translated: in the Khandhakas there are four great references, four answers to questions, discourse, what is in conformity with the discourse, the teacher’s words,

analyzed: attanomati tisso saṅgītiyā ti
translated: and one’s own opinion, and the three recitations.

original: Tattha – “ayaṃ dhammo, ayaṃ vinayo”ti dhammavinicchaye patte ime cattāro mahāpadesā pamāṇaṃ. Yaṃ ettha sameti tadeva gahetabbaṃ, itaraṃ viravantassapi na gahetabbaṃ.🔽“Idaṃ kappati, idaṃ na kappatī”ti kappiyākappiyavinicchaye patte – “yaṃ, bhikkhave,
analyzed: tattha ayam dhammaḥ ayam vinayo ti dhamma vinicchaye patte ime cattāro mahā padesā pamāṇam yat ettha sameti tat eva gahetabbam itaram viravantassa api na gahetabbam  idam kappati idam na kappati iti kappiya akappiya vinicchaye patte yam bhikkhave
translated: Herein, when there is a decision on the True Idea and the Discipline, “This is the True Idea, this is the Discipline, this is the Teacher’s instruction “ , these four great references are the measure. Whatever agrees with that should be accepted, and if it does not agree with the other it should not be accepted even if it is proclaimed.🔽When there is a decision on what is allowable and what is not allowable, “This is allowable, this is not allowable”,

original: mayā idaṃ na kappatīti appaṭikkhittaṃ, taṃ ce akappiyaṃ anulometi, kappiyaṃ paṭibāhati,
analyzed: mayā idam na kappati iti appaṭikkhittam tam ce akappiyam anuloma iti kappiyam paṭibāhati
translated: “Monks, whatever I have not prohibited as not allowable, if that agrees with what is not allowable and contradicts what is allowable,

analyzed: tam vaḥ na kappati iti ādinā nayena khandhake vuttā cattāro mahāpadesā pamāṇam tesam
translated: The four great authorities stated in the Khandhaka in the way beginning, “That is not allowable for you” are the measure.🔽The discussion of their interpretation is given in the Samantapāsādikā.

analyzed: vinicchaya kathā samantapāsādikā ayam vuttā tattha vutta nayena yam kappiyam anuloma iti
translated: There, after deciding that what is allowable is in conformity with what is stated there,

analyzed: tat eva kappiyam itaram a kappiyanti evam sanniṭṭhānam kātabbam  ekaṃsa byākaraṇīyaḥ pañhaḥ vibhajja byākaraṇīyaḥ pañho paṭipucchā byākaraṇīyaḥ pañho
translated: it should be concluded that the rest is not allowable.🔽There are these four kinds of answers to questions, that is to say, an answer that is definite, an answer that is to be analysed, an answer that is to be analysed in return, and an answer that is to be set aside.

original: ṭhapanīyo pañhoti imāni cattāri pañhabyākaraṇāni nāma. Tattha “cakkhuṃ anicca”nti
analyzed: ṭhapanīyaḥ pañho ti imāni cattāri pañha byākaraṇāni nāma tattha cakkhum aniccanti
translated: Herein, when asked, “Is the eye impermanent? ”

original: puṭṭhena – “āma anicca”nti ekaṃseneva byākātabbaṃ. Esa nayo sotādīsu. Ayaṃ ekaṃsabyākaraṇīyo🔽pañho. “Aniccaṃ nāma cakkhu”nti puṭṭhena – “na cakkhumeva, sotampi aniccaṃ ghānampi
analyzed: puṭṭhena ekaṃsena iva byākātabbam esa nayaḥ sota ādīsu ayam ekaṃsa byākaraṇīyaḥ  pañhaḥ aniccam nāma cakkhunti puṭṭhena na cakkhum eva sotam pi aniccam ghānam pi
translated: an answer is to be given definitely thus, “It is impermanent.” The same method applies in the case of the ear, and so on. This is a question to be answered definitely.🔽When asked, “What is impermanent is the eye? ”

original: anicca”nti evaṃ vibhajitvā byākātabbaṃ. Ayaṃ vibhajjabyākaraṇīyo pañho. “Yathā cakkhu
analyzed: aniccanti evam vibhajitvā byākātabbam ayam vibhajja byākaraṇīyaḥ pañhaḥ yathā cakkhu
translated: an answer is to be given by analysing it thus, “Not only the eye, but also the ear is impermanent, the nose is impermanent, the tongue is impermanent, the body is impermanent, the mind is impermanent” . This is a question to be answered by analysis. When asked, “Is the eye only impermanent, or is the ear, too, impermanent? ”

original: tathā sotaṃ, yathā sotaṃ tathā cakkhu”nti puṭṭhena “kenaṭṭhena pucchasī”ti paṭipucchitvā
analyzed: tathā sotam yathā sotam tathā cakkhunti puṭṭhena kenaṭṭhena pucchasi iti paṭipucchitvā
translated: and when asked, “In what sense do you ask? “

original: “dassanaṭṭhena pucchāmī”ti vutte “na hī”ti byākātabbaṃ, “aniccaṭṭhena pucchāmī”ti
analyzed: dassana ṭṭhena pucchāmi iti vutte na hi iti byākātabbam anicca ṭṭhena pucchāmi iti
translated: and he replies, “In the sense of seeing,” the answer is “No.” If he replies, “In the sense of impermanence,”🔽the answer is “Yes.” This is a question to be answered by a counter-question.

original: vutte āmāti byākātabbaṃ. Ayaṃ paṭipucchābyākaraṇīyo pañho. “Taṃ jīvaṃ taṃ sarīra”ntiādīni
analyzed: vutte āma ati byākātabbam ayam paṭipucchā byākaraṇīyaḥ pañho tam jīvam tam sarīram ti ādīni
translated: When asked, “Is the soul the same as the body? “

original: puṭṭhena pana “abyākatametaṃ bhagavatā”ti ṭhapetabbo, esa pañho na byākātabbo. Ayaṃ
analyzed: puṭṭhena pana a byākatam etam bhagavatā ati ṭhapetabbaḥ esa pañhaḥ na byākātabbaḥ ayaṃ
translated: the question is to be set aside with the words, “This has not been declared by the Blessed One.” This is a question to be set aside.

original: ṭhapanīyo pañho. Iti tenākārena pañhe sampatte imāni cattāri pañhabyākaraṇāni pamāṇaṃ.
analyzed: pañhaḥ iti tena ākārena pañhe sampatte imāni cattāri pañha byākaraṇāni pamāṇam
translated: So when a question is put in these four ways, these four answers to questions are the measure.

original: Imesaṃ vasena so pañho byākātabbo.
analyzed: imesam vasena so pañhaḥ byākātabbo
translated: The question is to be answered according to these.

original: Suttādīsu pana suttaṃ nāma tisso saṅgītiyo ārūḷhāni tīṇi piṭakāni. Suttānulomaṃ nāma
analyzed: sutta ādīsu pana suttam nāma tissaḥ saṅgītiyaḥ ārūḷhāni tīṇi piṭakāni suttānulomam nāma
translated: As regards the Scriptures, etc., the Scriptures are the three Piṭakas handed down in three Recensions. The Analogy is

original: anulomakappiyaṃ. Ācariyavādo nāma aṭṭhakathā. Attanomati nāma nayaggāhena anubuddhiyā

original: attano paṭibhānaṃ. Tattha suttaṃ appaṭibāhiyaṃ, taṃ paṭibāhantena buddhova paṭibāhito🔽hoti. Anulomakappiyaṃ pana suttena samentameva gahetabbaṃ, na itaraṃ. Ācariyavādopi
analyzed: attanaḥ paṭibhānam tattha suttam appaṭibāhiyam tam paṭibāhantena buddhaḥ iva paṭibāhitaḥ  hoti anulomakappiyam pana suttena gahetabbam na itaram ācariya vādaḥ api
translated: and his own opinion. Herein, if a sutta is not to be confuted, then he who confutes it confutes only the Enlightened One. But what is in conformity with what is proper can be accepted only when it is in conformity with the sutta, not otherwise. And the opinion of a teacher

original: suttena samentoyeva gahetabbo, na itaro. Attanomati pana sabbadubbalā, sāpi suttena🔽samentāyeva gahetabbā, na itarā. Pañcasatikā, sattasatikā, sahassikāti imā pana tisso🔽saṅgītiyo. Suttampi tāsu āgatameva pamāṇaṃ, itaraṃ gārayhasuttaṃ na gahetabbaṃ. Tattha
analyzed: suttena samentaḥ yā iva gahetabbaḥ na itaraḥ attanomati pana sabba dubbalā sā api suttena  samentāya iva gahetabbā na itarā pañcasatikā sattasatikā sahassikā ati imāḥ pana tisso  saṅgītiyo suttam pi tāsu āgatam eva pamāṇam itaram gārayha suttam na gahetabbam tattha
translated: and his own opinion. Herein, if a Thread is not contradicted, then when it is contradicted it is contradicted only by the Enlightened One. But what is in conformity with what is allowable must be taken only when it is in conformity with the Thread, not otherwise. And the teacher’s statement must be taken only when it is in conformity with the Thread, not otherwise. And one’s own opinion is the weakest of all; that too must be taken only when it is in conformity with the Thread, not otherwise.

original: otarantānipi hi padabyañjanāni na ceva sutte otaranti, na ca vinaye sandissantīti veditabbāni.
analyzed: otarantāni api hi pada byañjanāni na ca iva sutte otaranti na ca vinaye sandissanti iti veditabbāni
translated: The three Recitations are the recitation of five hundred, the recitation of seven hundred, and the recitation of a thousand. Herein, the Thread that occurs in them is the only measure, not the other, which is a Thread of dispraise and must not be taken. For even the words and syllables that occur in them do not occur in the Thread or conform to the Discipline.

original: Kammāraputtacundavatthuvaṇṇanā
analyzed: kammāra putta cunda vatthu vaṇṇanā
translated: The Description of the Case of the Goldsmith’s Son

original: 189. Kammāraputtassāti suvaṇṇakāraputtassa. So kira aḍḍho mahākuṭumbiko bhagavato
analyzed: kammāra puttassa ati suvaṇṇakāra puttassa so kira aḍḍhaḥ mahākuṭumbikaḥ bhagavataḥ
translated: The son of a goldsmith: the son of a goldsmith. He was rich and had a large family. He had faith in the Blessed One.

original: paṭhamadassaneneva sotāpanno hutvā attano ambavane vihāraṃ kārāpetvā niyyātesi. Taṃ
analyzed: paṭhama dassanena iva sotāpannaḥ hutvā attanaḥ ambavane vihāram kārāpetvā niyyātesi tam
translated: and by the first sight of the Master he became a Stream-Winner and had a monastery built in his own mango grove and presented it to the Master.

original: sandhāya vuttaṃ – “ambavane”ti.🔽Sūkaramaddavanti nātitaruṇassa nātijiṇṇassa ekajeṭṭhakasūkarassa pavattamaṃsaṃ. Taṃ🔽kira mudu ceva siniddhañca hoti, taṃ paṭiyādāpetvā sādhukaṃ pacāpetvāti attho. Eke
analyzed: sandhāya vuttam ambavana iti  sūkara maddavanti na ati taruṇassa na ati jiṇṇassa eka jeṭṭhaka sūkarassa pavatta maṃsam tam  kira mudu ca iva siniddham ca hoti tam paṭiyādāpetvā sādhukam pacāpetvā ati eke
translated: This is what is meant by “in the mango grove.”

original: bhaṇanti – “sūkaramaddavanti pana muduodanassa pañcagorasayūsapācanavidhānassa nāmetaṃ,
analyzed: bhaṇanti pana mudu odanassa pañca gorasa yūsa pācana vidhānassa nāma etam

Some say: “But tender pork is not the name for the cooking of the five kinds of meat and the five kinds of sauces,🔽just as the name ‘cow’s drink’ is not the name for the cooking of the five kinds of meat.”

original: yathā gavapānaṃ nāma pākanāma”nti. Keci bhaṇanti – “sūkaramaddavaṃ nāma rasāyanavidhi,

analyzed: rasāyanam paṭiyattanti tattha pana dvi sahassa dīpa parivāresu catūsu mahā dīpesu devatāḥ ojam pakkhipiṃsu
translated: ” Therein, however, the deities infused potency in the four great continents surrounded by two thousand islands.

original: Nāhaṃ tanti imaṃ sīhanādaṃ kimatthaṃ nadati? Parūpavādamocanatthaṃ. Attanā paribhuttāvasesaṃ
analyzed: na aham tanti imam sīha nādam kimattham nadati parūpa vāda mocana attham attanā
translated: Why did I utter this lion’s roar? In order to free myself from the reproach of others. I did not give to the bhikkhus or to men what was left over from my own use. I had it thrown into the cesspit and destroyed.

original: neva bhikkhūnaṃ, na manussānaṃ dātuṃ adāsi, āvāṭe nikhaṇāpetvā vināsesīti hi vattukāmānaṃ
analyzed: na iva bhikkhūnam na manussānam dātum adāsi āvāṭe nikhaṇāpetvā vināsesi iti hi vattu kāmānam
translated: If they want to say this,

analyzed: idam sutvā vacana ukāsaḥ na bhavissati iti paresam upavāda mocana attham sīha nādam nadati iti
translated: they will have no opportunity to speak after hearing this. Therefore I utter this lion’s roar in order to free myself from the reproach of others.

analyzed: bhuttassa ca sūkara maddavena ati bhuttassa udapādi na pana bhutta paccayā yadi
translated: . “And when the food had been digested” : it arose after the food had been digested, not as a result of the food.

original: hi abhuttassa uppajjissatha, atikharo bhavissati. Siniddhabhojanaṃ bhuttattā panassa
analyzed: hi a bhuttassa uppajjissatha ati kharaḥ bhavissati siniddha bhojanam bhutta ttā panassa
translated: For if it had arisen before the food had been digested, it would have been very sharp. But because he had eaten soft food,

original: tanuvedanā ahosi. Teneva padasā gantuṃ asakkhi. Virecamānoti abhiṇhaṃ pavattalohitavirecanova🔽samāno. Avocāti attanā patthitaṭṭhāne parinibbānatthāya evamāha. Imā pana dhammasaṅgāhakattherehi
analyzed: tanu vedanā ahosi tena iva padasā gantum asakkhi virecamānā iti abhiṇham pavatta lohita virecanā uva  samānaḥ avoca iti attanā patthita ṭṭhāne parinibbāna tthāya evam āha imā pana dhammasaṅgāhaka therehi
translated: his pain was slight. Therefore he was unable to go on foot. “With blood flowing” :

translated: having a frequent discharge of blood. “I spoke” : I spoke thus for the purpose of attaining final Nibbāna in the place I had chosen. But these verses should be understood as having been composed by the compilers of the Dhamma.

original: Pānīyāharaṇavaṇṇanā
analyzed: pānīya āharaṇa vaṇṇanā
translated: The Description of the Bringing of Drinking Water

original: 191. Iṅghāti codanatthe nipāto. Acchodakāti pasannodakā. Sātodakāti madhurodakā. Sītodakāti tanusītalasalilā. Setakāti nikkaddamā. Suppatitthāti sundaratitthā.
analyzed: iṅghā ati codana atthe nipātaḥ acchodakā ati pasanna udakā sātodakā ati madhura udakā sītodakā ati tanu sītala salilā setakā ati nikkaddamā suppatitthā ati sundaratitthā
translated: ‘Come now’: this is a particle in the sense of an exhortation. ‘Clear water’: water that is clear. ‘Pleasant water’: water that is sweet. ‘Cool water’: water that is cool and light. ‘Accessible water’: water that is not difficult to get to. ‘With beautiful banks’: water that has beautiful banks.

original: Pukkusamallaputtavatthuvaṇṇanā
translated: The story of Pukkusa Mallaputta

original: 192. Pukkusoti tassa nāmaṃ. Mallaputtoti mallarājaputto. Mallā kira vārena rajjaṃ
analyzed: pukkuso ti tassa nāmam malla putto ti malla rāja putto mallā kira vārena rajjam
translated: Pukkusa: this was his name. Mallaputta: the son of a king of the Malla clan. The Malla clan, it seems, ruled the kingdom by turns.

original: kārenti. Yāva nesaṃ vāro na pāpuṇāti, tāva vaṇijjaṃ karonti. Ayampi vaṇijjameva karonto
analyzed: kārenti yāva vāraḥ na pāpuṇāti tāva vaṇijjam karonti ayam pi vaṇijjam eva karontaḥ
translated: As long as their turn had not come, they made a living by trade. This man, too, was making a living by trade.

original: pañca sakaṭasatāni yojāpetvā dhuravāte vāyante purato gacchati, pacchā vāte vāyante
analyzed: pañca sakaṭa satāni yojā petvā dhura vāte vāyante puratas gacchati pacchā vāte vāyante
translated: He yoked five hundred carts and went ahead when the wind was favorable,🔽and sent the caravan-leader ahead and went himself when the wind was unfavorable.

original: satthavāhaṃ purato pesetvā sayaṃ pacchā gacchati. Tadā pana pacchā vāto vāyi, tasmā
analyzed: satthavāham puratas pesetvā sayam pacchā gacchati tadā pana pacchā vāto vāyi tasmā
translated: At that time, however, the wind was unfavorable, so

translated: he sent the caravan-leader ahead and, sitting in a jeweled vehicle, left Kusinara and went to Pava,

original: gamissāmī”ti maggaṃ paṭipajji. Tena vuttaṃ – “kusinārāya pāvaṃ addhānamaggappaṭipanno hotī”ti.
analyzed: gamissāmi iti maggam paṭipajji tena vuttam kusinārāya addhāna magga paṭipannaḥ hoti iti
translated: He set out on the road, and so it was said of him: “He was travelling along the highway from Kusinārā to Pāvā.”

original: Āḷāroti tassa nāmaṃ. Dīghapiṅgalo kireso, tenassa āḷāroti nāmaṃ ahosi. Kālāmoti gottaṃ.
analyzed: āḷāro ti tassa nāmam dīghapiṅgalo kireso tena assa āḷāro ti nāmam ahosi kālāmo ti gottam
translated: Ālāra is his name. He was a Kālāma, and so he was called Ālāra Kālāma.

original: Yatra hi nāmāti yo nāma. Neva dakkhatīti na addasa. Yatrasaddayuttattā panetaṃ anāgatavasena
analyzed: yatra hi nāma ati yaḥ nāma na iva dakkhati iti na anāgata vasena
translated: Yatra hi nāma: “Yatra hi nāma” means “if one could see.” Neva dakkhati: “he will not see.” But this is said in the future tense

original: vuttaṃ. Evarūpañhi īdisesu ṭhānesu saddalakkhaṇaṃ.🔽193. Niccharantīsūti vicarantīsu. Asaniyā phalantiyāti navavidhāya asaniyā bhijjamānāya
analyzed: vuttam evarūpam hi īdisesu ṭhānesu sadda lakkhaṇam  niccharantīsu iti vicarantīsu asaniyā phalantiyā ati navavidhāya asaniyā bhijjamānāya
translated: because of the connection with the word yattha. For such is the characteristic of the word yattha in such passages.🔽Niccharantīsu: “niccharantīsu” means “moving about.” Asaniyā phalantiyāti: “asaniyā phalantiyā” means “crashing down” like the lightning of the nine kinds of thunderbolts.

original: viya mahāravaṃ ravantiyā. Navavidhā hi asaniyo – asaññā, vicakkā, saterā, gaggarā,
analyzed: viya mahā ravam ravantiyāḥ navavidhāḥ hi asaniyaḥ asaññāḥ vicakkā saterāḥ gaggarā
translated: For there are nine kinds of thunderbolts: the unconscious, the wheel-like, the zigzag, the bubbling,

original: kapisīsā, macchavilolikā, kukkuṭakā, daṇḍamaṇikā, sukkhāsanīti. Tattha asaññā asaññaṃ
analyzed: kapisīsā macchavilolikā kukkuṭakā daṇḍamaṇikā sukkhāsanī ti tattha asaññā asaññam
translated: the monkey-like, the fish-like, the cock-like, the stick-like, and the dry lightning. Herein, the unconscious makes one unconscious;

original: karoti. Vicakkā ekaṃ cakkaṃ karoti. Saterā saterasadisā hutvā patati. Gaggarā gaggarāyamānā
analyzed: karoti vicakkā ekam cakkam karoti saterā satera sadisā hutvā patati gaggarā gaggarāyamānā
translated: the wheel-like makes a wheel; the zigzag moves about zigzagging; the bubbling makes a bubbling sound;🔽the monkey-like moves about like a monkey; the fish-like moves about like a fish; the cock-like makes a cock’s crow; the stick-like moves about like a stick; the dry lightning is dry.

original: patati. Kapisīsā bhamukaṃ ukkhipento makkaṭo viya hoti. Macchavilolikā vilolitamaccho🔽viya hoti. Kukkuṭakā kukkuṭasadisā hutvā patati. Daṇḍamaṇikā naṅgalasadisā hutvā
analyzed: patati kapi sīsā bhamukam ukkhipentaḥ makkaṭaḥ viya hoti maccha vilolikā vilolita macchaḥ  viya hoti kukkuṭakā kukkuṭa sadisāḥ hutvā patati daṇḍamaṇikā naṅgala sadisāḥ hutvā
translated: He falls like a monkey raising his snout and stretching his buttocks. He is like a fish wriggling about.🔽He falls like a cock. He is like a ploughshare.

original: patati. Sukkhāsanī patitaṭṭhānaṃ samugghāṭeti.🔽Deve vassanteti sukkhagajjitaṃ gajjitvā antarantarā vassante. Ātumāyanti ātumaṃ nissāya
analyzed: patati sukkha āsanī patita ṭṭhānam samugghāṭeti  deve vassante iti sukkha gajjitam gajjitvā antarantarā vassante ātumāyanti ātumam nissāya
translated: He falls down like a monkey who has lifted up a branch with a hollow in it. The fish-flopper is like a fish that has been flopped. The cock-fighter falls down like a cock. The stick-gem falls down like a ploughshare. The dry-cleaner tears up the place where he has fallen.

original: viharāmi. Bhusāgāreti khalasālāyaṃ. Etthesoti etasmiṃ kāraṇe eso mahājanakāyo sannipatito.
analyzed: viharāmi bhusāgāra iti etthā isaḥ iti etasmin kāraṇe esaḥ mahā jana kāyo sannipatitaḥ
translated: When the gods are raining: when the gods are thundering with a dry thunder and are raining now and then. In Ātumā: I am living near Ātumā. In the Bhusāgāra: in the hall with the peaked roof. Here is this: for this reason this great crowd has assembled.

original: Kva ahosīti kuhiṃ ahosi. So taṃ bhanteti so tvaṃ bhante.🔽194. Siṅgīvaṇṇanti siṅgīsuvaṇṇavaṇṇaṃ. Yugamaṭṭhanti maṭṭhayugaṃ, saṇhasāṭakayugaḷanti
analyzed: kva ahosi iti kuhim ahosi saḥ tam bhanta iti saḥ tvam bhante  siṅgī vaṇṇanti siṅgī suvaṇṇa vaṇṇam yugam aṭṭhanti maṭṭha yugam
translated: Where was he? Where was he? He, venerable sir: he, venerable sir.

original: attho. Dhāraṇīyanti antarantarā mayā dhāretabbaṃ, paridahitabbanti attho. Taṃ kira
analyzed: attho dhāraṇīyanti antar antarā mayā dhāretabbam paridahitabbam ti attho tam kira
translated: The colour of a jasmine: the colour of a jasmine flower. A pair of fine: a fine pair, the meaning is, a pair of fine cloths. To be borne: to be borne by me now and then, the meaning is to be carried. It seems that

analyzed: saḥ tathārūpe dhāretvā sesa kāle nikkhipati evam uttamam maṅgalavattha yugam  sandhāya āha anukampam upādāya ati mayi anukampam paṭicca acchādehi iti upacāra vacanam etam
translated: He kept them for the six days of the Observance and then put them away. The Elder said this, referring to the pair of robes as the supreme blessing.

original: – ekaṃ mayhaṃ dehi, ekaṃ ānandassāti attho. Kiṃ pana thero taṃ gaṇhīti? Āma gaṇhi.
analyzed: ekam mayham dehi ekam ānandassa ati attho kim pana theraḥ tam gaṇhi iti āma gaṇhi
translated: “Out of compassion for me”: out of compassion for me. “Give me one”: this is a polite form of expression. The meaning is: “Give me one, and one to Ānanda.” But did the Elder accept them? Yes, he did.

original: Kasmā? Matthakappattakiccattā. Kiñcāpi hesa evarūpaṃ lābhaṃ paṭikkhipitvā upaṭṭhākaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: kasmā matthaka ppatta kicca ttā kiñca api ha esa evarūpam lābham paṭikkhipitvā upaṭṭhāka ṭṭhānam
translated: Why? Because the service he had rendered had reached its climax. Although he had refused such gains, he had undertaken the service of the Teacher.

analyzed: paṭipanno tam panassa upaṭṭhāka kiccam matthakam pattam tasmai aggahesi ye ca api  evam vadeyyum anārādhakaḥ maññe ānando pañcavīsati vassāni upaṭṭhahantena na kiñci  bhagavato santikā tena laddha pubbanti tesam vacana ukāsa chedana attham pi aggahesi
translated: But that service had reached its climax. Therefore he accepted them.🔽And he accepted them also in order to refute those who might say: “It seems that Ānanda has not received anything from the Blessed One during the twenty-five years he served him.”

original: Api ca jānāti bhagavā – “ānando gahetvāpi attanā na dhāressati, mayhaṃyeva pūjaṃ
analyzed: api ca jānāti bhagavā ānandaḥ gahetvā api attanā na dhāressati pūjam
translated: And the Blessed One knew that Ānanda, although he had accepted the robes, would not keep them for himself but would offer them to the Blessed One for his worship.

original: karissati. Mallaputtena pana ānandaṃ pūjentena saṅghopi pūjito bhavissati, evamassa
analyzed: karissati malla puttena pana ānandam pūjentena saṅghaḥ api pūjitaḥ bhavissati evam assa
translated: But if the Mallas worship Ānanda, the Community will be worshipped too. Thus

original: mahāpuññarāsi bhavissatī”ti therassa ekaṃ dāpesi. Theropi teneva kāraṇena aggahesīti.
analyzed: mahā puñña rāsi bhavissati iti therassa ekam dāpesi theraḥ api tena iva kāraṇena aggahesi iti
translated: he will have a great heap of merit.” The Elder accepted the robe-cloth for that reason.

original: Dhammiyā kathāyāti vatthānumodanakathāya.
analyzed: dhammiyā kathāya ati vattha anumodana kathāya
translated: “A talk on Dhamma”: a talk on the subject of the robe-cloth.

original: 195. Bhagavato kāyaṃ upanāmitanti nivāsanapārupanavasena allīyāpitaṃ. Bhagavāpi tato
analyzed: bhagavataḥ kāyam nivāsana pārupana vasena bhagavā api tatas
translated: “Brought to the Blessed One”: put on him by way of wearing the inner and outer robes. The Blessed One

original: ekaṃ nivāsesi, ekaṃ pārupi. Hataccikaṃ viyāti yathā hatacciko aṅgāro antanteneva
analyzed: ekam hataccikam viyāti yathā hataccikaḥ aṅgāraḥ antantena iva
translated: put on one of the robes and wore the other. “Like a live coal”: just as a live coal glows

original: jotati, bahi panassa pabhā natthi, evaṃ bahi paṭicchannappabhaṃ hutvā khāyatīti attho.
analyzed: jotati bahi panassa pabhā na atthi evam bahi paṭicchanna ppabham hutvā khāyati iti attho
translated: inside and out, so it appeared, covered with light on the outside.

original: Imesu kho, ānanda, dvīsupi kālesūti kasmā imesu dvīsu kālesu evaṃ hoti? Āhāravisesena
analyzed: imesu kho ānanda dvīsu pi kālesu uti kasmai imesu dvīsu kālesu evam hoti āhāra visesena
translated: “In these two instances”: Why is it so in these two instances? Because of the special

analyzed: ca iva balava somanassena ca etesu hi dvīsu kālesu sakala cakkavāḷe devatā āhāre ojaṃ
translated: food and the strong joy. For in these two instances the deities of the entire universe🔽give strength to the food and to the joy.

original: pakkhipanti, taṃ paṇītabhojanaṃ kucchiṃ pavisitvā pasannarūpaṃ samuṭṭhāpeti. Āhārasamuṭṭhānarūpassa
analyzed: pakkhipanti tam paṇīta bhojanam kucchim pavisitvā pasanna rūpam samuṭṭhāpeti āhāra samuṭṭhāna rūpassa
translated: Because of the clarity of the material derived from nutriment,🔽the six faculties of the mind base become exceedingly clear.

analyzed: pasannattā manacchaṭṭhāni indriyāni ativiya virocanti sambodhi divase ca ssa aneka kappa koṭi sata sahassa sañcito
translated: On the day of his enlightenment, he reflected thus: “Today the mass of defilements, accumulated during many hundreds of thousands of world-cycles,

analyzed: vata me kilesa rāsi ajja pahīnaḥ ti āvajjantassa balava somanassam uppajjati cittam
translated: has been abandoned by me.” As he did so, a strong sense of joy arose in him, and his mind became clear.

analyzed: pasīdati citte pasanne lohitam pasīdati lohite pasanne manacchaṭṭhāni indriyāni  ativiya virocanti parinibbāna divase pi ajja dāna aham anekehi buddha sata sahassehi
translated: When the mind is clear, the blood becomes clear. When the blood is clear, the six faculties of the mind base become exceedingly clear.🔽On the day of his final Nibbāna, he reflected thus: “Today I shall enter the city of Nibbāna, the great deathless,

analyzed: paviṭṭham amatamahānibbānam nāma nagaram pavisissāmi iti āvajjantassa balava somanassam
translated: into which many hundreds of thousands of Buddhas have already entered.” As he did so, a strong sense of joy arose in him, and his mind became clear.

original: uppajjati, cittaṃ pasīdati, citte pasanne lohitaṃ pasīdati, lohite pasanne manacchaṭṭhāni
analyzed: uppajjati cittam pasīdati citte pasanne lohitam pasīdati lohite pasanne manacchaṭṭhāni
translated: When the mind is clear, the blood becomes clear. When the blood is clear, the six faculties of the mind base become exceedingly clear.

original: indriyāni ativiya virocanti. Iti āhāravisesena ceva balavasomanassena ca imesu dvīsu
analyzed: indriyāni ativiya virocanti iti āhāra visesena ca iva balava somanassena ca imesu dvīsu

analyzed: kālesu evam hoti iti veditabbam upavattane iti pācīnatas nivattana sālavane antarena
translated: and the faculties shine forth. So it should be understood that it is on these two occasions that it is so owing to the excellence of the nutriment and the strength of the joy. In Upavattana: in the turning-round rest-house to the east of the city. Between

translated: After bathing and drinking: it seems that at that time, when the Blessed One was bathing, the fish and turtles in the river

To venerable Cundaka: it seems that at that moment the Elder Ananda was sinking down, weighed down by his bathing robe, and the Elder Cundaka was near by. The Blessed One addressed him.

original: Gantvāna buddho nadikaṃ kakudhanti imāpi gāthā saṅgītikāleyeva ṭhapitā. Tattha pavattā
analyzed: gantvāna buddhaḥ nadikam kakudhanti imā api gāthā saṅgīti kāleyā iva ṭhapitā tattha pavattā
translated: The verses beginning “The Enlightened One went down to the river Kakuttha” were also recited at the time of the rehearsal of the True Dhamma. Herein,

original: bhagavā idha dhammeti bhagavā idha sāsane dhamme pavattā, caturāsīti dhammakkhandhasahassāni
analyzed: bhagavā idha dhammeti bhagavā idha sāsane dhamme pavattā catur asīti dhammakkhandha sahassāni
translated: The Blessed One is the Dhamma here: the Blessed One is the Dhamma that occurs here in his dispensation, the eighty-four thousand aggregates of Dhamma.

original: pavattānīti attho. Pamukhe nisīdīti satthu puratova nisīdi. Ettāvatā ca thero anuppatto.
analyzed: pavattāni iti attho pamukhe nisīdi iti satthu puratas va nisīdi ettāvatā ca theraḥ an uppatto
translated: The meaning is that he is the one who causes them to occur. He sat down in front: he sat down in front of the Master. And at this point the Elder had arrived.

analyzed: evam anuppattam atha kho bhagavā āyasmantam ānandam āmantesi
translated: When he had arrived, then the Blessed One addressed the venerable Ananda:

analyzed: alābha ati ye aññesam dāna anisaṃsa saṅkhātāḥ lābhāḥ honti te alābhāḥ
translated: No gain: the gains that are a gain of the benefits of giving to others are no gain. Hard to get:

analyzed: puñña visesena laddham api manussa ttam dulladdham yassa te ti yassa tava uttaṇḍulam  vā ati kilinnam vā kaḥ jānāti kīdisam pi pacchimam piṇḍapātam paribhuñjitvā tathāgataḥ
translated: human birth, which is got by a special kind of merit, is hard to get. Yours: yours. Rice-gruel:🔽who knows what kind of last alms food the Tathāgata has eaten and then attained final Nibbāna? Surely it must have been something or other given by you. Gain:

original: parinibbuto, addhā te yaṃ vā taṃ vā dinnaṃ bhavissatīti. Lābhāti diṭṭhadhammikasamparāyikadānānisaṃsasaṅkhātā
analyzed: parinibbutaḥ addhā te yam vā tam vā dinnam bhavissati iti diṭṭhadhammika samparāyika dāna anisaṃsa saṅkhātā
translated: the gains that are the benefits of giving in this life and the life to come. Well got:

original: lābhā. Suladdhanti tuyhaṃ manussattaṃ suladdhaṃ. Samasamaphalāti sabbākārena samānaphalā.
analyzed: lābhā su laddhanti tuyham manussattam su laddham sama sama phalā ati sabba ākārena samāna phalā
translated: your human birth is well got. Equal in fruit: it has the same fruit in every way.

original: Nanu ca yaṃ sujātāya dinnaṃ piṇḍapātaṃ bhuñjitvā tathāgato abhisambuddho, so sarāgasadosasamohakāle
analyzed: nanu ca yam sujātāya dinnam piṇḍapātam bhuñjitvā tathāgataḥ abhisambuddhaḥ saḥ sa rāga sa dosa sa moha kāle
translated: Did not the Blessed One become enlightened after eating the alms food given by Sujātā, and was that eaten at a time when he was still in the grip of lust, hatred, and delusion?

original: paribhutto, ayaṃ pana cundena dinno vītarāgavītadosavītamohakāle paribhutto, kasmā
analyzed: paribhuttaḥ ayam pana cundena dinnaḥ vīta rāga vīta dosa vīta moha kāle paribhuttaḥ kasmā
translated: But this was eaten by him after he had become enlightened, and it was eaten at a time when he was free from lust, hatred, and delusion. Why then is it said that they are of equal fruit?

original: ete samaphalāti? Parinibbānasamatāya ca samāpattisamatāya ca anussaraṇasamatāya ca.
analyzed: ete sama phalā ati parinibbāna samatāya ca samāpatti samatāya ca anussaraṇa samatāya ca
translated: They are equal in fruit because of the equality of final extinguishment, the equality of attainment, and the equality of recollection.

original: Bhagavā hi sujātāya dinnaṃ piṇḍapātaṃ paribhuñjitvā saupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā
analyzed: bhagavā hi sujātāya dinnam piṇḍapātam paribhuñjitvā sa aupādisesāya nibbāna dhātuyā
translated: For the Blessed One ate the alms food given by Sujātā and then attained final extinguishment in the element of extinction without trace left ;

original: parinibbuto, cundena dinnaṃ paribhuñjitvā anupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā parinibbutoti🔽evaṃ parinibbānasamatāyapi samaphalā. Abhisambujjhanadivase ca catuvīsatikoṭisatasahassasaṅkhyā
analyzed: parinibbutaḥ cundena dinnam paribhuñjitvā an upādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā parinibbutaḥ uti  evam sama phalā abhisambujjhana divase ca catuvīsati koṭi sata sahassa saṅkhyā
translated: and he ate the alms food given by Cunda and then attained final extinguishment in the element of extinction with trace left .🔽So they are equal in fruit because of the equality of final extinguishment.

original: samāpattiyo samāpajji, parinibbānadivasepi sabbā tā samāpajjīti evaṃ samāpattisamatāyapi
analyzed: samāpattiyaḥ samāpajji parinibbāna divase pi sabbā tā samāpajji iti evam samāpatti samatāya api
translated: And on the day of his enlightenment he attained the eighty-four thousand kinds of insight knowledge, and on the day of his final extinction he again attained all these. So they are equal in fruit because of the equality of attainment.

original: samaphalā. Sujātā ca aparabhāge assosi – “na kiresā rukkhadevatā, bodhisatto kiresa,
analyzed: samaphalā sujātā ca aparabhāge assosi na rukkhadevatā bodhisatto kiresa
translated: and the same result. Sujātā later heard that it was not a tree-spirit but a Bodhisatta who had eaten the alms food,

original: taṃ kira piṇḍapātaṃ paribhuñjitvā anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhiṃ abhisambuddho, sattasattāhaṃ
analyzed: tam kira piṇḍapātam paribhuñjitvā anuttaram sammāsambodhim abhisambuddhaḥ satta sattāham
translated: and that he had attained omniscience after eating it, and that he had lived on it for seven times seven days.

original: kirassa tena yāpanaṃ ahosī”ti. Tassā idaṃ sutvā – “lābhā vata me”ti anussarantiyā🔽balavapītisomanassaṃ udapādi. Cundassāpi aparabhāge – “avasānapiṇḍapāto kira mayā🔽dinno, dhammasīsaṃ kira me gahitaṃ, mayhaṃ kira piṇḍapātaṃ paribhuñjitvā satthā anupādisesāya
analyzed: kirassa tena yāpanam ahosi iti tassāḥ idam sutvā lābhāḥ vata mā iti anussarantiyā  balava pīti somanassam udapādi cundassa api aparabhāge avasāna piṇḍapātaḥ kira mayā  dinnaḥ dhamma sīsam kira me gahitam mayham kira piṇḍapātam paribhuñjitvā satthā anupādisesāya
translated: When she heard this, she thought, “How fortunate I was! ” and as she recalled it🔽a strong sense of spiritual joy and happiness arose in her. And later Cundaka heard that the last alms food had been given by him, that he had taken the lead in the Dhamma, and that after eating his alms food the Teacher had attained final Nibbāna in the element of Nibbāna that is without residue of clinging.

original: nibbānadhātuyā parinibbuto”ti sutvā “lābhā vata me”ti anussarato balavasomanassaṃ
analyzed: nibbāna dhātuyā parinibbuto ti sutvā lābhāḥ vata me iti anussarataḥ balava somanassam
translated: When he heard this, he thought, “How fortunate I was! ” and as he recalled it a strong sense of spiritual joy and happiness arose in him.

original: udapādīti evaṃ anussaraṇasamatāyapi samaphalāti veditabbā.
analyzed: udapādi iti evam sama phalā ati veditabbā
translated: So it should be understood that the result is the same because of the equality of their recollection.

original: Yasasaṃvattanikanti parivārasaṃvattanikaṃ. Ādhipateyyasaṃvattanikanti jeṭṭhakabhāvasaṃvattanikaṃ.
analyzed: yasa saṃvattanikanti parivāra saṃvattanikan ādhipateyya saṃvattanikanti jeṭṭhaka bhāva saṃvattanikan
translated: “Conducive to fame” : conducive to a retinue. “Conducive to lordship” : conducive to the state of a chief.

analyzed: saṃyamato ti sīla saṃyamena saṃyamantassa saṃvare ṭhitassa ati attho veram na cīyati iti
