analyzed: nandanti gate socanti tādisaḥ tvam āgamana nandanaḥ gamana socanaḥ tasmai tava āgamanam  su āgamanam ti vuttam hoti evam vutte pana rājā cakkavattī na api ettakam nāma me
translated: Herein, svāgata means “welcome.” For when someone comes, some people grieve and some rejoice. But when someone comes, you rejoice and when he goes, you grieve. Therefore your coming is a good coming.

analyzed: mañjunā sarena passatha tātā pāṇātipātaḥ nāma isaḥ āsevitaḥ bhāvitaḥ bahulīkataḥ niraya saṃvattanikaḥ

analyzed: hoti itiādinā nayena dhammam desetvā pāṇaḥ na hantabbaḥ iti ādikam ovādam deti mahāsudassanaḥ api

analyzed: tathā iva akāsi tena vuttam rājā mahāsudassanaḥ evam āha pāṇaḥ na hantabba upe  yathābhuttam ca bhuñjatha ati kim pana sabbe pi raññaḥ imam ovādam gaṇhanti iti buddhassa api
translated: “King Mahāsudassana said this: ‘Living beings should not be killed …🔽eat only what is given …’ But did all the people accept this advice of the king’s?🔽Even in the case of the Buddha, not all people accepted his advice; how could they in the case of a king?

original: tāva sabbe na gaṇhanti, rañño kiṃ gaṇhissantīti. Tasmā ye paṇḍitā vibhāvino, te gaṇhanti.
analyzed: tāva sabbe na gaṇhanti raññaḥ kim gaṇhissanti iti tasmai ye paṇḍitāḥ vibhāvinaḥ te gaṇhanti
translated: Therefore only the wise and the intelligent accepted it.

original: Sabbe pana anuyantā bhavanti. Tasmā ye kho panānandātiādimāha.
analyzed: sabbe pana anuyantāḥ bhavanti tasmai ye kho pana ānanda iti ādim āha
translated: But all the people became his followers. Therefore the Exalted One said: “Ānanda, those who are wise …

analyzed: atha tam cakkaratanam evam pubbavideha vāsīnam ovāde dinne kata pāta rāse cakka vatti balena
translated: Then, after the advice had been given to the people of Pubbavideha, the wheel-treasure, after the meal, together with the army of the wheel-turning monarch,

analyzed: vehāsam abbhut gantvā puratthima samuddam ajjhogāhati yathā yathā ca tam ajjhogāhati
translated: and it enters the Eastern Ocean. As it enters,

analyzed: tathā tathā agada gandham ghāyitvā saṅkhitta phaṇaḥ nāga rājā saṅkhitta ūmi vipphāram
translated: just as the king of the nāgas, Saṅkhapālo, having smelt the fragrance of the agada plant,

analyzed: viya tiṭṭhati ca tassa rañño puññasirim daṭṭhu kāmāni viya mahā samudda tale

analyzed: vippakiṇṇāni nānā ratanāni tatas tatas āgantvā tam padesam pūrayanti atha sā rāja parisā

analyzed: tam nānā ratana paripūram mahā samudda talam disvā yathāruci ucchaṅga ādīhi ādiyati yathāruci
translated: having seen the ocean floor filled with various jewels, takes them with their shoulders and so on, as they wish,

analyzed: ādinna ratanāya pana parisāya tam cakka ratanam paṭinivattati paṭinivattamāne ca tasmin
translated: but when the assembly has taken the jewels as they wish, that Wheel-Treasure turns back. And as it turns back,

analyzed: parisā aggatas hoti majjhe rājā ante cakka ratanam jalanidhi jalam palobhiyamānam iva

analyzed: abhivijinitvā dakkhiṇa samudda pariyantam jambudīpam vijetu kāmo cakkaratana desitena

original: maggena dakkhiṇasamuddābhimukho gacchati. Mahāsudassanopi tatheva agamāsi. Tena vuttaṃ
analyzed: maggena dakkhiṇa samudda abhimukhaḥ gacchati mahāsudassanaḥ pi tathā iva tena vuttam
translated: to the Southern Ocean. And so did Mahasudassana. Hence it is said:

original: – “atha kho, ānanda, cakkaratanaṃ puratthimaṃ samuddaṃ ajjhogāhetvā paccuttaritvā🔽dakkhiṇaṃ disaṃ pavattī”ti.
analyzed: atha kho ānanda cakkaratanam puratthimam samuddam ajjhogāhetvā paccuttaritvā  dakkhiṇam disam pavatti iti
translated: “Then, Ananda, the Wheel-Treasure plunged into the Eastern Ocean and reappeared in the West.”

original: Evaṃ pavattamānassa pana tassa pavattanavidhānaṃ, senāsanniveso, paṭirājāgamanaṃ,
analyzed: evam pavattamānassa pana tassa pavattana vidhānam senā sannivesaḥ paṭirāja āgamanam
translated: But the way in which it plunged into the Eastern Ocean, the way in which it was set up, the way in which the opposing kings came,

original: tesaṃ anusāsanippadānaṃ dakkhiṇasamuddaajjhogāhanaṃ samuddasalilassa ogacchamānaṃ
analyzed: tesam anusāsa nippadānam dakkhiṇa samudda ajjhogāhanam samudda salilassa ogacchamānam
translated: the way in which they were instructed, the way in which it plunged into the Southern Ocean, the way in which the water of the ocean receded,

original: ratanānaṃ ādānanti sabbaṃ purimanayeneva veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: rata nānam ādānam ti sabbam purima nayena iva veditabbam
translated: and the way in which the treasures were taken—all this should be understood in the same way as before.

original: Vijinitvā pana taṃ dasasahassayojanappamāṇaṃ jambudīpaṃ dakkhiṇasamuddatopi paccuttaritvā🔽sattayojanasahassappamāṇaṃ aparagoyānaṃ vijetuṃ pubbe vuttanayeneva gantvā tampi🔽samuddapariyantaṃ tatheva abhivijinitvā pacchimasamuddatopi uttaritvā aṭṭhayojanasahassappamāṇaṃ
analyzed: vijinitvā pana tam dasa sahassa yojana ppamāṇam jambudīpam dakkhiṇa samuddataḥ api paccuttaritvā  satta yojana sahassa ppamāṇam aparagoyānam vijetum pubbe vutta nayena iva gantvā tam pi  samudda pariyantam tathā iva abhivijinitvā pacchima samuddataḥ pi uttaritvā aṭṭha yojana sahassa ppamāṇam
translated: Having conquered the Rose-Apple Island, which is ten thousand leagues in extent, he crosses over to the Southern Ocean and,🔽having conquered the Western Cow-Pen Island, which is seven thousand leagues in extent, in the way already described, he crosses over to the Western Ocean and,

original: uttarakuruṃ vijetuṃ tatheva gantvā tampi samuddapariyantaṃ tatheva abhivijiya uttarasamuddato paccuttarati.
analyzed: uttarakurum vijetum tathā iva gantvā tam pi samudda pariyantam tathā iva abhivijiya uttara samuddataḥ paccuttarati
translated: having conquered the Northern Bear Island, which is eight thousand leagues in extent, in the way already described, he crosses over to the Northern Ocean.

original: Ettāvatā raññā cakkavattinā cāturantāya pathaviyā ādhipaccaṃ adhigataṃ hoti. So evaṃ
analyzed: ettāvatā raññā cakkavattinā cāturantāya pathaviyāḥ ādhipaccam adhigatam hoti so evam
translated: At this point the king has gained control over the four continents. Then,

original: vijitavijayo attano rajjasirisampattidassanatthaṃ sapariso uddhaṃ gaganatalaṃ abhilaṅghitvā
analyzed: vijita vijayaḥ attanaḥ rajja siri sampatti dassana attham sa parisaḥ uddham gagana talam abhilaṅghitvā
translated: having conquered all this, he soars up into the sky with his retinue in order to show the extent of his royal glory and,

original: suvikasitapadumakumudapuṇḍarīkavanavicitte cattāro jātassare viya pañcasatapañcasataparittadīpaparivāre
analyzed: su vikasita paduma kumuda puṇḍarīka vana vicitte cattāraḥ pañca sata pañca sata paritta dīpa parivāre
translated: like the four great lakes, which are adorned with well-opened lotuses, white lotuses, and blue lotuses, and which are surrounded by five hundred minor lakes on each side,

original: cattāro mahādīpe oloketvā cakkaratanadesiteneva maggena yathānukkamaṃ attano rājadhāniṃ
analyzed: cattāraḥ mahā dīpe oloketvā cakka ratana desitena iva maggena yathānukkamam attanaḥ rājadhānim
translated: and after surveying the four great continents, it returns by the same way it came and enters the royal stable.

original: paccāgacchati. Atha taṃ cakkaratanaṃ antepuradvāraṃ sobhayamānaṃ viya hutvā tiṭṭhati.
analyzed: paccāgacchati atha tam cakkaratanam antepura dvāram viya hutvā tiṭṭhati
translated: Then it stands there as if delighting in the beauty of the royal harem.

original: Evaṃ patiṭṭhite pana tasmiṃ cakkaratane rājantepure ukkāhi vā dīpikāhi vā kiñci karaṇīyaṃ
analyzed: evam patiṭṭhite pana tasmin cakkaratane rājantepure ukkāhi vā dīpikāhi vā kiñci karaṇīyam
translated: But when the Wheel-Treasure has thus been established, there is no need for torches or for lamps,🔽for the radiance of the Wheel-Treasure dispels the darkness. But for those who want darkness

original: na hoti, cakkaratanobhāsoyeva rattiṃ andhakāraṃ vidhamatiyeva. Ye pana andhakāratthikā
analyzed: na hoti rattim andhakāram ye pana
translated: it becomes dark; and for those who want light

original: honti, tesaṃ andhakārameva hoti. Mahāsudassanassāpi sabbametaṃ tatheva ahosi. Tena
analyzed: honti tesam andhakāram eva hoti mahāsudassanassa api sabbam etam tathā iva ahosi tena
translated: it becomes light. And all this happened to Mahasudassana just as it had to Vipassi.

original: vuttaṃ – “dakkhiṇaṃ samuddaṃ ajjhogāhetvā…pe… evarūpaṃ cakkaratanaṃ pāturahosī”ti.
analyzed: vuttam dakkhiṇam samuddaṃ ajjhogāhetvā āpe evarūpam cakkaratanam pāturahosi iti
translated: This is why it was said above: ‘The Wheel-Treasure appeared to King Mahasudassana, with a thousand spokes, with tire and hub, complete in every aspect’ .

original: Hatthiratanavaṇṇanā🔽246. Evaṃ pātubhūtacakkaratanasseva cakkavattino amaccā pakatimaṅgalahatthiṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: hatthi ratana vaṇṇanā  evam pātubhūta cakka ratanassa iva cakkavattinaḥ amaccā pakati maṅgala hatthi ṭṭhānam
translated: The Elephant Treasure🔽Now when the Wheel-Treasure has appeared, the king’s counsellor-treasure finds the elephant-treasure for him. He is a creature of the gaja species, pure white like a mass of fleecy wool, with sevenfold member,11 endowed with the speed of the wind, and able to live for a thousand years.🔽The king’s counsellor-treasure has a site prepared in a place that is suitable, even and clean,

original: samaṃ sucibhūmibhāgaṃ kāretvā haricandanādīhi surabhigandhehi upalimpāpetvā heṭṭhā
analyzed: samam suci bhūmi bhāgam kāretvā haricandana ādīhi surabhi gandhehi upalimpāpetvā heṭṭhā
translated: and has it sprinkled and swept.

original: vicittavaṇṇasurabhikusumasamokiṇṇaṃ upari suvaṇṇatārakānaṃ antarantarā samosaritamanuññakusumadāmapaṭimaṇḍitavitānaṃ
analyzed: vicitta vaṇṇa surabhi kusuma samokiṇṇam upari suvaṇṇa tārakānam antar antarā samosarita manuñña kusuma dāma paṭimaṇḍita vitānam
translated: and a canopy of gold-embroidered cloth, with garlands of flowers hanging down here and there, and strewn with flowers of various colours and sweet-smelling.

original: devavimānaṃ viya abhisaṅkharitvā – “evarūpassa nāma deva hatthiratanassa āgamanaṃ
analyzed: deva vimānam viya abhisaṅkharitvā evarūpassa nāma deva hatthi ratanassa āgamanam
translated: “Think of the coming of such a god’s elephant treasure.”

original: cintethā”ti vadanti. So pubbe vuttanayeneva mahādānaṃ datvā sīlāni ca samādāya taṃ
analyzed: cintetha ati vadanti saḥ pubbe vutta nayena iva mahā dānam da tvā sīlāni ca samādāya taṃ
translated: He gave great gifts in the way already described, and took upon himself the precepts of virtue, and sat down reflecting on his own great store of merit.

original: puññasampattiṃ āvajjanto nisīdi. Athassa puññānubhāvacodito chaddantakulā vā uposathakulā🔽vā taṃ sakkāravisesaṃ anubhavitukāmo taruṇaravimaṇḍalābhirattacaraṇagīvāmukhapaṭimaṇḍitavisuddhasetasarīro🔽sattapatiṭṭho susaṇṭhitaaṅgapaccaṅgasanniveso vikasitarattapadumacārupokkharo iddhimā
analyzed: puñña sampattim āvajjantaḥ nisīdi athassa puñña anubhāva codito chaddanta kulā vā uposatha kulā  vā tam sakkāra visesam anubhavitu kāmaḥ taruṇa ravi maṇḍala abhiratta caraṇa gīvā mukha paṭimaṇḍita visuddha seta sarīraḥ  satta patiṭṭhaḥ su saṇṭhita aṅga paccaṅga sannivesaḥ vikasita ratta paduma cāru pokkharaḥ iddhimā
translated: Then, urged on by the power of his merit, the elephant treasure, either of the Chaddanta family or of the Uposatha family,🔽eager to enjoy that special honour, his pure trunk, with its tip adorned with the feet and mouth of the young rising sun,🔽his seven members well-planted, his limbs and members well-formed, his head like a full-blown red lotus, endowed with the power of magic,

original: yogī viya vehāsagamanasamattho manosilācuṇṇarañjitapariyanto viya rajatapabbato hatthiseṭṭho
analyzed: yogī viya vehāsa gamana samatthaḥ manaḥ silā cuṇṇa rañjita pariyantaḥ viya rajata pabbataḥ hatthi seṭṭhaḥ
translated: like a yogin able to walk through the air, his body surrounded by a halo like a mountain of silver tinged with the dust of the rainbow, the best of elephants,

original: āgantvā tasmiṃ padese tiṭṭhati. So chaddantakulā āgacchanto sabbakaniṭṭho āgacchati.🔽Uposathakulā āgacchanto sabbajeṭṭho. Pāḷiyaṃ pana uposatho nāgarājā icceva āgataṃ.
analyzed: āgantvā tasmin padese tiṭṭhati so chaddanta kulā āgacchantaḥ sabbaka niṭṭhaḥ āgacchati  uposatha kulā āgacchanto sabba jeṭṭhaḥ pāḷiyam pana uposathaḥ nāga rājā iccā iva āgatam
translated: and it stands in that place. When it comes from the Chaddanta family, it comes as the youngest of all.🔽When it comes from the Uposatha family, it comes as the eldest of all. But in the text it is said to have come as the king of the nāgas.

original: Nāgarājā nāma kassaci aparibhogo, sabbakaniṭṭho āgacchatīti aṭṭhakathāsu vuttaṃ.
analyzed: nāga rājā nāma kassaci a paribhogaḥ sabba kaniṭṭhaḥ āgacchati iti aṭṭhakathāsu vuttam
translated: The king of the nāgas is not the property of anyone, and it comes as the youngest of all, according to the commentaries.

original: Svāyaṃ pūritacakkavattivattānaṃ cakkavattīnaṃ vuttanayeneva cintayantānaṃ āgacchati.
analyzed: svāyam pūrita cakkavatti vattānam cakkavattīnam vutta nayena iva cintayantānam āgacchati
translated: It comes to those who think of it in the way already described for the wheel-turning monarchs.

original: Mahāsudassanassa pana sayameva pakatimaṅgalahatthiṭṭhānaṃ āgantvā taṃ hatthiṃ apanetvā
analyzed: mahāsudassanassa pana sayam eva pakatimaṅgala hatthi ṭṭhānam āgantvā tam hatthim apanetvā
translated: But when Mahāsudassana was a wheel-turning monarch, the elephant came of its own accord to the place where the auspicious elephant was to be marked, and after driving away the elephant there,

original: tattha aṭṭhāsi. Tena vuttaṃ – “puna caparaṃ ānanda…pe… nāgarājā”ti.
analyzed: tattha aṭṭhāsi tena vuttam puna caparam ānandape nāga rājā iti
translated: it stood in its place. Hence it was said above: ‘Again, Ānanda, when the king of the nāgas …’

original: Evaṃ pātubhūtaṃ pana taṃ hatthiratanaṃ disvā hatthigopakādayo haṭṭhatuṭṭhā vegena
analyzed: evam pātubhūtam pana tam hatthi ratanam disvā hatthi gopaka ādayaḥ haṭṭha tuṭṭhāḥ vegena
translated: When the elephant treasure had appeared in this way, the elephant trainers and so on, being elated and joyful,

original: gantvā rañño ārocenti. Rājā turitaturito āgantvā taṃ disvā pasannacitto – “bhaddakaṃ
analyzed: gantvā raññaḥ ārocenti rājā turita turitaḥ āgantvā tam disvā pasanna cittaḥ bhaddakam
translated: went quickly and reported the matter to the king. The king came quickly and, seeing the elephant, was pleased and thought: ‘This is a good elephant.

original: vata bho hatthiyānaṃ, sace damathaṃ upeyyā”ti cintayanto hatthaṃ pasāreti. Atha so
analyzed: vata bho hatthi yānam sace damatham upeyya ati cintayantaḥ hattham pasāreti atha saḥ
translated: and he stretches out his hand to the elephant.

original: gharadhenuvacchako viya kaṇṇe olambitvā sūratabhāvaṃ dassento rājānaṃ upasaṅkamati.🔽Rājā taṃ ārohitukāmo hoti. Athassa parijanā adhippāyaṃ ñatvā taṃ hatthiratanaṃ suvaṇṇaddhajaṃ
analyzed: ghara dhenu vat śakaḥ viya kaṇṇe olambitvā sūrata bhāvam dassentaḥ rājānam upasaṅkamati  rājā tam ārohitu kāmaḥ hoti athassa parijanāḥ adhippāyam ñatvā tam hatthi ratanam suvaṇṇaddha jam
translated: Then the elephant comes to him, hanging down his ears like a house-elephant, showing that he is tractable.🔽The king wants to mount him, and then his retinue, understanding his wish, bring the elephant-treasure, which is covered with a golden network and adorned with gold and jewels,

original: suvaṇṇālaṅkāraṃ hemajālapaṭicchannaṃ katvā upanenti. Rājā taṃ anisīdāpetvāva sattaratanamayāya
analyzed: suvaṇṇa alaṅkāram hema jāla paṭicchannam katvā upanenti rājā tam satta ratana mayāya
translated: and the king mounts it without dismounting the elephant. He then wishes to fly up into the air.

original: nisseṇiyā āruyha ākāsagamananinnacitto hoti. Tassa saha cittuppādeneva so nāgarājā🔽rājahaṃso viya indanīlamaṇippabhājālaṃ nīlagaganatalaṃ abhilaṅghati. Tato cakkacārikāya🔽vuttanayeneva sakalarājaparisā. Iti sapariso rājā antopātarāseyeva sakalapathaviṃ
analyzed: nisseṇiyā āruyha ākāsagamana ninna cittaḥ hoti tassa saha cittuppādena iva saḥ nāga rājā  rājahaṃsaḥ viya inda nīla maṇi ppabhā jālam nīla gagana talam abhilaṅghati cakka cārikāya  vutta nayena iva sakala rāja parisā iti sa parisaḥ rājā sakala pathavim
translated: The moment he thinks of it, the elephant king flies up into the sky like a royal swan,🔽and the network of sapphire-jewels shines in the blue sky. Then the king, with his retinue,🔽travels over the whole earth in the morning, and returns to the capital in the same way as the wheel-turning king described in the Cakkavatti-sīhanāda Sutta.

original: anusaṃyāyitvā rājadhāniṃ paccāgacchati. Evaṃ mahiddhikaṃ cakkavattino hatthiratanaṃ
analyzed: anusaṃyāyitvā rājadhānim paccāgacchati evam mahiddhikam cakkavattinaḥ hatthi ratanam
translated: So great is the power of the elephant-treasure of a wheel-turning monarch.

original: hoti. Mahāsudassanassāpi tādisameva ahosi. Tena vuttaṃ – “disvā rañño…pe… pāturahosī”ti.
analyzed: hoti mahāsudassanassa api tādisam eva ahosi tena vuttam disvā raññā upe pāturahosi iti
translated: and so it was with Mahāsudassana. Hence it was said above: ‘The king saw the elephant-jewel … and he became glad and he rejoiced, saying: “Now I am indeed a king in the wheel-turning race!”’

original: Assaratanavaṇṇanā
analyzed: assa ratana vaṇṇanā
translated: The horse-jewel

original: 247. Evaṃ pātubhūtahatthiratanassa pana cakkavattino amaccā pakatimaṅgalaassaṭṭhānaṃ🔽sucisamatalaṃ kāretvā alaṅkaritvā ca purimanayeneva rañño tassa āgamanacintanatthaṃ
analyzed: evam pātubhūta hatthi ratanassa pana cakkavattino amaccā pakati maṅgala assaṭṭhānam  suci sama talam kāretvā alaṅkaritvā ca purima nayena iva raññaḥ tassa āgamana cintana attham
translated: Now when the wheel-turner’s elephant-jewel has appeared, his ministers prepare a place for the auspicious horse-jewel’s stall,

original: ussāhaṃ janenti. So purimanayeneva katadānamānanasakkāro samādinnasīlabbato pāsādatale
analyzed: ussāham janenti saḥ purima nayena iva kata dānam ānana sakkāro samādinna sīlabbataḥ pāsāda tale
translated: which is cleaned up, swept, and strewn with heaps of flowers, and so on, as before. And they inform the king of the elephant-jewel’s appearance, saying: ‘Sire, the elephant-jewel has appeared. It is ready for your majesty to ride.’

original: sukhanisinno puññasampattiṃ samanussarati. Athassa puññānubhāvacodito sindhavakulato🔽vijjulatāvinaddhasaradakālasetavalāhakarāsisassirīko rattapādo rattatuṇḍo candappabhāpuñjasadisasuddhasiniddhaghanasaṃhatasarīro
analyzed: sukha nisinnaḥ puñña sampattim samanussarati athassa puñña anubhāva codito sindhava kulataḥ  vijju latā vinaddha sarada kāla seta valāhaka rāsi sassirīkaḥ ratta pādaḥ ratta tuṇḍaḥ canda ppabhā puñja sadisa suddha siniddha ghana saṃhata sarīraḥ
translated: Then the king, after giving gifts, making merit, honouring those worthy of veneration, and observing the Uposatha precepts,🔽goes up to the terrace on top of his palace,🔽and there he sees the horse-jewel. It is the colour of a dark-blue gem, with a black head, a black neck, and black fetlocks, and it is swift as the wind.

original: kākagīvā viya indanīlamaṇi viya ca kāḷavaṇṇena sīsena samannāgatattā kāḷasīsoti suṭṭhu
analyzed: ca kāḷa vaṇṇena sīsena samannāgata ttā kāḷasīsā iti suṭṭhu
translated: It is called ‘the black-backed’ because its back is black like a crow’s neck or an indranīla gem.

original: kappetvā ṭhapitehi viya muñjasadisehi saṇhavaṭṭaujugatehi kesehi samannāgatattā muñjakeso
analyzed: kappetvā ṭhapitehi viya muñja sadisehi saṇha vaṭṭa oju gatehi kesehi samannāgata ttā muñja kesaḥ
translated: He was called “Hair-like-Munja-Grass” because his hair was soft, pliable, and straight, like the munja grass when it is cut and laid aside.

original: vehāsaṅgamo valāhako nāma assarājā āgantvā tasmiṃ ṭhāne patiṭṭhāti. Mahāsudassanassa
analyzed: vehāsaṅgamaḥ valāhakaḥ nāma assa rājā āgantvā tasmin ṭhāne patiṭṭhāti mahāsudassanassa
translated: The king of horses called Valāha, who was the king of the horses that had come from the sky, alighted at that spot.

original: panesa hatthiratanaṃ viya āgato. Sesaṃ sabbaṃ hatthiratane vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: pana esa hatthi ratanam viya āgataḥ sesam sabbam hatthi ratane vutta nayena iva veditabbam
translated: He came to the king just as the elephant treasure had done. The rest should be understood in the way already stated under the elephant treasure.

original: Evarūpaṃ assaratanaṃ sandhāya bhagavā – “puna ca para”ntiādimāha.
analyzed: evarūpam assa ratanam sandhāya bhagavā
translated: With reference to such a horse treasure, the Blessed One said: “Again, a horse treasure appeared to the King, golden in colour, with a head like the parrot, with wings, and with the name of ‘Valāha.’ ”

original: Maṇiratanavaṇṇanā
translated: The Jewel Treasure

original: 248. Evaṃ pātubhūtaassaratanassa pana rañño cakkavattino catuhatthāyāmaṃ sakaṭanābhisamapariṇāhaṃ🔽ubhosu antesu kaṇṇikapariyantato viniggatehi suparisuddhamuttākalāpehi dvīhi kañcanapadumehi
analyzed: evam pātubhūta assa ratanassa pana raññaḥ cakkavattino catu hattha āyāmam sakaṭa nābhi sama pariṇāham  ubhosu antesu kaṇṇika pariyantataḥ viniggatehi su parisuddha muttā kalāpehi dvīhi kañcana padumehi
translated: Now, when the wheel-turning monarch to whom the horse treasure had thus appeared had gone on his tour of conquest and returned to his capital,🔽he had a pair of golden lotuses made, each with a thousand petals,🔽and he had a jewel made, which was eight hundred thousand leagues in perimeter,

original: alaṅkataṃ caturāsītimaṇisahassaparivāraṃ tārāgaṇaparivutassa puṇṇacandasassiriṃ pharamānaṃ
analyzed: alaṅkatam catur āsīti maṇi sahassa parivāram tārā gaṇa parivutassa puṇṇa canda sassirim pharamānam
translated: and which was surrounded by a halo of a thousand leagues.

original: viya vepullapabbatato maṇiratanaṃ āgacchati. Tassevaṃ āgatassa muttājālake ṭhapetvā
analyzed: viya vepulla pabbatataḥ maṇi ratanam āgacchati tassa ivam āgatassa muttā jālake ṭhapetvā
translated: and a gem comes down from the Veḷuriya Mountain. When it has come down, it is placed in a network of gold and

original: veḷuparamparāya saṭṭhihatthappamāṇaṃ ākāsaṃ āropitassa rattibhāge samantā yojanappamāṇaṃ
analyzed: veḷu paramparāya saṭṭhi hattha ppamāṇam ākāsam āropitassa ratti bhāge samantā yojana ppamāṇam
translated: raised on a succession of bamboo poles to a height of sixty cubits. At night it illuminates a space a league in extent all

original: okāsaṃ ābhā pharati, yāya sabbo so okāso aruṇuggamanavelā viya sañjātāloko hoti.
analyzed: okāsam ābhā pharati yāya sabbaḥ saḥ okāsaḥ aruṇuggamana velāḥ viya sañjāta ālokaḥ hoti
translated: around it, and that space is as though it were lit by the dawn.

original: Tato kassakā kasikammaṃ vāṇijā āpaṇugghāṭanaṃ te te sippino taṃ taṃ kammantaṃ payojenti🔽“divā”ti maññamānā. Mahāsudassanassāpi sabbaṃ taṃ tatheva ahosi. Tena vuttaṃ – “puna
analyzed: tatas kassakā kasi kammam vāṇijāḥ āpaṇa ugghāṭanam te te sippinaḥ tam tam kammantam payojenti  divā ti maññamānā mahāsudassanassa api sabbam tam tathā iva ahosi tena vuttam puna
translated: Then the ploughmen plough, the traders open their shops, the craftsmen set to work at their various crafts,

original: ca paraṃ ānanda,…pe… maṇiratanaṃ pāturahosī”ti.
analyzed: ca param ānandape maṇi ratanam
translated: thinking it is daytime. And so it was with Mahāsudassana. Hence it was said: ‘And again, Ānanda, … the gem appeared to the Wheel-turning Monarch.’

original: Itthiratanavaṇṇanā
analyzed: itthi ratana vaṇṇanā
translated: The Description of the Supernormal Power of the Consort

original: 249. Evaṃ pātubhūtamaṇiratanassa pana cakkavattino visayasukhavisesassa visesakāraṇaṃ
analyzed: evam pātubhūta maṇi ratanassa pana cakkavattino visaya sukha visesassa visesa kāraṇam
translated: But the cause for the distinction in the distinction of the pleasure-object of the Wheel-Turner to whom the gem has appeared is🔽the appearance of the consort. For they bring him a chief consort either from the royal family of Madhurā or from the

original: itthiratanaṃ pātubhavati. Maddarājakulato vā hissa aggamahesiṃ ānenti, uttarakuruto
analyzed: itthi ratanam pātubhavati madda rāja kulataḥ vā hissa agga mahesim ānenti uttarakurutaḥ
translated: Uttarakurūs.

original: vā puññānubhāvena sayaṃ āgacchati. Avasesā panassā sampatti – “puna ca paraṃ, ānanda,
analyzed: vā puñña anubhāvena sayam āgacchati avasesā panassā sampatti puna ca param ānanda
translated: or she comes of her own accord through the power of her merit.

original: rañño mahāsudassanassa itthiratanaṃ pāturahosi, abhirūpā dassanīyā”tiādinā nayena pāḷiyaṃyeva āgatā.
analyzed: raññaḥ mahāsudassanassa itthi ratanam abhirūpā dassanīyā ati ādinā nayena āgatā
translated: or it comes of its own accord through the power of his merit. The rest of her excellence is given in the text beginning, “And again, Ānanda, a precious woman appeared to King Mahāsudassana, who was beautiful, comely, and graceful” .🔽Herein, she is beautiful because she has more than the usual amount of beauty due to the perfection of her figure.

original: Tattha saṇṭhānapāripūriyā adhikaṃ rūpaṃ assāti abhirūpā. Dissamānāva cakkhūni piṇayati,
analyzed: tattha saṇṭhāna pāripūriyā adhikam rūpam assāti abhirūpā dissamānā ava cakkhūni piṇayati
translated: She is comely because she attracts the eye just by being seen,

original: tasmā aññaṃ kiccavikkhepaṃ hitvāpi daṭṭhabbāti dassanīyā. Dissamānāva somanassavasena
analyzed: tasmai aññam kicca vikkhepam hitvā api daṭṭhabbā ati dassanīyā dissamānā ava somanassa vasena
translated: and so is worth looking at even though one has to neglect one’s work.🔽She is graceful because she delights the mind just by being seen,

original: cittaṃ pasādetīti pāsādikā. Paramāyāti evaṃ pasādāvahattā uttamāya. Vaṇṇapokkharatāyāti🔽vaṇṇasundaratāya. Samannāgatāti upetā. Abhirūpā vā yasmā nātidīghā nātirassā. Dassanīyā
analyzed: cittam pasādeti iti pāsādikā paramāya ati evam pasāda āvahattā uttamāya vaṇṇa pokkhara tāya ati  vaṇṇa sundara tāya samannāgatā ati upetā abhirūpā vā yasmai na ati dīghā na ati rassā dassanīyā
translated: and so is supreme, that is, the best, in arousing confidence.🔽She is endowed with perfect complexion, that is, with a beautiful complexion.🔽Or alternatively, she is beautiful because she is not too tall and not too short;🔽she is comely because she is not too thin and not too fat;

original: yasmā nātikisā nātithūlā. Pāsādikā yasmā nātikāḷikā nāccodātā. Paramāya vaṇṇapokkharatāya
analyzed: yasmai na ati kisā na ati thūlā pāsādikā yasmai na ati kāḷikā na accodātā paramāya vaṇṇa pokkharatāya
translated: she is graceful because she is not too dark and not too fair;

original: samannāgatā yasmā abhikkantā mānusivaṇṇaṃ appattā dibbavaṇṇaṃ. Manussānañhi vaṇṇābhā
analyzed: samannāgatāḥ yasmai abhikkantāḥ mānusi vaṇṇam appattāḥ dibba vaṇṇam manussānam hi vaṇṇa ābhā
translated: and so they are ‘surpassing the human figure’ in that they have not reached the divine figure. For the radiance of human beings

original: bahi na niccharati. Devānaṃ pana atidūrampi niccharati.
analyzed: bahis na niccharati devānam pana atidūram pi niccharati
translated: does not shine outside their bodies, but that of deities shines even at a distance.

original: Tassā pana dvādasahatthappamāṇaṃ padesaṃ sarīrābhā obhāseti. Nātidīghādīsu cassā
analyzed: tassā pana dvādasa hattha pamāṇam padesam sarīra ābhā obhāseti na ati dīgha ādīsu cassā
translated: And the radiance of this queen shines over an area twelve leagues in extent. And in the words ‘not too tall …’

original: paṭhamayugaḷena ārohasampatti, dutiyayugaḷena pariṇāhasampatti, tatiyayugaḷena vaṇṇasampatti
analyzed: paṭhama yugaḷena āroha sampatti dutiya yugaḷena pariṇāha sampatti tatiya yugaḷena vaṇṇa sampatti
translated: her excellence of height is stated by the first pair, her excellence of breadth by the second pair, and her excellence of colour by the third pair.

original: vuttā. Chahi vāpi etehi kāyavipattiyā abhāvo, atikkantā mānusivaṇṇanti iminā kāyasampatti
analyzed: vuttā chahi vā api etehi kāya vipattiyāḥ abhāvaḥ atikkantā iminā kāya sampatti
translated: Or alternatively, the absence of any bodily defect is stated by all six. Her excellence of body is stated by ‘surpassing the human figure.’

original: vuttā. Tūlapicuno vā kappāsapicuno vāti sappimaṇḍe pakkhipitvā ṭhapitassa satavāravihatassa
analyzed: vuttā tūla picuno vā kappāsa picuno vā ati sappi maṇḍe pakkhipitvā ṭhapitassa sata vāra vihatassa
translated: like a ball of cotton wool or a ball of kapok that has been put into oil and soaked with it,

original: tūlapicuno vā kappāsapicuno vā. Sīteti rañño sītakāle. Uṇheti rañño uṇhakāle. Candanagandhoti
analyzed: tūla picunaḥ vā kappāsa picunaḥ vā sītā iti rañño sīta kāle uṇhā iti rañño uṇha kāle candana gandho ti
translated: ‘In cold weather’ when it is cold for the king. ‘In hot weather’ when it is hot for the king. ‘The scent of sandalwood’

original: niccakālameva supisitassa abhinavassa catujjātisamāyojitassa haricandanassa gandho
analyzed: niccakālam eva su pisitassa abhinavassa catur jāti samāyojitassa haricandanassa gandho
translated: the scent of fresh, well-seasoned, four-year-old yellow sandalwood.

original: kāyato vāyati. Uppalagandho vāyatīti hasitakathitakālesu mukhato taṅkhaṇaṃ vikasitasseva
analyzed: kāyataḥ vāyati uppala gandhaḥ vāyati iti hasita kathita kālesu mukhataḥ vikasitassa iva
translated: or it blows from the body. The scent of a flower blows. At the time of laughing and talking it blows from the mouth like the scent of a flower that has just opened.

original: nīluppalassa atisurabhigandho vāyati.
analyzed: nīluppalassa ati surabhi gandhaḥ vāyati
translated: The fragrance of a blue lotus wafts from her body. The fragrance of a blue lotus wafts from her mouth when she laughs, talks, etc., like that of a blue lotus fully opened at that moment.

original: Evaṃ rūpasamphassagandhasampattiyuttāya panassā sarīrasampattiyā anurūpaṃ ācāraṃ
analyzed: evam rūpa samphassa gandha sampatti yuttāya panassā sarīra sampattiyā anurūpam ācāram
translated: But in order to show a conduct befitting her bodily perfection, which is endowed with the perfection of form, touch, and scent,

original: dassetuṃ taṃ kho panātiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha rājānaṃ disvā nisinnāsanato aggidaḍḍhā
analyzed: dassetum tam kho pana atiādi vuttam tattha rājānam disvā nisinna āsanataḥ aggi daḍḍhā
translated: it is said: “And when she saw the king, she rose first from her seat, as if it were burning, and stood there.” Herein, she rises first from her seat when she sees the king, as if it were burning,

original: viya paṭhamameva uṭṭhātīti pubbuṭṭhāyinī. Tasmiṃ nisinne tassa tālavaṇṭena bījanādikiccaṃ🔽katvā pacchā nipatati nisīdatīti pacchānipātinī. Kiṃ karomi, te devāti vācāya kiṃ-kāraṃ
analyzed: paṭhamam eva uṭṭhāti iti pubbuṭṭhāyinī tasmin nisinne tassa tāla vaṇṭena bījana ādi kiccam  katvā pacchā nipatati nisīdati iti pacchā nipātinī kim karomi te deva ati vācāya kiṃkāram
translated: so she is a “quick riser” . When he is seated, she attends on him by fanning him with a palm-leaf fan, etc., and then she sits down afterwards, so she is a “late sitter” .🔽She replies to the king’s words, “What can I do? What is your majesty’s pleasure? ” so she is a “questioner” .

original: paṭisāvetīti kiṃ kārapaṭissāvinī. Rañño manāpameva carati karotīti manāpacārinī.
analyzed: paṭisāveti iti kim kāra paṭissāvinī raññaḥ manāpam eva carati karoti iti manāpa cārinī
translated: She behaves and acts only to please the king, so she is a “pleaser” .

original: Yaṃ rañño piyaṃ tadeva vadatīti piyavādinī.
analyzed: yam rañño piyam tat eva vadati iti piya vādinī
translated: She speaks only what is pleasing to the king, so she is a “pleaser by speech” .

original: Idāni – “svāssā ācāro bhāvavisuddhiyāva, na sāṭheyyanā”ti dassetuṃ taṃ kho panātiādimāha.
analyzed: ācāraḥ na dassetum tam kho pana iti ādim āha
translated: Now, in order to show that her conduct was purified by her nature and not by hypocrisy, he said: “And she was not a hypocrite” .

original: Tattha no aticarīti na atikkamitvā cari, ṭhapetvā rājānaṃ aññaṃ purisaṃ cittenapi
analyzed: tattha no aticari iti na atikkamitvā cari ṭhapetvā rājānam aññam purisam cittena api
translated: Herein, he does not transgress is he does not go beyond. He does not wish for any man other than the king, not even in his thoughts.

original: na patthesīti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: na patthesi iti vuttam hoti
translated: This is what is meant.

original: Tattha ye tassā ādimhi “abhirūpā”tiādayo, ante “pubbuṭṭhāyinī”tiādayo guṇā vuttā,🔽te pakatiguṇā eva. “Atikkantā mānusivaṇṇa”ntiādayo pana cakkavattino puññaṃ upanissāya
analyzed: tattha ye tassāḥ ādimhi abhirūpā ti ādayaḥ ante pubbuṭṭhāyinī iti ādayaḥ guṇāḥ vuttā  te pakati guṇāḥ eva atikkantāḥ mānusi vaṇṇa nti ādayo pana cakkavattino puññam upanissāya
translated: Herein, the qualities beginning with “beautiful” and ending with “early rising” that are mentioned at the beginning and end of the passage,🔽are natural qualities. But the qualities beginning with “surpassing the beauty of human beings” should be understood as having arisen through the power of the king’s previous kamma,

original: cakkaratanapātubhāvato paṭṭhāya purimakammānubhāvena nibbattāti veditabbā.
analyzed: cakkaratana pātubhāvataḥ paṭṭhāya purima kamma anubhāvena nibbattā iti veditabbā
translated: beginning with the appearance of the Wheel-Jewel as a result of his merit.

original: Abhirūpatādikāpi vā cakkaratanapātubhāvato paṭṭhāya sabbākāraparipūrā jātā. Tenāha – “evarūpaṃ itthiratanaṃ pāturahosī”ti.
analyzed: abhirūpa tā ādikā api vā cakka ratana pātubhāvataḥ paṭṭhāya sabba ākāra paripūrā jātā tena āha evarūpam itthi ratanam pātuḥ ahosi iti
translated: Or else, beginning with the appearance of the Wheel-Jewel, his beauty and so forth became complete in every respect. Therefore it is said: “Such a woman-jewel appeared.”

original: Gahapatiratanavaṇṇanā🔽250. Evaṃ pātubhūtaitthiratanassa pana rañño cakkavattino dhanakaraṇīyānaṃ kiccānaṃ
analyzed: evam pātubhūta aitthi ratanassa pana raññaḥ cakkavattinaḥ dhana karaṇīyānam kiccānam
translated: The Householder-Jewel

original: yathāsukhaṃ pavattanatthaṃ gahapatiratanaṃ pātubhavati. So pakatiyāva mahābhogo,
analyzed: yathāsukham pavattana attham gahapati ratanam pātubhavati saḥ mahā bhogaḥ
translated: Now, for the wheel-turning monarch, to whom the woman-jewel has thus appeared, the householder-jewel appears for the purpose of his enjoying as he wishes the pleasures of the five senses. He is naturally very wealthy,

original: mahābhogakule jāto. Rañño dhanarāsivaḍḍhako seṭṭhigahapati hoti. Cakkaratanānubhāvasahitaṃ
analyzed: mahā bhoga kule jātaḥ raññaḥ dhana rāsi vaḍḍhako seṭṭhi gahapati hoti cakkaratana anubhāva sahitam
translated: He is born in a family of great wealth. He is a treasurer, a guild-president, a rich man, a money-lender, a great lord of property, a lord of men, a lord of the earth, a lord of riches.

original: panassa kammavipākajaṃ dibbacakkhu pātubhavati, yena antopathaviyampi yojanabbhantare
analyzed: panassa kamma vipāka jam dibba cakkhu pātubhavati yena antopathaviyam pi yojana abbhantare
translated: He has the divine eye arisen from the result of kamma, by means of which he sees hidden treasures both in the earth and in the water, a yojana into the ground and a yojana into the water.

original: nidhiṃ passati, so taṃ sampattiṃ disvā tuṭṭhamānaso gantvā rājānaṃ dhanena pavāretvā
analyzed: nidhim passati saḥ tam sampattim disvā tuṭṭha mānasaḥ gantvā rājānam dhanena pavāretvā
translated: He is pleased with his good fortune and goes to the king and offers him riches.

original: sabbāni dhanakaraṇīyāni sampādeti. Mahāsudassanassāpi tatheva sampādesi. Tena vuttaṃ
analyzed: sabbāni dhana karaṇīyāni sampādeti mahāsudassanassa api tathā iva sampādesi tena vuttam
translated: He carries out all the king’s business with money. He did the same for Mahasudassana. Hence it was said above:

original: – “puna caparaṃ ānanda…pe… evarūpaṃ gahapatiratanaṃ pāturahosī”ti.
analyzed: punar ca param ānandape evarūpam gahapati ratanam iti
translated: “Again, Ananda, when a Wheel-turning Monarch appears in the world, the Jewel of the Counsellor appears. Such is the Wheel-turning Monarch’s Counsellor Jewel.”

original: Pariṇāyakaratanavaṇṇanā🔽251. Evaṃ pātubhūtagahapatiratanassa pana rañño cakkavattissa sabbakiccasaṃvidhānasamatthaṃ
analyzed: pariṇāyaka ratana vaṇṇanā  evam pātubhūta gahapati ratanassa pana raññaḥ cakkavattissa sabba kicca saṃvidhāna samattham
translated: The Counsellor Jewel

original: pariṇāyakaratanaṃ pātubhavati. So rañño jeṭṭhaputtova hoti. Pakatiyā eva so paṇḍito
analyzed: pariṇāyaka ratanam pātubhavati saḥ raññaḥ jeṭṭha putto va hoti pakatiyā eva so paṇḍito
translated: Now, when a Wheel-turning Monarch has appeared, who is the possessor of the seven treasures and the four kinds of success, then the Counsellor Jewel appears, able and capable of carrying out all the king’s business.🔽He is the king’s eldest son, and by nature he is wise, clever, and intelligent.

original: byatto medhāvī vibhāvī. Rañño puññānubhāvaṃ nissāya panassa attano kammānubhāvena
analyzed: byattaḥ medhāvī vibhāvī raññaḥ puñña anubhāvam nissāya panassa attano kamma anubhāvena
translated: But by the power of the king’s merit and by his own kamma,

original: paracittañāṇaṃ uppajjati. Yena dvādasayojanāya rājaparisāya cittācāraṃ ñatvā rañño
analyzed: para citta ñāṇam uppajjati yena dvādasa yojanāya rāja parisāya citta ācāram ñatvā
translated: and the knowledge of the minds of others arose. Having known the thoughts and actions of the king’s assembly of twelve leagues, he said this to the king:

original: hite ca ahite ca vavatthapetuṃ samattho hoti, sopi taṃ attano ānubhāvaṃ disvā tuṭṭhahadayo
analyzed: hite ca ahite ca samatthaḥ hoti saḥ api tam attanaḥ ānubhāvam disvā tuṭṭha hadayaḥ
translated: He knows the state of mind of the twelve leagues of the king’s retinue, and he is able to distinguish what is beneficial and what is not beneficial for the king. He too, seeing his own power, is pleased in mind and

original: rājānaṃ sabbakiccānusāsanena pavāreti. Mahāsudassanampi tatheva pavāresi. Tena vuttaṃ
analyzed: rājānam sabba kicca anusāsanena pavāreti mahāsudassanam pi tathā iva pavāresi tena vuttam
translated: he invites the king to give him instructions in all his affairs. He invited Mahāsudassana in the same way. Therefore it is said:

original: – “puna caparaṃ…pe… pariṇāyakaratanaṃ pāturahosī”ti.
analyzed: punar pariṇāyaka ratanam
translated: “Again, when the jewel of a counsellor appeared … “

original: Tattha ṭhapetabbaṃ ṭhapetunti tasmiṃ tasmiṃ ṭhānantare ṭhapetabbaṃ ṭhapetuṃ.
analyzed: tattha ṭhapetabbam ṭhapetum ti tasmim tasmim ṭhānantare ṭhapetabbam ṭhapetum
translated: Herein, he should be appointed to the office he should be appointed to this or that office.

original: Catuiddhisamannāgatavaṇṇanā
analyzed: catu iddhi samannāgata vaṇṇanā
translated: The Description of the One Possessing the Four Kinds of Increase

original: 252. Samavepākiniyāti samavipācaniyā. Gahaṇiyāti kammajatejodhātuyā. Tattha yassa
analyzed: sama vepākiniyā ati sama vipācaniyā gahaṇiyā ati kamma ja tejaḥ dhātuyā tattha yassa
translated: That are to be Cooked Together: that are to be cooked together evenly. That are to be Seized: that are to be seized by the fire element born of kamma. Herein,

original: bhuttamattova āhāro jīrati, yassa vā pana puṭabhattaṃ viya tattheva tiṭṭhati, ubhopete
analyzed: bhutta mattaḥ uva āhāraḥ jīrati yassa vā pana puṭa bhattam viya tattha iva tiṭṭhati ubho upete
translated: one who has food that is digested as soon as eaten, and one who has food that stays there as if in a basket, are both🔽not possessed of that which is to be cooked together. But one in whom appetite arises again after eating

original: na samavepākiniyā samannāgatā. Yassa pana puna bhattakāle bhattachando uppajjateva,
analyzed: na samavepākiniyā samannāgatā yassa pana puna bhatta kāle bhatta chandaḥ uppajjateva
translated: but she is not one who is cold. But if, at the time of eating, appetite arises in her again,

original: ayaṃ samavepākiniyā samannāgatoti.
analyzed: ayam samavepākiniyā samannāgatā uti
translated: He is one who has a tremor.

original: Dhammapāsādapokkharaṇivaṇṇanā
translated: The description of the lotus-pond in the Dhamma Palace

original: 253. Māpesi khoti nagare bheriṃ carāpetvā janarāsiṃ kāretvā na māpesi, rañño pana
analyzed: māpesi kho ti nagare bherim carāpetvā jana rāsim kāretvā na māpesi raññaḥ pana
translated: He had it made: he had the multitude of people assembled by having drums beaten in the city. But it was not he who made it;

original: saha cittuppādeneva bhūmiṃ bhinditvā caturāsīti pokkharaṇīsahassāni nibbattiṃsu.
analyzed: saha cittuppādena iva bhūmim bhinditvā catur asīti pokkharaṇī sahassāni nibbattiṃsu
translated: for as soon as the thought arose in the king’s mind, the earth split open and eighty-four thousand lotus-ponds appeared.

original: Tāni sandhāyetaṃ vuttaṃ. Dvīhi vedikāhīti ekāya iṭṭhakānaṃ pariyanteyeva parikkhittā🔽ekāya pariveṇaparicchedapariyante. Etadahosīti kasmā ahosi? Ekadivasaṃ kira nahatvā
analyzed: tāni sandhāya itam vuttam dvīhi vedikāhi iti ekāya iṭṭhakānam pariyantā iya iva parikkhittā  ekāya etat ahosi iti kasmai eka divasam kira na hatvā
translated: It is these that are referred to here. With two railings: one was enclosed by bricks at the edge,

original: ca pivitvā ca gacchantaṃ mahājanaṃ mahāpuriso oloketvā ime ummattakaveseneva gacchanti.
analyzed: ca pivitvā ca gacchantam mahā janam mahā purisaḥ oloketvā ime ummattaka vesena iva gacchanti
translated: the other at the edge of the surrounding cloister. This occurred to him: why did it occur to him? It seems that one day the Great Man was watching a great crowd of people who were going to bathe and drink and were saying, “We are going mad.”

original: Sace etesaṃ ettha piḷandhanapupphāni bhaveyyuṃ, bhaddakaṃ siyāti. Athassa etadahosi.
analyzed: sace etesam ettha piḷandhana pupphāni bhaveyyum bhaddakam siyāti atha assa etat ahosi
translated: “They are going mad as it were,” he thought. “If there were some flowers growing here for them to play with, it would be good.” Then this occurred to him:

original: Tattha sabbotukanti pupphaṃ nāma ekasmiṃyeva utumhi pupphati. Ahaṃ pana tathā karissāmi
analyzed: tattha sabbotukanti puppham nāma ekasmin yeva utumhi pupphati aham pana tathā karissāmi
translated: Herein, flowers that flower in one season only flower in one season only. But I shall make them such that they will flower in all seasons.

original: – “yathā sabbesu utūsu pupphissatī”ti cintesiṃ. Ropāpesīti nānāvaṇṇauppalabījādīni

analyzed: udakam āḷulikam karonte disvā antar pāsāṇehi cinitvā bahi kaṇṭakavatim parikkhipitvā  tāla pantiyaḥ ropeti mahā caṅkame sammaṭṭha ṭṭhānam disvā
translated: and making the water muddy, he had it surrounded with a fence of stones outside and a fence of thorns inside,🔽and he had palm-leaf huts built on the inside of the fence. When he saw that they were making the great walking-place muddy,

analyzed: panaññam pi pabbajitānam paribhoga jātam sabbam adāsi therassa bodhisattena a dinna parikkhāro

analyzed: nāma na ahosi so sīlāni rakkhantaḥ uposatham karontaḥ yāvajīvam theram upaṭṭhahi thero

translated: The Bodhisatta, too, lived out his life, doing good works, and was reborn in the world of the gods. Passing thence, he came down into the world of men and was born in the city of Kusavati, and became king Mahasudassana.

original: “Evaṃ nātimahantampi, puññaṃ āyatane kataṃ;
analyzed: evam na atimahantam pi puññam āyatane katam

analyzed: mahā vipākam hoti iti kattabbam tat vibhāvinā
translated: Brings a great reward. Therefore the wise should do good works.”

analyzed: rajata mayam mahā kūṭāgāram tattha vasitu kāmaḥ hutvā agamāsi ettāvatā

original: 262. Mettāsahagatenātiādīsu yaṃ vattabbaṃ, taṃ sabbampi visuddhimagge vuttameva.
analyzed: mettā sahagatena ati ādīsu yam vattabbam tam sabbam pi visuddhi magge vuttam eva
translated: In the case of “with the mind-born, etc.,” what is to be said has all been said in the Path of Purity .

original: Iti pāḷiyaṃ cattāri jhānāni, cattāri appamaññāneva vuttāni. Mahāpuriso pana sabbāpi🔽aṭṭha samāpattiyo, pañca abhiññāyo ca nibbattetvā anulomapaṭilomādivasena cuddasahākārehi
analyzed: iti pāḷiyam cattāri jhānāni cattāri vuttāni  aṭṭha samāpattiyo pañca abhiññāyo ca nibbattetvā anuloma paṭiloma ādi vasena cuddasahā akārehi
translated: Thus four jhanas and four measureless states are mentioned in the texts. But the Great Man, after producing all🔽eight attainments and the five kinds of direct knowledge, enters the attainments in fourteen ways, namely, forwards, backwards, and forwards and backwards, in each case with and without relishing, and with full awareness in emerging.

original: samāpattiyo pavisanto madhupaṭalaṃ paviṭṭhabhamaro madhurasena viya samāpattisukheneva yāpeti.
analyzed: pavisantaḥ madhu paṭalam madhu rasena samāpatti sukhena iva yāpeti

translated: The description of the eighty-four thousand cities🔽Kusavati, the capital city, is the chief of those cities, the best of all.

original: 263. Kusāvatīrājadhānippamukhānīti kusāvatī rājadhānī tesaṃ nagarānaṃ pamukhā sabbaseṭṭhāti attho. Bhattābhihāroti abhiharitabbabhattaṃ.
analyzed: kusāvatī rājadhāni ppamukhāni iti kusāvatī rājadhānī tesam nagarānam pamukhā sabba seṭṭhā ti atthaḥ bhatta abhihāraḥ iti abhiharitabba bhattam
translated: The food was brought to him: he was fed by bringing the food to him.

translated: Why did he think thus? Because he was annoyed by the noise of the people. For it is said: “The sound is a thorn to one who has attained jhana.”

analyzed: saddo kaṇṭako ti hi vuttam tasmā saddena ukkaṇṭhitaḥ mahā purisaḥ atha kasmai mā āgacchantu uti

original: na vadati? Idāni rājā na passatīti nibaddhavattaṃ na labhissanti, taṃ tesaṃ mā uppajjitthāti na vadati.
analyzed: na vadati idāni rājā na passati iti nibaddha vattam na labhissanti tam tesam mā uppajjittha ati na vadati
translated: Because he thought, “Now the king will not see them, and they will not receive their regular allowance.”

original: Subhaddādeviupasaṅkamanavaṇṇanā
analyzed: subhaddā devī upasaṅkamana vaṇṇanā
translated: The description of the queen’s visit

analyzed: etat ahosi iti kadā etam ahosi rañño kālaṅkiriya divase tadā kira devatā cintesuṃ
translated: This occurred: on the day of the king’s death. For on that day, it seems, the deities thought:

analyzed: rājā anāthaka alaṅkiriyam mā karotu orodhehi bahūhi dhītūhi puttehi parivāritaḥ uva

translated: “Stay right here, queen,”

translated: means, “This meditation building is not a place for you to live in together with me; it is a place for me to find delight in meditation,

analyzed: kālaṅkiriyam an icchamānā sampati guṇam assa kathayitvā tiṭṭhamāna ākāram karissāmi iti

translated: She said, “These, your majesty,” and so forth. There, “Arouse desire” means arouse love, make delight.

translated: “Be concerned about life” means be concerned about life, make a refuge, make craving. This is the meaning.

translated: How shall we speak, great king?” Thinking that the king had gone forth, the queen said, “Sire, he is a monk.”

original: vutte – “evaṃ kho maṃ, tvaṃ devi, samudācarāhī”tiādimāha. Garahitāti buddhehi paccekabuddhehi🔽sāvakehi aññehi ca paṇḍitehi bahussutehi garahitā. Kiṃ kāraṇā? Sāpekkhakālakiriyā
analyzed: vutte evam kho mam tvam devi samudācarāhi iti ādim āha gara hitā ati buddhehi paccekabuddhehi  sāvakehi aññehi ca paṇḍitehi bahu ssutehi garahitā kim kāraṇā sa apekkha kāla kiriyā
translated: The king said, “Thus, Queen, you have treated me.” “Condemned” : by the Buddhas, by the Paccekabuddhas,

analyzed: atha kho ānanda subhaddā devī assūni puñchitvā ati devī ekamantam gantvā roditvā kanditvā assūni puñchitvā etat avoca
translated: . Then, Ananda, Queen Subhadda wiped away her tears and went to one side.

original: Brahmalokūpagamavaṇṇanā
analyzed: brahma loka upagama vaṇṇanā
translated: The Description of the Ascent to the Brahma-World

analyzed: gahapatissa vāti kasmai āha tesam kira soṇa seṭṭhi putta ādīnam viya mahatī sampatti
translated: . “Of the householder” : Why does he say this? It seems that the great prosperity of the Sonasettthiputta, etc.,

analyzed: hoti soṇassa kira seṭṭhi puttassa ekā bhatta pāti dve sata sahassāni agghati iti tesam

analyzed: tādisam bhattam bhuttānam muhuttam bhatta sammadaḥ bhatta mucchā bhatta kilamathaḥ hoti  yam tena samayena ajjhāvasāmi iti yattha vasāmi tam ekam yā iva nagaram hoti avasesesu
translated: So after eating such food, they had to lie down for a while, overcome by the heaviness of their stomachs, the fullness of their stomachs, the sluggishness of their stomachs.🔽I lived in one town only: I lived in one town only, while my sons and daughters and slaves lived in the other towns.

analyzed: putta dhīta ādayo ca iva dāsa manussā ca vasiṃsu pāsāda kūṭāgāresu pi esa iva nayo pallaṅka ādīsu pi

translated: I used one couch only: I used one couch only, while the others were used by my sons and so on.🔽I had one wife only: I had one wife only, while the others were the retinue.

analyzed: sesāni parivāretvā vicarantānam asīti sahassa adhikānam purisa sata sahassānam

analyzed: honti bhuñjāmi iti parama ppamāṇena nāḷika odana mattam bhuñjāmi sesam parivāretvā vicarantānam

original: cattālīsasahassādhikānaṃ aṭṭhannaṃ purisasatasahassānaṃ hotīti dasseti. Ekathālipāko
analyzed: cattālīsa sahassa adhikānam aṭṭhannam purisa sata sahassānam hoti iti dasseti ekathā ālipāko
