analyzed: purimañca disam rājā dhataraṭṭhaḥ pasāsati iti pācīna disam anusāsati gandhabbānam
translated: He rules the eastern quarter, he governs the eastern direction.

original: adhipatīti catūsupi disāsu gandhabbānaṃ jeṭṭhako. Sabbe te tassa vase vattanti. Mahārājā
analyzed: adhipati iti catūsu pi disāsu gandhabbānam jeṭṭhako sabbe te tassa vase vattanti mahā rājā
translated: He is the overlord of the Gandhabbas: he is the chief of the Gandhabbas in all four directions. All of them are subject to him.

original: yasassisoti mahāparivāro eso mahārājā.
analyzed: mahā parivāraḥ esaḥ mahā rājā
translated: The Great King, the famous one: he is a great king with a great retinue.

original: Puttāpi tassa bahavo, indanāmā mahabbalāti tassa dhataraṭṭhassa bahavo mahabbalā puttā, te sabbe sakkassa devarañño nāmadhārakā.
analyzed: puttā api tassa bahavaḥ inda nāmā mahabbalā ti tassa dhataraṭṭhassa bahavaḥ mahabbalā puttā te sabbe sakkassa deva rañño nāma dhārakā
translated: He has many sons, all of whom are named Indra, and are of great strength: he, Dhataraṭṭha, has many sons of great strength. All of them are named after Sakka, the king of the gods.

original: Virūḷho taṃ pasāsatīti taṃ disaṃ virūḷho anusāsati.
analyzed: virūḍhaḥ tam pasāsati iti tam disam virūḍhaḥ anusāsati
translated: Virūḷha rules the western quarter: he governs the western direction.

original: Puttāpi tassāti tassāpi tādisāyeva puttā. Pāḷiyaṃ pana “mahabbalā”ti likhanti. Aṭṭhakathāyaṃ sabbavāresu “mahābalā”ti pāṭho.
analyzed: puttā api tassa ti tassa api tādisāya iva puttā pāḷiyam pana mahabbalā ati likhanti aṭṭhakathāyam sabba vāresu mahābalā ti pāṭhaḥ
translated: He has sons like those of Dhataraṭṭha: he has sons like those of Dhataraṭṭha. But in the text they are written “mahabbalā.” In the commentary the reading is “mahābalā” in all places.🔽Dhataraṭṭha rules the eastern quarter,

original: “Purimaṃ disaṃ dhataraṭṭho, dakkhiṇena virūḷhako;
analyzed: purimam disam dhataraṭṭhaḥ dakkhiṇena virūḷhakaḥ
translated: Virūḷhaka rules the southern,🔽Virūpakkha rules the western,

original: Pacchimena virūpakkho, kuvero uttaraṃ disaṃ.
analyzed: pacchimena virūpakkhaḥ kuveraḥ uttaram disam
translated: Kuvera rules the northern quarter.

original: Cattāro te mahārājā, samantā caturo disā;
analyzed: cattāraḥ te mahā rājā samantā caturaḥ disā
translated: These four Great Kings, in all four directions,

original: Daddallamānā aṭṭhaṃsu, vane kāpilavatthave”ti.
analyzed: daddallamānāḥ aṭṭhaṃsu vane kāpilavattha vā iti
translated: and stood there shining in the forest of Kapilavatthu.

original: Imā pana gāthā sabbasaṅgāhikavasena vuttā.
analyzed: imā pana gāthā sabba saṅgāhika vasena vuttā
translated: But these verses are spoken in a general way.

original: Ayañcettha attho – dasasahassacakkavāḷe dhataraṭṭhā nāma mahārājāno atthi. Te sabbepi🔽koṭisatasahassakoṭisatasahassagandhabbaparivārā āgantvā puratthimāya disāya kapilavatthumahāvanato
analyzed: ayam ca ittha atthaḥ dasa sahassa cakkavāḷe dhataraṭṭhāḥ nāma mahā rājānaḥ atthi te sabbe pi  koṭi sata sahassa koṭi sata sahassa gandhabba parivārāḥ āgantvā puratthimāya disāya kapilavatthu mahā vanataḥ
translated: The meaning here is this. In the ten-thousandfold world-element there are great kings called Dhataraṭṭhas. All of them

original: paṭṭhāya cakkavāḷagabbhaṃ pūretvā ṭhitā. Evaṃ dakkhiṇadisādīsu virūḷhakādayo. Tenevāha🔽– “samantā caturo disā, daddallamānā aṭṭhaṃsū”ti. Idañhi vuttaṃ hoti – “samantā cakkavāḷehi
analyzed: paṭṭhāya cakkavāḷa gabbham pūretvā ṭhitāḥ evam dakkhiṇa disā ādīsu virūḷhaka ādayo tena iva āha  samantā caturo disā aṭṭhaṃsu iti idam hi vuttam hoti samantā cakkavāḷehi
translated: come with retinues of a hundred thousand koṭis of gandhabbas and stand filling the womb of the world-element, beginning from the great forest of Kapilavatthu in the eastern direction. So too in the southern direction, etc., Virūḷhaka, etc., do likewise. Hence it is said:

original: āgantvā caturo disā pabbatamatthakesu aggikkhandhā viya suṭṭhu jalamānā ṭhitā”ti.🔽Te pana yasmā kapilavatthuvanameva sandhāya āgatā, tasmā cakkavāḷaṃ pūretvā cakkavāḷena
analyzed: āgantvā caturo disā pabbata matthakesu aggi kkhandhā viya suṭṭhu jalamānā ṭhitā ati  te pana kapilavatthu vanam eva sandhāya āgatā tasmai cakkavāḷam pūretvā cakkavāḷena
translated: “In the four directions all around, shining, they stood.” For this is what is meant: “Having come from the world-spheres all around, they stood filling the four directions, shining well, like masses of fire on the peaks of mountains.”

original: samasamā ṭhitāpi – “vane kāpilavatthave”ti vuttā.
analyzed: samasamā ṭhitā api vane kāpilavatthavā iti vuttā
translated: But since they came with reference to the forest of Kapilavatthu, they are said to have stood “in the forest of Kapilavatthu,” although they stood on a level with the world-element, filling the world-element.

original: 337. Tesaṃ māyāvino dāsā, āguṃ vañcanikā saṭhāti tesaṃ mahārājānaṃ katapāpapaṭicchādanalakkhaṇāya
analyzed: tesam māyāvinaḥ dāsāḥ tesam mahā rājānam kata pāpa paṭicchādana lakkhaṇāya
translated: 337. Their slaves, deceivers, cheats, and frauds: they have slaves who are crooked in conduct, who are engaged in deceit, which is characterized by concealing the evil done to the great kings.

original: māyāya yuttā kuṭilācārā dāsā atthi, ye sammukhaparammukhavañcanāhi lokaṃ vañcanato
analyzed: yuttā kuṭila ācārā dāsāḥ atthi ye sammukha parammukha vañcanāhi lokam vañcanataḥ
translated: They are called “deceivers” because they deceive the world by cheating people in front and behind.

original: “vañcanikā”ti ca, kerāṭiyasāṭheyyena samannāgatattā “saṭhā”ti ca vuccanti, tepi āgatāti
analyzed: vañcanikā ati ca kerāṭiya sāṭheyyena samannāgata ttā saṭhā ati ca vuccanti te pi āgatā ati
translated: They are called “cheats” because they are endowed with the craftiness of a kerāṭi. The meaning is that they have come.

original: attho. Māyā kuṭeṇḍu viṭeṇḍu, viṭucca viṭuṭo sahāti te dāsā sabbepi māyākārakāva.
analyzed: atthaḥ māyā kuṭeṇḍu viṭeṇḍu viṭucca viṭuṭaḥ te dāsā sabbe pi māyā kārakā ava
translated: 338. Deceit, crookedness, fraud, and fraudulence: all those slaves are magicians.

original: Nāmena panettha eko kuṭeṇḍu nāma, eko viṭeṇḍu nāma. Pāḷiyaṃ pana “veṭeṇḍū”ti likhanti.
analyzed: nāmena pana ittha ekaḥ kuṭeṇḍu nāma ekaḥ viṭeṇḍu nāma pāḷiyam pana veṭeṇḍu iti likhanti
translated: But by name, one is called Kuṭeṇḍu, one is called Viṭeṇḍu. In the text, they write “Veṭeṇḍu.”

original: Eko viṭucca nāma, eko viṭuṭo nāma. Sahāti sopi viṭuṭo tehi saheva āgato.
analyzed: ekaḥ viṭucca nāma ekaḥ viṭuṭaḥ nāma saha ati saḥ api viṭuṭaḥ tehi saha iva āgataḥ
translated: One is called Viṭucca, one is called Viṭuṭa. Sahā ti sopi Viṭuṭa came with them.

original: Candano kāmaseṭṭho ca, kinnighaṇḍu nighaṇḍu cāti aparo kinnighaṇḍu nāma. Pāḷiyaṃ pana “kinnughaṇḍū”ti likhanti. Nighaṇḍu cāti añño nighaṇḍu nāma, ettakā dāsā. Ito pare pana –
analyzed: candano kāmaseṭṭho ca kinnighaṇḍu nighaṇḍu ca ati aparaḥ kinnighaṇḍu nāma pāḷiyam pana kinnughaṇḍu uti likhanti nighaṇḍu ca ati aññaḥ nighaṇḍu nāma ettakāḥ dāsāḥ itas pare pana
translated: 339. Candana, Kāmaseṭṭha, Kinnighaṇḍu, and Nighaṇḍu: another is called Kinnighaṇḍu. In the text, they write “Kinnughaṇḍu.” Nighaṇḍu: there are that many slaves. But from here on:

original: “Panādo opamañño ca, devasuto ca mātali;
analyzed: panādaḥ opamañño ca devasuto ca mātali
translated: “Panada, Opamañña, Devasuta, and Matali,

original: Cittaseno ca gandhabbo, naḷo rājā janesabho;
analyzed: cittasenaḥ ca gandhabbaḥ naḷaḥ rājā janesabhaḥ
translated: Cittasena, the gandhabba, King Nala, and Janesabha,

original: Āguṃ pañcasikho ceva, timbarū sūriyavacchasā”ti. –
analyzed: āgum pañcasikhaḥ ca iva timbarū sūriya vat śasāti
translated: Pañcasikha, and Timbaru, and Suriya’s daughter came.”

original: Ime devarājāno. Tattha devasutoti devasārathi. Cittasenoti citto ca seno ca cittaseno
analyzed: ime deva rājāno tattha deva suto ti deva sārathi cittaseno ti citto ca seno ca cittaseno
translated: These are the kings of the gods. Herein, Devasuta is the charioteer of the gods. Cittasena is both Citta and Sena.

original: ca. Gandhabboti ayaṃ cittaseno gandhabbakāyiko devaputto, na kevalaṃ cesa, sabbe
analyzed: ca gandhabbaḥ ti ayam cittasenaḥ gandhabba kāyikaḥ deva putto na kevalam ca isa sabbe
translated: The gandhabba is the god of the Cittasena gandhabba class. Not only he,

original: pete panādādayo gandhabbā eva. Naḷorājāti naḷakāradevaputto nāmeko. Janesabhoti janavasabho🔽devaputto. Āguṃ pañcasikho cevāti pañcasikho ceva devaputto āgato. Timbarūti timbarū
analyzed: panāda ādayaḥ gandhabbāḥ eva naḷorājā ati naḷakāradevaputto nāma ekaḥ janesabho ti jana vasabhaḥ  deva putto āgum pañcasikho ca iva ati pañcasikhaḥ ca iva deva putto āgataḥ timbarū iti timbarū
translated: but all the others beginning with Panada are gandhabbas. King Nala is the god named Nalakara. Janesabha is the god named Janavasabha.

original: nāma gandhabbadevarājā. Sūriyavacchasāti tasseva dhītā.
analyzed: nāma gandhabba deva rājā tassa iva dhītā
translated: Pañcasikha and came: the god named Pañcasikha came. Timbaru is the gandhabba king named Timbaru. Suriya’s daughter is his daughter.

original: Ete caññe ca rājāno, gandhabbā saha rājubhīti ete ca nāmavasena vuttagandhabbarājāno
analyzed: ete caññe ca rājānaḥ gandhabbā saha ete ca nāma vasena vutta gandhabba rājānaḥ
translated: These and other kings, gandhabbas, with the king of the gandhabbas,

original: aññe ca etehi rājūhi saddhiṃ bahū gandhabbā. Modamānā abhikkāmuṃ, bhikkhūnaṃ samitiṃ
analyzed: aññe ca etehi rājūhi saddhim bahū gandhabbāḥ modamānāḥ abhikkāmum bhikkhūnam samitim
translated: Rejoicing, they came to the assembly of the Bhikkhus.

original: vananti haṭṭhatuṭṭhacittā bhikkhusaṅghasamitiṃ imaṃ vanaṃ āgatāti attho.🔽338. Athāguṃ nāgasā nāgā, vesālā sahatacchakāti nāgasadahavāsikā ca vesālīvāsikā
analyzed: vananti haṭṭha tuṭṭha cittāḥ bhikkhu saṅgha samitim imam vanam āgatā iti attho  athāgum nāgasāḥ nāgāḥ vesālā ca vesālīvāsikā
translated: They are delighted and satisfied, and they came to the assembly of the Bhikkhus. The meaning is: they came to this forest.🔽Then came the Nāgas of Nāgasāda and Vesāli together with the Nāga Tissa.

original: ca nāgā saha tacchakanāgaparisāya āgatāti attho. Kambalassatarāti kambalo ca assataro
analyzed: ca nāgā saha tacchaka nāga parisāya āgatā ati attho kambalassatarā ati kambalaḥ ca assataro
translated: The meaning is: the Nāgas who live in Nāgasāda and the Nāgas who live in Vesāli came together with the Nāga assembly of Tissa. Kambala and Assatara.

original: ca. Ete kira sinerupāde vasanti, supaṇṇehipi anuddharaṇīyā mahesakkhanāgā pāyāgā
analyzed: ca ete kira sineru pāde vasanti an uddharaṇīyāḥ mahesakkha nāgā pāyāgā
translated: These, it seems, live at the foot of Sineru. They are great powerful Nāgas who cannot be carried off even by Supaṇṇas. Pāyāgī

original: saha ñātibhīti payāgatitthavāsino ca saha ñātisaṅghena āgatā.
analyzed: saha payāgatitthavāsino ca saha ñāti saṅghena āgatā
translated: together with his relatives, and the Nāgas who live at the place of pilgrimage called Payāga, came together with their Nāga assemblies.

original: Yāmunā dhataraṭṭhā cāti yamunavāsino ca dhataraṭṭhakule uppannā nāgā ca. Erāvaṇo
analyzed: yāmunā dhataraṭṭhā ca ati yamunavāsino ca dhataraṭṭha kule uppannā nāgā ca erāvaṇo
translated: Yāmuna and Dhataraṭṭha. The meaning is: the Nāgas who live in the Yāmuna and the Nāgas who were born in the family of Dhataraṭṭha. Eravana

original: mahānāgoti erāvaṇo ca devaputto, jātiyā nāgo na hoti. Nāgavohārena panesa vohariyati.
analyzed: mahā nāgaḥ ti erāvaṇaḥ ca deva putto jātiyā nāgaḥ na hoti nāga vohārena pana esa vohariyati
translated: the great Nāga. Eravana is a god, not a Nāga by birth. But he is called a Nāga in the sense of a Nāga-speaker.🔽He came.

original: Sopāgāti sopi āgato.
analyzed: saḥ upāgāti saḥ upi āgataḥ
translated: He also came.

original: Ye nāgarāje sahasā harantīti ye ime vuttappakāre nāge lobhābhibhūtā sāhasaṃ katvā🔽haranti gaṇhanti. Dibbā dijā pakkhī visuddhacakkhūti dibbānubhāvato dibbā mātukucchito🔽ca aṇḍakosato cāti dve vāre jātāti dijā pakkhayuttatāya pakkhī yojanasatantarepi
analyzed: ye nāga rāje sahasā haranti iti ye ime vutta ppakāre nāge lobha abhibhūtā sāhasam katvā  haranti gaṇhanti dibbāḥ dijāḥ pakkhī dibba anubhāvataḥ dibbāḥ mātukucchitaḥ  ca ca ati dve vāre jātā ati dijā pakkha yutta tāya pakkhī
translated: “Who seize the royal nāgas by force” : those who, overcome by greed, seize and take by force the nāgas of the kind described above.

original: yojanasahassantarepi nāge dassanasamatthacakkhutāya visuddhacakkhū. Vehāyasā te vanamajjhappattāti
analyzed: yojana sahassa antare pi nāge dassana samattha cakkhu tāya visuddha cakkhū vehāyasā te vana majjha ppattā ti
translated: “Divine birds, pure-eyed” : “Divine” because of their divine power; they are “divine” because they are born twice, from the womb and from an egg. They are “birds” because they have wings. They are “pure-eyed” because their eyes are capable of seeing nāgas even at a distance of a hundred or a thousand leagues.

original: te ākāseneva imaṃ mahāvanaṃ sampattā. Citrā supaṇṇā iti tesa nāmanti tesaṃ “citrasupaṇṇā”ti nāmaṃ.
analyzed: te ākāsena iva imam mahā vanam sampattā citrā supaṇṇā iti tesam nāmanti tesam citrasupaṇṇā ati nāmaṃ
translated: “They came through the air to the middle of the forest” : they came through the air to this great forest. “Their name is Citra-Supaṇṇas” : their name is Citra-Supaṇṇas.

original: Abhayaṃ tadā nāgarājānamāsi, supaṇṇato khemamakāsi buddhoti tasmā sabbepi te aññamaññaṃ
analyzed: abhayam tadā nāga rājānam āsi supaṇṇataḥ khemam akāsi buddho ti tasmā sabbe pi te aññamaññam
translated: “Then the nāga king was fearless, the Buddha made him safe from the Supaṇṇas” : therefore all of them,🔽embracing each other with friendly words, like friends and relatives, rejoicing,

original: saṇhāhi vācāhi upavhayantā mittā viya bandhavā viya ca samullapantā sammodamānā āliṅgantā
analyzed: saṇhāhi vācāhi mittā viya bandhavā viya ca samullapantā sammodamānā āliṅgantā
translated: rejoicing,

original: hatthe gaṇhantā aṃsakūṭe hatthaṃ ṭhapentā haṭṭhatuṭṭhacittā. Nāgā supaṇṇā saraṇamakaṃsu
analyzed: hatthe gaṇhantā aṃsakūṭe hattham ṭhapentā haṭṭha tuṭṭha cittā nāgā su paṇṇā saraṇam akaṃsu
translated: they took hold of his hands, they placed their hands on his shoulders, they were delighted and satisfied. Nāgas and Supaṇṇas went for refuge

original: buddhanti buddhaṃyeva saraṇaṃ gatā.
analyzed: buddhanti buddhaṃyā iva saraṇam gatā
translated: to the Buddha.

original: 339. Jitā vajirahatthenāti indena devaraññā jitā. Samuddaṃ asurāsitāti mahāsamuddavāsino sujātāya asurakaññāya kāraṇā sabbepi bhātaro vāsavassete, iddhimanto yasassino.
analyzed: jitā vajirahatthena ati indena deva raññā jitā samuddam asura asitā ati mahā samudda vāsinaḥ sujātāya asura kaññāya kāraṇā sabbe api bhātaraḥ vāsavassa ete iddhimantaḥ yasassinaḥ
translated: “Conquered by the god with the thunderbolt in his hand” means: conquered by the god Indra. “The ocean, the abode of the Asuras” means: all the Asuras who live in the great ocean, the brothers, Vāsava and so on, are powerful and famous.

original: Tesu kālakañcā mahābhismāti kālakañcā ca mahante bhiṃsane attabhāve māpetvā āgamiṃsu.
analyzed: tesu kālakañcā kālakañcā ca mahante bhiṃsane atta bhāve māpetvā āgamiṃsu
translated: Among them, the Kālakañjas, the Mahābhisas, having created great and fearful bodies, came.

original: Asurā dānaveghasāti dānaveghasā nāma aññe dhanuggahaasurā. Vepacitti sucitti ca,
analyzed: asurāḥ dānaveghasā ati dānaveghasāḥ nāma aññe dhanuggaha asurāḥ vepacitti sucitti ca
translated: The Asuras, the Dānaveghas, the Dānaveghas, other Asura archers, Vepacitti, Sucitti,

original: pahārādo namucī sahāti vepacittiasuro, sucittiasuro cāti ete ca asurā namuci ca māro
analyzed: namucī vepacitti asuro sucitti asuro ca ati ete ca asurāḥ namuci ca māro
translated: Pahārāda, Namuci, the Asura Vepacitti, the Asura Sucitti,

original: devaputto etehi saheva āgato. Ime asurā mahāsamuddavāsino, ayaṃ paranimmitadevalokavāsī,
analyzed: deva puttaḥ etehi saha iva āgataḥ ime asurāḥ mahā samudda vāsinaḥ ayam para nimmita deva loka vāsī
translated: and the god Namuci, Māra, came together with them. These Asuras live in the great ocean, this one lives in the world of the Paranimmitavasavattī gods,

original: kasmā etehi sahāgatoti? Acchandikattā. Tepi hi acchandikā abhabbā, ayampi tādisoyeva.
analyzed: kasmai etehi saha āgataḥ ti acchandika ttā te pi hi acchandikāḥ abhabbāḥ ayam pi tādisaḥ yā iva
translated: Why is he called “gone with them”? Because of his being a glutton. For they were gluttons and incapable, and he is just like them.

original: Tasmā dhātuso saṃsandamāno āgato.
analyzed: tasmai dhātusaḥ saṃsandamānaḥ āgataḥ
translated: So he went with them because of his element.

original: Satañca baliputtānanti balino mahāasurassa puttānaṃ sataṃ. Sabbe verocanāmakāti sabbe
analyzed: satam ca bali puttānam ti balinaḥ mahā asurassa puttānam satam sabbe sabbe
translated: And a hundred of Bali’s sons: a hundred of the sons of the powerful great asura. All were named Verocana: all

original: attano mātulassa rāhusseva nāmadharā. Sannayhitvā balisenanti attano balisenaṃ sannayhitvā
analyzed: attanaḥ mātulassa rāhussa iva nāma dharā sannayhitvā balisenanti attanaḥ balisenam sannayhitvā
translated: bore the name of their maternal uncle, Rāhu. Having equipped their own army: having equipped their own army,

original: sabbe katasannāhāva hutvā. Rāhubhaddamupāgamunti rāhuasurindaṃ upasaṅkamiṃsu. Samayo
analyzed: sabbe hutvā rāhubhaddam upāgamunti rāhu asurindam upasaṅkamiṃsu samayaḥ
translated: all having equipped themselves, they approached Rāhu’s good fortune: they approached the asura king Rāhu. The time

original: dāni bhaddanteti bhaddaṃ tava hotu, samayo te bhikkhūnaṃ samitiṃ vanaṃ upasaṅkamitvā
analyzed: dāni bhaddanta iti bhaddam tava hotu samayaḥ te bhikkhūnam samitim vanam upasaṅkamitvā
translated: is come, good sir: may it be good for you, the time has come for you to go to the forest to the bhikkhus’ assembly

original: bhikkhusaṅghaṃ dassanāyāti attho.🔽340. Āpo ca devā pathavī, tejo vāyo tadāgamunti āpokasiṇādīsu parikammaṃ katvā nibbattā
analyzed: bhikkhu saṅgham dassanāya iti atthaḥ  āpaḥ ca devā pathavī tejaḥ vāyo tadā āgamunti āpokasiṇa ādīsu parikammam katvā nibbattā
translated: and see the Community of Bhikkhus, is the meaning.🔽And the gods of water, of earth, of fire, and of air came then: the gods named “water” and so on, who were reborn

original: ca vuccati, sopi āgato.
analyzed: ca vuccati saḥ api āgataḥ
translated: Vāsava, who is called “Sakka” and “giver of men,” came.🔽The tenfold hosts of gods came in ten divisions.

original: Dasete dasadhā kāyāti etepi dasa devakāyā dasadhāva āgatā. Sabbe nānattavaṇṇinoti nīlādivasena nānattavaṇṇā.
analyzed: dasa ete dasadhā kāyā ti ete api dasa deva kāyā āgatā sabbe nānatta vaṇṇinaḥ ti nīla ādi vasena nānatta vaṇṇā

original: Athāguṃ sahabhū devāti atha sahabhū nāma devā āgatā. Jalamaggisikhārivāti aggisikhā
analyzed: atha agum sahabhū deva ati atha sahabhū nāma devāḥ āgatāḥ jalam aggi sikhā arivā ati aggi sikhā
translated: shining like flames of fire and water.

original: viya jalantā. Jalamaggi ca sikhārivāti imāni tesaṃ nāmānītipi vuttaṃ. Ariṭṭhakā ca
analyzed: viya jalantā jalamaggi ca sikhārivā ti imāni tesam nāmāni iti pi vuttam ariṭṭhakā ca
translated: It is said that these are their names: “fire-water” and “flames”.

original: rojā cāti ariṭṭhakadevā ca rojadevā ca. Umāpupphanibhāsinoti umāpupphadevā nāma ete
analyzed: rojā ca ati ariṭṭhakadevā ca rojadevā ca umā puppha nibhāsinaḥ ti umāpupphadevāḥ nāma ete
translated: The Ariṭṭhakas and the Rojas,🔽shining like umā flowers.

original: devā. Umāpupphasadisā hi tesaṃ sarīrābhā, tasmā “umāpupphanibhāsino”ti vuccanti.
analyzed: devāḥ umā puppha sadisāḥ hi tesam sarīra ābhā tasmai umā puppha nibhāsino ti vuccanti
translated: For their bodily radiance is like the umā flower, thus they are called “those with the radiance of the umā flower.”

original: Varuṇā sahadhammā cāti ete ca dve janā. Accutā ca anejakāti accutadevatā ca anejakadevatā
analyzed: varuṇā sahadhammā ca ati ete ca dve janāḥ accutā ca anejakā ati accuta devatā ca anejaka devatā
translated: The Varuṇas and Sahadhammas, these two groups of deities, and the Accutas and Anejakas,

original: ca. Suleyyarucirā āgunti suleyyā ca rucirā ca āgatā. Āguṃ vāsavanesinoti vāsavanesīdevā🔽nāma āgatā. Dasete dasadhā kāyāti etepi dasadevakāyā dasadhāva āgatā.
analyzed: ca suleyya rucirāḥ āgunti suleyyā ca rucirā ca āgatāḥ āgum vāsavanesinā iti vāsavanesī devā  nāma āgatā dasa ete dasadhā ete api dasa deva kāyāḥ āgatā
translated: the Suleyyas and Rucirās, the Vāsavanesīs,

original: Samānā mahāsamānāti samānā ca mahāsamānā ca. Mānusā mānusuttamāti mānusā ca mānusuttamā ca. Khiḍḍāpadosikā āguṃ, āguṃ manopadosikāti khiḍḍāpadosikā manopadosikā ca devā āgatā.
analyzed: samānā mahā samānā ati samānā ca mahā samānā ca mānusā mānusuttamā ati mānusā ca mānusuttamā ca khiḍḍāpadosikā āgum āgum manopadosikā ati khiḍḍāpadosikā manopadosikā ca devāḥ āgatā
translated: the ten groups of deities, the Samānās and Mahāsamānās, the Mānusas and Mānusuttamās, the Khiḍḍāpadosikas and Manopadosikas,

original: Athāguṃ harayo devāti haridevā nāma āgatā. Ye ca lohitavāsinoti lohitavāsino ca āgatā.
analyzed: atha agum harayaḥ deva ati haridevāḥ nāma āgatāḥ ye ca lohita vāsinaḥ iti lohita vāsinaḥ ca āgatā
translated: the Haris, the Lohitavāsins, the Pāragas and Mahāpāragas,

original: Pāragā mahāpāragāti ete ca duvidhā āgatā. Dasete dasadhā kāyāti etepi dasadevakāyā dasadhāva āgatā.
analyzed: pāragāḥ mahāpāragāḥ iti ete ca duvidhāḥ āgatāḥ dasa ete dasadhā ete api dasa deva kāyāḥ āgatā
translated: and the ten groups of deities—all these came in their tenfold form.

original: Sukkā karambhā aruṇā, āguṃ veghanasā sahāti ete sukkādayo tayo, tehi saha veghanasā
analyzed: sukkā karambhā aruṇā āgum veghanasā saha ati ete sukka ādayaḥ tayaḥ tehi saha veghanasā
translated: The Sukkas, Karambhas, and the ruddy-hued, and the Veghanasas came with them.🔽The Sukkas, etc., are three kinds of gods; the Veghanasas came with them.

original: ca āgatā. Odātagayhā pāmokkhāti odātagayhā nāma pāmokkhadevā āgatā. Āguṃ devā vicakkhaṇāti
analyzed: ca āgatāḥ odātagayhā pāmokkhā ati odātagayhāḥ nāma pāmokkha devāḥ āgatāḥ āgum devāḥ vicakkhaṇā ti
translated: The Pamojjas, the foremost, came with the Odhatas.

original: vicakkhaṇā nāma devā āgatā.🔽Sadāmattā hāragajāti sadāmattā ca hāragajā ca. Missakā ca yasassinoti yasasampannā
analyzed: vicakkhaṇāḥ nāma devāḥ āgatāḥ  sadāmattā hāragajā ati sadāmattā ca hāragajā ca missakā ca yasassinī iti yasa sampannā
translated: The Vicakkhanas came.🔽The Sadamattas, the Hagaragas, and the Missakas, the famous, came.🔽The Sadamattas, etc., are three kinds of gods; the famous gods are the gods of great glory.

original: missakadevā ca. Thanayaṃ āga pajjunnoti pajjunno ca devarājā thanayanto āgato. Yo
analyzed: missaka devā ca thanayam āga pajjunno ti pajjunnaḥ ca devarājā thanayantaḥ āgataḥ yaḥ
translated: Pajjuna came, singing.

original: disā abhivassatīti yo yaṃ yaṃ disaṃ yāti, tattha tattha devo vassati. Dasete dasadhā
analyzed: disāḥ abhivassati iti yaḥ yam yam disam yāti tattha tattha devaḥ vassati dasa ete dasadhā
translated: The god who rains in all directions.

original: kāyāti etepi dasadevakāyā dasadhā āgatā.🔽Khemiyā tusitā yāmāti khemiyā devā tusitapuravāsino ca yāmādevalokavāsino ca. Kathakā
analyzed: ete api dasa deva kāyāḥ dasadhā āgatā  khemiyā tusitā khemiyā devā tusita pura vāsino ca yāmādeva loka vāsino ca kathakā
translated: The ten groups of gods came in ten ways.🔽The Khemiyas, the Tusitas, and the Yamas,🔽and the Kathakas, the famous, came.

original: ca yasassinoti yasasampannā kathakadevā ca. Pāḷiyaṃ pana “kaṭṭhakā cā”ti likhanti.
analyzed: ca yasassinī ti yasa sampannā kathaka devā ca pāḷiyam pana kaṭṭhakā ca ati likhanti
translated: The Khemiyas, etc., are three kinds of gods; the famous gods are the gods of great glory. In the text, however, they write “Katthakas.”

original: Lambītakā lāmaseṭṭhāti lambitakadevā ca lāmaseṭṭhadevā ca. Jotināmā ca āsavāti pabbatamatthake
analyzed: lambītakā lāmaseṭṭhā ati lambitakadevā ca lāmaseṭṭhadevā ca jotināmā ca āsavā ti pabbata matthake
translated: The Lambītakas and the Lāmaseṭṭhas are the gods of the Lambītaka and Lāmaseṭṭha planes. The Jotināmās and the āsavas are the gods of the Joti and āsava planes.

original: katanaḷaggikkhandho viya jotamānā jotidevā nāma atthi, te ca āsā ca devā āgatāti
analyzed: viya jotamānā jotidevā nāma atthi te ca āsā ca devā āgatā ati
translated: The Jotināmās are gods who shine like a bundle of reeds on the top of a mountain. The āsavas are gods who are so called because they are gods of hope .

original: attho. Pāḷiyaṃ pana “jātināmā”ti likhanti. Āsā devatā chandavasena āsavāti vuttā.
analyzed: attho pāḷiyam pana jāti nāmā ati likhanti āsā devatā chanda vasena āsavā ti vuttā
translated: The text reads “Jātināmās,” but the meaning is “gods of hope.”

original: Nimmānaratino āguṃ, athāguṃ paranimmitā. Dasete dasadhā kāyāti etepi dasa devakāyā dasadhāva āgatā.
analyzed: nimmāna ratinaḥ āgum atha āgum para nimmitāḥ dasa ite dasadhā ete api dasa deva kāyāḥ dasadhā avas āgatā
translated: The Nimmānaratīs came, and the Paranimmitavasavattīs came. These ten kinds of gods came in ten groups.

original: Saṭṭhete devanikāyāti ete ca āpo ca devātiādikā cha dasakā saṭṭhi devanikāyā sabbe
analyzed: saṭṭhā ite deva nikāyā ti ete ca āpaḥ ca deva ati ādikā cha dasakā saṭṭhi deva nikāyā sabbe
translated: These are the sixty kinds of gods. The “Āpos” and the “Devās” are the first two of the ten groups. All these sixty kinds of gods

original: nīlādivasena nānattavaṇṇino. Nāmanvayena āgacchunti nāmabhāgena nāmakoṭṭhāsena āgatā.
analyzed: nīla ādi vasena nānatta vaṇṇinaḥ nāma anvayena āgacchunti nāma bhāgena nāma koṭṭhāsena āgatā
translated: have different colours, blue and so on. They come by name, by the name-group.

original: Ye caññe sadisā sahāti ye ca aññepi tehi sadisā vaṇṇatopi nāmatopi etādisāyeva sesacakkavāḷesu
analyzed: ye ca aññe sadisā saha ati ye ca aññe pi tehi sadisāḥ vaṇṇataḥ pi nāmataḥ pi sesa cakkavāḷesu
translated: And others like them as well. Others like them, the same in colour and name, are to be found in other world-spheres.

original: devā, tepi āgatāyevāti ekapadeneva kalāpaṃ viya puṭakaṃ viya ca katvā sabbā devatā niddisati.
analyzed: devā te pi āgatāya iva ati eka padena iva kalāpam viya puṭakam viya ca katvā sabbā devatāḥ niddisati
translated: and the gods have come too. ” Thus he shows all the gods as if he were making a bundle or a package with a single word.

original: Evaṃ dasasu lokadhātusahassesu devakāye niddisitvā idāni yadatthaṃ te āgatā, taṃ
analyzed: evam dasasu lokadhātu sahassesu deva kāye niddisitvā idāni yad attham te āgatā tam
translated: Having shown the hosts of gods in the ten thousand world-systems in this way, he now shows what they have come for,

original: dassento pavuṭṭhajātinti gāthamāha. Tassattho – pavuṭṭhā vigatā jāti assāti ariyasaṅgho
analyzed: dassentaḥ pavuṭṭha jāti nti gātham āha tassa atthaḥ pavuṭṭhā vigatā jāti assa ati ariya saṅghaḥ
translated: saying the verse “The company of the noble ones who have passed beyond birth. ” The meaning is: the company of the noble ones is called “the company that has passed beyond birth” because birth is passed beyond, gone, for them.🔽It is “without blemish” because of the absence of the blemishes of lust, hatred, and delusion.

original: pavuṭṭhajāti nāma, taṃ pavuṭṭhajātiṃ rāgadosamohakhīlānaṃ abhāvā akhīlaṃ cattāro🔽oghe taritvā ṭhitattā oghatiṇṇaṃ catunnaṃ āsavānaṃ abhāvena anāsavaṃ ariyasaṅghaṃ🔽dakkhema passissāma. Tesaññeva oghānaṃ tiṇṇattā oghataraṃ āguṃ akaraṇato nāgaṃ. Asitātiganti
analyzed: pavuṭṭhajāti nāma tam pavuṭṭhajātim rāga dosa moha khīlānam abhāvāḥ akhīlam cattāro  oghe taritvā ogha tiṇṇam catunnam āsavānam abhāvena anāsavam ariya saṅgham  dakkhema passissāma tesaṃ eva oghānam tiṇṇattā oghataram āgum a karaṇataḥ nāgam asita atiganti
translated: It is “without defilements” because of the absence of the four defilements, since it stands having crossed over the four floods.🔽It is “the best of all” because it has crossed over the floods. It is “the great nāga” because it has come to the state of non-doing. It is “the moon” because it has gone beyond the state of darkness. It is “the radiant one” because it shines with glory like the moon that has gone beyond the dark fortnight. It is “the one with the ten powers” because it has the ten powers.🔽We will see the company of the noble ones that has passed beyond birth, the best of all, the great nāga, the moon, the radiant one, the one with the ten powers.

original: kāḷakabhāvātītaṃ candaṃva siriyā virocamānaṃ dasabalañca dakkhema passissāmāti etadatthaṃ
analyzed: kāḷaka bhāva atītam candam iva siriyā virocamānam dasabalam ca dakkhema passissāma ati etad attham
translated: For this purpose

original: sabbepi te nāmanvayena āgacchuṃ, ye caññe sadisā sahāti.
analyzed: sabbe api te nāma anvayena āgacchum ye caññe sadisā saha ati
translated: all of them have come, and also others like them.

original: 341. Idāni brahmāno dassento subrahmā paramatto cātiādimāha. Tattha subrahmāti eko
analyzed: idāni brahmānaḥ dassento subrahmā paramatto ca atiādim āha tattha subrahmā ati ekaḥ
translated: Herein, Subrahma is one

original: brahmā. Paramattopi brahmāva. Puttā iddhimato sahāti ete iddhimato buddhassa bhagavato
analyzed: brahmā paramattaḥ api brahmā ava puttāḥ iddhimato saha ati ete iddhimataḥ buddhassa bhagavato
translated: Brahma. Paramatta is also a Brahma. The sons of the One of Psychic Power are the Noble Brahmas who have come with the One of Psychic Power, the Blessed One.

original: puttā ariyabrahmāno saheva āgatā. Sanaṅkumāro tisso cāti sanaṅkumāro ca tissamahābrahmā🔽ca. Sopāgāti sopi āgato.
analyzed: puttāḥ ariya brahmāno saha iva āgatā sanaṅkumāro tisso ca ati sanaṅkumāro ca tissa mahābrahmā  ca saḥ upāgāti saḥ upi āgataḥ
translated: Sanaṅkumāra and Tissa the Great Brahma have come too.🔽“A thousand of the Brahma worlds,🔽the Great Brahma rules.

original: “Sahassaṃ brahmalokānaṃ, mahābrahmābhitiṭṭhati;
analyzed: sahassam brahma lokānam mahābrahmā abhitiṭṭhati
translated: He has been reborn, radiant,

original: Upapanno jutimanto, bhismākāyo yasassi so”ti. –🔽Ettha sahassaṃ brahmalokānanti ekaṅguliyā ekasahassacakkavāḷe dasahi aṅgulīhi dasasahassicakkavāḷe
analyzed: upapannaḥ jutimantaḥ bhismākāyaḥ yasassi soti  ettha sahassam eka aṅguliyā eka sahassa cakkavāḷe dasahi aṅgulīhi dasa sahassi cakkavāḷe
translated: his body terrible, he is glorious.

original: ālokapharaṇasamatthānaṃ mahābrahmānaṃ sahassaṃ āgataṃ. Mahābrahmābhitiṭṭhatīti yattha
analyzed: āloka pharaṇa samatthānam mahābrahmānam sahassam āgatam mahābrahmā abhitiṭṭhati iti yattha
translated: Herein, a thousand of the Brahma worlds is a thousand world-spheres, that is to say, a thousand four-continent world-spheres, a thousand Jambu- dvīpas, a thousand Aparagoyānas, a thousand Uttarakurus, a thousand Pubbavidehas, a thousand of each of the four great oceans, a thousand of each of the four kings of the gods, a thousand of each of the four divine abodes, a thousand of each of the Brahmā-world orders, a thousand of each of the Brahmās’ palaces, a thousand of each of the Brahmās’ thrones, a thousand of each of the Brahmās’ bodies, a thousand of each of the Brahmās’ voices, a thousand of each of the Brahmās’ spans of life, a thousand of each of the Brahmās’ enjoyments of pleasure, a thousand of each of the Brahmās’ knowledges, a thousand of each of the Brahmās’ masteries, a thousand of each of the Brahmās’ powers.🔽The Great Brahma rules is where each Great Brahma rules, outrivalling other Brahmas.

original: ekeko mahābrahmā aññe brahme abhibhavitvā tiṭṭhati. Upapannoti brahmaloke nibbatto.
analyzed: ekekaḥ mahābrahmā aññe brahme abhibhavitvā tiṭṭhati upapanno ti brahma loke nibbatto
translated: He has been reborn is reborn in the Brahmā-world.

original: Jutimantoti ānubhāvasampanno. Bhismākāyoti mahākāyo, dvīhi tīhi māgadhikehi gāmakkhettehi
analyzed: jutimantaḥ ti ānubhāva sampannaḥ bhismākāyaḥ ti mahā kāyaḥ dvīhi tīhi māgadhikehi gāma kkhettehi
translated: Jutimanta: endowed with majesty. Bhismākā: of awesome form, of a huge body, the size of two or three Magadhan villages.

original: samappamāṇaattabhāvo. Yasassisoti attabhāvasirīsaṅkhātena yasena samannāgato.🔽Dasettha issarā āguṃ, paccekavasavattinoti etasmiñca brahmasahasse ye pāṭiyekkaṃ

analyzed: indasālaguhāyanti pubbe pi sā dvinnam pabbatānam antare guhā indasāla rukkhaḥ ca assā
translated: The Indasāla Cave: before the time of the Buddha, there was a cave between two rocks, and an Indasāla tree

analyzed: dvāre tasmai indasālaguhā ati saṅkhyam gatāḥ atha nam kuṭṭehi parikkhipitvā dvāra vāta pānāni
translated: was at the entrance to the cave. That is why it is known as the Indasāla Cave. Then they enclosed it with walls, put in windows and doors,

original: yojetvā supariniṭṭhitasudhākammamālākammalatākammavicittaṃ leṇaṃ katvā bhagavato🔽adaṃsu. Purimavohāravasena pana “indasālaguhā” tveva naṃ sañjānanti. Taṃ sandhāya
analyzed: yojetvā su pariniṭṭhita sudhā kamma mālā kamma latā kamma vicittam leṇam katvā bhagavataḥ  purima vohāra vasena pana inda sālaguhā tu eva nam sañjānanti tam sandhāya
translated: and made it into a very fine dwelling, decorated with stucco work, painted work, and lattice work. They offered it to the

original: vuttaṃ ‘indasālaguhāya’nti.
analyzed: vuttam
translated: Blessed One. But because of its previous name, they still call it the Indasāla Cave. That is why it is said, ‘in the Indasāla Cave.’

original: Ussukkaṃ udapādīti dhammiko ussāho uppajji. Nanu ca esa abhiṇhadassāvī bhagavato,
analyzed: ussukkam udapādi iti dhammikaḥ ussāhaḥ uppajji nanu ca esa abhiṇha dassāvī bhagavataḥ
translated: Ussukka udapādi: a righteous enthusiasm arose. But didn’t he often see the Blessed One?

original: na so devatāsannipāto nāma atthi, yatthāyaṃ na āgatapubbo, sakkena sadiso appamādavihārī
analyzed: na saḥ devatā sannipātaḥ nāma atthi yattha ayam na āgata pubbaḥ sakkena sadisaḥ appamāda vihārī
translated: There is no gathering of gods at which he has not been present before. There is no god who is more devoted to the practice of heedfulness than Sakka.

original: devaputto nāma natthi. Atha kasmā buddhadassanaṃ anāgatapubbassa viya assa ussāho
analyzed: devaputto nāma natthi atha kasmā buddha dassanam anāgata pubbassa viya assa ussāhaḥ
translated: So why should he have been enthusiastic about seeing the Buddha as if he had never seen him before?

original: udapādīti? Maraṇabhayena santajjitattā. Tasmiṃ kirassa samaye āyu parikkhīṇo, so
analyzed: udapādi iti maraṇa bhayena tasmin kirassa samaye āyu parikkhīṇo so
translated: Why did he appear? Because he was frightened by the fear of death. On that occasion, it seems, his life was coming to an end.

original: pañca pubbanimittāni disvā “parikkhīṇo dāni me āyū”ti aññāsi. Yesañca devaputtānaṃ
analyzed: pañca pubba nimittāni disvā parikkhīṇaḥ dāni me āyū ti aññāsi yesam ca deva puttānam

original: maraṇanimittāni āvi bhavanti, tesu ye parittakena puññakammena devaloke nibbattā,
analyzed: maraṇa nimittāni āvi bhavanti tesu ye parittakena puñña kammena deva loke nibbattā
translated: And when the signs of death appear to the devas, those who have been reborn in the deva world by means of a limited meritorious attainment

original: te “kuhiṃ nu kho idāni nibbattissāmā”ti bhayaṃ santāsaṃ āpajjanti. Ye katabhīruttānā
analyzed: te kuhim nu kho idāni nibbattissāma ati bhayam santāsam āpajjanti ye kata bhīru ttānā
translated: are frightened and terrified, thinking, “Where shall we be reborn now?” But those who have been reborn there by means of a great meritorious attainment,

analyzed: bahum puññam katvā nibbattā te attanā dinna dānam rakkhita sīlam bhāvita bhāvanañca
translated: having given gifts, observed the moral precepts, and developed the spiritual faculties,

original: āgamma “uparidevaloke sampattiṃ anubhavissāmā”ti na bhāyanti.
analyzed: āgamma upari deva loke sampattim anubhavissāma iti na bhāyanti
translated: are not frightened, thinking, “We shall experience the bliss of the higher deva-world.”

original: Sakko pana devarājā pubbanimittāni disvā dasayojanasahassaṃ devanagaraṃ, yojanasahassubbedhaṃ
analyzed: sakkaḥ pana devarājā pubba nimittāni disvā dasa yojana sahassam devanagaram yojana sahassa ubbedham
translated: But Sakka, the deva-king, saw the signs and thought, “My city of Ālakamandā is ten thousand leagues in extent,🔽my Vejayanta Palace is a thousand leagues high,

original: vejayantaṃ, tiyojanasatikaṃ sudhammadevasabhaṃ, yojanasatubbedhaṃ pāricchattakaṃ,
analyzed: vejayantam ti yojana satikam sudhammadevasabham yojana satubbedham pāricchattakam
translated: my Sudhamma Assembly Hall is three hundred leagues in extent,🔽and my Pāricchattaka tree is a hundred leagues high,

original: saṭṭhiyojanikaṃ paṇḍukambalasilaṃ, aḍḍhatiyā nāṭakakoṭiyo dvīsu devalokesu devaparisaṃ,
analyzed: saṭṭhi yojanikam paṇḍu kambala silam aḍḍhatiyāḥ nāṭaka koṭiyaḥ dvīsu deva lokesu deva parisam
translated: the rock of the white blanket, sixty leagues in extent, the retinue of gods in the two divine worlds,

original: nandanavanaṃ, cittalatāvanaṃ, missakavanaṃ, phārusakavananti etaṃ sabbasampattiṃ
analyzed: nandana vanam cittalatā vanam missaka vanam phārusaka vananti etam sabba sampattim
translated: the Nandana Grove, the Cittalatā Grove, the Missaka Grove, the Phārusaka Grove,

original: oloketvā “nassati vata bho me ayaṃ sampattī”ti bhayābhibhūto ahosi.
analyzed: oloketvā nassati vata bho me ayam sampattī iti bhaya abhibhūtaḥ ahosi
translated: and he thought: “Alas, this my prosperity will be destroyed.” He was overcome with fear.

original: Tato “atthi nu kho koci samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā lokapitāmaho mahābrahmā vā, yo me hadayanissitaṃ
analyzed: tatas atthi nu kho koci samaṇaḥ vā brāhmaṇaḥ vā lokapitāmahaḥ mahābrahmā vā yaḥ me hadaya nissitam
translated: Then he thought: “Is there any ascetic or brāhmaṇa or Great Brahmā, the Grandfather of the World, who could remove

original: sokasallaṃ samuddharitvā imaṃ sampattiṃ thāvaraṃ kareyyā”ti olokento kañci adisvā
analyzed: soka sallam samuddharitvā imam sampattim thāvaram kareyyāti olokentaḥ kañci a disvā
translated: the dart of sorrow lodged in my heart and make this prosperity firm?” Looking (for such a one) he saw none.

original: puna addasa “mādisānaṃ satasahassānampi uppannaṃ sokasallaṃ sammāsambuddho uddharituṃ
analyzed: puna addasa mādisānam sata sahassānam pi uppannam soka sallam sammāsambuddhaḥ uddharitum
translated: Then he saw: “Only a Perfectly Awakened Buddha is able to remove the dart of sorrow that has arisen in the hundreds of thousands like me.” As he was reflecting thus,

original: paṭibalo”ti. Athevaṃ parivitakkentassa tena kho pana samayena sakkassa devānamindassa🔽ussukkaṃ udapādi bhagavantaṃ dassanāya.
analyzed: paṭibalaḥ ti atha ivam parivitakkentassa tena khalu pana samayena sakkassa devānamindassa 🔽ussukkam udapādi bhagavantam dassanāya
translated: at that time a desire arose in Sakka, the Lord of the Gods, to see the Fortunate One.

original: Kahaṃ nu kho bhagavā etarahi viharatīti katarasmiṃ janapade kataraṃ nagaraṃ upanissāya
analyzed: kaham nu khalu bhagavā etarahi viharati iti katarasmin janapade kataram nagaram upanissāya
translated: “Where is the Blessed One living now, in what region, in what country, near what village?”🔽“In whose support is he living, teaching the Deathless Truth?”

original: kassa paccaye paribhuñjanto kassa amataṃ dhammaṃ desayamāno viharatīti. Addasā khoti
analyzed: kassa paccaye paribhuñjantaḥ kassa amatam dhammam desayamāno viharati iti addasā kho ti
translated: “He saw”:

original: addakkhi paṭivijjhi. Mārisāti piyavacanametaṃ, devatānaṃ pāṭiyekko vohāro. Niddukkhātipi
analyzed: addakkhi paṭivijjhi mārisa ati piya vacanam etam devatānam pāṭiyekkaḥ vohāraḥ niddukkha atipi
translated: he saw, he penetrated. “Māra”: this is a term of affection, a special expression of the deities. “Free from suffering”

original: vuttaṃ hoti. Kasmā panesa deve āmantesi? Sahāyatthāya. Pubbe kiresa bhagavati saḷalaghare
analyzed: vuttam hoti kasmā pana esa deve āmantesi sahāya tthāya pubbe kiresa bhagavati saḷalaghare
translated: is also said. But why did he address the deities? For the sake of companionship. Formerly, when the Blessed One was living in the six-walled monastery,

analyzed: viharante ekakaḥ iva dassanāya agamāsi satthā a paripakkam tāvassa ñāṇam kati pāham
translated: he went alone to see the Teacher. The Teacher thought: “His knowledge is not yet ripe. But after a few days,

analyzed: pana atikkamitvā mayi indasālaguhā ayam viharante pañca pubba nimittāni disvā maraṇa bhaya bhītaḥ
translated: when I am living in the Indasāla Cave, he will see five signs and, frightened by the fear of death,

analyzed: dvīsu deva lokesu devatāhi saddhim upasaṅkamitvā cuddasa pañhe pucchitvā upekkhā pañha vissajjana avasāne
translated: he will approach the deities in two divine worlds and ask fourteen questions. At the end of the answer to the question on equanimity,

original: asītiyā devatāsahassehi saddhiṃ sotāpattiphale patiṭṭhahissatī”ti cintetvā okāsaṃ
analyzed: asītiyā devatā sahassehi saddhim sotāpatti phale patiṭṭhahissati iti cintetvā okāsam

original: nākāsi. So “mama pubbepi ekakassa gatattā satthārā okāso na kato, addhā me natthi🔽maggaphalassa upanissayo, ekassa pana upanissaye sati cakkavāḷapariyantāyapi parisāya
analyzed: na akāsi saḥ mama pubbe pi ekakassa gatattā satthārā okāsaḥ na kataḥ addhā me natthi  magga phalassa upanissayaḥ ekassa pana upanissaye sati cakkavāḷa pariyantāya api parisāya
translated: He thought: ‘Formerly, when I went alone, the Teacher did not give an opportunity, surely I have no🔽support for the Path and the Fruits, but when there is a support for one person, the Fortunate One teaches the Dhamma to the assembly that extends to the edge of the world-sphere.

original: bhagavā dhammaṃ desetiyeva. Avassaṃ kho pana dvīsu devalokesu kassaci devassa upanissayo🔽bhavissati, taṃ sandhāya satthā dhammaṃ desessati. Taṃ sutvā ahampi attano domanassaṃ
analyzed: bhagavā dhammam deseti yeva avassam kho pana dvīsu deva lokesu kassaci devassa upanissayaḥ  bhavissati tam sandhāya satthā dhammaṃ desessati tam sutvā aham pi attanaḥ domanassam
translated: It is not likely that there is a support for anyone in the two Divine Worlds,🔽the Teacher will teach the Dhamma referring to that, after hearing it I will also be able to calm my own sorrow.’

original: vūpasamessāmī”ti cintetvā sahāyatthāya āmantesi.
analyzed: vūpasamessāmi iti cintetvā sahāya tthāya āmantesi
translated: After thinking like this he invited (them) to be his companions.

original: Evaṃ bhaddaṃ tavāti kho devā tāvatiṃsāti evaṃ hotu mahārāja, gacchāma bhagavantaṃ
analyzed: evam bhaddam tava ati kho devā evam hotu mahā rāja gacchāma bhagavantam
translated: “It would be good for you, Great King,” said the Divinities of the Thirty-three, “it will be good, Great King, we will go to see the Fortunate One,

analyzed: dassanāya dullabhaḥ buddhuppādaḥ bhaddam tava yaḥ tvam pabbata kīḷam nadī kīḷam gacchāma ati
translated: the arising of Buddhas is rare, it would be good for you, you should go to play in the mountains, play in the rivers, play in the parks,

original: avatvā amhe evarūpesu ṭhānesu niyojesīti. Paccassosunti tassa vacanaṃ sirasā sampaṭicchiṃsu.
analyzed: a vatvā amhe evarūpesu ṭhānesu niyojesi iti paccassosunti tassa vacanam sirasā sampaṭicchiṃsu
translated: and without consulting us, he has appointed us to such a position.” “We will do as you say,” they replied, and they agreed to his suggestion.

original: 345. Pañcasikhaṃ gandhabbadevaputtaṃ āmantesīti deve tāva āmantetu, imaṃ kasmā visuṃ🔽āmantesi? Okāsakaraṇatthaṃ. Evaṃ kirassa ahosi “dvīsu devalokesu devatā gahetvā dhurena🔽paharantassa viya satthāraṃ upasaṅkamituṃ na yuttaṃ, ayaṃ pana pañcasikho dasabalassa
analyzed: pañcasikham gandhabbadeva puttam āmantesi iti deve tāva āmantetu imam kasmai visum  āmantesi okāsa karaṇa attham evam kirassa ahosi dvīsu deva lokesu devatāḥ gahetvā dhurena  paharantassa viya satthāram upasaṅkamitum na yuttam ayam pana pañcasikhaḥ dasabalassa
translated: “He addressed the celestial musician Pañcasikha.” He addressed the gods first, but why did he address Pañcasikha separately?

original: upaṭṭhāko vallabho icchiticchitakkhaṇe gantvā pañhaṃ pucchitvā dhammaṃ suṇāti, imaṃ
analyzed: upaṭṭhākaḥ vallabhaḥ icchiticchita khaṇe gantvā pañham pucchitvā dhammam suṇāti imaṃ
translated: For the purpose of making an opening. He thought, “It is not proper for me to approach the Teacher as if I were striking him with a whip, taking the gods from two divine worlds. But this Pañcasikha is a servant and a favorite of the Ten Powered One. He can go whenever he wishes, ask questions, and listen to the Dhamma.

original: purato pesetvā okāsaṃ kāretvā iminā katokāse upasaṅkamitvā pañhaṃ pucchissāmī”ti
analyzed: puratas pesetvā okāsam kāretvā iminā kata ukāse upasaṅkamitvā pañham pucchissāmi iti
translated: If I send him ahead, he will make an opening. After he has made an opening, I will approach and ask my question.”

original: okāsakaraṇatthaṃ āmantesi.
analyzed: okāsa karaṇa attham āmantesi
translated: He addressed him for the purpose of making an opening.

original: Evaṃ bhaddaṃ tavāti so “evaṃ mahārāja, hotu, bhaddaṃ tava, yo tvaṃ maṃ ‘ehi, mārisa,
analyzed: evam bhaddam tava ati saḥ evam mahā rāja hotu bhaddam tava tvam mama ehi mārisa
translated: “It will be well with you.” He said, “It will be well with you, Great King, if you will go and say to the Teacher,

analyzed: uyyāna kīḷa ādīni vā naṭa samajja ādīni vā dassanāya gacchāma ati avatvā buddham passissāma

analyzed: dhammam sossāma ati vadasi iti daḷhataram upatthambhentaḥ devānamindassa vacanam paṭissutvā  anucariyam sahacaraṇam ekatas gamanam upāgami
translated: and he agreed to the Lord of the Gods’ request, and went with him.

original: Tattha beluvapaṇḍunti beluvapakkaṃ viya paṇḍuvaṇṇaṃ. Tassa kira sovaṇṇamayaṃ pokkharaṃ,
analyzed: tattha beluva paṇḍum ti beluva pakkam viya paṇḍu vaṇṇam tassa kira sovaṇṇa mayam pokkharam
translated: Herein, ‘Beluva-fair’ means fair like a ripe beluva fruit. It seems that his lute was made of gold,

analyzed: inda nīla mayaḥ daṇḍaḥ rajata mayā tantiyā pavāḷa mayā veṭhakā vīṇā pattakam gāvutam
translated: the neck was of sapphire, the strings were of silver, the bridge was of coral, the body was a cubit long,

analyzed: tanti bandhana ṭṭhānam gāvutam upari daṇḍakaḥ ti gāvuta ppamāṇā vīṇā iti so

analyzed: nicchāretvā sesa deve sakkassa gamana kālam jānāpento ekamantam aṭṭhāsi evam tassa
translated: and he stood to one side, letting the other gods know that Sakka was on his way. Thus

analyzed: gīta vādita saññāya sannipatite deva gaṇe atha kho sakkaḥ devānaminda upe vediyake pabbate paccuṭṭhāsi
translated: … appeared on the Vediyaka mountain.

original: 346. Atiriva obhāsajātoti aññesu divasesu ekasseva devassa vā mārassa vā brahmuno
analyzed: atirivaḥ obhāsa jātaḥ ti aññesu divasesu ekassa iva devassa vā mārassa vā brahmuno
translated: Very radiant: on other days he is radiant with the radiance of one god or Māra or Brahmā,

original: vā obhāsena obhāsajāto hoti, taṃdivasaṃ pana dvīsu devalokesu devatānaṃ obhāsena
analyzed: vai obhāsena obhāsa jātaḥ hoti taṃdivasam pana dvīsu deva lokesu devatānam obhāsena
translated: but on that day he was very radiant with the radiance of the gods in two divine worlds,

analyzed: atiriva obhāsa jātaḥ eka pajjotaḥ sahassa canda sūriya oggata kāla sadisaḥ ahosi paritas gāmesu
translated: and he was like a single flame, like the time when a thousand moons and suns are risen. People in the villages all around

original: manussāti samantā gāmesu manussā. Pakatisāyamāsakāleyeva kira gāmamajjhe dārakesu🔽kīḷantesu tattha sakko agamāsi, tasmā manussā passitvā evamāhaṃsu. Nanu ca majjhimayāme
analyzed: manussā ati samantā gāmesu manussā kira gāma majjhe dārakesu  kīḷantesu tattha sakkaḥ agamāsi tasmā manussā passitvā evam āhaṃsu nanu ca majjhima yāme
translated: said: “What is this?” People in the villages all around: people in the villages all around. It seems that at the time of the normal evening meal, while children were playing in the middle of the village,🔽Sakka went there, and so people, having seen him, said this. But didn’t gods approach the Fortunate One in the middle watch?

original: devatā bhagavantaṃ upasaṅkamanti, ayaṃ kasmā paṭhamayāmassāpi purimabhāgeyeva āgatoti?
analyzed: devatāḥ bhagavantam upasaṅkamanti ayam kasmā paṭhama yāmassa api āgataḥ ti

analyzed: maraṇa bhayena iva kiṃsu nāma ati kiṃsu nāma bho etam kaḥ nu khalu ajja mahesakkhaḥ
translated: Because he was terrified by the fear of death. What is this? What is this, good sirs? Who is this great lord today

analyzed: devaḥ vā brahmā vā bhagavantam pañham pucchitum dhammam sotum upasaṅkamantaḥ

analyzed: nāma bho bhagavā pañham vissajjessati dhammam desessati lābhāḥ amhākam yesam no  evam devatānam kaṅkhā vinodakaḥ satthā avidūre vihāre vasati ye labhāma thālaka bhikkham pi
translated: “How will the Blessed One answer the question and teach the Dhamma? It is our gain, it is our great gain,
