analyzed: kaṭacchu bhikkham pi dātunti saṃviggā loma haṭṭha jātā uddhagga lomā hutvā dasa nakha samodhāna samujjalam
translated: that we have such a teacher who removes our doubts, living so near in the monastery. We will get the chance to give him a palm-leaf bowl or a clay bowl.”

original: añjaliṃ sirasmiṃ patiṭṭhapetvā namassamānā aṭṭhaṃsu.🔽347. Durupasaṅkamāti dupayirupāsiyā. Ahaṃ sarāgo sadoso samoho, satthā vītarāgo vītadoso
analyzed: añjalim sirasmim patiṭṭhapetvā namassamānāḥ aṭṭhaṃsu  aham sa rāgaḥ sa dosaḥ sa mohaḥ satthā vīta rāgaḥ vīta dosaḥ
translated: Shaken and with hair standing on end, they raised their joined palms above their heads and paid homage to the Tathāgata, standing there with their hair disheveled.

original: vītamoho, tasmā dupayirupāsiyā tathāgatā mādisena. Jhāyīti lakkhaṇūpanijjhānena ca
analyzed: vīta mohaḥ tasmā tathāgatāḥ mādisena jhāyi iti lakkhaṇa upanijjhānena ca
translated: “Hard to approach” : hard to approach. I am full of lust, full of hatred, full of delusion, but the Teacher is free from lust, free from hatred, free from delusion. Therefore the Tathāgata is hard to approach for one like me. “Meditator” : a meditator by virtue of the meditation on the characteristics of impermanence, etc.,

original: ārammaṇūpanijjhānena ca jhāyī. Tasmiññeva jhāne ratāti jhānaratā. Tadantaraṃ paṭisallīnāti
analyzed: ārammaṇa upanijjhānena ca jhāyī tasmin ñeva jhāne ratā ati jhāna ratā tad antaram paṭisallīnā ati
translated: and by virtue of the meditation on the object of concentration. “Delighting in that meditation” : delighting in that meditation. “Gone to his rest” :

original: tadantaraṃ paṭisallīnā sampati paṭisallīnā vā. Tasmā na kevalaṃ jhāyī jhānaratāti
analyzed: tad antaram paṭisallīnā sampati paṭisallīnā vā tasmai na kevalam jhāyī jhāna ratā ati
translated: and those who had been in seclusion were still in seclusion. Therefore, not only the meditators, but also those who were in seclusion were difficult to approach.

original: durupasaṅkamā, idānimeva paṭisallīnātipi durupasaṅkamā. Pasādeyyāsīti ārādheyyāsi,
analyzed: durupasaṅkamā idānimā eva durupasaṅkamā pasādeyyā asi iti ārādheyyā asi
translated: “You should win him over”: you should please him,🔽and give him an opportunity, make a chance for him.

original: okāsaṃ me kāretvā dadeyyāsīti vadati. Beluvapaṇḍuvīṇaṃ ādāyāti nanu pubbeva ādinnāti?
analyzed: okāsam me kāretvā dadeyyāsi iti vadati beluva paṇḍu vīṇam ādāya ati nanu pubbā iva ādinnā ati
translated: “Taking his lute”: hasn’t he already taken it?

original: Āma, ādinnā. Maggagamanavasena pana aṃsakūṭe laggitā, idāni naṃ vāmahatthe ṭhapetvā
analyzed: āma ādinnā magga gamana vasena pana aṃsakūṭe laggitā idāni naṃ vāma hatthe ṭhapetvā
translated: “Yes, he has taken it, but he has been carrying it on his shoulder during the journey. Now he has placed it in his left hand,

original: vādanasajjaṃ katvā ādiyi. Tena vuttaṃ “ādāyā”ti.
analyzed: vādana sajjam katvā tena vuttam ādāya ati
translated: and he has started to play it, ready to play.” That is why it is said “taking it.”

original: Pañcasikhagītagāthāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: pañcasikhagītagāthā vaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the verses of the song of Pañcasikha.

original: 348. Assāvesīti sāvesi. Buddhūpasañhitāti buddhaṃ ārabbha buddhaṃ nissayaṃ katvā pavattāti attho. Sesapadesupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: assāvesi iti sā avesi buddha upasañhitā ati buddham ārabbha buddham nissayam katvā pavattā ati attho sesa padesu pi esā iva nayo
translated: “He sang”: he sang. “About the Buddha”: the meaning is that it occurred with reference to the Buddha, depending on the Buddha. The same method of explanation applies in the other cases.

original: Vande te pitaraṃ bhadde, timbaruṃ sūriyavacchaseti ettha sūriyavacchasāti sūriyasamānasarīrā.
analyzed: vande te pitaram bhadde timbarum sūriya vacchasā iti ettha sūriya vacchasā ati sūriya samāna sarīrā
translated: “I praise your father, fair lady, the timbaru tree, you who are radiant like the sun.” Here “radiant like the sun” means having a body like the sun.

original: Tassā kira devadhītāya pādantato rasmi uṭṭhahitvā kesantaṃ ārohati, tasmā bālasūriyamaṇḍalasadisā
analyzed: tassā kira deva dhītāya uṭṭhahitvā kesantam ārohati tasmā bāla sūriya maṇḍala sadisā
translated: The light, it seems, rose from the foot of this deva maiden and reached to the top of her head, so that she appeared like a young sun’s orb.

original: khāyati, iti naṃ “sūriyavacchasā”ti sañjānanti. Taṃ sandhāyāha – “bhadde, sūriyavacchase,
analyzed: khāyati iti nam sūriya vacchasā ati sañjānanti tam sandhāya āha bhadde sūriya vacchase
translated: Therefore they knew her as “Sūriyavacchasā” . Referring to her, he said: “Dear Sūriyavacchasā,

original: tava pitaraṃ timbaruṃ gandhabbadevarājānaṃ vandāmī”ti. Yena jātāsi kalyāṇīti yena
analyzed: tava pitaram timbarum gandhabba deva rājānam vandāmi iti yena jātā asi kalyāṇī iti yena
translated: I pay homage to your father, the gandhabba king Timbaru.”🔽By whom you were born beautiful: by what means,

original: kāraṇabhūtena yaṃ timbaruṃ devarājānaṃ nissāya tvaṃ jātā, kalyāṇī sabbaṅgasobhanā.
analyzed: kāraṇa bhūtena yam timbarum devarājānam nissāya tvam jātā kalyāṇī sabbaṅga sobhanā
translated: by whom as a cause, you were born, beautiful, lovely in all limbs.

original: Ānandajananī mamāti mayhaṃ pītisomanassavaḍḍhanī.🔽Vātova sedataṃ kantoti yathā sañjātasedānaṃ sedaharaṇatthaṃ vāto iṭṭho hoti kanto
analyzed: ānanda jananī mama ati mayham pīti somanaḥ savaḍḍhanī  vātaḥ uva sedatam kanto ti yathā sañjāta sedānam seda haraṇa attham vātaḥ iṭṭhaḥ hoti kanto
translated: You who bring joy to me: you who increase my joy and gladness.🔽You are welcome as a breeze to one all heated, as water to the thirsty: just as a breeze is welcome to one heated by a hot wind, so as to remove his heat,

original: manāpo, evanti attho. Pānīyaṃva pipāsatoti pātumicchantassa pipāsato pipāsābhibhūtassa.
analyzed: evanti attho pānīyam iva pipāsato ti pātum icchantassa pipāsataḥ pipāsā abhibhūtassa
translated: so as to remove his thirst.

original: Aṅgīrasīti aṅge rasmiyo assāti aṅgīrasī, tameva ārabbha ālapanto vadati. Dhammo arahatāmivāti
analyzed: aṅgīrasī iti aṅge rasmiyaḥ assa ati aṅgīrasī tam eva ārabbha ālapantaḥ vadati dhammaḥ arahatām iva ati
translated: You are welcome as a draught to one who thirsts, as Dhamma is to Arahats.

original: arahantānaṃ navalokuttaradhammo viya.🔽Jighacchatoti bhuñjitukāmassa khudābhibhūtassa. Jalantamiva vārināti yathā koci jalantaṃ
analyzed: arahantānam nava lokuttara dhammo viya  jighacchataḥ iti bhuñjitu kāmassa khudā abhibhūtassa jalantam iva vārinā ati yathā koci jalantam
translated: like the nine supramundane states of the Arahants.

original: jātavedaṃ udakakumbhena nibbāpeyya, evaṃ tava kāraṇā uppannaṃ mama kāmarāgapariḷāhaṃ nibbāpehīti vadati.
analyzed: jātavedam udaka kumbhena nibbāpeyya evam tava kāraṇā uppannam mama kāma rāga pariḷāham nibbāpehi iti vadati
translated: “I am hungry” : he is desirous of eating, overcome by hunger. “Like a fire with water” : just as one might extinguish a burning fire with a water-pot, so should you extinguish the fire of lust and passion that has arisen in me.

original: Yuttaṃ kiñjakkhareṇunāti padumakesarareṇunā yuttaṃ. Nāgo ghammābhitatto vāti ghammābhitattahatthī🔽viya. Ogāhe te thanūdaranti yathā so nāgo pokkharaṇiṃ ogāhitvā pivitvā aggasoṇḍamattaṃ🔽paññāyamānaṃ katvā nimuggo sukhaṃ sātaṃ vindati, evaṃ kadā nu kho te thanūdaraṃ thanavemajjhaṃ
analyzed: yuttam kiñjakkha reṇunā ati paduma kesara reṇunā yuttam nāgaḥ ghamma abhitattaḥ vā ati ghamma abhitatta hatthī  viyas ogāhe te yathā saḥ nāgaḥ pokkharaṇim ogāhitvā pivitvā agga soṇḍa mattam  paññāyamānam katvā nimuggaḥ sukham sātam vindati evam kadā nu kho te thanu udaram thana vemajjham
translated: “Fit for the pollen of the lotus” : fit for the pollen of the lotus filament. “Like an elephant oppressed by heat” : like an elephant oppressed by heat🔽“I would enter your belly” : just as that elephant, having entered the lotus pond, drinks, and having drunk, submerges his body, leaving only his trunk visible, and finds happiness and satisfaction, so when will I find happiness and satisfaction by entering your belly, your belly-midriff,

original: udarañca otaritvā ahaṃ sukhaṃ sātaṃ paṭilabhissāmīti vadati.
analyzed: udaram ca otaritvā aham sukham sātam paṭilabhissāmi iti vadati
translated: and your belly-cavity?

original: “Accaṅkusova nāgova, jitaṃ me tuttatomaraṃ;
analyzed: accaṅkusā uva nāgā uva jitam me tutta tomaram
translated: “Like an elephant without goad, like a tamed elephant with goad, conquered is my lust and passion;

original: Kāraṇaṃ nappajānāmi, sammatto lakkhaṇūruyā”ti. –
analyzed: kāraṇam na ppajānāmi sammattaḥ
translated: I do not understand the reason, I am satisfied with the thighs of the one with marks.”

original: Ettha tuttaṃ vuccati kaṇṇamūle vijjhanaayadaṇḍako. Tomaranti pādādīsu vijjhanadaṇḍatomaraṃ.
analyzed: ettha tuttam vuccati kaṇṇa mūle pāda ādīsu
translated: Herein, the goad is the iron hook at the end of the elephant-hook which pierces the elephant’s ear-hole. The spear is the spear-shaft with a spear-head for piercing the elephant’s feet, etc.

original: Aṅkusoti matthake vijjhanakuṭilakaṇṭako. Yo ca nāgo pabhinnamatto accaṅkuso hoti,
analyzed: aṅkusaḥ ti matthake vijjhana kuṭila kaṇṭakaḥ yaḥ ca nāgaḥ pabhinna mattaḥ accaṅkusaḥ hoti
translated: The iron hook is the curved iron hook for piercing the elephant’s head. An elephant that is mad with rut is called “beyond the iron hook” ,

original: aṅkusaṃ atīto; aṅkusena vijjhiyamānopi vasaṃ na gacchati, so “jitaṃ mayā tuttatomaraṃ,🔽yo ahaṃ aṅkusassapi vasaṃ na gacchāmī”ti madadappena kiñci kāraṇaṃ na bujjhati. Yathā
analyzed: aṅkusam atītaḥ aṅkusena vijjhiyamānaḥ api vasam na gacchati saḥ jitam mayā tutta tomaram  yaḥ aham aṅkusassa api vasam na gacchāmi iti mada dappena kiñci kāraṇam na bujjhati yathā
translated: because he is beyond the iron hook’s control. Even when he is being pierced with the iron hook he does not come under control. He is intoxicated with the conceit “I have conquered the goad and the spear,”🔽and he does not understand any reason for doing anything. As the elephant beyond the iron hook does not understand any reason for doing anything because he thinks “I have conquered the goad and the spear,”

original: so accaṅkuso nāgo “jitaṃ me tuttatomara”nti kiñci kāraṇaṃ nappajānāti, evaṃ ahampi🔽lakkhaṇasampannaūrutāya lakkhaṇūruyā sammatto matto pamatto ummatto viya kiñci kāraṇaṃ🔽nappajānāmīti vadati. Atha vā accaṅkusova nāgo ahampi sammatto lakkhaṇūruyā kiñci
analyzed: saḥ accaṅkusaḥ nāgaḥ jitam me tutta tomaranti kiñci kāraṇam na ppajānāti evam aham pi  lakkhaṇa sampanna ūru tāya lakkhaṇa ūruyā sammattaḥ mattaḥ pamattaḥ ummattaḥ viya kiñci kāraṇam  na ppajānāmi iti vadati atha vā accaṅkusaḥ uva nāgaḥ aham pi sammattaḥ kiñci
translated: so I, intoxicated with the conceit “I have conquered the goad and the spear,” do not understand any reason for doing anything.

original: tato virāgakāraṇaṃ nappajānāmi. Kasmā? Yasmā tena nāgena viya jitaṃ me tuttatomaraṃ,
analyzed: tatas virāga kāraṇam na ppajānāmi kasmai yasmā tena nāgena viya jitam me tutta tomaram
translated: Or alternatively, just as the elephant beyond the iron hook does not understand any reason for doing anything because he is intoxicated with the conceit “I have conquered the goad and the spear,” so I, intoxicated with the conceit “I have conquered the goad and the spear,” do not understand any reason for doing anything.🔽And why? Because, like the elephant, I have conquered the goad and the spear.

original: na kassaci vadato vacanaṃ ādiyāmi.
analyzed: na kassaci vadataḥ vacanam ādiyāmi
translated: I do not accept the words of anyone who speaks.

original: Tayi gedhitacittosmīti bhadde lakkhaṇūru tayi baddhacittosmi. Gedhitacittoti vā gedhaṃ
analyzed: tayi gedhita cittaḥ asmi iti bhadde lakkhaṇūru tayi baddha cittaḥ asmi gedhita cittaḥ iti vā gedham
translated: I am infatuated with you, O you of shapely thighs. I am bound by infatuation with you. Infatuated means having a mind that is attached.

original: ajjhupetacitto. Cittaṃ vipariṇāmitanti pakatiṃ jahitvā ṭhitaṃ. Paṭigantuṃ na sakkomīti🔽nivattituṃ na sakkomi. Vaṅkaghastova ambujoti baḷisaṃ gilitvā ṭhitamaccho viya. “Ghaso”tipi pāṭho, ayamevattho.
analyzed: ajjhupeta cittaḥ cittam vipariṇāmitanti pakatim jahitvā ṭhitam paṭigantum na sakkomi iti  nivattitum na sakkomi vaṅka ghastaḥ uva ambujaḥ iti baḷisam gilitvā ṭhitam acchaḥ pāṭhaḥ ayam eva atthaḥ
translated: My mind is changed means having abandoned its natural state, it remains. I am unable to return means I am unable to turn back.🔽Like a bird caught in a snare means like a fish caught and remaining after having swallowed a hook. The reading “ghaso” is the same in meaning.

original: Vāmūrūti vāmākārena saṇṭhitaūru, kadalikkhandhasadisaūrūti vā attho. Sajāti āliṅga.
analyzed: vām ūru iti vāma ākārena saṇṭhita ūru kadali khandha sadisa ūru iti vā attho sajāti āliṅga
translated: O you of shapely thighs means you whose thighs are shaped well. The meaning is: you whose thighs are like the trunk of a plantain tree. O Sajjāti embrace.

original: Mandalocaneti itthiyo na tikhiṇaṃ nijjhāyanti mandaṃ ālocenti olokenti, tasmā “mandalocanā”ti
analyzed: manda locanā iti itthiyaḥ na tikhiṇam nijjhāyanti mandam ālocenti olokenti tasmā manda locanā ati
translated: O you of round eyes means women do not look sharply. They look slowly, they look. Therefore they are called “round-eyed.”

original: vuccanti. Palissajāti sabbatobhāgena āliṅga. Etaṃ me abhipatthitanti etaṃ mayā abhiṇhaṃ patthitaṃ.
analyzed: vuccanti sabbatobhāgena āliṅga etam me abhipatthitam ti etam mayā abhiṇham patthitam
translated: Embrace me means embrace me with your whole body. This is my desire means this is my frequent desire.

original: Appako vata me santoti pakatiyāva mando samāno. Vellitakesiyāti kesā muñcitvā piṭṭhiyaṃ
analyzed: appakaḥ vata me santo ti pakatiyā ava mando samānaḥ vellitakesiyā ati kesāḥ muñcitvā piṭṭhiyam
translated: My desire is small means being naturally slow, it is the same. O you with disheveled hair means having loosened the hair on the back,

original: vissaṭṭhakāle sappo viya vellantā gacchantā assāti vellitakesī, tassā vellitakesiyā.
analyzed: vissaṭṭha kāle sappaḥ viya vellantā gacchantā assa ati vellita kesī tassā vellita kesiyā
translated: He goes about wriggling like a snake when it is time to wriggle, thus he is a wriggler, and he is a wriggler of that kind.🔽He has arisen in many a state, thus he is of many a kind, arisen, or the reading is ‘of many a state’;

original: Anekabhāvo samuppādīti anekavidho jāto. Anekabhāgoti vā pāṭho. Arahanteva dakkhiṇāti🔽arahantamhi dinnadānaṃ viya nānappakārato pabhinno.
analyzed: aneka bhāvo samuppādi iti anekavidhaḥ jātaḥ aneka bhāgo ti vā pāṭhaḥ arahantā iva dakkhiṇāti  arahantamhi dinna dānam viya nānā pakārato pabhinno
translated: The gift given to the Worthy One is distinguished in many a way, as a gift given to the Worthy One is.🔽Whatever merit there is of mine, whatever merit there is of mine that there is,

original: Yaṃ me atthi kataṃ puññanti yaṃ mayā kataṃ puññamatthi. Arahantesu tādisūti tādilakkhaṇappattesu arahantesu. Tayā saddhiṃ vipaccatanti sabbaṃ tayā saddhimeva vipākaṃ detu.🔽Ekodīti ekībhāvaṃ gato. Nipako satoti nepakkaṃ vuccati paññā, tāya samannāgatoti🔽nipako. Satiyā samannāgatattā sato. Amataṃ muni jigīsānoti yathā so buddhamuni amataṃ
analyzed: yam me atthi katam puññanti yam mayā katam puññam atthi arahantesu tādisu iti tādi lakkhaṇa ppattesu arahantesu tayā saddhim sabbam tayā saddhim eva vipākam detu  ekodī iti ekībhāvam gataḥ nipakaḥ satoti nepakkam vuccati paññā tāya samannāgato ti  nipakaḥ satiyā samannāgata ttā sataḥ amatam muni jigīsānaḥ uti yathā saḥ buddha muni amatam
translated: to those Worthy Ones of that kind, to those Worthy Ones who have attained to that description, let it be shared by you, let the entire result be shared by you.

original: nibbānaṃ jigīsati pariyesati, evaṃ taṃ ahaṃ sūriyavacchase jigīsāmi pariyesāmi. Yathā
analyzed: nibbānam jigīsati pariyesati evam tam aham sūriya vacchase jigīsāmi pariyesāmi yathā
translated: Gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity, thus gone to unity

original: vā so amataṃ jigīsāno esanto gavesanto vicarati, evāhaṃ taṃ esanto gavesanto vicarāmītipi attho.
analyzed: vā saḥ amatam jigīsānaḥ esantaḥ gavesantaḥ vicarati eva aham tam esantaḥ gavesantaḥ vicarāmi iti pi
translated: or he who seeks the Deathless, who goes in search of it, who wanders about in quest of it, so too, I am wandering about in quest of it.🔽As a sage would rejoice, having attained the supreme enlightenment,

original: Yathāpi muni nandeyya, patvā sambodhimuttamanti yathā buddhamuni bodhipallaṅke nisinno
analyzed: yathā api muni patvā sambodhim uttamanti yathā buddha muni bodhi pallaṅke nisinnaḥ
translated: just as the Buddha-sage, sitting on the seat of enlightenment,

original: sabbaññutaññāṇaṃ patvā nandeyya toseyya. Evaṃ nandeyyanti evameva ahampi tayā missībhāvaṃ
analyzed: sabbaññu ta ññāṇam patvā nandeyya toseyya evam nandeyyanti evam eva aham pi tayā missībhāvam
translated: having attained omniscient knowledge, would rejoice, would be glad, so too, I would rejoice, having become united with you,

original: gato nandeyyaṃ, pītisomanassajāto bhaveyyanti vadati.
analyzed: gataḥ nandeyyam pīti somanassa jātaḥ bhaveyya nti vadati
translated: I would be full of joy and gladness.🔽I would choose you, O blessed one, as my wife,

original: Tāhaṃ bhadde vareyyāheti aheti āmantanaṃ, ahe bhadde sūriyavacchase, sakkena devānamindena🔽“kiṃ dvīsu devalokesu devarajjaṃ gaṇhasi, suriyavacchasa”nti, evaṃ vare dinne devarajjaṃ
analyzed: tā aham bhadde vareyyā aheti aheti āmantanam ahe bhadde sūriyavacchase sakkena devānamindena  kim dvīsu deva lokesu deva rajjam gaṇhasi evam vare dinne deva rajjam
translated: “O blessed one, O Sun-like Lady, having been asked by Sakka, king of the gods,🔽‘Do you choose to be queen of the two heavenly worlds, O Sun-like Lady?’🔽having been offered the kingship of the gods,

original: pahāya “sūriyavacchasaṃ gaṇhāmī”ti evaṃ taṃ ahaṃ vareyyaṃ iccheyyaṃ gaṇheyyanti attho.
analyzed: pahāya sūriya vat śasam gaṇhāmi iti evam tam aham vareyyam iccheyyam gaṇheyyanti attho
translated: I would choose you, I would wish, I would take you, as my wife, having given up the kingship of the gods.”

original: Sālaṃva na ciraṃ phullanti tava pitu nagaradvāre naciraṃ pupphito sālo atthi. So
analyzed: na ciram phullanti tava pitu nagara dvāre naciram pupphito sālo atthi so
translated: Like the sala tree that blooms not long after flowering,

original: ativiya manoharo. Taṃ naciraṃ phullasālaṃ viya. Pitaraṃ te sumedhaseti atisassirīkaṃ
analyzed: manoharaḥ tam naciram phulla sālam viya pitaram te sumedhasā iti atisassirīkam
translated: and it was exceedingly lovely, like a flowering sāla tree. Your father, O you of great wisdom,

original: tava pitaraṃ vandamāno namassāmi namo karomi. Yassāsetādisī pajāti yassa āsi etādisī dhītā.
analyzed: tava pitaram vandamānaḥ namassāmi namaḥ karomi yassa āsi etādisī pajāti yassa āsi etādisī dhītā
translated: I pay homage to your father, I honour him, I revere him, whose daughter you are, whose child you are.

original: 349. Saṃsandatīti kasmā gītasaddassa ceva vīṇāsaddassa ca vaṇṇaṃ kathesi? Kiṃ tattha
analyzed: saṃsandati iti kasmā gīta saddassa ca iva vīṇā saddassa ca vaṇṇam kathesi kim tattha
translated: Why did he speak in praise of the sound of the song and the sound of the lute? What was his purpose?

original: bhagavato sārāgo atthīti? Natthi. Chaḷaṅgupekkhāya upekkhako bhagavā etādisesu ṭhānesu,
analyzed: bhagavato sārāgaḥ atthi iti natthi chaḷaṅgu pekkhāya upekkhakaḥ bhagavā etādisesu ṭhānesu
translated: Was there any passion in the Exalted One? No, there was not. The Exalted One is impartial towards such things, being indifferent through the six kinds of equanimity.

original: kevalaṃ iṭṭhāniṭṭhaṃ jānāti, na tattha rajjati. Vuttampi cetaṃ “saṃvijjati kho, āvuso,
analyzed: kevalam iṭṭha aniṭṭham jānāti na tattha rajjati vuttam pi ca itam saṃvijjati kho āvuso
translated: He knows what is desirable and undesirable, but he is not attached to it. For this is said:

original: bhagavato cakkhu, passati bhagavā cakkhunā rūpaṃ, chandarāgo bhagavato natthi, suvimuttacitto
analyzed: bhagavato cakkhu passati bhagavā cakkhunā rūpam chanda rāgaḥ bhagavataḥ natthi su vimutta cittaḥ
translated: “Friend, the Exalted One has eyes; he sees with his eyes. He has no desire and lust. His mind is well liberated.

original: bhagavā. Saṃvijjati kho, āvuso, bhagavato sota”ntiādi. Sace pana vaṇṇaṃ na katheyya,
analyzed: bhagavā saṃvijjati kho āvuso bhagavato sota nti ādi sace pana vaṇṇam na katheyya
translated: He has ears; he hears with his ears. He has a nose; he smells with his nose. He has a tongue; he tastes with his tongue. He has a body; he feels with his body. He has a mind; he cognizes with his mind. He has no desire and lust. His mind is well liberated.”

original: pañcasikho “okāso me kato”ti na jāneyya. Atha sakko “bhagavatā pañcasikhassa okāso
analyzed: pañcasikhaḥ okāsaḥ me kataḥ iti na jāneyya atha sakkaḥ bhagavatā pañcasikhassa okāsaḥ
translated: But if he had not spoken in praise, Pañcasikha would not have known that he had been given an opportunity.

original: na kato”ti devatā gahetvā tatova paṭinivatteyya, tato mahājāniyo bhaveyya. Vaṇṇe
analyzed: na devatāḥ gahetvā tatas uva paṭinivatteyya tatas mahā jāniyaḥ bhaveyya vaṇṇe
translated: and if the deity were to seize him and turn him back from there, then there would be a great disaster.

original: pana kathite “kato bhagavatā pañcasikhassa okāso”ti devatāhi saddhiṃ upasaṅkamitvā
analyzed: pana kathite kataḥ bhagavatā pañcasikhassa okāsaḥ ti devatāhi saddhim upasaṅkamitvā
translated: and if he were to turn back from there, there would be a great loss. But when the praise was spoken, the deities would come with the thought, “The opportunity has been made by the Blessed One for Pañcasikha,”🔽and after approaching, he would ask a question and when it was answered,

original: pañhaṃ pucchitvā vissajjanāvasāne asītiyā devatāsahassehi saddhiṃ sotāpattiphale
analyzed: pañham pucchitvā vissajjana avasāne asītiyā devatā sahassehi saddhim sotāpatti phale
translated: he would establish eighty-four thousand deities in the fruit of stream-entry.

original: patiṭṭhahissatīti ñatvā vaṇṇaṃ kathesi.
analyzed: patiṭṭhahissati iti ñatvā vaṇṇam kathesi
translated: Knowing this, the Blessed One spoke the praise.

original: Tattha kadā saṃyūḷhāti kadā ganthitā piṇḍitā. Tena kho panāhaṃ, bhante, samayenāti
analyzed: tattha kadā saṃyūḍhā ati kadā ganthitā piṇḍitā tena kho pana aham bhante samayena ati
translated: Herein, when was it composed? When was it bound together and collected?

original: tena samayena tasmiṃ tumhākaṃ sambodhippattito paṭṭhāya aṭṭhame sattāhe. Bhaddā nāma
analyzed: tena samayena tasmin tumhākam sambodhi ppattitaḥ paṭṭhāya aṭṭhame sattāhe bhaddā nāma
translated: At that time, venerable sir, means at that time, in the eighth week after the Blessed One’s enlightenment. Bhaddā by name means she was called Bhaddā.🔽Sunīdha’s daughter means she was the daughter of Sunīdha.

original: sūriyavacchasāti nāmato bhaddā sarīrasampattiyā sūriyavacchasā. Bhaginīti vohāravacanametaṃ,🔽devadhītāti attho. Parakāminīti paraṃ kāmeti abhikaṅkhati.
analyzed: sūriyavacchasā ati nāmataḥ bhaddā sarīra sampattiyā sūriyavacchasā bhaginī iti vohāra vacanam etam  deva dhītā ati para kāminī iti param kāmeti abhikaṅkhati
translated: A sister means this is a term of address.🔽A deity’s daughter is the meaning.🔽She desired another means she desired, she longed for, another.

original: Upanaccantiyāti naccamānāya. Sā kira ekasmiṃ samaye cātumahārājikadevehi saddhiṃ
analyzed: upanaccantiyā ati naccamānāya sā kira ekasmin samaye cātumahārājika devehi saddhim
translated: She was dancing means she was dancing, it seems. On one occasion, it seems, she was dancing with the deities of the Cātumahārājika heaven.

original: sakkassa devarājassa naccaṃ dassanatthāya gatā, tasmiñca khaṇe sakko tathāgatassa
analyzed: sakkassa devarājassa naccam dassana tthāya gatā tasmin ca khaṇe sakko tathāgatassa
translated: and had gone to see the dancing of Sakka, King of the Gods, and at that time Sakka,

original: aṭṭha yathābhucce guṇe payirudāhāsi. Evaṃ tasmiṃ divase gantvā naccantī assosi.
analyzed: yathābhucce guṇe evam tasmin divase gantvā naccantī assosi
translated: and had gone to see Sakka, King of the Gods, dancing. And at that moment Sakka extolled the eight proper qualities of the Tathāgata. Thus she went on that day and heard them dancing.

original: Sakkūpasaṅkamavaṇṇanā🔽350. Paṭisammodatīti “saṃsandati kho te”tiādīni vadanto bhagavā sammodati, pañcasikho
analyzed: sakkūpasaṅkama vaṇṇanā  paṭisammodati iti saṃsandati kho te iti ādīni vadantaḥ bhagavā sammodati pañcasikho
translated: The Description of the Approach to Sakka🔽“He exchanged greetings with him”: the Blessed One exchanged greetings by saying, “You are looking healthy, friend,” etc., and Pañcasikha exchanged greetings by saying, “The Blessed One is looking healthy, venerable sir,” etc.

original: paṭisammodati. Gāthā ca bhāsanto pañcasikho sammodati, bhagavā paṭisammodati. Āmantesīti
analyzed: paṭisammodati gāthā ca bhāsanto pañcasikho sammodati bhagavā paṭisammodati āmantesi iti
translated: “And he spoke this verse”: Pañcasikha spoke the verse by saying, “The Blessed One has the thirty-two …” , and the Blessed One spoke the verse by saying, “The wise one has the thirty-two …” .

original: jānāpesi. Tassa kirevaṃ ahosi “ayaṃ pañcasikho mayā mama kammena pesito attano kammaṃ
analyzed: tassa kira evam ahosi ayam pañcasikho mayā mama kammena pesitaḥ attano kammaṃ
translated: “He addressed him”: he made him understand. He thought, “This Pañcasikha, sent by me on my business, is doing his own business.

original: karoti. Evarūpassa satthu santike ṭhatvā kāmaguṇūpasañhitaṃ ananucchavikaṃ kathesi,
analyzed: karoti evarūpassa satthu santike ṭhatvā kāma guṇa upasañhitam ananucchavikam kathesi
translated: Standing in the presence of a teacher like this, he is talking an improper talk connected with the strands of sensual desire.

original: naṭā nāma nillajjā honti, kathento vippakārampi dasseyya, handa naṃ mama kammaṃ jānāpemī”ti cintetvā āmantesi.
analyzed: naṭāḥ nāma nillajjāḥ honti kathentaḥ vippakāram pi dasseyya handa nam mama kammam jānāpemi iti cintetvā āmantesi
translated: Actors are shameless. While talking, he might show his displeasure. Let me make him understand my business.” Thinking thus, he addressed him.

original: 351. Evañca pana tathāgatāti dhammasaṅgāhakattherehi ṭhapitavacanaṃ. Abhivadantīti abhivādanasampaṭicchanena vaḍḍhitavacanena vadanti. Abhivaditoti vaḍḍhitavacanena vutto.
analyzed: evam ca pana tathāgatā ati dhamma saṅgāhaka ttherehi ṭhapita vacanam abhivadanti iti abhivādana sampaṭicchanena vaḍḍhita vacanena vadanti abhivaditaḥ iti vaḍḍhita vacanena vuttaḥ
translated: And thus the words “thus-gone” were established by the Dhamma-reciters. “They greeted him”: they spoke with the greeting and with the words of welcome. “He was greeted”: he was spoken to with the words of welcome.

original: Urundā samapādīti mahantā vivaṭā ahosi, andhakāro guhāyaṃ antaradhāyi. Āloko udapādīti
analyzed: urundā samapādi iti mahantā vivaṭā ahosi andhakāraḥ guhā ayam antaradhāyi ālokaḥ udapādi iti
translated: “The cave was filled with light”: it became great and open; the darkness in the cave disappeared. “There was light”:

original: yo pakatiyā guhāyaṃ andhakāro, so antarahito, āloko jāto. Sabbametaṃ dhammasaṅgāhakānaṃ vacanaṃ.
analyzed: yaḥ pakatiyā guhā ayam andhakāraḥ so antarahitaḥ ālokaḥ jātaḥ sabbam etam dhamma saṅgāhakānam vacanam
translated: the darkness that was in the cave by nature disappeared, and light arose. All this is the words of the Dhamma-reciters.

original: 352. Cirapaṭikāhaṃ, bhanteti cirato ahaṃ, cirato paṭṭhāyāhaṃ dassanakāmoti attho.🔽Kehici kehici kiccakaraṇīyehīti devānaṃ dhītā ca puttā ca aṅke nibbattanti, pādaparicārikā🔽itthiyo sayane nibbattanti, tāsaṃ maṇḍanapasādhanakārikā devatā sayanaṃ parivāretvā
analyzed: cirapaṭikā aham bhante ti ciratas aham ciratas paṭṭhāya aham dassana kāmo ti attho  kehici kehici kicca karaṇīyehi iti devānam dhītā ca puttā ca aṅke nibbattanti pāda paricārikā  itthiyaḥ sayane nibbattanti tāsam maṇḍana pasādhana kārikā devatā sayanam parivāretvā
translated: “For a long time, venerable sir”: for a long time, for a long period, I have been desirous of seeing him.🔽“In the performance of various duties”: the daughters and sons of the gods are conceived in the laps of their parents;🔽the female attendants are conceived in the bed;

original: nibbattanti, veyyāvaccakarā antovimāne nibbattanti, etesaṃ atthāya aḍḍakaraṇaṃ nāma
analyzed: nibbattanti veyyāvacca karāḥ antovimāne nibbattanti etesam atthāya aḍḍakaraṇam nāma
translated: the deities who are their adorners and beautifiers are conceived surrounding the bed; the servants are conceived inside the mansion. For their sake the gods make a proclamation:🔽“

original: natthi. Ye pana sīmantare nibbattanti, te “tava santakā, mama santakā”ti nicchetuṃ
analyzed: natthi ye pana sīmantare nibbattanti te tava santakāḥ mama santakāḥ iti nicchetum
translated: There is none. But those who are reborn on the border of the two realms cannot decide, “This is yours, this is mine.”

original: asakkontā aḍḍaṃ karonti, sakkaṃ devarājānaṃ pucchanti. So “yassa vimānaṃ āsannataraṃ,
analyzed: a sakkontāḥ aḍḍam karonti sakkam devarājānam pucchanti saḥ yassa vimānam āsannataram
translated: They quarrel and ask Sakka, king of the gods, to settle the dispute. He says, “They belong to the one whose mansion is nearer.”

original: tassa santakā”ti vadati. Sace dvepi samaṭṭhāne honti, “yassa vimānaṃ olokentī ṭhitā,🔽tassa santakā”ti vadati. Sace ekampi na oloketi, taṃ ubhinnaṃ kalahupacchedanatthaṃ
analyzed: tassa santakā iti vadati sace dve pi samaṭṭhāne honti yassa vimānam olokentī ṭhitā  tassa vadati sace ekam pi na oloketi tam ubhinnam kalaha upacchedana ttham
translated: If the two mansions are at the same distance, he says, “They belong to the one who is standing looking at the mansion.”🔽If she is not looking at either, he makes them his own in order to settle the dispute.

original: attano santakaṃ karoti. Kīḷādīnipi kiccāni karaṇīyāneva. Evarūpāni tāni karaṇīyāni
analyzed: santakam karoti kīḷa ādīni pi kiccāni evarūpāni tāni karaṇīyāni
translated: The same applies to the games, etc.

original: sandhāya “kehici kehici kiccakaraṇīyehī”ti āha.
analyzed: sandhāya kehici kehici kicca karaṇīyehi iti āha
translated: It is with such duties in mind that the Exalted One says, “in some places with duties to be done.”

original: Salaḷāgāraketi salaḷamayagandhakuṭiyaṃ. Aññatarena samādhināti tadā kira bhagavā
analyzed: salaḷa āgāraka iti salaḷa maya gandha kuṭiyam aññatarena samādhinā ati tadā kira bhagavā
translated: In a fragrant chamber made of salaḷ wood: in a fragrant chamber made of salaḷ wood. With another concentration: it seems that at that time the Exalted One,

original: sakkasseva aparipākagataṃ ñāṇaṃ viditvā okāsaṃ akāretukāmo phalasamāpattivihārena
analyzed: sakkassa iva a paripāka gatam ñāṇam viditvā okāsam a kāretu kāmo phala samāpatti vihārena
translated: knowing that Sakka’s knowledge was not yet fully matured, wished to give him an opportunity to attain it. Therefore he entered into the abiding of the fruition attainment.

original: nisīdi. Taṃ esa ajānanto “aññatarena samādhinā”ti āha. Bhūjati ca nāmāti bhūjatīti
analyzed: tam esa a jānantaḥ aññatarena samādhinā ati āha bhūjati ca nāma ati bhūjatī iti
translated: not knowing this, he said “with some other concentration.”🔽

original: tassā nāmaṃ. Paricārikāti pādaparicārikā devadhītā. Sā kira dve phalāni pattā, tenassā🔽devaloke abhiratiyeva natthi. Niccaṃ bhagavato upaṭṭhānaṃ āgantvā añjaliṃ sirasi
analyzed: tassāḥ nāmam paricārikā ati pāda paricārikā deva dhītā sā kira dve phalāni pattā tena assā  deva loke abhiratiyā iva natthi niccam bhagavataḥ upaṭṭhānam āgantvā añjalim sirasi
translated: not knowing this, he said, “with some other concentration.” Bhūjati is her name. She is a devatā who attends on the Buddha’s feet. It is said that she has received two fruits, and so

original: ṭhapetvā bhagavantaṃ namassamānā tiṭṭhati. Nemisaddena tamhā samādhimhā vuṭṭhitoti
analyzed: ṭhapetvā bhagavantam namassamānā tiṭṭhati nemi saddena tamhā samādhimhā vuṭṭhitā ti
translated: she has no delight in the deva world. She always comes to attend on the Buddha, and she stands there worshipping the Buddha by placing her hands together above her head. He arose from that concentration because of the sound of the wheel-gem.

original: “samāpanno saddaṃ suṇātī”ti no vata re vattabbe, nanu bhagavā sakkassa devānamindassa
analyzed: samāpannaḥ saddam suṇāti iti no vata re vattabbe nanu bhagavā sakkassa devānamindassa
translated: “It is not right to say that one who has attained concentration hears a sound. But did not the Buddha say to Sakka, the lord of the devas,

original: “apicāhaṃ āyasmato cakkanemisaddena tamhā samādhimhā vuṭṭhito”ti bhaṇatīti. Tiṭṭhatu🔽nemisaddo, samāpanno nāma antosamāpattiyaṃ kaṇṇamūle dhamamānassa saṅkhayugaḷassāpi
analyzed: apica aham āyasmataḥ cakkanemi saddena tamhā samādhimhā vuṭṭhitaḥ iti bhaṇati iti tiṭṭhatu  nemi saddo samāpannaḥ nāma antosamāpattiyam kaṇṇa mūle dhamamānassa saṅkha yugaḷassa api
translated: ‘I arose from that concentration because of the sound of your wheel-gem’? Let alone the sound of the wheel-gem,

original: asanisannipātassāpi saddaṃ na suṇāti. Bhagavā pana “ettakaṃ kālaṃ sakkassa okāsaṃ
analyzed: asani sannipātassa api saddam na suṇāti bhagavā pana ettakam kālam sakkassa okāsam
translated: one who has attained concentration does not hear the sound of a pair of conches blown at the ear or the sound of a pair of cymbals clashed right next to the ear. But the Buddha said, ‘I arose from that concentration because of the sound of Sakka’s wheel-gem.’

original: na karissāmī”ti paricchinditvā kālavasena phalasamāpattiṃ samāpanno. Sakko “na dāni🔽me satthā okāsaṃ karotī”ti gandhakuṭiṃ padakkhiṇaṃ katvā rathaṃ nivattetvā devalokābhimukhaṃ
analyzed: na karissāmi iti paricchinditvā kāla vasena phala samāpattim samāpannaḥ sakkaḥ na dāni  me satthā okāsam karoti iti gandhakuṭim padakkhiṇam katvā ratham nivattetvā deva loka abhimukham
translated: and he entered upon the fruition attainment of the path of arahantship for the period of a watch of the night. Sakka thought, “My teacher will not give me an opportunity now,” and he circumambulated the Perfumed Cell, turned his chariot around, and went back to the Tāvatiṃsa heaven.

original: pesesi. Gandhakuṭipariveṇaṃ rathasaddena samohitaṃ pañcaṅgikatūriyaṃ viya ahosi.
analyzed: pesesi gandha kuṭi pariveṇam ratha saddena samohitam pañcaṅgika tūriyam viya ahosi
translated: and he entered upon the fruition attainment for the time being. Sakka thought, “My Master does not give me an opportunity now,” and he circumambulated the Perfumed Cell keeping it to his right, turned back, and sent the chariot on its way back to the world of the gods. The Perfumed Cell’s courtyard resounded with the sound of the chariot as if with the sound of a five-piece orchestra.

original: Bhagavato yathāparicchinnakālavasena samāpattito vuṭṭhitassa rathasaddeneva paṭhamāvajjanaṃ
analyzed: bhagavataḥ yathā paricchinna kāla vasena samāpattitaḥ vuṭṭhitassa ratha saddena iva paṭhama āvajjanam
translated: The Blessed One emerged from his attainment at the time he had determined, and the sound of the chariot was the first thing he became aware of.

original: uppajji, tasmā evamāha.
analyzed: tasmai evam āha
translated: This is why he said, “Sakka has turned back.”

original: Gopakavatthuvaṇṇanā🔽353. Sīlesu paripūrakārinīti pañcasu sīlesu paripūrakārinī. Itthittaṃ virājetvāti🔽itthittaṃ nāma alaṃ, na hi itthitte ṭhatvā cakkavattisiriṃ, na sakkamārabrahmasiriyo
analyzed: gopaka vatthu vaṇṇanā  sīlesu paripūra kārinī iti pañcasu sīlesu paripūra kārinī itthittam virājetvā ati  itthittam nāma alam na hi itthitte cakkavatti sirim na
translated: The Story of Gopaka

original: paccanubhavituṃ, na paccekabodhiṃ, na sammāsambodhiṃ gantuṃ sakkāti evaṃ itthittaṃ
analyzed: paccanubhavitum na paccekabodhim na sammāsambodhim gantum sakkā ati evam itthittam
translated: “One who has fulfilled virtue”: one who has fulfilled the five kinds of virtue. “Having lost interest in being a woman”: the state of being a woman is called “woman’s state.” One who has lost interest in that thinks, “It is no good being a woman. For by remaining a woman one cannot enjoy the glory of a Wheel-turning Monarch, the glory of Sakka, the glory of Maara, the glory of Brahmā, the enlightenment of a Paccekabuddha, or the supreme perfect enlightenment. ” So she loses interest in being a woman.

original: virājeti nāma. Mahantamidaṃ purisattaṃ nāma seṭṭhaṃ uttamaṃ, ettha ṭhatvā sakkā etā
analyzed: virājā iti nāma mahantam idam purisattam nāma seṭṭham uttamam ettha ṭhatvā sakkā etā
translated: Virājeti nāma. Mahantamidaṃ purisattaṃ nāma seṭṭhaṃ uttamaṃ, ettha ṭhatvā sakkā etā

original: sampattiyo pāpuṇitunti evaṃ pana purisattaṃ bhāveti nāma. Sāpi evamakāsi. Tena vuttaṃ
analyzed: sampattiyaḥ pāpuṇitunti evam pana purisa ttam bhāveti nāma sā api evam akāsi tena vuttam
translated: sampattiyo pāpuṇitunti evaṃ pana purisattaṃ bhāveti nāma. Sāpi evamakāsi. Tena vuttaṃ

original: – “itthittaṃ virājetvā purisattaṃ bhāvetvā”ti. Hīnaṃ gandhabbakāyanti hīnaṃ lāmakaṃ
analyzed: itthittam virājetvā purisattam bhāvetvā ati hīnam gandhabbakāyanti hīnam lāmakam
translated: – “itthittaṃ virājetvā purisattaṃ bhāvetvā”ti. Hīnaṃ gandhabbakāyanti hīnaṃ lāmakaṃ

original: gandhabbanikāyaṃ. Kasmā pana te parisuddhasīlā tattha uppannāti? Pubbanikantiyā.
analyzed: gandhabbanikāyam kasmā pana te parisuddha sīlā tattha uppannā ati pubba nikantiyā
translated: gandhabbanikāyaṃ. Kasmā pana te parisuddhasīlā tattha uppannāti? Pubbanikantiyā.

original: Pubbepi kira nesaṃ etadeva vasitaṭṭhānaṃ, tasmā nikantivasena tattha uppannā. Upaṭṭhānanti
analyzed: pubbe pi kira nesam etat eva vasita ṭṭhānam tasmā nikanti vasena tattha uppannā upaṭṭhānan ti
translated: Pubbepi kira nesaṃ etadeva vasitaṭṭhānaṃ, tasmā nikantivasena tattha uppannā. Upaṭṭhānanti

original: upaṭṭhānasālaṃ. Pāricariyanti paricaraṇabhāvaṃ. Gītavāditehi amhe paricarissāmāti āgacchanti.

analyzed: guṇehi samannāgatāḥ honti na tattha kim kaṅkhati koci sāvako ti kim tattha tesu sāvakesu  koci eka sāvakaḥ api buddha ādīsu vā cātuddisa bhāve vā na kaṅkhati sabba disāsu a sajjamānaḥ
translated: virtues. No disciple has any doubt here: no disciple has any doubt here🔽about the Master, the Dispensation, the Community, or the fourfold assembly. He abides unattached, unhindered, regarding all existents.

original: agayhamāno viharatī”ti. Idāni bhagavato vaṇṇaṃ bhaṇanto “nitiṇṇaoghaṃ vicikicchachinnaṃ,
analyzed: a gayhamānaḥ viharati iti idāni bhagavataḥ vaṇṇam bhaṇantaḥ nitiṇṇa ogham vicikiccha chinnam
translated: Now, praising the Blessed One, he said: “The flood-free, doubt-free,

original: buddhaṃ namassāma jinaṃ janinda”nti āha. Tattha vicikicchachinnanti chinnavicikicchaṃ.
analyzed: buddham namassāma jinam janindanti āha tattha vicikiccha chinnam ti chinna vicikiccham
translated: We honour the Buddha, the Victor, the Lord of men.” Herein, doubt-free means free from doubt.

original: Janindanti sabbalokuttamaṃ.🔽Yaṃ te dhammanti yaṃ tava dhammaṃ. Ajjhagaṃsu teti te devaputtā adhigatā. Kāyaṃ brahmapurohitanti
analyzed: janindanti sabba lokuttamam  yam te dhammanti yam tava dhammam ajjhagaṃsu te iti te deva puttāḥ adhigatā kāyam brahma purohitanti
translated: Lord of men means best of all the world.🔽They have reached your Dhamma: those deities have attained your Dhamma. The body of the Brahma-priest:

original: amhākaṃ passantānaṃyeva brahmapurohitasarīraṃ. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – yaṃ tava dhammaṃ
analyzed: amhākam passantānam yeva brahma purohita sarīram idam vuttam hoti yam tava dhammaṃ
translated: while we are looking on. This is what is said: they have reached your Dhamma.

original: jānitvā tesaṃ tiṇṇaṃ janānaṃ te dve visesagū amhākaṃ passantānaṃyeva kāyaṃ brahmapurohitaṃ
analyzed: jānitvā tesam tiṇṇam janānam te dve visesagū amhākam passantānam yeva kāyam brahma purohitam
translated: and knowing that these three had attained the distinction of the Brahma-world,

original: adhigantvā maggaphalavisesaṃ ajjhagaṃsu, mayampi tassa dhammassa pattiyā āgatamhāsi
analyzed: adhigantvā magga phala visesam mayam pi tassa dhammassa pattiyā āgatamhā asi
translated: and had attained the distinction of the path and fruit, we have come, good sir,

original: mārisāti. Āgatamhaseti sampattamha. Katāvakāsā bhagavatā, pañhaṃ pucchemu mārisāti
analyzed: mārisa ati kata avakāsāḥ bhagavatā pañham pucchemu mārisa ati
translated: to attain that state.” “You have come, good sir,” means “we have arrived.” “Having been given an opportunity by the Fortunate One, we will ask a question, good sir,”

original: sace no bhagavā okāsaṃ karoti, atha bhagavatā katāvakāsā hutvā pañhaṃ, mārisa, puccheyyāmāti attho.
analyzed: sace naḥ bhagavā okāsam karoti atha bhagavatā kata avakāsāḥ hutvā pañham mārisa puccheyyāma ati attho
translated: means “if the Fortunate One gives us an opportunity, then having been given an opportunity by the Fortunate One, we will ask a question.”

original: Maghamāṇavavatthu
analyzed: magha māṇava vatthu
translated: The Story of the Young Man Magha

original: 355. Dīgharattaṃ visuddho kho ayaṃ yakkhoti cirakālato pabhuti visuddho. Kīva cirakālato?
analyzed: dīgharattam visuddhaḥ kho ayam yakkho ti cira kālataḥ visuddhaḥ kīva cira kālataḥ
translated: “For a long time purified” means “for a long time pure.” How long?

original: Anuppanne buddhe magadharaṭṭhe macalagāmake maghamāṇavakālato paṭṭhāya. Tadā kiresa
analyzed: anuppanne buddhe magadha raṭṭhe macalagāmake magha māṇava kālataḥ paṭṭhāya tadā kiresa
translated: From the time of the young man Magha in the Magadha village of Macala before the Buddha arose. At that time he was a young man

original: ekadivasaṃ kālasseva vuṭṭhāya gāmamajjhe manussānaṃ gāmakammakaraṇaṭṭhānaṃ gantvā
analyzed: eka divasam kālassa iva vuṭṭhāya gāma majjhe manussānam gāma kamma karaṇa ṭhānam gantvā
translated: who one day, having risen early, went to the place where people were doing village work in the middle of the village, and having seen

original: attano ṭhitaṭṭhānaṃ pādanteneva paṃsukacavaraṃ apanetvā ramaṇīyamakāsi, añño āgantvā🔽tattha aṭṭhāsi. So tāvatakeneva satiṃ paṭilabhitvā majjhe gāmassa khalamaṇḍalamattaṃ🔽ṭhānaṃ sodhetvā vālukaṃ okiritvā dārūni āharitvā sītakāle aggiṃ karoti, daharā ca
analyzed: attanaḥ ṭhita ṭṭhānam pāda antena iva paṃsuka cavaram apanetvā ramaṇīyam akāsi aññaḥ āgantvā  tattha aṭṭhāsi saḥ tāvatakena iva satim paṭilabhitvā majjhe gāmassa khala maṇḍala mattam  ṭhānam sodhetvā vālukam okiritvā dārūni āharitvā sīta kāle aggim karoti daharā ca
translated: He removed the dust and dirt with the edge of his foot, and made it pleasant. Another came and stood there.

original: mahallakā ca āgantvā tattha nisīdanti.
analyzed: ca āgantvā tattha nisīdanti
translated: He obtained mindfulness just by that much. In the middle of the village he cleaned a place the size of a threshing floor, sprinkled sand, brought wood, and made a fire in cold weather. Young and old came and sat there.

original: Athassa ekadivasaṃ etadahosi – “mayaṃ nagaraṃ gantvā rājarājamahāmattādayo passāma,
analyzed: athassa eka divasam mayam nagaram gantvā rāja rāja mahāmatta ādayo passāma
translated: Then one day he thought, “We go to the city and see kings, ministers, and so on.

original: imesupi candimasūriyesu ‘cando nāma devaputto, sūriyo nāma devaputto’ti vadanti.🔽Kiṃ nu kho katvā ete etā sampattiyo adhigatā”ti? Tato “nāññaṃ kiñci, puññakammameva
analyzed: imesu pi candima sūriyesu candaḥ nāma deva putto sūriyaḥ nāma deva putto ti vadanti  kim nu kho katvā ete etāḥ sampattiyaḥ adhigatāḥ ati tatas na aññam kiñci puñña kammam eva
translated: They say that the moon and the sun are gods named Canda and Suriya.🔽What did they do to attain these riches?” Then he thought, “They did nothing else, but only meritorious deeds.

original: katvā”ti cintetvā “mayāpi evaṃvidhasampattidāyakaṃ puññakammameva kattabba”nti cintesi.
analyzed: katvā iti cintetvā mayā api evaṃvidha sampatti dāyakam puñña kammam eva kattabban ti cintesi
translated: I too must do meritorious deeds that give such riches.”

original: So kālasseva vuṭṭhāya yāguṃ pivitvā vāsipharasukudālamusalahattho catumahāpathaṃ🔽gantvā musalena pāsāṇe uccāletvā pavaṭṭeti, yānānaṃ akkhapaṭighātarukkhe harati,
analyzed: saḥ kālassa iva vuṭṭhāya yāgum pivitvā catu mahāpatham  gantvā musalena pāsāṇe uccāletvā pavaṭṭeti yānānam akkha paṭighāta rukkhe harati
translated: He rose early, drank rice gruel, and taking his spade, his basket, and his axe, went to the cross roads.

original: visamaṃ samaṃ karoti, catumahāpathe sālaṃ karoti, pokkharaṇiṃ khaṇati, setuṃ bandhati,
analyzed: visamam samam karoti catu mahāpathe sālam karoti pokkharaṇim khaṇati setum bandhati
translated: He dug up the stones, levelled the uneven places, planted sāla trees at the cross roads, dug tanks, and built bridges.

original: evaṃ divasaṃ kammaṃ katvā atthaṅgate sūriye gharaṃ eti. Taṃ añño pucchi – “bho, magha,
analyzed: evam divasam kammam katvā atthaṅgate sūriye gharam eti tam añño pucchi bho magha
translated: After working all day in this way, he returned home at sunset. Another man asked him, “Magha,

original: tvaṃ pātova nikkhamitvā sāyaṃ araññato esi, kiṃ kammaṃ karosī”ti? Puññakammaṃ karomi.
analyzed: tvam pātova nikkhamitvā sāyam araññataḥ esi kim kammam karosi iti puñña kammam karomi
translated: you leave home early in the morning and return from the forest in the evening. What work do you do?” “I do meritorious work.”

original: Saggagāmimaggaṃ sodhemīti. Kimidaṃ, bho, puññaṃ nāmāti? Tvaṃ na jānāsīti? Āma, na
analyzed: sagga gāmi maggam sodhemi iti kim idam bho puññam nāma ati tvam na jānāsi iti āma na
translated: “I am clearing the path to heaven.” “What is this thing called merit?” “You don’t know?” “Yes, I don’t know.”

original: jānāmīti. Nagaraṃ gatakāle diṭṭhapubbā te rājarājamahāmattādayoti? Āma, diṭṭhapubbāti.
analyzed: jānāmi iti nagaram gata kāle diṭṭha pubbā te rāja rāja mahāmatta ādayo ti āma diṭṭha pubbā ati
translated: “Have you ever seen kings, royal ministers, and others in the city?” “Yes, I have seen them.”

original: Puññakammaṃ katvā tehi taṃ ṭhānaṃ laddhaṃ, ahampi evaṃvidhasampattidāyakaṃ kammaṃ
analyzed: puñña kammam katvā tehi tam ṭhānam laddham aham pi evaṃvidha sampatti dāyakam kammaṃ
translated: “They have attained that position by doing meritorious deeds. I too will do such deeds, which give such great rewards.”

original: karomi. “Cando nāma devaputto, sūriyo nāma devaputto”ti sutapubbaṃ tayāti? Āma sutapubbanti.
analyzed: karomi candaḥ nāma deva putto sūriyaḥ nāma deva putto ti suta pubbam tayā ati āma suta pubbam ti
translated: “Have you ever heard of the god Canda and the god Suriya?” “Yes, I have heard of them.”

original: Etassa saggassa gamanamaggaṃ ahaṃ sodhemīti. Idaṃ pana puññakammaṃ kiṃ taveva vaṭṭati,
analyzed: etassa saggassa gamana maggam aham sodhemi iti idam pana puñña kammam kim tava iva vaṭṭati
translated: “I am clearing the way to heaven for them.” “But is this meritorious deed yours alone?

original: aññassa na vaṭṭatīti? Na kassacetaṃ vāritanti. Yadi evaṃ sve araññaṃ gamanakāle mayhampi
analyzed: aññassa na vaṭṭati iti na kassaci itam vāritan ti yadi evam sve araññam gamana kāle mayham pi
translated: Is it not also that of others?” “It is not denied to anyone.” “If that is so, then tomorrow when you go to the forest,

original: saddaṃ dehīti. Punadivase taṃ gahetvā gato, evaṃ tasmiṃ gāme tettiṃsa manussā taruṇavayā
analyzed: saddam dehi iti puna divase tam gahetvā gataḥ evam tasmin gāme tettiṃsa manussā taruṇa vayā
translated: give me also a share in it.” The next day he took him with him, and in this way thirty-three men of the village, young and old,

original: sabbe tasseva anuvattakā ahesuṃ. Te ekacchandā hutvā puññakammāni karontā vicaranti.
analyzed: sabbe tassa iva anuvattakāḥ ahesum te ekacchandāḥ hutvā puñña kammāni karontā vicaranti
translated: all became his followers. They all went about doing meritorious deeds, acting in concert.

original: Yaṃ disaṃ gacchanti, maggaṃ samaṃ karontā ekadivaseneva karonti, pokkharaṇiṃ khaṇantā,
analyzed: yam disam gacchanti maggam samam karontāḥ eka divasena iva karonti pokkharaṇim khaṇantā
translated: Wherever they went, they made the road smooth, and in one day they would do the work of a month. They dug tanks,

original: sālaṃ karontā, setuṃ bandhantā ekadivaseneva niṭṭhāpenti.
analyzed: sālam karontā setum bandhantā eka divasena iva niṭṭhāpenti
translated: planted groves, and built bridges, and in one day they would finish the work of a month.

original: Atha nesaṃ gāmabhojako cintesi – “ahaṃ pubbe etesu suraṃ pivantesu pāṇaghātādīni
analyzed: atha nesam gāma bhojakaḥ cintesi aham pubbe etesu suram pivantesu pāṇa ghāta ādīni
translated: Then the village headman thought to himself, “Formerly these men drank strong drink, took life, and did other evil deeds.

original: karontesu ca kahāpaṇādivasena ceva daṇḍabalivasena ca dhanaṃ labhāmi. Idāni etesaṃ🔽puññakaraṇakālato paṭṭhāya ettako āyo natthi, handa ne rājakule paribhindāmī”ti rājānaṃ🔽upasaṅkamitvā core, mahārāja, passāmīti. Kuhiṃ, tātāti? Mayhaṃ gāmeti. Kiṃ corā nāma,🔽tātāti? Rājāparādhikā devāti. Kiṃ jātikāti? Gahapatijātikā devāti. Gahapatikā kiṃ
analyzed: ca ca dhanam labhāmi idāni  puñña karaṇa kālataḥ paṭṭhāya ettakaḥ āyaḥ natthi handa ne rāja kule paribhindāmi iti rājānam  upasaṅkamitvā core mahā rāja passāmi iti kuhim tāta ati mayham gāma iti kim corāḥ nāma  tāta ati rāja aparādhikā deva ati kim jātikā ati gahapati jātikā deva ati gahapatikā kim
translated: “While they were doing this, I got money from them in the form of kahāpaṇas and so on, and in the form of fines and forced labor. Now that they are doing meritorious deeds, I get no such income. Well, I’ll denounce them to the king.” He went to the king and said, “Your Majesty, I see thieves.” “Where, my dear?” “In my village.” “What are they like?” “They’ve offended the king, Your Majesty.” “What’s their caste?” “They’re householders, Your Majesty.” “What are householders?”

original: karissanti, tayā jānamānena kasmā mayhaṃ na kathitanti? Bhayena, mahārāja, na kathemi,🔽idāni mā mayhaṃ dosaṃ kareyyāthāti. Atha rājā “ayaṃ mayhaṃ mahāravaṃ ravatī”ti saddahitvā🔽“tena hi gaccha, tvameva ne ānehī”ti balaṃ datvā pesesi. So gantvā divasaṃ araññe🔽kammaṃ katvā sāyamāsaṃ bhuñjitvā gāmamajjhe nisīditvā “sve kiṃ kammaṃ karissāma,
analyzed: karissanti tayā jānamānena kasmai mayham na bhayena mahā rāja na kathemi 🔽idāni mā mayham dosam kareyyātha ati atha rājā ayam mayham mahā ravam ravati iti saddahitvā 🔽tena hi gaccha tvam eva ne ānehi iti balam da tvā pesesi saḥ gantvā divasam araññe 🔽kammam katvā sāyamāsam bhuñjitvā gāma majjhe nisīditvā sve kim kammam karissāma
translated: and while they were doing so, I got money from them in the form of kahāpaṇas and so on, and in the form of fines and forced labour. Now that they are doing meritorious deeds, I get no such income. Well, I will denounce them to the king.” So he went to the king and said, “Sire, I see thieves.” “Where, my dear?” “In my village.” “What sort of thieves?” “Sire, they are offenders against the king.” “What are they by caste?” “They are householders, sire.” “What will householders do?” “Why did you not tell me when you knew?” “Through fear, sire, I did not tell; now do not be angry with me.” Then the king thought, “This man is shouting at me,” and he believed him. “Well then, go and bring them yourself,” he said, and he gave him a force and sent him off. He went and worked in the forest all day. In the evening he ate his meal and sat in the middle of the village. “What work shall we do tomorrow?”

original: kiṃ maggaṃ samaṃ karoma, pokkharaṇiṃ khaṇāma, setuṃ bandhāmā”ti mantayamāneyeva te
analyzed: kim maggam samam karoma pokkharaṇim khaṇāma setum bandhāma ati mantayamānā iya iva te
translated: “What can we do? Shall we make a road? Shall we dig a lake? Shall we build a bridge?”

original: parivāretvā “mā phandittha, rañño āṇā”ti bandhitvā pāyāsi. Atha kho nesaṃ itthiyo
analyzed: parivāretvā mā phandittha raññaḥ āṇāti bandhitvā pāyāsi atha kho nesam itthiyo
translated: While they were discussing this, the king’s men surrounded them, bound them, and took them away, saying, “Don’t make a fuss. This is the king’s command.”🔽The women of the village heard that the men were being taken away, bound, and labeled as “criminals against the king.”

original: “sāmikā kira vo ‘rājāparādhikā corā’ti bandhitvā niyyantī”ti sutvā “aticirena kūṭā
analyzed: sāmikā kira vaḥ rāja aparādhikā corā ati bandhitvā sutvā aticirena
translated: “They’re taking too long,” they said.

original: ete ‘puññakammaṃ karomā’ti divase divase araññeva acchanti, sabbakammantā parihīnā,
analyzed: ete puñña kammam karoma ati divase divase araññā iva acchanti sabba kammantā parihīnā
translated: “They’re staying in the wilderness all day, saying, ‘We’re doing meritorious deeds.’ All our work is neglected.

original: gehe na kiñci vaḍḍhati, suṭṭhu baddhā suṭṭhu gahitā”ti vadiṃsu.
analyzed: gehe na kiñci vaḍḍhati suṭṭhu baddhā suṭṭhu gahitā ati vadiṃsu
translated: Nothing is getting done at home. They’re well bound and well caught.”

original: Gāmabhojakopi te netvā rañño dassesi. Rājā anupaparikkhitvāyeva “hatthinā maddāpethā”ti
analyzed: gāmabhojakaḥ api te netvā raññaḥ dassesi rājā an upaparikkhitvāya iva hatthinā maddāpetha ati
translated: The village headman took them to the king. Without investigating, the king said, “Have them trampled to death by an elephant.”

original: āha. Tesu nīyamānesu magho itare āha – “bho, sakkhissatha mama vacanaṃ kātu”nti?
analyzed: āha tesu nīyamānesu maghaḥ itare āha bho sakkhissatha mama vacanam kātunti
translated: While they were being led away, Magha said to the others, “Sirs, will you do what I say?”

original: Tava vacanaṃ karontāyevamha imaṃ bhayaṃ pattā, evaṃ santepi tava vacanaṃ karoma,
analyzed: tava vacanam karontāḥ imam bhayam pattāḥ evam santaḥ ipi tava vacanam karoma
translated: “We’ve gotten into this danger by doing what you said. Still, we’ll do what you say.

original: bhaṇa bho, kiṃ karomāti? Ettha bho vaṭṭe carantānaṃ nāma nibaddhaṃ etaṃ, kiṃ pana
analyzed: bhaṇa bho kim karoma iti ettha bho vaṭṭe carantānam nāma nibaddham etam kim pana
translated: “Well then, say what you want done.” “It is a fixed rule that those who go about in a circle in this place are thieves.

original: tumhe corāti? Na coramhāti. Imassa lokassa saccakiriyā nāma avassayo, tasmā sabbepi
analyzed: tumhe corā ti na coramha ati imassa lokassa saccakiriyāḥ nāma avassayo tasmā sabbe pi
translated: What then, are you thieves?” “We are not thieves.” “In this world the performance of truth is a support. Therefore all of you

original: “yadi amhe corā, hatthī maddatu, atha na corā, mā maddatū”ti saccakiriyaṃ karothāti.
analyzed: yadi amhe corāḥ hatthī maddatu atha na corāḥ mā maddatu uti saccakiriyam karotha ati
translated: perform a truth-act, saying: ‘If we are thieves, let the elephant trample us to death; if we are not thieves, let him not trample us to death.’ ”

original: Te tathā akaṃsu. Hatthī upagantumpi na sakkoti, viravanto palāyati, hatthiṃ tuttatomaraṅkusehi
analyzed: te tathā akaṃsu hatthī upagantum pi na sakkoti viravantaḥ palāyati hatthim tutta tomara aṅkusehi
translated: They did so. The elephant could not approach them, but fled, trumpeting. They beat the elephant with goads and spears,

original: koṭṭentāpi upanetuṃ na sakkonti. “Hatthiṃ upanetuṃ na sakkomā”ti rañño ārocesuṃ.
analyzed: koṭṭentā api upanetum na sakkonti hatthim upanetum na sakkoma ati raññaḥ ārocesuṃ
translated: but could not lead him up. “We cannot lead the elephant up,” they reported to the king.

original: Tena hi upari kaṭena paṭicchādetvā maddāpethāti. Upari kaṭe dinne diguṇaravaṃ viravanto palāyati.
analyzed: tena hi upari kaṭena paṭicchādetvā upari kaṭe dinne diguṇa ravam palāyati
translated: “Well then, cover him with a mat on top and lead him up.” When the mat was put on top, the elephant fled, trumpeting twice as loudly.

original: Rājā sutvā pesuññakārakaṃ pakkosāpetvā āha – “tāta, hatthī maddituṃ na icchatī”ti?
analyzed: rājā sutvā pesuñña kārakam pakkosāpetvā āha tāta hatthī madditum naḥ icchati iti
translated: The king heard this and summoned the one who had caused the trouble and said, “Dear, the elephant does not want to trample to death?”

original: Āma, deva, jeṭṭhakamāṇavo mantaṃ jānāti, mantasseva ayamānubhāvoti. Rājā taṃ pakkosāpetvā
analyzed: āma deva jeṭṭhaka māṇavaḥ mantam jānāti mantassa iva ayam ānubhāvaḥ ti rājā tam pakkosāpetvā
translated: “Yes, your majesty, the senior student knows a spell, and this is the power of the spell.” The king summoned him and said,🔽“Is it true that you know a spell?”

original: “manto kira te atthī”ti pucchi? Natthi, deva, mayhaṃ manto, saccakiriyaṃ pana mayaṃ
analyzed: manto kira te atthi iti pucchi na atthi deva mayham manto saccakiriyam pana mayam

analyzed: sudhammā deva sabhā nibbatti nandāya pokkharaṇiyā nissandena paññāsa yojanā nandā 🔽nāma pokkharaṇī nibbatti cittāya mālāvaccha vatthu nissandena saṭṭhi yojanikam citta latā vanam
translated: by the influence of the lotus-pool of Nandā, a lotus-pool was produced, fifty leagues in extent,🔽by the influence of the garland-creeper, a grove of creepers was produced, sixty leagues in extent.

translated: Sakka, king of the gods, was sitting on a golden couch in the Sudhamma Assembly, which was a league in size,🔽and he was being fanned by the gods and goddesses with a white parasol that was three leagues in size.🔽He was surrounded by the gods and goddesses of the two worlds, and by 1.5 million dancing girls.

original: dvīsu devalokesu devatāhi ca parivārito mahāsampattiṃ olokento tā tisso itthiyo disvā

analyzed: imā tāva paññāyanti sujātā kuhinti olokentaḥ ayam mama vacanam a katvā girikandarāya

original: bakasakuṇikā hutvā nibbattā”ti disvā devalokato otaritvā tassā santikaṃ gato. Sā

original: ca mahāsampatti nibbattā, ehi amhākaṃ sampattiṃ passā”ti devalokaṃ netvā nandāya
analyzed: ca mahā sampatti nibbattā ehi amhākam sampattim passāti deva lokam netvā nandāya

analyzed: bho amhākam mukham keḷim akaṃsu  sā ativiya aṭṭiyamānā sakkam devarājānam āha mahā rāja imāni suvaṇṇa rajata maṇi vimānāni
translated: your ladyships, at our lady’s face, which is like a saw-edge smeared with meat.” And they made fun of her.🔽She was so ashamed that she said to Sakka, king of the gods, “Your majesty, what am I to do with these golden and silver palaces and these bejewelled couches?

analyzed: aggahesi macchaḥ naṅguṭṭham cālesi sā jīvati maññeti udake vissajjesi sakkaḥ ākāse  ṭhatvā sādhu sādhu rakkhasi sikkhāpadam evam tam rakkhamānam kati pāhena iva nāṭakānam

analyzed: kumbhakāra gehe nibbatti  sakko kuhim nibbattā ati olokentaḥ disvā tatas idha ānetum na sakkā jīvita vuttim assā
translated: in the house of a potter.

analyzed: dassāmi iti suvaṇṇa eḷālukānam yānakam pūretvā majjhe gāmassa mahallaka vesena nisīditvā
translated: Sakka looked about to see where she had been reborn. When he saw that she had been reborn there, he thought, “I cannot bring her from there. I will give her a living.” So he filled a cart with gold coins, and in the middle of the village he sat down in the guise of an old man and

analyzed: eḷālukāni gaṇhatha ati ukkuṭṭhimakā asi samantā gāmavāsikā āgantvā dehi tāta ati  ahaṃsu aham sīla rakkhakānam demi tumhe sīlam rakkhatha ati tāta mayam sīlam nāma

analyzed: na jānāma mūlena dehi iti dammi iti āha re  ko asi ayam eḷāluka mahallako ti sabbe nivattiṃsu
translated: “I give them to those who keep the virtue of the five precepts,” he said. “We don’t even know what the virtue of the five precepts is, father,” they said. “Give us some for the price.” “I give them only to those who keep the virtue of the five precepts,” he said. “What is this fellow doing, giving away gold coins for nothing?” And they all turned away.🔽The little girl asked, “Mother, why do you come back with empty hands when you went out for gold coins?”

original: Sā dārikā pucchi – “amma, tumhe eḷālukatthāya gatā tucchahatthāva āgatā”ti. Kosi,

translated: “Mother, the king of the Eḷeyyas says that he will give his daughter to one who is virtuous. It is evident that his daughter is virtuous, and that she has eaten up the virtue of all of us. We do not know what virtue is.”

translated: “I will bring it to you,” said she. So she went to the king and said to him, “Give me the Eḷeyya jewel, my lord.” “Are you virtuous, my lady?” “Yes, my lord, I am virtuous.”

translated: Vepacitti thought to himself, “I will celebrate the marriage of my daughter.” Accordingly he assembled the Asuras.

analyzed: karissanti iti disvā idāni yaṃ kiñci katvā ānetabbā mayā iti asura vaṇṇam nimminitvā

analyzed: gantvā asurānaṃ antare aṭṭhāsi tava sāmikam vadehi iti tassā hatthe pitā puppha dāmam

analyzed: adāsi yam icchasi tassu upari khipāhi iti sā olokentī sakkam disvā pubba sannivāsena
translated: saying, “Throw it over the one you wish to have for a husband.” As she looked about, she saw Sakka, and through the force of her former affection for him,

translated: We will not give him our daughter.” Vepacitti asked, “Who has taken her?”🔽“The old Sakka, great king.” “Among the rest he is the best. Let him go.” Sakka took her and set her over a hundred and fifty koṭis of nymphs, making her his chief consort.

translated: She asked a boon of Sakka, saying, “Great king,
