analyzed: a byāpajjā ati vigata domanassāḥ viharemu averinaḥ ti aho vata kenacid saddhim averinaḥ vihareyyāma
translated: Abyāpajjā means “without grief.” Viharemu averino means “May we live without enmity with anyone.”

original: katthaci kopaṃ na uppādetvā accharāya gahitakaṃ jaṅghasahassena saddhiṃ paribhuñjeyyāmāti
analyzed: katthaci kopam na uppādetvā accharāya gahitakam jaṅgha sahassena saddhim paribhuñjeyyāma ati
translated: Katthaci kopaṃ na uppādetvā means “without arousing anger anywhere.” Accharāya gahitakaṃ means “like a man who has taken a woman by the hand.” Jaṅghasahassena saddhiṃ paribhuñjeyyāti means “I would enjoy myself with a thousand women.”

original: dānaṃ datvā pūjaṃ katvā ca patthayanti. Iti ca nesaṃ hotīti evañca nesaṃ ayaṃ patthanā🔽hoti. Atha ca panāti evaṃ patthanāya satipi.🔽Issāmacchariyasaṃyojanāti parasampattikhīyanalakkhaṇā issā, attasampattiyā parehi🔽sādhāraṇabhāvassa asahanalakkhaṇaṃ macchariyaṃ, issā ca macchariyañca saṃyojanaṃ🔽etesanti issāmacchariyasaṃyojanā. Ayamettha saṅkhepo. Vitthārato pana issāmacchariyāni
analyzed: dānam da tvā pūjam katvā ca patthayanti iti ca nesam hoti iti evam ca nesam ayam patthanā  hoti atha ca panāti evam patthanāya sati pi  para sampatti khīyana lakkhaṇā issā atta sampattiyā parehi  sādhāraṇa bhāvassa a sahana lakkhaṇam macchariyam issā ca macchariyam ca saṃyojanam  issāmacchariya saṃyojanāḥ ayam ettha saṅkhepaḥ vitthārato pana issāmacchariyāni
translated: But even though they have this hope,

original: abhidhamme vuttāneva.🔽Āvāsamacchariyena panettha yakkho vā peto vā hutvā tasseva āvāsassa saṅkāraṃ sīsena🔽ukkhipitvā vicarati. Kulamacchariyena tasmiṃ kule aññesaṃ dānādīni karonte disvā
analyzed: abhidhamme vuttāna eva  āvāsa macchariyena pana ittha yakkhaḥ vā petaḥ vā hutvā tassa iva āvāsassa saṅkāram sīsena  ukkhipitvā vicarati kula macchariyena tasmim kule aññesam dāna ādīni karonte disvā
translated: they are fettered by envy and avarice: envy has the characteristic of disparaging another’s success; avarice has the characteristic of inability to share one’s own success with others. The fetter that is envy and avarice is the fetter of envy and avarice. This is the brief account here. But the detailed account of envy and avarice is given in the Abhidhamma.

original: “bhinnaṃ vatidaṃ kulaṃ mamā”ti cintayato lohitampi mukhato uggacchati, kucchivirecanampi
analyzed: bhinnam vatidam kulam mama ati cintayataḥ lohitam pi mukhataḥ uggacchati kucchi virecanam pi
translated: But here, by the fetter of avarice about dwelling, a spirit or ghost carries on its head the rubbish of that very dwelling and wanders about. By the fetter of avarice about families, when he sees others giving gifts, etc., in a certain family, he thinks, “That family is split up for me,” and blood comes out of his mouth and he has a purging from both ends.

original: hoti, antānipi khaṇḍākhaṇḍāni hutvā nikkhamanti. Lābhamacchariyena saṅghassa vā gaṇassa🔽vā santake lābhe maccharāyitvā puggalikaparibhogena paribhuñjitvā yakkho vā peto🔽vā mahāajagaro vā hutvā nibbattati. Sarīravaṇṇaguṇavaṇṇamacchariyena pana pariyattidhammamacchariyena
analyzed: hoti antāni api khaṇḍa akhaṇḍāni hutvā nikkhamanti lābha macchariyena saṅghassa vā gaṇassa  vā santake lābhe maccharāyitvā puggalika paribhogena paribhuñjitvā yakkhaḥ vā peto  vā mahā ajagaraḥ vā hutvā nibbattati sarīra vaṇṇa guṇa vaṇṇa macchariyena pana pariyatti dhamma macchariyena
translated: and the ends of the bones break up and come out. Through stinginess about gains he is reborn as a yakkha, a ghost, or a big python, after having used for himself gains belonging to the Community or a group of bhikkhus. Through stinginess about the excellence of his complexion and his fame he is reborn in a low-class family. Through stinginess about the True Idea he is reborn in a state of mind-made form or in the Pure Abodes.

original: ca attanova vaṇṇaṃ vaṇṇeti, na paresaṃ vaṇṇaṃ, “kiṃ vaṇṇo eso”ti taṃ taṃ dosaṃ vadanto🔽pariyattiñca kassaci kiñci adento dubbaṇṇo ceva eḷamūgo ca hoti.🔽Apica āvāsamacchariyena lohagehe paccati. Kulamacchariyena appalābho hoti. Lābhamacchariyena
analyzed: ca attanā uva vaṇṇam vaṇṇeti na paresam vaṇṇam kim vaṇṇaḥ eso ti tam tam dosam vadantaḥ  pariyattiñca kassaci kiñci a dentaḥ dubbaṇṇaḥ ca iva eḷamūgaḥ ca hoti  apica āvāsa macchariyena loha gehe paccati kula macchariyena appalābhaḥ hoti lābha macchariyena
translated: and the limbs come out in pieces. Through stinginess about gains, after being stingy about gains belonging to the Community or a group and using them for one’s own enjoyment, one is reborn as a spirit or a ghost or a great serpent. Through stinginess about the special qualities of one’s own bodily appearance and virtue, and through stinginess about the special qualities of the Dhamma, one praises oneself and does not praise others, saying, “What is he like? ” and one speaks of this and that fault. And through not giving the Dhamma to anyone, one is reborn ugly and dumb.

original: gūthaniraye nibbattati. Vaṇṇamacchariyena bhave nibbattassa vaṇṇo nāma na hoti. Dhammamacchariyena
analyzed: gūthaniraye nibbattati vaṇṇa macchariyena bhave nibbattassa vaṇṇaḥ nāma na hoti dhamma macchariyena
translated: Moreover, through stinginess about dwellings one is roasted in a copper hell. Through stinginess about families one has little gain. Through stinginess about gains one is reborn in the Hell of Excrement. Through stinginess about special qualities one has no special qualities in the rebirth that follows. Through stinginess about the Dhamma one is reborn in a place where the vegetation is scanty.

original: kukkuḷaniraye nibbattati. Idaṃ pana issāmacchariyasaṃyojanaṃ sotāpattimaggena pahīyati.
analyzed: kukkuḷaniraye nibbattati idam pana issāmacchariya saṃyojanam sotāpatti maggena pahīyati
translated: he is reborn in the Kukkula Hell. But this fetter of envy and avarice is abandoned by the path of stream-entry.

original: Yāva taṃ nappahīyati, tāva devamanussā averatādīni patthayantāpi verādīhi na parimuccantiyeva.
analyzed: yāva tam na pahīyati tāva deva manussāḥ a vera tā ādīni patthayantā api vera ādīhi na
translated: As long as it is not abandoned, so long are gods and men not freed from enmity, etc., even though they may wish for freedom from enmity, etc.

original: Tiṇṇā mettha kaṅkhāti etasmiṃ pañhe mayā tumhākaṃ vacanaṃ sutvā kaṅkhā tiṇṇāti vadati,
analyzed: tiṇṇā mā ittha kaṅkhā ati etasmin pañhe mayā tumhākam vacanam sutvā kaṅkhā tiṇṇā iti vadati
translated: “Their doubts have all been cut away”: he says that he has heard their statement of the question and that their doubts have been cut away;

original: na maggavasena tiṇṇakaṅkhataṃ dīpeti. Vigatā kathaṃkathāti idaṃ kathaṃ, idaṃ kathanti
analyzed: na magga vasena dīpeti vigatā kathaṃkathā ati idam katham idam kathanti
translated: he does not show that their doubts have been cut away by the path. “Their hesitation has been overcome”: this is the hesitation, “Is it so? Is it not so?”

original: ayampi kathaṃkathā vigatā.
analyzed: ayam pi kathaṃkathā vigatā
translated: This hesitation has been overcome.

original: 358. Nidānādīni vuttatthāneva. Piyāppiyanidānanti piyasattasaṅkhāranidānaṃ macchariyaṃ,
analyzed: nidāna ādīni piya appiya nidānam ti piya satta saṅkhāra nidānam mad śariyam
translated: The “source” , etc., are in the same place as the above . The “source of the dear and the not-dear” is the source of the formations consisting of dear and not-dear beings.

original: appiyasattasaṅkhāranidānā issā. Ubhayaṃ vā ubhayanidānaṃ. Pabbajitassa hi saddhivihārikādayo,
analyzed: appiya satta saṅkhāra nidānāḥ issāḥ ubhayam vā ubhaya nidānam pabbajitassa hi saddhivihārika ādayaḥ
translated: Envy has as its source the formations consisting of not-dear beings, and avarice has as its source the formations consisting of dear beings. Or both have as their source both kinds of beings. For the one gone forth has as his dear beings his pupils, etc.,

original: gahaṭṭhassa puttādayo hatthiassādayo vā sattā piyā honti keḷāyitā mamāyitā, muhuttampi
analyzed: gaha ṭṭhassa putta ādayaḥ hatthi assa ādayaḥ vā sattā piyāḥ honti keḷāyitāḥ mamāyitāḥ muhuttam pi
translated: and the one living in a house has as his dear beings his children, wife, etc., or his elephants, horses, etc. He is attached to them, he is possessive of them, and he is not willing to give them up even for a moment.

original: te apassanto adhivāsetuṃ na sakkoti. So aññaṃ tādisaṃ piyasattaṃ labhantaṃ disvā🔽issaṃ karoti. “Iminā amhākaṃ kiñci kammaṃ atthi, muhuttaṃ tāva naṃ dethā”ti tameva
analyzed: te a passantaḥ adhivāsetum na sakkoti so aññam tādisam piya sattam labhantam disvā  issam karoti iminā amhākam kiñci kammam atthi muhuttam tāva naṃ detha ati tam eva
translated: He cannot bear to see it. When he sees another getting a dear one like it,

original: aññehi yācito “na sakkā dātuṃ, kilamissati vā ukkaṇṭhissati vā”tiādīni vatvā macchariyaṃ
analyzed: aññehi yācitaḥ na sakkā dātum kilamissati vā ukkaṇṭhissati vā ati ādīni vatvā macchariyam
translated: he is jealous. When asked to give it to another, he says, “There is some work for us to do. Give it to him for a little while.”

original: karoti. Evaṃ tāva ubhayampi piyasattanidānaṃ hoti. Bhikkhussa pana pattacīvaraparikkhārajātaṃ,
analyzed: karoti evam tāva ubhayam pi piya satta nidānam hoti bhikkhussa pana patta cīvara parikkhāra jātam
translated: He is stingy. Thus both are rooted in a dear person. But a bhikkhu’s bowl, robe, requisites,

original: gahaṭṭhassa vā alaṅkārādiupakaraṇaṃ piyaṃ hoti manāpaṃ, so aññassa tādisaṃ uppajjamānaṃ🔽disvā “aho vatassa evarūpaṃ na bhaveyyā”ti issaṃ karoti, yācito vāpi “mayampetaṃ
analyzed: gahaṭṭhassa vā alaṅkāra ādi upakaraṇam piyam hoti manāpam so aññassa tādisam uppajjamānam  disvā aho vatassa evarūpam na bhaveyya ati issam karoti yācitaḥ vā api mayampetam
translated: or a layman’s ornaments, etc., are dear to him and pleasing. When he sees another getting such things,

original: mamāyantā na paribhuñjāma, na sakkā dātu”nti macchariyaṃ karoti. Evaṃ ubhayampi piyasaṅkhāranidānaṃ
analyzed: na paribhuñjāma na sakkāḥ dātunti mad śariyam karoti evam ubhayam pi piya saṅkhāra nidānam
translated: he is jealous, thinking, “Oh that he should get such things!” When asked to give them to another, he says, “I cannot give them. He will get tired or disgusted,” and so on.🔽He is stingy. Thus both are rooted in what is dear.

original: hoti. Appiye pana te vuttappakāre satte ca saṅkhāre ca labhitvā sacepissa te amanāpā🔽honti, tathāpi kilesānaṃ viparītavuttitāya “ṭhapetvā maṃ ko añño evarūpassa lābhī”ti🔽issaṃ vā karoti, yācito tāvakālikampi adadamāno macchariyaṃ vā karoti. Evaṃ ubhayampi
analyzed: hoti appiye pana te vutta ppakāre satte ca saṅkhāre ca labhitvā sace pissa te amanāpā  honti tathā api kilesānam viparīta vutti tāya ṭhapetvā mam kaḥ aññaḥ evarūpassa lābhī iti  issam vā karoti yācitaḥ tāvakālikam pi a dadamānaḥ macchariyam vā karoti evam ubhayam pi
translated: But if he gets the sort of beings and the sort of formations that are not agreeable to him, then even though they are disagreeable to him,🔽still, because of the perversity of the defilements, he thinks, “Who else is there to get such things except me?” and he becomes conceited. Or else he is miserly and does not give even when asked, though he may give later on. So in both cases🔽🔽

original: appiyasattasaṅkhāranidānaṃ hoti.
analyzed: appiya satta saṅkhāra nidānam hoti
translated: But if he gets such kinds of unloved creatures and formations, then even if they are unlovely to him, still, because of the perversity of defilements, he thinks, “Who else is there to get such things except me?” and he becomes conceited. Or else, though he does not give them away when asked, he becomes miserly. So in both cases it is due to unloved creatures and formations.

original: Chandanidānanti ettha pariyesanachando, paṭilābhachando, paribhogachando, sannidhichando, vissajjanachandoti pañcavidho chando.
analyzed: chanda nidānam ti ettha pariyesana chando paṭilābha chando paribhoga chando sannidhi chando vissajjana chando ti pañcavidhaḥ chando
translated: Due to desire: here desire is of five kinds, that is, desire to seek, desire to obtain, desire to use, desire to hoard, and desire to give away.

original: Katamo pariyesanachando? Idhekacco atitto chandajāto rūpaṃ pariyesati, saddaṃ. Gandhaṃ. Rasaṃ. Phoṭṭhabbaṃ pariyesati, dhanaṃ pariyesati. Ayaṃ pariyesanachando.
analyzed: katamaḥ pariyesana chandaḥ idha ekaccaḥ atittaḥ chanda jātaḥ rūpam pariyesati saddam gandham rasam phoṭṭhabbam pariyesati dhanam pariyesati ayam pariyesana chandaḥ
translated: What is desire to seek? Here someone, greedy and lustful, seeks visible forms, sounds, smells, tastes, and touches, and he seeks wealth. This is desire to seek.

original: Katamo paṭilābhachando? Idhekacco atitto chandajāto rūpaṃ paṭilabhati, saddaṃ. Gandhaṃ. Rasaṃ. Phoṭṭhabbaṃ paṭilabhati, dhanaṃ paṭilabhati. Ayaṃ paṭilābhachando.
analyzed: katamaḥ paṭilābha chandaḥ idha ekaccaḥ a tittaḥ chanda jātaḥ rūpam paṭilabhati saddam gandham rasam phoṭṭhabbam paṭilabhati dhanam paṭilabhati ayam paṭilābha chandaḥ
translated: What is the will for acquisition? Here someone, greedy and lustful, acquires visible forms, acquires sounds, acquires smells, acquires tastes, acquires tangibles, acquires wealth. This is the will for acquisition.

original: Katamo paribhogachando? Idhekacco atitto chandajāto rūpaṃ paribhuñjati, saddaṃ. Gandhaṃ. Rasaṃ. Phoṭṭhabbaṃ paribhuñjati, dhanaṃ paribhuñjati. Ayaṃ paribhogachando.
analyzed: katamaḥ paribhoga chandaḥ idha ekaccaḥ a tittaḥ chanda jātaḥ rūpam paribhuñjati saddam gandham rasam phoṭṭhabbam paribhuñjati dhanam paribhuñjati ayam paribhoga chandaḥ
translated: What is the will for enjoyment? Here someone, greedy and lustful, enjoys visible forms, enjoys sounds, enjoys smells, enjoys tastes, enjoys tangibles, enjoys wealth. This is the will for enjoyment.

original: Katamo sannidhichando? Idhekacco atitto chandajāto dhanasannicayaṃ karoti “āpadāsu bhavissatī”ti. Ayaṃ sannidhichando.
analyzed: katamaḥ sannidhi chandaḥ idha ekaccaḥ atittaḥ chanda jātaḥ dhana sannicayam karoti āpadāsu bhavissati iti ayam sannidhi chandaḥ
translated: What is the will for storage? Here someone, greedy and lustful, stores up goods, thinking: “This will be mine in the future.” This is the will for storage.

original: Katamo vissajjanachando? Idhekacco atitto chandajāto dhanaṃ vissajjeti, hatthārohānaṃ,
analyzed: katamaḥ vissajjana chandaḥ idha ekaccaḥ atittaḥ chanda jātaḥ dhanam vissajjeti hattha ārohānam
translated: What is the will for dispersal? Here someone, greedy and lustful, disperses his wealth on elephant troops,

original: assārohānaṃ, rathikānaṃ, dhanuggahānaṃ – “ime maṃ rakkhissanti gopissanti mamāyissanti
analyzed: assa ārohānam rathikānam dhanuggahānam ime mama rakkhissanti gopissanti mamāyissanti
translated: horse troops, chariot troops, infantry troops, on gambling, drinking, hunting, gambling with dice, or on strolling about at night. This is the will for dispersal.

original: samparivārayissantī”ti. Ayaṃ vissajjanachando. Ime pañca chandā. Idha taṇhāmattameva,
analyzed: samparivārayissanti iti ayam vissajjana chandaḥ ime pañca chandāḥ idha taṇhā mattam eva
translated: they will surround it.” This is the “desire to reply.” These are the five kinds of desire. Herein, craving is what is meant.

original: taṃ sandhāya idaṃ vuttaṃ.
analyzed: tam sandhāya idam vuttam
translated: This is what is referred to here.

original: Vitakkanidānoti ettha “lābhaṃ paṭicca vinicchayo”ti evaṃ vutto vinicchayavitakko
analyzed: vitakka nidānaḥ ti ettha lābham paṭicca vinicchayo ti evam vuttaḥ vinicchaya vitakko
translated: “The source of thinking” : here, the thinking called “determining” stated thus: “Determining is dependent on gain” is thinking.

original: vitakko nāma. Vinicchayoti dve vinicchayā taṇhāvinicchayo ca, diṭṭhivinicchayo ca.
analyzed: vitakkaḥ nāma vinicchayo ti dve vinicchayā taṇhā vinicchayo ca diṭṭhi vinicchayo ca
translated: “Determining” is twofold: determining as craving and determining as view.

original: Aṭṭhasataṃ taṇhāvicaritaṃ taṇhāvinicchayo nāma. Dvāsaṭṭhi diṭṭhiyo diṭṭhivinicchayo
analyzed: aṭṭhasatam taṇhāvicaritam taṇhāvinicchayaḥ nāma dvāsaṭṭhi diṭṭhiyaḥ diṭṭhivinicchayo
translated: The eighty-four hundred kinds of craving are called determining as craving. The sixty-two views are called determining as view.

original: nāmāti evaṃ vuttataṇhāvinicchayavasena hi iṭṭhāniṭṭhapiyāppiyavavatthānaṃ na hoti.🔽Tadeva hi ekaccassa iṭṭhaṃ hoti, ekaccassa aniṭṭhaṃ paccantarājamajjhimadesarājūnaṃ
analyzed: nāma ati evam vutta taṇhā vinicchaya vasena hi iṭṭha aniṭṭha piya appiya vavatthānam na hoti  tat eva hi ekaccassa iṭṭham hoti ekaccassa aniṭṭham paccanta rāja majjhima desa rājūnam
translated: For it is by means of determining as craving stated thus that the delimitation of the desirable and undesirable does not take place.🔽For what is desirable for one is undesirable for another, like the flesh of the Gandhamadana deer for the kings of the middle country and the kings of the border regions.

original: gaṇḍuppādamigamaṃsādīsu viya. Tasmiṃ pana taṇhāvinicchayavinicchite paṭiladdhavatthusmiṃ
analyzed: gaṇḍuppāda miga maṃsa ādīsu tasmin pana taṇhā vinicchaya vinicchite paṭiladdha vatthusmin
translated: But when the object has been obtained by means of determining as craving,

original: “ettakaṃ rūpassa bhavissati, ettakaṃ saddassa, ettakaṃ gandhassa, ettakaṃ rasassa,
analyzed: ettakam rūpassa bhavissati ettakam saddassa ettakam gandhassa ettakam rasassa
translated: “This much will be form, this much will be sound, this much will be odour, this much will be flavour,

original: ettakaṃ phoṭṭhabbassa bhavissati, ettakaṃ mayhaṃ bhavissati, ettakaṃ parassa bhavissati,
analyzed: ettakam phoṭṭhabbassa bhavissati ettakam mayham bhavissati ettakam parassa bhavissati
translated: “There will be this much tangible-data, this much will be mine, this much will be another’s,”

original: ettakaṃ nidahissāmi, ettakaṃ parassa dassāmī”ti vavatthānaṃ vitakkavinicchayena hoti.
analyzed: ettakam nidahissāmi ettakam parassa dassāmi iti vavatthānam vitakka vinicchayena hoti
translated: “This much I shall store up, this much I shall give to another,” is the delimitation by choice-incidence.

original: Tenāha “chando kho, devānaminda, vitakkanidāno”ti.
analyzed: tena āha chandaḥ khalu devānam inda vitakka nidānaḥ ti
translated: Hence it was said above: “Desire has choice-incidence” .

original: Papañcasaññāsaṅkhānidānoti tayo papañcā taṇhāpapañco, mānapapañco, diṭṭhipapañcoti.
analyzed: papañca saññā saṅkhā nidāno ti tayo papañcā taṇhā papañcaḥ māna papañcaḥ diṭṭhi papañco ti
translated: With the condition of the manifestation of perceptions and of the many and varied determinations of conceiving : there are three kinds of manifestation : the manifestation of craving, the manifestation of conceit, and the manifestation of views.

original: Tattha aṭṭhasatataṇhāvicaritaṃ taṇhāpapañco nāma. Navavidho māno mānapapañco nāma.🔽Dvāsaṭṭhi diṭṭhiyo diṭṭhipapañco nāma. Tesu idha taṇhāpapañco adhippeto. Kenaṭṭhena
analyzed: tattha aṭṭhasata taṇhā vicaritam taṇhāpapañcaḥ nāma navavidhaḥ mānaḥ mānapapañcaḥ nāma  dvāsaṭṭhi diṭṭhiyaḥ diṭṭhipapañcaḥ nāma tesu idha taṇhāpapañcaḥ adhippeto kenaṭṭhena
translated: Herein, the eighty-four kinds of craving are called the manifestation of craving. The nine kinds of conceit are called the manifestation of conceit.🔽The sixty-two views are called the manifestation of views. Herein, the manifestation of craving is intended. In what sense is it a manifestation?

original: papañco? Mattapamattākārapāpanaṭṭhena papañco. Taṃsampayuttā saññā papañcasaññā.
analyzed: papañcaḥ matta pamatta ākāra pāpana ṭṭhena papañcaḥ tad sampayuttā saññā papañca saññā
translated: It is a manifestation in the sense of a spreading out of what is measured and meted. The perception associated with it is called the manifestation of perception.

original: Saṅkhā vuccati koṭṭhāso “saññānidānā hi papañcasaṅkhā”tiādīsu viya. Iti papañcasaññāsaṅkhānidānoti
analyzed: saṅkhā vuccati koṭṭhāsaḥ saññā nidānā hi papañca saṅkhā ati ādīsu viya iti papañca saññā saṅkhā nidānā ti
translated: The determinations are called determinations of conceiving, as in such passages as “Perceptions are the condition for the determinations of conceiving” . So with the condition of the manifestation of perceptions and of the many and varied determinations of conceiving :

original: papañcasaññākoṭṭhāsanidāno vitakkoti attho.
analyzed: papañca saññā koṭṭhāsa nidānaḥ vitakko ti attho
translated: the meaning is, “the thinking that has the basis of the proliferation of perception as its source.”

original: Papañcasaññāsaṅkhānirodhasāruppagāmininti etissā papañcasaññāsaṅkhāya khayā nirodho vūpasamo, tassa sāruppañceva tattha gāminiṃ cāti saha vipassanāya maggaṃ pucchati.
analyzed: papañca saññā saṅkhā nirodha sāruppa gāminim ti etissā papañca saññā saṅkhāya khayā nirodho vūpasamo tassa sāruppam ca iva tattha gāminim ca ati saha vipassanāya maggam pucchati
translated: “Leading to the state of conformity with the cessation of the proliferation of perception and the proliferation of cognizance”: with the exhaustion of that proliferation of perception and cognizance there is cessation, stopping, of that, and it is the path together with insight that leads to that state of conformity with it.

original: Vedanākammaṭṭhānavaṇṇanā
analyzed: vedanā kammaṭṭhāna vaṇṇanā
translated: The Description of the Meditation Subject of Feeling

original: 359. Athassa bhagavā somanassaṃpāhanti tisso vedanā ārabhi. Kiṃ pana bhagavatā pucchitaṃ🔽kathitaṃ, apucchitaṃ, sānusandhikaṃ, ananusandhikanti? Pucchitameva kathitaṃ, no
analyzed: athassa bhagavā tissaḥ vedanāḥ ārabhi kim pana bhagavatā pucchitam  kathitam a pucchitam sa anusandhikam an anusandhikam ti pucchitam eva kathitam no
translated: Then the Blessed One began with the three kinds of feeling. But why did he do so?🔽Was what he said asked by the deities or not? Was it connected with the question or not?

original: apucchitaṃ, sānusandhikameva, no ananusandhikaṃ. Devatānañhi rūpato arūpaṃ pākaṭataraṃ,
analyzed: a pucchitam sa anusandhikam eva no an anusandhikam devatā nañ hi rūpataḥ arūpam pākaṭataram
translated: What he said was asked by the deities, not unasked; it was connected with the question, not unconnected. For deities find the formless more obvious than the formed,

original: arūpepi vedanā pākaṭatarā. Kasmā? Devatānañhi karajakāyaṃ sukhumaṃ, kammajaṃ balavaṃ,
analyzed: arūpe api vedanā pākaṭatarā kasmā devatānam hi karaja kāyam sukhumam kamma jam balavam
translated: and in the formless they find feeling more obvious. Why? Because deities’ born-of-kamma body is subtle and their born-of-food body is powerful.

original: karajakāyassa sukhumattā, kammajassa balavattā ekāhārampi atikkamitvā na tiṭṭhanti,
analyzed: karaja kāyassa sukhuma ttā kamma jassa balavat tā ekāhāram pi atikkamitvā na tiṭṭhanti
translated: Since the born-of-kamma body is subtle, and since the born-of-food body is powerful, they do not remain without eating for a second day.

original: uṇhapāsāṇe ṭhapitasappipiṇḍi viya vilīyantīti sabbaṃ brahmajāle vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: uṇha pāsāṇe ṭhapita sappi piṇḍi viya vilīyanti iti sabbam brahmajāle vutta nayena iva veditabbam
translated: They melt away like a lump of sugar thrown into a red-hot pan. All this should be understood as stated in the Brahmajāla Sutta.

original: Tasmā bhagavā sakkassa tisso vedanā ārabhi. Duvidhañhi kammaṭṭhānaṃ – rūpakammaṭṭhānaṃ,
analyzed: tasmai bhagavā sakkassa tissaḥ vedanāḥ ārabhi duvidham hi kammaṭṭhānam rūpa kammaṭṭhānam
translated: Therefore the Blessed One began with the three kinds of feeling. For there are two kinds of meditation subject:

original: arūpakammaṭṭhānañca. Rūpapariggaho, arūpapariggahotipi etadeva vuccati. Tattha bhagavā🔽yassa rūpaṃ pākaṭaṃ, tassa saṅkhepamanasikāravasena vā vitthāramanasikāravasena vā
analyzed: arūpa kammaṭṭhānam ca rūpa pariggaho arūpa pariggaho ti pi etat eva vuccati tattha bhagavā  yassa rūpam pākaṭam tassa saṅkhepa manasikāra vasena vā vitthāra manasikāra vasena vā
translated: the meditation subject consisting of materiality and the meditation subject consisting of the immaterial. These are also called “the discernment of materiality” and “the discernment of the immaterial.” Herein,

original: catudhātuvavatthānaṃ vitthārento rūpakammaṭṭhānaṃ katheti. Yassa arūpaṃ pākaṭaṃ,🔽tassa arūpakammaṭṭhānaṃ katheti. Kathento ca tassa vatthubhūtaṃ rūpakammaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: catu dhātu vavatthānam vitthārentaḥ rūpa kammaṭṭhānam katheti yassa arūpam pākaṭam  tassa arūpa kammaṭṭhānam katheti kathento ca tassa vatthu bhūtam rūpa kammaṭṭhānam
translated: the Blessed One teaches the meditation subject consisting of materiality to one for whom materiality is evident, either by way of the brief reviewing of the four elements or by way of the detailed reviewing of the four elements.🔽He teaches the meditation subject consisting of the immaterial to one for whom the immaterial is evident.🔽And in teaching it he teaches it by showing the meditation subject consisting of materiality, which is the basis for the immaterial,

original: dassetvāva katheti, devānaṃ pana arūpakammaṭṭhānaṃ pākaṭanti arūpakammaṭṭhānavasena vedanā ārabhi.
analyzed: dassetvā ava kathā iti devānam pana arūpa kammaṭṭhānam pākaṭanti arūpa kammaṭṭhāna vasena vedanāḥ ārabhi
translated: but the meditation subject consisting of the immaterial is evident to deities. So he began with the three kinds of feeling by way of the meditation subject consisting of the immaterial.

original: Tividho hi arūpakammaṭṭhāne abhiniveso – phassavasena, vedanāvasena, cittavasenāti.
analyzed: tividhaḥ hi arūpa kammaṭṭhāne abhinivesaḥ phassa vasena vedanā vasena citta vasena ati
translated: For there are three ways of applying oneself to the meditation subject consisting of the immaterial: by way of contact, by way of feeling, and by way of consciousness.

original: Kathaṃ? Ekaccassa hi saṅkhittena vā vitthārena vā pariggahite rūpakammaṭṭhāne tasmiṃ
analyzed: katham ekaccassa hi saṅkhittena vā vitthārena vā pariggahite rūpa kammaṭṭhāne tasmin
translated: How? In the case of some, when the meditation subject consisting of material form is being taken up either in brief or in detail,

original: ārammaṇe cittacetasikānaṃ paṭhamābhinipāto taṃ ārammaṇaṃ phusanto uppajjamāno phasso
analyzed: ārammaṇe citta cetasikānam paṭhama abhinipātaḥ tam ārammaṇam phusantaḥ uppajjamānaḥ phasso
translated: the first impact of the consciousness and consciousness-concomitants on that object, which impact is called contact, is evident.

original: pākaṭo hoti. Ekaccassa taṃ ārammaṇaṃ anubhavantī uppajjamānā vedanā pākaṭā hoti.
analyzed: pākaṭaḥ hoti ekaccassa tam ārammaṇam anubhavantī uppajjamānā vedanā pākaṭā hoti
translated: In the case of some it is the feeling that is evident as it arises experiencing that object.

original: Ekaccassa taṃ ārammaṇaṃ pariggahetvā taṃ vijānantaṃ uppajjamānaṃ viññāṇaṃ pākaṭaṃ hoti.
analyzed: ekaccassa tam ārammaṇam pariggahetvā tam vijānantam uppajjamānam viññāṇam pākaṭam hoti
translated: In the case of some it is the perception that is evident as it apprehends that object.

original: Tattha yassa phasso pākaṭo hoti, sopi na kevalaṃ phassova uppajjati, tena saddhiṃ
analyzed: tattha yassa phassaḥ pākaṭaḥ hoti saḥ api na kevalam phassaḥ uva uppajjati tena saddhim
translated: Herein, when contact is evident to anyone, then not only contact arises in him together with

original: tadeva ārammaṇaṃ anubhavamānā vedanāpi uppajjati, sañjānamānā saññāpi, cetayamānā
analyzed: tat eva ārammaṇam anubhavamānā vedanā api uppajjati sañjānamānā saññā api cetayamānā
translated: feeling, perception, volition, and consciousness, but also the object is experienced by feeling, apprehended by perception,🔽determined by applied thought, and investigated by sustained thought.

original: cetanāpi, vijānamānaṃ viññāṇampi uppajjatīti phassapañcamakeyeva pariggaṇhāti. Yassa
analyzed: cetanā api vijānamānam viññāṇam pi uppajjati iti phassa pañcamakeyya iva pariggaṇhāti yassa
translated: So he discerns the five aggregates together with their conditions.

original: vedanā pākaṭā hoti, sopi na kevalaṃ vedanāva uppajjati, tāya saddhiṃ tadeva ārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: vedanā pākaṭā hoti sā upi na kevalam uppajjati tāya saddhim tat eva ārammaṇam
translated: When feeling is evident to anyone, then not only feeling arises in him, but also the object is experienced by feeling,🔽apprehended by perception, determined by applied thought, and investigated by sustained thought.

original: phusamāno phassopi uppajjati, sañjānamānā saññāpi, cetayamānā cetanāpi, vijānamānaṃ
analyzed: phusamānaḥ phassaḥ api uppajjati sañjānamānā saññā api cetayamānā cetanā api vijānamānam
translated: and when it touches, contact arises, and when it discerns, perception arises, and when it intends, volition arises, and when it cognizes,🔽consciousness arises. So he discerns the five aggregates together with their conditions.

original: viññāṇampi uppajjatīti phassapañcamakeyeva pariggaṇhāti. Yassa viññāṇaṃ pākaṭaṃ hoti,🔽sopi na kevalaṃ viññāṇameva uppajjati, tena saddhiṃ tadevārammaṇaṃ phusamāno phassopi
analyzed: viññāṇam pi uppajjati iti pariggaṇhāti yassa viññāṇam pākaṭam hoti  saḥ api na kevalam viññāṇam eva uppajjati tena saddhim tat eva ārammaṇam phusamānaḥ phassaḥ api
translated: If his consciousness is evident,🔽he discerns the five aggregates together with their conditions thus: “When consciousness arises, then these things arise, namely, contact, feeling, perception, volition, and consciousness.🔽When consciousness touches, then these things touch, namely, contact, feeling, perception, volition, and consciousness.🔽When consciousness feels, then these things feel, namely, contact, feeling, perception, volition, and consciousness.🔽When consciousness discerns, then these things discern, namely, contact, feeling, perception, volition, and consciousness.🔽When consciousness intends, then these things intend, namely, contact, feeling, perception, volition, and consciousness.

original: uppajjati, anubhavamānā vedanāpi, sañjānamānā saññāpi, cetayamānā cetanāpi uppajjatīti
analyzed: uppajjati anubhavamānā vedanā api sañjānamānā saññā api cetayamānā cetanā api uppajjati iti
translated: When consciousness cognizes, then these things cognize, namely, contact, feeling, perception, volition, and consciousness.”

original: phassapañcamakeyeva pariggaṇhāti.
analyzed: phassa pañcamakeya iva pariggaṇhāti
translated: He discerns the five aggregates together with their conditions.

original: So “ime phassapañcamakā dhammā kiṃ nissitā”ti upadhārento “vatthunissitā”ti pajānāti.🔽Vatthu nāma karajakāyo, yaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ – “idañca pana me viññāṇaṃ ettha sitaṃ
analyzed: so ime phassa pañcamakā dhammā kim nissitā ati upadhārentaḥ vatthu nissitā ati pajānāti  vatthu nāma karaja kāyaḥ yam sandhāya vuttam idam ca pana me viññāṇam ettha sitam
translated: When he comprehends them thus, he discerns their dependence thus: “These five aggregates with their conditions are dependent on the physical heart- basis.”

original: ettha paṭibaddha”nti. So atthato bhūtāni ceva upādārūpāni ca. Evamettha vatthu rūpaṃ,
analyzed: ettha paṭibaddhanti saḥ atthataḥ bhūtāni ca iva upādā rūpāni ca evam ettha vatthu rūpam
translated: The physical heart-basis is the material body, in reference to which it is said: “This my consciousness is dependent on, bound up with, this body” . The physical heart-basis is the four great primaries and the materiality derived from the great primaries. So here the physical heart-basis is materiality,

original: phassapañcamakā nāmanti nāmarūpamattameva passati. Rūpañcettha rūpakkhandho, nāmaṃ
analyzed: phassa pañcamakāḥ nāmanti nāma rūpam attam eva passati rūpam ca ittha rūpakkhandho nāmaṃ
translated: He sees only mentality-materiality, which is the five aggregates with contact as fifth. Herein, materiality is the materiality aggregate, and mentality

original: cattāro arūpino khandhāti pañcakkhandhamattaṃ hoti. Nāmarūpavinimuttā hi pañcakkhandhā,
analyzed: cattāro arūpino khandhā ti pañca kkhandha mattam hoti nāma rūpa vinimuttāḥ hi pañca kkhandhāḥ
translated: is the other four immaterial aggregates. For apart from mentality and materiality there are no five aggregates,

original: pañcakkhandhavinimuttaṃ vā nāmarūpaṃ natthi. So “ime pañcakkhandhā kiṃ hetukā”ti
analyzed: pañca kkhandha vinimuttam vā nāma rūpam natthi so ime pañca kkhandhā kiṃhetukā ti
translated: and apart from the five aggregates there is no mentality-materiality. He examines thus: “What is the cause of these five aggregates?”

original: upaparikkhanto “avijjādihetukā”ti passati. Tato “paccayo ceva paccayuppannañca idaṃ,
analyzed: upaparikkhantaḥ avijjā ādi hetukā ati passati tatas paccayaḥ ca iva paccaya uppannam ca idam
translated: He sees that it is ignorance, etc., and then he sees that this is a condition and what is conditioned by it.

original: añño satto vā puggalo vā natthi, suddhasaṅkhārapuñjamattamevā”ti sappaccayanāmarūpavasena
analyzed: aññaḥ sattaḥ vā puggalo vā natthi suddha saṅkhāra puñja mattam eva ati sappaccaya nāma rūpa vasena
translated: There is no other being or person. It is just a heap of pure formations. He comprehends mentality-materiality with its conditions

original: tilakkhaṇaṃ āropetvā vipassanāpaṭipāṭiyā “aniccaṃ dukkhaṃ anattā”ti sammasanto vicarati,🔽so ajja ajjāti paṭivedhaṃ ākaṅkhamāno tathārūpe divase utusappāyaṃ, puggalasappāyaṃ,
analyzed: ti lakkhaṇam āropetvā vipassanā paṭipāṭiyā aniccam dukkham anattā ti sammasantaḥ vicarati  saḥ ajja ajja ati paṭivedham ākaṅkhamāno tathārūpe divase utu sappāyam puggala sappāyam
translated: by characterizing it with the three characteristics in the order in which they arise in insight. He then considers it as “impermanent, painful, not-self,”🔽and he lives contemplating impermanence, etc., in formations. If he wishes to penetrate to the realization of the paths and fruits on that very day,

original: bhojanasappāyaṃ, dhammasavanasappāyaṃ vā labhitvā ekapallaṅkena nisinnova vipassanaṃ
analyzed: bhojana sappāyam dhamma savana sappāyam vā labhitvā eka pallaṅkena nisinnaḥ uva vipassanam
translated: he should obtain on that day suitable weather conditions, suitable personal conditions, suitable food, and suitable conditions for hearing the Dhamma. Then, sitting cross-legged, he should develop insight

original: matthakaṃ pāpetvā arahatte patiṭṭhāti. Evamimesampi tiṇṇaṃ janānaṃ yāva arahattā
analyzed: matthakam pāpetvā arahatte patiṭṭhāti evam imesam pi tiṇṇam janānam yāva arahattā
translated: and he establishes them in Arahantship.

original: kammaṭṭhānaṃ kathitaṃ hoti.
analyzed: kammaṭṭhānam kathitam hoti
translated: Thus the meditation subject has been taught for these three persons up to Arahantship.

original: Idha pana bhagavā arūpakammaṭṭhānaṃ kathento vedanāsīsena kathesi. Phassavasena hi
analyzed: idha pana bhagavā arūpa kammaṭṭhānam kathentaḥ vedanā sīsena kathesi phassa vasena hi
translated: But here the Blessed One, in teaching the immaterial states, taught them by way of the feelings.🔽For if he had taught them by way of contact or consciousness,

original: viññāṇavasena vā kathiyamānaṃ etassa na pākaṭaṃ hoti, andhakāraṃ viya khāyati. Vedanāvasena
analyzed: viññāṇa vasena vā kathiyamānam etassa na pākaṭam hoti andhakāram viya khāyati vedanā vasena
translated: they would not have been clear to this person, they would have seemed as if in the dark.🔽But by way of the feelings they are clear to him.

original: pana pākaṭaṃ hoti. Kasmā? Vedanānaṃ uppattiyā pākaṭatāya. Sukhadukkhavedanānañhi
analyzed: pana pākaṭam hoti kasmā vedanānaṃ uppattiyā pākaṭa tāya sukha dukkha vedanānaṃ hi
translated: And why? Because the arising of the feelings is clear.🔽For the arising of pleasant and painful feelings

original: uppatti pākaṭā. Yadā sukhaṃ uppajjati, tadā sakalaṃ sarīraṃ khobhentaṃ maddantaṃ
analyzed: uppatti pākaṭā yadā sukham uppajjati tadā sakalam sarīram khobhentam maddantam
translated: is clear. When pleasure arises, it does so making the whole body quiver and thrill,🔽as if anointing it with hot oil or massaging it,

original: pharamānaṃ abhisandayamānaṃ satadhotasappiṃ khādāpayantaṃ viya, satapākatelaṃ makkhayamānaṃ
analyzed: pharamānam abhisandayamānam satadhā uta sappim khādāpayantam viya sata pāka telam makkhayamānam
translated: as if extinguishing a fire lit in the body,

original: viya, ghaṭasahassena pariḷāhaṃ nibbāpayamānaṃ viya, “aho sukhaṃ, aho sukha”nti vācaṃ
analyzed: viya ghaṭa sahassena pariḷāham nibbāpayamānam viya aho sukham aho sukhanti vācam
translated: as if saying, “Ah, what pleasure!”

original: nicchārayamānameva uppajjati. Yadā dukkhaṃ uppajjati, tadā sakalasarīraṃ khobhentaṃ🔽maddantaṃ pharamānaṃ abhisandayamānaṃ tattaphālaṃ pavesentaṃ viya, vilīnatambalohena
analyzed: nicchārayamānam eva uppajjati yadā dukkham uppajjati tadā sakala sarīram khobhentam  maddantam pharamānam abhisandayamānam tatta phālam viya vilīna tamba lohena
translated: It arises as if it were being poured in. When pain arises, it arises as if it were shaking,

original: āsiñcantaṃ viya, sukkhatiṇavanappatimhi araññe dāruukkākalāpaṃ khipamānaṃ viya “aho🔽dukkhaṃ, aho dukkha”nti vippalāpayamānameva uppajjati. Iti sukhadukkhavedanānaṃ uppatti pākaṭā hoti.🔽Adukkhamasukhā pana duddīpanā andhakārena viya abhibhūtā. Sā sukhadukkhānaṃ apagame
analyzed: āsiñcantam viya sukkha tiṇa vanappatimhi araññe dāru ukkā kalāpam khipamānam viya aho  dukkham aho dukkhanti vippalāpayamānam eva uppajjati iti sukha dukkha vedanānam uppatti pākaṭā hoti  adukkham asukhā pana duddīpanā andhakārena viya abhibhūtā sā sukha dukkhānaṃ apagame
translated: crushing, tearing, and splitting the whole body, as if it were pouring in molten iron, as if it were throwing a bundle of sticks into dry grass, reeds, and forest trees, and as if it were crying out, “Oh, the pain, oh, the pain!”🔽Thus the arising of pleasant and painful feeling is evident.

original: sātāsātapaṭikkhepavasena majjhattākārabhūtā adukkhamasukhā vedanāti nayato gaṇhantassa
analyzed: sāta asāta paṭikkhepa vasena majjhatta ākāra bhūtā adukkham asukhā vedanā ati nayataḥ gaṇhantassa
translated: But the neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling is hard to explain, being as it is obscured, as it were, by darkness. It is evident to one who apprehends it by inference in this way: “When the cessation of pleasant and painful feeling is discerned, the state that remains is the neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling.”

original: pākaṭā hoti. Yathā kiṃ? Yathā antarā piṭṭhipāsāṇaṃ āruhitvā palātassa migassa anupadaṃ
analyzed: pākaṭā hoti yathā kim yathā antarā piṭṭhi pāsāṇam āruhitvā palātassa migassa anupadam
translated: How is it evident? It is like the track of a bird in the sky,

original: gacchanto migaluddako piṭṭhipāsāṇassa orabhāgepi parabhāgepi padaṃ disvā majjhe apassantopi
analyzed: gacchantaḥ migaluddakaḥ piṭṭhi pāsāṇassa ora bhāge pi para bhāge pi padam disvā majjhe a passantaḥ pi
translated: The hunter, as he goes along, sees the deer’s foot-marks in front and behind on the near side of the rock and on the far side of the rock, but he does not see them in the middle.

original: “ito āruḷho, ito oruḷho, majjhe piṭṭhipāsāṇe iminā padesena gato bhavissatī”ti nayato
analyzed: itas āruḷhaḥ itas oruḷhaḥ majjhe piṭṭhi pāsāṇe iminā padesena gataḥ bhavissati iti nayataḥ
translated: Nevertheless, he infers thus: ‘He must have gone by this part in the middle of the rock.’

original: jānāti. Evaṃ āruḷhaṭṭhāne padaṃ viya hi sukhavedanāya uppatti pākaṭā hoti, oruḷhaṭṭhāne
analyzed: jānāti evam āruḷha ṭṭhāne padam viya hi sukha vedanāya uppatti pākaṭā hoti oruḷha ṭṭhāne
translated: For just as the foot-mark is evident at the place of mounting, so the arising of pleasant feeling is evident;

original: padaṃ viya dukkhavedanāya uppatti pākaṭā hoti, ito āruyha, ito oruyha, majjhe evaṃ🔽gatoti nayato gahaṇaṃ viya sukhadukkhānaṃ apagame sātāsātapaṭikkhepavasena majjhattākārabhūtā
analyzed: padam viya dukkha vedanāya uppatti pākaṭā hoti itas āruyha itas oruyha majjhe evam  gataḥ ti nayataḥ gahaṇam viya sukha dukkhānam apagame sāta asāta paṭikkhepa vasena majjhatta ākāra bhūtā
translated: just as the foot-mark is evident at the place of dismounting, so the arising of painful feeling is evident;🔽and just as the apprehending of the going by this part in the middle is evident, so the apprehending of the neutral feeling that has become a state of equanimity by the rejection of pleasure and pain is evident.

original: adukkhamasukhā vedanāti nayato gaṇhantassa pākaṭā hoti. Evaṃ bhagavā paṭhamaṃ rūpakammaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: adukkham asukhā vedanā ti nayataḥ gaṇhantassa pākaṭā hoti evam bhagavā paṭhamam rūpa kammaṭṭhānam
translated: So the Blessed One first expounded the meditation subject of the kinds of materiality,

original: kathetvā pacchā arūpakammaṭṭhānaṃ vedanāvasena nivattetvā dassesi.
analyzed: kathetvā pacchā arūpa kammaṭṭhānam vedanā vasena nivattetvā dassesi
translated: and afterwards he expounded the meditation subject of the kinds of feeling by turning it up by the roots.

original: Na kevalañca idheva evaṃ dassesi, mahāsatipaṭṭhāne, majjhimanikāyamhi satipaṭṭhāne,
analyzed: na kevalam ca idha iva evam dassesi mahā sati paṭṭhāne majjhima nikāyamhi sati paṭṭhāne
translated: And not only here but also in the Great Forty, in the Majjhima Nikāya, in the Satipaṭṭhāna Sutta ,

original: cūḷataṇhāsaṅkhaye, mahātaṇhāsaṅkhaye, cūḷavedallasutte, mahāvedallasutte, raṭṭhapālasutte,
analyzed: cūḷa taṇhā saṅkhaye mahā taṇhā saṅkhaye cūḷavedalla sutte mahāvedalla sutte raṭṭhapāla sutte
translated: In the Cūḷa-Taṇhāsaṅkhaya Sutta, the Mahā-Taṇhāsaṅkhaya Sutta, the Cūḷa-Vedalla Sutta, the Mahā-Vedalla Sutta, the Ratthapala Sutta,

original: māgaṇḍiyasutte, dhātuvibhaṅge, āneñjasappāye, sakale vedanāsaṃyutteti evaṃ anekesu🔽suttantesu paṭhamaṃ rūpakammaṭṭhānaṃ kathetvā pacchā arūpakammaṭṭhānaṃ vedanāvasena🔽nivattetvā dassesi. Yathā ca tesu tesu, evaṃ imasmimpi sakkapañhe paṭhamaṃ rūpakammaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: māgaṇḍiya sutte dhātu vibhaṅge āneñjasappāye sakale vedanā saṃyuttā iti evam anekesu  suttantesu paṭhamam rūpa kammaṭṭhānam kathetvā pacchā arūpa kammaṭṭhānam vedanā vasena  nivattetvā dassesi yathā ca tesu tesu evam imasmin pi sakka pañhe paṭhamam rūpa kammaṭṭhānam
translated: the Māgaṇḍiya Sutta, the Dhātuvibhaṅga, the Āneñjasappāya, and the whole of the Feeling-Aggregate Sutta . In these and other suttas🔽he first expounded the meditation subject of foulness and afterwards, by way of feeling, he concluded with the meditation subject of the beautiful.

original: kathetvā pacchā arūpakammaṭṭhānaṃ vedanāvasena nivattetvā dassesi. Rūpakammaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: kathetvā pacchā arūpa kammaṭṭhānam vedanā vasena nivattetvā dassesi rūpa kammaṭṭhānam
translated: And just as in these various suttas, so here too in this very Sakka Question he first expounded the meditation subject of foulness and afterwards, by way of feeling, he concluded with the meditation subject of the beautiful.

original: panettha vedanāya ārammaṇamattakaṃyeva saṅkhittaṃ, tasmā pāḷiyaṃ nāruḷhaṃ bhavissati.
analyzed: pana ittha vedanāya ārammaṇa mattakam yā iva saṅkhittam tasmā pāḷiyam na āruḷham bhavissati
translated: But the meditation subject of foulness is only briefly mentioned here in the text as the object of mere attention, so it will not be elaborated here.

original: 360. Arūpakammaṭṭhāne yaṃ tassa pākaṭaṃ vedanāvasena abhinivesamukhaṃ, tameva dassetuṃ
analyzed: arūpa kammaṭṭhāne yam tassa pākaṭam vedanā vasena abhinivesa mukham tam eva dassetuṃ
translated: In the meditation subject of the beautiful he points out the aspect of perception that is evident to him by way of feeling,

original: somanassaṃpāhaṃ, devānamindātiādimāha. Tattha duvidhenāti dvividhena, dvīhi koṭṭhāsehīti
analyzed: devānam indā ti ādim āha tattha duvidhena ati dvividhena dvīhi koṭṭhāsehi iti
translated: saying “I say that happiness is a state with the possibility of equanimity” , and so on. Herein, two-factored is twofold, with two sections.

original: attho. Evarūpaṃ somanassaṃ na sevitabbanti evarūpaṃ gehasitasomanassaṃ na sevitabbaṃ.🔽Gehasitasomanassaṃ nāma “tattha katamāni cha gehasitāni somanassāni? Cakkhuviññeyyānaṃ
analyzed: attho evarūpam somanassam na sevitabbanti evarūpam gehasita somanassam na sevitabbam  gehasita somanassam nāma tattha katamāni cha gehasitāni somanassāni cakkhu viññeyyānam
translated: Meaning. Such joy should not be pursued: such joy connected with the household life should not be pursued.

original: rūpānaṃ iṭṭhānaṃ kantānaṃ manāpānaṃ manoramānaṃ lokāmisapaṭisaṃyuttānaṃ paṭilābhaṃ
analyzed: rūpānaṃ iṭṭhānam kantānam manāpānam manoramānam loka āmisa paṭisaṃyuttānam paṭilābham
translated: Joy connected with the household life is that stated in the way beginning, “Herein, what are the six kinds of joy connected with the household life? On seeing a visible object with the eye,

original: vā paṭilābhato samanupassato, pubbe vā paṭiladdhapubbaṃ atītaṃ niruddhaṃ vipariṇataṃ
analyzed: vā paṭilābhataḥ samanupassato pubbe vā paṭiladdha pubbam atītam niruddham vipariṇatam
translated: on seeing a desirable, pleasing, agreeable visible object, on recollecting it when it is past,

original: samanussarato uppajjati somanassaṃ, yaṃ evarūpaṃ somanassaṃ, idaṃ vuccati gehasitaṃ🔽somanassa”nti evaṃ chasu dvāresu vuttakāmaguṇanissitaṃ somanassaṃ.🔽Evarūpaṃ somanassaṃ sevitabbanti evarūpaṃ nekkhammasitaṃ somanassaṃ sevitabbaṃ. Nekkhammasitaṃ
analyzed: samanussarato uppajjati somanassam yam evarūpam somanassam idam vuccati gehasitam  somanassanti evam chasu dvāresu vutta kāmaguṇa nissitam somanassam  evarūpam somanassam sevitabbanti evarūpam nekkhamma sitam somanassam sevitabbam nekkhamma sitam
translated: there arises joy. Such joy as this is called joy connected with the household life” .

original: somanassaṃ nāma – “tattha katamāni cha nekkhammasitāni somanassāni? Rūpānaṃ tveva
analyzed: somanassam nāma tattha katamāni cha nekkhamma sitāni somanassāni rūpānam tu eva
translated: Such joy should be pursued: such joy connected with renunciation should be pursued. Joy connected with renunciation is that stated in the way beginning, “Herein, what are the six kinds of joy connected with renunciation? On seeing a visible object with the eye,

original: aniccataṃ viditvā vipariṇāmavirāganirodhaṃ pubbe ceva rūpā etarahi ca sabbe te rūpā
analyzed: anicca tam viditvā vipariṇāma virāga nirodham pubbe ca iva rūpāḥ etarahi ca sabbe te rūpāḥ
translated: Having known impermanence, change, fading away, and cessation, both former and present forms,🔽

original: aniccā, dukkhā, vipariṇāmadhammāti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya passato uppajjati
analyzed: aniccā dukkhā vipariṇāma dhammā ti evam etam yathābhūtam sammappaññāya passato uppajjati
translated: When he has seen as they actually are with proper wisdom that all material things are impermanent, subject to suffering, and subject to change, then joy arises in him.

original: somanassaṃ, yaṃ evarūpaṃ somanassaṃ, idaṃ vuccati nekkhammasitaṃ somanassa”nti evaṃ🔽chasu dvāresu iṭṭhārammaṇe āpāthagate aniccādivasena vipassanaṃ paṭṭhapetvā ussukkāpetuṃ
analyzed: somanassam yam evarūpam somanassam idam vuccati nekkhamma sitam somanassanti evam  chasu dvāresu iṭṭha ārammaṇe āpātha gate anicca ādi vasena vipassanam paṭṭhapetvā ussukkāpetum
translated: This kind of joy is called “joy based on renunciation.”🔽When he has thus begun insight by means of the contemplation of impermanence, etc., in the six bases beginning with visible forms, and he is able to keep it going, then his joy is called “my insight is progressing.”

original: sakkontassa “ussukkitā me vipassanā”ti somanassajātassa uppannaṃ somanassaṃ. Sevitabbanti
analyzed: sakkontassa ussukkitā me vipassanā ati somanassa jātassa uppannam somanassam sevitabbanti
translated: “To be cultivated”:

original: idaṃ nekkhammavasena, vipassanāvasena, anussativasena, paṭhamajjhānādivasena ca uppajjanakasomanassaṃ sevitabbaṃ nāma.
analyzed: idam nekkhamma vasena vipassanā vasena anussati vasena paṭhama jhāna ādi vasena ca uppajjanaka somanassam sevitabbam nāma
translated: the kind of joy that arises through renunciation, through insight, through recollection of the Buddha, etc., and through the first jhāna, etc., is what should be cultivated.

original: Tattha yaṃ ce savitakkaṃ savicāranti tasmimpi nekkhammasite somanasse yaṃ nekkhammavasena,
analyzed: tattha yam ce sa vitakkam sa vicāranti tasmin pi nekkhamma site somanasse yam nekkhamma vasena
translated: Herein, as regards the words “accompanied by applied thought and accompanied by sustained thought” , the joy based on renunciation that arises through renunciation, through insight,

original: vipassanāvasena, anussativasena, paṭhamajjhānavasena ca uppannaṃ savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ
analyzed: vipassanā vasena anussati vasena paṭhama jhāna vasena ca uppannam sa vitakkam sa vicāram
translated: and arisen through insight, through recollection, and through the first jhāna, is accompanied by applied and sustained thought.

original: somanassanti jāneyya. Yaṃ ce avitakkaṃ avicāranti yaṃ pana dutiyatatiyajjhānavasena
analyzed: somanassanti jāneyya yam ce a vitakkam a vicāranti yam pana dutiya tatiya jhāna vasena
translated: He should know that the happiness arisen through the second and third jhānas is without applied thought and sustained thought.

original: uppannaṃ avitakkaṃ avicāraṃ somanassanti jāneyya. Ye avitakke avicāre, te paṇītatareti
analyzed: uppannam a vitakkam a vicāram somanassanti jāneyya ye a vitakke a vicāre te paṇītatarā iti
translated: And he should know that the happiness without applied thought and sustained thought is superior.

original: etesupi dvīsu yaṃ avitakkaṃ avicāraṃ, taṃ paṇītataranti attho.🔽Iminā kiṃ kathitaṃ hoti? Dvinnaṃ arahattaṃ kathitaṃ. Kathaṃ? Eko kira bhikkhu savitakkasavicāre
analyzed: etesu pi dvīsu yam a vitakkam a vicāram tam  iminā kim kathitam hoti dvinnam arahattam kathitam katham ekaḥ kira bhikkhu sa vitakka sa vicāre
translated: The meaning is that of the two kinds of happiness, that without applied and sustained thought is superior.

original: somanasse vipassanaṃ paṭṭhapetvā “idaṃ somanassaṃ kiṃ nissita”nti upadhārento “vatthunissita”nti
analyzed: somanasse vipassanam paṭṭhapetvā idam somanassam kim nissitanti upadhārento vatthu nissitanti
translated: What is stated here? The two kinds of arahatship are stated. How? A certain bhikkhu, it seems, undertook insight with happiness accompanied by applied and sustained thought. He considered “What is this happiness supported by? ” and he understood “It is supported by the physical basis.”🔽Then he established himself in the attainment of arahatship in the way already described in the case of the five aggregates beginning with “contact.”

original: pajānātīti phassapañcamake vuttanayeneva anukkamena arahatte patiṭṭhāti. Eko avitakkaavicāre
analyzed: pajānāti iti phassa pañcamake vutta nayena iva anukkamena arahatte patiṭṭhāti ekaḥ avitakka avicāre
translated: A certain bhikkhu undertook insight with happiness without applied and sustained thought.

original: somanasse vipassanaṃ paṭṭhapetvā vuttanayeneva arahatte patiṭṭhāti. Tattha abhiniviṭṭhasomanassesupi
analyzed: somanasse vipassanam paṭṭhapetvā vutta nayena iva arahatte patiṭṭhāti tattha abhiniviṭṭha somanassesu pi
translated: Herein, the joy that is clung to is inferior

original: savitakkasavicārato avitakkaavicāraṃ paṇītataraṃ. Savitakkasavicārasomanassavipassanātopi
analyzed: sa vitakka sa vicārataḥ avitakka avicāram paṇītataram sa vitakka sa vicāra somanassa vipassanātaḥ pi
translated: to the joy that is not so. And the insight with joy that is not clung to is more excellent than the insight with joy that is clung to.🔽And the insight with joy that is not clung to is more excellent than the insight with joy that is clung to.

original: avitakkaavicāravipassanā paṇītatarā. Savitakkasavicārasomanassaphalasamāpattitopi🔽avitakkaavicārasomanassaphalasamāpattiyeva paṇītatarā. Tenāha bhagavā “ye avitakke
analyzed: a vitakka a vicāra vipassanā paṇītatarā sa vitakka sa vicāra somanassa phala samāpattitaḥ pi  a vitakka a vicāra somanassa phala samāpattiyā iva paṇītatarā tena āha bhagavā ye a vitakke
translated: And the fruition attainment with joy that is not clung to is more excellent than the fruition attainment with joy that is clung to.

original: avicāre, te paṇītatare”ti.
analyzed: a vicāre te paṇītatarā iti
translated: That is why the Blessed One said: “Those that are without thought and without exploration are more excellent” .

original: 361. Evarūpaṃ domanassaṃ na sevitabbanti evarūpaṃ gehasitadomanassaṃ na sevitabbaṃ.
analyzed: evarūpam domanassam na sevitabbanti evarūpam gehasita domanassam na sevitabbam
translated: Such grief should not be indulged in: such grief as is indulged in by a clansman who is a worldling should not be indulged in.

original: Gehasitadomanassaṃ nāma – “tattha katamāni cha gehasitāni domanassāni? Cakkhuviññeyyānaṃ
analyzed: gehasita domanassam nāma tattha katamāni cha gehasitāni domanassāni cakkhu viññeyyānam
translated: What is called “grief indulged in by a clansman” is as follows. Herein, what are the six kinds of grief indulged in by a clansman?

original: rūpānaṃ iṭṭhānaṃ kantānaṃ manāpānaṃ manoramānaṃ lokāmisapaṭisaṃyuttānaṃ appaṭilābhaṃ
analyzed: rūpānam iṭṭhānam kantānam manāpānam manoramānam loka āmisa paṭisaṃyuttānam a paṭilābham
translated: When there is non-acquisition of visible objects cognizable by the eye, desirable, pleasing, agreeable, lovable, connected with worldliness, sensuous, sensual,🔽and so on.

original: vā appaṭilābhato samanupassato pubbe vā apaṭiladdhapubbaṃ atītaṃ niruddhaṃ vipariṇataṃ
analyzed: vā a paṭilābhataḥ samanupassato pubbe vā a paṭiladdha pubbam atītam niruddham vipariṇatam
translated: or he does not see it as obtainable, then, if he has not previously obtained it, it is past, ceased, changed;🔽

original: samanussarato uppajjati domanassaṃ, yaṃ evarūpaṃ domanassaṃ, idaṃ vuccati gehasitadomanassa”nti.
analyzed: samanussarato uppajjati domanassam yam evarūpam domanassam idam vuccati gehasita domanassa nti
translated: or he does not get what is not got, or he sees what is not seen, or he does not attain what is not attained, or he does not understand what is not understood, then sorrow arises in him. Whatever sorrow, sorrowing, sorrowfulness, inner sorrow, inward sorrowing, inward sorrowfulness, vexation, sorrowing due to vexation, the state of sorrowing, the state of vexation, grief, the state of grief, the sorrowing aggregate, the sorrowing constituent, the sorrowing element, the state of sorrow, the state of vexation, this is called sorrow born of home life.🔽“And what is sorrow born of renunciation? Here, bhikkhus, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unwholesome states, a bhikkhu enters upon and abides in the first jhana…🔽With the stilling of applied and sustained thought, he enters upon and abides in the second jhana…

original: Evaṃ chasu dvāresu iṭṭhārammaṇaṃ nānubhaviṃ, nānubhavissāmi, nānubhavāmīti vitakkayato
analyzed: evam chasu dvāresu iṭṭha ārammaṇam na anubhavim na anubhavissāmi na anubhavāmi iti vitakkayato
translated: With the fading away as well of rapture, he enters upon and abides in the third jhana…

original: uppannaṃ kāmaguṇanissitaṃ domanassaṃ.
analyzed: uppannam kāma guṇa nissitam domanassam
translated: With the abandoning of pleasure and pain…he enters upon and abides in the fourth jhana…

original: Evarūpaṃ domanassaṃ sevitabbanti evarūpaṃ nekkhammasitadomanassaṃ sevitabbaṃ. Nekkhammasitadomanassaṃ
analyzed: evarūpam domanassam sevitabbanti evarūpam nekkhamma sita domanassam sevitabbam nekkhamma sita domanassam
translated: “Therein, bhikkhus, whatever sorrow, sorrowing, sorrowfulness, inner sorrow, inward sorrowing, inward sorrowfulness, vexation, sorrowing due to vexation, the state of sorrowing, the state of vexation, grief, the state of grief, the sorrowing aggregate, the sorrowing constituent, the sorrowing element, the state of sorrow, the state of vexation, this is called sorrow born of renunciation.

original: nāma – “tattha katamāni cha nekkhammasitāni domanassāni? Rūpānaṃ tveva aniccataṃ🔽viditvā vipariṇāmavirāganirodhaṃ pubbe ceva rūpā etarahi ca sabbe te rūpā aniccā,
analyzed: nāma tattha katamāni cha nekkhamma sitāni domanassāni rūpānam tu eva aniccataṃ  viditvā vipariṇāma virāga nirodham pubbe ca iva rūpāḥ etarahi ca sabbe te rūpāḥ aniccā
translated: “Therein, bhikkhus, what are the six kinds of sorrow born of renunciation?🔽Having known the impermanence of forms, their change, fading away, and cessation, he sees that all forms, whether past or present, are impermanent, suffering, and subject to change.

original: dukkhā, vipariṇāmadhammāti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sampappaññāya disvā anuttaresu vimokkhesu
analyzed: dukkhāḥ vipariṇāma dhammā ti evam etam yathābhūtam sampappaññāya disvā anuttaresu vimokkhesu
translated: Having seen this thus as it actually is with proper wisdom, he turns away from all forms, his desire for them fades away, and he is liberated by nonclinging.

original: pihaṃ upaṭṭhāpeti ‘kudāssu nāmāhaṃ tadāyatanaṃ, upasampajja viharissāmi, yadariyā
analyzed: piham upaṭṭhāpeti kudāssu nāma aham tad āyatanam upasampajja viharissāmi yat ariyā
translated: he is intent on that attainment, thinking: ‘When, by realising for myself with direct knowledge,🔽shall I here and now enter upon and abide in that supreme goal of the holy life for the sake of which clansmen rightly go forth from the home life into homelessness?’

original: etarahi āyatanaṃ upasampajja viharantī’ti. Iti anuttaresu vimokkhesu pihaṃ upaṭṭhāpayato
analyzed: etarahi āyatanam upasampajja viharanti iti iti anuttaresu vimokkhesu piham upaṭṭhāpayato
translated: He cherishes a longing for the attainment thus, ‘When, oh when, shall I attain and dwell in that attainment which the Noble Ones now attain and in which they now dwell? ‘ Thus he cherishes a longing for the unsurpassed deliverance of the mind.🔽So when he cherishes a longing in this way,

original: uppajjati pihapaccayā domanassaṃ, yaṃ evarūpaṃ domanassaṃ, idaṃ vuccati nekkhammasitadomanassa”nti🔽evaṃ chasu dvāresu iṭṭhārammaṇe āpāthagate anuttaravimokkhasaṅkhātaariyaphaladhammesu
analyzed: uppajjati piha paccayā domanassam yam evarūpam domanassam idam vuccati nekkhamma sita domanassa nti  evam chasu dvāresu iṭṭha ārammaṇe āpātha gate anuttara vimokkha saṅkhāta ariya phala dhammesu
translated: grief arises in him with that longing as condition. Any such grief is called grief at separation due to renunciation.🔽So when he cherishes a longing in this way for the desirable object that has come into focus in the six bases of contact,

original: pihaṃ upaṭṭhapetvā tadadhigamāya aniccādivasena vipassanaṃ paṭṭhapetvā ussukkāpetumasakkontassa
analyzed: piham upaṭṭhapetvā tad adhigamāya anicca ādi vasena vipassanam paṭṭhapetvā ussukkāpetum asakkontassa
translated: and he is unable to apply himself to insight by contemplating the impermanence, etc., in order to attain the noble fruition called the unsurpassed deliverance of the mind,

original: imampi pakkhaṃ, imampi māsaṃ, imampi saṃvaccharaṃ vipassanaṃ ussukkāpetvā ariyabhūmiṃ
analyzed: imam pi pakkham imam pi māsam imam pi saṃvaccharam vipassanam ussukkāpetvā ariya bhūmim
translated: and he is unable to apply himself to insight for a fortnight, a month, or a year, and he is unable to reach the plane of the Noble Ones,

original: pāpuṇituṃ nāsakkhinti anusocato uppannaṃ domanassaṃ. Sevitabbanti idaṃ nekkhammavasena,
analyzed: pāpuṇitum na asakkhinti anusocataḥ uppannam domanassam sevitabbanti idam nekkhamma vasena
translated: then grief arises in him as he recollects his failure. This is called grief at separation due to renunciation.

original: vipassanāvasena, anussativasena, paṭhamajjhānādivasena ca uppajjanakadomanassaṃ sevitabbaṃ nāma.🔽Tattha yaṃ ce savitakkasavicāranti tasmimpi duvidhe domanasse gehasitadomanassameva🔽savitakkasavicāradomanassaṃ nāma. Nekkhammavasena, vipassanāvasena, anussativasena,
analyzed: vipassanā vasena anussati vasena paṭhama jhāna ādi vasena ca uppajjanaka domanassam sevitabbam nāma  tattha yam ce tasmim pi duvidhe domanasse geha sita domanassam eva  sa vitakka sa vicāra domanassam nāma nekkhamma vasena vipassanā vasena anussati vasena
translated: and the kind that arises through insight, through recollection, and through the first jhāna, etc., should be cultivated.🔽Herein, the kind of grief that is called with applied and sustained thought is the grief that is rooted in the home life.

original: paṭhamadutiyajjhānavasena ca uppannadomanassaṃ pana avitakkaavicāradomanassanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: paṭhama dutiya jhāna vasena ca uppanna domanassam pana avitakka avicāra domanassa nti veditabbam
translated: The kind that arises through renunciation, through insight, through recollection, and through the first and second jhānas should be understood as the kind without applied and sustained thought.

original: Nippariyāyena pana avitakkaavicāradomanassaṃ nāma natthi. Domanassindriyañhi ekaṃsena🔽akusalañceva savitakkasavicārañca, etassa pana bhikkhuno maññanavasena savitakkasavicāranti
analyzed: nippariyāyena pana avitakka avicāra domanassam nāma natthi domanassindriyam hi ekaṃsena  akusalam ca iva sa vitakka sa vicārañca etassa pana bhikkhuno maññana vasena sa vitakka sa vicāranti
translated: But in the ultimate sense there is no grief without applied and sustained thought. For the grief faculty is unwholesome and always accompanied by applied and sustained thought.

original: ca avitakkaavicāranti ca vuttaṃ.
analyzed: ca avitakka avicāram ti ca vuttam
translated: But this bhikkhu’s grief is called with applied and sustained thought and without applied and sustained thought according to the way he reflects on it.

original: Tatrāyaṃ nayo – idha bhikkhu domanassapaccayabhūte savitakkasavicāradhamme avitakkaavicāradhamme
analyzed: tatra ayam nayaḥ idha bhikkhu domanassa paccaya bhūte sa vitakka sa vicāra dhamme avitakka avicāra dhamme
translated: Here is the way. The bhikkhu should reflect on the things that are the conditions for grief as being with applied and sustained thought and without applied and sustained thought.

original: ca domanassapaccayā eva uppanne maggaphaladhamme ca aññesaṃ paṭipattidassanavasena
analyzed: ca domanassa paccayā eva uppanne magga phala dhamme ca aññesam paṭipatti dassana vasena
translated: and the states of the path and fruit that have arisen due to grief, and others, by way of the seeing of practice,

original: domanassanti gahetvā “kadā nu kho me savitakkasavicāradomanasse vipassanā paṭṭhapitā🔽bhavissati, kadā avitakkaavicāradomanasse”ti ca “kadā nu kho me savitakkasavicāradomanassaphalasamāpatti

original: ekaṃ dve maggaphalāni nibbattessāmīti rodāmi, bhante”ti.
analyzed: ekam dve magga phalāni nibbattessāmi iti rodāmi bhante iti
translated: am a goddess.” “Why are you weeping?” “I am weeping because I have attained the paths and fruits while weeping. I thought, ‘I will weep and so attain one or two paths and fruits.’ That is why I am weeping, venerable sir.”

original: Tato thero – “bho mahāsīvatthera, devatāpi tayā saddhiṃ keḷiṃ karonti, anucchavikaṃ
analyzed: tatas theraḥ bho mahāsīva thera devatā api tayā saddhim keḷim karonti anucchavikam
translated: Then the elder thought, “Venerable Mahā-Sīva, even the deities are playing with you. Is this becoming of you?

original: nu kho te eta”nti vipassanaṃ vaḍḍhetvā saha paṭisambhidāhi arahattaṃ aggahesi. So🔽“idāni nipajjissāmī”ti senāsanaṃ paṭijaggitvā mañcakaṃ paññapetvā udakaṭṭhāne udakaṃ
analyzed: nu kho te etat ti vipassanam vaḍḍhetvā saha paṭisambhidāhi arahattam aggahesi so  idāni nipajjissāmi iti senāsanam paṭijaggitvā mañcakam paññapetvā udakaṭṭhāne udakaṃ
translated: ” He increased his insight and reached Arahantship together with the discriminations.

original: paccupaṭṭhapetvā “pāde dhovissāmī”ti sopānaphalake nisīdi.
analyzed: paccupaṭṭhapetvā pāde dhovissāmi iti sopāna phalake nisīdi
translated: He thought, “Now I will lie down,” and he prepared his lodging, arranged his resting place, set out water for drinking and water for washing, and sat down on the step of the staircase to wash his feet.

original: Antevāsikāpissa “amhākaṃ ācariyassa samaṇadhammaṃ kātuṃ gacchantassa tiṃsa vassāni,
analyzed: antevāsika apissa amhākam ācariyassa samaṇa dhammam kātum gacchantassa tiṃsa vassāni
translated: His pupil thought, “For thirty years I have been following my teacher as he went to do his ascetic,

original: sakkhi nu kho visesaṃ nibbattetuṃ, nāsakkhī”ti āvajjayamānā “arahattaṃ patvā pādadhovanatthaṃ🔽nisinno”ti disvā “amhākaṃ ācariyo amhādisesu antevāsikesu tiṭṭhantesu ‘attanāva pāde🔽dhovissatī’ti aṭṭhānametaṃ, ahaṃ dhovissāmi ahaṃ dhovissāmī”ti tiṃsasahassānipi ākāsena
analyzed: sakkhi nu kho visesam nibbattetum na asakkhi iti āvajjayamānāḥ arahattam patvā pāda dhovana attham  nisinnaḥ ti disvā amhākam ācariyaḥ amhādisesu antevāsikesu tiṭṭhantesu pāde  dhovissati iti aṭṭhānam etam aham dhovissāmi aham dhovissāmi iti tiṃsa sahassāni pi ākāsena
translated: “Did he succeed in developing distinction or not?” As she was adverting her mind to this, she saw him sitting down to wash his feet after attaining Arahantship.

original: gantvā vanditvā “pāde dhovissāma, bhante”ti āhaṃsu. Āvuso, idāni tiṃsa vassāni honti
analyzed: gantvā vanditvā pāde dhovissāma bhante ti āhaṃsu āvuso idāni tiṃsa vassāni honti
translated: “It is not possible that our teacher should wash his own feet when we, his pupils, are standing here. I will wash them. I will wash them,” and thirty thousand of them went through the air and paid homage to him, saying, “Venerable sir, we will wash his feet.”

original: mama pādānaṃ adhotānaṃ, tiṭṭhatha, tumhe, ahameva dhovissāmīti.
analyzed: mama pādānam a dhotānam tiṭṭhatha tumhe aham eva dhovissāmi iti
translated: “Friends, it is thirty years since my feet were washed. Stand aside, I will wash them myself.”

original: Sakkopi āvajjanto – “mayhaṃ ayyo mahāsīvatthero arahattaṃ patto tiṃsasahassānaṃ antevāsikānaṃ🔽‘pāde dhovissāmā’ti āgatānaṃ pāde dhovituṃ na deti. Mādise pana upaṭṭhāke tiṭṭhante
analyzed: sakkaḥ api āvajjantaḥ mayham ayyaḥ mahāsīva theraḥ arahattam pattaḥ tiṃsa sahassānam antevāsikānam  pāde dhovissāma ati āgatānam pāde dhovitum na deti mādise pana upaṭṭhāke tiṭṭhante
translated: Sakka, too, was adverting his mind to this, thinking, “My venerable elder Mahā-Sīva has attained Arahantship. Thirty thousand pupils have come to wash his feet,

original: ‘mayhaṃ ayyo sayaṃ pāde dhovissatī’ti aṭṭhānametaṃ, ahaṃ dhovissāmī”ti sanniṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: mayham ayyo sayam pāde dhovissati iti aṭṭhānam etam aham dhovissāmi iti sanniṭṭhānam
translated: but he will not let them. But it is not possible that he should wash his own feet when a servant like me is standing here. I will wash them.” And he made up his mind thus.

original: katvā sujātāya deviyā saddhiṃ bhikkhusaṅghassa santike pāturahosi. So sujaṃ asurakaññaṃ
analyzed: katvā sujātāya deviyā saddhim bhikkhu saṅghassa santike pāturahosi saḥ su jam asura kaññam
translated: and together with Queen Sujātā, he appeared before the Community of monks. He gave Sujātā the asura maiden

original: purato katvā “apetha, bhante, mātugāmo”ti okāsaṃ kāretvā theraṃ upasaṅkamitvā vanditvā🔽purato ukkuṭiko nisīditvā “pāde dhovissāmi, bhante”ti āha. Kosiya, idāni me tiṃsa
analyzed: puratas katvā apetha bhante mātugāmaḥ iti okāsam kāretvā theram upasaṅkamitvā vanditvā  puratas ukkuṭikaḥ nisīditvā pāde dhovissāmi bhante ti āha kosiya idāni me tiṃsa
translated: and he appeared before the Community of monks together with Queen Sujātā. He made a space for the monks, saying, “Go away, Venerables, women are impure,” and he approached the Elder, worshipped him,

original: vassāni pādānaṃ adhotānaṃ, devatānañca pakatiyāpi manussasarīragandho nāma jeguccho,
analyzed: vassāni pādānam adhotānam devatānam ca pakatiyā api manussa sarīra gandho nāma jegucchaḥ
translated: and sat down in front of him cross-legged, saying, “I will wash your feet, Venerable.” “Kosiya, it has been thirty years since I washed my feet, and the natural smell of a human body is disgusting to the gods,

original: yojanasate ṭhitānampi kaṇṭhe āsattakuṇapaṃ viya hoti, ahameva dhovissāmīti. Bhante,
analyzed: yojana sate ṭhitānam pi kaṇṭhe āsatta kuṇapam viya hoti aham eva dhovissāmi iti bhante
translated: it is like a rotting corpse hanging around their necks, even if it is a hundred leagues away. I will wash them myself.” “Venerable,

original: ayaṃ gandho nāma na paññāyati, tumhākaṃ pana sīlagandho cha devaloke atikkamitvā
analyzed: ayam gandhaḥ nāma na paññāyati tumhākam pana sīlagandho deva loke atikkamitvā
translated: this smell is not noticeable, but the smell of your virtue has gone beyond the six divine worlds

original: upari bhavaggaṃ patvā ṭhito. Sīlagandhato añño uttaritaro gandho nāma natthi, bhante,
analyzed: upari bhavaggam patvā ṭhitaḥ sīla gandhato aññaḥ uttaritaraḥ gandho nāma natthi bhante
translated: and has reached the highest heaven. There is no smell superior to the smell of virtue, Venerable,

original: tumhākaṃ sīlagandhenamhi āgatoti vāmahatthena gopphakasandhiyaṃ gahetvā dakkhiṇahatthena
analyzed: tumhākam āgataḥ ti vāma hatthena gopphaka sandhiyam gahetvā dakkhiṇa hatthena
translated: I have come because of the smell of your virtue.” He took hold of the Elder’s ankle with his left hand at the joint, and with his right hand he took hold of the foot, and he washed the Elder’s feet.

original: pādatalaṃ parimajji. Daharakumārasseva pādā ahesuṃ. Sakko pāde dhovitvā vanditvā devalokameva gato.
analyzed: pāda talam parimajji dahara kumārassa iva pādāḥ ahesum sakkaḥ pāde dhovitvā vanditvā deva lokam eva gataḥ
translated: and his feet became like those of a young boy. Sakka washed his feet, worshipped him, and went off to the divine world.

original: Evaṃ “na labhāmi sabrahmacārīhi saddhiṃ visuddhipavāraṇaṃ pavāretu”nti āvajjantassa
analyzed: evam na labhāmi sabrahmacārīhi saddhim visuddhi pavāraṇam pavāretun ti āvajjantassa
translated: So when he adverts thinking, “I do not get to hold the Invitation ceremony with my companions in the life of purity,”

original: uppannaṃ domanassaṃ nissāya bhikkhuno maññanavasena vipassanāya ārammaṇampi vipassanāpi
analyzed: uppannam domanassam nissāya bhikkhuno maññana vasena vipassanāya ārammaṇam pi vipassanā api
translated: the displeasure that arises in him is called “displeasure” in the description of the contemplation of displeasure in the case of one who develops insight by the way of perception,

original: maggopi phalampi savitakkasavicāradomanassanti ca avitakkāvicāradomanassanti ca vuttanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: maggaḥ api phalam pi sa vitakka sa vicāra domanassanti ca avitakka avicāra domanassanti ca vuttanti veditabbam
translated: and the object of that contemplation, the contemplation itself, the path, and the fruition are called “displeasure accompanied by applied and sustained thought” and “displeasure without applied thought but with sustained thought” respectively.

original: Tattha eko bhikkhu savitakkasavicāradomanasse vipassanaṃ paṭṭhapetvā idaṃ domanassaṃ
analyzed: tattha ekaḥ bhikkhu sa vitakka sa vicāra domanasse vipassanam paṭṭhapetvā idam domanassam
translated: Herein, one bhikkhu, after arousing insight by developing the contemplation of displeasure in the case of displeasure accompanied by applied and sustained thought,

original: kiṃ nissitanti upadhārento vatthunissitanti pajānātīti phassapañcamake vuttanayeneva
analyzed: kim nissitanti upadhārentaḥ vatthu nissitanti pajānāti iti phassa pañcamake vutta nayena iva
translated: examines the question, “What is this displeasure supported by?” and he understands thus, “It is supported by a physical basis,” according to the method given in the Description of the Five- constituent Being .

original: anukkamena arahatte patiṭṭhāti. Eko avitakkāvicāre domanasse vipassanaṃ paṭṭhapetvā
analyzed: anukkamena arahatte patiṭṭhāti ekaḥ a vitakka a vicāre domanasse vipassanam paṭṭhapetvā
translated: and he is established in Arahantship in due course. Another arouses insight by developing the contemplation of displeasure in the case of displeasure without applied thought but with sustained thought,🔽and he is established in Arahantship in due course.

original: vuttanayeneva arahatte patiṭṭhāti. Tattha abhiniviṭṭhadomanassesupi savitakkasavicārato🔽avitakkaavicāraṃ paṇītataraṃ. Savitakkasavicāradomanassavipassanātopi avitakkāvicāradomanassavipassanā
analyzed: vutta nayena iva arahatte patiṭṭhāti tattha abhiniviṭṭha domanassesu pi sa vitakka sa vicārato  avitakka avicāram paṇītataram sa vitakka sa vicāra domanassa vipassanātaḥ pi avitakka avicāra domanassa vipassanā
translated: Herein, the equanimity of the fine-material sphere is more excellent than the equanimity of the sense sphere, which is accompanied by applied and sustained thought, in the way already described.🔽And the equanimity of the immaterial sphere is more excellent than the equanimity of the fine-material sphere.

original: paṇītatarā. Savitakkasavicāradomanassaphalasamāpattitopi avitakkāvicāradomanassaphalasamāpattiyeva
analyzed: paṇītatarā sa vitakka sa vicāra domanassa phala samāpattitaḥ pi avitakka avicāra domanassa phala samāpattiyā iva
translated: And the fruition attainment of the immaterial sphere is more excellent than the fruition attainment of the fine-material sphere.

original: paṇītatarā. Tenāha bhagavā – “ye avitakkaavicāre te paṇītatare”ti.
analyzed: paṇītatarā tena āha bhagavā ye a vitakka a vicāre te paṇītatarā iti
translated: That is why the Blessed One said: “Those that are without applied thought and sustained thought are more excellent” .

original: 362. Evarūpā upekkhā na sevitabbāti evarūpā gehasitaupekkhā na sevitabbā. Gehasitaupekkhā
analyzed: evarūpā upekkhā na sevitabbā ati evarūpā geha sita aupekkhā na sevitabbā geha sita aupekkhā
translated: Such equanimity should not be pursued: such equanimity as is called “of the house life” should not be pursued.

original: nāma “tattha katamā cha gehasitaupekkhā. Cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvā uppajjati upekkhā bālassa
analyzed: nāma tattha katamā cha gehasita aupekkhā cakkhunā rūpam disvā uppajjati upekkhā bālassa
translated: What is called “of the house life” is this: “Herein, what is equanimity of the house life?

original: mūḷhassa puthujjanassa anodhijinassa avipākajinassa anādīnavadassāvino assutavato
analyzed: mūḷhassa puthujjanassa anodhi jinassa avipāka jinassa anādīnava dassāvinaḥ assutavataḥ
translated: On seeing a visible object with the eye, equanimity arises in a fool, an undeveloped ordinary person, one not in training, one not a conqueror, one not a seer of the danger of wrongdoing, one who is not a knower of the Noble Ones’ arising and passing away, an undeveloped person.

original: puthujjanassa, yā evarūpā upekkhā, rūpaṃ sā nātivattati, tasmā sā upekkhā gehasitāti
analyzed: puthujjanassa yā evarūpā upekkhā rūpam sā na ativattati tasmā sā upekkhā gehasitā ati
translated: Such equanimity as this does not transcend the visible object. That is why this equanimity is called ‘of the house life.’

original: vuccatī”ti evaṃ chasu dvāresu iṭṭhārammaṇe āpāthagate guḷapiṇḍike nilīnamakkhikā🔽viya rūpādīni anativattamānā tattheva laggā laggitā hutvā uppannā kāmaguṇanissitā
analyzed: vuccati iti evam chasu dvāresu iṭṭha ārammaṇe āpātha gate guḷa piṇḍike nilīna makkhikā  rūpa ādīni an ativattamānā tattha iva laggā laggitā hutvā uppannā kāmaguṇa nissitā
translated: “It is called ‘detached’ ” .

original: upekkhā na sevitabbā.
analyzed: upekkhā na sevitabbā
translated: So when a desirable object comes into focus in the six doors, this equanimity dependent on the five cords of sense desire, which arises in one who does not transcend the object but sticks to it like a fly in treacle, should not be cultivated.

original: Evarūpā upekkhā sevitabbāti evarūpā nekkhammasitā upekkhā sevitabbā. Nekkhammasitā
analyzed: evarūpā upekkhā sevitabbā ati evarūpā nekkhamma sitā upekkhā sevitabbā nekkhamma sitā
translated: “Such equanimity should be cultivated”: such equanimity as is detached should be cultivated.

original: upekkhā nāma – “tattha katamā cha nekkhammasitā upekkhā? Rūpānaṃ tveva aniccataṃ
analyzed: upekkhā nāma tattha katamā cha nekkhamma sitā upekkhā rūpānam tu eva anicca taṃ
translated: Equanimity that is detached is described in the way beginning, “Herein, what is equanimity that is detached? When one contemplating impermanence …

original: viditvā vipariṇāmavirāganirodhaṃ ‘pubbe ceva rūpā etarahi ca, sabbe te rūpā aniccā,
analyzed: viditvā vipariṇāma virāga nirodham pubbe ca iva rūpāḥ etarahi ca sabbe te rūpāḥ aniccā
translated: knows thus far and no more, equanimity arises. That equanimity is detached from form,

original: dukkhā, vipariṇāmadhammā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya passato uppajjati🔽upekkhā, yā evarūpā upekkhā, rūpaṃ sā ativattati, tasmā sā upekkhā nekkhammasitāti
analyzed: dukkhā vipariṇāma dhammā ti evam etam yathābhūtam sammappaññāya passato uppajjati  upekkhā yā evarūpā upekkhā rūpam sā ativattati tasmā sā upekkhā nekkhamma sitā ati
translated: and so on. That is why that equanimity is called ‘detached’ ” .

original: vuccatī”ti. Evaṃ chasu dvāresu iṭṭhāniṭṭhaārammaṇe āpāthagate iṭṭhe arajjantassa,
analyzed: vuccati iti evam chasu dvāresu iṭṭha aniṭṭha ārammaṇe āpātha gate iṭṭhe a rajjantassa
translated: So when a desirable or undesirable object comes into focus in the six doors, this equanimity that is detached should be cultivated.

original: aniṭṭhe adussantassa, asamapekkhanena asammuyhantassa uppannā vipassanā ñāṇasampayuttā
analyzed: aniṭṭhe a dussantassa a samapekkhanena a sammuyhantassa uppannā vipassanā ñāṇa sampayuttā
translated: When he does not hate what is unlovable, and when he does not misapprehend what is not to be misapprehended, the equanimity that arises in him connected with that knowledge is equanimity about formations.

original: upekkhā. Apica vedanāsabhāgā tatra majjhattupekkhāpi ettha upekkhāva. Tasmā sevitabbāti🔽ayaṃ nekkhammavasena vipassanāvasena anussatiṭṭhānavasena paṭhamadutiyatatiyacatutthajjhānavasena
analyzed: upekkhā apica vedanā sabhāgā tatra majjhattupekkhā api ettha upekkhā va tasmā sevitabbā ti  ayam nekkhamma vasena vipassanā vasena anussati ṭṭhāna vasena paṭhama dutiya tatiya catuttha jhāna vasena
translated: Moreover, equanimity about feelings is equanimity here too.

original: ca uppajjanakaupekkhā sevitabbā nāma.🔽Ettha yaṃ ce savitakkaṃ savicāranti tāyapi nekkhammasitaupekkhāya yaṃ nekkhammavasena
analyzed: ca uppajjanakā aupekkhā sevitabbā nāma  ettha yam ce sa vitakkam sa vicāranti yam nekkhamma vasena
translated: So equanimity that arises in the way stated as renunciation, as insight, as a foundation of mindfulness, and as the first, second, third, and fourth jhānas is what should be developed.

original: vipassanāvasena anussatiṭṭhānavasena paṭhamajjhānavasena ca uppannaṃ savitakkasavicāraṃ🔽upekkhanti jāneyya. Yaṃ ce avitakkaṃ avicāranti yaṃ pana dutiyajjhānādivasena uppannaṃ
analyzed: vipassanā vasena anussati ṭhāna vasena paṭhamajjhāna vasena ca uppannam sa vitakka sa vicāram  upekkhanti jāneyya yam ce a vitakkam a vicāranti yam pana dutiya jhāna ādi vasena uppannam
translated: Herein, when he knows “It is applied and sustained,” he should understand that equanimity as equanimity about formations that has arisen in the way stated as renunciation, as insight, as a foundation of mindfulness, and as the first jhāna.🔽When he knows “It is neither applied nor sustained,” he should understand that equanimity as equanimity about formations that has arisen in the way stated as the second jhāna, etc.

original: avitakkāvicāraṃ upekkhanti jāneyya. Ye avitakke avicāre te paṇītatareti etāsu dvīsu
