analyzed: a vitakka a vicāram upekkhanti jāneyya ye a vitakke a vicāre te paṇītatarā iti etāsu dvīsu
translated: When he knows “It is exalted,” etc., he should understand that equanimity as equanimity about formations that has arisen in the way stated as the first jhāna, etc.,

original: yā avitakkaavicārā, sā paṇītatarāti attho. Iminā kiṃ kathitaṃ hoti? Dvinnaṃ arahattaṃ🔽kathitaṃ. Eko hi bhikkhu savitakkasavicāraupekkhāya vipassanaṃ paṭṭhapetvā ayaṃ upekkhā
analyzed: yā a vitakka a vicārā sā paṇītatarā ti iminā kim kathitam hoti dvinnam arahattam  kathitam ekaḥ hi bhikkhu sa vitakka sa vicāra aupekkhāya vipassanam paṭṭhapetvā ayam upekkhā
translated: What is meant is that the jhāna accompanied by applied and sustained thought is less refined than that accompanied by sustained thought only. What is said here?

original: kiṃ nissitāti upadhārento vatthunissitāti pajānātīti phassapañcamake vuttanayeneva
analyzed: kim nissitā ati upadhārentaḥ vatthu nissitā ati pajānāti iti phassa pañcamake vutta nayena eva
translated: The two kinds of Arahantship are said. For one bhikkhu, it seems, begins insight by way of the equanimity accompanied by applied and sustained thought. He then considers thus: “What is this equanimity dependent on? ” He understands thus: “It is dependent on materiality … (as in the case of the first Arahant above) … it is dependent on contact.” He is established in Arahantship in due course in the way already described.

original: anukkamena arahatte patiṭṭhāti. Eko avitakkāvicārāya upekkhāya vipassanaṃ paṭṭhapetvā🔽vuttanayeneva arahatte patiṭṭhāti. Tattha abhiniviṭṭhaupekkhāsupi savitakkasavicārato
analyzed: anukkamena arahatte patiṭṭhāti ekaḥ a vitakka a vicārāya upekkhāya vipassanam paṭṭhapetvā  vutta nayena iva arahatte patiṭṭhāti tattha abhiniviṭṭha aupekkhāsu pi sa vitakka sa vicārato
translated: Another begins insight by way of the equanimity accompanied by sustained thought only.🔽He is established in Arahantship in the way already described. Herein, the equanimity accompanied by sustained thought only is less refined than that accompanied by applied and sustained thought.

original: avitakkāvicārā paṇītatarā. Savitakkasavicāraupekkhāvipassanātopi avitakkāvicāraupekkhāvipassanāpaṇītatarā.
analyzed: a vitakka a vicārā paṇītatarā sa vitakka sa vicāra aupekkhā vipassanātaḥ pi avitakka avicāra aupekkhā vipassanā paṇītatarā
translated: The insight with equanimity accompanied by sustained thought only is less refined than that with equanimity accompanied by applied and sustained thought.

original: Savitakkasavicāraupekkhāphalasamāpattitopi avitakkāvicārupekkhāphalasamāpattiyeva
analyzed: sa vitakka sa vicāra aupekkhā phala samāpattitaḥ api avitakka avicāra upekkhā phala samāpattiyā iva
translated: The fruition attainment with equanimity accompanied by sustained thought only is less refined than that with equanimity accompanied by applied and sustained thought.

original: paṇītatarā. Tenāha bhagavā “ye avitakke avicāre te paṇītatare”ti.
analyzed: paṇītatarā tena āha bhagavā ye a vitakke a vicāre te paṇītatarā iti
translated: That is why the Blessed One said, “Those that are without applied thought and sustained thought are more refined” .

original: 363. Evaṃ paṭipanno kho, devānaminda, bhikkhu papañcasaññāsaṅkhānirodhasāruppagāminiṃ🔽paṭipadaṃ paṭipanno hotīti bhagavā arahattanikūṭena desanaṃ niṭṭhapesi. Sakko pana🔽sotāpattiphalaṃ patto. Buddhānañhi ajjhāsayo hīno na hoti, ukkaṭṭhova hoti. Ekassapi🔽bahūnampi dhammaṃ desentā arahatteneva kūṭaṃ gaṇhanti. Sattā pana attano anurūpe
analyzed: evam paṭipannaḥ kho devānaminda bhikkhu papañca saññā saṅkhā nirodha sāruppa gāminim  paṭipadam paṭipanno hoti iti bhagavā arahatta nikūṭena desanam niṭṭhapesi sakko pana  sotāpatti phalam pattaḥ buddhānam hi ajjhāsayaḥ hīnaḥ na hoti ukkaṭṭhaḥ uva hoti ekassa api  bahūnam pi dhammam desentāḥ arahattena iva kūṭam gaṇhanti sattā pana attanaḥ anurūpe
translated: The Blessed One concluded the teaching with the peak of arahantship. Sakka attained the fruit of stream-entry. The intention of the Buddhas is never low; it is always lofty. Whether they teach the Dhamma to one person or to many, they always conclude with the peak of arahantship. But beings receive the teaching according to their capacity.

original: upanissaye ṭhitā keci sotāpannā honti, keci sakadāgāmī, keci anāgāmī, keci arahanto.🔽Rājā viya hi bhagavā, rājakumārā viya veneyyā. Yathā hi rājā bhojanakāle attano pamāṇena🔽piṇḍaṃ uddharitvā rājakumārānaṃ upaneti, te tato attano mukhappamāṇeneva kabaḷaṃ
analyzed: upanissaye ṭhitā keci sotāpannāḥ honti keci sakadāgāmī keci anāgāmī keci arahanto  rājā viya hi bhagavā rāja kumārāḥ viya veneyyāḥ yathā hi rājā bhojana kāle pamāṇena  piṇḍam uddharitvā upaneti te tatas attanaḥ mukha ppamāṇena iva kabaḷam
translated: The Blessed One concluded his teaching with the peak of arahantship. Sakka attained the fruit of stream-entry. The intention of the Buddhas is never low; it is always high. Whether they teach the Dhamma to one person or to many, they always conclude with the peak of arahantship. But beings, standing on different levels of receptivity, attain the fruit of stream-entry, the fruit of once-return, the fruit of non-return, and arahantship.

original: karonti, evaṃ bhagavā attajjhāsayānurūpāya desanāya arahatteneva kūṭaṃ gaṇhāti. Veneyyā
analyzed: karonti evam bhagavā atta jhāsayā anurūpāya desanāya arahattena iva kūṭam gaṇhāti veneyyā
translated: The Blessed One is like a king, and the disciples are like princes. Just as a king, at mealtime, takes a morsel from his own plate and places it on the plate of the princes, so that they may eat it, so the Blessed One, with a teaching appropriate to their dispositions, concludes with the peak of arahantship.

original: attano upanissayappamāṇena tato sotāpattiphalamattaṃ vā sakadāgāmianāgāmiarahattaphalameva
analyzed: attanaḥ upanissaya ppamāṇena tatas sotāpatti phalam attam vā sakadāgāmi anāgāmi arahatta phalam eva
translated: and the measure of his own support, then the fruit of Stream-Entry, or the fruit of Once-Returning, or the fruit of Non-Returning, or the fruit of Liberation,🔽

original: vā gaṇhanti. Sakko pana sotāpanno jāto. Sotāpanno ca hutvā bhagavato puratoyeva cavitvā
analyzed: vā gaṇhanti sakkaḥ pana sotāpannaḥ jātaḥ sotāpannaḥ ca hutvā bhagavato puratoyā iva cavitvā
translated: and they took the fruit of Stream-Entry, or the fruit of Once-Return, or the fruit of Non-Return, or the fruit of Liberation, according to the measure of their own support. Sakka, however, became a Stream-Enterer. And having become a Stream-Enterer, he died in front of the Lord,

original: taruṇasakko hutvā nibbatti, devatānañhi cavamānānaṃ attabhāvassa gatāgataṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: taruṇa sakkaḥ hutvā nibbatti devatānam hi cavamānānam atta bhāvassa gata āgata ṭṭhānam
translated: and being reborn as a young god, he was not known by the other gods, because the place where the gods die and are reborn

original: nāma na paññāyati, dīpasikhāgamanaṃ viya hoti. Tasmā sesadevatā na jāniṃsu. Sakko
analyzed: nāma na paññāyati dīpa sikhā gamanam viya hoti tasmā sesa devatāḥ na jāniṃsu sakko
translated: is not known, it is like the coming and going of a flame. Therefore the other gods did not know. But Sakka

original: pana sayaṃ cutattā bhagavā ca appaṭihatañāṇattā dveva janā jāniṃsu. Atha sakko cintesi
analyzed: pana sayam cuta ttā bhagavā ca appaṭihata ñāṇa ttā dve iva janāḥ jāniṃsu atha sakkaḥ cintesi
translated: himself knew, and the Lord knew because of his unobstructed knowledge. Then Sakka thought

original: “mayhañhi bhagavatā tīsu ṭhānesu nibbattitaphalameva kathitaṃ, ayañca pana maggo🔽vā phalaṃ vā sakuṇikāya viya uppatitvā gahetuṃ na sakkā, āgamanīyapubbabhāgapaṭipadāya
analyzed: mayhan hi bhagavatā tīsu ṭhānesu nibbattita phalam eva kathitam ayaṃ ca pana maggo  vā phalam vā sakuṇikāya viya uppatitvā gahetum na sakkā āgamanīya pubbabhāga paṭipadāya
translated: “The Lord has told me the fruit of rebirth in three places, and this path

original: assa bhavitabbaṃ. Handāhaṃ upari khīṇāsavassa pubbabhāgapaṭipadaṃ pucchāmī”ti.
analyzed: assa bhavitabbam handa aham upari khīṇāsavassa pubbabhāga paṭipadam pucchāmi iti
translated: or fruit cannot be taken by flying up like a bird, it must be the prior practice that is to be approached. Well now, I will ask about the prior practice of the one who is without pollutants above.”

original: Pātimokkhasaṃvaravaṇṇanā🔽364. Tato taṃ pucchanto kathaṃ paṭipanno pana, mārisātiādimāha. Tattha pātimokkhasaṃvarāyāti🔽uttamajeṭṭhakasīlasaṃvarāya. Kāyasamācārampītiādi sevitabbakāyasamācārādivasena pātimokkhasaṃvaradassanatthaṃ
analyzed: pātimokkha saṃvara vaṇṇanā  tatas tam pucchanto katham paṭipannaḥ pana mārisa iti ādim āha tattha pātimokkha saṃvarāya iti  uttama jeṭṭhaka sīla saṃvarāya kāya samācāram pi itiādi sevitabba kāya samācāra ādi vasena pātimokkha saṃvara dassana tham
translated: The commentary on the Pātimokkha restraint

original: vuttaṃ. Sīlakathā ca nāmesā kammapathavasena vā paṇṇattivasena vā kathetabbā hoti.
analyzed: vuttam sīla kathā ca nāma isā kammapatha vasena vā paṇṇatti vasena vā kathetabbā hoti
translated: . Then, asking him, “But how, dear Sir, is one practicing?” he said, “Here, friend, a monk is virtuous,” etc. Herein, for the sake of the Pātimokkha restraint is for the sake of the restraint of the highest, chief, and special virtue. As to bodily conduct: this is said in order to show the Pātimokkha restraint by means of the bodily conduct that should be practised. And this talk on virtue should be given either as a course of action or as a description.

original: Tattha kammapathavasena kathentena asevitabbakāyasamācāro tāva pāṇātipātaadinnādānamicchācārehi🔽kathetabbo. Paṇṇattivasena kathentena kāyadvāre paññattasikkhāpadavītikkamavasena
analyzed: tattha kamma patha vasena kathentena asevitabba kāya samācāro tāva pāṇa atipāta a dinnādāna micchā ācārehi  kathetabbo paṇṇatti vasena kathentena kāya dvāre paññatta sikkhāpada vītikkama vasena
translated: Herein, one who gives it as a course of action should give it as the bodily conduct that should not be practised by means of killing breathing things, taking what is not given, and misconduct in sensual desires.🔽One who gives it as a description should give it as the transgression of the training precepts described in the body door.

original: kathetabbo. Sevitabbakāyasamācāro pāṇātipātādiveramaṇīhi ceva kāyadvāre paññattasikkhāpadaavītikkamena
analyzed: kathetabbaḥ sevitabba kāya samācāraḥ pāṇātipāta ādi veramaṇīhi ca iva kāyadvāre paññatta sikkhāpada a vītikkamena
translated: As to bodily conduct that should be practised: this should be given as abstention from killing breathing things, etc., and as the non-transgression of the training precepts described in the body door.

original: ca kathetabbo. Asevitabbavacīsamācāro musāvādādivacīduccaritena ceva vacīdvāre paññattasikkhāpadavītikkamena
analyzed: ca kathetabbaḥ asevitabba vacī samācāraḥ musāvāda ādi vacī duccaritena ca iva vacī dvāre paññatta sikkhāpada vītikkamena
translated: As to verbal conduct that should not be practised: this should be given as verbal misconduct by means of false speech, etc., and as the transgression of the training precepts described in the speech door.

original: ca kathetabbo. Sevitabbavacīsamācāro musāvādādiveramaṇīhi ceva vacīdvāre paññattasikkhāpadaavītikkamena ca kathetabbo.
analyzed: ca kathetabbo sevitabba vacī samācāraḥ musāvāda ādi veramaṇīhi ca iva vacī dvāre paññatta sikkhāpada avītikkamena ca kathetabbo
translated: and the right kind of verbal conduct should be told by means of the abstentions from false speech, etc., and by means of the training precepts announced in the clause ‘ Abstaining from malicious speech ’ .

original: Pariyesanā pana kāyavācāhi pariyesanāyeva. Sā kāyavacīsamācāragahaṇena gahitāpi samānā🔽yasmā ājīvaṭṭhamakasīlaṃ nāma etasmiññeva dvāradvaye uppajjati, na ākāse, tasmā ājīvaṭṭhamakasīladassanatthaṃ
analyzed: pariyesanā pana sā kāya vacī samācāra gahaṇena gahitā api samānā  yasmai ājīva ṭhamaka sīlam nāma etasmin ñeva dvāra dvaye uppajjati na ākāse tasmai ājīva ṭṭhamaka sīla dassana ttham
translated: The wrong kind of search and the right kind of search are only the search by body and speech. Although they are included in the verbal and bodily conduct,🔽nevertheless they are stated separately here in order to show the virtue of the eighth factor of the rightness-section, namely, right livelihood,

original: visuṃ vuttā. Tattha nasevitabbapariyesanā anariyapariyesanāya kathetabbā. Sevitabbapariyesanā
analyzed: visum vuttā tattha na sevitabba pariyesanā anariya pariyesanāya kathetabbā sevitabba pariyesanā
translated: since that arises only in the two doors of body and speech and not in the air. Herein, the wrong kind of search should be told by means of the wrong kind of search,

original: ariyapariyesanāya. Vuttañhetaṃ –
analyzed: ariya pariyesanāya vuttam ha etam
translated: and the right kind of search by means of the right kind of search. For this is said:

original: “Dvemā, bhikkhave, pariyesanā anariyā ca pariyesanā, ariyā ca pariyesanā. Katamā
analyzed: dvemā bhikkhave pariyesanāḥ anariyā ca pariyesanā ariyā ca pariyesanā katamā
translated: ‘ Bhikkhus, there are these two kinds of search, namely, the ignoble search and the noble search.

original: ca, bhikkhave, anariyā pariyesanā? Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco attanā jātidhammo samāno
analyzed: ca bhikkhave anariyā pariyesanā idha bhikkhave ekaccaḥ attanā jāti dhammo samāno
translated: And what is the ignoble search? Here someone, himself subject to birth,

original: jātidhammaṃyeva pariyesati, attanā jarādhammo, byādhidhammo, maraṇadhammo, sokadhammo,
analyzed: jāti dhammaṃyā iva pariyesati attanā jarā dhammaḥ byādhi dhammaḥ maraṇa dhammo soka dhammo
translated: seeks what is also subject to birth; himself subject to ageing, subject to sickness, subject to death, subject to sorrow,

original: saṃkilesadhammo samāno saṃkilesadhammaṃyeva pariyesati.🔽Kiñca, bhikkhave, jātidhammaṃ vadetha? Puttabhariyaṃ, bhikkhave, jātidhammaṃ, dāsidāsaṃ🔽jātidhammaṃ ajeḷakaṃ jātidhammaṃ, kukkuṭasūkaraṃ jātidhammaṃ, hatthigavāssavaḷavaṃ
analyzed: saṃkilesa dhammo samānaḥ saṃkilesa dhammaṃyā iva pariyesati  kiñca bhikkhave jāti dhammam vadetha putta bhariyam bhikkhave jāti dhammam dāsi dāsam  jāti dhammam ajeḷakam jāti dhammam kukkuṭa sūkaram jāti dhammam hatthi gavāssa vaḷavam
translated: and so he seeks out what has the same nature as himself.🔽“And what, monks, is subject to birth that you should call it ‘birth’? Wife and children, monks, are subject to birth …

original: jātidhammaṃ, jātarūparajataṃ jātidhammaṃ. Jātidhammā hete, bhikkhave, upadhayo, etthāyaṃ
analyzed: jāti dhammam jātarūpa rajatam jāti dhammam jāti dhammāḥ ha ete bhikkhave upadhayaḥ ettha ayam
translated: cattle are subject to birth. Gold and silver are subject to birth. These acquisitions, monks, are subject to birth,

original: gathito mucchito ajjhāpanno attanā jātidhammo samāno jātidhammaṃyeva pariyesati.🔽Kiñca, bhikkhave, jarādhammaṃ vadetha? Puttabhariyaṃ, bhikkhave, jarādhammaṃ…pe… jarādhammaṃyeva pariyesati.
analyzed: gathitaḥ mucchitaḥ ajjhāpannaḥ attanā jāti dhammo samānaḥ jāti dhammaṃyā iva pariyesati  kiñca bhikkhave jarā dhammam vadetha putta bhariyam bhikkhave jarā dhammam pe jarā dhammaṃ yeva pariyesati
translated: and so he seeks out what has the same nature as himself.

original: Kiñca, bhikkhave, byādhidhammaṃ vadetha? Puttabhariyaṃ, bhikkhave, byādhidhammaṃ,
analyzed: kiñca bhikkhave byādhi dhammam vadetha putta bhariyam bhikkhave byādhi dhammam
translated: “And what, monks, is subject to old age that you should call it ‘old age’? Wife and children, monks, are subject to old age …

original: dāsidāsaṃ byādhidhammaṃ, ajeḷakaṃ, kukkuṭasūkaraṃ, hatthigavāssavaḷavaṃ byādhidhammaṃ.
analyzed: dāsi dāsam byādhi dhammam ajeḷakam kukkuṭa sūkaram hatthi gavāssa vaḷavam byādhi dhammam
translated: cattle are subject to old age. Gold and silver are subject to old age.🔽“And what, monks, is subject to sickness that you should call it ‘sickness’? Wife and children, monks, are subject to sickness …

original: Byādhidhammā hete, bhikkhave, upadhayo, etthāyaṃ gathito mucchito ajjhāpanno attanā
analyzed: byādhi dhammāḥ ha ete bhikkhave upadhayaḥ ettha ayam gathitaḥ mucchitaḥ ajjhāpannaḥ attanā
translated: These acquisitions, monks, are subject to sickness. One is bound to them, infatuated with them, attached to them,

original: byādhidhammo samāno byādhidhammaṃyeva pariyesati.
analyzed: byādhi dhammaḥ samānaḥ byādhi dhammaṃyā iva pariyesati
translated: These acquisitions are subject to sickness. Being subject to sickness himself, he seeks what is subject to sickness.

original: Kiñca, bhikkhave, maraṇadhammaṃ vadetha? Puttabhariyaṃ, bhikkhave, maraṇadhammaṃ…pe… maraṇadhammaṃyeva pariyesati.🔽Kiñca, bhikkhave, sokadhammaṃ vadetha? Puttabhariyaṃ…pe… sokadhammaṃyeva pariyesati.
analyzed: kiñca bhikkhave maraṇa dhammam vadetha putta bhariyam bhikkhave maraṇa dhammam pe maraṇa dhammaṃ yeva pariyesati  kiñca bhikkhave soka dhammam vadetha soka dhammaṃ yā iva pariyesati
translated: What do we say is subject to death? Wife and children are subject to death. … Being subject to death himself, he seeks what is subject to death.

original: Kiñca, bhikkhave, saṃkilesadhammaṃ vadetha…pe… jātarūparajataṃ saṃkilesadhammaṃ.🔽Saṃkilesadhammā, hete, bhikkhave, upadhayo, etthāyaṃ gathito mucchito ajjhāpanno
analyzed: kiñca bhikkhave saṃkilesa dhammam jātarūpa rajatam saṃkilesa dhammam  saṃkilesa dhammāḥ ha ete bhikkhave upadhayaḥ ettha ayam gathitaḥ mucchitaḥ ajjhāpannaḥ
translated: What do we say is subject to sorrow? Wife and children are subject to sorrow. … Being subject to sorrow himself, he seeks what is subject to sorrow.

original: attanā saṃkilesadhammo samāno saṃkilesadhammaṃyeva pariyesati. Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, anariyā pariyesanāti.
analyzed: attanā saṃkilesa dhammo samānaḥ saṃkilesa dhammaṃ yeva pariyesati ayam bhikkhave anariyā pariyesanā ti
translated: What do we say is subject to defilement? Gold and silver are subject to defilement. … Being subject to defilement himself, he seeks what is subject to defilement. These acquisitions are subject to defilement. Being subject to defilement himself, he seeks what is subject to defilement. This is the ignoble search.

original: Apica kuhanādivasena pañcavidhā, agocaravasena chabbidhā vejjakammādivasena ekavīsatividhā, evaṃ pavattā sabbāpi anesanā anariyapariyesanāyevāti veditabbā.
analyzed: apica kuhanā ādi vasena pañcavidhā agocara vasena chabbidhā vejja kamma ādi vasena ekavīsatividhā evam pavattā sabbā api anesanā anariya pariyesanāya iva ati veditabbā
translated: Furthermore, it is of five kinds as hypocrisy, etc., of six kinds as outside the right course, and of twenty-one kinds as medical practice, etc.; and all of it should be understood as unprofitable search, unaristocratic search, in that it occurs in these ways.

original: “Katamā ca, bhikkhave, ariyā pariyesanā? Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco attanā jātidhammo🔽samāno jātidhamme ādīnavaṃ viditvā ajātaṃ anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ nibbānaṃ pariyesati,🔽attanā jarādhammo, byādhi, maraṇa, soka, saṃkilesadhammo samāno saṃkilesadhamme ādīnavaṃ
analyzed: katamā ca bhikkhave ariyā pariyesanā idha bhikkhave ekaccaḥ attanā jāti dhammo  samānaḥ jāti dhamme ādīnavam viditvā ajātam anuttaram yogakkhemam nibbānam pariyesati  attanā jarā dhammo samānaḥ saṃkilesa dhamme ādīnavam
translated: “And what, bhikkhus, is the noble search? Here someone, himself subject to birth … … seeks the unborn supreme security from bondage, Nibbāna.

original: viditvā asaṃkiliṭṭhaṃ anuttaraṃ yogakkhemaṃ nibbānaṃ pariyesati. Ayaṃ ariyā pariyesanāti.
analyzed: viditvā asaṃkiliṭṭham anuttaram yogakkhemam nibbānam pariyesati ayam ariyā pariyesanā ati
translated: “Himself subject to ageing … subject to sickness … subject to death … subject to sorrow … subject to defilement, he seeks the undefiled supreme security from bondage, Nibbāna. This is the noble search” .

original: Apica pañca kuhanādīni cha agocare ekavīsatividhañca anesanaṃ vajjetvā bhikkhācariyāya dhammena samena pariyesanāpi ariyapariyesanāyevāti veditabbā.
analyzed: apica pañca kuhanā ādīni cha agocare ekavīsatividham ca anesanam vajjetvā bhikkhā cariyāya dhammena samena pariyesanā api ariya pariyesanāya iva ati veditabbā
translated: Furthermore, the profitable search should be understood as the noble search in that it is the search by alms round, etc., after avoiding the five kinds of hypocrisy, etc., the six outside the right course, and the twenty-one kinds of unprofitable search.

original: Ettha ca yo yo “na sevitabbo”ti vutto, so so pubbabhāge pāṇātipātādīnaṃ sambhārapariyesanāpayogakaraṇagamanakālato
analyzed: ettha ca yaḥ yaḥ na sevitabbaḥ iti vutto so so pubba bhāge pāṇātipāta ādīnam sambhāra pariyesana apayoga karaṇa gamana kālato
translated: And here, the kind of bodily action that is to be avoided should be avoided from the time of the preliminary stage of seeking the requisites for killing living beings, etc.,

original: paṭṭhāya na sevitabbova. Itaro ādito paṭṭhāya sevitabbo, asakkontena cittampi uppādetabbaṃ.
analyzed: paṭṭhāya na sevitabbaḥ uva itaro āditaḥ paṭṭhāya sevitabbaḥ a sakkontena cittam api uppādetabbam
translated: and from the time of the actual performance of the action of going to the place . The other kind should be undertaken from the very beginning; and if one is unable to do it, one should arouse the thought of it.

original: Apica saṅghabhedādīnaṃ atthāya parakkamantānaṃ devadattādīnaṃ viya kāyasamācāro na🔽sevitabbo, divasassa dvattikkhattuṃ tiṇṇaṃ ratanānaṃ upaṭṭhānagamanādivasena pavatto
analyzed: apica saṅgha bheda ādīnam atthāya parakkamantānam devadatta ādīnam viya kāya samācāraḥ na  sevitabbaḥ divasassa dvattikkhattum tiṇṇam ratanānam upaṭṭhāna gamana ādi vasena pavatto
translated: Moreover, the bodily action of Devadatta, etc., who strive for the purpose of schism in the Saṅgha, etc., should not be undertaken;

original: dhammasenāpatimahāmoggallānattherādīnaṃ viya kāyasamācāro sevitabbo. Dhanuggahapesanādivasena
analyzed: dhamma senāpati mahāmoggallāna thera ādīnam viya kāya samācāraḥ sevitabbaḥ dhanuggaha pesanā ādi vasena
translated: but the bodily action of such as the Elder Sāriputta, the General of the Dhamma, which occurs by way of going to wait upon the Three Jewels twenty-four times a day, should be undertaken.

original: vācaṃ bhindantānaṃ devadattādīnaṃ viya vacīsamācāro na sevitabbo, tiṇṇaṃ ratanānaṃ
analyzed: vācam bhindantānam devadatta ādīnam viya vacī samācāraḥ na sevitabbaḥ tiṇṇam ratanānam
translated: Or, the verbal action of Devadatta, etc., who break out in speech by way of archery contests, etc., should not be undertaken;

original: guṇakittanādivasena pavatto dhammasenāpatimahāmoggallānattherādīnaṃ viya vacīsamācāro
analyzed: guṇa kittana ādi vasena pavattaḥ dhammasenāpati mahāmoggallāna tthera ādīnam viya vacī samācāraḥ
translated: but the verbal action of such as the Elder Sāriputta, the General of the Dhamma, which occurs by way of praising the virtues of the Three Jewels,

original: sevitabbo. Anariyapariyesanaṃ pariyesantānaṃ devadattādīnaṃ viya pariyesanā na sevitabbā,
analyzed: sevitabbaḥ anariya pariyesanam pariyesantānam devadatta ādīnam viya pariyesanā na sevitabbā
translated: The search should be pursued that is to be pursued, not the search that is not to be pursued, like the search of Devadatta and others.

original: ariyapariyesanameva pariyesantānaṃ dhammasenāpatimahāmoggallānattherādīnaṃ viya pariyesanā sevitabbā.🔽Evaṃ paṭipanno khoti evaṃ asevitabbaṃ kāyavacīsamācāraṃ pariyesanañca pahāya sevitabbānaṃ🔽pāripūriyā paṭipanno, devānaminda, bhikkhu pātimokkhasaṃvarāya uttamajeṭṭhakasīlasaṃvaratthāya🔽paṭipanno nāma hotīti bhagavā khīṇāsavassa āgamanīyapubbabhāgapaṭipadaṃ kathesi.🔽Indriyasaṃvaravaṇṇanā
analyzed: ariya pariyesanam eva pariyesantānam dhammasenāpati mahāmoggallāna thera ādīnam viya pariyesanā sevitabbā  evam paṭipanno kho ti evam asevitabbam kāya vacī samācāram pariyesanam ca pahāya sevitabbānam  pāripūriyā paṭipannaḥ devānaminda bhikkhu pātimokkha saṃvarāya uttama jeṭṭhaka sīla saṃvara tthāya  paṭipannaḥ nāma hoti iti bhagavā khīṇāsavassa āgamanīya pubbabhāga paṭipadam kathesi  indriya saṃvara vaṇṇanā
translated: The search should be pursued that is to be pursued, like the search of such as the General of the Dhamma, the Elder Moggallāna the Great, and others.

original: 365. Dutiyapucchāyaṃ indriyasaṃvarāyāti indriyānaṃ pidhānāya, guttadvāratāya saṃvutadvāratāyāti🔽attho. Vissajjane panassa cakkhuviññeyyaṃ rūpampītiādi sevitabbarūpādivasena indriyasaṃvaradassanatthaṃ
analyzed: indriya saṃvarāya ati indriyānam pidhānāya gutta dvāratāya saṃvuta dvāratāya ati 🔽atthaḥ vissajjane pana assa cakkhu viññeyyam rūpam pi itiādi sevitabba rūpa ādi vasena indriya saṃvara dassana ttham
translated: “A bhikkhu who is practising thus, Ruler of Gods, is practising for the restraint of the body, for the restraint of speech, for the restraint of the mind, for the restraint of the search, for the restraint of the search that is not to be pursued, for the restraint of the search that is to be pursued, for the restraint of the search that is to be pursued in the way of the Noble Ones, for the restraint of the search that is not to be pursued in the way of the Noble Ones, for the restraint of the search that is to be pursued in the way of the Noble Ones, for the restraint of the search that is not to be pursued in the way of the Noble Ones, for the restraint of the search that is to be pursued in the way of the Noble Ones, for the restraint of the search that is not to be pursued in the way of the Noble Ones, for the restraint of the search that is to be pursued in the way of the Noble Ones, for the restraint of the search that is not to be pursued in the way of the Noble Ones, for the restraint of the search that is to be pursued in the way of the Noble Ones, for the restraint of the search that is not to be pursued in the way of the Noble Ones, for the restraint of the search that is to be pursued in the way of the Noble Ones, for the restraint of the search that is not to be pursued in the way of the Noble Ones, for the restraint of the search that is to be pursued in the way of the Noble Ones, for the restraint of the search that is not to be pursued in the way of the Noble Ones, for the restraint of the search that is to be pursued in the way of the Noble Ones, for the restraint of the search that is not to be pursued in the way of the Noble Ones, for the restraint of the search that is to be pursued in the way of the Noble Ones, for the restraint of the search that is not to be pursued in the way of the Noble Ones, for the restraint of the search that is to be pursued in the way of the Noble Ones, for the restraint of the search

original: vuttaṃ. Tattha evaṃ vutteti heṭṭhā somanassādipañhāvissajjanānaṃ sutattā imināpi
analyzed: vuttam tattha evam vuttā iti heṭṭhā somanassa ādi pañhā vissajjanānam suta ttā iminā api
translated: This has been said. Herein, when this was said, because the questions beginning with “joy” had been answered below , the inspiration came to Sakka to ask the question in this way.

original: evarūpena bhavitabbanti sañjātapaṭibhāno bhagavatā evaṃ vutte sakko devānamindo bhagavantaṃ🔽etadavoca, etaṃ imassa kho ahaṃ, bhanteti ādikaṃ vacanaṃ avoca. Bhagavāpissa okāsaṃ🔽datvā tuṇhī ahosi. Kathetukāmopi hi yo atthaṃ sampādetuṃ na sakkoti, atthaṃ sampādetuṃ🔽sakkonto vā na kathetukāmo hoti, na tassa bhagavā okāsaṃ karoti. Ayaṃ pana yasmā
analyzed: evarūpena bhavitabbanti sañjāta paṭibhānaḥ bhagavatā evam vutte sakkaḥ devānamindaḥ bhagavantam  etat avoca etam imassa kho aham bhante ti ādikam vacanam avoca bhagavā api ssa okāsam  da tvā tuṇhī ahosi kathetu kāmaḥ api hi yaḥ attham sampādetum na sakkoti attham sampādetum  sakkontaḥ vā na kathetu kāmo hoti na tassa bhagavā okāsam karoti ayam pana yasmā
translated: When this was said, Sakka, lord of the devas, said to the Exalted One:

original: kathetukāmo ceva, sakkoti ca atthaṃ sampādetuṃ tenassa bhagavā okāsamakāsi.🔽Tattha evarūpaṃ na sevitabbanti ādīsu ayaṃ saṅkhepo – yaṃ rūpaṃ passato rāgādayo
analyzed: kathetu kāmo ca iva sakkoti ca attham sampādetum tena assa bhagavā okāsam akāsi  tattha evarūpam na sevitabbanti ādīsu ayam saṅkhepaḥ yam rūpam passataḥ rāga ādayo
translated: “This, Lord, is what I understand thus,” and so on. The Exalted One gave him leave to speak and remained silent. For when one is desirous of speaking but is unable to complete the meaning, or when one is able to complete the meaning but is not desirous of speaking, the Exalted One does not give leave to speak. But since Sakka was both desirous of speaking and able to complete the meaning, the Exalted One gave him leave.

original: uppajjanti, taṃ na sevitabbaṃ na daṭṭhabbaṃ na oloketabbanti attho. Yaṃ pana passato
analyzed: uppajjanti tam na sevitabbam na daṭṭhabbam na oloketabbam ti atthaḥ yam pana passato
translated: Herein, as regards the passages beginning with “Such things should not be attended to,” the brief meaning is this: The kind of visible form that gives rise to lust, etc., when seen should not be attended to, should not be looked at, should not be gazed at, is the meaning. But the kind of visible form that gives rise to the thought “This is a noble person” when seen should be attended to, should be looked at, should be gazed at.

original: asubhasaññā vā saṇṭhāti, pasādo vā uppajjati, aniccasaññāpaṭilābho vā hoti, taṃ sevitabbaṃ.
analyzed: asubha saññā vā saṇṭhāti pasādaḥ vā uppajjati anicca saññā paṭilābho vā hoti tat sevitabbam
translated: or the perception of foulness becomes stabilized in him, or confidence in the Teacher arises, or he acquires the perception of inconstancy, then that sound should be attended to.

original: Yaṃ cittakkharaṃ cittabyañjanampi saddaṃ suṇato rāgādayo uppajjanti, evarūpo saddo🔽na sevitabbo. Yaṃ pana atthanissitaṃ dhammanissitaṃ kumbhadāsigītampi suṇantassa
analyzed: yam citta kkharam citta byañjanam pi saddam suṇataḥ rāga ādayaḥ uppajjanti evarūpaḥ saddaḥ  na sevitabbaḥ yam pana attha nissitam dhamma nissitam kumbha dāsi gītam pi suṇantassa
translated: When a sound is heard that gives rise to lust, hate, or delusion, that kind of sound

original: pasādo vā uppajjati, nibbidā vā saṇṭhāti, evarūpo saddo sevitabbo.
analyzed: pasādaḥ vā uppajjati nibbidā vā saṇṭhāti evarūpaḥ saddaḥ sevitabbo
translated: should not be attended to. But when a sound is heard that is connected with the Dhamma, that gives rise to confidence, or that leads to disenchantment, that kind of sound should be attended to.

original: Yaṃ gandhaṃ ghāyato rāgādayo uppajjanti, evarūpo gandho na sevitabbo. Yaṃ pana gandhaṃ ghāyato asubhasaññādipaṭilābho hoti, evarūpo gandho sevitabbo.
analyzed: yam gandham ghāyataḥ rāga ādayaḥ uppajjanti evarūpaḥ gandhaḥ na sevitabbaḥ yam pana gandham ghāyataḥ asubha saññā ādi paṭilābhaḥ hoti evarūpaḥ gandho sevitabbaḥ
translated: When a smell is smelt that gives rise to lust, hate, or delusion, that kind of smell should not be attended to. But when a smell is smelt that leads to the perception of foulness, that kind of smell should be attended to.

original: Yaṃ rasaṃ sāyato rāgādayo uppajjanti, evarūpo raso na sevitabbo. Yaṃ pana rasaṃ sāyato
analyzed: yam rasam sāyataḥ rāga ādayaḥ uppajjanti evarūpaḥ rasaḥ na sevitabbaḥ yam pana rasam sāyataḥ
translated: When a taste is tasted that gives rise to lust, hate, or delusion, that kind of taste should not be attended to. But when a taste is tasted

original: āhāre paṭikūlasaññā ceva uppajjati, sāyitapaccayā ca kāyabalaṃ nissāya ariyabhūmiṃ
analyzed: āhāre paṭikūla saññā ca iva uppajjati sāyita paccayā ca kāya balam nissāya ariya bhūmiṃ
translated: and the perception of the repulsiveness of food arises, and when, depending on the strength of the body, the noble path arises with the condition of tasting as its basis, that kind of taste should be attended to.

original: okkamituṃ sakkoti, mahāsīvattherabhāgineyyasīvasāmaṇerassa viya paribhuñjantasseva
analyzed: okkamitum sakkoti mahāsīva tthera bhāgineyya sīva sāmaṇerassa viya paribhuñjantassa iva
translated: and he is able to enter upon the jhāna, then he can use it.

original: kilesakkhayo vā hoti, evarūpo raso sevitabbo.
analyzed: kilesa khayaḥ vā hoti evarūpaḥ rasaḥ sevitabbo
translated: Or else the defilements are destroyed in him while he is using it, as happened to the novice Sīvaka, the nephew of the Elder Mahā-Sīva.🔽This kind of tangible datum should be used.

original: Yaṃ phoṭṭhabbaṃ phusato rāgādayo uppajjanti, evarūpaṃ phoṭṭhabbaṃ na sevitabbaṃ.
analyzed: yam phoṭṭhabbam phusataḥ rāga ādayaḥ uppajjanti evarūpam phoṭṭhabbam na sevitabbam
translated: But when a tangible datum is touched that gives rise to lust, hate, and so on, it should not be used.

original: Yaṃ pana phusato sāriputtattherādīnaṃ viya āsavakkhayo ceva, vīriyañca supaggahitaṃ,🔽pacchimā ca janatā diṭṭhānugatiṃ āpādanena anuggahitā hoti, evarūpaṃ phoṭṭhabbaṃ
analyzed: yam pana phusato sāriputta thera ādīnam viya āsava kkhayo ca iva vīriyam ca su paggahitam  pacchimā ca janatā diṭṭha anugatim āpādanena anuggahitā hoti evarūpam phoṭṭhabbam
translated: But when a tangible datum is touched that brings about the destruction of the defilements, and also the right application of energy,

original: sevitabbaṃ. Sāriputtatthero kira tiṃsa vassāni mañce piṭṭhiṃ na pasāresi. Tathā mahāmoggallānatthero.
analyzed: sevitabbam sāriputta thero kira tiṃsa vassāni mañce piṭṭhim na pasāresi tathā mahāmoggallāna thero
translated: and it benefits later generations by their being made to enter the way of the ancient Elders, then that kind of tangible datum should be used. The Elder Sāriputta, it seems, did not lean his back against anything for thirty years. So too the Elder Mahā-Moggallāna.

original: Mahākassapatthero vīsavassasataṃ mañce piṭṭhiṃ na pasāresi. Anuruddhatthero paññāsa
analyzed: mahākassapa theraḥ vīsa vassa satam mañce piṭṭhim na pasāresi anuruddha thero paññāsa
translated: The Elder Mahā-Kassapa did not lean his back against anything for two hundred years. The Elder Anuruddha did not do so for fifty years,

original: vassāni. Bhaddiyatthero tiṃsa vassāni. Soṇatthero aṭṭhārasa vassāni. Raṭṭhapālatthero
analyzed: vassāni bhaddiya tthero tiṃsa vassāni soṇa tthero aṭṭhārasa vassāni raṭṭhapāla tthero
translated: the Elder Bhaddiya for thirty years, the Elder Soṇa for eighteen years, the Elder Raṭṭhapāla for twelve years, the Elder Revata for seven years, the Elder Sāgata for six years, the Elder Upasena for five years, the Elder Nāgasena for four years, the Elder Mahā-Dhammarakkhita for three years, the Elder Mahā-Siva for two years, and the Elder Mahā-Kaccāyana did not lean his back against anything for one year.

original: dvādasa. Ānandatthero pannarasa. Rāhulatthero dvādasa. Bākulatthero asīti vassāni.
analyzed: ānandatthero pannarasa rāhulatthero dvādasa bākulatthero asīti vassāni
translated: Twelve. The Elder Ānanda fifteen. The Elder Rāhula twelve. The Elder Bākula eighty years.

original: Nāḷakatthero yāvaparinibbānā mañce piṭṭhiṃ na pasāresīti.🔽Ye manoviññeyye dhamme samannāharantassa rāgādayo uppajjanti, “aho, vata yaṃ paresaṃ🔽paravittūpakaraṇaṃ taṃ mamassā”tiādinā nayena vā abhijjhādīni āpāthamāgacchanti evarūpā🔽dhammā na sevitabbā. “Sabbe sattā averā hontū”ti evaṃ mettādivasena, ye vā pana tiṇṇaṃ🔽therānaṃ dhammā, evarūpā sevitabbā. Tayo kira therā vassūpanāyikadivase kāmavitakkādayo
analyzed: nāḷaka theraḥ yāva parinibbānā mañce piṭṭhim na pasāresi iti  ye manaḥ viññeyye dhamme samannāharantassa rāga ādayaḥ uppajjanti aho vata yam paresam  para vittu upakaraṇam tam mamassa ati ādinā nayena vā abhijjhā ādīni āpātham āgacchanti evarūpā  dhammā na sevitabbā sabbe sattāḥ averāḥ hontu iti evam mettā ādi vasena ye vā pana tiṇṇam  therānam dhammā evarūpā sevitabbā tayaḥ kira therāḥ vassūpanāyika divase kāma vitakka ādayaḥ
translated: The Elder Nāḷi, until his final passing, never laid his back on a bed.

original: akusalavitakkā na vitakketabbāti katikaṃ akaṃsu. Atha pavāraṇadivase saṅghatthero🔽saṅghanavakaṃ pucchi – “āvuso, imasmiṃ temāse kittake ṭhāne cittassa dhāvituṃ dinna”nti?
analyzed: akusala vitakkā na vitakketabbā ati katikam akaṃsu atha pavāraṇa divase saṅgha tthero 🔽saṅgha navakam pucchi āvuso imasmin temāse kittake ṭhāne cittassa dhāvitum dinnanti
translated: When one directs the mind to things cognizable by the mind, lust, etc., arise. Or covetousness, etc., come into focus. Such things should not be pursued. “May all beings be free from enmity” — such thoughts of loving-kindness, etc., should be pursued. Or the things of the three elders should be pursued. It is said that on the day of the beginning of the rains, the three elders made a rule not to think unwholesome thoughts such as thoughts of sense desire. Then on the invitation day, the senior elder asked the junior elder: “Friend, during this three-month period, how many times did you give your mind leave to run?”

original: Na, bhante, pariveṇaparicchedato bahi dhāvituṃ adāsinti. Dutiyaṃ pucchi – “tava āvuso”ti?🔽Nivāsagehato, bhante, bahi dhāvituṃ na adāsinti. Atha dvepi theraṃ pucchiṃsu “tumhākaṃ
analyzed: na bhante pariveṇa paricchedataḥ bahi dhāvitum adāsinti dutiyam pucchi tava āvuso ti  nivāsa gehataḥ bhante bahi dhāvitum na adāsinti atha dve pi theram tumhākam
translated: “No, venerable sir, I did not run outside the boundaries of the monastery.”🔽“Outside your dwelling, venerable sir?”🔽“No, venerable sir, I did not run outside my dwelling.”

original: pana, bhante”ti? Niyakajjhattakhandhapañcakato, āvuso, bahi dhāvituṃ na adāsinti.
analyzed: pana bhantā iti niyaka jjhatta khandha pañcakataḥ āvuso bahi dhāvitum na adāsinti
translated: “Outside the five aggregates subject to clinging, venerable sir?”🔽“You have done a difficult thing, venerable sir.”

original: Tumhehi, bhante, dukkaraṃ katanti. Evarūpo manoviññeyyo dhammo sevitabbo.
analyzed: tumhehi bhante dukkaram katanti evarūpaḥ manaḥ viññeyyaḥ dhammaḥ sevitabbaḥ
translated: “One should cultivate that idea which, when developed and expanded, leads to a pleasant dwelling in this very life.”

original: 366. Ekantavādāti ekoyeva anto vādassa etesaṃ, na dvedhā gatavādāti ekantavādā, ekaññeva
analyzed: ekantavādā ti eko yā iva antaḥ vādassa etesam na dvedhā gatavādā ati ekantavādā ekaññā iva
translated: “To what extent, Reverend Gotama, is one a sectarian, to what extent does one hold the views of a sectarian, to what extent is one a sectarian and a holder of the views of a sectarian?”🔽“To what extent, Reverend Gotama, is one virtuous, to what extent does one have the virtue of a sectarian, to what extent is one virtuous and has the virtue of a sectarian?”

original: vadantīti pucchati. Ekantasīlāti ekācārā. Ekantachandāti ekaladdhikā. Ekantaajjhosānāti ekantapariyosānā.🔽Anekadhātu nānādhātu kho, devānaminda, lokoti devānaminda, ayaṃ loko anekajjhāsayo
analyzed: vadanti iti pucchati ekanta sīlā ati eka ācārā ekanta chandā ati eka laddhikā ekanta ajjhosānā ati ekanta pariyosānā  aneka dhātu nānā dhātu kho devānaminda lokaḥ ti devānaminda ayam lokaḥ aneka ajjhāsayo
translated: “To what extent, Reverend Gotama, is one devoted, to what extent does one have the devotion of a sectarian, to what extent is one devoted and has the devotion of a sectarian?”🔽“To what extent, Reverend Gotama, is one a complete extremist, to what extent does one hold the views of a complete extremist, to what extent is one a complete extremist and a holder of the views of a complete extremist?”🔽“To what extent, Reverend Gotama, is one a complete extremist, to what extent does one hold the views of a complete extremist, to what extent is one a complete extremist and a holder of the views of a complete extremist?”🔽“To what extent, Reverend Gotama, is one virtuous, to what extent does one have the virtue of a sectarian, to what extent is one virtuous and has the virtue of a sectarian?”

original: nānajjhāsayo. Ekasmiṃ gantukāme eko ṭhātukāmo hoti. Ekasmiṃ ṭhātukāme eko sayitukāmo
analyzed: ekasmin gantu kāme ekaḥ ṭhātu kāmo hoti ekasmin ṭhātu kāme ekaḥ sayitu kāmo
translated: “To what extent, Reverend Gotama, is one devoted, to what extent does one have the devotion of a sectarian, to what extent is one devoted and has the devotion of a sectarian?”🔽“To what extent, Reverend Gotama, is one a complete extremist, to what extent does one hold the views of a complete extremist, to what extent is one a complete extremist and a holder of the views of a complete extremist?”

original: hoti. Dve sattā ekajjhāsayā nāma dullabhā. Tasmiṃ anekadhātunānādhātusmiṃ loke yaṃ
analyzed: hoti dve sattā ekajjhāsayā nāma dullabhā tasmin aneka dhātu nānā dhātusmin loke yaṃ
translated: It is difficult to find two beings who have the same disposition. In this world with its many different elements and dispositions,

original: yadeva dhātuṃ yaṃ yadeva ajjhāsayaṃ sattā abhinivisanti gaṇhanti, taṃ tadeva. Thāmasā🔽parāmāsāti thāmena ca parāmāsena ca. Abhinivissa voharantīti suṭṭhu gaṇhitvā voharanti,
analyzed: yat eva dhātum yam yat eva ajjhāsayam sattāḥ abhinivisanti gaṇhanti tam tat eva thāmasā  thāmena ca parāmāsena ca abhinivissa voharanti iti suṭṭhu gaṇhitvā voharanti
translated: whatever element and whatever disposition beings adhere to and grasp, that is their disposition.🔽With stubbornness and grasping: with stubbornness and grasping.

original: kathenti dīpenti kittenti. Idameva saccaṃ moghamaññanti idaṃ amhākameva vacanaṃ saccaṃ,🔽aññesaṃ vacanaṃ moghaṃ tucchaṃ niratthakanti.🔽Accantaniṭṭhāti anto vuccati vināso, antaṃ atītā niṭṭhā etesanti accantaniṭṭhā. Yā🔽etesaṃ niṭṭhā, yo paramassāso nibbānaṃ, taṃ sabbesaṃ vināsātikkantaṃ niccanti vuccati.
analyzed: kathenti dīpenti kittenti idam eva saccam mogham aññanti idam amhākam eva vacanam saccam  aññesam vacanam mogham tuccham niratthakanti  accanta niṭṭhā ti antaḥ vuccati vināsaḥ antam atītāḥ niṭṭhāḥ etesan ti accanta niṭṭhā yā  etesam niṭṭhā yaḥ parama ssāsaḥ nibbānam tam sabbesam vināsa atikkantam niccanti vuccati
translated: They speak out of a settled view: they speak, they proclaim, they declare, they explain, they set forth, they reveal, they make known, they analyse, they make plain, having grasped it well.🔽This alone is the truth, other than this there is none: this statement of ours alone is the truth, other statements are worthless, empty, useless.🔽They are utterly finished: destruction is called “the end.” Those who have gone to the end of their destruction are “utterly finished.”🔽The end of these, their ultimate goal, their Nibbāna, is said to be beyond all destruction, to be permanent.

original: Yogakkhemoti nibbānasseva nāmaṃ, accanto yogakkhemo etesanti accantayogakkhemī. Seṭṭhaṭṭhena
analyzed: yogakkhemaḥ ti nibbānassa iva nāmam accantaḥ yogakkhemaḥ etesan ti accanta yogakkhemī seṭṭha aṭṭhena
translated: The state of peace: this is a name for Nibbāna. Those who have the ultimate state of peace are “utterly secure.”

original: brahmaṃ ariyamaggaṃ carantīti brahmacārī. Accantatthāya brahmacārī accantabrahmacārī.
analyzed: brahmaṃ ariya maggam caranti iti brahmacārī accanta tthāya brahmacārī accanta brahmacārī
translated: He is a celibate because he is one who goes by the noble path that is celibacy. He is a celibate for the ultimate, a celibate for the supreme.

original: Pariyosānantipi nibbānassa nāmaṃ. Accantaṃ pariyosānaṃ etesanti accantapariyosānā.
analyzed: pariyosānam tipi nibbānassa nāmam accantam pariyosānam etesan ti accanta pariyosānā
translated: The word “end” is a name for Nibbāna. They have the ultimate end, thus they are those having the ultimate end.

original: Taṇhāsaṅkhayavimuttāti taṇhāsaṅkhayoti maggopi nibbānampi. Maggo taṇhaṃ saṅkhiṇāti
analyzed: taṇhā saṅkhaya vimuttā ati taṇhā saṅkhayo ti maggaḥ api nibbānam api maggaḥ taṇham saṅkhiṇāti
translated: They are liberated by the destruction of craving: the path and Nibbāna are called the destruction of craving. The path destroys craving,

original: vināsetīti taṇhāsaṅkhayo. Nibbānaṃ yasmā taṃ āgamma taṇhā saṅkhiyati vinassati, tasmā🔽taṇhāsaṅkhayo. Taṇhāsaṅkhayena maggena vimuttā, taṇhāsaṅkhaye nibbāne vimuttā adhimuttāti
analyzed: vināseti iti taṇhā saṅkhayaḥ nibbānam yasmā tam āgamma taṇhā saṅkhiyati vinassati tasmā  taṇhā saṅkhayaḥ taṇhā saṅkhayena maggena vimuttā taṇhā saṅkhaye nibbāne vimuttā adhimuttā ati
translated: it annihilates it, thus it is the destruction of craving. Nibbāna is called the destruction of craving because craving is destroyed, annihilated, in regard to it.

original: taṇhāsaṅkhayavimuttā.
analyzed: taṇhā saṅkhaya vimuttā
translated: They are liberated by the destruction of craving, liberated by the Nibbāna element that is the destruction of craving, thus they are liberated by the destruction of craving.

original: Ettāvatā ca bhagavatā cuddasapi mahāpañhā byākatā honti. Cuddasa mahāpañhā nāma issāmacchariyaṃ
analyzed: ettāvatā ca bhagavatā cuddasa api mahā pañhāḥ byākatāḥ honti cuddasa mahā pañhāḥ nāma
translated: And at this point the Blessed One has answered the fourteen great questions. The fourteen great questions are these: envy and avarice,

original: eko pañho, piyāppiyaṃ eko, chando eko, vitakko eko, papañco eko, somanassaṃ eko,
analyzed: ekaḥ pañhaḥ piya appiyam ekaḥ chandaḥ ekaḥ vitakko ekaḥ papañcaḥ ekaḥ somanassam ekaḥ
translated: one question; the dear and the not dear, one question; will, one question; thought, one question; obsession, one question; joy, one question;

original: domanassaṃ eko, upekkhā eko, kāyasamācāro eko, vacīsamācāro eko, pariyesanā eko,
analyzed: domanassam ekaḥ upekkhā ekaḥ kāya samācāraḥ ekaḥ vacī samācāraḥ ekaḥ pariyesanā ekaḥ
translated: one is grief, one is equanimity, one is bodily action, one is verbal action, one is search,

original: indriyasaṃvaro eko, anekadhātu eko, accantaniṭṭhā ekoti.
analyzed: indriya saṃvaraḥ ekaḥ aneka dhātu ekaḥ accanta niṭṭhā ekaḥ iti
translated: one is restraint of the faculties, one is the various elements, one is the ultimate goal.

original: 367. Ejāti calanaṭṭhena taṇhā vuccati. Sā pīḷanaṭṭhena rogo, anto padussanaṭṭhena
analyzed: calana ṭṭhena taṇhā vuccati sā pīḷana ṭṭhena rogaḥ antar padussana ṭṭhena
translated: “Craving” is said to be shaking in the sense of shaking. It is a disease in the sense of afflicting,

original: gaṇḍo, anuppaviṭṭhaṭṭhena sallaṃ. Tasmā ayaṃ purisoti yasmā ejā attanā katakammānurūpena
analyzed: gaṇḍaḥ an uppaviṭṭha ṭṭhena sallam tasmai ayam puriso iti yasmai ejā attanā kata kamma anurūpena
translated: a boil in the sense of festering inside, a dart in the sense of being deeply embedded. Therefore this person, in accordance with the deeds he has done,

original: purisaṃ tattha tattha abhinibbattatthāya kaḍḍhati, tasmā ayaṃ puriso tesaṃ tesaṃ
analyzed: purisam tattha tattha abhinibbatta tthāya kaḍḍhati tasmai ayam puriso tesam tesam
translated: pulls the person to be reborn here and there. Therefore this person, in accordance with the various

original: bhavānaṃ vasena uccāvacaṃ āpajjati. Brahmaloke ucco hoti, devaloke avaco. Devaloke
analyzed: bhavānam vasena uccāvacam āpajjati brahma loke uccaḥ hoti deva loke avacaḥ deva loke
translated: existences, falls into high and low. He is high in the Brahma world, low in the deva world. In the deva world

original: ucco, manussaloke avaco. Manussaloke ucco, apāye avaco. Yesāhaṃ, bhanteti yesaṃ ahaṃ
analyzed: uccaḥ manussa loke avacaḥ manussa loke uccaḥ apāye avacaḥ yesā aham bhante iti yesam aham
translated: he is high, in the human world he is low. In the human world he is high, in the lower realms he is low. Those, venerable sir,

original: bhante. Sandhivasena panettha “yesāha”nti hoti. Yathāsutaṃ yathāpariyattanti yathā
analyzed: bhante sandhi vasena pana ittha hoti yathāsutam yathā
translated: means those, venerable sir. But here “those” is in the sense of connection. As heard, as received means as

original: mayā suto ceva uggahito ca, evaṃ. Dhammaṃ desemīti sattavatapadaṃ dhammaṃ desemi.
analyzed: mayā sutaḥ ca iva uggahitaḥ ca evam dhammam desemi iti sattavata padam dhammam desemi
translated: I have heard and learned it thus: I teach the Dhamma thus.

original: Na cāhaṃ tesanti ahaṃ pana tesaṃ sāvako na sampajjāmi. Ahaṃ kho pana, bhantetiādinā
analyzed: na ca aham tesam ti aham pana tesam sāvakaḥ na sampajjāmi aham kho pana bhante iti ādinā
translated: I am not their equal: I do not become a disciple of theirs. But, venerable sir:

original: attano sotāpannabhāvaṃ jānāpeti.
analyzed: attanaḥ sotāpanna bhāvam jānāpeti
translated: he makes it known that he is a stream-enterer.

original: Somanassapaṭilābhakathāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: somanassa paṭilābha kathā vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the “story of the acquisition of joy” is ended.

original: 368. Vedapaṭilābhanti tuṭṭhipaṭilābhaṃ. Devāsurasaṅgāmoti devānañca asurānañca saṅgāmo.🔽Samupabyūḷhoti samāpanno nalāṭena nalāṭaṃ paharaṇākārappatto viya. Etesaṃ kira kadāci
analyzed: veda paṭilābhanti tuṭṭhi paṭilābham deva asura saṅgāmaḥ iti deva anañca asura anañca saṅgāmaḥ  samupabyūḍhaḥ iti samāpannaḥ nalāṭena nalāṭam paharaṇa ākāra ppattaḥ viya etesam kira kadācid
translated: The acquisition of knowledge: the acquisition of satisfaction. The battle between the gods and the demons: the battle between the gods and the demons.

original: mahāsamuddapiṭṭhe saṅgāmo hoti tattha pana chedanavijjhanādīhi aññamaññaṃ ghāto nāma
analyzed: mahā samudda piṭṭhe saṅgāmaḥ hoti tattha pana chedana vijjhana ādīhi aññamaññam ghātaḥ nāma
translated: Joined in conflict: engaged in conflict, as if they had met forehead to forehead. It seems that sometimes the battle takes place on the surface of the ocean. But there is no such thing as killing each other by cutting each other to pieces with swords and stabbing each other with spears.

original: natthi, dārumeṇḍakayuddhaṃ viya jayaparājayamattameva hoti. Kadāci devā jinanti,
analyzed: natthi dārumeṇḍaka yuddham viya jaya parājaya mattam eva kadāci devāḥ jinanti
translated: It is like the battle of two bundles of sticks. There is only victory and defeat. Sometimes the gods win,

original: kadāci asurā. Tattha yasmiṃ saṅgāme devā puna apaccāgamanāya asure jiniṃsu, taṃ sandhāya
analyzed: kadāci asurā tattha yasmin saṅgāme devā puna apaccāgamanāya asure tam sandhāya
translated: sometimes the demons. In this story it refers to the battle in which the gods defeated the demons so that they never returned.

original: tasmiṃ kho pana bhantetiādimāha. Ubhayametanti ubhayaṃ etaṃ. Duvidhampi ojaṃ ettha
analyzed: tasmin kho pana bhanta iti ādim āha ubhayam etat iti ubhayam etam duvidham pi ojam ettha
translated: The two kinds of nutriment here

original: devaloke devāyeva paribhuñjissantīti evamassa āvajjantassa balavapītisomanassaṃ uppajji.
analyzed: deva loke devāya iva paribhuñjissanti iti evam assa āvajjantassa balava pīti somanassam uppajji
translated: the gods in the divine world will enjoy themselves.

original: Sadaṇḍāvacaroti sadaṇḍāvacarako, daṇḍaggahaṇena satthaggahaṇena saddhiṃ ahosi, na
analyzed: sa daṇḍa avacaroti sa daṇḍa avacarakaḥ daṇḍa ggahaṇena sattha ggahaṇena saddhim na
translated: He who goes with a staff: he who goes with a staff, with the mention of the staff there is the mention of the sword,🔽he shows that he was not one who had laid aside staff and sword.

original: nikkhittadaṇḍasatthoti dasseti. Ekantanibbidāyāti ekanteneva vaṭṭe nibbindanatthāyāti
analyzed: nikkhitta daṇḍa satthaḥ ti dasseti ekanta nibbidāya āti ekantena iva vaṭṭe nibbindana atthāya āti
translated: For the sake of complete dispassion: for the sake of complete dispassion for the round.

original: sabbaṃ mahāgovindasutte vuttameva.
analyzed: sabbam mahāgovindasutte vuttam eva
translated: All this is as stated in the Mahā-Govinda Sutta.🔽He preached: he spoke, he explained.🔽Here: in this very place.

original: 369. Pavedesīti kathesi dīpesi. Idhevāti imasmiññeva okāse. Devabhūtassa me satoti
analyzed: pavedesi iti kathesi dīpesi idha iva ati imasmin ñeva okāse deva bhūtassa me satoti
translated: While I was a god: while I was a god.

original: devassa me sato. Punarāyu ca me laddhoti puna aññena kammavipākena me jīvitaṃ laddhanti,
analyzed: devassa me sataḥ punar āyu ca me laddhaḥ ti puna aññena kamma vipākena me jīvitam laddhanti
translated: I have obtained life again: by another ripening of kamma I have obtained life again,

original: iminā attano cutabhāvaṃ ceva upapannabhāvañca āvikaroti.
analyzed: iminā cuta bhāvam ca iva upapanna bhāvam ca āvikaroti
translated: by this he reveals his state of death and his state of rebirth.🔽Divine forms: divine individual forms.

original: Diviyā kāyāti dibbā attabhāvā. Āyuṃ hitvā amānusanti dibbaṃ āyuṃ jahitvā. Amūḷho
analyzed: diviyā kāyā ati dibbāḥ atta bhāvāḥ āyum hitvā amānusanti dibbam āyum jahitvā amūḍhaḥ
translated: Having given up the divine life: having given up the divine life,

original: gabbhamessāmīti niyatagatikattā amūḷho hutvā. Yattha me ramatī manoti yattha me mano
analyzed: gabbhamessāmi iti niyata gatikattā amūḍhaḥ hutvā yattha me ramatī yattha me mano
translated: “I will enter the womb” means that he enters the womb with full awareness, not confused. “Where my mind delights” means where his mind delights.

original: ramissati, tattheva khattiyakulādīsu gabbhaṃ upagacchissāmīti sattakkhattuṃ deve🔽ca mānuse cāti imamatthaṃ dīpeti.
analyzed: ramissati tattha eva khattiya kula ādīsu gabbham upagacchissāmi iti satta kkhattum deve  ca mānuse ca ati imam attham dīpeti
translated: “I shall enter the womb” : because of the fixedness of his destiny, he is not confused. “Where my mind delights” : where my mind will delight, there in the families of nobles, etc., I shall enter the womb. “Seven times among gods and men” : this is what he shows.

original: Ñāyena viharissāmīti manussesu upapannopi mātaraṃ jīvitā voropanādīnaṃ abhabbattā ñāyena kāraṇena samena viharissāmīti attho.
analyzed: ñāyena viharissāmi iti manussesu upapannaḥ api mātaram jīvitā voropana ādīnam abhabba ttā ñāyena kāraṇena samena viharissāmi iti atthaḥ
translated: “I shall live righteously” : even though reborn among men, he is incapable of killing his mother, etc., so he says, “I shall live righteously, by right means, by reason.”

original: Sambodhi ce bhavissatīti idaṃ sakadāgāmimaggaṃ sandhāya vadati, sace sakadāgāmī bhavissāmīti🔽dīpeti. Aññātā viharissāmīti aññātā ājānitukāmo hutvā viharissāmi. Sveva anto bhavissatīti
analyzed: sambodhi ce bhavissati iti idam sakadāgāmi maggam sandhāya vadati sace sakadāgāmī bhavissāmi iti  dīpeti aññātā viharissāmi iti aññātā ājānitu kāmaḥ hutvā viharissāmi su eva antaḥ bhavissati iti
translated: “If there is enlightenment” : he speaks with reference to the path of once-returner, showing that if he is to be a once-returner,

original: so eva me manussaloke anto bhavissatīti.
analyzed: saḥ eva me manussa loke antaḥ bhavissati iti
translated: “I shall live desiring to know” : I shall live desiring to know what is to be known. “It will be here within” : it will be here within me in the human world.

original: Puna devo bhavissāmi, devalokasmiṃ uttamoti puna devalokasmiṃ uttamo sakko devānamindo bhavissāmīti vadati.
analyzed: puna devaḥ bhavissāmi deva lokasmiṃ uttamaḥ ti puna deva lokasmiṃ uttamaḥ sakkaḥ devānamindaḥ bhavissāmi iti vadati
translated: “Again I shall be a god, the highest in the world of the gods” : he says that again he will be the highest Sakka, lord of the gods, in the world of the gods.

original: Antime vattamānamhīti antime bhave vattamāne. So nivāso bhavissatīti ye te āyunā
analyzed: antime vattamānamhi iti antime bhave vattamāne saḥ nivāsaḥ bhavissati iti ye te āyunā
translated: In the last existence: in the last becoming. That will be his abode: that will be his abode for a long time.

original: ca paññāya ca akaniṭṭhā jeṭṭhakā sabbadevehi paṇītatarā devā, avasāne me so nivāso🔽bhavissati. Ayaṃ kira tato sakkattabhāvato cuto tasmiṃ attabhāve anāgāmimaggassa🔽paṭiladdhattā uddhaṃsoto akaniṭṭhagāmī hutvā avihādīsu nibbattanto avasāne akaniṭṭhe🔽nibbattissati. Taṃ sandhāya evamāha. Esa kira avihesu kappasahassaṃ vasissati, atappesu🔽dve kappasahassāni, sudassesu cattāri kappasahassāni, sudassīsu aṭṭha, akaniṭṭhesu
analyzed: ca paññāya ca akaniṭṭhāḥ jeṭṭhakā sabba devehi paṇītatarāḥ devāḥ avasāne me so nivāso  bhavissati ayam kira tatas sakkatta bhāvataḥ cutaḥ tasmin atta bhāve anāgāmi maggassa  paṭiladdha ttā uddhaṃsotaḥ akaniṭṭha gāmī hutvā a vihādīsu nibbattantaḥ avasāne akaniṭṭhe  nibbattissati tam sandhāya evam āha esa kira avihesu kappa sahassam vasissati atappesu  dve kappa sahassāni sudassesu cattāri kappa sahassāni sudassīsu aṭṭha akaniṭṭhesu
translated: In my last life: in my last existence. That will be my abode: the gods called Akaniṭṭhas are the most excellent of all gods, being the highest in the form realm. They are the abode of those who have attained the highest distinction in life span and wisdom.

original: soḷasāti ekatiṃsa kappasahassāni brahmaāyuṃ anubhavissati. Sakko devarājā anāthapiṇḍiko🔽gahapati visākhā mahāupāsikāti tayopi hi ime ekappamāṇaāyukā eva, vaṭṭābhiratasattā
analyzed: ekatiṃsa kappa sahassāni brahma āyum anubhavissati sakkaḥ devarājā anāthapiṇḍiko 🔽gahapati visākhā mahā upāsikā ati tayaḥ api hi ime eka ppamāṇa āyukāḥ eva vaṭṭa abhirata sattā
translated: Translation: Antime vattamānamhīti antime bhave vattamāne | So nivāso bhavissatīti ye te āyunā ca paññāya ca akaniṭṭhā jeṭṭhakā sabbadevehi paṇītatarā devā, avasāne me so nivāso bhavissati | Ayaṃ kira tato sakkattabhāvato cuto tasmiṃ attabhāve anāgāmimaggassa paṭiladdhattā uddhaṃsoto akaniṭṭhagāmī hutvā avihādīsu nibbattanto avasāne akaniṭṭhe nibbattati | Taṃ sandhāya evamāha | Esa kira avihesu kappasahassaṃ vasissati, atappesu dve kappasahassāni, sudassesu cattāri kappasahassāni, sudassīsu aṭṭha, akaniṭṭhesu soḷasāti ekatiṃsa kappasahassāni brahmaāyuṃ anubhavissati | Sakko devarājā anāthapiṇḍiko gahapati visākhā mahāupāsikāti ime tayo ekappamāṇāyukāva, vaṭṭābhiratasattā

original: nāma etehi sadisā sukhabhāgino nāma natthi.
analyzed: nāma etehi sadisā sukhabhāginaḥ nāma natthi
translated: There are none who are so happy as they.

original: 370. Apariyositasaṅkappoti aniṭṭhitamanoratho. Yassu maññāmi samaṇeti ye ca samaṇe pavivittavihārinoti maññāmi.
analyzed: a pariyosita saṅkappo ti a niṭṭhita manorathaḥ yassu maññāmi samaṇa iti ye ca samaṇe pavivitta vihārino ti maññāmi
translated: “Whose wishes are not yet fulfilled”: whose desires are not yet satisfied. “I think they are ascetics”: I think they are those who live in seclusion.

original: Ārādhanāti sampādanā. Virādhanāti asampādanā. Na sampāyantīti sampādetvā kathetuṃ na sakkonti.
analyzed: ārādhanā ati sampādanā virādhanā ati a sampādanā na sampāyanti iti sampādetvā kathetum na sakkonti
translated: “To please”: to satisfy. “To displease”: to not satisfy. “They do not satisfy”: they are not able to satisfy and speak.

original: Ādiccabandhunanti ādiccopi gotamagotto, bhagavāpi gotamagotto, tasmā evamāha. Yaṃ🔽karomasīti yaṃ pubbe brahmuno namakkāraṃ karoma. Samaṃ devehīti devehi saddhiṃ, ito
analyzed: ādiccabandhunanti ādiccaḥ upi gotama gottaḥ bhagavā api gotama gottaḥ tasmai evam āha yam  karomasi iti yam pubbe brahmunaḥ namakkāram karoma samam devehi iti devehi saddhim itas
translated: “The kinsman of the sun”: the sun is of the Gotama clan, and the Blessed One is also of the Gotama clan, therefore he says this.

original: paṭṭhāya idāni amhākaṃ brahmuno namakkārakaraṇaṃ natthīti dasseti. Sāmaṃ karomāti namakkāraṃ karoma.
analyzed: paṭṭhāya idāni amhākam brahmunaḥ namakkāra karaṇam natthi iti dasseti sāmam karoma ati namakkāram karoma
translated: “What we do”: what we previously did in paying homage to Brahma. “Equally with the gods”: together with the gods. From now on, he shows that we will no longer pay homage to Brahma. “We do ourselves”: we pay homage.

original: 371. Parāmasitvāti tuṭṭhacitto sahāyaṃ hatthena hatthamhi paharanto viya pathaviṃ
analyzed: parāmasitvā ati tuṭṭha citto sahāyam hatthena hatthamhi paharantaḥ viya pathavim
translated: “Having grasped”: with a delighted mind, striking the earth as if striking a friend’s hand,

original: paharitvā, sakkhibhāvatthāya vā paharitvā “yathā tvaṃ niccalo, evamahaṃ bhagavatī”ti.
analyzed: paharitvā sakkhibhāvatthāya vā paharitvā yathā tvam niccalaḥ evam aham bhagavatī iti
translated: having struck for the sake of being a witness, “Just as you are steady, so am I, Blessed One.”

original: Ajjhiṭṭhapañhāti ajjhesitapañhā patthitapañhā. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānamevāti.
analyzed: ajjhiṭṭha pañhā ati ajjhesita pañhā patthita pañhā sesam sabbattha uttānam eva ati
translated: The question asked is the question asked for, requested. The rest is clear throughout.

original: Iti sumaṅgalavilāsiniyā dīghanikāyaṭṭhakathāyaṃ🔽Sakkapañhasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: iti sumaṅgalavilāsiniyā dīgha nikāya ṭṭhakathā ayam  sakkapañha sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: Thus ends the commentary on the Sakkapañhasutta in the Dīgha Nikāya.

original: 9. Mahāsatipaṭṭhānasuttavaṇṇanā
translated: The Mahāsatipaṭṭhāna Sutta

original: Uddesavārakathāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: uddesa vāra kathā vaṇṇanā
translated: The Commentary on the Introduction

original: 373. Evaṃ me sutanti mahāsatipaṭṭhānasuttaṃ. Tatrāyamapubbapadavaṇṇanā – ekāyano
analyzed: evam me sutam ti mahā sati paṭṭhāna suttam tatra ayam apubba pada vaṇṇanā ekāyanaḥ
translated: Thus have I heard. The Mahāsatipaṭṭhāna Sutta. Here is the commentary on the introductory words: This is the only way, monks, for the purification of beings, for the overcoming of sorrow and distress, for the disappearance of pain and sadness, for the gaining of the right path, for the realization of Nibbāna, namely, the four foundations of mindfulness.

original: ayaṃ, bhikkhave, maggoti kasmā bhagavā idaṃ suttamabhāsi? Kururaṭṭhavāsīnaṃ gambhīradesanāpaṭiggahaṇasamatthatāya.
analyzed: ayam bhikkhave maggaḥ ti kasmai bhagavā idam suttam abhāsi kuru raṭṭha vāsīnam gambhīra desanā paṭiggahaṇa samattha tāya
translated: Why did the Exalted One speak this discourse? Because the monks living in the Kuru country were capable of receiving a profound teaching.

original: Kururaṭṭhavāsino kira bhikkhū bhikkhuniyo upāsakā upāsikāyo utupaccayādisampannattā
analyzed: kururaṭṭhavāsinaḥ kira bhikkhū bhikkhuniyaḥ upāsakāḥ upāsikāyaḥ utu paccaya ādi sampanna ttā
translated: It seems that the monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen living in the Kuru country were endowed with the requisites of life such as clothing, etc.

original: tassa raṭṭhassa sappāyautupaccayasevanena niccaṃ kallasarīrā kallacittā ca honti.
analyzed: tassa raṭṭhassa sappāya otu paccaya sevanena niccam kalla sarīrā kalla cittā ca honti
translated: By using the requisites suitable to that country, they always had healthy bodies and minds.

original: Te cittasarīrakallatāya anuggahitapaññābalā gambhīrakathaṃ paṭiggahetuṃ samatthā
analyzed: te citta sarīra kalla tāya anuggahita paññā balāḥ gambhīra katham paṭiggahetum samatthāḥ
translated: Being assisted by healthy bodies and minds, they were able to receive a profound teaching.

original: honti. Tena nesaṃ bhagavā imaṃ gambhīradesanāpaṭiggahaṇasamatthataṃ sampassanto ekavīsatiyā
analyzed: honti tena na isam bhagavā imam gambhīra desanā paṭiggahaṇa samattha tam sampassantaḥ ekavīsatiyā
translated: The Exalted One, seeing that they were able to receive this profound teaching,🔽expounded the Mahāsatipaṭṭhāna Sutta, which is of profound meaning,

original: ṭhānesu kammaṭṭhānaṃ arahatte pakkhipitvā idaṃ gambhīratthaṃ mahāsatipaṭṭhānasuttaṃ

translated: But if any woman says, “I am attending to such and such an establishment of mindfulness,”🔽they applaud her, saying, “Well done, well done!” and they praise her, saying, “Your life is well lived, you have attained to humanity, the Enlightened One has arisen in vain for others.”

original: sammāsambuddho uppanno”tiādīhi pasaṃsanti. Na kevalañcettha manussajātikāva satipaṭṭhānamanasikārayuttā,

analyzed: natthi ayye iti āvuso pabbajitānam santike vasantena nāma vissaṭṭha atta bhāvena bhavitum  na vaṭṭati kocid eva manasikāraḥ icchitabbo tvam pana aññam na sakkhissasi

original: Taṃ ekadivasaṃ pātova toraṇagge nisīditvā bālātapaṃ tapamānaṃ eko sakuṇo nakhapañjarena🔽aggahesi. So “kiri kirī”ti saddamakāsi. Sāmaṇeriyo sutvā “ayye buddharakkhito sakuṇena🔽gahito, mocema na”nti leḍḍuādīni gahetvā anubandhitvā mocesuṃ. Taṃ ānetvā purato🔽ṭhapitaṃ therī āha – “buddharakkhita, sakuṇena gahitakāle kiṃ cintesī”ti? Na, ayye,
analyzed: tam eka divasam toraṇa gge nisīditvā bāla ātapam tapamānam ekaḥ sakuṇaḥ nakha pañjarena  aggahesi so kiri kiri iti saddam akāsi sāmaṇeriyaḥ sutvā ayye buddha rakkhito sakuṇena  gahitaḥ mocema leḍḍu ādīni gahetvā anubandhitvā tam ānetvā puratas  ṭhapitam therī āha buddha rakkhita sakuṇena gahita kāle kim cintesi iti na ayye

original: aññaṃ kiñci cintesiṃ, aṭṭhipuñjova aṭṭhipuñjaṃ gahetvā gacchati, katarasmiṃ ṭhāne🔽vippakirissatīti, evaṃ ayye aṭṭhipuñjameva cintesinti. Sādhu, sādhu, buddharakkhita,🔽anāgate bhavakkhayassa te paccayo bhavissatīti. Evaṃ tattha tiracchānagatāpi satipaṭṭhānamanasikārayuttā.
analyzed: aññam kiñci cintesiṃ aṭṭhi puñjā uva aṭṭhi puñjam gahetvā gacchati katarasmim ṭhāne  vippakirissati iti evam ayye aṭṭhi puñjam eva cintesin ti sādhu sādhu buddha rakkhita  anāgate bhava kkhayassa te paccayaḥ bhavissati iti evam tattha tiracchāna gatā api sati paṭṭhāna manasikāra yuttā
translated: One day a bird caught him in its claws as he was sunning himself on the top of a gateway. He cried out “kiri kiri.” The female novices heard him and said, “Venerable, Buddharakkhita has been caught by a bird. Let us free him.” They took up clods and sticks and followed the bird, which dropped Buddharakkhita in front of them as soon as it saw them. The female novices took him and put him in front of the nun. The nun said, “Buddharakkhita, what were you thinking of when you were caught by the bird?” “Venerable, I was not thinking of anything else. I was thinking only of bones, ‘Where will he scatter me, a heap of bones, as he carries me off, a heap of bones?’” “Good, good, Buddharakkhita. This will be a condition for you for the destruction of future becoming.” So even animals are occupied with the establishment of mindfulness.

original: Tasmā nesaṃ bhagavā satipaṭṭhānabuddhimeva janento idaṃ suttamabhāsi.
analyzed: tasmai bhagavā sati paṭṭhāna buddhim eva janentaḥ idam suttam abhāsi
translated: That is why the Blessed One, wishing to make them mindful by means of the establishment of mindfulness, uttered this sutta.

translated: “Way, path, road, track, course,

original: Atha vā ekena ayitabboti ekāyano. Ekenāti gaṇasaṅgaṇikaṃ pahāya vūpakaṭṭhena pavivittacittena.

translated: Or alternatively, it is a single way since it is to be gone by means of one only. By means of one only is by means of one who has gone forth by means of the going forth consisting in the renunciation of the hindrances.

original: Ayitabbo paṭipajjitabbo, ayanti vā etenāti ayano, saṃsārato nibbānaṃ gacchantīti🔽attho. Ekassa ayano ekāyano. Ekassāti seṭṭhassa. Sabbasattaseṭṭho ca bhagavā, tasmā
analyzed: ayitabbaḥ paṭipajjitabbaḥ ayanti vai etena ati ayanaḥ saṃsārataḥ nibbānam gacchanti iti  atthaḥ ekassa ayanaḥ eka ayanaḥ ekassa ati seṭṭhassa sabba satta seṭṭho ca bhagavā tasmai
translated: It is to be gone by means of that, to be practised by means of that, is what is meant. Or alternatively, it is a way since it is gone by means of that, is practised by means of that. The meaning of that is that it goes to Nibbāna from the round of rebirths.🔽It is a single person’s way since it is gone by means of one only. By means of one only is by means of the best. And the Blessed One is the best of all beings,🔽so it is said of the Blessed One that “it is a single person’s way.”

original: bhagavatoti vuttaṃ hoti. Kiñcāpi hi tena aññepi ayanti, evaṃ santepi bhagavatova
analyzed: bhagavato ti vuttam hoti kiñcā api hi tena aññe pi ayanti evam sante pi bhagavato va

analyzed: saḥ ayanaḥ tena uppādita ttā yathā āha saḥ hi brāhmaṇa bhagavā anuppannassa maggassa  uppādeta atiādi ayati iti vā ayanaḥ gacchati pavattati iti attho ekasmin ayano ti ekāyanaḥ  imasmin ñeva dhamma vinaye pavattati na aññattha ati vuttam hoti yathā āha imasmiṃ  kho subhadda dhamma vinaye ariyaḥ aṭṭhaṅgikaḥ maggo upalabbhati iti desanā bhedaḥ yā iva  ha iso atthataḥ pana ekaḥ iva apica ekam ayati iti ekāyanaḥ pubbabhāge nānā mukha bhāvanā naya ppavattaḥ api
translated: It is a way because it is produced by that. As it is said: “That Blessed One, brahmin, is the producer of the unproduced path” , and so on. Or alternatively, it goes , thus it is a way ; the meaning is that it occurs. It is a single way in this , thus it is the single way ; it occurs only in this Dhamma and Discipline, not elsewhere, is what is meant. As it is said: “In this Dhamma and Discipline, friend, the noble eight-factored path is found” . This is a mere difference in the teaching; in meaning it is the same. Moreover, it goes as one , thus it is the single way . Although in the earlier stage it occurs as the development of the way in various aspects,

original: aparabhāge ekaṃ nibbānameva gacchatīti vuttaṃ hoti. Yathāha brahmā sahampati –
analyzed: aparabhāge ekam nibbānam eva gacchati iti vuttam hoti yathā āha brahmā sahampati
translated: It is a way because it is generated by that. As it is said: “That Blessed One, brahmin, is the generator of the un generated path” , and so on. Or alternatively, it goes , thus it is a way ; the meaning is that it occurs. It is a single way in one , thus it is a single way ; it occurs in this Dhamma and Discipline only, not elsewhere, is what is meant. As it is said: “In this Dhamma and Discipline, Subhadda, the ariyan eightfold path is obtained” . This is a mere difference of phrasing; in meaning it is the same. Moreover, it goes in one way, thus it is a single way . Although in the earlier stage it occurs as the development of the way in various aspects, still it is said that in the later stage it goes in one way only to extinction. As the divine being Sahampati said:

original: Ekāyanaṃ jātikhayantadassī,

analyzed: tasmai ekāyanā iti vadanti tam na yujjati imassa hi atthassa iminā  byañjanena bhavitabbam yadi pana ekam ayanam assa ekā gati pavatti iti evam attham

analyzed: yojetvā vucceyya byañjanam yujjeyya attho pana ubhayathā api na yujjati kasmai idha

translated: Because the path of the preliminary stage is intended here. For the path of the foundations of mindfulness occurring with the four objects beginning with the body is intended here, not the supramundane path, and that occurs many times and has many occurrences.
