analyzed: kathitaḥ cūḷanāgaḥ pubbabhāga maggo ti ādāya voharati kaḥ nu kho ettha nicchayo ti suttantam  āditaḥ paṭṭhāya parivattento yaḥ hi koci bhikkhave ime cattāro sati paṭṭhāne evam  bhāveyya satta vassāni iti imasmin ṭhāne sallakkhesi lokuttara maggo uppajjitvā satta
translated: but Cūḷanāga is teaching the preliminary path. Which is correct?” He therefore began to recite the suttas from the beginning.

original: vassāni tiṭṭhamāno nāma natthi, mayā vutto missakamaggo na labbhati. Cūḷanāgena diṭṭho
analyzed: vassāni tiṭṭhamānaḥ nāma natthi mayā vuttaḥ missaka maggaḥ na labbhati cūḷanāgena diṭṭho
translated: When he came to the passage, “If anyone should develop these four foundations of mindfulness in such a way for seven years” , he understood, “There is no supramundane path that arises and lasts for seven years. The mixed path that I have taught is not found. The preliminary path that Cūḷanāga has seen is the only one that is found.”

original: pubbabhāgamaggova labbhatīti ñatvā aṭṭhamiyaṃ dhammasavane saṅghuṭṭhe agamāsi.
analyzed: pubbabhāga maggaḥ uva labbhati iti ñatvā aṭṭhamiyam dhammasavane saṅghuṭṭhe agamāsi
translated: On the eighth day, when the Dhamma discussion was held, he went to the assembly.

original: Porāṇakattherā kira piyadhammasavanā honti, saddaṃ sutvāva “ahaṃ paṭhamaṃ, ahaṃ paṭhama”nti
analyzed: porāṇaka therā kira piya dhamma savanā honti saddam sutvā va aham paṭhamam aham paṭhamanti
translated: It seems that the elder bhikkhus were fond of hearing the Dhamma. When they heard the sound of the gong, they said, “I first, I first!”

original: ekappahāreneva osaranti. Tasmiñca divase cūḷanāgattherassa vāro, tena dhammāsane
analyzed: eka ppahārena iva osaranti tasmin ca divase cūḷanāga ttherassa vāro tena dhamma āsane
translated: and they all descend at once. On that day it was the turn of the Elder Cūḷanāga. He sat down in the Dhamma seat,

original: nisīditvā bījaniṃ gahetvā pubbagāthāsu vuttāsu therassa āsanapiṭṭhiyaṃ ṭhitassa etadahosi
analyzed: nisīditvā bījanim gahetvā pubba gāthāsu vuttāsu therassa āsana piṭṭhiyam ṭhitassa etat ahosi
translated: took his fan, and when the first stanza was recited, he stood behind the teacher’s seat and thought,

original: – “raho nisīditvā na vakkhāmī”ti. Porāṇakattherā hi anusūyakā honti. Na attano rucimeva
analyzed: rahaḥ nisīditvā na vakkhāmi iti porāṇaka therāḥ hi anusūyakāḥ honti na attanaḥ rucim eva
translated: “I will not speak in private.” For the elders of old were not envious. They did not go about proclaiming their own views

original: ucchubhāraṃ viya evaṃ ukkhipitvā vicaranti, kāraṇameva gaṇhanti, akāraṇaṃ vissajjenti.
analyzed: ucchu bhāram viya evam ukkhipitvā vicaranti kāraṇam eva gaṇhanti akāraṇam vissajjenti
translated: like a flag hoisted on a chariot. They took up only what was reasonable and rejected what was not.

original: Tasmā thero “āvuso, cūḷanāgā”ti āha. So ācariyassa viya saddoti dhammaṃ ṭhapetvā🔽“kiṃ bhante”ti āha. Āvuso, cūḷanāga, mayā vutto missakamaggo na labbhati, tayā vutto
analyzed: tasmā theraḥ āvuso cūḷanāgā ti āha so ācariyassa viya saddo ti dhammam ṭhapetvā  kim bhante ti āha āvuso cūḷanāga mayā vuttaḥ missaka maggaḥ na labbhati tayā vuttaḥ
translated: So the elder said, “Friend Cūḷanāga.” The other thought, “The sound is like that of my teacher,” and he put aside his own view

original: pubbabhāgasatipaṭṭhānamaggova labbhatīti. Thero cintesi – “amhākaṃ ācariyo sabbapariyattiko
analyzed: pubbabhāga sati paṭṭhāna maggaḥ uva labbhati iti thero cintesi amhākam ācariyaḥ sabba pariyattiko
translated: and said, “What is it, venerable sir?” “Friend Cūḷanāga, the path I have described cannot be found. The path of the preliminary stages of the foundations of mindfulness that you have described can be found.” The elder thought, “Our teacher is a master of the entire tradition,

original: tepiṭako sutabuddho, evarūpassāpi nāma bhikkhuno ayaṃ pañho āluḷeti, anāgate mama
analyzed: tepiṭakaḥ suta buddhaḥ evarūpassa api nāma bhikkhunaḥ ayam pañhaḥ āluḷeti anāgate mama
translated: a master of the scriptures, a man of great learning. Yet even for such a bhikkhu this question is too hard for him. In the future,

original: bhātikā imaṃ pañhaṃ āluḷessantīti suttaṃ gahetvā imaṃ pañhaṃ niccalaṃ karissāmī”ti🔽paṭisambhidāmaggato “ekāyanamaggo vuccati pubbabhāgasatipaṭṭhānamaggo”.
analyzed: bhātikāḥ imam pañham āluḷessanti iti suttam gahetvā imam pañham niccalam karissāmi iti  paṭisambhidā maggataḥ ekāyana maggaḥ vuccati pubbabhāga satipaṭṭhāna maggo
translated: I will take the Thread and make this question stand still.”🔽In the Path of Discrimination he took the Thread beginning, “The one-way path is said to be the path of the four foundations of mindfulness in the prior stage” ,

original: Maggānaṭṭhaṅgiko seṭṭho, saccānaṃ caturo padā;
analyzed: maggān aṭṭhaṅgikaḥ seṭṭhaḥ saccānam caturaḥ padā
translated: and he made the question stand still with the verse, “The path with eight factors is best, the four truths are the best of words,

original: Virāgo seṭṭho dhammānaṃ, dvipadānañca cakkhumā.
analyzed: virāgaḥ seṭṭhaḥ dhammānam dvipadānam ca cakkhumā
translated: Fading of lust is best of states, the Enlightened One is best of men.

original: Eseva maggo natthañño, dassanassa visuddhiyā;
analyzed: esa iva maggaḥ dassanassa visuddhiyā
translated: This is the path, there is no other, for the purification of vision,

original: Etañhi tumhe paṭipajjatha, mārasenappamaddanaṃ;
analyzed: etat hi tumhe paṭipajjatha māra sena pamaddanam
translated: So do you follow this, to crush Mara’s power,

original: Etañhi tumhe paṭipannā, dukkhassantaṃ karissathāti. –
analyzed: etam hi tumhe paṭipannāḥ dukkhassantam karissatha ati
translated: For by following this you will make an end of suffering” .

original: Suttaṃ āharitvā ṭhapesi.
analyzed: suttam āharitvā ṭhapesi
translated: and he made the question stand still with the verse.

original: Maggoti kenaṭṭhena maggo? Nibbānagamanaṭṭhena nibbānatthikehi magganīyaṭṭhena ca.
analyzed: maggaḥ iti kena ṭṭhena maggaḥ nibbāna gamana ṭṭhena nibbāna atthikehi magganīya ṭṭhena ca
translated: “ Path” : in what sense is it a path? In the sense of going to extinction, and in the sense of being what should be gone by those who want extinction.

original: Sattānaṃ visuddhiyāti rāgādīhi malehi abhijjhāvisamalobhādīhi ca upakkilesehi kiliṭṭhacittānaṃ
analyzed: sattānam visuddhiyā ati rāga ādīhi malehi abhijjhā visama lobha ādīhi ca upakkilesehi kiliṭṭha cittānam
translated: “ For the purification of beings” : for the purification of beings whose minds are soiled by defilements such as lust and by stains such as covetousness and wrong livelihood.

original: sattānaṃ visuddhatthāya. Tathā hi imināva maggena ito satasahassakappādhikānaṃ catunnaṃ
analyzed: sattānam visuddha tthāya tathā hi iminā āva maggena itas sata sahassa kappa adhikānam catunnam
translated: For it is by this path that those who have been in existence for a hundred thousand aeons or more have attained extinction.

original: asaṅkhyeyyānaṃ upari ekasmiṃyeva kappe nibbatte taṇhaṅkaramedhaṅkarasaraṇaṅkaradīpaṅkaranāmake
analyzed: upari ekasmin yeva kappe nibbatte taṇhaṅkara medhaṅkara saraṇaṅkara dīpaṅkara nāmake
translated: In the course of a single aeon after the aeon incalculable in the past, there appeared the Buddhas Taṇhaṅkara, Medhaṅkara, Saraṇaṅkara, Dīpaṅkara,

original: buddhe ādiṃ katvā sakyamunipariyosānā aneke sammāsambuddhā anekasatā paccekabuddhā🔽gaṇanapathaṃ vītivattā ariyasāvakā cāti ime sattā sabbe cittamalaṃ pavāhetvā paramavisuddhiṃ
analyzed: buddhe ādim katvā sakya muni pariyosānāḥ aneke sammāsambuddhāḥ aneka satā paccekabuddhā  gaṇana patham vītivattāḥ ariya sāvakā ca ati ime sattā sabbe citta malam pavāhetvā parama visuddhim
translated: and so on, ending with the Sage of the Sakyans. There were many fully enlightened Buddhas, many hundreds of paccekabuddhas,🔽and countless noble disciples. All these beings purified their minds of defilements and attained the highest purity. But there is no such thing as the purification of matter by means of the process of purification of defilements.

original: pattā. Rūpamalavasena pana saṃkilesavodānapaññattiyeva natthi. Tathā hi –
analyzed: pattā rūpa mala vasena pana saṃkilesa vodāna paññattiyā iva natthi tathā hi
translated: For it is said:

original: “Rūpena saṃkiliṭṭhena, saṃkilissanti māṇavā;
analyzed: rūpena saṃkiliṭṭhena saṃkilissanti māṇavāḥ
translated: “By defiled matter, young men, beings are defiled;

original: Rūpe suddhe visujjhanti, anakkhātaṃ mahesinā.
analyzed: rūpe suddhe visujjhanti an akkhātam mahesinā
translated: By pure matter they are purified, though the Great Sage has not declared it.

original: Cittena saṃkiliṭṭhena, saṃkilissanti māṇavā;
analyzed: cittena saṃkiliṭṭhena saṃkilissanti māṇavāḥ
translated: By defiled mind, young men, beings are defiled;

original: Citte suddhe visujjhanti, iti vuttaṃ mahesinā”.
analyzed: citte suddhe visujjhanti iti vuttam mahesinā
translated: By pure mind they are purified, as the Great Sage has declared.”

original: Yathāha – “cittasaṃkilesā, bhikkhave, sattā saṃkilissanti, cittavodānā visujjhantī”ti. Tañca cittavodānaṃ iminā satipaṭṭhānamaggena hoti. Tenāha “sattānaṃ visuddhiyā”ti.
analyzed: yathā āha citta saṃkilesāḥ bhikkhave sattā saṃkilissanti citta vodānāḥ visujjhanti iti tat ca citta vodānam iminā sati paṭṭhāna maggena hoti tena āha sattānam visuddhiyā ati
translated: As it is said: “Bhikkhus, it is by the defilement and cleansing of the mind that beings are defiled and purified” . And that purification of the mind comes about through this path of the establishment of mindfulness. Hence it is said “for the purification of beings” .

original: Sokaparidevānaṃ samatikkamāyāti sokassa ca paridevassa ca samatikkamāya pahānāyāti🔽attho, ayañhi maggo bhāvito santatimahāmattādīnaṃ viya sokasamatikkamāya, paṭācārādīnaṃ
analyzed: soka paridevānam samatikkamāya ati sokassa ca paridevassa ca samatikkamāya pahānāya ati  atthaḥ ayam hi maggaḥ bhāvitaḥ santati mahāmatta ādīnam viya soka samatikkamāya paṭa ācāra ādīnam
translated: For the surmounting of sorrow and lamentation: the meaning is for the abandoning of sorrow and lamentation. For this path, when developed, leads to the surmounting of sorrow as in the case of the Elder Mahā Moggallāna, and to the surmounting of lamentation as in the case of the Elder Cunda.🔽

original: viya paridevasamatikkamāya saṃvattati. Tenāha “sokaparidevānaṃ samatikkamāyā”ti.
analyzed: viya parideva samatikkamāya saṃvattati tena āha soka paridevānam samatikkamāya iti
translated: For the surmounting of sorrow and lamentation : for the surmounting of sorrow and for the surmounting of lamentation. The meaning is: for the abandoning of sorrow and lamentation. For this path, when developed, leads to the surmounting of sorrow, as in the case of the Elder Santati the Great Steward, and to the surmounting of lamentation, as in the case of the lay woman disciple Paṭācārā. That is why he said: “For the surmounting of sorrow and lamentation.”

original: Kiñcāpi hi santatimahāmatto –
analyzed: kiñca api hi santati mahā mattaḥ
translated: And although the Elder Santati the Great Steward

original: “Yaṃ pubbe taṃ visodhehi, pacchā te mātu kiñcanaṃ;
analyzed: yam pubbe tam visodhehi pacchā te mātu kiñcanam
translated: “Clear away what was done before, and what you have for your mother later;

original: Majjhe ce no gahessasi, upasanto carissasī”ti. ;
analyzed: majjhe ce naḥ gahessasi upasantaḥ carissasi iti
translated: If you do not grasp at the middle, you will go about quite secluded” ,

original: Imaṃ gāthaṃ sutvāva saha paṭisambhidāhi arahattaṃ patto. Paṭācārā –
analyzed: imam gātham sutvā ava saha arahattam patto paṭa ācārā
translated: he reached Arahantship together with the analytical knowledges as soon as he had heard this stanza. And although the lay woman disciple Paṭācārā

original: “Na santi puttā tāṇāya, na pitā nāpi bandhavā;
analyzed: na santi puttā tāṇāya na pitā na api bandhavā
translated: “There are no sons to be a refuge, nor father nor relatives;

original: Antakenādhipannassa, natthi ñātīsu tāṇatā”ti. ;
analyzed: antakena adhipannassa na atthi ñātīsu tāṇa tā ati
translated: When one is overcome by death, there is no protection in kinsmen” ,

original: Imaṃ gāthaṃ sutvā sotāpattiphale patiṭṭhitā. Yasmā pana kāyavedanācittadhammesu kañci
analyzed: imam gātham sutvā sa utāpatti phale patiṭṭhitāḥ yasmai pana kāya vedanā citta dhammesu kañci
translated: she became established in the fruition of Stream Entry as soon as she had heard this stanza. But when one has seen with understanding that in the case of bodily pain,

original: dhammaṃ anāmasitvā bhāvanā nāma natthi, tasmā tepi imināva maggena sokaparideve samatikkantāti veditabbā.
analyzed: dhammaṃ a nāmasitvā bhāvanā nāma natthi tasmā te pi iminā ava maggena soka parideve samatikkantā ati veditabbā
translated: And since there is no development without the Dhamma, they too should be understood as having overcome sorrow and lamentation by this same path.

original: Dukkhadomanassānaṃ atthaṅgamāyāti kāyikadukkhassa cetasikadomanassassa cāti imesaṃ🔽dvinnaṃ atthaṅgamāya, nirodhāyāti attho. Ayañhi maggo bhāvito tissattherādīnaṃ viya
analyzed: dukkha domanassānaṃ atthaṅgamāya ati kāyika dukkhassa cetasika domanassassa ca ati imesam  dvinnam atthaṅgamāya nirodhāya ati atthaḥ ayan hi maggaḥ bhāvito tissa tthera ādīnam viya
translated: For the cessation of pain and grief: for the cessation of bodily pain and mental grief.

original: dukkhassa, sakkādīnaṃ viya ca domanassassa atthaṅgamāya saṃvattati.🔽Tatrāyaṃ atthadīpanā – sāvatthiyaṃ kira tisso nāma kuṭumbikaputto cattālīsa hiraññakoṭiyo🔽pahāya pabbajitvā agāmake araññe viharati. Tassa kaniṭṭhabhātu bhariyā “gacchatha,
analyzed: dukkhassa sakka ādīnam viya ca domanassassa atthaṅgamāya saṃvattati  tatra ayam attha dīpanā sāvatthiyam kira tisso nāma kuṭumbika putto cattālīsa hirañña koṭiyaḥ  pahāya pabbajitvā agāmake araññe viharati tassa kaniṭṭha bhātu bhariyāḥ gacchatha
translated: The meaning is: for their cessation, for their stopping. For this path, when developed, leads to the cessation of pain as in the case of the Elder Tissa, and to the cessation of grief as in the case of Sakka, the chief of the devas.

original: naṃ jīvitā voropethā”ti pañcasate core pesesi. Te gantvā theraṃ parivāretvā nisīdiṃsu.
analyzed: nam jīvitā vā uropetha ati pañca sate core pesesi te gantvā theram parivāretvā nisīdiṃsu
translated: Here is the explanation of the meaning. A clansman named Tissa, it seems, who was the son of a wealthy family in Sāvatthī, went forth into homelessness after giving up forty crores of treasure. He lived in the forest in an uninhabited place. His younger brother’s wife sent five hundred thieves to him, telling them, “Go and kill him.” They went and sat down surrounding the elder.

original: Thero āha – “kasmā āgatattha upāsakā”ti? Taṃ jīvitā voropessāmāti. Pāṭibhogaṃ me
analyzed: theraḥ āha kasmai āgatatthaḥ upāsakā ati tam jīvitā voropessāma ati pāṭibhogam me
translated: The elder said, “Why have you come, lay followers?” —“To kill you.” —“Then wait until I have finished my meditation period.”

original: upāsakā, gahetvā ajjekarattiṃ jīvitaṃ dethāti. Ko te, samaṇa, imasmiṃ ṭhāne pāṭibhogo🔽bhavissatīti? Thero mahantaṃ pāsāṇaṃ gahetvā dve ūruṭṭhīni bhinditvā “vaṭṭati upāsakā
analyzed: upāsakāḥ gahetvā ajja eka rattim jīvitam detha ati kaḥ te samaṇaḥ imasmin ṭhāne pāṭibhogaḥ  bhavissati iti theraḥ mahantam pāsāṇam gahetvā dve ūruṭṭhīni bhinditvā vaṭṭati upāsakā
translated: “Monks, take him and kill him this very night.” “Who will be your guarantor in this matter?”

original: pāṭibhogo”ti āha. Te apakkamitvā caṅkamanasīse aggiṃ katvā nipajjiṃsu. Therassa vedanaṃ
analyzed: āha te a pakkamitvā caṅkamana sīse aggim katvā nipajjiṃsu therassa vedanam
translated: The Elder took a large stone, broke both his thighs, and said, “Monks, I am your guarantor.” They departed, built a fire at the head of the Elder’s bed, and lay down.

original: vikkhambhetvā sīlaṃ paccavekkhato parisuddhaṃ sīlaṃ nissāya pītipāmojjaṃ uppajji.
analyzed: vikkhambhetvā sīlam paccavekkhato parisuddham sīlam nissāya pīti pāmojjam uppajji
translated: The Elder suppressed his pain, reviewed the purity of his virtue, and experienced joy and happiness.

original: Tato anukkamena vipassanaṃ vaḍḍhento tiyāmarattiṃ samaṇadhammaṃ katvā aruṇuggamane
analyzed: tatas anukkamena vipassanam vaḍḍhento tiyāma rattim samaṇa dhammam katvā aruṇuggamane
translated: Then, gradually increasing his insight, he practiced the Dhamma for three watches of the night and attained arahatship at dawn.

original: arahattaṃ patto imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi –
analyzed: arahattam pattaḥ imam udānam udānesi
translated: At that moment he uttered this verse of joy:

original: “Ubho pādāni bhinditvā, saññapessāmi vo ahaṃ;
analyzed: ubho pādāni bhinditvā saññapessāmi vaḥ aham
translated: “Having broken both my thighs, I will instruct you.

original: Aṭṭiyāmi harāyāmi, sarāgamaraṇaṃ ahaṃ.
analyzed: aham
translated: I am disgusted and ashamed of dying with lust.

original: Evāhaṃ cintayitvāna, yathābhūtaṃ vipassisaṃ;
analyzed: eva aham cintayitvāna yathābhūtam vipassisam
translated: Having thus reflected, I saw things as they really are.

original: Sampatte aruṇuggamhi, arahattamapāpuṇi”nti.
analyzed: sampatte aruṇuggamhi arahattam apāpuṇinti
translated: When dawn broke, I attained arahatship.”

original: Aparepi tiṃsa bhikkhū bhagavato santike kammaṭṭhānaṃ gahetvā araññavihāre vassaṃ
analyzed: apare pi tiṃsa bhikkhū bhagavato santike kammaṭṭhānam gahetvā arañña vihāre vassam
translated: Thirty other bhikkhus also received a meditation subject from the Exalted One and entered upon residence for the Rains in a forest dwelling.

original: upagantvā “āvuso, tiyāmarattiṃ samaṇadhammova kātabbo, na aññamaññassa santikaṃ āgantabba”nti
analyzed: upagantvā āvuso tiyāma rattim samaṇa dhammaḥ uva kātabbaḥ na añña maññassa santikam āgantabbanti
translated: They made an agreement among themselves: “Friends, the whole of the night should be devoted to the ascetic practices; no one should come to see anyone else.”

original: vatvā vihariṃsu. Tesaṃ samaṇadhammaṃ katvā paccūsasamaye pacalāyantānaṃ eko byaggho
analyzed: vatvā vihariṃsu tesam samaṇa dhammam katvā paccūsa samaye pacalāyantānam ekaḥ byagghaḥ
translated: They lived in this way. When they had practiced the ascetic practices and it was the time for the first watch of the night, a tiger came and took away one of the bhikkhus.

original: āgantvā ekekaṃ bhikkhuṃ gahetvā gacchati. Na koci “maṃ byaggho gaṇhī”ti vācampi nicchāresi.
analyzed: āgantvā ekekam bhikkhum gahetvā gacchati na koci mam byagghaḥ gaṇhi iti vācam pi nicchāresi
translated: No one uttered a sound, thinking: “The tiger has taken away a bhikkhu.”

original: Evaṃ pañcasu dasasu bhikkhūsu khāditesu uposathadivase “itare, āvuso, kuhi”nti pucchitvā
analyzed: evam pañcasu dasasu bhikkhūsu khāditesu uposatha divase itare āvuso kuhin ti pucchitvā
translated: When five or ten bhikkhus had been devoured in this way, on the Uposatha day they asked: “Friends, where are the others?”

original: ñatvā ca “idāni gahitena gahitomhīti vattabba”nti vatvā vihariṃsu. Atha aññataraṃ
analyzed: ñatvā ca idāni gahitena gahito mhi iti vattabbanti vatvā vihariṃsu atha aññataram
translated: When they found out what had happened, they said: “Now we must say: ‘I have been taken away by the one who has taken away the others.’” And they lived in this way.

original: daharabhikkhuṃ purimanayeneva byaggho gaṇhi. So “byaggho bhante”ti āha. Bhikkhū kattaradaṇḍe
analyzed: dahara bhikkhum purima nayena iva byagghaḥ gaṇhi saḥ byagghaḥ bhante ti āha bhikkhū kattaradaṇḍe
translated: Then a certain young bhikkhu was taken away by the tiger in the manner described above. He said: “Tiger, venerable sir!” The bhikkhus said:🔽“What is the use of saying ‘tiger, venerable sir’?

original: ca ukkāyo ca gahetvā mocessāmāti anubandhiṃsu. Byaggho bhikkhūnaṃ agatiṃ chinnataṭaṭṭhānamāruyha
analyzed: ca ukkāyaḥ ca gahetvā mocessāma ati anubandhiṃsu byagghaḥ bhikkhūnam agatim chinna taṭa ṭṭhānam āruyha
translated: and taking torches, followed after him. The tiger, having climbed to the place where the bhikkhu’s clothes were hanging,

original: taṃ bhikkhuṃ pādaṅguṭṭhakato paṭṭhāya khādituṃ ārabhi. Itarepi “idāni sappurisa,
analyzed: tam bhikkhum pādaṅguṭṭhakataḥ paṭṭhāya khāditum ārabhi itare pi idāni sappurisa
translated: began to eat the bhikkhu from the tip of his toe. The others said: “Now, good man,

original: amhehi kattabbaṃ natthi, bhikkhūnaṃ viseso nāma evarūpe ṭhāne paññāyatī”ti āhaṃsu.
analyzed: amhehi kattabbam natthi bhikkhūnam visesaḥ nāma evarūpe ṭhāne paññāyati iti āhaṃsu
translated: there is nothing we can do. The distinction of the bhikkhus is known in such a place.”

original: So byagghamukhe nipannova taṃ vedanaṃ vikkhambhetvā vipassanaṃ vaḍḍhento yāva gopphakā
analyzed: saḥ byaggha mukhe nipannaḥ iva tam vedanam vikkhambhetvā vipassanam vaḍḍhentaḥ yāva gopphakā
translated: While lying in the tiger’s mouth, he suppressed the feeling, and increasing his insight, from the ankles🔽while being eaten, he became a Stream-Winner; from the knees

original: khāditasamaye sotāpanno hutvā, yāva jaṇṇukā khāditasamaye sakadāgāmī, yāva nābhiyā
analyzed: khādita samaye sa utāpannaḥ hutvā yāva jaṇṇukā khādita samaye sakadāgāmī yāva nābhiyā
translated: while being eaten, he became a Once-Returner; from the navel🔽while being eaten, he became a Non-Returner; and without the flesh of the heart being eaten,

original: khāditasamaye anāgāmī hutvā, hadayarūpe akhāditeyeva saha paṭisambhidāhi arahattaṃ
analyzed: khādita samaye anāgāmī hutvā hadaya rūpe saha arahattam
translated: having attained Liberation together with the analytical knowledges,

original: patvā imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi –
analyzed: patvā imam udānam udānesi
translated: he uttered this exalted utterance:

original: “Sīlavā vatasampanno, paññavā susamāhito;🔽Muhuttaṃ pamādamanvāya, byagghenoruddhamānaso.
analyzed: sīlavā vata sampannaḥ paññavā su samāhito  muhuttam pamādam anvāya byagghena uruddha mānasaḥ
translated: “Verily, he who is virtuous, who has attained concentration, who is wise, and is well-composed,🔽having for a moment been negligent, is obstructed by the tiger in his mind.

original: Pañjarasmiṃ gahetvāna, silāya uparī kato;
analyzed: pañjarasmin silāyaḥ uparī kato
translated: Having been seized in the cage, he is made to lie on the rock;

original: Kāmaṃ khādatu maṃ byaggho, aṭṭhiyā ca nhārussa ca;
analyzed: kāmam khādatu mama byagghaḥ aṭṭhiyā ca nhārussa ca
translated: Let the tiger eat me, bones and sinews,

original: Kilese khepayissāmi, phusissāmi vimuttiya”nti.
analyzed: kilese khepayissāmi phusissāmi vimuttiyanti
translated: I will destroy the defilements, and will touch Nibbāna.”

original: Aparopi pītamallatthero nāma gihikāle tīsu rajjesu paṭākaṃ gahetvā tambapaṇṇidīpaṃ
analyzed: aparaḥ api pītamalla ttheraḥ nāma gihi kāle tīsu rajjesu paṭākam gahetvā tamba paṇṇi dīpam
translated: Another was the Elder Pītamallatissa. In the time when he was a layman he had hoisted flags in three kingdoms and had come to the island of Tambapaṇṇi.

original: āgamma rājānaṃ passitvā raññā katānuggaho ekadivasaṃ kilañjakāpaṇasāladvārena gacchanto
analyzed: āgamma rājānam passitvā raññā kata anuggahaḥ eka divasam kilañja kāpaṇa sāla dvārena gacchantaḥ
translated: After he had seen the king and had been favoured by the king, one day as he was going along the door of the gambling house,

original: “rūpaṃ, bhikkhave, na tumhākaṃ, taṃ pajahatha, taṃ vo pahīnaṃ dīgharattaṃ hitāya
analyzed: rūpam bhikkhave na tumhākam tam pajahatha tam vaḥ pahīnam dīgharattam hitāya
translated: “Form, monks, is not yours; abandon it. When you have abandoned it, it will lead to your welfare and happiness for a long time.”

original: sukhāya bhavissatī”ti na tumhākavākyaṃ sutvā cintesi “neva kira rūpaṃ attano, na
analyzed: sukhāya bhavissati iti na tumhāka vākyam sutvā cintesi na iva kira rūpam na
translated: After hearing the words “It is not yours,” he thought, “It seems that neither form nor feeling is one’s own.”

original: vedanā”ti. So taṃyeva aṅkusaṃ katvā nikkhamitvā mahāvihāraṃ gantvā pabbajjaṃ yācitvā
analyzed: vedanā iti saḥ taṃyeva aṅkusam katvā nikkhamitvā mahāvihāram gantvā pabbajjam yācitvā
translated: Making that very goad, he went forth, went to the Great Monastery, asked for the going forth,

original: pabbajito upasampanno dvemātikā paguṇā katvā tiṃsa bhikkhū gahetvā gabalavāliyaaṅgaṇaṃ
analyzed: pabbajitaḥ upasampannaḥ dve mātikā paguṇā katvā tiṃsa bhikkhū gahetvā gabalavāliya aṅgaṇam
translated: and after he had gone forth and been ordained, he made the two Codes his very own, took thirty monks, went to the courtyard of Gabalavāliya,

original: gantvā samaṇadhammaṃ akāsi. Pādesu avahantesu jaṇṇukehi caṅkamati. Tamenaṃ rattiṃ
analyzed: gantvā samaṇa dhammam akāsi pādesu avahantesu jaṇṇukehi caṅkamati tam enam rattim
translated: and did the ascetic’s duties. When his feet would not move, he walked on his knees. At night

original: eko migaluddako migoti maññamāno pahari. Satti vinivijjhitvā gatā, so taṃ sattiṃ
analyzed: ekaḥ miga luddakaḥ migo ti maññamāno pahari satti vinivijjhitvā gatā saḥ tam sattim
translated: A hunter, thinking it was a deer, struck it. The spear went right through it and came out the other side. He pulled out the spear

original: harāpetvā paharaṇamukhāni tiṇavaṭṭiyā pūrāpetvā pāsāṇapiṭṭhiyaṃ attānaṃ nisīdāpetvā🔽okāsaṃ kāretvā vipassanaṃ vaḍḍhetvā saha paṭisambhidāhi arahattaṃ patvā ukkāsitasaddena
analyzed: harāpetvā paharaṇa mukhāni tiṇavaṭṭiyā pūrāpetvā pāsāṇa piṭṭhiyam attānam nisīdāpetvā  okāsam kāretvā vipassanam vaḍḍhetvā saha paṭisambhidāhi arahattam patvā ukkāsita saddena
translated: and filled the wound with a tuft of grass, after which he sat down on a flat rock and had his meal.

original: āgatānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ byākaritvā imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi –
analyzed: āgatānam bhikkhūnam byākaritvā imam udānaṃ udānesi
translated: Then he made a sign to the bhikkhus, who came and asked him what he wanted. He told them what he had done and asked them to expound the Dhamma. They did so, and he reached Arahantship together with the analytical knowledges. Then he announced his attainment to the bhikkhus by a sign and uttered this stanza of rejoicing:

original: “Bhāsitaṃ buddhaseṭṭhassa, sabbalokaggavādino;
analyzed: bhāsitam buddha seṭṭhassa sabba lokagga vādinaḥ
translated: “The Buddha, the best of speakers, has said,

original: Na tumhākamidaṃ rūpaṃ, taṃ jaheyyātha bhikkhavo.
analyzed: na tumhākam idam rūpam tam jaheyyātha bhikkhavaḥ
translated: ‘This is not your form, bhikkhus; abandon it.’🔽Impermanent, alas! are formations;

original: Aniccā vata saṅkhārā, uppādavayadhammino;
analyzed: aniccāḥ vata saṅkhārāḥ uppāda vaya dhammino
translated: Their nature is to arise and vanish;

original: Uppajjitvā nirujjhanti, tesaṃ vūpasamo sukho”ti.
analyzed: uppajjitvā nirujjhanti tesam vūpasamaḥ sukhaḥ ti
translated: Having arisen, they cease: their stilling is bliss.”

original: Evaṃ tāva ayaṃ maggo tissattherādīnaṃ viya dukkhassa atthaṅgamāya saṃvattati.
analyzed: evam tāva ayam maggo tissa thera ādīnam viya dukkhassa atthaṅgamāya saṃvattati
translated: So this path leads to the cessation of suffering in the way just described.

original: Sakko pana devānamindo attano pañcavidhapubbanimittaṃ disvā maraṇabhayasantajjito
analyzed: sakkaḥ pana devānamindaḥ attanaḥ pañcavidha pubba nimittam disvā maraṇa bhaya santajjitaḥ
translated: Sakka Ruler of Gods, on the other hand, saw the five signs portending his death, and he was terrified by the fear of death.

original: domanassajāto bhagavantaṃ upasaṅkamitvā pañhaṃ pucchi. So upekkhāpañhavissajjanāvasāne
analyzed: domanassa jātaḥ bhagavantam upasaṅkamitvā pañham pucchi so upekkhā pañha vissajjana avasāne
translated: and he went to the Lord and asked him a question. At the end of the answer to his question on equanimity,

original: asītisahassāhi devatāhi saddhiṃ sotāpattiphale patiṭṭhāsi. Sā cassa upapatti puna pākatikāva ahosi.
analyzed: asīti sahassāhi devatāhi saddhim sotāpatti phale patiṭṭhāsi sā ca ssa upapatti puna pākatikā ava ahosi
translated: he was established in the fruit of stream-entry together with eighty thousand deities. And his rebirth was restored to its former state.

original: Subrahmāpi devaputto accharāsahassaparivuto saggasampattiṃ anubhoti. Tattha pañcasatā
analyzed: subrahmā api deva putto accharā sahassa parivuto sagga sampattim anubhoti tattha pañcasatā
translated: The god Subrahma, surrounded by a thousand celestial nymphs, was enjoying celestial glory. There, five hundred of the nymphs,

original: accharāyo rukkhato pupphāni ocinantiyo cavitvā niraye uppannā. So “kiṃ imā cirāyantī”ti
analyzed: accharāyaḥ rukkhataḥ pupphāni ocinantiyaḥ cavitvā niraye uppannā so kim imā cirāyanti iti
translated: while plucking flowers from a tree, died and were reborn in hell. He thought: “Why are they so long? “

original: upadhārento tāsaṃ niraye nibbattanabhāvaṃ ñatvā “kittakaṃ nu kho mama āyū”ti upaparikkhanto
analyzed: upadhārentaḥ tāsam niraye nibbattana bhāvam ñatvā kittakam nu kho mama āyūti upaparikkhantaḥ
translated: He looked into it and saw that they had been reborn in hell. Then he thought: “How long is my own life? “

original: attano āyuparikkhayaṃ viditvā cavitvā tattheva niraye nibbattanabhāvaṃ disvā bhīto
analyzed: attanaḥ āyu parikkhayam viditvā cavitvā tattha iva niraye nibbattana bhāvam disvā bhītaḥ
translated: He saw that his own life was at an end. Then he saw that he himself would be reborn in that same hell. He was frightened

original: ativiya domanassajāto hutvā “imaṃ me domanassaṃ satthā vinayissati, na añño”ti avasesā
analyzed: ativiya domanassa jātaḥ hutvā imam me domanassam satthā vinayissati na aññaḥ ti avasesā
translated: and became very depressed. He thought: “The Lord will remove this depression of mine, not anyone else.” So he took the remaining

original: pañcasatā accharāyo gahetvā bhagavantaṃ upasaṅkamitvā pañhaṃ pucchi –
analyzed: pañca satāḥ accharāyaḥ gahetvā bhagavantam upasaṅkamitvā pañham pucchi
translated: five hundred nymphs and went to the Lord and asked him a question:

original: “Niccaṃ utrastamidaṃ cittaṃ, niccaṃ ubbiggidaṃ mano;
analyzed: niccam utrastam idam cittam niccam ubbiggidam manaḥ
translated: “This mind is ever fearful, ever anxious,

original: Anuppannesu kicchesu, atho uppatitesu ca;
analyzed: anuppannesu kicchesu atho uppatitesu ca
translated: About troubles that have not yet arisen, and about those that have.

original: Sace atthi anutrastaṃ, taṃ me akkhāhi pucchitoti. ;
analyzed: sace atthi anutrastam tam me akkhāhi pucchito ti
translated: If there is a mind that is not fearful, please tell me, when asked.”

original: Tato naṃ bhagavā āha –
analyzed: tatas nam bhagavān āha
translated: Then the Blessed One said:

original: “Nāññatra bojjhā tapasā, nāññatrindriyasaṃvarā;
analyzed: na aññatra bojjhā tapasā na aññatra indriya saṃvarā
translated: “Not apart from striving, not apart from restraint of the senses,

original: Nāññatra sabbanissaggā, sotthiṃ passāmi pāṇina”nti. ;
analyzed: na aññatra sabba nissaggā sotthim passāmi pāṇinaṃ ti
translated: Not apart from relinquishing all, do I see safety for breathing beings.”

original: So desanāpariyosāne pañcahi accharāsatehi saddhiṃ sotāpattiphale patiṭṭhāya taṃ sampattiṃ
analyzed: saḥ desanā pariyosāne pañcahi accharāsatehi saddhim sotāpatti phale patiṭṭhāya tam sampattim
translated: At the conclusion of the teaching, together with five hundred celestial nymphs, he was established in the fruit of stream-entry.🔽Making that attainment firm, he went to the heavenly world.

original: thāvaraṃ katvā devalokameva agamāsīti. Evaṃ ayaṃ maggo bhāvito sakkādīnaṃ viya domanassassa🔽atthaṅgamāya saṃvattatīti veditabbo.🔽Ñāyassa adhigamāyāti ñāyo vuccati ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo, tassa adhigamāya, pattiyāti
analyzed: thāvaram katvā deva lokam eva agamāsi iti evam ayam maggo bhāvitaḥ sakka ādīnam viya domanassassa  atthaṅgamāya saṃvattati iti veditabbaḥ  ñāyassa adhigamāya ati ñāyaḥ vuccati ariyaḥ aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo tassa adhigamāya pattiyā ati
translated: Thus this path, when developed, leads to the destruction of sorrow, as in the case of Sakka and others.🔽To the realization of the right way: the right way is said to be the noble eightfold path. To its realization, to its attainment, is what is meant.

original: vuttaṃ hoti. Ayañhi pubbabhāge lokiyo satipaṭṭhānamaggo bhāvito lokuttaramaggassa
analyzed: vuttam hoti ayam hi pubba bhāge lokiyaḥ sati paṭṭhāna maggaḥ bhāvitaḥ lokuttara maggassa
translated: For this path of the establishment of mindfulness, which is mundane in the earlier stage, when developed, leads to the attainment of the supramundane path.

original: adhigamāya saṃvattati. Tenāha “ñāyassa adhigamāyā”ti. Nibbānassa sacchikiriyāyāti
analyzed: adhigamāya saṃvattati tena āha ñāyassa adhigamāya ati nibbānassa sacchikiriyāya ati
translated: It leads to the realization of the knowledge of the way. Hence it is said: “to the realization of the knowledge of the way.”🔽To the direct-knowledge of Nibbana:

original: taṇhāvānavirahitattā nibbānanti laddhanāmassa amatassa sacchikiriyāya, attapaccakkhatāyāti
analyzed: taṇhā vāna virahita ttā nibbānanti laddha nāmassa amatassa sacchikiriyāya atta paccakkha tāya ati
translated: to the direct-knowledge, the personal experience, of the deathless, which is called “Nibbana” because it is the absence of craving.

original: vuttaṃ hoti. Ayañhi maggo bhāvito anupubbena nibbānasacchikiriyaṃ sādheti. Tenāha
analyzed: vuttam hoti ayam hi maggaḥ bhāvitaḥ anupubbena nibbāna sacchikiriyam sādheti tena āha
translated: For this path, when developed, eventually brings about the direct-knowledge of Nibbana. Hence it is said:

original: “nibbānassa sacchikiriyāyā”ti.
analyzed: nibbānassa sacchikiriyāya ati
translated: “to the direct-knowledge of Nibbana.”

original: Tattha kiñcāpi “sattānaṃ visuddhiyā”ti vutte sokasamatikkamādīni atthato siddhāneva🔽honti, ṭhapetvā pana sāsanayuttikovide aññesaṃ na pākaṭāni, na ca bhagavā paṭhamaṃ
analyzed: tattha kiñcā api sattānam visuddhiyā ti vutte soka sama tikkama ādīni atthato siddhāna eva  honti ṭhapetvā pana sāsana yutti kovide aññesam na pākaṭāni na ca bhagavā paṭhamam
translated: Here, although the overcoming of sorrow, etc., are actually included when “for the purification of beings” is said,

original: sāsanayuttikovidaṃ janaṃ katvā pacchā dhammaṃ deseti. Tena teneva pana suttena taṃ
analyzed: sāsana yutti kovidam janam katvā pacchā dhammam deseti tena tena iva pana suttena tam
translated: nevertheless, except for those skilled in the interpretation of the Dispensation, it is not obvious to others. And the Blessed One does not teach the Dhamma first to those skilled in the interpretation of the Dispensation and afterwards to others.

original: taṃ atthaṃ ñāpeti. Tasmā idha yaṃ yaṃ atthaṃ ekāyanamaggo sādheti, taṃ taṃ pākaṭaṃ
analyzed: tam attham ñāpeti tasmai idha yam yam attham ekāyana maggo sādheti tam tam pākaṭam
translated: But he makes known this and that meaning by this and that sutta. Therefore here the meaning that the One-Way Path accomplishes is made obvious.

original: katvā dassento “sokaparidevānaṃ samatikkamāyā”tiādimāha. Yasmā vā yā sattānaṃ visuddhi
analyzed: katvā dassento soka paridevānam samatikkamāya ati ādim āha yasmai vā yā sattānam visuddhi
translated: and he said “For the overcoming of sorrow and lamentation” and so on. Or alternatively, since the purification of beings

original: ekāyanamaggena saṃvattati, sā sokaparidevānaṃ samatikkamena hoti. Sokaparidevānaṃ🔽samatikkamo dukkhadomanassānaṃ atthaṅgamena, dukkhadomanassānaṃ atthaṅgamo ñāyassādhigamena,🔽ñāyassādhigamo nibbānassa sacchikiriyāya. Tasmā imampi kamaṃ dassento “sattānaṃ visuddhiyā”ti
analyzed: ekāyana maggena saṃvattati sā soka paridevānam samatikkamena hoti soka paridevānam  samatikkamaḥ dukkha domanassānaṃ atthaṅgamena dukkha domanassānaṃ atthaṅgamaḥ ñāyassa adhigamena  ñāyassa adhigamaḥ nibbānassa sacchikiriyāya tasmai imam pi kamam dassentaḥ sattānam visuddhiyā ti
translated: comes about by the means of the direct path, that purification is the overcoming of sorrow and lamentation. The overcoming of sorrow and lamentation🔽is the cessation of pain and grief. The cessation of pain and grief is the realization of the state of peace. The realization of the state of peace is the realization of Nibbāna. Therefore, showing this benefit too, he said “For the purification of beings”

original: vatvā “sokaparidevānaṃ samatikkamāyā”tiādimāha.🔽Apica vaṇṇabhaṇanametaṃ ekāyanamaggassa. Yatheva hi bhagavā – “dhammaṃ vo, bhikkhave,🔽desessāmi ādikalyāṇaṃ majjhekalyāṇaṃ pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ
analyzed: vatvā soka paridevānam samatikkamāya ati ādim āha  apica vaṇṇa bhaṇanam etam ekāyana maggassa yathā iva hi bhagavā dhammam vaḥ bhikkhave  desessāmi ādi kalyāṇam majjhe kalyāṇam pariyosāna kalyāṇam sa attham sa byañjanam kevala paripuṇṇam
translated: and so on.

original: parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pakāsessāmi yadidaṃ chachakkānī”ti chachakkadesanāya aṭṭhahi
analyzed: parisuddham brahmacariyam pakāsessāmi yat idam chachakkāni iti chachakka desanāya aṭṭhahi
translated: Moreover, this is a praise of the direct path. For just as the Exalted One, in the Chachakka Sutta, said: “Monks, I shall teach you the Dhamma, which is beautiful in the beginning, beautiful in the middle, and beautiful in the end, with its own meaning, with its own phrasing, the spiritual life—that is, the community of monks” , and then he taught the Dhamma in eight sections,

original: padehi vaṇṇaṃ abhāsi. Yathā ca ariyavaṃsadesanāya “cattārome, bhikkhave, ariyavaṃsā
analyzed: padehi vaṇṇam abhāsi yathā ca ariya vaṃsa desanāya cattāro me bhikkhave ariya vaṃsā
translated: “Bhikkhus, there are these four noble lineages,

original: aggaññā rattaññā vaṃsaññā porāṇā asaṃkiṇṇā asaṃkiṇṇapubbā na saṅkīyanti na saṅkīyissanti,
analyzed: aggaññāḥ rattaññāḥ vaṃsaññāḥ porāṇāḥ a saṃkiṇṇāḥ a saṃkiṇṇa pubbāḥ na saṅkīyanti na saṅkīyissanti
translated: noble, ancient, traditional, this-worldly, unworldly, not liable to extinction until the end of the aeon,🔽not despised by wise recluses and brahmins.”

original: appaṭikuṭṭhā samaṇehi brāhmaṇehi viññūhī”ti navahi padehi vaṇṇaṃ abhāsi; evaṃ imassāpi
analyzed: appaṭikuṭṭhā samaṇehi brāhmaṇehi viññūhi iti navahi padehi vaṇṇam abhāsi evam imassa api
translated: So too, he extolled this

original: ekāyanamaggassa sattānaṃ visuddhiyātiādīhi sattahi padehi vaṇṇaṃ abhāsi. Kasmāti
analyzed: ekāyana maggassa sattānam visuddhiyā ati ādīhi sattahi padehi vaṇṇam abhāsi kasmā iti
translated: Noble Eightfold Path in seven terms beginning with “for the purification of beings.”🔽Why?

original: ce, tesaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ ussāhajananatthaṃ. Vaṇṇabhāsanañhi sutvā te bhikkhū “ayaṃ kira🔽maggo hadayasantāpabhūtaṃ sokaṃ, vācāvippalāpabhūtaṃ paridevaṃ, kāyikaasātabhūtaṃ
analyzed: ce tesam bhikkhūnam ussāha janana attham vaṇṇa bhāsanam hi sutvā te bhikkhū ayam kira  maggaḥ hadaya santāpa bhūtam sokam vācā vippalāpa bhūtam paridevam kāyika asāta bhūtam
translated: In order to arouse enthusiasm in those bhikkhus. For when they heard the Exalted One extolling the path, they would think:

original: dukkhaṃ, cetasikaasātabhūtaṃ domanassanti cattāro upaddave hanati, visuddhiṃ ñāyaṃ
analyzed: dukkham cetasika asātabhūtam domanassanti cattāro upaddave hanati visuddhim ñāyam
translated: “This path destroys the four dangers, namely, sorrow, lamentation, pain,🔽grief, and despair, and brings about the three kinds of distinction, namely, purification, the true way, and Nibbana.”

original: nibbānanti tayo visese āvahatī”ti ussāhajātā imaṃ dhammadesanaṃ uggahetabbaṃ pariyāpuṇitabbaṃ
analyzed: nibbānanti tayaḥ visese āvahati iti ussāha jātāḥ imam dhamma desanam uggahetabbam pariyāpuṇitabbam
translated: Thus they would be inspired to learn and master this teaching.

original: dhāretabbaṃ, vācetabbaṃ, imañca maggaṃ bhāvetabbaṃ maññissanti. Iti tesaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ🔽ussāhajananatthaṃ vaṇṇaṃ abhāsi. Kambalavāṇijādayo kambalādīnaṃ vaṇṇaṃ viya.
analyzed: dhāretabbam vācetabbam imañca maggam bhāvetabbam maññissanti iti tesam bhikkhūnam  ussāha janana attham vaṇṇam abhāsi kambala vāṇija ādayaḥ kambala ādīnam vaṇṇam viya
translated: In order to generate enthusiasm in those bhikkhus, he extolled it, just as the merchants extolled the blankets, etc.

original: Yathā hi satasahassagghanikapaṇḍukambalavāṇijena ‘kambalaṃ gaṇhathā’ti ugghositepi
analyzed: yathā hi sata sahassa gghanika paṇḍu kambala vāṇijena kambalam gaṇhatha ati ugghosite pi
translated: For when the merchant who had brought the blanket worth a hundred thousand was announcing, “Take the blanket!”

original: asukakambaloti na tāva manussā jānanti. Kesakambalavāḷakambalādayopi hi duggandhā
analyzed: asuka kambalaḥ ti na tāva manussāḥ jānanti kesa kambala vāḷa kambala ādayaḥ api hi duggandhā
translated: people did not know which one it was. For even the blankets of goats’ hair and sheep’s hair, etc., are called “blankets,” though they are malodorous and rough to the touch.

original: kharasamphassā kambalātveva vuccanti. Yadā pana tena gandhārako rattakambalo sukhumo🔽ujjalo sukhasamphassoti ugghositaṃ hoti, tadā ye pahonti, te gaṇhanti. Ye nappahonti,🔽tepi dassanakāmā honti; evameva ‘ekāyano, bhikkhave, ayaṃ maggo’ti vuttepi asukamaggoti

original: “Catunnaṃ, bhikkhave, satipaṭṭhānānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca desessāmi, taṃ suṇātha…pe…🔽ko ca, bhikkhave, kāyassa samudayo. Āhārasamudayā kāyassa samudayo”tiādīsu hi satigocaro🔽satipaṭṭhānanti vuccati. Tathā “kāyo upaṭṭhānaṃ no sati, sati pana upaṭṭhānañceva
analyzed: catunnam bhikkhave satipaṭṭhānānam samudayam ca atthaṅgamam ca desessāmi tam suṇāthape  kaḥ ca bhikkhave kāyassa samudayaḥ āhāra samudayā kāyassa samudayaḥ ti ādīsu hi sati gocaraḥ  satipaṭṭhānanti vuccati tathā kāyaḥ upaṭṭhānam no sati sati pana upaṭṭhānam ca eva
translated: “Bhikkhus, I will teach you the origin and the passing away of the four foundations of mindfulness. Listen and attend closely to what I shall say” .🔽Herein, the object of mindfulness is called a “foundation of mindfulness”🔽in the sense of footing for mindfulness, just as “mind and bodily form” are called a “footing for mindfulness” .

original: sati cā”tiādīsupi. Tassattho – patiṭṭhāti asminti paṭṭhānaṃ. Kā patiṭṭhāti? Sati.🔽Satiyā paṭṭhānaṃ satipaṭṭhānaṃ, padhānaṃ ṭhānanti vā paṭṭhānaṃ. Satiyā paṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: sati ca ati ādīsu pi tassa atthaḥ patiṭṭhāti asmin ti paṭṭhānam kā patiṭṭhāti sati  satiyā paṭṭhānam sati paṭṭhānam padhānam ṭhānam anti vā paṭṭhānam satiyā paṭṭhānam
translated: The meaning is this: it is a footing because it is stood upon by this, that is to say, by mindfulness. What is the footing? Mindfulness.🔽The foundation of mindfulness is the footing for mindfulness. Or alternatively, the foundation of mindfulness is the footing of mindfulness.

original: satipaṭṭhānaṃ hatthiṭṭhānaassaṭṭhānādīni viya.
analyzed: sati paṭṭhānam hatthi ṭṭhāna assa ṭṭhāna ādīni viya
translated: Just as “the footing of an elephant” or “the footing of a bull” is the place for walking, standing, sitting and lying down of the elephant, the bull, etc.,

original: “Tayo satipaṭṭhānā yadariyo sevati, yadariyo sevamāno satthā gaṇamanusāsituṃ arahatī”ti
analyzed: tayo sati paṭṭhānā yat ariyaḥ sevati yat ariyaḥ sevamāno satthā gaṇam anusāsitum arahati iti
translated: “There are these three foundations of mindfulness that the Noble One cultivates, cultivating which the Noble One is a teacher fit to instruct a group” ,

original: ettha tidhā paṭipannesu sāvakesu satthuno paṭighānunayavītivattatā “satipaṭṭhāna”nti
analyzed: ettha tidhā paṭipannesu sāvakesu satthuno paṭigha anunaya vītivatta tā sati paṭṭhānan ti
translated: here the Noble One’s absence of aversion and absence of greed in regard to disciples who are rightly practising in the three ways is called “foundation of mindfulness” .

original: vuttā. Tassattho – paṭṭhapetabbato paṭṭhānaṃ, pavattayitabbatoti attho. Kena paṭṭhapetabbatoti?
analyzed: vuttā tassa atthaḥ paṭṭhapetabbataḥ paṭṭhānam pavattayitabbataḥ ti attho kena paṭṭhapetabbataḥ ti
translated: and the meaning is that they are to be caused to occur. By what are they to be caused to occur?

original: Satiyā. Satiyā paṭṭhānaṃ satipaṭṭhānaṃ. “Cattāro satipaṭṭhānā bhāvitā bahulīkatā
analyzed: satiyā satiyā paṭṭhānam sati paṭṭhānam cattāro sati paṭṭhānāḥ bhāvitāḥ bahulīkatā
translated: By mindfulness. Mindfulness is the cause of occurrence, thus they are “Foundations of Mindfulness” . In such passages as “The four foundations of mindfulness, developed and repeatedly practised,

original: satta sambojjhaṅge paripūrentī”tiādīsu pana satiyeva “satipaṭṭhānaṃ”ti vuccati. Tassattho
analyzed: satta sambojjhaṅge paripūrenti itiādīsu pana satiyā iva sati paṭṭhānam ti vuccati tassa attho
translated: complete the seven factors of enlightenment” , it is mindfulness itself that is called “foundation of mindfulness” . The meaning of that is this:

original: – paṭṭhātīti paṭṭhānaṃ, upaṭṭhāti okkanditvā pakkhanditvā pattharitvā pavattatīti
analyzed: paṭṭhāti iti paṭṭhānam upaṭṭhāti okkanditvā pakkhanditvā pattharitvā pavattati iti
translated: it occurs , thus it is a foundation ; the meaning is that it occurs by leaping across and descending and spreading out.

original: attho. Satiyeva satipaṭṭhānaṃ. Atha vā saraṇaṭṭhena sati, upaṭṭhānaṭṭhena paṭṭhānaṃ.
analyzed: atthaḥ satiyā iva sati paṭṭhānam atha vā saraṇa ṭṭhena satī upaṭṭhāna ṭṭhena paṭṭhānam
translated: Mindfulness itself is a foundation of mindfulness. Or alternatively, it is mindfulness in the sense of remembering ; it is a foundation in the sense of cause of occurrence .

original: Iti sati ca sā paṭṭhānaṃ cātipi satipaṭṭhānaṃ. Idamidhādhippetaṃ.
analyzed: iti sati ca sā paṭṭhānam sati paṭṭhānam idam idha adhippetam
translated: So it is both mindfulness and a foundation , thus it is a foundation of mindfulness . This is the meaning intended here.

original: Yadi evaṃ kasmā “satipaṭṭhānā”ti bahuvacanaṃ? Satibahuttā. Ārammaṇabhedena hi bahukā
analyzed: yadi evam kasmā bahuvacanam sati bahuttā ārammaṇa bhedena hi bahukā
translated: If that is so, why is the plural form “satipaṭṭhānā” used? Because of the plurality of the mindfulnesses. For these mindfulnesses are many

original: etā satiyo. Atha maggoti kasmā ekavacanaṃ? Maggaṭṭhena ekattā. Catassopi hi etā satiyo
analyzed: etāḥ satiyaḥ atha maggo ti kasmai eka vacanam magga ṭṭhena ekattā catasso api hi etāḥ satiyaḥ
translated: because of the different objects. Then why is the singular form “maggo” used? Because of the unity in the sense of path. For all these four mindfulnesses

original: maggaṭṭhena ekattaṃ gacchanti. Vuttañhetaṃ – “maggoti kenaṭṭhena maggo? Nibbānagamanaṭṭhena.
analyzed: magga aṭṭhena ekattam gacchanti vuttam ha etam maggo iti kenaṭṭhena maggaḥ nibbāna gamana ṭṭhena
translated: They go by the one-way path of the path. For this is said: “What is the path in the sense of a path? In the sense of going to Nibbāna.🔽And in the sense of being what should be gone by those who seek Nibbāna.”

original: Nibbānatthikehi magganīyaṭṭhena cā”ti. Catassopi cetā aparabhāge kāyādīsu ārammaṇesu
analyzed: nibbāna atthikehi magganīya ṭṭhena ca ati catasso pi cetāḥ apara bhāge kāya ādīsu ārammaṇesu
translated: And all four of them, in the later part of the round, go to Nibbāna, accomplishing their function in the objects consisting of the body, and so on.

original: kiccaṃ sādhayamānā nibbānaṃ gacchanti, ādito paṭṭhāya ca nibbānatthikehi maggiyanti,
analyzed: kiccam sādhayamānāḥ nibbānam gacchanti āditaḥ paṭṭhāya ca nibbāna atthikehi
translated: And they are what should be gone by those who seek Nibbāna from the beginning.

original: tasmā catassopi eko maggoti vuccanti. Evañca sati vacanānusandhinā sānusandhikāva
analyzed: tasmā catassaḥ api ekaḥ maggo ti vuccanti evam ca sati vacana anusandhinā sa anusandhikā ava
translated: So all four are called “one path.” And when that is so, the teaching is one that has a sequel,

original: desanā hoti, “mārasenappamaddanaṃ, vo bhikkhave, maggaṃ desessāmi, taṃ suṇātha…pe…
analyzed: desanā hoti mārasena pamaddanam vaḥ bhikkhave maggam desessāmi tam suṇāthape
translated: in accordance with the text, as in the case of the following passage: “Bhikkhus, I shall teach you the path that leads to cessation, hear it …

original: katamo ca, bhikkhave, mārasenappamaddano maggo? Yadidaṃ satta bojjhaṅgā”tiādīsu viya.
analyzed: katamaḥ ca bhikkhave māra senā pamaddanaḥ maggaḥ yat idam satta bojjhaṅgā ti ādīsu viya
translated: What, bhikkhus, is the path that leads to cessation? It is this Noble Eightfold Path; that is, right view … right concentration” .🔽Just as “the path that leads to cessation” and “the Noble Eightfold Path” are the same in meaning,

original: Yathā mārasenappamaddanoti ca, satta bojjhaṅgāti ca atthato ekaṃ, byañjanamevettha
analyzed: yathā ca satta bojjhaṅgā ati ca atthataḥ ekam byañjanam eva ittha
translated: but different in the phrasing,

original: nānaṃ. Evaṃ “ekāyanamaggo”ti ca “cattāro satipaṭṭhānā”ti ca atthato ekaṃ, byañjanamevettha
analyzed: nānam evam ekāyana maggo ti ca cattāro sati paṭṭhānā ti ca atthataḥ ekam byañjanam eva ittha
translated: so “the one-way path” and “the four foundations of mindfulness” are the same in meaning, but different in the phrasing.

original: nānaṃ, tasmā maggaṭṭhena ekattā ekavacanaṃ. Ārammaṇabhedena satibahuttā bahuvacanaṃ veditabbaṃ.🔽Kasmā pana bhagavatā cattārova satipaṭṭhānā vuttā anūnā anadhikāti? Veneyyahitattā.
analyzed: nānam tasmā maggaṭṭhena eka ttā eka vacanam ārammaṇa bhedena sati bahu ttā bahu vacanam veditabbam  kasmā pana bhagavatā cattāro va sati paṭṭhānā vuttāḥ anūnā anadhikā ati veneyya hita ttā
translated: Therefore, because of their being one in the sense of path, the singular number is used. But the plural number should be understood as being used because of the multiplicity of mindfulnesses due to the multiplicity of objects.🔽But why are only four foundations of mindfulness stated by the Blessed One, neither less nor more? Because of the benefit to disciples.

original: Taṇhācaritadiṭṭhicaritasamathayānikavipassanāyānikesu hi mandatikkhavasena dvedhā
analyzed: taṇhā carita diṭṭhi carita samatha yānika vipassanā yānikesu hi manda tikkha vasena dvedhā
translated: For the four kinds of disciples are mentioned in the texts, that is, those of the sensual-desire temperament, those of the tendency to false views, those of the vehicle of serenity, and those of the vehicle of insight.

original: dvedhā pavattesu veneyyesu mandassa taṇhācaritassa oḷārikaṃ kāyānupassanāsatipaṭṭhānaṃ🔽visuddhimaggo, tikkhassa sukhumaṃ vedanānupassanāsatipaṭṭhānaṃ. Diṭṭhicaritassapi🔽mandassa nātippabhedagataṃ cittānupassanāsatipaṭṭhānaṃ visuddhimaggo, tikkhassa atippabhedagataṃ
analyzed: dvedhā pavattesu veneyyesu mandassa taṇhā caritassa oḷārikam kāya anupassanā sati paṭṭhānam  visuddhi maggo tikkhassa sukhumam vedanā anupassanā sati paṭṭhānam diṭṭhi caritassa pi  mandassa na ati pabheda gatam citta anupassanā sati paṭṭhānam visuddhi maggo tikkhassa ati pabheda gatam
translated: Of these, the foundation of mindfulness consisting in contemplation of the body is the path to purity for the dull sensual-desire temperament,🔽and the foundation of mindfulness consisting in contemplation of feelings is the path to purity for the keen sensual-desire temperament.🔽And the foundation of mindfulness consisting in contemplation of consciousness is the path to purity for the dull temperament of those who tend to false views,

original: dhammānupassanāsatipaṭṭhānaṃ visuddhimaggo. Samathayānikassa ca mandassa akicchena
analyzed: dhamma anupassanā sati paṭṭhānam visuddhi maggo samatha yānikassa ca mandassa a kicchena
translated: and the foundation of mindfulness consisting in contemplation of mental objects is the path to purity for the keen temperament of those who tend to false views.

original: adhigantabbanimittaṃ paṭhamaṃ satipaṭṭhānaṃ visuddhimaggo, tikkhassa oḷārikārammaṇe
analyzed: adhigantabba nimittam paṭhamam satipaṭṭhānam visuddhi maggo tikkhassa oḷārika ārammaṇe
translated: And the first foundation of mindfulness, which has a sign that can be easily apprehended, is the path to purity for the dull temperament of those of the vehicle of serenity,🔽and the foundation of mindfulness consisting in contemplation of mental objects, which has a gross object, is the path to purity for the keen temperament of those of the vehicle of serenity.

original: asaṇṭhahanato dutiyaṃ. Vipassanāyānikassapi mandassa nātippabhedagatārammaṇaṃ tatiyaṃ,
analyzed: a saṇṭhahanataḥ dutiyam vipassanāyānikassa api mandassa na ati pabheda gata ārammaṇam tatiyam
translated: The third is called “contemplation-as-arising” because it is the opposite of the second.🔽The fourth is called “not-contemplation-as-arising” because it is the opposite of the third.

original: tikkhassa atippabhedagatārammaṇaṃ catutthaṃ. Iti cattārova vuttā anūnā anadhikāti.
analyzed: tikkhassa atippabheda gata ārammaṇam catuttham iti cattāro va vuttāḥ anūnā anadhikā ti
translated: So they are stated as four only, neither more nor less.🔽Or alternatively, the first foundation of mindfulness is stated for the purpose of abandoning the perversion consisting in taking the foul as fair, the second for the purpose of abandoning the perversion consisting in taking what is unlovely as lovely, the third for the purpose of abandoning the perversion consisting in taking what is impermanent as permanent, and the fourth for the purpose of abandoning the perversion consisting in taking what is not self as self.

original: Subhasukhaniccaattabhāvavipallāsappahānatthaṃ vā. Kāyo hi asubho, tattha ca subhavipallāsavipallatthā
analyzed: subha sukha nicca atta bhāva vipallāsa ppahāna attham vā kāyaḥ hi asubhaḥ tattha ca subha vipallāsa vipallatthā
translated: For the body is foul, and beings are perverted by perversion about the body in taking it as fair.

original: sattā. Tesaṃ tattha asubhabhāvadassanena tassa vipallāsassa pahānatthaṃ paṭhamaṃ
analyzed: sattā tesam tattha asubha bhāva dassanena tassa vipallāsassa pahāna attham paṭhamam
translated: So the first foundation of mindfulness is stated for the purpose of abandoning that perversion by showing them the foulness in the body.

original: satipaṭṭhānaṃ vuttaṃ. Sukhaṃ niccaṃ attāti gahitesupi ca vedanādīsu vedanā dukkhā,
analyzed: sati paṭṭhānam vuttam sukham niccam attā ati gahitesu pi ca vedanā ādīsu vedanā dukkhā
translated: And in the case of feeling, etc., which are taken as pleasure, permanence, and self, feeling is pain, consciousness is impermanent, and ideas are not self.

original: cittaṃ aniccaṃ, dhammā anattā, tesu ca sukhaniccaattavipallāsavipallatthā sattā.
analyzed: cittam aniccam dhammāḥ anattā tesu ca sukha nicca atta vipallāsa vipallatthā sattā
translated: Beings are perverted by perversion about pleasure, permanence, and self in regard to them.

original: Tesaṃ tattha dukkhādibhāvadassanena tesaṃ vipallāsānaṃ pahānatthaṃ sesāni tīṇi vuttānīti
analyzed: tesam tattha dukkha ādi bhāva dassanena tesam vipallāsānam pahāna attham sesāni tīṇi vuttāni iti
translated: So the remaining three foundations of mindfulness are stated for the purpose of abandoning those perversions by showing them the pain, etc., in those three.

original: evaṃ subhasukhaniccaattabhāvavipallāsappahānatthaṃ vā cattārova vuttā anūnā anadhikāti
analyzed: evam subha sukha nicca atta bhāva vipallāsa ppahāna attham vā cattāro va vuttāḥ anūnā anadhikā ti
translated: So they are stated as four only, neither more nor less, for the purpose of abandoning the perversions about the foul, the lovely, the impermanent, and the self.

original: veditabbā. Na kevalañca vipallāsappahānatthameva, atha kho caturoghayogāsavaganthaupādānaagatipahānatthampi
analyzed: veditabbā na kevalam ca vipallāsa ppahāna attham eva atha kho catur ogha yoga āsava gantha upādāna agati pahāna attham pi
translated: and they should be understood as the four foundations of mindfulness.

original: catubbidhāhārapariññatthañca cattārova vuttāti veditabbā. Ayaṃ tāva pakaraṇanayo.
analyzed: catubbidha āhāra pariñña ttham ca cattāro va vuttā ati veditabbā ayam tāva pakaraṇa nayo
translated: And they should be understood as the four foundations of mindfulness for the purpose of completely understanding the four kinds of nutriment, not only for the purpose of abandoning the four perversions.🔽This, in the first place, is the method of the text.

original: Aṭṭhakathāyaṃ pana saraṇavasena ceva ekattasamosaraṇavasena ca ekameva satipaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: pana saraṇa vasena ca iva ekatta samosaraṇa vasena ca ekam eva sati paṭṭhānam
translated: But in the commentary it is said that there is only one foundation of mindfulness, which is Arahantship,🔽and that is fourfold according to meaning, and it is fourfold according to object.

original: ārammaṇavasena cattāroti etadeva vuttaṃ. Yathā hi catudvāre nagare pācīnato āgacchantā🔽pācīnadisāya uṭṭhānakaṃ bhaṇḍaṃ gahetvā pācīnadvārena nagarameva pavisanti, dakkhiṇato.
analyzed: ārammaṇa vasena cattāro ti etat eva vuttam yathā hi catu dvāre nagare pācīnatas āgacchantā  pācīna disāya uṭṭhānakam bhaṇḍam gahetvā pācīna dvārena nagaram eva pavisanti dakkhiṇatas
translated: Just as when people come to a city with four gates,

original: Pacchimato. Uttarato āgacchantā uttaradisāya uṭṭhānakaṃ bhaṇḍaṃ gahetvā uttaradvārena
analyzed: pacchimatas uttaratas āgacchantāḥ uttara disāya uṭṭhānakam bhaṇḍam gahetvā uttara dvārena
translated: those coming from the east take goods produced in the east and enter the city by the eastern gate; those coming from the south, west, and north do likewise with goods produced in the south, west, and north.

original: nagarameva pavisanti; evaṃ – sampadamidaṃ veditabbaṃ. Nagaraṃ viya hi nibbānamahānagaraṃ,
analyzed: nagaram eva pavisanti evam sampadam idam veditabbam nagaram viya hi nibbāna mahā nagaram
translated: So too, this should be understood in the following way. The city is like Nibbāna, the great city;

original: dvāraṃ viya aṭṭhaṅgiko lokuttaramaggo, pācīnadisādayo viya kāyādayo.
analyzed: dvāram viya aṭṭhaṅgikaḥ lokuttara maggo pācīna disā ādayaḥ viya kāya ādayaḥ
translated: the gate is like the supramundane path with its eight factors; the eastern direction, etc., are like the body, and so on;

original: Yathā pācīnato āgacchantā pācīnadisāya uṭṭhānakaṃ bhaṇḍaṃ gahetvā pācīnadvārena nagarameva
analyzed: yathā pācīnataḥ āgacchantā pācīna disāya uṭṭhānakam bhaṇḍam gahetvā pācīna dvārena nagaram eva
translated: Just as those coming from the east enter the city by the eastern gate, taking with them the goods they have acquired in the eastern direction,

original: pavisanti, evaṃ kāyānupassanāmukhena āgacchantā cuddasavidhena kāyānupassanaṃ bhāvetvā
analyzed: pavisanti evam kāya anupassanā mukhena āgacchantā cuddasavidhena kāya anupassanam bhāvetvā
translated: so too, those who come by the way of contemplation of the body develop the fourteen aspects of contemplation of the body,

original: kāyānupassanābhāvanānubhāvanibbattena ariyamaggena ekaṃ nibbānameva osaranti. Yathā
analyzed: kāya anupassanā bhāvanā anubhāva nibbattena ariya maggena ekam nibbānam eva osaranti yathā
translated: and by the path generated by the power of the development of contemplation of the body they enter only to the one nibbana.

original: dakkhiṇato āgacchantā dakkhiṇāya disāya uṭṭhānakaṃ bhaṇḍaṃ gahetvā dakkhiṇadvārena
analyzed: dakkhiṇatas āgacchantā dakkhiṇāya disāya uṭṭhānakam bhaṇḍam gahetvā dakkhiṇa dvārena
translated: Just as those coming from the south enter the city by the southern gate, taking with them the goods they have acquired in the southern direction,

original: nagarameva pavisanti, evaṃ vedanānupassanāmukhena āgacchantā navavidhena vedanānupassanaṃ
analyzed: nagaram eva pavisanti evam vedanā anupassanā mukhena āgacchantāḥ navavidhena vedanā anupassanam
translated: so too, those who come by the way of contemplation of feeling develop the nine aspects of contemplation of feeling,

original: bhāvetvā vedanānupassanābhāvanānubhāvanibbattena ariyamaggena ekaṃ nibbānameva osaranti.
analyzed: bhāvetvā vedanā anupassanā bhāvanā anubhāva nibbattena ariya maggena ekam nibbānam eva osaranti
translated: and by the path generated by the power of the development of contemplation of feeling they enter only to the one nibbana.

original: Yathā pacchimato āgacchantā pacchimadisāya uṭṭhānakaṃ bhaṇḍaṃ gahetvā pacchimadvārena
analyzed: yathā pacchimatas āgacchantā pacchima disāya uṭṭhānakam bhaṇḍam gahetvā pacchima dvārena
translated: Just as those coming from the west enter the city by the western gate, taking with them the goods they have acquired in the western direction,

original: nagarameva pavisanti, evaṃ cittānupassanāmukhena āgacchantā soḷasavidhena cittānupassanaṃ
analyzed: nagaram eva pavisanti evam citta anupassanā mukhena āgacchantā soḷasavidhena citta anupassanam
translated: so too, those who come by the way of contemplation of consciousness develop the sixteen aspects of contemplation of consciousness,

original: bhāvetvā cittānupassanābhāvanānubhāvanibbattena ariyamaggena ekaṃ nibbānameva osaranti.
analyzed: bhāvetvā citta anupassanā bhāvanā anubhāva nibbattena ariya maggena ekam nibbānam eva osaranti
translated: and they all descend to a single extinction, which is produced by the noble path generated by the influence of the development of the contemplation of mind.

original: Yathā uttarato āgacchantā uttaradisāya uṭṭhānakaṃ bhaṇḍaṃ gahetvā uttaradvārena nagarameva
analyzed: yathā uttaratas āgacchantaḥ uttara disāya uṭṭhānakam bhaṇḍam gahetvā uttara dvārena nagaram eva
translated: Just as those coming from the north enter the city by the northern gate after taking up goods produced in the north,

original: pavisanti, evaṃ dhammānupassanāmukhena āgacchantā pañcavidhena dhammānupassanaṃ bhāvetvā
analyzed: pavisanti evam dhamma anupassanā mukhena āgacchantā pañcavidhena dhamma anupassanam bhāvetvā
translated: so those coming by the way of the contemplation of mental objects develop the fivefold contemplation of mental objects

original: dhammānupassanābhāvanānubhāvanibbattena ariyamaggena ekaṃ nibbānameva osaranti. Evaṃ
analyzed: dhamma anupassanā bhāvanā anubhāva nibbattena ariya maggena ekam nibbānam eva osaranti evam
translated: and they all descend to a single extinction, which is produced by the noble path generated by the influence of the development of the contemplation of mental objects.🔽Thus it should be understood that although the four establishments of mindfulness are stated as four by way of object,

original: saraṇavasena ceva ekattasamosaraṇavasena ca ekameva satipaṭṭhānaṃ ārammaṇavasena🔽cattārova vuttāti veditabbā.
analyzed: saraṇa vasena ca iva ekatta samosaraṇa vasena ca ekam eva sati paṭṭhānam ārammaṇa vasena  cattāraḥ eva vuttā ati veditabbā
translated: they are one in the sense of the way of entry and in the sense of the way of descending to unity.

original: Katame cattāroti kathetukamyatā pucchā. Idhāti imasmiṃ sāsane. Bhikkhaveti dhammapaṭiggāhakapuggalālapanametaṃ.
analyzed: katame cattāro ti kathā itu kamyatā pucchā idha ati imasmin sāsane bhikkhave ti dhamma paṭiggāhaka puggala ālapanam etam
translated: “Which four?” is a question expressing a desire to explain. “Here” means in this Dispensation. “Monks” is said to the persons who receive the Dhamma.

original: Bhikkhūti paṭipattisampādakapuggalanidassanametaṃ. Aññepi ca devamanussā paṭipattiṃ
analyzed: bhikkhū ti paṭipatti sampādaka puggala nidassanam etam aññe pi ca deva manussāḥ paṭipattim
translated: “Monks” is said to show the persons who accomplish the practice. And also other gods and men who practice

original: sampādentiyeva, seṭṭhattā pana paṭipattiyā bhikkhubhāvadassanato ca “bhikkhū”ti āha.
analyzed: sampādentiyā iva seṭṭha ttā pana paṭipattiyāḥ bhikkhu bhāva dassanato ca bhikkhū ti āha
translated: He says “monks” because of their pre-eminence and because of the fact that one who is a monk is one who practices the practice.

original: Bhagavato hi anusāsaniṃ sampaṭicchantesu bhikkhu seṭṭho, sabbappakārāya anusāsaniyā🔽bhājanabhāvato. Tasmā seṭṭhattā “bhikkhū”ti āha. Tasmiṃ gahite pana sesā gahitāva🔽honti, rājagamanādīsu rājaggahaṇena sesaparisā viya. Yo ca imaṃ paṭipattiṃ paṭipajjati,
analyzed: bhagavataḥ hi anusāsanim sampaṭicchantesu bhikkhu seṭṭhaḥ sabbappakārāya anusāsaniyā  bhājana bhāvato tasmā seṭṭha ttā bhikkhū ti āha tasmin gahite pana sesāḥ gahitā ava  honti rāja gamana ādīsu rāja ggahaṇena sesa parisāḥ yo ca imam paṭipattim paṭipajjati
translated: For in the Blessed One’s Dispensation the monk is pre-eminent among those who have undertaken to practice it,🔽because of his being a fit vessel for the whole of the Dispensation. Therefore he says “monks” because of their pre-eminence. But when he says “monks,” the rest are included too,

original: so bhikkhu nāma hotīti paṭipattiyā bhikkhubhāvadassanatopi “bhikkhū”ti āha. Paṭipannako
analyzed: so bhikkhu nāma hoti iti paṭipattiyā bhikkhu bhāva dassanataḥ pi bhikkhū ti āha paṭipannakaḥ
translated: just as when the chief of a number of people is mentioned, the others are included too. And he says “monks” because one who practices this practice is called a “monk.”

original: hi devo vā hotu manusso vā, bhikkhūti saṅkhyaṃ gacchatiyeva yathāha –
analyzed: hi devaḥ vā hotu manusso vā bhikkhu iti saṅkhyam gacchatiyā iva yathā āha
translated: For one who practices it, whether he be a god or a human being, is called a “monk,” as it is said:

original: “Alaṅkato cepi samaṃ careyya,
analyzed: alaṅkato cepi samam careyya
translated: “Though decked with ornaments he who is calm,

original: Santo danto niyato brahmacārī;
analyzed: santaḥ dantaḥ niyataḥ brahmacārī
translated: Controlled, restrained, and lives the holy life,

original: Sabbesu bhūtesu nidhāya daṇḍaṃ,
analyzed: sabbesu bhūtesu nidhāya daṇḍam
translated: Who has laid aside the rod against all beings,

original: So brāhmaṇo so samaṇo sa bhikkhū”ti. ;
analyzed: saḥ brāhmaṇaḥ saḥ samaṇaḥ sa bhikkhu iti
translated: Is a true brahmin, a true ascetic, a true monk” .

original: Kāyeti rūpakāye. Rūpakāyo hi idha aṅgapaccaṅgānaṃ kesādīnañca dhammānaṃ samūhaṭṭhena
analyzed: kāya iti rūpa kāye rūpa kāyaḥ hi idha aṅga paccaṅgānam kesa ādīnam ca dhammānam samūha aṭṭhena
translated: “Body” is the material body. For the material body is intended here in the sense of a collection of parts and components beginning with head hairs and body hairs,

original: hatthikāyarathakāyādayo viya kāyoti adhippeto. Yathā ca samūhaṭṭhena, evaṃ kucchitānaṃ
analyzed: hatthi kāya ratha kāya ādayaḥ adhippetaḥ yathā ca samūha aṭṭhena evam
translated: like the body of an army, the body of a tree, etc. And just as it is in the sense of a collection, so also it is in the sense of a heap of what is contemptible,

original: āyaṭṭhena. Kucchitānañhi paramajegucchānaṃ so āyotipi kāyo. Āyoti uppattideso. Tatthāyaṃ
analyzed: āya ṭṭhena saḥ kāyaḥ uppatti deso tattha ayam
translated: for that is a body in the sense of a heap of what is contemptible, of what is utterly disgusting. “Heap” is the place of origin. Here is the word meaning:

original: vacanattho. Āyanti tatoti āyo. Ke āyanti? Kucchitā kesādayo. Iti kucchitānaṃ āyoti kāyo.
analyzed: vacana attho āyanti tatoti āyo ke āyanti kucchitā kesa ādayo iti kāyo
translated: it comes from there, thus it is a heap . What comes? The contemptible things, head hairs, etc. So the body is a heap of what is contemptible.

original: Kāyānupassīti kāye anupassanasīlo kāyaṃ vā anupassamāno. Kāyeti ca vatvāpi puna kāyānupassīti
analyzed: kāya anupassī iti kāye anupassana sīlo kāyam vā anupassamānaḥ kāya iti ca vatvā api puna kāya anupassī iti
translated: “Contemplating the body as a body”: possessing contemplation of the body, or contemplating the body. And although he said “body,”

original: dutiyakāyaggahaṇaṃ asammissato vavatthānaghanavinibbhogādidassanatthaṃ katanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: dutiya kāya ggahaṇam a sammissataḥ vavatthāna ghana vinibbhoga ādi dassana tham katam ti veditabbam
translated: the repetition of “contemplating the body as a body” should be understood as stated in order to show the delimitation, the compact nature, the analysis, etc., of the body, as in the case of “He breathes out, he breathes in.”

original: Tena na kāye vedanānupassī vā, cittadhammānupassī vā, atha kho kāyānupassīyevāti
analyzed: tena na kāye vedanā anupassī vā citta dhamma anupassī vā atha kho kāya anupassī iva ati
translated: By that he shows that he is not contemplating feeling, consciousness, or mental objects, but rather he is contemplating only the body,

original: kāyasaṅkhāte vatthusmiṃ kāyānupassanākārasseva dassanena asammissato vavatthānaṃ
analyzed: kāya saṅkhāte vatthusmim kāya anupassanā ākārassa iva dassanena a sammissataḥ vavatthānam
translated: the delimitation of the body by showing the mode of contemplation of the body in the object called “body.”

original: dassitaṃ hoti. Tathā na kāye aṅgapaccaṅgavinimuttaekadhammānupassī, nāpi kesalomādivinimuttaitthipurisānupassī,
analyzed: dassitam hoti tathā na kāye aṅga paccaṅga vinimutta eka dhamma anupassī na api kesa loma ādi vinimutta aitthi purisa anupassī
translated: And so it is not as one who sees a single, individual entity free from limbs and secondary parts, nor as one who sees a woman or a man free from head-hairs, etc.,

original: yopi cettha kesalomādiko bhūtupādāyasamūhasaṅkhāto kāyo, tatthapi na bhūtupādāyavinimuttaekadhammānupassī,
analyzed: yaḥ api ca ittha kesa loma ādikaḥ bhūta upādāya samūha saṅkhāto kāyaḥ tattha api na bhūta upādāya vinimutta eka dhamma anupassī
translated: that he sees the body. Nor is it as one who sees a single, individual entity free from the elements and primaries that he sees the body, which is a collection of elements and primaries.🔽But rather as one who sees a collection of limbs and secondary parts, like a chariot,

original: atha kho rathasambhārānupassako viya aṅgapaccaṅgasamūhānupassī, nagarāvayavānupassako🔽viya kesalomādisamūhānupassī, kadalikkhandhapattavaṭṭivinibbhujako viya rittamuṭṭhiviniveṭhako
analyzed: atha kho ratha sambhāra anupassakaḥ viya aṅga paccaṅga samūha anupassī nagara avayava anupassakaḥ  viya kesa loma ādi samūha anupassī kadali kkhandha patta vaṭṭi vinibbhujakaḥ viya ritta muṭṭhi viniveṭhakaḥ
translated: as one who sees a collection of head-hairs, etc., like the parts of a city,🔽as one who, like one who unravels a kaṭahārinī mat, sees a collection of elements and primaries.

original: viya ca bhūtupādāyasamūhānupassīyevāti nānappakārato samūhavaseneva kāyasaṅkhātassa🔽vatthuno dassanena ghanavinibbhogo dassito hoti. Na hettha yathāvuttasamūhavinimutto
analyzed: ca bhūta upādāya samūha anupassīya iva ati nānā pakārato samūha vasena iva kāya saṅkhātassa  vatthuno dassanena ghana vinibbhogaḥ dassitaḥ hoti na ha ittha yathāvutta samūha vinimutto
translated: Thus the demonstration of the resolution of the compact is effected by the seeing of the “sign of the body” in the various ways as a collection.

original: kāyo vā itthī vā puriso vā añño vā koci dhammo dissati, yathāvuttadhammasamūhamatteyeva
analyzed: kāyaḥ vā itthī vā purisaḥ vā aññaḥ vā koci dhammo dissati yathāvutta dhamma samūha mattā iva iva
translated: For no body or woman or man or any such thing is seen here apart from the collection described in the way already stated.

original: pana tathā tathā sattā micchābhinivesaṃ karonti. Tenāhu porāṇā –
analyzed: pana tathā tathā sattāḥ micchā abhinivesam karonti tena āhu porāṇā
translated: but beings misapprehend it in this way and that. Hence the ancients said:

original: “Yaṃ passati na taṃ diṭṭhaṃ, yaṃ diṭṭhaṃ taṃ na passati;
analyzed: yam passati na tam diṭṭham yam diṭṭham tam na passati
translated: What one sees is not seen; What is seen is not seen.

original: Apassaṃ bajjhate mūḷho, bajjhamāno na muccatī”ti.
analyzed: a passam bajjhate mūḍhaḥ bajjhamānaḥ na muccati iti
translated: The fool, deluded, is caught; Being caught, he is not freed.

original: Ghanavinibbhogādidassanatthanti vuttaṃ, ādisaddena cettha ayampi attho veditabbo.🔽Ayañhi etasmiṃ kāye kāyānupassīyeva, na añña dhammānupassīti vuttaṃ hoti. Yathā anudakabhūtāyapi
analyzed: ghana vinibbhoga ādi dassana atthan ti vuttam ādi saddena ca ittha ayam pi atthaḥ veditabbaḥ  ayam hi etasmin kāye kāya anupassī iva na añña dhamma anupassī iti vuttam hoti yathā anudaka bhūtāya api
translated: The meaning of the words “in order to show the penetration of the compact” is this. And here the word “etc.” should be understood to include this meaning too.

original: marīciyā udakānupassino honti, na evaṃ aniccadukkhānattaasubhabhūteyeva imasmiṃ kāye
analyzed: marīciyā udaka anupassinaḥ honti na evam imasmin kāye
translated: For what is meant is that he is only a contemplator of the body in this body, not a contemplator of anything else. Just as those who are contemplating water do not contemplate the mirage though it is unwatery, so too, this meditator does not contemplate the body as permanent, blissful, self, or healthy, though it is impermanent, painful, not self, and unhealthy.

original: niccasukhaattasubhabhāvānupassī, atha kho kāyānupassī aniccadukkhānattaasubhākārasamūhānupassīyevāti
analyzed: nicca sukha atta subha bhāva anupassī atha kho kāya anupassī anicca dukkha anatta asubha ākāra samūha anupassī iva ati
translated: But he is a contemplator of the body in the sense that he is a contemplator of the body’s mode of bodilyness, of the body’s impermanence, of the body’s painfulness, of the body’s not-selfhood, and of the body’s foulness.🔽Or alternatively, what is meant is that he is a contemplator of the body in the sense that he is a contemplator of the collection of the modes of bodilyness, of the collection of the body’s impermanences, of the collection of the body’s pains, of the collection of the body’s not-selfhoods, and of the collection of the body’s foulnesses.

original: vuttaṃ hoti. Atha vā yvāyaṃ parato “idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu araññagato vā…pe… so
analyzed: vuttam hoti atha vā yvā ayam paratas idha bhikkhave bhikkhu arañña gataḥ vāpe so
translated: “Here, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu, gone to the forest or to the root of a tree or to an empty place, sits down; having folded his legs crosswise, set his body erect, and established mindfulness in front of him,

original: satova assasatī”tiādinā nayena assāsapassāsādicuṇṇikajātaaṭṭhikapariyosāno kāyo vutto,🔽yo ca “idhekacco pathavīkāyaṃ aniccato anupassati, āpokāyaṃ tejokāyaṃ vāyokāyaṃ kesakāyaṃ🔽lomakāyaṃ chavikāyaṃ cammakāyaṃ maṃsakāyaṃ rudhirakāyaṃ nhārukāyaṃ aṭṭhikāyaṃ aṭṭhimiñjakāya”nti
analyzed: sataḥ iva assasati itiādinā nayena assāsa passāsa ādi cuṇṇika jāta aṭṭhika pariyosānaḥ kāyaḥ vutto  yaḥ ca idha ekaccaḥ pathavīkāyam aniccataḥ anupassati āpokāyam tejaḥ kāyam vāyokāyam kesa kāyam  loma kāyam chavi kāyam camma kāyam maṃsa kāyam rudhira kāyam nhāru kāyam aṭṭhi kāyam aṭṭhimiñjakāyanti
translated: The body is stated in the way beginning, “Breathing in long, he knows ‘I breathe in long,’ breathing out long, he knows ‘I breathe out long’ ” , and ending, “He trains thus: experiencing the whole body I shall breathe in, I shall breathe out” .🔽And the body is stated in the way beginning, “Here someone contemplates the earth kasiṇa as earth, contemplates water as water, contemplates fire as fire, contemplates air as air, contemplates the base consisting of infinite space as the base consisting of infinite space, contemplates the base consisting of infinite consciousness as the base consisting of infinite consciousness, contemplates the base consisting of nothingness as the base consisting of nothingness, contemplates the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception as the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception, contemplates this world as this world, contemplates the other world as the other world, contemplates whatever is seen, heard, sensed, cognized, reached, sought after, pondered by the intellect,🔽and the body is stated in the way beginning, “Here someone contemplates the earth body as a body, contemplates the water body, the fire body, the air body, the space body, the consciousness body as a body” .🔽
