original: āgatanayassa sabbasseva aniccalakkhaṇādino ākārasamūhasaṅkhātassa kāyassa anupassanatopi
analyzed: āgata nayassa sabbassa eva anicca lakkhaṇa ādinaḥ ākāra samūha saṅkhātassa kāyassa anupassanataḥ pi
translated: and by the contemplation of the entire method of approach, which is a collection of aspects such as impermanence, etc., of the body.

original: kāye kāyānupassīti evampi attho daṭṭhabbo. Tathā hi ayaṃ kāye kāyānupassanāpaṭipadaṃ🔽paṭipanno bhikkhu imaṃ kāyaṃ aniccānupassanādīnaṃ sattannaṃ anupassanānaṃ vasena
analyzed: kāye kāya anupassī iti evam pi atthaḥ daṭṭhabbo tathā hi ayam kāye kāya anupassanā paṭipadam  paṭipannaḥ bhikkhu imam kāyam anicca anupassanā ādīnam sattannam anupassanānam vasena
translated: And the meaning may also be regarded as “contemplating the body as a collection of components called ‘material form,’ etc., which is the method of contemplation of impermanence, etc., in all its aspects.”🔽For when a bhikkhu is practising the way of contemplation of the body as a body,🔽he contemplates this body as impermanent by means of the seven contemplations beginning with contemplation of the thirty-two-fold parts.

original: aniccato anupassati, no niccato. Dukkhato anupassati, no sukhato. Anattato anupassati,
analyzed: aniccataḥ anupassati no niccataḥ dukkhataḥ anupassati no sukhataḥ anattataḥ anupassati
translated: He contemplates it as painful by means of the contemplation of the four kinds of nutriment.🔽He contemplates it as not-self by means of the contemplation of the six elements.

original: no attato. Nibbindati, no nandati, virajjati, no rajjati, nirodheti. No samudeti,
analyzed: no attataḥ nibbindati no nandati virajjati no rajjati nirodheti no samudeti
translated: He becomes dispassionate towards it by means of the contemplation of the nine charnel-ground contemplations.🔽He detaches his mind from it by means of the contemplation of the six.🔽When he contemplates it as impermanent, he abandons the perception of permanence.

original: paṭinissajjati, no ādiyati. So taṃ aniccato anupassanto niccasaññaṃ pajahati, dukkhato
analyzed: paṭinissajjati no ādiyati so tam aniccataḥ anupassantaḥ nicca saññam pajahati dukkhato
translated: When he contemplates it as painful, he abandons the perception of pleasure.

original: anupassanto sukhasaññaṃ pajahati, anattato anupassanto attasaññaṃ pajahati, nibbindanto
analyzed: anupassantaḥ sukha saññam pajahati anattataḥ anupassantaḥ atta saññam pajahati nibbindantaḥ
translated: When he contemplates it as not-self, he abandons the perception of self. When he becomes dispassionate towards it, he abandons delight in it.

original: nandiṃ pajahati, virajjanto rāgaṃ pajahati, nirodhento samudayaṃ pajahati, paṭinissajjanto
analyzed: nandim pajahati virajjantaḥ rāgam pajahati nirodhentaḥ samudayam pajahati paṭinissajjantaḥ
translated: When he detaches his mind from it, he abandons craving for it. When he brings about its cessation, he abandons its origin. When he relinquishes it, he abandons clinging to it.

original: ādānaṃ pajahatīti veditabbo.
analyzed: ādānam pajahati iti veditabbaḥ
translated: He should be understood as abandoning the appropriating of materiality.

original: Viharatīti iriyati. Ātāpīti tīsu bhavesu kilese ātāpetīti ātāpo, vīriyassetaṃ nāmaṃ.
analyzed: viharati iti iriyati ātāpī iti tīsu bhavesu kilese ātāpeti iti ātāpaḥ vīriyassa etam nāmam
translated: He abides: he lives. He is ardent: ardour is the name for energy in the three kinds of existence.

original: Ātāpo assa atthīti ātāpī. Sampajānoti sampajaññasaṅkhātena ñāṇena samannāgato. Satimāti
analyzed: ātāpaḥ assa atthi iti ātāpī sampajānoti sampajañña saṅkhātena ñāṇena samannāgataḥ satimā ati
translated: He has ardour, thus he is ardent. He is clearly comprehending: he is provided with the knowledge called clear comprehension. He is mindful:

analyzed: kāya pariggāhikāya satiyā samannāgataḥ ayam pana yasmai satiyā ārammaṇam pariggahetvā  paññāya anupassati na hi sati virahitassa anupassanā nāma atthi tena iva āha satiñca
translated: he is provided with mindfulness that is the conascent support for the mind. But since he discerns the object by means of mindfulness and

original: khvāhaṃ, bhikkhave, sabbatthikaṃ vadāmī”ti. Tasmā ettha “kāye kāyānupassī viharatī”ti
analyzed: khvā aham bhikkhave sabbatthikam vadāmi iti tasmai ettha kāye kāya anupassī viharati iti
translated: sees it by means of understanding, and there is no seeing without mindfulness, therefore it is said, “Mindfulness, bhikkhus, I say is useful for all states” . So here “he abides contemplating the body as a body”

original: ettāvatā kāyānupassanāsatipaṭṭhānaṃ vuttaṃ hoti. Atha vā yasmā anātāpino antosaṅkhepo
analyzed: ettāvatā kāya anupassanā sati paṭṭhānam vuttam hoti atha vā yasmai anātāpinaḥ antosaṅkhepo
translated: is said to be the development of the foundation of mindfulness consisting in contemplation of the body.

original: antarāyakaro hoti, asampajāno upāyapariggahe anupāyaparivajjane ca sammuyhati, muṭṭhassati
analyzed: antarāya karaḥ hoti a sampajānaḥ upāya pariggahe an upāya parivajjane ca sammuyhati muṭṭhaḥ sati
translated: Or alternatively, since one who is not ardent is slack, and one who is not clearly comprehending is confused, and one who is not mindful is negligent,

original: upāyāpariccāge anupāyāpariggahe ca asamattho hoti, tenassa taṃ kammaṭṭhānaṃ na sampajjati.🔽Tasmā yesaṃ dhammānaṃ ānubhāvena taṃ sampajjati, tesaṃ dassanatthaṃ “ātāpī sampajāno
analyzed: upāya a pariccāge anupāya a pariggahe ca asamatthaḥ hoti tena assa tat kammaṭṭhānam na sampajjati  tasmai yesam dhammānam ānubhāvena tam sampajjati tesam dassana attham ātāpī sampajānaḥ
translated: He is unable to relinquish the wrong way and adopt the right way, and so his meditation subject does not succeed.

original: satimā”ti idaṃ vuttanti veditabbaṃ.🔽Iti kāyānupassanāsatipaṭṭhānaṃ sampayogaṅgañcassa dassetvā idāni pahānaṅgaṃ dassetuṃ
analyzed: satimā iti idam vuttan ti veditabbam  iti kāya anupassanā sati paṭṭhānam sampayoga aṅgam ca assa dassetvā idāni pahāna aṅgam dassetuṃ
translated: So it should be understood that the words “keen, clearly comprehending, and mindful” are said in order to show the states that are the source of its success.🔽So, having shown the factors of conjunction with the development of mindfulness occupied with the body, he now said “Abandoning” in order to show the factors of abandoning.

original: vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassanti vuttaṃ. Tattha vineyyāti tadaṅgavinayena vā vikkhambhanavinayena
analyzed: vineyya loke abhijjhā domanassan ti vuttam tattha vineyya ti tad aṅga vinayena vā vikkhambhana vinayena
translated: Herein, abandoning is abandoning by substitution of opposites and abandoning by suppression.

original: vā vinayitvā. Loketi tasmiññeva kāye. Kāyo hi idha lujjanapalujjanaṭṭhena lokoti
analyzed: vā vinayitvā loka iti tasmin ñeva kāye kāyaḥ hi idha
translated: World: in that same body. For the world is intended here in the sense of that which is worn away and wasted .

original: adhippeto. Yasmā panassa na kāyamatteyeva abhijjhādomanassaṃ pahīyati, vedanādīsupi
analyzed: adhippetaḥ yasmā panassa na abhijjhā domanassam pahīyati vedanā ādīsu pi
translated: But since greed and grief are not abandoned in the mere body but in feeling, etc., too,🔽it is said in the Vibhaṅga, “The world is the five aggregates as objects of clinging.

original: pahīyatiyeva. Tasmā pañcapi upādānakkhandhā lokoti vibhaṅge vuttaṃ. Lokasaṅkhātattā
analyzed: tasmā upādānakkhandhāḥ vibhaṅge vuttam loka saṅkhāta ttā
translated: Because of being called the world” .

original: vā tesaṃ dhammānaṃ atthuddhāranayenetaṃ vuttaṃ. Yaṃ panāha – “tattha katamo loko?🔽Sveva kāyo loko”ti, ayamevettha attho. Tasmiṃ loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ vineyyāti evaṃ
analyzed: vā tesam dhammānam attha uddhāra nayena itam vuttam yam pana āha tattha katamaḥ loko  su eva kāyaḥ loko ti ayam eva itthā attho tasmin loke abhijjhā domanassam vineyya ati evam
translated: But when it is said, “Herein, what is the world?🔽This very body is the world,” the meaning is just this.🔽The connection should be seen in this way: “In that world, the lust and grief are to be abandoned.”

original: sambandho daṭṭhabbo. Yasmā panettha abhijjhāggahaṇena kāmacchando, domanassaggahaṇena
analyzed: sambandhaḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ yasmā pana itthā abhijjhā ggahaṇena kāmacchandaḥ domanassa ggahaṇena
translated: But since lust is included by the term “lust,” and grief by the term “grief,”

original: byāpādo saṅgahaṃ gacchati, tasmā nīvaraṇapariyāpannabalavadhammadvayadassanena nīvaraṇappahānaṃ
analyzed: byāpādaḥ saṅgaham gacchati tasmai nīvaraṇa pariyāpanna balava dhamma dvaya dassanena nīvaraṇa ppahānam
translated: the abandoning of the hindrances is stated by the seeing of the two powerful states included in the hindrances.

original: vuttaṃ hotīti veditabbaṃ.🔽Visesena cettha abhijjhāvinayena kāyasampattimūlakassa anurodhassa, domanassavinayena
analyzed: vuttam hoti iti veditabbam  visesena ca ittha abhijjhā vinayena kāya sampatti mūlakassa anurodhassa domanassa vinayena
translated: This should be understood.🔽Herein, by the abandoning of lust, the compliance that has the excellence of the body for its basis is abandoned;🔽by the abandoning of grief, the resistance that has the imperfections of the body for its basis is abandoned.

original: kāyavipattimūlakassa virodhassa, abhijjhāvinayena ca kāye abhiratiyā, domanassavinayena
analyzed: kāya vipatti mūlakassa virodhassa abhijjhā vinayena ca kāye abhiratiyā domanassa vinayena
translated: By the abandoning of lust, delight in the body is abandoned;🔽by the abandoning of grief, the non-delight in the development of the body is abandoned.

original: kāyabhāvanāya anabhiratiyā, abhijjhāvinayena kāye abhūtānaṃ subhasukhabhāvādīnaṃ
analyzed: kāya bhāvanāya anabhiratiyā abhijjhā vinayena kāye abhūtānam subha sukha bhāva ādīnam
translated: By the abandoning of lust, the non-existence in the body of the states of beauty, pleasure, permanence, and substantiality is seen;

original: pakkhepassa, domanassavinayena kāye bhūtānaṃ asubhāsukhabhāvādīnaṃ apanayanassa ca
analyzed: pakkhepassa domanassa vinayena kāye bhūtānaṃ asubha asukha bhāva ādīnam apanayanassa ca
translated: and in the case of the wing of the wingless, by the abandoning of grief, by the removal of the pleasant and unpleasant, etc., in the case of the elements in the body.

original: pahānaṃ vuttaṃ. Tena yogāvacarassa yogānubhāvo yogasamatthatā ca dīpitā hoti. Yogānubhāvo
analyzed: pahānam vuttam tena yogāvacarassa yoga anubhāvaḥ yoga samattha tā ca dīpitā hoti yoga anubhāvaḥ
translated: So the abandoning of the wing of the wingless is stated. And thereby the potency of the meditator’s meditation and his ability in meditation are also shown.

original: hi esa, yadidaṃ anurodhavirodhavippamutto aratiratisaho abhūtapakkhepabhūtāpanayanavirahito🔽ca hoti. Anurodhavirodhavippamutto cesa aratiratisaho abhūtaṃ apakkhipanto bhūtañca
analyzed: hi esa yat idam anurodha virodha vippamuttaḥ arati rati sahaḥ abhūta pakkhepa bhūta apanayana virahitaḥ  ca hoti anurodha virodha vippamutto ca esa arati rati sahaḥ abhūtam apakkhipantaḥ bhūtam ca
translated: For this is the potency of meditation that one becomes free from compliance and contradiction, that one can endure pleasure and pain, and that one can avoid the removal of what is not there and the retention of what is there.

original: anapanayanto yogasamattho hotīti.🔽Aparo nayo “kāye kāyānupassī”ti ettha anupassanāya kammaṭṭhānaṃ vuttaṃ. “Viharatī”ti🔽ettha vuttavihārena kammaṭṭhānikassa kāyapariharaṇaṃ, “ātāpī”tiādīsu pana ātāpena
analyzed: an apanayantaḥ yoga samatthaḥ hoti iti  aparaḥ nayaḥ kāye kāya anupassī iti ettha anupassanāya kammaṭṭhānam vuttam viharati iti  ettha vutta vihārena kammaṭṭhānikassa kāya pariharaṇam ātāpi iti ādīsu pana ātāpena
translated: And being free from compliance and contradiction, being able to endure pleasure and pain, avoiding the removal of what is not there and the retention of what is there, he is able in meditation.

original: sammappadhānaṃ, satisampajaññena sabbatthakakammaṭṭhānaṃ, kammaṭṭhānapariharaṇūpāyo
analyzed: sammappadhānam sati sampajaññena sabbatthaka kammaṭṭhānam kammaṭṭhāna pariharaṇa upāyaḥ
translated: Another method: in the clause “Contemplating the body as a body” the subject of meditation is stated. In the clause “He dwells” the maintenance of the body by one who has taken up the subject of meditation is stated by the kind of dwelling. In the clauses beginning with “Ardent” the right endeavour is stated by the ardour. In the clause “Clearly comprehending” the subject of meditation for all is stated. In the clause “Mindful” the means of maintaining the subject of meditation is stated by mindfulness.

original: vā. Satiyā vā kāyānupassanāvasena paṭiladdhasamatho, sampajaññena vipassanā abhijjhādomanassavinayena
analyzed: vā satiyā vā kāya anupassanā vasena paṭiladdha samathaḥ sampajaññena vipassanā abhijjhā domanassa vinayena
translated: Or else the concentration is obtained by means of mindfulness of the body, and the insight is by means of full awareness.

original: bhāvanābalaṃ vuttanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: bhāvanā balam vuttan ti veditabbam
translated: The power of development should be understood as stated by the words “through the abandoning of covetousness and grief” .🔽But in the Vibhaṅga the word “contemplating” is explained as follows: “What is contemplating? It is understanding, discerning,

original: Vibhaṅge pana anupassīti tattha “katamā anupassanā? Yā paññā pajānanā vicayo pavicayo🔽dhammavicayo sallakkhaṇā upalakkhaṇā paccupalakkhaṇā paṇḍiccaṃ kosallaṃ nepuññaṃ🔽vebhabyā cintā upaparikkhā bhūrīmedhā pariṇāyikā vipassanā sampajaññaṃ patodo paññā
analyzed: vibhaṅge pana anupassī ti tattha katamā anupassanā yā paññā pajānanā vicayo pavicayo  dhammavicayo sallakkhaṇā upalakkhaṇā paccupalakkhaṇā paṇḍiccam kosallam nepuññam  vebhabyā cintā upaparikkhā bhūrīmedhā pariṇāyikā vipassanā sampajaññam patodaḥ paññā
translated: investigating, comprehensive scrutiny, appreciation, discrimination,🔽discernment, penetration, erudition, subtlety, limpidity,🔽insight, full awareness, exploration, mental work,🔽great understanding, great discernment, great erudition,🔽great investigation, great subtlety, great limpidity,🔽great insight, great full awareness, great exploration, great mental work,

analyzed: paññindriyam paññābalam paññāsattham paññāpāsādo paññāāloko paññāobhāso paññā pajjoto  paññā ratanam amohaḥ dhamma vicayo sammādiṭṭhi ayam vuccati anupassanā imāya anupassanāya
translated: great understanding, great discernment, great erudition, great investigation, great subtlety, great limpidity, great insight, great full awareness, great exploration, great mental work, great wisdom, great full understanding, great penetration, the faculty of wisdom, the power of wisdom, the sword of wisdom, the flame of wisdom, the torch of wisdom, the light of wisdom, the radiance of wisdom, the clarification of wisdom, the treasure of wisdom, non-delusion, investigation of states, right view.🔽He is provided with this contemplation, supplied with it, furnished with it, possessed of it,

original: upeto hoti samupeto upagato samupagato upapanno samannāgato, tena vuccati anupassīti.
analyzed: upetaḥ hoti samupetaḥ upagataḥ samupagataḥ upapanno samannāgato tena vuccati anupassī iti

analyzed: viharati iti iriyati pavattati pāleti yapeti yāpeti carati viharati tena vuccati viharati iti  ātāpī iti tattha katamam ātāpam yaḥ cetasikaḥ vīriya ārambhaḥ nikammaḥ parakkamaḥ uyyāmaḥ
translated: He abides: he moves, he moves along, he proceeds, he progresses, he continues, he lives, he conducts himself, he maintains himself, that is why it is said he abides.

original: vāyāmo ussāho ussoḷhī thāmo dhiti asithilaparakkamatā anikkhittaddandatā anikkhittadhuratā🔽dhurasampaggāhī vīriyaṃ vīriyindriyaṃ vīriyabalaṃ sammāvāyāmo, idaṃ vuccati ātāpaṃ.
analyzed: vāyāmaḥ ussāhaḥ ussoḷhī thāmaḥ dhiti a sithila parakkama tā a nikkhitta ddanda tā a nikkhitta dhura tā  dhura sampaggāhī vīriyam vīriyindriyam vīriya balam sammāvāyāmaḥ idam vuccati ātāpam
translated: He is ardent: herein, what is ardour? original: nāma gopo kūṭadhenuyā sabbaṃ khīraṃ pivitvā vaḍḍhitaṃ kūṭavacchaṃ dametukāmo dhenuto🔽apanetvā ekamante mahantaṃ thambhaṃ nikhaṇitvā tattha yottena bandheyya. Athassa🔽so vaccho ito cito ca vipphanditvā palāyituṃ asakkonto tameva thambhaṃ upanisīdeyya
analyzed: nāma gopaḥ kūṭa dhenuyā sabbam khīram pivitvā vaḍḍhitam kūṭa vaccham dametu kāmaḥ dhenutaḥ  apanetvā eka mante mahantam thambham nikhaṇitvā tattha yottena bandheyya  saḥ vacchaḥ itas citas ca vipphanditvā palāyitum a sakkontaḥ tam eva thambham upanisīdeyya
translated: reflect thus: “Just as if a cow to be tamed🔽were tied to a post of a feeding trough, at first it struggles, paws the air with its foot, and makes to run away, but as it grows tired it stands still,” so too, this bhikkhu’s consciousness, which has long been accustomed to wandering among forms, etc., as it pleases, will struggle, paw the air with its foot, as it were, and make to run away to forms, etc., as it pleases, but as it grows tired it will stand still, and it will enter the track of the meditation subject.

original: vā upanipajjeyya vā, evameva imināpi bhikkhunā dīgharattaṃ rūpārammaṇādirasapānavaḍḍhitaṃ
analyzed: vā upanipajjeyya vā evam eva iminā api bhikkhunā dīgharattam rūpa ārammaṇa ādi rasa pāna vaḍḍhitam
translated: So he should not give up the sign, which is the basis for concentration, and go wandering among external objects.

original: duṭṭhacittaṃ dametukāmena rūpādiārammaṇato apanetvā araññaṃ vā rukkhamūlaṃ vā suññāgāraṃ🔽vā pavisitvā tattha satipaṭṭhānārammaṇatthambhe satiyottena bandhitabbaṃ. Evamassa🔽taṃ cittaṃ ito cito ca vipphanditvāpi pubbe āciṇṇārammaṇaṃ alabhamānaṃ satiyottaṃ
analyzed: duṭṭha cittam dametu kāmena rūpa ādi ārammaṇataḥ apanetvā araññam vā rukkha mūlam vā suññāgāram  vā pavisitvā tattha sati paṭṭhāna ārammaṇa tthambhe satiyā uttena bandhitabbam evam assa  tat cittam itas citas ca vipphanditvā api pubbe āciṇṇa ārammaṇam a labhamānam satiyā uttam
translated: He who wishes to subdue a mind that is evil should go to the forest or to the foot of a tree or to an empty place and, by turning away from sense desires, etc.,🔽he should bind his mind to the post of the object of contemplation with the rope of mindfulness. Then,🔽even though his mind may wander hither and thither, it will not be able to find a former object of attachment and will be unable to break the rope of mindfulness and escape.

original: chinditvā palāyituṃ asakkontaṃ tamevārammaṇaṃ upacārappanāvasena upanisīdati ceva
analyzed: chinditvā palāyitum a sakkontam tam eva ārammaṇam upacāra ppanā vasena upanisīdati ca iva
translated: It will sit down and lie down right there on that object by way of access concentration and absorption concentration.

original: upanipajjati ca. Tenāhu porāṇā –
analyzed: upanipajjati ca tena āhuḥ porāṇāḥ
translated: Therefore the ancients said:

original: “Yathā thambhe nibandheyya, vacchaṃ damaṃ naro idha;
analyzed: yathā thambhe vaccham damam naraḥ idha
translated: Just as a man would bind a calf To a post with a rope,

analyzed: bandheyya evam sakam cittam satiyā ārammaṇe daḷhanti
translated: So should a man bind his mind To the object with mindfulness strong.

original: Evamassetaṃ senāsanaṃ bhāvanānurūpaṃ hoti. Tena vuttaṃ “idamassa satipaṭṭhānabhāvanānurūpasenāsanapariggahaparidīpana”nti.
analyzed: evam assa etam senāsanam bhāvanā anurūpam hoti tena vuttam idam assa sati paṭṭhāna bhāvanā anurūpa senāsana pariggaha paridīpanam ti
translated: Thus his lodging is in conformity with his development. Hence it was said: “This shows his choice of lodging in conformity with the development of the foundation of mindfulness.”

original: Apica yasmā idaṃ kāyānupassanāya muddhabhūtaṃ sabbabuddhapaccekabuddhasāvakānaṃ visesādhigamadiṭṭhadhammasukhavihārapadaṭṭhānaṃ🔽ānāpānassatikammaṭṭhānaṃ itthipurisahatthiassādisaddasamākulaṃ gāmantaṃ apariccajitvā

original: na sukaraṃ sampādetuṃ, saddakaṇḍakattā jhānassa. Agāmake pana araññe sukaraṃ yogāvacarena🔽idaṃ kammaṭṭhānaṃ pariggahetvā ānāpānacatutthajjhānaṃ nibbattetvā tadeva jhānaṃ pādakaṃ
analyzed: na sukaram sampādetum sadda kaṇḍaka ttā jhānassa a gāmake pana araññe sukaram yogāvacarena  idam kammaṭṭhānam pariggahetvā āna apāna catuttha jhānam nibbattetvā tat eva jhānam pādakam
translated: because the jhāna of the meditator who is not free from desire for sound is broken up by the noise. But it is easy for the meditator who has gone to the forest,

original: dantasūcivedhakādīnaṃ likhanakāle mandamandaṃ rassaṃ kaḍḍhanto. Evameva khoti evaṃ
analyzed: danta sūci vedhaka ādīnam likhana kāle manda mandam rassam kaḍḍhantaḥ evam eva kho ti evam
translated: “Bhikkhus, just as a skilled potter’s apprentice or potter sitting at his wheel might make and fashion out of well-prepared clay any kind of vessel he wishes, or as a skilled ivory-worker might make and fashion any kind of ivory work he wishes, or as a skilled goldsmith might make and fashion any kind of gold work he wishes, so too, bhikkhus, the bhikkhu who is an arahant with taints destroyed, who has lived the holy life, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, reached the true goal, destroyed the fetters of being, and is completely liberated through final knowledge, makes and fashions for himself

original: ayampi bhikkhu addhānavasena ittaravasena ca pavattānaṃ assāsapassāsānaṃ vasena dīghaṃ
analyzed: ayam pi bhikkhu addhāna vasena ittara vasena ca pavattānam assāsa passāsānam vasena dīgham
translated: This bhikkhu, too, knows “I am breathing in long” or “I am breathing out long” by means of the in-breaths and out-breaths that occur in the long way.

original: vā assasanto dīghaṃ assasāmīti pajānāti…pe… passasissāmīti sikkhatīti. Tassevaṃ sikkhato
analyzed: va assasantaḥ dīgham assasāmi iti pajānāti pe passasissāmi iti sikkhati iti tassa ivam sikkhato
translated: He trains thus “I shall breathe in experiencing the whole body” …

original: assāsapassāsanimitte cattāri jhānāni uppajjanti, so jhānā vuṭṭhahitvā assāsapassāse
analyzed: assāsa passāsa nimitte cattāri jhānāni uppajjanti so jhānā vuṭṭhahitvā assāsa passāse
translated: As he trains thus, the four jhanas arise in him with respect to the in-breaths and out-breaths as object.

original: vā pariggaṇhāti jhānaṅgāni vā.
analyzed: vā pariggaṇhāti jhāna aṅgāni vā
translated: When he emerges from the jhanas, he discerns either the in-breaths and out-breaths or the jhana factors.

original: Tattha assāsapassāsakammiko “ime assāsapassāsā kiṃ nissitā? Vatthunissitā. Vatthu
analyzed: tattha assāsa passāsa kammikaḥ ime assāsa passāsā kim nissitāḥ vatthu nissitāḥ vatthu
translated: Herein, one who is occupied with the in-breaths and out-breaths discerns thus: “These in-breaths and out-breaths are dependent on the body.

original: nāma karajakāyo, karajakāyo nāma cattāri mahābhūtāni upādārūpañce”ti evaṃ rūpaṃ pariggaṇhāti.🔽Tato tadārammaṇe phassapañcamake nāmanti. Evaṃ nāmarūpaṃ pariggahetvā tassa paccayaṃ
analyzed: nāma karaja kāyaḥ karaja kāyaḥ nāma cattāri mahābhūtāni upādā rūpam ca iti evam rūpam pariggaṇhāti  tatas tad ārammaṇe phassa pañcamake nāman ti evam nāma rūpam pariggahetvā tassa paccayam
translated: The body is the materiality aggregate. The materiality aggregate is the four great entities and the materiality derived by clinging from the four great entities.” So he discerns materiality.🔽Then he discerns the five aggregates with their bases and sources.🔽Having discerned mentality-materiality, he seeks the condition for it and sees that it is the determinations.

original: pariyesanto avijjādipaṭiccasamuppādaṃ disvā “paccayapaccayuppannadhammamattamevetaṃ,
analyzed: pariyesantaḥ avijjā ādi paṭiccasamuppādam disvā paccaya paccaya uppanna dhamma mattam eva etam
translated: He sees that the determinations have ignorance as their condition.

original: añño satto vā puggalo vā natthī”ti vitiṇṇakaṅkho sappaccayanāmarūpe tilakkhaṇaṃ āropetvā
analyzed: aññaḥ sattaḥ vā puggalo vā natthi iti vitiṇṇa kaṅkhaḥ sappaccaya nāmarūpe ti lakkhaṇam āropetvā
translated: He then extends insight by discerning the three characteristics in mentality-materiality with its conditions.

original: vipassanaṃ vaḍḍhento anukkamena arahattaṃ pāpuṇāti. Idaṃ ekassa bhikkhuno yāva arahattā niyyānamukhaṃ.
analyzed: vipassanam vaḍḍhentaḥ anukkamena arahattam pāpuṇāti idam ekassa bhikkhuno yāva arahattā niyyāna mukham
translated: In due course he reaches Arahantship. This is the outlet to Arahantship for one bhikkhu.

original: Jhānakammikopi “imāni jhānaṅgāni kiṃ nissitāni, vatthunissitāni, vatthu nāma karajakāyo
analyzed: jhāna kammikaḥ api imāni jhāna aṅgāni kim nissitāni vatthu nissitāni vatthu nāma karaja kāyaḥ
translated: One who cultivates jhāna should discern the jhāna factors thus: “These jhāna factors are dependent on something, they are not without a basis. The basis is the physical body.

original: jhānaṅgāni nāmaṃ, karajakāyo rūpa”nti nāmarūpaṃ vavatthapetvā tassa paccayaṃ pariyesanto🔽avijjādipaccayākāraṃ disvā “paccayapaccayuppannadhammamattamevetaṃ, añño satto vā
analyzed: jhāna aṅgāni nāmam karaja kāyaḥ rūpanti nāma rūpam vavatthapetvā tassa paccayam pariyesanto  avijjā ādi paccaya ākāram disvā paccaya paccaya uppanna dhamma mattam eva etam aññaḥ sattaḥ vā
translated: The jhāna factors are mentality, the physical body is materiality. ” He defines mentality-materiality and then seeks its conditions.🔽When he sees the way in which ignorance, etc., are its conditions, he concludes thus: “This is only a succession of states with birth as condition and so on. There is no being or person here. ”

original: puggalo vā natthī”ti vitiṇṇakaṅkho sappaccayanāmarūpe tilakkhaṇaṃ āropetvā vipassanaṃ
analyzed: puggalaḥ vā natthi iti vitiṇṇa kaṅkho sappaccaya nāmarūpe ti lakkhaṇam āropetvā vipassanam

original: vaḍḍhento anukkamena arahattaṃ pāpuṇāti. Idamekassa bhikkhuno yāva arahattā niyyānamukhaṃ.
analyzed: vaḍḍhentaḥ anukkamena arahattam pāpuṇāti idam ekassa bhikkhuno yāva arahattā niyyāna mukham
translated: In due course he reaches Arahantship. This is the outlet to Arahantship for one bhikkhu.

original: Iti ajjhattaṃ vāti evaṃ attano vā assāsapassāsakāye kāyānupassī viharati. Bahiddhā🔽vāti parassa vā assāsapassāsakāye. Ajjhattabahiddhā vāti kālena attano, kālena parassa
analyzed: iti ajjhattam vā ati evam attanaḥ vā assāsa passāsa kāye kāya anupassī viharati bahiddhā  vāti parassa vā assāsa passāsa kāye ajjhatta bahiddhā vāti kālena attanaḥ kālena parassa
translated: Thus in regard to his own in-breath and out-breath as a mental datum he abides contemplating mind-objects as mind-objects. In regard to another’s in-breath and out-breath as a mental datum he abides contemplating mind-objects as mind-objects. In regard to his own and another’s in-breath and out-breath as a mental datum he abides contemplating mind-objects as mind-objects. By this he is said to abide contemplating mind-objects as mind-objects in the sixfold way in regard to the body as a mental datum.

original: assāsapassāsakāye. Etenassa paguṇakammaṭṭhānaṃ aṭṭhapetvā aparāparaṃ sañcaraṇakālo🔽kathito. Ekasmiṃ kāle panidaṃ ubhayaṃ na labbhati.
analyzed: assāsa passāsa kāye etena assa paguṇa kammaṭṭhānam aṭṭhapetvā apara aparam sañcaraṇa kālo  ekasmin kāle ubhayam na labbhati
translated: In regard to his own in-breath and out-breath as a mental datum he abides contemplating mind-objects as mind-objects. In regard to another’s in-breath and out-breath as a mental datum he abides contemplating mind-objects as mind-objects. In regard to his own and another’s in-breath and out-breath as a mental datum he abides contemplating mind-objects as mind-objects. By this he is said to abide contemplating mind-objects as mind-objects in the sixfold way in regard to the body as a mental datum.

translated: In regard to his own in-breath and out-breath as a mental datum he abides contemplating mind-objects as mind-objects. In regard to another’s in-breath and out-breath as a mental datum he abides contemplating mind-objects as mind-objects. In regard to his own and another’s in-breath and out-breath as a mental datum he abides contemplating mind-objects as mind-objects. By this he is said to abide contemplating mind-objects as mind-objects in the sixfold way in regard to the body as a mental datum.

original: te passanto “samudayadhammānupassī vā kāyasmiṃ viharatī”ti vuccati. Vayadhammānupassī
analyzed: te passantaḥ samudaya dhamma anupassī vā kāyasmiṃ viharati iti vuccati vaya dhamma anupassī
translated: In regard to his own in-breath and out-breath as a mental datum he abides contemplating mind-objects as mind-objects. In regard to another’s in-breath and out-breath as a mental datum he abides contemplating mind-objects as mind-objects. In regard to his own and another’s in-breath and out-breath as a mental datum he abides contemplating mind-objects as mind-objects. By this he is said to abide contemplating mind-objects as mind-objects in the sixfold way in regard to the body as a mental datum.🔽In regard to his own in-breath and out-breath as a mental datum he abides contemplating mind-objects as mind-objects. In regard to

original: vāti yathā bhastāya apanītāya gaggaranāḷiyā bhinnāya tajje ca vāyāme asati so vāto
analyzed: vāti yathā bhastāya apanītāya gaggara nāḷiyā bhinnāya tad je ca vā āyāme asati saḥ vātaḥ
translated: just as when a bellows is blown, if the bellows skin is not torn, and if the bellows frame is not broken, and if the bellows nozzle is not loose, and if the bellows rope is not cut, and if the man blowing on it is not exhausted,🔽

original: nappavattati, evameva kāye bhinne nāsapuṭe viddhaste citte ca niruddhe assāsapassāsakāyo🔽nāma nappavattatīti kāyādinirodhā assāsapassāsanirodhoti evaṃ passanto “vayadhammānupassī
analyzed: na ppavattati evam eva kāye bhinne nāsa puṭe citte ca niruddhe assāsa passāsa kāyaḥ  nāma na pavattati iti kāya ādi nirodhā assāsa passāsa nirodho ti evam passantaḥ vaya dhamma anupassī
translated: Just as when a bellows is full of air and the mouth and the nose are closed, the air inside does not move to and fro, so too, when the body is broken up and the nose-tip is pierced, the air in the nostrils ceases,

original: vā kāyasmiṃ viharatī”ti vuccati. Samudayavayadhammānupassī vāti kālena samudayaṃ
analyzed: vā kāyasmim viharati iti vuccati samudaya vaya dhamma anupassī vāti kālena samudayam
translated: and the body called “in-breath and out-breath” does not occur. So the cessation of in-breath and out-breath comes about with the cessation of the body, and so on. Seeing thus, “He dwells contemplating dissolution in the body or in the mind” is said.🔽Contemplating origination and dissolution: contemplating origination at one time and contemplating dissolution at another time.

original: kālena vayaṃ anupassanto. Atthi kāyoti vā panassāti kāyova atthi, na satto, na puggalo,
analyzed: kālena vayam anupassanto atthi kāyo ti vā pana assa ati kāyo iva atthi na satto na puggalo
translated: Or else, “There is only the body” means that there is only the body, not a being, not a soul,

original: na itthī, na puriso, na attā, na attaniyaṃ, nāhaṃ, na mama, na koci, na kassacīti
analyzed: na itthī na purisaḥ na attā na attaniyam na aham na mama na koci na kassaci iti
translated: not a man, not a woman, not an entity, not a non-entity, not “mine,” not “I,” not anyone, not anything.

original: evamassa sati paccupaṭṭhitā hoti.
analyzed: evam assa sati paccupaṭṭhitā hoti
translated: Thus his mindfulness is established.

original: Yāvadevāti payojanaparicchedavavatthāpanametaṃ. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – yā sā sati paccupaṭṭhitā
analyzed: yāvat eva ati payojana pariccheda vavatthāpanam etam idam vuttam hoti yā sā sati paccupaṭṭhitā
translated: As long as … is a delimitation of the purpose. This is what is said: the mindfulness that is established

original: hoti, sā na aññadatthāya. Atha kho yāvadeva ñāṇamattāya aparāparaṃ uttaruttari ñāṇapamāṇatthāya
analyzed: hoti sā na aññadatthāya atha kho yāvat eva ñāṇa mattāya apara aparam uttaruttari ñāṇa pamāṇa tthāya
translated: It is not for the sake of that. It is for the sake of the measure of knowledge, for the sake of the measure of higher and higher knowledge.

original: ceva satipamāṇatthāya ca, satisampajaññānaṃ vuḍḍhatthāyāti attho. Anissito ca viharatīti
analyzed: ca iva sati pamāṇa tthāya ca sati sampajaññānam vuḍḍha tthāya ati attho a nissitaḥ ca viharati iti
translated: It is not for any other purpose. But it is for the purpose of the measure of knowledge, for the purpose of the measure of mindfulness, for the purpose of the increase of mindfulness and full awareness.

original: taṇhānissayadiṭṭhinissayānaṃ vasena anissitova viharati. Na ca kiñci loke upādiyatīti
analyzed: taṇhā nissaya diṭṭhi nissayānam vasena anissitaḥ iva viharati na ca kiñci loke upādiyati iti
translated: He dwells without cleaving to anything in the world: he dwells without cleaving to anything by way of cleaving to craving and cleaving to views.

original: lokasmiṃ kiñci rūpaṃ vā…pe… viññāṇaṃ vā “ayaṃ me attā vā attaniyaṃ vā”ti na gaṇhāti.
analyzed: lokasmim kiñci rūpam vā ape viññāṇam vā ayam me attā vā attaniyam vā ati na gaṇhāti
translated: He does not cling to anything in the world: he does not take anything in the world as “This is my self” or “This belongs to my self.”

original: Evampīti upari atthaṃ upādāya sampiṇḍanattho pi-kāro. Iminā pana padena bhagavā ānāpānapabbadesanaṃ niyyātetvā dasseti.🔽Tattha assāsapassāsapariggāhikā sati dukkhasaccaṃ, tassā samuṭṭhāpikā purimataṇhā
analyzed: evam pi iti upari attham upādāya sampiṇḍana atthaḥ pikāraḥ iminā pana padena bhagavā āna apāna pabba desanam niyyātetvā dasseti  tattha assāsa passāsa pariggāhikā sati dukkha saccam tassā samuṭṭhāpikā purima taṇhā
translated: In this way too: the word pi is in the sense of a summary referring to the meaning above. But by this expression the Blessed One shows that he has concluded the teaching of the Ānāpānasati.

original: samudayasaccaṃ ubhinnaṃ appavatti nirodhasaccaṃ, dukkhaparijānano samudayapajahano
analyzed: samudaya saccam ubhinnam appavatti nirodha saccam dukkha parijānano samudaya pajahano
translated: Herein, the mindfulness which is the apprehender of in-breaths and out-breaths is the Truth of Suffering, the craving which is its origin is the Truth of the Origin, the non-occurrence of both is the Truth of Cessation, the understanding of suffering and the abandoning of the origin are the Truth of the Path.

original: nirodhārammaṇo ariyamaggo maggasaccaṃ. Evaṃ catusaccavasena ussakkitvā nibbutiṃ pāpuṇātīti
analyzed: nirodha ārammaṇaḥ ariya maggaḥ magga saccam evam catu sacca vasena ussakkitvā nibbutim pāpuṇāti iti
translated: Thus he reaches complete extinction by striving in this way with the four truths.

original: idamekassa assāsapassāsavasena abhiniviṭṭhassa bhikkhuno yāva arahattā niyyānamukhanti.
analyzed: idam ekassa assāsa passāsa vasena abhiniviṭṭhassa bhikkhuno yāva arahattā niyyāna mukhanti
translated: This is the outlet for a bhikkhu who is devoted to the in-breaths and out-breaths by way of the four noble truths up to arahatship.

original: Ānāpānapabbaṃ niṭṭhitaṃ.
analyzed: ānāpānapabbam niṭṭhitam
translated: The section on mindfulness of breathing is ended.

original: Iriyāpathapabbavaṇṇanā
analyzed: iriyāpatha pabba vaṇṇanā
translated: The section on postures

original: 375. Evaṃ assāsapassāsavasena kāyānupassanaṃ vibhajitvā idāni iriyāpathavasena vibhajituṃ
analyzed: evam assāsa passāsa vasena kāya anupassanam vibhajitvā idāni iriyāpatha vasena vibhajitum
translated: Having thus analysed the contemplation of the body by way of in-breaths and out-breaths, the Master said,🔽“And again, Ananda,” in order to analyse it by way of the postures.

original: puna caparantiādimāha. Tattha kāmaṃ soṇasiṅgālādayopi gacchantā “gacchāmā”ti jānanti,🔽na panetaṃ evarūpaṃ jānanaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ. Evarūpañhi jānanaṃ sattūpaladdhiṃ na
analyzed: punar kāmam soṇa siṅgāla ādayaḥ api gacchantā gacchāma iti jānanti  na pana itam evarūpam jānanam sandhāya vuttam evarūpam hi jānanam sattu upaladdhim na
translated: Now, although dogs, jackals, etc., know when they are walking that they are walking,

original: pajahati, attasaññaṃ na ugghāṭeti, kammaṭṭhānaṃ vā satipaṭṭhānabhāvanā vā na hoti.
analyzed: pajahati atta saññam na ugghāṭeti kammaṭṭhānam vā satipaṭṭhāna bhāvanā vā na hoti
translated: this is not what is meant here. For such knowledge does not abandon the assumption of a being, does not remove the perception of a self, and is not a meditation subject or development of the foundation of mindfulness consisting in contemplation of the body.

original: Imassa pana bhikkhuno jānanaṃ sattūpaladdhiṃ pajahati, attasaññaṃ ugghāṭeti kammaṭṭhānañceva
analyzed: imassa pana bhikkhuno jānanam sattu upaladdhim pajahati atta saññam ugghāṭeti kammaṭṭhānam ca eva
translated: But this bhikkhu’s knowledge abandons the assumption of a being, removes the perception of a self, and is a meditation subject and development of the foundation of mindfulness consisting in contemplation of the body.

original: satipaṭṭhānabhāvanā ca hoti. Idañhi “ko gacchati, kassa gamanaṃ, kiṃ kāraṇā gacchatī”ti
analyzed: sati paṭṭhāna bhāvanā ca hoti idam hi kaḥ gacchati kassa gamanam kim kāraṇā gacchati iti
translated: and there is the development of the foundations of mindfulness. For this is said with reference to the clear comprehension of “Who goes? Whose going is it? For what purpose does he go?”

original: evaṃ sampajānanaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ. Ṭhānādīsupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: evam sampajānanam sandhāya vuttam ṭhāna ādīsu pi esā iva nayaḥ
translated: The same method applies to standing and so on.

original: Tattha ko gacchatīti? Na koci satto vā puggalo vā gacchati. Kassa gamananti? Na kassaci🔽sattassa vā puggalassa vā gamanaṃ. Kiṃ kāraṇā gacchatīti? Cittakiriyavāyodhātuvipphārena
analyzed: tattha kaḥ gacchati iti na koci sattaḥ vā puggalaḥ vā gacchati kassa gamananti na kassaci  sattassa vā puggalassa vā gamanam kim kāraṇā gacchati iti citta kiriya vāyodhātu vipphārena
translated: Herein, who goes? No being or person goes. Whose going is it? It is not the going of any being or person. For what purpose does he go?🔽He goes by the diffusion of the air element set in motion by the mind’s activity.

original: gacchati. Tasmā esa evaṃ pajānāti – “gacchāmī”ti cittaṃ uppajjati, taṃ vāyaṃ janeti,🔽vāyo viññattiṃ janeti, cittakiriyavāyodhātuvipphārena sakalakāyassa purato abhinīhāro
analyzed: gacchati tasmai esaḥ evam pajānāti gacchāmi iti cittam uppajjati tam vā ayam janeti  vāyo viññattim janeti citta kiriya vāyodhātu vipphārena sakala kāyassa puratas abhinīhāraḥ
translated: Therefore he should understand it thus: “The thought ‘I shall go’ arises, and that sets the air element in motion,

original: gamananti vuccati. Ṭhānādīsupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: gamananti vuccati ṭhāna ādīsu pi esa eva nayo
translated: and the diffusion of the air element set in motion by the mind’s activity and called ‘going’ is said to be the going of the whole body forward. The same method applies to standing and so on.

original: Tatrāpi hi “tiṭṭhāmī”ti cittaṃ uppajjati, taṃ vāyaṃ janeti, vāyo viññattiṃ janeti,
analyzed: tatra api hi tiṭṭhāmi iti cittam uppajjati tam vā ayam janeti vāyo viññattim janeti
translated: For there too the thought “I shall stand” arises, and that sets the air element in motion, and the diffusion of the air element set in motion by the mind’s activity and called ‘standing’ is said to be the standing of the whole body.

original: cittakiriyavāyodhātuvipphārena sakalakāyassa koṭito paṭṭhāya ussitabhāvo ṭhānanti
analyzed: citta kiriya vāyodhātu vipphārena sakala kāyassa koṭitaḥ paṭṭhāya ussita bhāvaḥ ṭhānan ti
translated: The state of the whole body’s being extended by the diffusion of the air element set going by the mind’s activity is called “standing.”

original: vuccati. “Nisīdāmī”ti cittaṃ uppajjati, taṃ vāyaṃ janeti, vāyo viññattiṃ janeti,
analyzed: vuccati nisīdāmi iti cittam uppajjati tam vā ayam janeti vāyo viññattim janeti
translated: The mind occurs thinking “I shall sit down,” and that generates air, and the air generates the intimation,

original: cittakiriyavāyodhātuvipphārena heṭṭhimakāyassa samiñjanaṃ uparimakāyassa ussitabhāvo
analyzed: citta kiriya vāyodhātu vipphārena heṭṭhima kāyassa samiñjanam uparima kāyassa ussita bhāvo
translated: The bending of the lower part of the body and the extension of the upper part by the diffusion of the air element set going by the mind’s activity is called “sitting.”

original: nisajjāti vuccati. “Sayāmī”ti cittaṃ uppajjati, taṃ vāyaṃ janeti, vāyo viññattiṃ
analyzed: nisajja iti vuccati sayāmi iti cittam uppajjati tam vā ayam janeti vāyo viññattim
translated: The mind occurs thinking “I shall lie down,” and that generates air, and the air generates the intimation,

original: janeti, cittakiriyavāyodhātuvipphārena sakalasarīrassa tiriyato pasāraṇaṃ sayananti vuccatīti.
analyzed: jana iti citta kiriya vāyodhātu vipphārena sakala sarīrassa tiriyataḥ pasāraṇam sayananti vuccati iti
translated: The spreading out of the whole body sideways by the diffusion of the air element set going by the mind’s activity is called “lying down.”

original: Tassa evaṃ pajānato evaṃ hoti “satto gacchati, satto tiṭṭhatī”ti vuccati, atthato🔽pana koci satto gacchanto vā ṭhito vā natthi. Yathā pana “sakaṭaṃ gacchati, sakaṭaṃ
analyzed: tassa evam pajānataḥ evam hoti sattaḥ gacchati satto tiṭṭhati iti vuccati atthato  pana koci sattaḥ gacchantaḥ vā ṭhitaḥ vā natthi yathā pana sakaṭam gacchati sakaṭam
translated: When he has thus understood it, then this idea occurs to him: “It is said that a being goes and stands,🔽but in reality there is no being that goes or stands. Just as it is said that a cart goes and stands,

original: tiṭṭhatī”ti vuccati, na ca kiñci sakaṭaṃ nāma gacchantaṃ vā ṭhitaṃ vā atthi, cattāro
analyzed: tiṭṭhati iti vuccati na ca kiñci sakaṭam nāma gacchantam vā ṭhitam vā atthi cattāro
translated: but there is no cart at all that goes or stands, so too,

original: pana goṇe yojetvā chekamhi sārathimhi pājente “sakaṭaṃ gacchati, sakaṭaṃ tiṭṭhatī”ti
analyzed: pana goṇe yojetvā chekamhi sārathimhi pājente sakaṭam gacchati sakaṭam tiṭṭhati iti
translated: But when the oxen are yoked and the charioteer is driving, there is only the mere usage “The cart goes,” “The cart stands,”

original: vohāramattameva hoti, evameva ajānanaṭṭhena sakaṭaṃ viya kāyo, goṇā viya cittajavātā,
analyzed: vohāra mattam eva hoti evam eva a jānana ṭṭhena sakaṭam viya kāyaḥ goṇā viya citta ja vātā
translated: just so, in the sense of not knowing, the body is like the cart, the mind-made winds are like the oxen,

original: sārathi viya cittaṃ. “Gacchāmi tiṭṭhāmī”ti citte uppanne vāyodhātu viññattiṃ janayamānā
analyzed: sārathi viya cittam gacchāmi tiṭṭhāmi iti citte uppanne vāyodhātu viññattim janayamānā
translated: and the mind is like the charioteer. When the thought “I shall go,” or “I shall stand,” arises, the air element, producing intimation,

original: uppajjati, cittakiriyavāyodhātuvipphārena gamanādīni pavattanti, tato “satto gacchati,
analyzed: uppajjati citta kiriya vāyo dhātu vipphārena gamana ādīni pavattanti tatas sattaḥ gacchati
translated: arises. By the diffusion of the mind-made air element, going and so forth occur. Then there is only the mere usage “The being goes,”

original: satto tiṭṭhati, ahaṃ gacchāmi, ahaṃ tiṭṭhāmī”ti vohāramattaṃ hoti. Tenāha –
analyzed: satto tiṭṭhati aham gacchāmi aham tiṭṭhāmi iti vohāra mattam hoti tena āha
translated: “The being stands,” “I go,” “I stand.” Therefore it is said:

original: “Nāvā mālutavegena, jiyāvegena tejanaṃ;
analyzed: nāvā māluta vegena jiyā vegena tejanam
translated: “By the force of the wind, the boat moves fast;🔽By the force of the wind, the fan moves fast;🔽By the force of the wind, the body moves fast;

original: Yathā yāti tathā kāyo, yāti vātāhato ayaṃ.🔽Yantaṃ suttavaseneva, cittasuttavasenidaṃ;
analyzed: yathā yāti tathā kāyaḥ yāti vāta āhataḥ ayam  yantam sutta vasena iva citta sutta vasena idam
translated: By the force of the wind, the body moves fast.🔽By the force of the thread, the puppet moves;🔽By the force of the mind, the body moves;🔽By the force of the thread, the puppet moves;

original: Payuttaṃ kāyayantampi, yāti ṭhāti nisīdati.
analyzed: payuttam kāyayantam pi yāti ṭhāti nisīdati
translated: By the force of the mind, the body moves.

original: Ko nāma ettha so satto, yo vinā hetupaccaye;
analyzed: kaḥ nāma ettha saḥ sattaḥ yaḥ vinā hetu paccaye
translated: Who is the being here, that without cause and condition,

original: Attano ānubhāvena, tiṭṭhe vā yadi vā vaje”ti.
analyzed: attanaḥ ānubhāvena tiṭṭhe vā yadi vā vaja iti
translated: By its own power, stands or moves?”

original: Tasmā evaṃ hetupaccayavaseneva pavattāni gamanādīni sallakkhento esa “gacchanto vā gacchāmīti pajānāti, ṭhito vā, nisinno vā, sayāno vā sayānomhīti pajānātī”ti veditabbo.
analyzed: tasmai evam hetu paccaya vasena iva pavattāni gamana ādīni sallakkhentaḥ esa gacchantaḥ vā gacchāmi iti pajānāti ṭhitaḥ vā nisinnaḥ vā sa yānaḥ vā sa yānaḥ asmi iti pajānāti iti veditabbaḥ
translated: So it should be understood that he is “cognizant of that as it really is thus: ‘I am walking’ ” and so on, by observing the goings, etc., as they occur by way of cause and condition.

original: Yathā yathā vā panassa kāyo paṇihito hoti, tathā tathā naṃ pajānātīti sabbasaṅgāhikavacanametaṃ.
analyzed: yathā yathā vā panassa kāyaḥ paṇihitaḥ hoti tathā tathā nam pajānāti iti sabbasaṅgāhika vacanam etam
translated: “Or in whatever way his body is disposed, he is likewise aware” is a comprehensive expression.

original: Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – yena yena vā ākārenassa kāyo ṭhito hoti, tena tena naṃ pajānāti.
analyzed: idam vuttam hoti yena yena vā ākārena assa kāyaḥ ṭhitaḥ hoti tena tena nam pajānāti
translated: What is meant is this: he is aware of his body in whatever posture it is in.

original: Gamanākārena ṭhitaṃ gacchatīti pajānāti. Ṭhānanisajjasayanākārena ṭhitaṃ sayānoti pajānātīti.
analyzed: gamana ākārena ṭhitam gacchati iti pajānāti ṭhāna nisajja sayana ākārena ṭhitam pajānāti iti
translated: If it is standing in the act of going, he is aware of it as “going”; if it is standing in the act of standing, sitting, or lying down, he is aware of it as “standing,” “sitting,” or “lying down.”

original: Iti ajjhattaṃ vāti evaṃ attano vā catuiriyāpathapariggaṇhanena kāye kāyānupassī viharati.
analyzed: iti ajjhattam vā ati evam attanaḥ vā catu iriyāpatha pariggaṇhanena kāye kāya anupassī viharati
translated: Thus in regard to himself: so he dwells contemplating the body in the body internally.🔽In regard to another: so he dwells contemplating the body in the body externally.

original: Bahiddhā vāti parassa vā catuiriyāpathapariggaṇhanena. Ajjhattabahiddhā vāti kālena
analyzed: bahiddhā vāti parassa vā catu iriyāpatha pariggaṇhanena ajjhatta bahiddhā vāti kālena
translated: In regard to himself and another: at one time contemplating the body in the body internally, and at another time contemplating the body in the body externally,

original: attano, kālena parassa catuiriyāpathapariggaṇhanena kāye kāyānupassī viharati. Samudayadhammānupassī🔽vātiādīsu pana avijjāsamudayā rūpasamudayotiādinā nayena pañcahākārehi rūpakkhandhassa
analyzed: attano kālena parassa catu iriyāpatha pariggaṇhanena kāye kāya anupassī viharati samudaya dhamma anupassī  vā ti ādīsu pana avijjā samudayā rūpa samudayā iti ādinā nayena pañcahā ākārehi rūpa kkhandhassa
translated: He is contemplating the body in the body by defining the four postures in his own body from time to time.🔽As to “contemplating origination in the body” and so on, the origination and the fall of the materiality aggregate should be pointed out in the five ways beginning with “With the arising of ignorance there is the arising of materiality” .

original: samudayo ca vayo ca nīharitabbo. Tañhi sandhāya idha “samudayadhammānupassī vā”tiādi
analyzed: samudayaḥ ca vayaḥ ca nīharitabbo tat hi sandhāya idha samudaya dhamma anupassī vā ti ādi
translated: For it is with reference to that that it is said here “contemplating origination in the body” and so on.

original: vuttaṃ. Atthi kāyoti vā panassātiādi vuttasadisameva.🔽Idhāpi catuiriyāpathapariggāhikā sati dukkhasaccaṃ, tassā samuṭṭhāpikā purimataṇhā🔽samudayasaccaṃ, ubhinnaṃ appavatti nirodhasaccaṃ, dukkhaparijānano samudayapajahano
analyzed: vuttam atthi kāyo ti vā panassa atiādi vutta sadisam eva  idha api catu iriyāpatha pariggāhikā sati dukkha saccam tassā samuṭṭhāpikā purima taṇhā  samudaya saccam ubhinnam appavatti nirodha saccam dukkha parijānano samudaya pajahano
translated: And “there is a body” and so on are as already stated.🔽Herein, the mindfulness that defines the four postures is the truth of suffering; the prior craving that is the cause of that is the truth of origin; the non- occurrence of both is the truth of cessation; the noble path that has cessation as its object, which is the understanding of suffering and the abandoning of origin, is the truth of the path.

original: nirodhārammaṇo ariyamaggo maggasaccaṃ. Evaṃ catusaccavasena ussakkitvā nibbutiṃ pāpuṇātīti
analyzed: nirodha ārammaṇaḥ ariya maggaḥ magga saccam evam catu sacca vasena ussakkitvā nibbutim pāpuṇāti iti
translated: Thus he strives by way of the four truths and reaches peace.

original: idamekassa catuiriyāpathapariggāhakassa bhikkhuno yāva arahattā niyyānamukhanti.
analyzed: idam ekassa catu iriyāpatha pariggāhakassa bhikkhuno yāva arahattā niyyāna mukhanti
translated: This is the outlet for a bhikkhu who defines the four postures and reaches Arahantship.

original: Iriyāpathapabbaṃ niṭṭhitaṃ.
analyzed: iriyāpatha pabbam niṭṭhitam
translated: The section on postures is finished.

original: Catusampajaññapabbavaṇṇanā🔽376. Evaṃ iriyāpathavasena kāyānupassanaṃ vibhajitvā idāni catusampajaññavasena vibhajituṃ🔽puna caparantiādimāha. Tattha abhikkantetiādīni sāmaññaphale vaṇṇitāni. Iti ajjhattaṃ🔽vāti evaṃ catusampajaññapariggaṇhanena attano vā kāye, parassa vā kāye, kālena vā🔽attano, kālena vā parassa kāye kāyānupassī viharati. Idhāpi samudayavayadhammānupassītiādīsu
analyzed: catu sampajañña pabba vaṇṇanā  evam iriyāpatha vasena kāya anupassanam vibhajitvā idāni catu sampajañña vasena vibhajitum  puna ca param ti ādim āha tattha abhikkanta iti ādīni sāmañña phale vaṇṇitāni iti ajjhattam  vā ti evam catu sampajañña pariggaṇhanena attanaḥ vā kāye parassa vā kāye kālena vā  attanaḥ kālena vā parassa kāye kāya anupassī viharati idha api samudaya vaya dhamma anupassī iti ādīsu
translated: The Description of the Four Arousings of Mindfulness

original: rūpakkhandhasseva samudayo ca vayo ca nīharitabbo. Sesaṃ vuttasadisameva.🔽Idha catusampajaññapariggāhikā sati dukkhasaccaṃ, tassā samuṭṭhāpikā purimataṇhā
analyzed: rūpa kkhandhassa iva samudayaḥ ca vayaḥ ca nīharitabbo sesam vutta sadisam eva  idha catu sampajañña pariggāhikā sati dukkha saccam tassā samuṭṭhāpikā purima taṇhā
translated: Having thus analyzed the contemplation of the body in terms of postures, now, in order to analyze it in terms of the four kinds of full awareness , he said, “Again, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu, when walking, knows ‘I am walking’ ” . Herein, the words “when walking” and so on have been explained in the Fruits of the Homeless Life . So in this way, by discerning with the four kinds of full awareness, he dwells contemplating the body as a body, either externally, in another’s body, or internally, in his own body, or both internally and externally, in his own body at one time and in another’s body at another time. Here too, in the passage beginning, “Again, a bhikkhu, when going forward or back, is one who acts with full awareness” , the arising and falling away of the material form aggregate should be brought into focus. The rest is as already stated.

original: samudayasaccaṃ, ubhinnaṃ appavatti nirodhasaccaṃ, vuttappakāro ariyamaggo maggasaccaṃ.
analyzed: samudaya saccam ubhinnam appavatti nirodha saccam vutta ppakāraḥ ariya maggaḥ magga saccam
translated: Herein, the mindfulness that discerns by means of the four kinds of full awareness is the truth of suffering. The craving that originates it is the truth of the origin. The non-occurrence of both is the truth of cessation. The noble path of the aforementioned kind is the truth of the way.

original: Evaṃ catusaccavasena ussakkitvā nibbutiṃ pāpuṇātīti idamekassa catusampajaññapariggāhakassa
analyzed: evam catu sacca vasena ussakkitvā nibbutim pāpuṇāti iti idam ekassa catu sampajañña pariggāhakassa
translated: Thus he strives by way of the four Truths and reaches Nibbāna. This is the one who has the four kinds of clear knowing.🔽

original: bhikkhuno vasena yāva arahattā niyyānamukhanti.
analyzed: bhikkhuno vasena yāva arahattā niyyāna mukhanti
translated: So he strives by way of the four truths and reaches Nibbāna. This is the outlet in the case of a bhikkhu who possesses the four kinds of full awareness and reaches Arahantship.

original: Catusampajaññapabbaṃ niṭṭhitaṃ.
analyzed: catusampajañña pabbam niṭṭhitam
translated: The section on the four kinds of full awareness is ended.

original: Paṭikūlamanasikārapabbavaṇṇanā🔽377. Evaṃ catusampajaññavasena kāyānupassanaṃ vibhajitvā idāni paṭikūlamanasikāravasena🔽vibhajituṃ puna caparantiādimāha. Tattha imameva kāyantiādīsu yaṃ vattabbaṃ siyā,
analyzed: paṭikūla manasikāra pabba vaṇṇanā  evam catu sampajañña vasena kāya anupassanam vibhajitvā idāni paṭikūla manasikāra vasena  vibhajitum puna ca param ti ādim āha tattha imam eva yam vattabbam siyā
translated: The exposition of the section on bringing what is not a sign to mind as a sign

original: taṃ sabbaṃ sabbākārena vitthārato visuddhimagge kāyagatāsatikammaṭṭhāne vuttaṃ. Ubhatomukhāti
analyzed: tat sabbam sabba ākārena vitthārataḥ visuddhi magge kāya gata asati kammaṭṭhāne vuttam ubhatomukhā ti
translated: . Having thus analysed the contemplation of the body by way of the four kinds of full awareness, he now said, “Again, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu … brings to mind … as a sign” in order to analyse it by way of bringing what is not a sign to mind as a sign. Herein, what is to be said about the passages beginning “This body … has such a nature and such a constitution” has all been said in the Path of Purity in the chapter on the development of mindfulness of the body in all its details.🔽The “double-mouthed” oil-tube is connected at both ends.

original: heṭṭhā ca upari cāti dvīhi mukhehi yuttā. Nānāvihitassāti nānāvidhassa.
analyzed: heṭṭhā ca upari ca ati dvīhi mukhehi yuttāḥ nānā vihitassa ati nānāvidhassa
translated: “Of various kinds” means of different kinds.

original: Idaṃ panettha opammasaṃsandanaṃ – ubhatomukhā putoḷi viya hi cātumahābhūtiko kāyo,
analyzed: idam pana ittha opamma saṃsandanam ubhatomukhā viya hi cātumahābhūtikaḥ kāyo
translated: The application of the simile here is as follows. The body consisting of the four great primaries is like the double-mouthed oil-tube.

original: tattha missetvā pakkhittanānāvidhadhaññaṃ viya kesādayo dvattiṃsākārā, cakkhumā puriso🔽viya yogāvacaro, tassa taṃ putoḷiṃ muñcitvā paccavekkhato nānāvidhadhaññassa pākaṭakālo
analyzed: tattha missetvā pakkhitta nānāvidha dhaññam viya kesa ādayaḥ dvattiṃsa ākārā cakkhumā puriso  viya yogāvacaro tassa tam putoḷim muñcitvā paccavekkhataḥ nānāvidha dhaññassa pākaṭa kālo
translated: Herein, the thirty-two aspects beginning with head hairs and ending with urine are like the various kinds of grain mixed together.🔽The meditator is like the man with good sight.🔽The time when the various kinds of grain become evident to him after he has released the bag and is looking at it is like the time when the thirty-two aspects become evident to the meditator.

original: viya yogino dvattiṃsākārassa vibhūtakālo veditabbo. Iti ajjhattaṃ vāti evaṃ kesādipariggaṇhanena
analyzed: viya yoginaḥ dvattiṃsa ākārassa vibhūta kālaḥ veditabbaḥ iti ajjhattam vāti evam kesa ādi pariggaṇhanena
translated: Thus in the beginning he is called “one who possesses the sign in part” because he possesses the sign only in part.🔽“In the body”: in his own body or in another’s body.🔽“Or internally in oneself”: in his own body.

original: attano vā kāye, parassa vā kāye, kālena vā attano, kālena vā parassa kāye kāyānupassī🔽viharati. Ito paraṃ vuttanayameva. Kevalañhi idha dvattiṃsākārapariggāhikā sati dukkhasaccanti
analyzed: attanaḥ vā kāye parassa vā kāye kālena vā attanaḥ kālena vā parassa kāye kāya anupassī  viharati itas param vutta nayam eva kevalam hi idha dvattiṃsa ākāra pariggāhikā sati dukkha saccanti
translated: “Or externally in another”: in another’s body.🔽“Or internally and externally”: in his own body or in another’s body.🔽“Or internally he dwells contemplating the body in the body, or externally he dwells contemplating the body in the body, or internally and externally he dwells contemplating the body in the body”: he dwells in the body, he makes his dwelling in the body, he devotes himself to the body, he commits himself to the body.

original: evaṃ yojanaṃ katvā niyyānamukhaṃ veditabbaṃ. Sesaṃ purimasadisamevāti.
analyzed: evam yojanam katvā niyyāna mukham veditabbam sesam purima sadisam eva ati
translated: “Ardent, clearly comprehending, mindful”: these things have already been explained.

original: Paṭikūlamanasikārapabbaṃ niṭṭhitaṃ.🔽Dhātumanasikārapabbavaṇṇanā
analyzed: paṭikūlamanasikārapabbam niṭṭhitam  dhātu manasikāra pabba vaṇṇanā
translated: The section on the contemplation of the unrepulsive is ended.🔽The explanation of the section on the contemplation of the elements follows next.

original: 378. Evaṃ paṭikūlamanasikāravasena kāyānupassanaṃ vibhajitvā idāni dhātumanasikāravasena
analyzed: evam paṭikūla manasikāra vasena kāya anupassanam vibhajitvā idāni dhātu manasikāra vasena
translated: Having thus analyzed the contemplation of the body by way of the unrepulsive, now, in order to show the contemplation of the body by way of the elements, the Master says:

original: vibhajituṃ puna caparantiādimāha. Tatthāyaṃ opammasaṃsandanena saddhiṃ atthavaṇṇanā
analyzed: vibhajitum puna ca param ti ādim āha tattha ayam opamma saṃsandanena saddhim attha vaṇṇanā
translated: He says “To discern again and again” and so on. Here is the commentary on the meaning.

original: – yathā koci goghātako vā tasseva vā bhattavetanabhato antevāsiko gāviṃ vadhitvā
analyzed: yathā koci go ghātakaḥ vā tassa iva vā bhatta vetana bhataḥ antevāsikaḥ gāvim vadhitvā
translated: Just as a butcher of cows or his apprentice, having killed a cow,

original: vinivijjhitvā catasso disā gatānaṃ mahāpathānaṃ vemajjhaṭṭhānasaṅkhāte catumahāpathe🔽koṭṭhāsaṃ koṭṭhāsaṃ katvā nisinno assa, evameva bhikkhu catunnaṃ iriyāpathānaṃ yena🔽kenaci ākārena ṭhitattā yathāṭhitaṃ, yathāṭhitattā ca yathāpaṇihitaṃ kāyaṃ “atthi
analyzed: vinivijjhitvā catassaḥ disāḥ gatānam mahāpathānam vemajjha ṭṭhāna saṅkhāte catu mahāpathe  koṭṭhāsam koṭṭhāsam katvā nisinnaḥ assa evam eva bhikkhu catunnam iriyāpathānam yena  kenacid ākārena ṭhita ttā yathāṭhitam yathāṭhita ttā ca yathāpaṇihitam kāyam atthi
translated: would sit at the crossroads having divided it into portions,

original: imasmiṃ kāye pathavīdhātu…pe… vāyodhātū”ti evaṃ paccavekkhati.
analyzed: imasmin kāye pathavī dhātupe vāyo dhātu uti evam paccavekkhati
translated: so too the bhikkhu considers thus: “In this body there are the earth element, the water element, the fire element, and the air element.”

original: Kiṃ vuttaṃ hoti – yathā goghātakassa gāviṃ posentassāpi āghātanaṃ āharantassāpi āharitvā🔽tattha bandhitvā ṭhapentassapi vadhentassāpi vadhitaṃ mataṃ passantassāpi tāvadeva
analyzed: kim vuttam hoti yathā go ghātakassa gāvim posentassa api āghātanam āharantassa api āharitvā 🔽tattha bandhitvā ṭhapentassa api vadhentassa api vadhitam matam passantassa api tāvat eva
translated: What is meant? Just as when a butcher of cows kills a cow and having divided it into portions sits at the crossroads,🔽so too the bhikkhu considers thus: “In this body there are the earth element, the water element, the fire element, and the air element.”

original: gāvīti saññā na antaradhāyati, yāva naṃ padāletvā bilaso na vibhajati. Vibhajitvā
analyzed: gāvī iti saññā na antaradhāyati yāva nam padāletvā bilasaḥ na vibhajati vibhajitvā
translated: The perception of a cow does not disappear until he has cut it up and divided it into parts.

original: nisinnassa panassa gāvīti saññā antaradhāyati, maṃsasaññā pavattati. Nāssa evaṃ hoti
analyzed: nisinnassa panassa gāvi iti saññā antaradhāyati maṃsa saññā pavattati na assa evam hoti
translated: But when he is sitting there after dividing it up, the perception of a cow disappears and the perception of meat appears. It does not occur to him,

original: – “ahaṃ gāviṃ vikkiṇāmi, ime gāviṃ harantī”ti. Atha khvassa “ahaṃ maṃsaṃ vikkiṇāmi,🔽ime maṃsaṃ haranti” cceva hoti; evameva imassāpi bhikkhuno pubbe bālaputhujjanakāle
analyzed: aham gāvim vikkiṇāmi ime gāvim haranti iti atha khvassa aham maṃsam vikkiṇāmi  ime maṃsam haranti cca iva hoti evam eva imassa api bhikkhuno pubbe bāla puthujjana kāle
translated: ‘I am selling the cow, they are taking away the cow,’ but rather it occurs to him, ‘I am selling meat, they are taking away meat.’ So too, in this bhikkhu’s case, as long as he does not divide up this body …

original: gihibhūtassāpi pabbajitassāpi tāvadeva sattoti vā puggaloti vā saññā na antaradhāyati,🔽yāva imameva kāyaṃ yathāṭhitaṃ yathāpaṇihitaṃ ghanavinibbhogaṃ katvā dhātuso na paccavekkhati.
analyzed: gihi bhūtassa api pabbajitassa api tāvat eva satto ti vā puggalo ti vā saññā na antaradhāyati  yāva imam eva kāyam yathā ṭhitam yathā paṇihitam ghana vinibbhogam katvā dhātusaḥ na paccavekkhati
translated: and review it by elements, the perception of a being or the perception of a person does not disappear in him, whether he is a layman or a monastic.

original: Dhātuso paccavekkhato panassa sattasaññā antaradhāyati, dhātuvaseneva cittaṃ santiṭṭhati.
analyzed: dhātuso paccavekkhato panassa satta saññā antaradhāyati dhātu vasena iva cittam santiṭṭhati
translated: But when he reviews it by elements, the perception of a being disappears and his mind becomes steadied in the mode of the elements.

original: Tenāha bhagavā – “‘imameva kāyaṃ yathāṭhitaṃ yathāpaṇihitaṃ dhātuso paccavekkhati
analyzed: tena āha bhagavā imam eva kāyam yathā ṭhitam yathā paṇihitam dhātuso paccavekkhati
translated: That is why the Blessed One said: ‘He reviews this body up from the soles of the feet and down from the top of the hair and skin as beset with many kinds of impurities thus: “In this body there are head-hairs, body-hairs, nails, teeth, skin, flesh, sinews, bones, bone-marrow, kidneys, heart, liver, pleura, spleen, lungs, intestines, mesentery, contents of the stomach, excrement, bile, phlegm, pus, blood, sweat, fat, tears, grease, saliva, snot, synovic fluid, urine.”

original: ‘atthi imasmiṃ kāye pathavīdhātu āpodhātu tejodhātu vāyodhātū’ti. Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave,
analyzed: atthi imasmin kāye pathavī dhātu āpaḥ dhātu tejaḥ dhātu vāyaḥ dhātu uti sā iyyathā api bhikkhave
translated: ‘In this body there are the earth element, the water element, the fire element, and the air element.’ Just as though, bhikkhus,

original: dakkho goghātako vā…pe… vāyodhātū”ti. Goghātako viya hi yogī, gāvīti saññā viya sattasaññā,
analyzed: dakkhaḥ go ghātakaḥ vāpe vāyodhātu uti go ghātakaḥ viya hi yogī gāvī iti saññā viya satta saññā
translated: the air element” . For the meditator is like the skilled butcher, perception of a living being is like the perception of a cow,

original: catumahāpatho viya catuiriyāpatho, bilaso vibhajitvā nisinnabhāvo viya dhātuso paccavekkhaṇanti
analyzed: catu mahā pathaḥ viya catu iriyāpathaḥ bilasaḥ vibhajitvā nisinna bhāvaḥ viya dhātusaḥ paccavekkhaṇanti
translated: the four cross-roads is like the four postures, and his sitting down after dividing up the carcass is like the reviewing of the elements.

original: ayamettha pāḷivaṇṇanā. Kammaṭṭhānakathā pana visuddhimagge vitthāritā.
analyzed: ayam ettha pāḷi vaṇṇanā kammaṭṭhāna kathā pana visuddhi magge vitthāritā
translated: This is the commentary on the letter A. But the explanation of the meditation subject is given in the Path of Purity .

original: Iti ajjhattaṃ vāti evaṃ catudhātupariggaṇhanena attano vā kāye, parassa vā kāye,
analyzed: iti ajjhattam vā ati evam catu dhātu pariggaṇhanena attanaḥ vā kāye parassa vā kāye
translated: Thus in the body: thus in his own body or in another’s body he contemplates the elements as the fourfold sign of the contemplation of the body, or sometimes in his own body and sometimes in another’s.

original: kālena vā attano, kālena vā parassa kāye kāyānupassī viharati. Ito paraṃ vuttanayameva.
analyzed: kālena vā attanaḥ kālena vā parassa kāye kāya anupassī viharati itas param vutta nayam eva
translated: The rest is as already stated.🔽Herein, the way in which the four kinds of insight beginning with that of impermanence should be given is this.🔽The way in which the four kinds of full-understanding should be given is this.

original: Kevalañhi idha catudhātupariggāhikā sati dukkhasaccanti evaṃ yojanaṃ katvā niyyānamukhaṃ
analyzed: kevalam hi idha catu dhātu pariggāhikā sati dukkha saccanti evam yojanam katvā niyyāna mukham
translated: The way in which the four kinds of proper attention should be given is this.

original: veditabbaṃ, sesaṃ purimasadisamevāti.
analyzed: veditabbam sesam purima sadisam eva ati
translated: The way in which the four kinds of thorough knowledge should be given is this.🔽The way in which the four applications of mindfulness should be given is this.

original: Dhātumanasikārapabbaṃ niṭṭhitaṃ.
analyzed: dhātumanasikārapabbam niṭṭhitam
translated: The way in which the four foundations of mindfulness should be given is this.🔽The way in which the four paths should be given is this.🔽The way in which the four fruits should be given is this.🔽The way in which the four investigations should be given is this.🔽The way in which the four kinds of careful attention should be given is this.🔽The way in which the four discriminations should be given is this.🔽The way in which the four grounds for arousing states should be given is this.🔽The way in which the four grounds for arousing effort should be given is this.🔽The way in which the four grounds for arousing desire should be given is this.🔽The way in which the four grounds for arousing enthusiasm should be given is this.🔽The way in which the four grounds for arousing ardour should be given is this.🔽The way in which the four grounds for arousing endeavour should be given is this.🔽The way in which the four grounds for arousing exertion should be given is this.🔽The way in which the four grounds for arousing mindfulness should be given is this.🔽The way in which the four grounds

original: Navasivathikapabbavaṇṇanā🔽379. Evaṃ dhātumanasikāravasena kāyānupassanaṃ vibhajitvā idāni navahi sivathikapabbehi🔽vibhajituṃ puna caparantiādimāha. Tattha seyyathāpi passeyyāti yathā passeyya. Sarīranti
analyzed: nava sivathika pabba vaṇṇanā  evam dhātu manasikāra vasena kāya anupassanam vibhajitvā idāni navahi sivathikapabbehi  vibhajitum puna ca param ti ādim āha tattha seyyathā api passeyya ati yathā passeyya sarīran ti
translated: Description of the nine-part charnel-ground meditation subject

original: matasarīraṃ. Sivathikāya chaḍḍitanti susāne apaviddhaṃ. Ekāhaṃ matassa assāti ekāhamataṃ.
analyzed: mata sarīram sivathikāya chaḍḍitanti susāne apaviddham eka aham matassa assa ati eka aha matam
translated: Having thus analysed the contemplation of the body by means of the elements, he now said “Again, bhikkhus” in order to analyse it by means of the nine-part charnel-ground meditation subject. Herein, as if he saw: as though he saw. A corpse: a dead body. Cast away in a charnel ground: thrown away in a charnel ground. One day dead: one day after death.

original: Dvīhaṃ matassa assāti dvīhamataṃ. Tīhaṃ matassa assāti tīhamataṃ. Kammārabhastā viya
analyzed: dvīham matassa assa ati dvīha matam tīham matassa assa ati tīha matam kammāra bhastā viya
translated: Two days dead: two days after death. Three days dead: three days after death. Like a smith’s bellows

original: vāyunā uddhaṃ jīvitapariyādānā yathānukkamaṃ samuggatena sūnabhāvena uddhumātattā🔽uddhumātaṃ, uddhumātameva uddhumātakaṃ. Paṭikūlattā vā kucchitaṃ uddhumātanti uddhumātakaṃ.
analyzed: vāyunā uddham jīvita pariyādānā yathānukkamam samuggatena sūna bhāvena  uddhumātam uddhumātam eva uddhumātakam vā kucchitam uddhumātanti uddhumātakam
translated: trunk, with the wind of in-breath and out-breath driven out by the exhaustion of life, it is bloated with the condition of inflation that has arisen in due course.🔽It is “swollen” because it is swollen with inflation, or it is “swollen” because it is contemptible owing to repulsiveness.

original: Vinīlaṃ vuccati viparibhinnavaṇṇaṃ, vinīlameva vinīlakaṃ. Paṭikūlattā vā kucchitaṃ
analyzed: vinīlam vuccati viparibhinna vaṇṇam vinīlam eva vinīlakam paṭikūla ttā vā kucchitam
translated: “Discoloured” is said of a change in appearance. It is “discoloured” because it is discoloured, or it is “discoloured” because it is contemptible owing to repulsiveness.

original: vinīlanti vinīlakaṃ. Maṃsussadaṭṭhānesu rattavaṇṇassa pubbasannicayaṭṭhānesu setavaṇṇassa
analyzed: vinīlanti vinīlakam maṃsussada ṭṭhānesu ratta vaṇṇassa pubba sannicaya ṭṭhānesu seta vaṇṇassa
translated: “Discolored” : discolored means discolored by the color of decay. In places where the flesh is thick, it is discolored by the color of blood, in places where the humors are accumulated, it is discolored by the color of pus,

original: yebhuyyena ca nīlavaṇṇassa nīlaṭṭhānesu nīlasāṭakapārutasseva chavasarīrassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ.
analyzed: yebhuyyena ca nīla vaṇṇassa nīla ṭṭhānesu nīla sāṭaka pārutassa iva chava sarīrassa itam adhivacanam
translated: and in places where the color is blue, it is discolored by the color of blue. This is a designation for a dead body wrapped in a blue cloth.

original: Paribhinnaṭṭhānehi navahi vā vaṇamukhehi vissandamānapubbaṃ vipubbaṃ, vipubbameva🔽vipubbakaṃ. Paṭikūlattā vā kucchitaṃ vipubbanti vipubbakaṃ. Vipubbakaṃ jātaṃ tathābhāvaṃ
analyzed: paribhinna ṭṭhānehi navahi vā vaṇa mukhehi vissandamāna pubbam vipubbam vipubbam eva  vipubbakam paṭikūla ttā vā kucchitam vipubbanti vipubbakam vipubbakam jātam tathābhāvam
translated: “With openings” : with openings means with nine openings. With the openings of the nine orifices, the body is full of pus,

original: gatanti vipubbakajātaṃ.
analyzed: gatam ti vipubbaka jātam
translated: and it oozes pus from the openings.🔽Or alternatively, it is full of pus because it is revolting and repulsive, and it is full of pus because it has become so.

original: So imameva kāyanti so bhikkhu imaṃ attano kāyaṃ tena kāyena saddhiṃ ñāṇena upasaṃharati
analyzed: saḥ imam eva kāyan ti saḥ bhikkhu imam attano kāyam tena kāyena saddhim ñāṇena upasaṃharati
translated: “With a corpse in it” : the bhikkhu brings this body into relationship with that body by knowledge,

original: upaneti. Kathaṃ? Ayampi kho kāyo evaṃdhammo evaṃbhāvī evaṃanatītoti. Idaṃ vuttaṃ
analyzed: upaneti katham ayam pi kho kāyaḥ evaṃdhammaḥ evaṃbhāvī evaṃanatītaḥ ti idam vuttam
translated: he brings it forward, he presents it. How? “This body too is of the same nature, has the same characteristics, and will not go beyond this.”🔽This is what is meant.

original: hoti – āyu, usmā, viññāṇanti imesaṃ tiṇṇaṃ dhammānaṃ atthitāya ayaṃ kāyo ṭhānagamanādikhamo
analyzed: hoti āyu usmā viññāṇanti imesam tiṇṇam dhammānam atthitāya ayam kāyo ṭhāna gamana ādi khamo
translated: Because of the absence of these three things—life, heat, and consciousness—this body is incapable of standing, walking, etc.

original: hoti, imesaṃ pana vigamā ayampi kho kāyo evaṃdhammo evaṃ pūtikasabhāvoyeva, evaṃbhāvī
analyzed: hoti imesam pana vigamāḥ ayam pi kho kāyaḥ evaṃdhammo evam evaṃbhāvī
translated: But this body is of such a nature, is of such an origination, is of such a destiny, that it will be like that, it is not exempt from that fate.

original: evaṃ uddhumātādibhedo bhavissati, evaṃanatīto evaṃ uddhumātādibhāvaṃ anatikkantoti.
analyzed: evam uddhumātā ādi bhedaḥ bhavissati evaṃanatītaḥ evam uddhumātā ādi bhāvam an atikkantaḥ ti
translated: It will become bloated, etc., in the way already described.

original: Iti ajjhattaṃ vāti evaṃ uddhumātādipariggaṇhanena attano vā kāye, parassa vā kāye,
analyzed: iti ajjhattam vāti evam uddhu mātā ādi pariggaṇhanena attanaḥ vā kāye parassa vā kāye
translated: Thus internally or externally: by discerning a bloatedness, etc., in his own body or in the body of another,

original: kālena vā attano, kālena vā parassa kāye kāyānupassī viharati.🔽Khajjamānanti udarādīsu nisīditvā udaramaṃsaoṭṭhamaṃsaakkhikūṭādīni luñcitvā luñcitvā
analyzed: kālena vā attanaḥ kālena vā parassa kāye kāya anupassī viharati  khajjamānanti udara ādīsu nisīditvā udara maṃsa oṭṭha maṃsa akkhikūṭa ādīni luñcitvā luñcitvā
translated: or at one time in his own body and at another in the body of another, he abides contemplating a body as a body.🔽Being devoured: being eaten by creatures that take up residence in the stomach, etc., and bore through the intestines, the stomach lining, and so on.

original: khādiyamānaṃ. Samaṃsalohitanti sāvasesamaṃsalohitayuttaṃ. Nimaṃsalohitamakkhitanti
analyzed: khādiyamānam sa maṃsa lohitanti sa avasesa maṃsa lohita yuttam nimaṃsa lohita makkhitanti
translated: With flesh and blood: together with the remaining flesh and blood. Smeared with sinews:

original: maṃse khīṇepi lohitaṃ na sussati, taṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ “nimaṃsalohitamakkhita”nti.
analyzed: maṃse khīṇe api lohitam na sussati tam sandhāya vuttam nimaṃsa lohita makkhitanti
translated: even though the flesh is used up, the blood does not dry up. “Smeared with sinews” is said with reference to that.

original: Aññenāti aññena disābhāgena. Hatthaṭṭhikanti catusaṭṭhibhedampi hatthaṭṭhikaṃ pāṭiyekkaṃ
analyzed: aññena ati aññena disā bhāgena hatthaṭṭhikam ti catur aṭṭhi bhedam pi hatthaṭṭhikam pāṭiyekkam
translated: In another place: in another direction. Hand bones: the hand bones, which are of sixty different pieces.

original: pāṭiyekkaṃ vippakiṇṇaṃ. Pādaṭṭhikādīsupi eseva nayo.🔽Terovassikānīti atikkantasaṃvaccharāni. Pūtīnīti abbhokāse ṭhitāni vātātapavuṭṭhisamphassena
analyzed: pāṭiyekkam vippakiṇṇam pādaṭṭhika ādīsu pi esa iva nayaḥ  terovassikāni iti atikkanta saṃvaccharāni pūtīni iti abbhokāse ṭhitāni vāta ātapa vuṭṭhi samphassena
translated: and scattered separately. The same method applies to the foot bones, etc.🔽Three years old: more than one year old. Rotting: those that, being left in the open, have become rotten through the contact of wind and sun.

original: terovassikāneva pūtīni honti, antobhūmigatāni pana cirataraṃ tiṭṭhanti. Cuṇṇakajātānīti
analyzed: pūtīni honti antobhūmi gatāni pana cirataram tiṭṭhanti cuṇṇaka jātāni iti
translated: Those that are buried underground last longer. To powder:

original: cuṇṇaṃ cuṇṇaṃ hutvā vippakiṇṇāni. Sabbattha so imamevāti vuttanayena khajjamānādīnaṃ🔽vasena yojanā kātabbā. Iti ajjhattaṃ vāti evaṃ khajjamānādipariggaṇhanena yāva cuṇṇakabhāvā
analyzed: cuṇṇam cuṇṇam hutvā vippakiṇṇāni sabbattha so imam eva ati vutta nayena khajjamāna ādīnam  vasena yojanā kātabbā iti ajjhattam vāti evam khajjamāna ādi pariggaṇhanena yāva cuṇṇaka bhāvā
translated: they are scattered as fine powder. In all cases the construction is to be done by way of “devouring,” etc., as already stated.

original: attano vā kāye, parassa vā kāye kālena vā attano, kālena vā parassa kāye kāyānupassī viharati.🔽Idha pana ṭhatvā navasivathikā samodhānetabbā. Ekāhamataṃ vāti hi ādinā nayena vuttā
analyzed: attanaḥ vā kāye parassa vā kāye kālena vā attanaḥ kālena vā parassa kāye kāya anupassī viharati  idha pana ṭhatvā nava sivathikā samodhānetabbā eka aha matam vā iti hi ādinā nayena vuttā
translated: Thus internally: thus by discerning the skeleton as long as it lasts in the form of “devouring,” etc., he dwells contemplating the body in the body, either in his own body or in another’s body, or sometimes in his own body and sometimes in another’s body.🔽Here, however, the nine cemetery contemplations should be combined with this meditation subject. All of them, beginning with “a skeleton one year old,”

original: sabbāpi ekā, kākehi vā khajjamānantiādikā ekā, aṭṭhikasaṅkhalikaṃ samaṃsalohitaṃ
analyzed: sabbā api ekā kākehi vā khajjamānanti ādikā ekā aṭṭhika saṅkhalikam sa maṃsa lohitam
translated: are one. Those beginning with “being devoured by crows” are one. A skeleton without flesh but smeared with blood,

original: nhārusambandhanti ekā, nimaṃsalohitamakkhitaṃ nhārusambandhanti ekā, apagatamaṃsalohitaṃ🔽nhārusambandhanti ekā, aṭṭhikāni apagatasambandhānītiādikā ekā aṭṭhikāni setāni saṅkhavaṇṇapaṭibhāgānīti
analyzed: ekā nimaṃsa lohita makkhitam nhāru sambandhanti ekā apagata maṃsa lohitam  ekā aṭṭhikāni apagata sambandhāni iti ādikā ekā aṭṭhikāni sā etāni saṅkha vaṇṇa paṭibhāgāni iti
translated: one as ‘joined by sinews’, one as ‘without flesh and blood’,🔽one as ‘joined by bones’, one as ‘bones detached’, and so on, and one as ‘bones white, the colour of shells’;🔽

original: ekā, puñjakitāni terovassikānīti ekā, pūtīni cuṇṇakajātānīti ekāti.
analyzed: ekā puñjakitāni terovassikāni iti ekā pūtīni cuṇṇaka jātāni iti ekā ati
translated: One as “joined by sinews” , one as “without flesh and blood, joined by sinews” , one as “without flesh and blood, not joined by sinews” , one as “bones” , one as “white bones” , one as “rotten bones” , one as “bones turned to dust” , one as “earth” , one as “water” , one as “fire” , one as “air” , one as “space” .

original: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhaveti idaṃ navasivathikā dassetvā kāyānupassanaṃ niṭṭhapento āha.🔽Tattha navasivathikapariggāhikā sati dukkhasaccaṃ, tassā samuṭṭhāpikā purimataṇhā
analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave ti idam nava sivathikāḥ dassetvā kāya anupassanam niṭṭhapentaḥ āha  tattha nava sivathika pariggāhikā sati dukkha saccam tassā samuṭṭhāpikā purima taṇhā
translated: This is how you should practise, bhikkhus.” After showing the nine charnel-ground contemplations in this way, he said this in order to conclude the contemplation of the body.

original: samudayasaccaṃ, ubhinnaṃ appavatti nirodhasaccaṃ, dukkhaparijānano samudayapajahano
analyzed: samudaya saccam ubhinnam appavatti nirodha saccam dukkha parijānano samudaya pajahano
translated: Herein, the mindfulness that discerns the nine charnel-ground contemplations is the truth of suffering, the prior craving that causes that is the truth of the origin, the non-occurrence of both is the truth of cessation, full-understanding of suffering, abandoning of origin,

original: nirodhārammaṇo ariyamaggo maggasaccaṃ. Evaṃ catusaccavasena ussakkitvā nibbutiṃ pāpuṇātīti
analyzed: nirodha ārammaṇaḥ ariya maggaḥ magga saccam evam catu sacca vasena ussakkitvā nibbutim pāpuṇāti iti
translated: and the noble path that has cessation as its object is the truth of the path. Thus he exhorts them to strive for the four truths and so reach extinction.

original: idaṃ navasivathikapariggāhakānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ yāva arahattā niyyānamukhanti.
analyzed: idam nava sivathika pariggāhakānam bhikkhūnam yāva arahattā niyyāna mukhan ti
translated: This is the outlet to the state of full understanding of the nine charnel-ground contemplations for bhikkhus who are candidates for the fruit of arahantship.

original: Navasivathikapabbaṃ niṭṭhitaṃ.
analyzed: navasivathika pabbam niṭṭhitam
translated: The “Nine Cemetery Contemplations” is finished.

original: Ettāvatā ca ānāpānapabbaṃ, iriyāpathapabbaṃ, catusampajaññapabbaṃ, paṭikūlamanasikārapabbaṃ,
analyzed: ettāvatā ca āna apāna pabbam iriyāpatha pabbam catu sampajañña pabbam paṭikūla manasikāra pabbam
