translated: And at this point the “exercise of mindfulness of breathing,” the “exercise of mindfulness of postures,” the “exercise of the four kinds of full awareness,” the “exercise of bringing to mind the loathsomeness of food,”🔽the “exercise of bringing in mind the sign of the foul,” and the “nine cemetery contemplations” have been explained.

original: dhātumanasikārapabbaṃ, navasivathikapabbānīti cuddasapabbā kāyānupassanā niṭṭhitā
analyzed: dhātu manasikāra pabbam nava sivathika pabbāni iti cuddasa pabbā kāya anupassanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The fourteen exercises in mindfulness of the body are finished.

original: hoti. Tattha ānāpānapabbaṃ, paṭikūlamanasikārapabbanti imāneva dve appanākammaṭṭhānāni,
analyzed: hoti tattha āna apāna pabbam paṭikūla manasikāra pabban ti imāni eva dve appanā kammaṭṭhānāni
translated: Herein, the “exercise of mindfulness of breathing” and the “exercise of bringing to mind the loathsomeness of food” are the two basic meditation subjects.

original: sivathikānaṃ pana ādīnavānupassanāvasena vuttattā sesāni dvādasāpi upacārakammaṭṭhānānevāti.
analyzed: sivathikānam pana ādīnava anupassanā vasena vutta ttā sesāni dvādasa api upacāra kammaṭṭhānāni eva ati
translated: The remaining twelve are only access meditation subjects because they are stated in terms of the contemplation of exposure to suffering.

original: Kāyānupassanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: kāya anupassanā niṭṭhitā
translated: Mindfulness of the body is finished.

original: Vedanānupassanāvaṇṇanā🔽380. Evaṃ bhagavā cuddasavidhena kāyānupassanāsatipaṭṭhānaṃ kathetvā idāni navavidhena
analyzed: vedanā anupassanā vaṇṇanā  evam bhagavā cuddasavidhena kāya anupassanā sati paṭṭhānam kathetvā idāni navavidhena
translated: Contemplation of feeling

original: vedanānupassanaṃ kathetuṃ kathañca, bhikkhavetiādimāha. Tattha sukhaṃ vedananti kāyikaṃ
analyzed: vedanā anupassanam kathetum katham ca bhikkhave ti ādim āha tattha sukham vedananti kāyikam
translated: So the Blessed One, after teaching the fourteenfold exercise of mindfulness of the body, now began the teaching of the ninefold exercise of mindfulness of feelings with the words “And how, bhikkhus, is there mindfulness occupied with the body? Here a bhikkhu, when experiencing a pleasant feeling, understands: ‘I experience a pleasant feeling’;

original: vā cetasikaṃ vā sukhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayamāno “ahaṃ sukhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayāmī”ti pajānātīti
analyzed: vā cetasikam vā sukham vedanam vedayamānaḥ aham sukham vedanam vedayāmi iti pajānāti iti
translated: or when experiencing a painful feeling, he understands: ‘I experience a painful feeling’; or when experiencing a neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling, he understands: ‘I experience a neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling.’

original: attho. Tattha kāmaṃ uttānaseyyakāpi dārakā thaññapivanādikāle sukhaṃ vedayamānā “sukhaṃ🔽vedanaṃ vedayāmā”ti pajānanti, na panetaṃ evarūpaṃ jānanaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ. Evarūpañhi🔽jānanaṃ sattūpaladdhiṃ na jahati, attasaññaṃ na ugghāṭeti, kammaṭṭhānaṃ vā satipaṭṭhānabhāvanā
analyzed: attho tattha kāmam uttānaseyyakā api dārakā thañña pivana ādi kāle sukham vedayamānā sukham  vedanam vedayāma iti pajānanti na pana etat evarūpam jānanam sandhāya vuttam evarūpam hi  jānanam sattu upaladdhim na jahati atta saññam na ugghāṭeti kammaṭṭhānam vā sati paṭṭhāna bhāvanā
translated: “Meaning” . Herein, although even very young children, when they are drinking milk, etc., know pleasure as “pleasant feeling,” still this is not said with reference to such knowledge. For such knowledge does not abandon the assumption of a being, it does not remove the perception of self, and it is not a condition for the development of mindfulness by body, etc.,

original: vā na hoti. Imassa pana bhikkhuno jānanaṃ sattūpaladdhiṃ jahati, attasaññaṃ ugghāṭeti,🔽kammaṭṭhānañceva satipaṭṭhānabhāvanā ca hoti. Idañhi “ko vedayati, kassa vedanā,🔽kiṃ kāraṇā vedanā”ti evaṃ sampajānavediyanaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ.🔽Tattha ko vedayatīti na koci satto vā puggalo vā vedayati. Kassa vedanāti na kassaci
analyzed: vā na hoti imassa pana bhikkhuno jānanam sattu upaladdhim jahati atta saññam ugghāṭeti  kammaṭṭhānam ca iva sati paṭṭhāna bhāvanā ca hoti idam hi kaḥ vedayati kassa vedanā  kim kāraṇā vedanā iti evam sampajāna vediyanam sandhāya vuttam  tattha kaḥ vedayati iti na koci sattaḥ vā puggalaḥ vā vedayati kassa vedanā ati na kassaci
translated: Meaning. Herein, although young children who are sucklings and so on do experience pleasure when they are being suckled, and so on, and they know “We are experiencing pleasure,” still this is not what is meant here. For such knowledge does not abandon the assumption of a being, it does not demolish the perception of self, and it is not a meditation subject or development of the foundations of mindfulness. But this bhikkhu’s knowledge abandons the assumption of a being, it demolishes the perception of self, and it is a meditation subject and development of the foundations of mindfulness. For this is said with reference to the clear comprehension of feeling stated thus, “Who feels? Whose is the feeling? Why does feeling arise?”

original: sattassa vā puggalassa vā vedanā. Kiṃ kāraṇā vedanāti vatthuārammaṇāva panassa vedanā,
analyzed: sattassa vā puggalassa vā vedanā kim kāraṇā vedanā ati vatthu ārammaṇā ava pana assa vedanā
translated: Herein, who feels? No being or person feels. Whose is the feeling? It is not the feeling of any being or person. Why does feeling arise? Feeling arises because of an object.

original: tasmā esa evaṃ pajānāti “taṃ taṃ sukhādīnaṃ vatthuṃ ārammaṇaṃ katvā vedanāva vedayati
analyzed: tasmai esaḥ evam pajānāti tam tam sukha ādīnam vatthum ārammaṇam katvā vedanā ava vedayati
translated: Therefore he understands thus: “Feeling feels the respective object, such as a visible form, etc., that is present.

original: taṃ pana vedanāya pavattiṃ upādāya’ahaṃ vedayāmī’ti vohāramattaṃ hotī”ti. Evaṃ vatthuṃ
analyzed: tam pana vedanāya pavattim upādāya aham vedayāmi iti vohāra mattam hoti iti evam vatthum
translated: But the expression ‘I feel’ is a mere mode of description based on the occurrence of feeling.”🔽Thus, when he discerns that “Feeling feels the object that is present,”

original: ārammaṇaṃ katvā vedanāva vedayatīti sallakkhento esa “sukhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayāmīti pajānātī”ti
analyzed: ārammaṇam katvā vedanā ava vedayati iti sallakkhentaḥ esa sukham vedanam vedayāmi iti pajānāti iti
translated: he understands thus: “I am experiencing a pleasant feeling.”

original: veditabbo cittalapabbate aññataratthero viya.🔽Thero kira aphāsukakāle balavavedanāya nitthunanto aparāparaṃ parivattati, tameko
analyzed: veditabbo cittala pabbate aññatara theraḥ viya  theraḥ kira a phāsuka kāle balava vedanāya nitthunantaḥ apara aparam parivattati tam ekaḥ
translated: And this should be known as like the Elder Cittagutta on Mount Citta.

original: daharo āha – “kataraṃ vo, bhante, ṭhānaṃ rujjatī”ti. Āvuso, pāṭiyekkaṃ rujjanaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: daharaḥ āha kataram vaḥ bhante ṭhānam rujjati iti āvuso pāṭiyekkam rujjana ṭṭhānam
translated: The elder, it seems, was turning over and over in pain from a severe illness. A certain novice monk said to him: “Venerable sir, where does it pain you?”

original: nāma natthi, vatthuṃ ārammaṇaṃ katvā vedanāva vedayatīti. Evaṃ jānanakālato paṭṭhāya
analyzed: nāma natthi vatthum ārammaṇam katvā vedanā ava vedayati iti evam jānana kālataḥ paṭṭhāya
translated: “There is no place, friend, that does not pain me. Feeling feels the object that is present.”🔽“Venerable sir, it is proper to endure it.”🔽“I am enduring it, friend.”

original: adhivāsetuṃ vaṭṭati no, bhante,ti. Adhivāsemi, āvusoti. Adhivāsanā, bhante, seyyoti.
analyzed: adhivāsetum vaṭṭati no bhante iti adhivāsemi āvuso iti adhivāsanā bhante seyyā iti
translated: “Endurance is good, venerable sir.”

original: Thero adhivāsesi. Vāto yāva hadayā phālesi, mañcake antāni rāsikatāni ahesuṃ. Thero
analyzed: theraḥ adhivāsesi vātaḥ yāva hadayā mañcake antāni rāsikatāni ahesum theraḥ
translated: The elder consented. The wind tore his heart open. His entrails were piled up on the bed. The elder

original: daharassa dassesi “vaṭṭatāvuso, ettakā adhivāsanā”ti. Daharo tuṇhī ahosi. Thero vīriyasamataṃ
analyzed: daharassa dassesi vaṭṭati avuso ettakā adhivāsanā ti daharaḥ tuṇhī ahosi theraḥ vīriya samataṃ
translated: showed them to the youth, saying, “Friend, I have endured this much.” The youth was silent. The elder,

original: yojetvā saha paṭisambhidāhi arahattaṃ pāpuṇitvā samasīsī hutvā parinibbāyi.🔽Yathā ca sukhaṃ, evaṃ dukkhaṃ…pe… nirāmisaṃ adukkhamasukhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayamāno “nirāmisaṃ
analyzed: yojetvā saha paṭisambhidāhi arahattam pāpuṇitvā samasīsī hutvā parinibbāyi  yathā ca sukham evam nirāmisam adukkham asukham vedanam vedayamānaḥ nirāmisam
translated: having applied himself to the equanimity of energy, attained arahatship together with the analytical knowledges. He attained final Nibbāna with his head on the elder’s lap.

original: adukkhamasukhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayāmī”ti pajānāti. Iti bhagavā rūpakammaṭṭhānaṃ kathetvā🔽arūpakammaṭṭhānaṃ kathento yasmā phassavasena cittavasena vā kathiyamānaṃ pākaṭaṃ
analyzed: adukkham asukham vedanam vedayāmi iti pajānāti iti bhagavā rūpa kammaṭṭhānam kathetvā  arūpa kammaṭṭhānam kathentaḥ phassa vasena citta vasena vā kathiyamānam pākaṭam
translated: Just as he did with pleasure, so too with pain, and so on. When he feels a neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling, he knows “I feel a neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling.” Thus the Exalted One, having explained the subject of meditation on material form,

original: na hoti, andhakāraṃ viya khāyati, vedanānaṃ pana uppattipākaṭatāya vedanāvasena pākaṭaṃ
analyzed: na hoti andhakāram viya khāyati vedanānam pana uppatti pākaṭa tāya vedanā vasena pākaṭam
translated: explained the subject of meditation on the immaterial by way of feeling, for it is not clear when it is explained by way of contact or by way of consciousness, and it seems as if it were in darkness. But when it is explained by way of feeling, it is clear,

original: hoti, tasmā sakkapañhe viya idhāpi vedanāvasena arūpakammaṭṭhānaṃ kathesi. Tattha
analyzed: hoti tasmā sakka pañhe viya idha api vedanā vasena arūpa kammaṭṭhānam kathesi tattha
translated: because the arising of feeling is clear. Therefore, just as in the Sakkapañha Sutta, so too here in the Mahāsatipaṭṭhāna Sutta, the subject of meditation on the immaterial is explained by way of feeling.

original: “duvidhañhi kammaṭṭhānaṃ rūpakammaṭṭhānaṃ arūpakammaṭṭhānañcā”tiādi kathāmaggo sakkapañhe
analyzed: duvidham hi kammaṭṭhānam rūpa kammaṭṭhānam arūpa kammaṭṭhānam ca atiādi kathā maggaḥ sakka pañhe
translated: “For there are two kinds of meditation subjects, that is to say, meditation subjects for developing and meditation subjects for attaining.

original: vuttanayeneva veditabbo.
analyzed: vutta nayena iva veditabbaḥ
translated: The Path of Purification, which is the commentary on the meditation subject of foulness, should be understood as given in the Description of Foulness .

original: Tattha sukhaṃ vedanantiādīsu ayaṃ aparopi pajānanapariyāyo, sukhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayāmīti🔽pajānātīti sukhavedanākkhaṇe dukkhavedanāya abhāvato sukhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayamāno “sukhaṃ
analyzed: tattha sukham vedanam ti ādīsu ayam aparaḥ api pajānana pariyāyaḥ sukham vedanam vedayāmi iti  pajānāti iti sukha vedanā khaṇe dukkha vedanāya abhāvataḥ sukham vedanam vedayamānaḥ sukham
translated: Herein, there is also this method of understanding: he understands when he feels a pleasant feeling thus, ‘I feel a pleasant feeling’ .🔽He understands when he feels a painful feeling thus, ‘I feel a painful feeling’ .🔽He understands when he feels a neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling thus, ‘I feel a neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling’ .

original: vedanaṃyeva vedayāmī”ti pajānāti. Tena yā pubbe bhūtapubbā dukkhavedanā, tassa idāni
analyzed: vedanaṃyā iva vedayāmi iti pajānāti tena yā pubbe bhūta pubbā dukkha vedanā tassa idāni
translated: He understands how the unarisen pleasant feeling arises,🔽how the arisen pleasant feeling is abandoned,

original: abhāvato imissā ca sukhāya vedanāya ito paṭhamaṃ abhāvato vedanā nāma aniccā adhuvā🔽vipariṇāmadhammā, itiha tattha sampajāno hoti. Vuttampi cetaṃ bhagavatā –
analyzed: abhāvataḥ imissā ca sukhāya vedanāya itas paṭhamam abhāvataḥ vedanā nāma aniccā adhuvā  vipariṇāma dhammā iti ha tattha sampajānaḥ hoti vuttam pi ca itam bhagavatā
translated: how the unarisen painful feeling arises,🔽how the arisen painful feeling is abandoned,

original: “Yasmiṃ, aggivessana, samaye sukhaṃ vedanaṃ vedeti, neva tasmiṃ samaye dukkhaṃ vedanaṃ
analyzed: yasmin aggivessana samaye sukham vedanam vedeti na iva tasmin samaye dukkham vedanam
translated: how the unarisen neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling arises,🔽how the arisen neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling is abandoned.🔽And this is said by the Blessed One:

original: vedeti, na adukkhamasukhaṃ vedanaṃ vedeti, sukhaṃyeva tasmiṃ samaye vedanaṃ vedeti.
analyzed: vedeti na adukkham asukham vedanam vedeti sukham yā iva tasmin samaye vedanam vedeti
translated: he feels neither-unpleasant-nor-pleasant feeling.🔽On that occasion he does not feel pleasant feeling, he does not feel painful feeling, he does not feel neither-unpleasant-nor-pleasant feeling.

original: Yasmiṃ, aggivessana, samaye dukkhaṃ…pe… adukkhamasukhaṃ vedanaṃ vedeti, neva tasmiṃ🔽samaye sukhaṃ vedanaṃ vedeti, na dukkhaṃ vedanaṃ vedeti, adukkhamasukhaṃyeva tasmiṃ
analyzed: yasmin aggivessana samaye dukkhaṃpe adukkham asukham vedanam vedeti na iva tasmin  samaye sukham vedanam vedeti na dukkham vedanam vedeti adukkham asukhaṃ yā iva tasmin
translated: On that occasion he feels neither-unpleasant-nor-pleasant feeling.

original: samaye vedanaṃ vedeti. Sukhāpi, kho, aggivessana, vedanā aniccā saṅkhatā paṭiccasamuppannā
analyzed: samaye vedanam vedeti sukhā api kho aggivessana vedanā aniccā saṅkhatā paṭicca samuppannā
translated: “Aggivessana, pleasant feeling is impermanent, conditioned, dependently arisen,

original: khayadhammā vayadhammā virāgadhammā nirodhadhammā. Dukkhāpi, kho…pe… adukkhamasukhāpi
analyzed: khaya dhammāḥ vaya dhammāḥ virāga dhammāḥ nirodha dhammāḥ dukkhā api khope adukkham asukhā api
translated: subject to destruction, subject to fall, subject to fading away, subject to cessation. Painful feeling is impermanent, conditioned, dependently arisen,🔽subject to destruction, subject to fall, subject to fading away, subject to cessation. Neither-unpleasant-nor-pleasant feeling is impermanent, conditioned, dependently arisen,

original: kho, aggivessana, vedanā aniccā…pe… nirodhadhammā. Evaṃ passaṃ, aggivessana, sutavā
analyzed: kho aggivessana vedanāḥ anicca āpe nirodha dhammāḥ evam passam aggivessana sutavā
translated: subject to destruction, subject to fall, subject to fading away, subject to cessation. Seeing thus, Aggivessana, the well-taught noble disciple

original: ariyasāvako sukhāyapi vedanāya nibbindati, dukkhāyapi vedanāya nibbindati, adukkhamasukhāyapi
analyzed: ariya sāvako sukhāya api vedanāya nibbindati dukkhāya api vedanāya nibbindati adukkham asukhāya api
translated: becomes disenchanted with pleasant feeling, disenchanted with painful feeling, disenchanted with neither-unpleasant-nor-pleasant feeling.

original: vedanāya nibbindati, nibbindaṃ virajjati, virāgā vimuccati, vimuttasmiṃ ‘vimuttamī’ti
analyzed: vedanāya nibbindati nibbindam virajjati virāgā vimuccati vimuttasmin
translated: Being disenchanted, he becomes dispassionate. Through dispassion his mind is liberated. When it is liberated there comes the knowledge: ‘It’s liberated.’🔽“Aggivessana, there are these three feelings. What three?🔽Pleasant feeling, painful feeling, neither-unpleasant-nor-pleasant feeling.🔽These, Aggivessana, are the three feelings.

original: ñāṇaṃ hoti, ‘khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti pajānātī”ti.
analyzed: ñāṇam hoti khīṇā jāti vusitam brahmacariyam katam karaṇīyam na aparam itthattāya ati pajānāti iti
translated: and he knows: ‘Birth is destroyed, the holy life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there is no more coming to any state of being.’

original: Sāmisaṃ vā sukhantiādīsu sāmisā sukhā nāma pañcakāmaguṇāmisasannissitā cha gehasitasomanassavedanā.🔽Nirāmisā sukhā nāma cha nekkhammasitasomanassavedanā. Sāmisā dukkhā nāma cha gehasitadomanassavedanā.🔽Nirāmisā dukkhā nāma cha nekkhammasitadomanassavedanā. Sāmisā adukkhamasukhā nāma
analyzed: sa āmisam vā sukham ti ādīsu sāmisā sukhā nāma pañca kāmaguṇa āmisa sannissitā cha geha sita somanassa vedanā  nirāmisā sukhā nāma cha nekkhamma sita somanassa vedanā sāmisā dukkhā nāma cha geha sita domanassa vedanā  nirāmisāḥ dukkhāḥ nāma cha nekkhamma sita domanassa vedanāḥ sa āmisāḥ adukkhamasukhāḥ nāma
translated: “With attachment” is the five strands of sense pleasure dependent on the material, and the six kinds of joy dependent on the home life.🔽“Without attachment” is the six kinds of joy dependent on renunciation. “With attachment” is the six kinds of grief dependent on the home life.🔽“Without attachment” is the six kinds of grief dependent on renunciation. “With attachment” is the six kinds of equanimity dependent on the home life.

original: cha gehasitaupekkhāvedanā. Nirāmisā adukkhamasukhā nāma cha nekkhammasitaupekkhāvedanā.
analyzed: cha geha sita aupekkhā vedanāḥ nirāmisāḥ adukkha masukhāḥ nāma cha nekkhamma sita aupekkhā vedanāḥ
translated: “Without attachment” is the six kinds of equanimity dependent on renunciation.

original: Tāsaṃ vibhāgo sakkapañhe vuttoyeva.
analyzed: tāsam vibhāgaḥ sakka pañhe vuttaḥ yā eva
translated: The exposition of these should be understood as given in the Sakkapañha Sutta .

original: Iti ajjhattaṃ vāti evaṃ sukhavedanādipariggaṇhanena attano vā vedanāsu, parassa vā
analyzed: iti ajjhattam vāti evam sukha vedanā ādi pariggaṇhanena attanaḥ vā vedanāsu parassa vā
translated: Thus internally or externally: in his own feelings or in the feelings of others,

original: vedanāsu, kālena vā attano, kālena vā parassa vedanāsu vedanānupassī viharati. Samudayavayadhammānupassī
analyzed: vedanāsu kālena vā attanaḥ kālena vā parassa vedanāsu vedanā anupassī viharati samudaya vaya dhamma anupassī
translated: or sometimes in his own and sometimes in the others’, he dwells contemplating feelings as feelings.

original: vāti ettha pana avijjāsamudayā vedanāsamudayotiādīhi pañcahi pañcahi ākārehi vedanānaṃ
analyzed: vāti ettha pana avijjā samudayā vedanā samudayā uti ādīhi pañcahi pañcahi ākārehi vedanānaṃ
translated: Herein, the fivefold method of exposition should be understood as follows: “With the arising of ignorance there is the arising of feeling,” and so on.

original: samudayañca vayañca passanto “samudayadhammānupassī vā vedanāsu viharati, vayadhammānupassī🔽vā vedanāsu viharati, kālena samudayadhammānupassī vā vedanāsu, kālena vayadhammānupassī
analyzed: samudayañca vayañca passanto samudaya dhamma anupassī vā vedanāsu viharati vaya dhamma anupassī  vā vedanāsu viharati kālena samudaya dhamma anupassī vā vedanāsu kālena vaya dhamma anupassī
translated: Herein, one who sees the arising of feeling with the arising of ignorance, and so on, in the five ways, and its falling away with the falling away of ignorance, and so on, in the five ways, should be understood as “abiding contemplating arising in feelings, or … abiding contemplating falling away in feelings, or … abiding contemplating arising and falling away in feelings, or … abiding contemplating fading away in feelings, or … abiding contemplating relinquishment in feelings.” The rest is as already stated under the body contemplations .

original: vā vedanāsu viharatī”ti veditabbo. Ito paraṃ kāyānupassanāyaṃ vuttanayameva. Kevalañhi🔽idha vedanāpariggāhikā sati dukkhasaccanti evaṃ yojanaṃ katvā vedanāpariggāhakassa
analyzed: vā vedanāsu viharati iti veditabbaḥ itas param kāya anupassanā ayam vutta nayam eva kevalam hi  idha vedanā pariggāhikā sati dukkha saccan ti evam yojanam katvā vedanā pariggāhakassa
translated: Herein, the way in which the mindfulness that discerns feelings is to be developed has already been shown in the Description of the Earth Kasiṇa .

original: bhikkhuno niyyānamukhaṃ veditabbaṃ, sesaṃ tādisamevāti.
analyzed: bhikkhuno niyyāna mukham veditabbam sesam tādisam eva ati
translated: The portal to deliverance in the case of a bhikkhu who discerns feelings is this: “When he brings to mind the deathless element in the way stated in the passage beginning, ‘For in dependence upon aging and death, friend, consciousness’ , then his feelings as objects of clinging cease in him, and with their cessation his craving ceases, and with the cessation of craving his clinging ceases, and with the cessation of clinging his becoming ceases, and with the cessation of becoming his birth ceases, and with the cessation of birth all his suffering ceases” .

original: Vedanānupassanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: vedanā anupassanā niṭṭhitā
translated: Contemplation of feelings is ended.

original: Cittānupassanāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: citta anupassanā vaṇṇanā
translated: The contemplation of consciousness

original: 381. Evaṃ navavidhena vedanānupassanāsatipaṭṭhānaṃ kathetvā idāni soḷasavidhena cittānupassanaṃ
analyzed: evam navavidhena vedanā anupassanā sati paṭṭhānam kathetvā idāni soḷasavidhena citta anupassanam
translated: Having thus expounded the development of the foundation of mindfulness consisting in contemplation of feelings in nine ways, he now began to expound the development of the foundation of mindfulness consisting in contemplation of cognizance in sixteen ways, with the words “How, bhikkhus, is contemplation of cognizance as cognizance a development of the foundation of mindfulness?

original: kathetuṃ kathañca, bhikkhavetiādimāha. Tattha sarāganti aṭṭhavidhalobhasahagataṃ.
analyzed: kathetum katham ca bhikkhave ti ādim āha tattha sa rāgam ti aṭṭhavidha lobha sahagatam
translated: and how, bhikkhus? ‘, he said. Herein, with hate is that associated with the eight kinds of greed.

original: Vītarāganti lokiyakusalābyākataṃ. Idaṃ pana yasmā sammasanaṃ na dhammasamodhānaṃ🔽tasmā idha ekapadepi lokuttaraṃ na labbhati. Sesāni cattāri akusalacittāni neva purimapadaṃ
analyzed: vīta rāganti lokiya kusala abyākatam idam pana yasmā sammasanam na dhamma samodhānam  tasmai idha eka pade pi lokuttaram na labbhati sesāni cattāri akusala cittāni na iva purima padam
translated: Without hate is that associated with profitable and indeterminate states of the sense sphere. But since this is a discerning, not a combining,

original: na pacchimapadaṃ bhajanti. Sadosanti duvidhadomanassasahagataṃ. Vītadosanti lokiyakusalābyākataṃ.🔽Sesāni dasa akusalacittāni neva purimapadaṃ, na pacchimapadaṃ bhajanti. Samohanti🔽vicikicchāsahagatañceva, uddhaccasahagatañcāti duvidhaṃ. Yasmā pana moho sabbākusalesu
analyzed: na pacchima padam bhajanti sa dosanti duvidha domanassa sahagatam vīta dosanti lokiya kusala abyākatam  sesāni dasa akusala cittāni na iva purima padam na pacchima padam bhajanti samohanti  vicikicchā sahagatam ca iva uddhacca sahagatam ca ati duvidham yasmā pana moho sabba akusalesu
translated: of ideas, no supramundane consciousness is included here. And the remaining four kinds of unprofitable consciousness do not belong either to the first term or to the second. With delusion is that associated with the two kinds of grief.🔽Without delusion is that associated with profitable and indeterminate states of the sense sphere.🔽The remaining ten kinds of unprofitable consciousness do not belong either to the first term or to the second. With worry is that associated with doubt and that associated with agitation.

original: uppajjati, tasmā sesānipi idha vaṭṭantiyeva. Imasmiññeva hi duke dvādasākusalacittāni
analyzed: uppajjati tasmā sesāni api idha imasmin na eva hi duke dvādasa akusala cittāni
translated: But since delusion arises in all unprofitable consciousness, the remaining kinds of unprofitable consciousness are also included here. For in this dyad the twelve kinds of unprofitable consciousness are included.

original: pariyādinnānīti. Vītamohanti lokiyakusalābyākataṃ. Saṅkhittanti thinamiddhānupatitaṃ.
analyzed: pariyādinnāni iti vīta mohanti lokiya kusala abyākatam thinam iddha anupatitam
translated: Without worry is that associated with profitable and indeterminate states of the sense sphere. With fever is that accompanied by torpor and lethargy.

original: Etañhi saṅkuṭitacittaṃ nāma. Vikkhittanti uddhaccasahagataṃ, etañhi pasaṭacittaṃ nāma.🔽Mahaggatanti rūpārūpāvacaraṃ. Amahaggatanti kāmāvacaraṃ. Sauttaranti kāmāvacaraṃ.🔽Anuttaranti rūpāvacaraṃ arūpāvacarañca. Tatrāpi sauttaraṃ rūpāvacaraṃ, anuttaraṃ
analyzed: etat hi saṅkuṭita cittam nāma vikkhittanti uddhacca sahagatam etat hi pasaṭa cittam nāma  rūpa arūpāvacaram amahaggatanti kāmāvacaram sauttaranti kāmāvacaram  rūpāvacaram a rūpāvacaram ca tatra api sauttaram rūpāvacaram anuttaram
translated: for this is called “contracted” mind. “Distracted” is that associated with agitation; for this is called “scattered” mind.🔽“Magnified” is that of the fine-material and immaterial spheres. “Unmagnified” is that of the sense sphere. “With something superior” is that of the sense sphere.🔽“Without something superior” is that of the fine-material and immaterial spheres. Herein, that of the fine-material sphere has something superior,

original: arūpāvacarameva. Samāhitanti yassa appanāsamādhi upacārasamādhi vā atthi. Asamāhitanti
analyzed: arūpāvacaram eva samāhitanti yassa appanā samādhi upacāra samādhi vā atthi asamāhitanti
translated: but that of the immaterial sphere has not. “Concentrated” is that in which there is absorption concentration or access concentration. “Unconcentrated” is

original: ubhayasamādhivirahitaṃ. Vimuttanti tadaṅgavikkhambhanavimuttīhi vimuttaṃ. Avimuttanti
analyzed: ubhaya samādhi virahitam vimuttanti tad aṅga vikkhambhana vimuttīhi vimuttam a vimuttam
translated: that devoid of both kinds of concentration. “Liberated” is that liberated by the suppression of the particular defilements belonging to the several jhānas. “Unliberated” is

original: ubhayavimuttivirahitaṃ. Samucchedapaṭippassaddhinissaraṇavimuttīnaṃ pana idha okāsova natthi.
analyzed: ubhaya vimutti virahitam samuccheda paṭippassaddhi nissaraṇa vimuttīnam pana idha okāsaḥ uva natthi
translated: that devoid of both kinds of liberation. But there is no opportunity here for the liberations consisting in the abandoning of defilements and in the removal of hindrances.

original: Iti ajjhattaṃ vāti evaṃ sarāgādipariggaṇhanena yasmiṃ yasmiṃ khaṇe yaṃ yaṃ cittaṃ
analyzed: iti ajjhattam vāti evam sa rāga ādi pariggaṇhanena yasmin yasmin khaṇe yam yam cittam
translated: Thus internally: thus in the way stated, he should advert to and review whichever of the kinds of consciousness beginning with lust is appropriate in each case,

original: pavattati, taṃ taṃ sallakkhento attano vā citte, parassa vā citte, kālena vā attano,
analyzed: pavattati tam tam sallakkhentaḥ attanaḥ vā citte parassa vā citte kālena vā attanaḥ
translated: as it occurs either in himself or in another or in due course.

original: kālena vā parassa citte cittānupassī viharati. Samudayavayadhammānupassīti ettha
analyzed: kālena vā parassa citte citta anupassī viharati samudaya vaya dhamma anupassī iti ettha
translated: As regards the contemplation of ideas of arising and falling away,

original: pana avijjāsamudayā viññāṇasamudayoti evaṃ pañcahi pañcahi ākārehi viññāṇassa samudayo
analyzed: pana avijjā samudayā viññāṇa samudayo ti evam pañcahi pañcahi ākārehi viññāṇassa samudayo
translated: the arising and falling away of consciousness should be brought out in the five ways beginning thus, “With the arising of ignorance there is the arising of consciousness” .

original: ca vayo ca nīharitabbo. Ito paraṃ vuttanayameva. Kevalañhi idha cittapariggāhikā🔽sati dukkhasaccanti evaṃ padayojanaṃ katvā cittapariggāhakassa bhikkhuno niyyānamukhaṃ
analyzed: ca vayaḥ ca nīharitabbaḥ itas param vutta nayam eva kevalam hi idha citta pariggāhikā  sati dukkha saccan ti evam pada yojanam katvā citta pariggāhakassa bhikkhuno niyyāna mukham
translated: The rest is as already stated. Only here the establishment of mindfulness that lays hold of cognizance

original: veditabbaṃ. Sesaṃ tādisamevāti.
analyzed: veditabbam sesam tādisam eva ati
translated: is to be understood as the outlet for the bhikkhu who lays hold of cognizance by construing the words in this way: “The establishment of mindfulness is the truth of suffering.” The rest is as already stated.

original: Cittānupassanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: citta anupassanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Contemplation of Cognizance is finished.

original: Dhammānupassanā nīvaraṇapabbavaṇṇanā🔽382. Evaṃ soḷasavidhena cittānupassanāsatipaṭṭhānaṃ kathetvā idāni pañcavidhena dhammānupassanaṃ
analyzed: dhamma anupassanā nīvaraṇa pabba vaṇṇanā  evam soḷasavidhena citta anupassanā sati paṭṭhānam kathetvā idāni pañcavidhena dhamma anupassanam
translated: The Contemplation of Ideas. The Description of the Hindrances and the Floods🔽Having thus taught the foundation of mindfulness consisting in contemplation of cognizance in sixteen ways, he now said, “And how, bhikkhus, does a bhikkhu develop the foundation of mindfulness consisting in contemplation of ideas” in order to teach the foundation of mindfulness consisting in contemplation of ideas in five ways.

original: kathetuṃ kathañca, bhikkhavetiādimāha. Apica bhagavatā kāyānupassanāya suddharūpapariggaho
analyzed: kathetum katham ca bhikkhave ti ādim āha api ca bhagavatā kāya anupassanāya suddha rūpa pariggahaḥ
translated: Besides, the Blessed One said “And how, bhikkhus, does a bhikkhu develop the foundation of mindfulness consisting in contemplation of ideas” in order to teach the discernment of ideas that is quite purified by the contemplation of the body.

original: kathito, vedanācittānupassanāhi suddhaarūpapariggaho. Idāni rūpārūpamissakapariggahaṃ
analyzed: kathitaḥ vedanā citta anupassanāhi suddha arūpa pariggahaḥ idāni rūpa arūpa missaka pariggaham
translated: The discerning of materiality alone has been stated by the contemplations of feeling, consciousness, and mental objects.🔽Now, in order to state the discerning of materiality and mentality together, he said: “And how, bhikkhus?”

original: kathetuṃ “kathañca, bhikkhave”tiādimāha. Kāyānupassanāya vā rūpakkhandhapariggahova
analyzed: kathetum katham ca bhikkhave ti ādim āha kāya anupassanāya vā rūpa kkhandha pariggahaḥ uva
translated: Or else, the discerning of the materiality aggregate has been stated by the contemplation of the body;

original: kathito, vedanānupassanāya vedanākkhandhapariggahova, cittānupassanāya viññāṇakkhandhapariggahova

Frequent practice, development, and cultivation of these states: this is a nutriment for the arising of the unarisen enlightenment factor of energy and for the fulfilment by development of the arisen enlightenment factor of energy” .🔽Moreover, six things lead to the abandoning of sluggishness and drowsiness:

original: Apica cha dhammā thinamiddhassa pahānāya saṃvattanti – atibhojane nimittaggāho, iriyāpathasamparivattanatā,
analyzed: apica cha dhammā thinamiddhassa pahānāya saṃvattanti ati bhojane nimitta ggāhaḥ iriyāpatha samparivattana tā
translated: taking interest in the external signs of the dawn, changing the posture,🔽contemplating the perception of light, living in the open,

original: ālokasaññāmanasikāro, abbhokāsavāso, kalyāṇamittatā, sappāyakathāti. Āharahatthaka🔽tatravaṭṭaka alaṃsāṭaka kākamāsaka bhuttavamitakabhojanaṃ bhuñjitvā rattiṭṭhānadivāṭṭhāne🔽nisinnassa hi samaṇadhammaṃ karoto thinamiddhaṃ mahāhatthī viya ottharantaṃ āgacchati,
analyzed: āloka saññā manasikāro abbhokāsa vāso kalyāṇa mitta tā sappāya kathā ati āharahatthaka  tatravaṭṭaka alaṃsāṭaka kākamāsaka bhutta vamitaka bhojanam bhuñjitvā ratti ṭṭhāna divāṭṭhāne  nisinnassa hi samaṇa dhammam karoto thinam iddham mahā hatthī viya ottharantam āgacchati
translated: having good friends, and talk that inspires.🔽When a bhikkhu has eaten until his belly is full and has gone to the place for walking up and down or to his own lodging and sits down, then sluggishness and drowsiness come upon him like a great heavy rain cloud.

original: catupañcaālopaokāsaṃ pana ṭhapetvā pānīyaṃ pivitvā yāpanasīlassa bhikkhuno taṃ na
analyzed: catu pañca āla upaokāsam pana ṭhapetvā pānīyam pivitvā yāpana sīlassa bhikkhuno tam na
translated: But when a bhikkhu is in the habit of taking only as much as he needs, of drinking water that is not stored, and of going out for alms, then sluggishness and drowsiness do not come upon him.

original: hotīti evaṃ atibhojane nimittaṃ gaṇhantassāpi thinamiddhaṃ pahīyati. Yasmiṃ iriyāpathe🔽thinamiddhaṃ okkamati, tato aññaṃ parivattentassāpi, rattiṃ candālokadīpālokaukkāloke🔽divā sūriyālokaṃ manasikarontassāpi, abbhokāse vasantassāpi, mahākassapattherasadise🔽pahīnathinamiddhe kalyāṇamitte sevantassāpi thinamiddhaṃ pahīyati. Ṭhānanisajjādīsu🔽dhutaṅganissitasappāyakathāyapi pahīyati. Tena vuttaṃ – “cha dhammā thinamiddhassa🔽pahānāya saṃvattantī”ti. Imehi pana chahi dhammehi pahīnassa thinamiddhassa arahattamaggena🔽āyatiṃ anuppādo hotīti pajānāti.
analyzed: evam ati bhojane nimittam gaṇhantassa api thinam iddham pahīyati yasmin iriyāpathe  thinam iddham okkamati tatas aññam parivattentassa api rattim canda āloka dīpa āloka okkāloke  divā sūriya ālokam manasikarontassa api abbhokāse vasantassa api mahā kassapa tthera sadise  pahīna thinamiddhe kalyāṇa mitte sevantassa api thinamiddham pahīyati ṭhāna nisajja ādīsu  pahīyati tena vuttam cha dhammā thinamiddhassa  pahānāya saṃvattanti iti imehi pana chahi dhammehi pahīnassa thinamiddhassa arahatta maggena  āyatim anuppādaḥ hoti iti pajānāti
translated: and so on. When he adverts thus to the cause of sluggishness and drowsiness, they are abandoned in him. Also they are abandoned in him by changing over from the posture in which sluggishness and drowsiness have beset him to some other one,🔽and by giving attention to light, either by day to the light element or by night to the light of the stars and the constellations, or to the gleam of the dawn even by night,🔽and by living in the open air, and by attending on good friends whose followers are free from sluggishness and drowsiness, and by talk on what is suitable,🔽which is concerned with the ascetic practices and is conducive to the removal of sluggishness and drowsiness.🔽It should be understood that when sluggishness and drowsiness are abandoned in these six ways, their future non-arising comes about through the attainment of the path of arahatship.

original: Cetaso avūpasame ayonisomanasikārena uddhaccakukkuccassa uppādo hoti. Avūpasamo nāma
analyzed: cetasaḥ avūpasame a yoniso manasikārena uddhacca kukkuccassa uppādaḥ hoti avūpasamaḥ nāma
translated: and so on. When he adverts thus to the cause of over-fullness, his stiffness and torpor are abandoned. Also his stiffness and torpor are abandoned by changing the posture when stiffness and torpor arise in a certain posture, and by giving attention to light, to space, and to perception of light, and by living in the open, and by attending on a good friend who has abandoned stiffness and torpor, and by talk on the Dhamma connected with the ascetic practices. When he does these things, his stiffness and torpor are abandoned. That is why it was said above: “Six things lead to the abandoning of stiffness and torpor” . But the abandoning of stiffness and torpor that has been abandoned by these six things is further suppressed by the path of arahatship. He understands: “With the arising of this, that arises”: with the arising of unreasoned attention there is the arising of worry and fretting. “With the arising of this” is said to refer to unreasoned attention. “With the arising of this, that arises” is said to refer to the arising of worry and fretting. “With the cessation of this, that ceases”: with the cessation of unreasoned attention there is the cessation of worry and fretting. “With the cessation of this, that ceases” is said to refer to the cessation of worry and fretting. He understands: “With the arising of this, that arises”: with the non-stilling of the mind there is the arising of agitation and worry. “Non-stilling” is said to refer to the non-stilling of the mind.

original: avūpasantākāro, uddhaccakukkuccamevetaṃ atthato. Tattha ayonisomanasikāraṃ bahulaṃ
analyzed: a vūpasanta ākāraḥ uddhacca kukkuccam eva etam atthatas tattha a yoniso manasikāram bahulam
translated: the mode of non-pacification is agitation and worry itself. Herein, wrong reflection is the cause of agitation and worry.

original: pavattayato uddhaccakukkuccaṃ uppajjati. Tenāha – “atthi, bhikkhave, cetaso avūpasamo,🔽tattha ayonisomanasikārabahulīkāro, ayamāhāro anuppannassa vā uddhaccakukkuccassa
analyzed: pavattayataḥ uddhacca kukkuccam uppajjati tena āha atthi bhikkhave cetasaḥ a vūpasamaḥ  tattha a yoniso manasikāra bahulīkāraḥ ayam āhāraḥ anuppannassa vā uddhacca kukkuccassa
translated: and the state of non-tranquillity of mind is restlessness and remorse itself. Herein, restlessness and remorse arise in one who often gives attention to impulsiveness. That is why it is said: “There is, bhikkhus, non-tranquillity of mind.

original: uppādāya, uppannassa vā uddhaccakukkuccassa bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāyā”ti.
analyzed: uppādāya uppannassa vā uddhacca kukkuccassa bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya ati
translated: The often repeated attention to that is a condition for the arising of the unarisen restlessness and remorse and for the increase and expansion of the arisen restlessness and remorse” .

original: Samādhisaṅkhāte pana cetaso vūpasame yonisomanasikārenassa pahānaṃ hoti. Tenāha –🔽“atthi, bhikkhave, cetaso vūpasamo, tattha yonisomanasikārabahulīkāro, ayamāhāro
analyzed: samādhi saṅkhāte pana cetasaḥ vūpasame yoniso manasikārena assa pahānam hoti tena āha  atthi bhikkhave cetasaḥ vūpasamaḥ tattha yoniso manasikāra bahulīkāraḥ ayam āhāraḥ
translated: But the abandoning of restlessness and remorse comes about through the tranquillity of mind called concentration. That is why it is said:

original: anuppannassa vā uddhaccakukkuccassa anuppādāya, uppannassa vā uddhaccakukkuccassa pahānāyā”ti.
analyzed: anuppannassa vā uddhacca kukkuccassa anuppādāya uppannassa vā uddhacca kukkuccassa pahānāya ati
translated: “There is, bhikkhus, tranquillity of mind. The often repeated attention to that is a condition for the non-arising of the unarisen restlessness and remorse and for the abandoning of the arisen restlessness and remorse” .

original: Apica cha dhammā uddhaccakukkuccassa pahānāya saṃvattanti bahussutatā paripucchakatā
analyzed: apica cha dhammā uddhacca kukkuccassa pahānāya saṃvattanti bahu ssuta tā paripucchaka tā
translated: Besides, six things lead to the abandoning of restlessness and remorse: much listening, questioning,

original: vinaye pakataññutā vuddhasevitā kalyāṇamittatā sappāyakathāti. Bāhussaccenapi hi
analyzed: vinaye pakataññu tā vuddha sevi tā kalyāṇa mitta tā bāhussaccena api hi
translated: and in the Vinaya, being skilled, associating with the elder, being a good friend, and talk that is suitable.

original: ekaṃ vā dve vā tayo vā cattāro vā pañca vā nikāye pāḷivasena atthavasena ca uggaṇhantassāpi🔽uddhaccakukkuccaṃ pahīyati. Kappiyākappiyaparipucchābahulassāpi, vinayapaññattiyaṃ🔽ciṇṇavasibhāvatāya pakataññunopi, vuḍḍhe mahallakatthere upasaṅkamantassāpi, upālittherasadise
analyzed: ekam vā dve vā tayaḥ vā cattāraḥ vā pañca vā nikāye pāḷi vasena attha vasena ca uggaṇhantassa api  uddhacca kukkuccam pahīyati kappiya akappiya paripucchā bahulassa api vinaya paññattiyam  ciṇṇa vasi bhāvatāya pakataññunaḥ api vuḍḍhe mahallaka tthere upasaṅkamantassa api upāli tthera sadise
translated: For even one who has learned one or two or three or four or five Nikāyas by heart, either as the text or as the meaning,🔽and one who is often asking about what is allowable and what is not, and one who is skilled in the Vinaya because of having mastered the analysis,🔽and one who approaches the elder, the senior monk, and one who associates with a good friend who is a Vinaya-holder such as the Elder Upāli,

original: vinayadhare kalyāṇamitte sevantassāpi uddhaccakukkuccaṃ pahīyati, ṭhānanisajjādīsu🔽kappiyākappiyanissitasappāyakathāyapi pahīyati. Tena vuttaṃ – “cha dhammā uddhaccakukkuccassa🔽pahānāya saṃvattantī”ti. Imehi pana chahi dhammehi pahīne uddhaccakukkucce uddhaccassa
analyzed: vinaya dhare kalyāṇa mitte sevantassa api uddhacca kukkuccam pahīyati ṭhāna nisajja ādīsu  kappiya akappiya nissita sappāya kathāya api pahīyati tena vuttam cha dhammā uddhacca kukkuccassa  pahānāya saṃvattanti iti imehi pana chahi dhammehi pahīne uddhacca kukkucce uddhaccassa
translated: and one who has talk that is suitable about what is allowable and what is not in the matter of standing, sitting, etc.,🔽it is said: “Six ideas lead to the abandoning of agitation and worry.”🔽But when agitation and worry are abandoned by means of these six ideas, then he knows: “Agitation is abandoned in me; it is not left in me to be abandoned by the path of arahatship.

original: arahattamaggena, kukkuccassa anāgāmimaggena āyatiṃ anuppādo hotīti pajānāti.
analyzed: arahatta maggena kukkuccassa anāgāmi maggena āyatim anuppādaḥ hoti iti pajānāti
translated: And worry is abandoned in me; it is not left in me to be abandoned by the path of non-returning.”

original: Vicikicchāṭhānīyesu dhammesu ayonisomanasikārena vicikicchāya uppādo hoti. Vicikicchāṭhānīyā
analyzed: vicikicchā ṭhānīyesu dhammesu a yoniso manasikārena vicikicchāyaḥ uppādaḥ hoti vicikicchā ṭhānīyā
translated: Doubt arises in one who gives attention improperly to ideas provocative of doubt.

original: dhammā nāma punappunaṃ vicikicchāya kāraṇattā vicikicchāva. Tattha ayonisomanasikāraṃ🔽bahulaṃ pavattayato vicikicchā uppajjati. Tenāha – “atthi, bhikkhave, vicikicchāṭhānīyā🔽dhammā, tattha ayonisomanasikārabahulīkāro, ayamāhāro anuppannāya vā vicikicchāya
analyzed: dhammāḥ nāma punappunam vicikicchāya kāraṇattā vicikicchāva tattha a yoniso manasikāram  bahulam pavattayataḥ vicikicchā uppajjati tena āha atthi bhikkhave vicikicchā ṭhānīyā  dhammā tattha a yoniso manasikāra bahulīkāraḥ ayam āhāraḥ anuppannāya vā vicikicchāya
translated: Ideas provocative of doubt are simply doubt itself, since they are the cause of doubt again and again.🔽Herein, when one who gives attention much to improper attention, doubt arises in him.

original: uppādāya, uppannāya vā vicikicchāya bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāyā”ti.🔽Kusalādidhammesu yonisomanasikārena panassā pahānaṃ hoti, tenāha – “atthi, bhikkhave,🔽kusalākusalā dhammā sāvajjānavajjā dhammā sevitabbāsevitabbā dhammā hīnapaṇītā dhammā
analyzed: uppādāya uppannāya vā vicikicchāya bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya ati  kusala ādi dhammesu yoniso manasikārena pana assā pahānam hoti tena āha atthi bhikkhave  kusala akusalāḥ dhammā sāvajja anavajjāḥ dhammāḥ sevitabba asevitabbāḥ dhammāḥ hīna paṇītāḥ dhammāḥ
translated: That is why it is said: “There are ideas provocative of doubt, bhikkhus; much exercise in giving attention improperly to them is the reason why doubt arises in a bhikkhu, or, if arisen, increases and expands” .

original: kaṇhasukkasappaṭibhāgā dhammā. Tattha yonisomanasikārabahulīkāro, ayamāhāro, anuppannāya
analyzed: kaṇha sukka sappaṭibhāgāḥ dhammāḥ tattha yoniso manasikāra bahulīkāraḥ ayam āhāraḥ anuppannāya
translated: But its abandoning comes about through giving attention rightly to profitable, etc., ideas. That is why it is said: “There are, bhikkhus, profitable and unprofitable ideas, blameless and blameable ideas, low and noble ideas, dark and bright ideas with their counterparts.🔽Much exercise in giving attention rightly to them is the reason why doubt does not arise in a bhikkhu, or, if arisen, is abandoned” .

original: vā vicikicchāya anuppādāya; uppannāya vā vicikicchāya pahānāyā”ti.
analyzed: vā vicikicchāya anuppādāya uppannāya vā vicikicchāya pahānāya ati
translated: or for the non-arising of doubt that has not yet arisen, or for the abandoning of doubt that has arisen.”

original: Apica cha dhammā vicikicchāya pahānāya saṃvattanti bahussutatā, paripucchakatā, vinaye
analyzed: apica cha dhammā vicikicchāya pahānāya saṃvattanti bahu ssuta tā paripucchaka tā vinaye
translated: Furthermore, six things lead to the abandoning of doubt: being learned, asking questions,

original: pakataññutā, adhimokkhabahulatā, kalyāṇamittatā, sappāyakathāti. Bāhussaccenapi hi
analyzed: pakataññu tā adhimokkha bahula tā kalyāṇa mitta tā sappāya kathā ati bāhussaccena api hi
translated: being skilled in the Discipline, having much resolution, having good friends, and suitable talk. For doubt is abandoned

analyzed: ekam vāpe pañca vā nikāye pāḷi vasena ca attha vasena ca uggaṇhantassa api vicikicchā
translated: in one who has learned by heart one section of the nine-sectioned Canon, or two, three, four, or five sections, both by the letter and by the meaning;

analyzed: pahīyati tīṇi ratanāni ārabbha paripucchā bahulassa api vinaye ciṇṇavasībhāvassa api  tīsu ratanesu okappaniya saddhā saṅkhāta adhimokkha bahulassa api saddhā adhimutte vakkali tthera sadise  kalyāṇa mitte sevantassa api vicikicchā pahīyati ṭhāna nisajja ādīsu tiṇṇam rata nānam
translated: in one who asks many questions about the Three Jewels; in one who has mastered the Discipline;🔽in one who has much resolution called “confidence” in the Three Jewels; in one who frequents good friends who are devoted to confidence;🔽in one who has suitable talk about the special qualities of the Three Jewels in such places as the monastery, the assembly hall, and the refectory. analyzed: āyatim anuppādaḥ hoti iti pajānāti  iti ajjhattam vā ati evam pañca nīvaraṇa pariggaṇhanena attanaḥ vā dhammesu parassa vā
translated: He understands: “When these six ideas have been developed and cultivated, the uncertainty that arose has been abandoned.”

analyzed: dhammesu kālena vā attanaḥ kālena vā parassa dhammesu dhamma anupassī viharati samudaya vayā  pana ittha subha nimitta asubha nimitta ādīsu ayonisoma nasikāra yonisoma nasikāra vasena pañcasu

analyzed: nīvaraṇesu vuttāya iva nīharitabbā itas param vutta nayam eva kevalam hi idha nīvaraṇa pariggāhikā

analyzed: rūpassa atthaṅgamaḥ vedanā ādīsu pi esā iva nayaḥ ayam ettha saṅkhepaḥ vitthāraḥ pana visuddhi magge

original: udayabbayañāṇakathāya vutto.

analyzed: dhammesu kālena vā attanaḥ kālena vā parassa dhammesu dhamma anupassī viharati samudaya vayā  pana ittha avijjā samudayā rūpa samudayaḥ ti ādīnam pañcasu khandhesu vuttānam paññāsāya

original: 384. Evaṃ pañcakkhandhavasena dhammānupassanaṃ vibhajitvā idāni āyatanavasena vibhajituṃ🔽puna caparantiādimāha. Tattha chasu ajjhattikabāhiresu āyatanesūti cakkhu sotaṃ ghānaṃ🔽jivhā kāyo manoti imesu chasu ajjhattikesu, rūpaṃ saddo gandho raso phoṭṭhabbo dhammoti🔽imesu chasu bāhiresu. analyzed: evam pañca kkhandha vasena dhamma anupassanam vibhajitvā idāni āyatana vasena vibhajitum  puna ca param ti ādim āha tattha chasu ajjhattika bāhiresu āyatanesu iti cakkhu sotam ghānam  jivhā kāyaḥ manaḥ ti imesu chasu ajjhattikesu rūpam saddaḥ gandhaḥ rasaḥ phoṭṭhabbaḥ dhammaḥ ti  imesu chasu bāhiresu cakkhuñca pajānāti iti cakkhu pasādam yāthāvasa rasa lakkhaṇa vasena  pajānāti rūpe ca pajānāti iti bahiddhā catu samuṭṭhānika rūpam ca yāthāvasa rasa lakkhaṇa vasena  pajānāti yat ca tat ubhayam paṭicca uppajjati saṃyojananti yat ca tam cakkhum ca iva  rūpe ca ati ubhayam paṭicca kāma rāga saṃyojanam vicikicchā
translated: Having thus analyzed the contemplation of ideas in terms of the five categories, he now said “Again, bhikkhus” in order to analyze it in terms of the bases. Herein, in the six internal and external bases is in the six internal ones beginning with the eye and in the six external ones beginning with visible data. He understands eye is he understands the eye sensitivity by its specific characteristic of mere sensitivity. He understands visible data is he understands the visible data that are external and have the four origins by their specific characteristic of mere visibility. And the fetter that arises dependent on both is the fetter of lust for sensual desires, the fetter of resentment, the fetter of pride, the fetter of false view, the fetter of uncertainty,

original: sīlabbataparāmāsa, bhavarāga, issā, macchariya, avijjāsaṃyojananti dasavidhaṃ saṃyojanaṃ
analyzed: bhava rāga issā macchariya avijjā saṃyojana nti dasavidham saṃyojanam
translated: Having thus analyzed the contemplation of ideas in terms of the five categories, he now said “Again, bhikkhus” in order to analyze it in terms of the bases. Herein, in the six internal and external bases is in the six internal ones beginning with the eye and in the six external ones beginning with visible data. He understands eye is he understands the eye sensitivity by its specific characteristic of mere sensitivity. He understands visible data is he understands the visible data that originate externally as objects of the eye sensitivity by their specific characteristic of mere data. And the fetter that arises dependent on both is the tenfold fetter that arises dependent on both the eye and visible data thus: the fetter of sense-desire, the fetter of resentment, the fetter of conceit, the fetter of wrong view, the fetter of uncertainty, the fetter of views about conduct, the fetter of desire for fine-material existence, the fetter of desire for immaterial existence, the fetter of conceit, the fetter of ignorance.

original: uppajjati, tañca yāthāvasarasalakkhaṇavasena pajānāti.🔽Kathaṃ panetaṃ uppajjatīti? Cakkhudvāre tāva āpāthagataṃ iṭṭhārammaṇaṃ kāmassādavasena
analyzed: uppajjati tat ca yāthāvasa rasa lakkhaṇa vasena pajānāti  katham pana etam uppajjati iti cakkhu dvāre tāva āpātha gatam iṭṭha ārammaṇam kāma ssāda vasena
translated: and he understands it as it actually is in its specific characteristics.

Etaṃ rūpārammaṇaṃ niccaṃ dhuvanti gaṇhato diṭṭhisaṃyojanaṃ🔽uppajjati. “Etaṃ rūpārammaṇaṃ satto nu kho, sattassa nu kho”ti vicikicchato vicikicchāsaṃyojanaṃ
analyzed: assādayataḥ abhinandataḥ kāma rāga saṃyojanam uppajjati aniṭṭha ārammaṇe kujjhato paṭigha saṃyojanam  uppajjati ṭhapetvā mam kaḥ aññaḥ etam ārammaṇam vibhāvetum samatthaḥ atthi iti maññataḥ  māna saṃyojanam uppajjati etam rūpa ārammaṇam niccam dhuvanti gaṇhataḥ diṭṭhi saṃyojanam  uppajjati etam rūpa ārammaṇam sattaḥ nu kho sattassa nu kho ti vicikicchataḥ vicikicchā saṃyojanam
translated: But how does it arise? In the eye door, firstly, when one relishes and delights in a desirable object that has come into focus, the fetter of sensual lust arises. When one is irritated with an undesirable object, the fetter of resentment arises.🔽When one thinks: “Who is more competent than I to discern this object?” the fetter of conceit arises. When one apprehends this object as permanent and lasting, the fetter of views arises.

original: uppajjati. “Sampattibhave vata no idaṃ sulabhaṃ jāta”nti bhavaṃ patthentassa bhavarāgasaṃyojanaṃ
analyzed: uppajjati sampatti bhave vata no idam sulabham jātanti bhavam patthentassa bhava rāga saṃyojanam
translated: When one is doubtful and uncertain whether this object is a being or not a being, the fetter of doubt arises. When one undertakes and observes the precepts, thinking:

original: uppajjati. “Āyatimpi evarūpaṃ sīlabbataṃ samādiyitvā sakkā laddhu”nti sīlabbataṃ
analyzed: uppajjati āyatim pi evarūpam sīlabbatam samādiyitvā sakkā laddhunti sīlabbatam
translated: “By this means we may obtain such an object in the future,” the fetter of adherence to rules and observances arises.

original: samādiyantassa sīlabbataparāmāsasaṃyojanaṃ uppajjati. “Aho vata taṃ rūpārammaṇaṃ🔽aññe na labheyyu”nti usūyato issāsaṃyojanaṃ uppajjati. Attanā laddhaṃ rūpārammaṇaṃ🔽aññassa maccharāyato macchariyasaṃyojanaṃ uppajjati. Sabbeheva sahajātaaññāṇavasena
analyzed: samādiyantassa sīlabbata parāmāsa saṃyojanam uppajjati aho vata tam rūpa ārammaṇam  aññe na labheyyunti usūyato issā saṃyojanam uppajjati attanā laddham rūpa ārammaṇam  aññassa maccharāyataḥ macchariya saṃyojanam uppajjati sabbehi iva sahajāta aññāṇa vasena
translated: When one undertakes it, the fetter of adherence to rules and observances arises. Because of envy, thinking “May others not get that object of form,” the fetter of envy arises. Because of stinginess, thinking “I alone should get the object of form I have got,” the fetter of avarice arises. Because of ignorance, all these things arise together.🔽

original: avijjāsaṃyojanaṃ uppajjati.🔽Yathā ca anuppannassāti yena kāraṇena asamudācāravasena anuppannassa tassa dasavidhassāpi🔽saṃyojanassa uppādo hoti, tañca kāraṇaṃ pajānāti. Yathā ca uppannassāti appahīnaṭṭhena
analyzed: avijjā saṃyojanam uppajjati  yathā ca anuppannassa ati yena kāraṇena asamudācāra vasena anuppannassa tassa dasavidhassa api  saṃyojanassa uppādaḥ hoti tat ca kāraṇam pajānāti yathā ca uppannassa ati a pahīna ṭṭhena
translated: When one undertakes it, the fetter of adherence to rules and observances arises. When one is jealous of others’ obtaining a visible form as object, thinking, “Oh that they should not get it,” the fetter of envy arises. When one is miserly with regard to a visible form as object that one has oneself obtained, the fetter of avarice arises. And in all cases ignorance arises through not knowing the seven kinds of states beginning with the associated as they actually are.🔽And he knows the cause by which the arising of the tenfold fetter comes about that has not arisen, that is to say, the cause of its occurrence.🔽And he knows the cause by which the abandoning of the tenfold fetter comes about that has arisen, that is to say, the cause of its abandoning.

original: pana samudācāravasena vā uppannassa tassa dasavidhassāpi saṃyojanassa yena kāraṇena🔽pahānaṃ hoti, tañca kāraṇaṃ pajānāti. Yathā ca pahīnassāti tadaṅgavikkhambhanappahānavasena
analyzed: pana samudācāra vasena vā uppannassa tassa dasavidhassa api saṃyojanassa yena kāraṇena 🔽pahānam hoti tat ca kāraṇam pajānāti yathā ca pahīnassa ati tad aṅga vikkhambhana ppahāna vasena
translated: And he knows the cause by which the non-arising of the tenfold fetter comes about after it has been abandoned, that is to say, the cause of its non-arising.

original: pahīnassāpi tassa dasavidhassa saṃyojanassa yena kāraṇena āyatiṃ anuppādo hoti, tañca🔽pajānāti. Kena kāraṇena panassa āyatiṃ anuppādo hoti?
