original: Nirayapālesūti niraye kammakāraṇikasattesu. Ye pana “kammameva kammakāraṇaṃ karoti,
analyzed: niraya pālesu iti niraye kamma kāraṇika sattesu ye pana kammam eva kamma kāraṇam karoti
translated: The wardens of hell: the beings who are the agents of kamma in hell. But those who say that kamma itself is the agent of kamma in hell

original: natthi nirayapālā”ti vadanti. Te “tamenaṃ, bhikkhave, nirayapālā”ti devadūtasuttaṃ
analyzed: natthi niraya pālā iti vadanti te tam enam bhikkhave niraya pālā iti deva dūta suttam
translated: and that there are no wardens of hell contradict the Devadūta Sutta, where it is said, “Bhikkhus, the wardens of hell seize him and lead him to King Yama” .

original: paṭibāhanti. Manussaloke rājakulesu kāraṇikamanussā viya hi niraye nirayapālā honti.
analyzed: paṭibāhanti manussa loke rāja kulesu kāraṇika manussāḥ viya hi niraye niraya pālāḥ honti
translated: For the wardens of hell are like the agents of the king in the human world.

original: 415. Veḷupesikāhīti veḷuvilīvehi. Sunimmajjathāti yathā suṭṭhu nimmajjitaṃ hoti, evaṃ nimmajjatha, apanethāti attho.
analyzed: veḷu pesikāhi iti veḷu vilīvehi su nimmajjatha ati yathā suṭṭhu nimmajjitam hoti evam nimmajjatha apanetha ati attho
translated: ‘In the reed-beds’ means in the reeds. ‘You should wash it well’ means you should wash it thoroughly; the meaning is, you should get rid of it.

original: Asucīti amanāpo. Asucisaṅkhātoti asucikoṭṭhāsabhūto asucīti ñāto vā. Duggandhoti
analyzed: asuci iti amanāpaḥ asuci saṅkhāto ti asuci koṭṭhāsa bhūto asuci iti ñātaḥ vā duggandho ti
translated: ‘Filth’ is disagreeable. ‘As filth’ means as a place for filth or as known as filth. ‘Stinking’ means

original: kuṇapagandho. Jegucchoti jigucchitabbayutto. Paṭikūloti dassaneneva paṭighāvaho.🔽Ubbādhatīti divasassa dvikkhattuṃ nhatvā tikkhattuṃ vatthāni parivattetvā alaṅkatapaṭimaṇḍitānaṃ
analyzed: kuṇapa gandhaḥ jeguccho ti jigucchitabba yutto paṭikūlo ti dassanena iva paṭigha āvaho  ubbādhati iti divasassa dvi khattum nhatvā ti khattum vatthāni parivattetvā alaṅkata paṭimaṇḍitānam
translated: smelling of corpses. ‘Loathsome’ means connected with loathing. ‘Repulsive’ means arousing repugnance just by being seen.

original: cakkavattiādīnampi manussānaṃ gandho yojanasate ṭhitānaṃ devatānaṃ kaṇṭhe āsattakuṇapaṃ viya bādhati.
analyzed: cakkavatti ādīnam pi manussānam gandhaḥ yojana sate ṭhitānam devatānam kaṇṭhe āsatta kuṇapam viya bādhati
translated: ‘It oppresses’ means that even the smell of human beings who have bathed twice a day and changed their clothes three times a day and are adorned and decorated oppresses the deities who stand a hundred leagues away as though it were a corpse pressed to their throats.

original: 416. Puna pāṇātipātādipañcasīlāni samādāyavattentānaṃ vasena vadati. Tāvatiṃsānanti idañca dūre nibbattā tāva mā āgacchantu, ime kasmā na entīti vadati.
analyzed: puna vasena vadati idam ca dūre nibbattā tāva mā āgacchantu ime kasmai na enti iti vadati
translated: . He speaks again with reference to those who undertake and observe the five precepts beginning with abstention from killing breathing things. ‘The Thirty-Three’—he says this as though they were far away, adding, ‘Why don’t they come here?’🔽. ‘

original: 418. Jaccandhūpamo maññe paṭibhāsīti jaccandho viya upaṭṭhāsi. Araññavanapatthānīti araññakaṅgayuttatāya araññāni, mahāvanasaṇḍatāya vanapatthāni. Pantānīti dūrāni.
analyzed: jat candhu upamaḥ maññe paṭibhāsi iti jat candhaḥ viya upaṭṭhāsi arañña vana patthāni iti arañña kaṅga yutta tāya araññāni mahā vana saṇḍa tāya vana patthāni pantāni iti dūrāni
translated: He appeared as if he were a man born blind: he was like a man born blind. Forests and groves: forests because of the presence of the forest-dwellers, and groves because of the presence of the great forest tracts. Deserts: far-flung places.

original: 419. Kalyāṇadhammeti teneva sīlena sundaradhamme. Dukkhapaṭikūleti dukkhaṃ apatthente. Seyyo bhavissatīti paraloke sugatisukhaṃ bhavissatīti adhippāyo.
analyzed: kalyāṇa dhamme iti tena iva sīlena sundara dhamme dukkha paṭikūle iti dukkham a patthente seyyaḥ bhavissati iti para loke sugati sukham bhavissati iti adhippāyaḥ
translated: With good conduct: with the good state consisting in that virtue. Unwelcome: unlovely. It will be better: the intention is that it will be the bliss of heaven in the world beyond.

original: 420. Upavijaññāti upagatavijāyanakālā, paripakkagabbhā na cirasseva vijāyissatīti
analyzed: upavijaññā ati upagata vijāyana kālā paripakka gabbhā na cirassa iva vijāyissati iti
translated: The time for delivery has approached: the time for delivery has come, the time for the birth of the child has come. The meaning is that the time for the birth of the child is not long delayed, since the time for delivery has come and the time for the birth of the child is ripe.

original: attho. Opabhoggā bhavissatīti pādaparicārikā bhavissati. Anayabyasananti mahādukkhaṃ.🔽Ayoti sukhaṃ, na ayo anayo, dukkhaṃ. Tadetaṃ sabbaso sukhaṃ byasati vikkhipatīti
analyzed: atthaḥ opabhoggā bhavissati iti pāda paricārikā bhavissati anaya byasanam ti mahā dukkham  ayaḥ iti sukham na ayaḥ anayaḥ dukkham tat etam sabbaso sukham byasati vikkhipati iti
translated: She will be a support: she will be a servant. Misery: great suffering.🔽Misery is not good, it is bad. It is that which completely destroys all this good: it is misery in the sense of “it throws away.”

original: byasanaṃ. Iti anayova byasanaṃ anayabyasanaṃ, mahādukkhanti attho. Ayonisoti anupāyena.
analyzed: byasanam iti anayā uva byasanam anaya byasanam mahā dukkham ti attho ayonisaḥ ti anupāyena
translated: Thus misery is bad, misery is bad in the sense of “misery is not good.” The meaning is that it is great suffering.

original: Apakkaṃ na paripācentīti apariṇataṃ akhīṇaṃ āyuṃ antarāva na upacchindanti. Paripākaṃ
analyzed: a pakkam na paripācenti iti a pariṇatam a khīṇam āyum antarā ava na upacchindanti paripākam
translated: They do not bring to an end what is not ripe: they do not interrupt the life that is not exhausted and not ripe for death. They bring to an end what is ripe: they do not interrupt the life that is ripe for death.

original: āgamentīti āyuparipākakālaṃ āgamenti. Dhammasenāpatināpetaṃ vuttaṃ –
analyzed: āgamenti iti āyu paripāka kālam āgamenti dhammasenāpatinā apetam vuttam
translated: They do not bring to an end what is not yet ripe: they do not interrupt the life that is not yet exhausted and not yet finished. They bring to an end what is ripe: they bring to an end the life that is ripe for ending. This was said by the General of the Dhamma:🔽I do not delight in death,

original: “Nābhinandāmi maraṇaṃ, nābhinandāmi jīvitaṃ;
analyzed: na abhinandāmi maraṇam na abhinandāmi jīvitam
translated: Nor do I delight in life;🔽But when the time is come,

original: Kālañca paṭikaṅkhāmi, nibbisaṃ bhatako yathāti.
analyzed: kālam ca paṭikaṅkhāmi nibbisam bhatakaḥ yathā ati
translated: I will depart like a hireling.

original: 421. Ubbhinditvāti mattikālepaṃ bhinditvā.
analyzed: ubbhinditvā iti mattikā lepam bhinditvā
translated: Having burst through the clay plaster: having broken through the clay plaster.

original: 422. Rāmaṇeyyakanti ramaṇīyabhāvaṃ. Velāsikāti khiḍḍāparādhikā. Komārikāti taruṇadārikā.
analyzed: rāmaṇeyyakam ti ramaṇīya bhāvam velāsikā ati khiḍḍāparādhikā komārikā ati taruṇa dārikā
translated: Delightful: having the nature of being delightful. Playful: playing tricks. Young girls: young women.

original: Tuyhaṃ jīvanti supinadassanakāle nikkhamantaṃ vā pavisantaṃ vā jīvaṃ api nu passanti.
analyzed: tuyham jīvanti supina dassana kāle nikkhamantam vā pavisantam vā jīvam api nu passanti
translated: Do you see: do you see the life that goes out or comes in at the time of seeing the dream?

original: Idha cittācāraṃ “jīva”nti gahetvā āha. So hi tattha jīvasaññīti.
analyzed: idha citta ācāram jīvanti gahetvā āha saḥ hi tattha jīva saññī iti
translated: Here the word “life” is taken in the sense of the mind’s activity. He said: “He is alive there, thinking ‘I am alive.’”

original: 423. Jiyāyāti dhanujiyāya, gīvaṃ veṭhetvāti attho. Patthinnataroti thaddhataro. Iminā
analyzed: jiyāya ati dhanu jiyāya gīvam veṭhetvā ati attho patthinnataro ti thaddhataro iminā
translated: With a bow: with a bow and arrow; the meaning is, with his neck bent. More tightly: more firmly.

original: kiṃ dasseti? Tumhe jīvakāle sattassa pañcakkhandhāti vadanti, cavanakāle pana rūpakkhandhamattameva
analyzed: kim dasse ti tumhe jīva kāle sattassa pañcakkhandhā ti vadanti cavana kāle pana rūpa kkhandha mattam eva
translated: What does he show? He shows this meaning: “You say that when a being is alive, there are five aggregates, but when he dies, only the material form aggregate remains,

original: avasissati, tayo khandhā appavattā honti, viññāṇakkhandho gacchati. Avasiṭṭhena rūpakkhandhena
analyzed: avasissati tayo khandhāḥ appavattāḥ honti viññāṇa kkhandho gacchati avasiṭṭhena rūpa kkhandhena
translated: the other three aggregates cease, and the consciousness aggregate goes. The remaining material form aggregate

original: lahutarena bhavitabbaṃ, garukataro ca hoti. Tasmā natthi koci kuhiṃ gantāti imamatthaṃ dasseti.
analyzed: lahutarena bhavitabbam garukataraḥ ca hoti tasmā natthi koci kuhim gantā ati imam attham dasseti
translated: must be lighter, but it is heavier. Therefore no one goes anywhere.”

original: 424. Nibbutanti vūpasantatejaṃ.
analyzed: nibbutanti vūpasanta tejam
translated: “Extinguished”: with its heat allayed.

original: 425. Anupahaccāti avināsetvā. Āmato hotīti addhamato marituṃ āraddho hoti. Odhunāthāti🔽orato karotha. Sandhunāthāti parato karotha. Niddhunāthāti aparāparaṃ karotha. Tañcāyatanaṃ
analyzed: an upahacca ati a vināsetvā āmataḥ hoti iti addhamataḥ maritum āraddhaḥ hoti odhunātha ati  oratas karotha sandhunātha ati paratas karotha niddhunātha ati apara aparam karotha tat ca āyatanam
translated: “Without remainder”: without destruction. “Is half dead”: has begun to die. “Shake him”:

original: na paṭisaṃvedetīti tena cakkhunā taṃ rūpāyatanaṃ na vibhāveti. Esa nayo sabbattha.
analyzed: na paṭisaṃvedeti iti tena cakkhunā tam rūpa āyatanam na vibhāveti esa nayo sabbattha
translated: make him go away. “Shake him well”: make him go far away. “Shake him thoroughly”: make him go away again and again. “He does not experience that base”: he does not discern that visible-form base with that eye. The same method applies in all cases.

original: 426. Saṅkhadhamoti saṅkhadhamako. Upalāpetvāti dhamitvā.
analyzed: saṅkha dhamā iti saṅkha dhamakaḥ dhamitvā
translated: “Conch-blower”: a conch-blower. “After blowing”: after blowing the conch.

original: 428. Aggikoti aggiparicārako. Āpādeyyanti nipphādeyyaṃ, āyuṃ vā pāpuṇāpeyyaṃ. Poseyyanti bhojanādīhi bhareyyaṃ. Vaḍḍheyyanti vaḍḍhiṃ gameyyaṃ. Araṇīsahitanti araṇīyugaḷaṃ.
analyzed: aggiko ti aggi paricārakaḥ āpādeyyanti nipphādeyyam āyum vā pāpuṇāpeyyam poseyyanti bhojana ādīhi bhareyyam vaḍḍheyyanti vaḍḍhim gameyyam araṇī sahitanti araṇī yugaḷam
translated: ‘A fire-worshipper’ is one who attends on the sacred fire. ‘I would make it yield’ means I would make it produce. ‘I would make it last’ means I would make it last as long as my life. ‘I would make it grow’ means I would make it increase. ‘With the two fire-sticks’ means with the pair of fire-sticks.

original: 429. Tirorājānopīti tiroraṭṭhe aññasmimpi janapade rājāno jānanti. Abyattoti avisado🔽acheko. Kopenapīti ye maṃ evaṃ vakkhanti, tesu uppajjanakena kopenapi etaṃ diṭṭhigataṃ
analyzed: tirorājānaḥ api iti tiroraṭṭhe aññasmim pi janapade rājānaḥ jānanti abyattaḥ ti avisadaḥ  achekaḥ kopena api iti ye mama evam vakkhanti tesu uppajjanakena kopena api etam diṭṭhi gatam
translated: ‘Even the kings of the neighbouring countries’ means the kings of other countries in the neighbouring regions. ‘I would be free from debt’ means I would be free from danger.

original: harissāmi pariharissāmīti gahetvā vicarissāmi. Makkhenāti tayā vuttayuttakāraṇamakkhalakkhaṇena
analyzed: harissāmi pariharissāmi iti gahetvā vicarissāmi makkhena ati tayā vutta yutta kāraṇa makkha lakkhaṇena
translated: ‘I would not be alone’ means I would not be without a companion. ‘Even if they should say’ means if they should say this to me. ‘I would carry off’ means I would take it and go about with it. ‘By flattery’ means by flattery characterized by the reason given by you.

original: makkhenāpi. Palāsenāti tayā saddhiṃ yugaggāhalakkhaṇena palāsenāpi.
analyzed: makkhena api palāsena ati tayā saddhim yuga ggāha lakkhaṇena palāsena api
translated: ‘By deceit’ means by deceit characterized by taking hold of you as a companion.

original: 430. Haritakapaṇṇanti yaṃ kiñci haritakaṃ, antamaso allatiṇapaṇṇampi na hotīti attho.
analyzed: haritaka paṇṇam ti yam kiñci haritakam antamasaḥ alla tiṇa paṇṇam pi na hoti iti attho
translated: ‘A green leaf’ means any green leaf; the meaning is, not even a withered grass leaf.

original: Sannaddhakalāpanti sannaddhadhanukalāpaṃ. Āsittodakāni vaṭumānīti paripuṇṇasalilā
analyzed: sannaddha kalāpanti sannaddha dhanu kalāpam āsitta udakāni vaṭumāni iti paripuṇṇa salilā
translated: ‘With a quiver and a bow’ means with a quiver and a bow strung. ‘The waters are full and the grass is succulent’ means the waters are full of water and the grass is succulent.

original: maggā ca kandarā ca. Yoggānīti balibadde.
analyzed: maggā ca kandarā ca yoggāni iti balibadde
translated: and the paths and the caves. ‘The yoked oxen’ are the sacrificial victims.

original: Bahunikkhantaroti bahunikkhanto ciranikkhantoti attho. Yathābhatena bhaṇḍenāti yaṃ vo tiṇakaṭṭhodakabhaṇḍakaṃ āropitaṃ, tena yathābhatena yathāropitena, yathāgahitenāti attho.
analyzed: bahu nikkhantaro ti bahu nikkhanto cira nikkhanto ti attho yathābhatena bhaṇḍena ati yam vaḥ tiṇa kaṭṭha udaka bhaṇḍakam āropitam tena yathābhatena yathā āropitena yathā gahitena ati attho
translated: ‘With a great deal of exit’: the meaning is, with a great deal of going out, with a long time of going out. ‘With the goods as they were loaded’ means with the goods as they were loaded, with the goods as they were put on, is the meaning.

original: Appasārānīti appagghāni. Paṇiyānīti bhaṇḍāni.
analyzed: appasārāni iti appagghāni paṇiyāni iti bhaṇḍāni
translated: ‘With a small profit’: with a small price. ‘Goods’: wares.

original: Gūthabhārikādiupamāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: gūtha bhārikā ādi upamā vaṇṇanā
translated: The Simile of the Man Carrying Dung, etc.

original: 432. Mama ca sūkarabhattanti mama ca sūkarānaṃ idaṃ bhattaṃ. Uggharantanti upari🔽gharantaṃ. Paggharantanti heṭṭhā parissavantaṃ. Tumhe khvettha bhaṇeti tumhe kho🔽ettha bhaṇe. Ayameva vā pāṭho. Tathā hi pana me sūkarabhattanti tathā hi pana me
analyzed: mama ca mama ca idam bhattam upari  gharantam paggharantam ti heṭṭhā parissavantam tumhe khu ettha bhaṇa iti tumhe kho  ettha bhaṇe ayam eva vā pāṭhaḥ tathā hi pana me tathā hi pana me
translated: ‘And this is the pigs’ food for me’: this dung is the pigs’ food for me. ‘Flowing out’: flowing out above.

original: ayaṃ gūtho sūkarānaṃ bhattaṃ.
analyzed: ayam gūthaḥ sūkarānam bhattam
translated: ‘Dripping out’: dripping out below. ‘You say here’: you say here, Bhaṇe. Or this is the reading. For thus: ‘This dung is the pigs’ food for me.’

original: 434. Āgatāgataṃ kaliṃ gilatīti āgatāgataṃ parājayaguḷaṃ gilati. Pajjohissāmīti pajjohanaṃ
analyzed: āgata āgatam kalim gilati iti āgata āgatam parājaya guḷam gilati pajjohissāmi iti pajjohanam
translated: ‘Swallows the incoming misfortune’: swallows the incoming misfortune of defeat. ‘I will light it’: the lighting.

original: karissāmi, balikammaṃ karissāmīti attho. Akkhehi dibbissāmāti guḷehi kīḷissāma. Littaṃ
analyzed: karissāmi bali kammam karissāmi iti attho akkhehi dibbissāma ati guḷehi kīḷissāma littam
translated: I will do a sacrifice: the meaning is, I will perform a sacrifice. We will play dice: we will play with dice.

original: paramena tejasāti paramatejena visena littaṃ.
analyzed: paramena tejasā ati parama tejena visena
translated: Anointed with the highest poison: smeared with the most powerful poison.

original: 436. Gāmapaṭṭanti vuṭṭhitagāmapadeso vuccati. “Gāmapada”ntipi pāṭho, ayamevattho.
analyzed: gāma paṭṭanti vuṭṭhita gāma padesaḥ vuccati pāṭhaḥ ayam eva atthaḥ
translated: The outskirts of the village: the place outside the village is what is meant. The reading “gāmapada” is also correct, having the same meaning.

original: Sāṇabhāranti sāṇavākabhāraṃ. Susannaddhoti subaddho. Tvaṃ pajānāhīti tvaṃ jāna. Sace
analyzed: sāṇa bhāranti sāṇavāka bhāram su sannaddhaḥ iti su baddhaḥ tvam pajānāhi iti tvam jāna sace
translated: A load of coarse cloth: a load of coarse cloth. Well-bound: well-tied. You know: you understand.

original: gaṇhitukāmosi, gaṇhāhīti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: gaṇhitu kāmaḥ asi gaṇhāhi iti vuttam hoti
translated: If you want to take it, take it: this is what is meant.

original: Khomanti khomavākaṃ. Ayanti kāḷalohaṃ. Lohanti tambalohaṃ. Sajjhanti rajataṃ. Suvaṇṇanti suvaṇṇamāsakaṃ. Abhinandiṃsūti tussiṃsu.
analyzed: khomanti khomavākam ayanti kāḷa loham lohanti tamba loham sajjhanti rajatam suvaṇṇanti suvaṇṇa māsakam abhinandiṃsu iti tussiṃsu
translated: Coarse cloth: coarse cloth. Iron: black iron. Copper: copper. Silver: silver. Gold: a gold coin. They rejoiced: they were pleased.

original: 437. Attamanoti sakamano tuṭṭhacitto. Abhiraddhoti abhippasanno. Pañhāpaṭibhānānīti
analyzed: attamano ti sa kamano tuṭṭha citto abhiraddho ti abhippasanno pañhā paṭibhānāni iti
translated: Delighted: with his own mind, with a happy mind. Satisfied: full of confidence. Answers to questions:

original: pañhupaṭṭhānāni. Paccanīkaṃ kattabbanti paccanīkaṃ paṭiviruddhaṃ viya kattabbaṃ amaññissaṃ,
analyzed: pañhupaṭṭhānāni paccanīkam kattabbanti paccanīkam paṭiviruddham viya kattabbam amaññissam
translated: answers to questions. I thought: I thought, “I will act as if I were opposing you,

original: paṭilomagāhaṃ gahetvā aṭṭhāsinti attho.
analyzed: paṭiloma gāham gahetvā aṭṭhāsin ti attho
translated: I will stand up taking the opposite view.”

original: 438. Saṅghātaṃ āpajjantīti saṅghātaṃ vināsaṃ maraṇaṃ āpajjanti. Na mahapphaloti vipākaphalena🔽na mahapphalo hoti. Na mahānisaṃsoti guṇānisaṃsena mahānisaṃso na hoti. Na mahājutikoti
analyzed: saṅghātam āpajjanti iti saṅghātam vināsam maraṇam āpajjanti na mahapphalo ti vipāka phalena  na mahapphalaḥ hoti na mahā nisaṃso ti guṇa anisaṃsena mahā nisaṃsaḥ na hoti na mahājutiko ti
translated: They come to destruction: they come to death, to destruction. It does not have great fruit: it does not have great fruit as fruition.

original: ānubhāvajutiyā mahājutiko na hoti. Na mahāvipphāroti vipākavipphāratāya mahāvipphāro🔽na hoti. Bījanaṅgalanti bījañca naṅgalañca. Dukkhetteti duṭṭhukhette nissārakhette.
analyzed: ānubhāva jutiyā mahā jutiko na hoti na mahā vipphāro ti vipāka vipphāra tāya mahā vipphāro  na hoti bīja naṅgalanti bījam ca naṅgalam ca dukkhetteti duṭṭhu khette nissāra khette
translated: It does not have great profit: it does not have great profit as the profit of special qualities. It does not have great influence: it does not have great influence as the influence of psychic power. It does not have great spread: it does not have great spread as the spread of the fruition.🔽Seed and plough: seed and plough. In a bad field: in a bad field, in a barren field.

original: Dubbhūmeti visamabhūmibhāge. Patiṭṭhāpeyyāti ṭhapeyya. Khaṇḍānīti chinnabhinnāni.
analyzed: dubbhūmā iti visama bhūmi bhāge patiṭṭhāpeyya ati ṭhapeyya khaṇḍāni iti chinna bhinnāni
translated: On uneven ground: in a place of uneven ground. He would sow: he would plant. They would be broken: they would be cut and split.

original: Pūtīnīti nissārāni. Vātātapahatānīti vātena ca ātapena ca hatāni pariyādinnatejāni.
analyzed: pūtīni iti nissārāni vāta ātapa hatāni iti vātena ca ātapena ca hatāni pariyādinna tejāni
translated: They would be barren: they would be barren. They would be withered by wind and sun: they would be withered by wind and sun, their sap would be dried up.

original: Asārādānīti taṇḍulasārādānarahitāni palālāni. Asukhasayitānīti yāni sukkhāpetvā koṭṭhe
analyzed: asāra ādāni iti taṇḍula sāra ādāna rahitāni palālāni asukha sayitāni iti yāni sukkhāpetvā koṭṭhe
translated: They would be worthless: they would be straw, devoid of the sap of rice. They would not be easily stored: those that are dried and stored

original: ākiritvā ṭhapitāni, tāni sukhasayitāni nāma. Etāni pana na tādisāni. Anuppaveccheyyāti
analyzed: ākiritvā ṭhapitāni tāni sukhasayitāni nāma etāni pana na tādisāni
translated: in a granary are called easily stored. But these are not like that. They would be destroyed:

original: anupaveseyya, na sammā vasseyya, anvaddhamāsaṃ anudasāhaṃ anupañcāhaṃ na vasseyyāti
analyzed: an upaveseyya na sammā vasseyya anu addha māsam anu dasa aham anu pañca aham na vasseyya ati
translated: he would not sow them properly, he would not tend them properly, and he would not reap them every half-month, every ten days, or every five days.

original: attho. Api nu tānīti api nu evaṃ khettabījavuṭṭhidose sati tāni bījāni aṅkuramūlapattādīhi🔽uddhaṃ vuddhiṃ heṭṭhā virūḷhiṃ samantato ca vepullaṃ āpajjeyyunti. Evarūpo kho rājañña🔽yaññoti evarūpaṃ rājañña dānaṃ parūpaghātena uppāditapaccayatopi dāyakatopi pariggāhakatopi
analyzed: atthaḥ api nu tāni iti api nu evam khetta bīja vuṭṭhi dose sati tāni bījāni aṅkura mūla patta ādīhi  uddham vuddhim heṭṭhā virūḷhim samantataḥ ca vepullam āpajjeyyunti evarūpaḥ kho rājañña  yañño ti evarūpam rājañña dānam para upaghātena uppādita paccaya taḥ pi dāyaka taḥ pi pariggāhaka taḥ pi
translated: What is the meaning? Even if there were these faults in the field, the seed, and the rain, would those seeds grow upwards, grow across, and grow full in girth?🔽Such, Prince, is the sacrifice.

original: avisuddhattā na mahapphalaṃ hoti.
analyzed: a visuddha ttā na mahapphalam hoti
translated: Such a sacrifice, Prince, is not fruitful and not of great fruit, not of great splendour and not of great results, because of the impurity of the requisites, of the giver, and of the receiver.

original: Evarūpo kho rājañña yaññoti evarūpaṃ rājaññadānaṃ aparūpaghātena uppannapaccayatopi
analyzed: evarūpaḥ kho rājañña yañño ti evarūpam rājañña dānam aparūpa ghātena uppanna paccayataḥ pi
translated: Such, Prince, is the sacrifice.

original: aparūpaghātitāya sīlavantadāyakatopi sammādiṭṭhiādiguṇasampannapaṭiggāhakatopi mahapphalaṃ
analyzed: aparūpa ghātitāya sīlavanta dāyakataḥ api sammādiṭṭhi ādi guṇa sampanna paṭiggāhakataḥ api mahapphalam
translated: Such a sacrifice, Prince, is fruitful and of great fruit, of great splendour and of great results, because of the purity of the requisites, of the giver, and of the receiver.

original: hoti. Sace pana guṇātirekaṃ nirodhā vuṭṭhitaṃ paṭiggāhakaṃ labhati, cetanā ca vipulā🔽hoti, diṭṭheva dhamme vipākaṃ detīti.
analyzed: hoti sace pana guṇa atirekam nirodhāt vuṭṭhitam paṭiggāhakam labhati cetanā ca vipulā 🔽hoti diṭṭhe iva dhamme vipākam deti iti
translated: If one should obtain a receiver who has emerged from the attainment of cessation, and if one’s volition is extensive, it would give results in this very life.

original: 439. Imaṃ pana therassa dhammakathaṃ sutvā pāyāsirājañño theraṃ nimantetvā sattāhaṃ
analyzed: imam pana therassa dhamma katham sutvā pāyāsi rājaññaḥ theram nimantetvā sattāham
translated: After hearing this Dhamma talk of the Elder’s, the royal treasurer Pāyāsi invited the Elder and

original: therassa mahādānaṃ datvā tato paṭṭhāya mahājanassa dānaṃ paṭṭhapesi. Taṃ sandhāya
analyzed: therassa mahādānam da tvā tatas paṭṭhāya mahājanassa dānam paṭṭhapesi tam sandhāya
translated: after giving the Elder a great gift for seven days, he then set up a gift for the great multitude. In reference to that it is said:🔽Then the royal treasurer Pāyāsi …

original: atha kho pāyāsi rājaññotiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha kaṇājakanti sakuṇḍakaṃ uttaṇḍulabhattaṃ.
analyzed: atha kho pāyāsi rājaññā iti ādi vuttam tattha kaṇājakanti sa kuṇḍakam uttaṇḍula bhattam
translated: Kaṇājakā means with broken rice, rice with the tip broken off.

original: Bilaṅgadutiyanti kañjikadutiyaṃ. Dhorakāni ca vatthānīti thūlāni ca vatthāni. Guḷavālakānīti
analyzed: bilaṅga dutiyanti kañjika dutiyam dhorakāni ca vatthāni iti thūlāni ca vatthāni guḷa vālakāni iti
translated: Bilaṅgadutiyā means with sour gruel. Dhorakāni ca vatthānīti thūlāni ca vatthāni. Guḷavālakānīti

original: guḷadasāni, puñjapuñjavasena ṭhitamahantadasānīti attho. Evaṃ anuddisatīti evaṃ upadisati. Pādāpīti pādenapi.
analyzed: guḷa dasāni puñja puñja vasena ṭhita mahanta dasāni iti evam anuddisati iti evam upadisati pādā api iti pādena api
translated: guḷadasāni, puñjapuñjavasena ṭhitamahantadasānīti attho. Evaṃ anuddisatīti evaṃ upadisati. Pādāpīti pādenapi.

original: 440. Asakkaccanti saddhāvirahitaṃ assaddhadānaṃ. Asahatthāti na sahatthena. Acittīkatanti
analyzed: saddhā virahitam assaddha dānam asahatthā ati na sahatthena acittīkatanti
translated: Asakkaccanti saddhāvirahitaṃ assaddhadānaṃ. Asahatthāti na sahatthena. Acittīkatanti

original: cittīkāravirahitaṃ, na cittīkārampi paccupaṭṭhāpetvā na paṇītacittaṃ katvā adāsi.
analyzed: cittīkāra virahitam na cittīkāram pi paccupaṭṭhāpetvā na paṇīta cittam katvā adāsi
translated: cittīkāravirahitaṃ, na cittīkārampi paccupaṭṭhāpetvā na paṇītacittaṃ katvā adāsi.

original: Apaviddhanti chaḍḍitaṃ vippatitaṃ. Suññaṃ serīsakanti serīsakaṃ nāma ekaṃ tucchaṃ
analyzed: apaviddham ti chaḍḍitam vippatitam suññam serīsakanti serīsakam nāma ekam tuccham
translated: Cast away: discarded, thrown away. Empty: the Serisaka mansion was an empty

original: rajatavimānaṃ upagato. Tassa kira dvāre mahāsirīsarukkho, tena taṃ “serīsaka”nti vuccati.
analyzed: rajata vimānam upagataḥ tassa kira dvāre mahā sirīsa rukkho tena tam serīsakanti vuccati
translated: silver mansion. There was a great Serisaka tree at its gate, and so it was called “Serisaka.”

original: 441. Āyasmā gavaṃpatīti thero kira pubbe manussakāle gopāladārakānaṃ jeṭṭhako hutvā
analyzed: āyasman gavaṃpatīti theraḥ kira pubbe manussa kāle gopāla dārakānam jeṭṭhakaḥ hutvā
translated: The venerable Gavampati: the elder was formerly, it seems, the eldest of a group of cowherd boys.

original: mahato sirīsassa mūlaṃ sodhetvā vālikaṃ okiritvā ekaṃ piṇḍapātikattheraṃ rukkhamūle
analyzed: mahataḥ sirīsassa mūlam sodhetvā vālikam okiritvā ekam piṇḍapātika theram rukkha mūle
translated: He cleared the roots of a great Serisaka tree, spread sand, and invited a certain alms-food-eater bhikkhu to sit down at the foot of the tree.

original: nisīdāpetvā attanā laddhaṃ āhāraṃ datvā tato cuto tassānubhāvena tasmiṃ rajatavimāne
analyzed: nisīdāpetvā attanā laddham āhāram da tvā tatas cutaḥ tassa anubhāvena tasmim rajata vimāne
translated: After giving him the food he had obtained, he died and was reborn by the power of that act in that silver mansion.

original: nibbatti. Sirīsarukkho vimānadvāre aṭṭhāsi. So paññāsāya vassehi phalati, tato paññāsa
analyzed: nibbatti sirīsa rukkhaḥ vimāna dvāre aṭṭhāsi so paññāsāya vassehi phalati tato paññāsa
translated: The Serisaka tree stood at the mansion gate. It flowered every fifty years, and fifty years had passed since its last flowering.

original: vassāni gatānīti devaputto saṃvegaṃ āpajjati. So aparena samayena amhākaṃ bhagavato
analyzed: vassāni gatāni iti deva putto saṃvegam āpajjati saḥ aparena samayena amhākam bhagavataḥ
translated: The deva became anxious. Later, in the dispensation of our own Buddha,

original: kāle manussesu nibbattitvā satthu dhammakathaṃ sutvā arahattaṃ patto. Pubbāciṇṇavasena
analyzed: kāle manussesu nibbattitvā satthu dhamma katham sutvā arahattam pattaḥ pubba āciṇṇa vasena
translated: he was reborn among men. He heard the Dhamma of the Master, and he reached Arahantship.

original: pana divāvihāratthāya tadeva vimānaṃ abhiṇhaṃ gacchati, taṃ kirassa utusukhaṃ hoti.
analyzed: pana divāvihāra atthāya tat eva vimānam abhiṇham gacchati tam kirassa utu sukham hoti
translated: but he went to that same mansion frequently during the day to spend the day there, for it was pleasant there in all seasons.

original: Taṃ sandhāya “tena kho pana samayena āyasmā gavaṃpatī”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: tam sandhāya tena kho pana samayena āyasmā gavaṃpati itiādi vuttam
translated: It was with reference to him that the passage beginning “Now at that time the venerable Gavampati” was uttered.

original: So sakkaccaṃ dānaṃ datvāti so parassa santakampi dānaṃ sakkaccaṃ datvā. Evamārocesīti
analyzed: so sakkaccam dānam da tvā ati saḥ parassa santakam pi dānam sakkaccam da tvā evam ārocesi iti
translated: Having given a gift with his own hands: having given a gift that was the property of another with his own hands. He exhorted:

original: “sakkaccaṃ dānaṃ dethā”tiādinā nayena ārocesi. Tañca pana therassa ārocanaṃ sutvā
analyzed: sakkaccam dānam detha ati ādinā nayena ārocesi tat ca pana therassa ārocanam sutvā
translated: he exhorted by the method beginning, “Give a gift with your own hands.” And after hearing the Elder’s exhortation,

original: mahājano sakkaccaṃ dānaṃ datvā devaloke nibbatto. Pāyāsissa pana rājaññassa paricārakā🔽sakkaccaṃ dānaṃ datvāpi nikantivasena gantvā tasseva santike nibbattā. Taṃ kira disācārikavimānaṃ🔽vaṭṭaniaṭaviyaṃ ahosi. Pāyāsidevaputto ca ekadivasaṃ vāṇijakānaṃ dassetvā attano
analyzed: mahā janaḥ sakkaccam dānam da tvā deva loke nibbattaḥ pāyāsissa pana rājaññassa paricārakā  sakkaccam dānam da tvā api nikanti vasena gantvā tassa iva santike nibbattā tam kira disācārika vimānam  vaṭṭani aṭaviyam ahosi pāyāsi deva putto ca eka divasam vāṇijakānam dassetvā attano
translated: the multitude gave a gift with their own hands and were reborn in the world of the gods. But the servants of the noble Pāyāsi🔽gave a gift with their own hands, but because of their attachment to him they went and were reborn in his presence. That mansion for visitors, it seems,

original: katakammaṃ kathesīti.
analyzed: kata kammam kathesi iti
translated: was in the Vaṭṭaniya jungle. And one day the god Pāyāsi showed it to some merchants and told them what he had done.

original: Iti sumaṅgalavilāsiniyā dīghanikāyaṭṭhakathāyaṃ🔽Pāyāsirājaññasuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: iti sumaṅgalavilāsiniyā dīgha nikāya ṭṭhakathā ayam 🔽pāyāsi rājañña sutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: So ends the commentary on the Pāyāsi Sutta in the Dīgha Nikāya.

original: Niṭṭhitā ca mahāvaggassatthavaṇṇanā.
analyzed: niṭṭhitā ca mahā vaggassa attha vaṇṇanā
translated: And the commentary on the Great Chapter is finished.

original: Mahāvaggaṭṭhakathā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: mahā vagga ṭṭhakathā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Great Chapter is finished.
